Unfortunately, due to the difference between engineering simulation and well-known GNN applications such as social networks, existing distributed GNN models do not perform well on largescale mesh graphs, suffering from intensive message passing and communication overhead across distributed workers. To tackle this issue, in this paper, we propose a novel distributed mesh graph network D-MGN. By a vertex-cut partitioning policy, D-MGN divides large mesh graphs into partitions. After the partitions are assigned to distributed workers, D-MGN allows local communication-free message passing within each worker, and performs distributed message aggregation with rather low communication cost. Evaluation on an example dataset demonstrates that D-MGN outperforms a recent work SAC by 38.66% lower errors, $\mathbf{5 4 . 6 7 \%}$ faster convergence time, and $\mathbf{1 1 9 . 2 2 \%}$ higher speedup ratio on 8 GPUs.

title: Time Series Prediction of Distribution Transformers Failure Rate
authors: Sebastian Aguirre Vargas, Germán Andrés Holguín Londoño, Mauricio Holguín Londoño
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: Analyzing the failure rate of physical assets enables the assessment of the current reliability of complex systems in sectors such as energy, manufacturing, robotics, and others. In this article, deep learning techniques are implemented to predict the failure rate of typical transformers in a power distribution system, based on historical failure data. This approach aims to improve the estimation of reliability levels, providing a key metric for objective decision-making in investment or maintenance projects.

title: Plug and Play Tool for Battery Cooling Plate
authors: S. Sharmila Devi, A.G. Franklen Joseph, J.R. Atchaya, S. Balaeswar, S. Gokul Hari
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Thermal management is critical to the performance, safety, and lifespan of modern battery systems, particularly in electric vehicles, portable devices, and embedded applications. Excessive heat generation during battery operation can cause performance degradation, reduced cycle life, and, in extreme cases, thermal runaway. This paper presents a modular, Raspberry Pi–based Plug and Play Cooling Plate that offers a smart, compact, and scalable solution for real-time battery temperature control. The proposed system continuously monitors battery temperature using digital sensors and activates a thermoelectric (Peltier) module when predefined limits are exceeded. This enables timely and localized cooling, effectively addressing thermal hotspots more precisely than traditional passive methods. The plug-and-play design allows for rapid integration into various battery configurations with minimal effort or hardware modification. Remote monitoring and data logging are supported through the Raspberry Pi, making the solution compatible with IoT-based applications. Experimental validation demonstrates improved thermal stability, reduced peak temperature, and faster cooling response times. Unlike conventional methods, this system adapts dynamically to temperature variations, enhancing both battery performance and operational safety. The work contributes a flexible and cost-effective platform that can be expanded or upgraded for future smart energy applications. These features make it suitable for use in next-generation systems requiring intelligent thermal management under varying load and environmental conditions.

title: Power Side-Channel Vulnerabilities in Distributed Quantum Systems with Classical Communication
authors: Quanjiang Long, Kyle Ponte, Ying Wang, Juntao Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: As quantum circuits grow in complexity, distributed quantum computing (DQC) system with classical communication provides a practical path for scalable execution. However, midcircuit measurements and conditional feedback from this emerging paradigm introduce side-channel vulnerabilities. We analyze how power traces reveal sensitive information in partitioned circuits. Our detection algorithm identifies mid-circuit measurements with up to 100% accuracy and reconstructs decomposed CNOT gates. Additionally, we demonstrate up to 80% accuracy in identifying user circuits from adjusted energy profiles. These findings highlight the risk of power-based leakage in LOCC-enabled DQC systems and call for more secure execution strategies.

title: GGWO: A Golden Grey Wolf Optimizer for Solving Constrained Optimization Problems
authors: Kaiyuan Zheng, Jing Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: The Gray Wolf Optimization (GWO) algorithm is a well-established metaheuristic approach recognized for its exceptional ability to explore global optima and its inherent stability. However, the original GWO algorithm faces certain limitations, including slow convergence rates and a tendency to become trapped in local optima. To address these challenges, this paper introduces the Golden Gray Wolf Optimization (GGWO) algorithm, which aims to enhance the performance and efficiency of GWO by incorporating innovative strategies to overcome its shortcomings. By utilizing advanced techniques, GGWO seeks to achieve faster convergence speeds and a higher probability of finding global solutions, thereby providing a more robust framework for optimization tasks. Initially, the GGWO algorithm employs an optimized point set for population initialization, ensuring a uniform distribution of gray wolves across the search space. This strategic initialization lays a solid foundation for sub-sequent iterative processes. At the start of each iteration, a non-linear adjustment of the convergence factor is applied, facilitating broader exploration of the search space in the initial phases and gradually shifting to a more focused exploitation of local optima in later stages. This approach significantly improves the overall optimization performance of the algorithm. Furthermore, the integration of the golden sine strategy enriches population diversity and enhances search capabilities. This innovative strategy not only reduces the risk of premature convergence to local optima but also boosts the algorithm's global search ability. To assess the effectiveness of GGWO, a series of experiments were conducted using 23 classical benchmark test functions. The results show that the GGWO algorithm exhibits exceptional solving performance and robust resilience, with a notable improvement in convergence speed. Moreover, the ability of GGWO to address constrained optimization problems was validated through its application in pressure vessel design, demonstrating an 18% improvement in solution accuracy over the original GWO algorithm and highlighting its superior effectiveness in solving complex practical engineering problems.

title: Transformer-Driven Offset Convolutional Network for Brain Tumor MRI Classification
authors: Mingrui Qi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Although brain tumors can be diagnosed using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), automatic classification remains challenging due to the complex and irregular shapes of tumors. This paper proposes a transformer-based offset convolutional network (T-OffsetConv). This hybrid deep learning architecture combines the local adaptability of deformable convolutions with the global contextual knowledge of lightweight transformers. T-OffsetConv utilizes transformer modules to learn spatial offsets for convolutions, thereby ensuring the proper alignment of input features with tumor structures before standard convolution operations. Experimental results on a publicly accessible brain tumor MRI dataset demonstrate that T-OffsetConv outperforms standard CNNs, deformable convolutional models, and vision transformers in terms of classification accuracy, robustness, and interpretability. Ablation studies provide more evidence for the critical role that transformer-guided spatial alignment plays in improving performance. This approach has significant potential for clinical application, as it provides a computationally effective and morphologically adaptive means of classifying brain cancer.

title: Composite SHAP Methylation Machine Learning Framework for Epigenetic Gene Ranking in Rheumatoid Arthritis
authors: A. Ezhil Grace, Mary Suganya, R Sakthi Prabha, G. Subinson, G. P. Pavithra, M. R. Arun
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune disease that causes progressive joint inflammation and systemic complications. Epigenetic alterations, particularly DNA methylation, play a critical role in its pathogenesis. This work introduces an interpretable machine learning framework that integrates Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) filtering, Gradient Boosting Machines (GBM), and explainable AI methods (SHAP and LIME) to identify and prioritize methylation-driven genes relevant to RA. The approach addresses multicollinearity in methylation datasets and enhances biological interpretability. The model achieved a high R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of 0.998, with log-FC, average expression, and methylation score emerging as dominant predictors. A composite methylation-SHAP score ranked key genes, including MIR4513, MIR3152, and DEFB113, which have documented immune-regulatory roles in RA. These findings provide a robust and transparent framework for epigenetic biomarker discovery, supporting the development of precision medicine strategies for early RA diagnosis.

title: Basketball Player Dynamic Posture Recognition Based on Neural Network Algorithm
authors: Hao Lv, Lan Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: To address the problem that existing wearable devices are limited in recognition accuracy and generalization ability due to single-modal feature extraction and insufficient temporal information capture in dynamic posture recognition of basketball players, this paper proposes a new method that combines a Multi-Modal Convolutional Neural Network (MCNN) with an Enhanced Temporal Attention Mechanism (ETAM). Firstly, wearable devices are used to collect multi-modal raw data such as acceleration, gyroscope, and geomagnetism. The features of each modality are extracted through a multi-branch convolutional structure, and cross-modal residual connections are introduced in the feature fusion stage to enhance the complementarity of information. Secondly, an improved temporal attention mechanism based on a gated recurrent unit GRU is proposed. By introducing multi-scale time windows and dynamic weight allocation, the fine modeling of the temporal dependence of motion actions is achieved, thereby improving the ability to capture motion changes. Finally, the proposed method is verified on a real basketball court. The experimental results show that the proposed method achieves an average recognition accuracy of 0.91 − 0.96 and demonstrates stronger robustness in complex, dynamic scenes. This method can effectively enhance the dynamic posture recognition performance of basketball players using wearable devices and has significant application value for intelligent motion analysis and training support.

title: A Self-Supervised Learning Approach for Motor Imagery Signal Classification Based on Multivariate Noise Transformations
authors: Yusong Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Motor imagery (MI) EEG classification plays a critical role in brain-computer interface (BCI) systems, yet challenges such as label scarcity and low signal-to-noise ratios persist. A self-supervised learning framework is proposed, where five types of noise are applied to unlabeled EEG signals to create a six-class pretext task. This enables the encoder to learn robust features prior to downstream fine-tuning with limited labeled data. Four deep learning models are evaluated. EEGNet demonstrates a 4.9% increase in accuracy and F1-score. Rhythm analysis highlights substantial improvements in delta and theta bands. Data ablation experiments further confirm the method's advantage in low-resource scenarios. The proposed framework effectively enhances MI EEG classification through structureaware representation learning.

title: Quantum-Inspired Optimization for Smart Aluminum Extrusion in Industry 4.0
authors: Yun-Ting Lai, Chien-Ming Chen, Shu-Yu Kuo, Yao-Hsin Chou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum and quantum-inspired optimization (QIO) offer strong potential for solving complex optimization problems. This paper is the first to apply QIO in a real-world industrial setting, where it is used to efficiently optimize the hyperparameters of an AI-driven Aluminum Extrusion Profile Temperature Prediction Model, based on eXtreme Gradient Boosting (AEPTPM-X). AEPTPM-X aims to enable isothermal extrusion by accurately predicting profile temperatures in real time, thereby enhancing product quality and reducing waste. Experimental results show that QIO significantly improves prediction accuracy, indicating a promising direction for intelligent manufacturing and fostering broader adoption of QIO in real-world applications.

title: SQL2Circuits: Estimating Cardinalities, Execution Times, and Costs for SQL Queries With Quantum Natural Language Processing
authors: Valter Uotila
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Recent advances in quantum computing have led to progress in exploring quantum applications across diverse fields, including databases and data management. This work presents a quantum machine learning model that tackles the challenge of estimating metrics, such as cardinalities, execution times, and costs, for SQL queries in relational databases. Precise estimations are crucial for the query optimizer to optimize query processing in relational databases efficiently. Our proposed quantum machine learning model consists of a novel query encoding mechanism, which maps SQL queries into high-dimensional Hilbert spaces using grammatical representations of the queries. The encoding mechanism translates SQL queries into parameterized quantum circuits, forming the core of the quantum machine learning model. The parameters in this model are tuned using standard quantum machine learning techniques. This encoding was first developed in quantum natural language processing (QNLP), and this work demonstrates its natural application in database optimization. Because the encoding mechanism is mathematically robust, the quantum machine learning model is also explainable, allowing us to draw a one-to-one correspondence between the elements in SQL queries and the model's parameters. The method is also scalable because it consists of multiple circuits, and we train and evaluate the model with hundreds of queries. Compared to previous research, our model achieves high accuracy, supporting the results obtained in the original QNLP research. We extend the previous QNLP work by adding 4-class and 8 -class classification tasks and comparing the cardinality estimation results with those from state-of-the-art databases. This model shows a competitive accuracy compared to the estimators in the databases. We theoretically analyze the quantum machine learning model by calculating its expressibility and entangling capabilities, which have been suggested as representative metrics describing the model's trainability and learnability features.

title: Parallel KNN for Real Time Human Activity Recognition using OpenMP, MPI and CUDA
authors: Rajeev Sekar, Christopher Columbus C, Dhanushkodi S, Muhammad Kifayathullah, Tulasi Raman R, Akilesh S
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Human activity recognition (HAR) using sensor data has become increasingly important in applications such as healthcare monitoring, fitness tracking, and smart environments. However, processing sensor data in real-time poses significant computational challenges due to the continuous stream of movement readings, often in large volumes. The K-Nearest Neighbours (KNN) algorithm, though effective for classification tasks, suffers from inefficiency when executed in serial mode, especially with large datasets. The current work implements parallelization of KNN to improve its performance in activity recognition tasks using the HARTH sensor dataset, which contains diverse activity data classified into $\mathbf{1 4}$ categories. By employing parallel programming models like OpenMP (for multi-core CPU processing), MPI (for distributed systems), and CUDA (for GPU acceleration), the study aims to reduce the computational time required for distance calculations, which is the most time-consuming step in KNN. The study compares the execution time, speed up, scalability, and classification accuracy of these parallel implementations against the traditional serial version of KNN. The results could offer practical insights into optimizing KNN for real-time activity recognition and other resource-intensive tasks in machine learning, enabling faster and more scalable solutions. The proposed method achieved a maximum accuracy of $93.8(\mathrm{k}=7)$ and a maximum speedup of 22.22 times (using CUDA).

title: Demo: Decentralized Product Lifecycle Management Using Blockchain and Digital Twins
authors: Ranjit Kannappan, Julien Hatin, Emmanuel Bertin, Noel Crespi
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Managing a product throughout its various lifecycle stages is essential for all stakeholders involved. Efficient management is supposed to streamline process, enhance product quality, increase customer satisfaction, and improve profitability. The current architecture faces challenges that impact trust among stakeholders because of its centralized architecture. This paper presents a blockchain-based solution to enhance trust and transparency in product lifecycle management. Using Asset Administration Shell (AAS) as a standardized digital representation, we model and share product digital twins via IPFS. The proposed architecture demonstrates how smart contracts and IPFS enable the creation, sharing, and traceability of digital twins throughout the product lifecycle, fostering collaboration among stakeholders. This is illustrated through the use case of an electric vehicle, where digital twins are created for critical components like the EV battery and tire and enabling tracking across different lifecycle stages. Additionally, we evaluate the implementation for scalability, latency, and cost efficiency.

title: Real-Time ASL Recognition with AI Chatbot: A Deep Learning Approach
authors: Pooja B, Kavitha Subramani, Shree Rithi A, Srinitha M
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Sign language is essential for people with hearing and speaking impairments, but barriers exist between signers and non-signers. To enhance accessibility, this study suggests a live ASL (American Sign Language) detection system combined with an AI-powered chatbot. Using computer vision, deep learning, and natural language processing (NLP), the system bridges this communication gap. A camera records hand motions, which are processed by convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for ASL identification. NLP then converts these gestures into spoken or written language for real-time communication. An AI-powered chatbot further enhances user experience by promoting dynamic conversations. Experimental research shows 92% real-time ASL recognition accuracy, ensuring effective sign-to-text conversion and improving communication. This technology reduces reliance on human interpreters and promotes social inclusion. Combining machine learning with human-computer interaction transforms assistive technology, enabling more accessible communication for those with hearing disabilities. Its impact in social, educational, and professional settings fosters inclusivity and removes communication barriers, ensuring practical application in real-world situations.

title: Quantum-Assisted Automatic Path-Planning for Robotic Quality Inspection in Industry 4.0
authors: Eneko Osaba, Estibaliz Garrote, Pablo Miranda-Rodriguez, Alessia Ciacco, Itziar Cabanes, Aitziber Mancisidor
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: This work explores the application of hybrid quantum-classical algorithms to optimize robotic inspection trajectories derived from Computer-Aided Design (CAD) models in industrial settings. By modeling the task as a 3D variant of the Traveling Salesman Problem-incorporating incomplete graphs and open-route constraints-this study evaluates the performance of two D-Wave-based solvers against classical methods such as GUROBI and Google OR-Tools. Results across five real-world cases demonstrate competitive solution quality with significantly reduced computation times, highlighting the potential of quantum approaches in automation under Industry 4.0.

title: GNNFusion: A Hybrid Graph Neural Network Framework for Binding Affinity Prediction with Explainable AI
authors: Sivadharshani R S, A. Prasina, Samuthira Pandi V, Maram Y. Al-Safarini, Bolagani Balaj, M. Dinesh
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Protein–ligand binding affinity prediction plays a pivotal role in drug discovery, as it helps identify potential candidate compounds that strongly interact with target proteins. Instead of relying solely on traditional scoring functions or single-model architectures, this research integrates several advanced techniques such as a Multi-GNN fusion model (GCN, GAT, GraphSAGE, and GIN), Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) using GNNExplainer, and biologically meaningful dataset splitting strategies to improve accuracy and generalization. While existing models achieve good predictive performance, they often lack transparency in how decisions are made, limiting their utility in practical biomedical applications. Additionally, generalization across structurally diverse protein–ligand pairs remain a significant challenge. To overcome these limitations, this study proposes a novel GraphLambda framework to combine multiple GNNs each of unique functionality into a unified architecture capable of capturing diverse molecular interactions. The CASF-2016 dataset is used to train and evaluate four prebuilt models under interaction, ligand, protein, and random-based splits. The use of GNNExplainer further enhances interpretability by highlighting critical atoms and substructures contributing to predictions. The proposed model achieved an RMSE of 0.76 and a Pearson correlation of 0.94 under the hardest split, confirming both robustness and explainability. This approach provides a reliable and interpretable solution for structure-based drug discovery applications.

title: Noise-Resilient, Explainable Classifications of High-Resolution Images Using Quanvolution-Pooling
authors: Philipp Moser, Dominik Freinberger
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Applying Quantum Machine Learning (QML) to high-resolution image classification is a significant challenge, typically requiring extensive classical pre-processing. This work proposes a QML model that uses a novel quanvolution-pooling to directly extract features from high-resolution images, eliminating the need for classical pre-processing with fixed or learnable operations. By utilizing a compact configuration of only hardware-native gates, our approach achieves a high degree of inherent noise resilience. We also present the first LIME-based explainability study of QML models for high-resolution image classification tasks. Our approach was evaluated on three datasets under both noise-free and noisy simulations, exhibiting minimal performance degradation in the presence of noise. Explainability analysis revealed that the model consistently focused on clinically relevant regions, even under noisy conditions. These findings demonstrate the feasibility and robustness of QML models for high-resolution image classification.

title: Consensus Mapping of Professional Skills Required for Engineering Practice
authors: Patcharin Chen, Anna Lidfors Lindqvist, Zachery Quince
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: Professional engineering skills have evolved significantly in response to the demands of a rapidly changing society. However, a persistent disconnect remains between the skills taught in university programs and those required in the workplace. This research investigates which professional skills are most relevant to common engineering activities in the workplace. The ten high-level competencies from the newly developed ‘Competency in Professional and Authentic Skills for Success (COMPASS)' framework were mapped against 86 engineering activities from the BeLongEng longitudinal study. Consensus-based mapping method was used to analyze taskcompetency alignments through a multi-stage process. This included (1) an initial consensus mapping of high-level competencies, (2) a micro-level analysis of sub-competencies, and (3) a post-mapping frequency analysis to quantify competency occurrence. This approach provides a holistic view of the competencies most relevant to graduate engineers. The mapping showed the strongest consensus around interpersonal and transferable skills such as communication, collaboration and project management, which identifies their broad relevance across engineering contexts. In contrast, core technical competencies such as problem definition, investigation and sustainability were aligned less frequently, suggesting they are more context-specific or embedded within broader tasks. A high rate of partial consensus in the mapping reflects the complexity and variability of engineering practice across disciplines. Overall, the findings demonstrate the value of the COMPASS framework for capturing the diverse professional skills that underpin engineering work. It also shows the complexity of engineering practice and the need for clearer articulation and integration of professional competencies across curricula and ongoing professional development.

title: Bridging the Gap Between Competency-Based Learning and Standardized Exam Results
authors: Lorena B. Martínez Elizalde, Luis Humberto González-Guerra, Luis Ricardo Salgado Garza
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: This paper examines the alignment between competency-based assessments and standardized exam performance among undergraduate engineering students. Through the analysis of two cohorts in a software engineering program, the study compares internal competency evaluations with national exam results from the EGEL-ISOFT assessment. Findings demonstrate a strong correlation between students' internal performance and their outcomes on the standardized exam, indicating that competency-based assessments can serve as reliable predictors of external success. The study also highlights areas where minor discrepancies persist, suggesting opportunities for refining assessment rubrics and improving evaluator calibration. These results support the integration of competencybased learning with standardized exam preparation to provide students with accurate, formative feedback and to ensure they are well-equipped for both academic evaluations and professional demands.

title: Comparing Performance of Variational Quantum Algorithm Simulations on HPC Systems
authors: Marco de Pascale, Tobias Valentin Bauer, Yaknan John Gambo, Mario Hernández Vera, Stefan Huber, Burak Mete, Amit Jamadagni, Amine Bentellis, Marita Oliv, Luigi Iapichino, Jeanette Miriam Lorenz
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Variational quantum algorithms are of special importance in the research on quantum computing applications because of their applicability to current Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) devices. The main building blocks of these algorithms define a relatively large parameter space, making the comparison of results and performance between different approaches and software simulators cumbersome and prone to errors. In this paper, we employ a generic description of the problem, in terms of both Hamiltonian and ansatz, to consistently port a problem definition across different simulators. A use case relevant to current quantum hardware has been run on a set of HPC systems and software simulators to study the dependence of performance on the runtime environment, the scalability of the simulation codes, and the agreement between the physical results, respectively. The results show that our toolchain can successfully translate a problem definition between different simulators. On the other hand, variational algorithms are limited in their scaling by the long runtimes with respect to their memory footprint, so they expose limited parallelism to computation. This shortcoming is partially mitigated by using techniques like job arrays. The potential of the parser tool within the toolchain for exploring HPC performance and comparisons of results of variational algorithm simulations is highlighted.

title: A Good First Impression for Quantum Algorithms
authors: Shashvat Shukla
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: What is the first quantum algorithm that students should learn? A common choice is the Deutsch-Jozsa algorithm because of its historical importance. However, the algorithm and the problem it solves are disconnected from familiar computational tasks and approaches. This paper provides an alternate starting point: the decision version of search. The main algorithmic idea is simple, involving encoding a function into a quantum state, and checking whether this quantum state is equal to a reference state. Moreover, we retain the Deutsch-Jozsa problem and algorithm as a special case of this presentation. We hope that students will find this a more satisfying start to studying quantum algorithms.

title: Exploring ML for Stroke Prediction: Evaluation of XGBoost, KNN, and Naive Bayes with and without Data Leakage
authors: Anyam Chaitanya, Y Sarada Devi, K Venu Gopal, A Vijayasankar, Fahemullah Fathemullam, B Sarath Chandra
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Stroke is a major global health issue, requiring precise prediction models to enable early intervention and enhance patient outcomes. This study assesses the performance of KNN, Naive Bayes, and XGBoost in stroke prediction, considering both data leakage and properly handled scenarios. The dataset for this analysis is obtained from Kaggle’s Stroke Prediction Dataset [16]. It includes essential clinical features such as age, hypertension, heart disease, glucose levels, smoking status, and other relevant factors. Data leakage in healthcare ML models can lead to overly optimistic performance, misrepresenting real-world effectiveness. This study evaluates its impact by comparing models under both conditions using precision, recall, $\mathbf{F 1}$ score and overall accuracy. Results indicates that data leakage inflates accuracy, while proper handling ensures reliable assessments. Future work includes exploring ensemble methods like Stacking Classifier and CatBoost for improved accuracy. A Flask-based web application will also be developed for real-time stroke risk assessment, aiding healthcare providers and individuals in making well-informed choices.

title:
Quantitative STEM-EDS Analysis of Salicidation of SiC MOSFETs with a NiSi

authors: Beitian Zheng, Ruolan Wang, Minkang Liu, Xu Chen, Changji Zhou, Baohua Tan, Anli Yang, Kaixuan Li, Bing Yang, Qichao Ding, Zhihong Mai
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: Nickel salicide is widely used in semiconductor devices owing to their advantageous properties, including low sheet resistance, minimal silicon consumption, and high work function. These materials are particularly critical as ohmic contacts in SiC power devices. However, the microstructure of nickel silicide used in SiC MOSFET has not sufficiently characterized. For high-current applications, salicide could have can reliability issues if the salicidation is not well processed. Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS), commonly coupled with Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) or Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (STEM), is a powerful analytical tool for elemental and chemical characterizations. STEM-EDS provides high-resolution compositional mapping in semiconductor research and manufacturing, enabling precise defect analysis and thickness measurements. This study presents a STEM-EDS quantification method using a NiSi<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> standard sample, determining the Ni/Si k-factor to be 1.15. We apply this technique to analyze nickel salicide compositions in both planar and trench SiC MOSFETs. Our approach offers a reliable tool for process monitoring and failure analysis, contributing to improved device performance and reliability.

title: Integrating CRISPR Technology and Computational Bioinformatics for Deeper Insights into Autism Spectrum Disorder
authors: Yogita Bhatt, Yasha Hasija
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Autism spectrum disorder is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a strong hereditary construct that requires the development of novel treatment strategies. This study focuses on selection of ideal guide RNAs (gRNAs) for use in the CRISPR-Cas9 system, a transformative genome-editing tool, to target crucial genes implicated in ASD, such as SHANK3, CHD8, FMR1, TSC2 and SCN2A. Using bioinformatics tools, including SnapGene for sequence visualization and Prosite for functional motif identification, we offered precise annotation of exonic regions and designed single and dual gRNAs with high specificity and efficiency. These gRnas have also emerged in ex vivo therapies such as editing stem cells for blood disorders and also cancer immunotherapies. Various computational techniques were employed to perform off- and on-target checks, enhancing the reliability of the gRNAs. By enabling precise genetic modifications, CRISPR offers a commendable approach to understand ASD’s genetical changes and pathophysiology. Further validation of these findings through laboratory protocols and clinical criteria establishes this work as a novel step toward the prevention and potential treatment of ASD, providing a framework for future studies exploring CRISPR-based therapies in neurodevelopmental disorders.

title: HORIZON EYES: Smart Mobile Technology for Visually Impaired People
authors: Sai Deepika S, Priyadharshini S, Sangeetha K, Sasikala M, Bharathi B
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Visually impaired people face a lot of challenges during their day-to-day routine of their activities such as navigation, financial transactions, currency detection, object detection etc. The visually impaired people mainly depend on the external assistive devices, technologies and physical volunteers to assist them in real world. The proposed system is developed to enhance the accessibility as a voice-based assistance for the navigation assistance, currency detection, object detection etc. The news podcast feature delivers the breaking news and category news like sports, finance, health and all these features are provided through voice commands. The obstacle detection feature is provided through the technology of computer vision and machine learning models and sensors provide the real time voice commands and safety alerts. The offline functionality of the specific features ensures to work without any network connectivity issue to help them in the critical situation. The data security and privacy are secured through local data processing and data encryption. By testing these features the tests shows high accuracy in the following features namely navigation, object detection and currency detection thus improving mobility and financial independence. The future enhancements of the proposed system includes multi language support and integration of the proposed system with the spectacles.

title: Benchmarking Federated Learning Under Realistic Non-IID Conditions: A Structured Partitioning Approach Using ImageNet
authors: Tatjana Legler, Vinit Hegiste, Martin Ruskowski
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) faces significant challenges in handling data heterogeneity, as real-world client datasets are inherently non-independent and identically distributed (nonIID). Existing FL benchmarks often rely on synthetic non-IID partitions that fail to capture real-world data complexity, limiting their effectiveness in evaluating FL robustness. This study introduces a structured partitioning approach for ImageNet that groups data based on hierarchical class relationships, enabling controlled variations in non-IID distributions. By systematically varying data heterogeneity levels, we assess the impact of different distribution shifts on FL algorithm performance. Our evaluation highlights how varying label skew, data volume per client, and distribution imbalance influence model convergence and generalization. The results provide a more realistic and scalable FL benchmarking framework, offering insights into algorithm robustness under diverse real-world data distributions and enabling more effective non-IID evaluation in FL research.Supplementary code is available at https://github.com/ fedlearn-hub/Non-IID_ImageNet.

title: Uncertainty-Aware PCA Revisited_supp1-3633868.txt
authors: Lukas Friesecke
abstract: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is perhaps the most popular linear projection technique for dimensionality reduction. We consider PCA under the assumption that the high-dimensional data points are equipped with Gaussian uncertainty. Several approaches to such uncertainty-aware PCA have been developed recently in the visualization community. Since PCA is a discontinuous map, a small uncertainty in the data points can result in a huge uncertainty in the projected points. We show that the uncertainty of the data points also creates uncertainty in the eigenvectors of the covariance matrix that defines the PCA projection. We present a closed-form expression to quantify eigenvector uncertainty. Based on this, we propose a 3D glyph that supports the decision whether existing solutions for uncertainty-aware PCA are sufficient, or whether a more expensive sampling-based approach is required. We apply our approach to several test data sets.

title: Unified VideoMAE Framework for Detection of Multi-Disorder ADHD and Depression
authors: Yichun Li, Yi Li, Syed Mohsen Naqvi
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Mental disorders have become a major public health issue worldwide. Traditional face-to-face and clinical diagnostic methods are not only time-consuming and expensive but also rely heavily on the expertise of professionals and require costly equipment. With the rapid development of computer vision and deep learning, a growing number of studies are exploring deep learning methods to assist in diagnosing and evaluating various mental disorders. However, most current research focuses on a single type of mental disorder, which limits the broader application of these technologies. This paper proposes a novel system aimed at detecting multiple mental disorders, i.e., Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) and depression, within one unified framework. To make the proposed system both computationally efficient and robust despite the limited availability of mental health datasets, we first preprocess the original videos to extract cost-effective facial video segments and then fine-tune pre-trained models on these facial videos for classification. In our mental disorder detection task, three distinct fine-tuning methods are adopted for the pre-trained video-masked autoencoder (VideoMAE) model. Moreover, unlike conventional fine-tuning procedures, the proposed methods innovatively refine the attention masks during fine-tuning to prioritise facial features most relevant to mental disorders. Experimental results show that our proposed method outperforms existing multi-mental disorder detection approaches on standard benchmarks, achieving competitive accuracy with fewer parameters, stable cross-dataset performance, and improved robustness. This work points to a promising direction for automated mental disorder diagnostic technologies.

title: Miniaturized ScAlN bimorph MEMS Microphone with Windmill Structure Achieving 61.2 dB SNR
authors: Chaoxiang Yang, Wenjuan Liu, Yaxin Wang, Liangyu Lu, Bohao Hu, Yan Liu, Yao Cai, Shishang Guo, Guoqiang Wu, Chengliang Sun
abstract: The demand for compact, low‑noise acoustic transducers have motivated rapid advances in MEMS microphone technology. This work presents a high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) piezoelectric MEMS microphone that utilizes a Sc<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0.1</sub>Al<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0.9</sub>N bimorph diaphragm with a windmill structure, occupying an area of only 0.3721 mm². The diaphragm consists of four fixed-anchored beams linked by a central hub, which significantly increases the vibration displacement, effective and maximum bending stress. The fixed-anchored beams enable synchronous movement, forming a piston-like vibration mode. Fabricated on an 8-inch thermal-oxide silicon wafer using a 9-mask surface-micromachining process, the device features integrated pad routing and parallel electrical interconnections among segmented piezoelectric elements. Acoustic measurements show that the original and amplified sensitivities at 1 kHz are −70.12 dB and −35.41 dB (re 1 V/Pa), respectively. The microphone achieves an SNR exceeding 61.2 dB over the full audio band, along with a minimum detectable sound pressure of 1 mPa (34 dB SPL) and a resolution of 1 mPa. These performance metrics demonstrate the suitability of the device for low-frequency voice capture and other miniaturized acoustic sensing applications.

title: Joint Trajectory and Resource Optimization for Delay Minimization of UAV-Enabled NOMA-MEC System With LWPT
authors: Xuecai Bao, Fugui Liu, Fenghui Zhang, Kun Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) enhance mobile edge computing (MEC) coverage, but in remote emergency scenarios limited battery life and scarce spectrum exacerbate interference, link instability, and end-to-end delay. To address these issues, we propose a joint trajectory and delay-minimization framework that integrates laser-beamed wireless power transfer (LWPT) with UAV-enabled non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) MEC. First, we present a practical system architecture where a ground laser-powered beacon (PB) continuously recharges the UAV during flight, enabling persistent aerial patrols that concurrently offer wireless charging and computation services to ground users. Second, we formulate a unified mixed-integer nonconvex optimization problem that jointly optimizes the UAV trajectory, task offloading ratios, PB power distribution, and user-scheduling policy under energy-causality, NOMA interference, and flight-dynamics constraints. Third, to address the resulting non-convexity, we develop a hierarchical decomposition and alternating-optimization method: the original problem is decomposed into trajectory and resource-allocation subproblems and solved using convex approximations and efficient scheduling algorithms to obtain practical solutions. Fourth, extensive simulations demonstrate that the proposed LWPT-assisted NOMA UAV-MEC scheme substantially reduces total system delay while improving energy efficiency and throughput compared with conventional OMA-MEC baselines and five recent heuristic algorithms.

title: Privacy-Preserving Proxy Bilateral Access Control for Secure Data Forwarding
authors: Axin Wu, Dengguo Feng, Min Zhang, Haining Yang, Jialin Chi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Secure data forwarding involves converting decrypted ciphertext, initially readable by one user, into a format that can be deciphered by another user. Proxy re-encryption is a commonly employed technique for secure data forwarding. However, this technique faces two inherent limitations. Firstly, only the data owner possesses the ability to control which data users can decrypt the ciphertext, resulting in receivers receiving irrelevant or uninterested information. Secondly, when data is forwarded through multiple nodes, it becomes vulnerable to various attacks such as impersonation and forgery. A solution called bilateral access control addresses these issues by letting the sender and receiver specify access control policies that the other party should comply with and ensure message confidentiality and authenticity. Nevertheless, to the best of our knowledge, there is currently no existing bilateral access control scheme capable of achieving secure data forwarding. In response to this issue, we propose a privacy-preserving proxy bilateral access control scheme, which simultaneously achieves all the above functionalities. Subsequently, we prove the message confidentiality and authenticity under the standard assumptions in the random oracle model. Finally, extensive theoretical analysis and performance evaluation demonstrate that the scheme provides unique features and comparable performance.

title: ConvLSTM Autoencoder-based CSI Prediction for Efficient Target Detection in TDD-Based OFDM ISAC Systems
authors: Yeong Choi, Chanul Park, Jong-Ho Lee, Seongwook Lee
abstract: Integrated sensing and communication has emerged as a key paradigm in next-generation wireless systems. In orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM)-based radar systems with time-division duplexing (TDD), the separation of downlink (DL) and uplink (UL) slots leads to spectral replicas along the Doppler axis, degrading sensing performance. To address this issue, we propose a convolutional long short-term memory autoencoder that predicts the channel state information (CSI) associated with unobserved UL slots between DL transmissions in a TDD frame. By estimating the CSI in unobserved UL slots, the proposed method effectively suppresses spectral replicas in the range-Doppler (RD) map. Simulation results under 3rd Generation Partnership Project New Radio numerologies (μ=1,2,3) demonstrate that the proposed model accurately predicts CSI values across diverse channel conditions. The model achieves a magnitude mean squared error (MSE) of 0.014 and a phase MSE of 0.038, consistently outperforming other methods. In addition, under equal parameter budgets, it achieves superior accuracy–efficiency trade-offs over alternative deep learning models, requiring only 7.2 ms per frame on a modern Internet-of-Things edge device. RD map analysis further confirms replica suppression, improving velocity coverage from 13.05 m/s to 613.5 m/s and signal-to-noise ratio from 45.16 dB to 60.91 dB compared with conventional methods, while maintaining target detection rates above 0.99. These results confirm that accurate CSI reconstruction by the proposed model significantly improves sensing fidelity in TDD-based OFDM radar systems.
