title: Statistical Forecasting of Fat in Body Proportion Utilizing Nonlinear Anthropological Parameters and Density Evaluation
authors: G Dinesh, T Vigneshwaran, B L Velammal, S Sweetline, C Sasthi Kumar, V Brinda
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Body Fat Percentage (BFP) is an accurate body fat assessment, plays vital role in order to evaluate an individual’s health status and disease risk. Traditional BFP assessments, such as dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) and hydrostatic weighing are high in accuracy which is compromised by their cost and complexity. This research work focuses on creating a predictive BFP model using anthropometric techniques. For formulating and validating the proposed model, a benchmark dataset is used consisting of 252 samples having measures of weight, height, waist circumference (WC), hip circumference (HC), skinfold thicknesses along with air displacement plethysmography (ADP) based density estimates. For feature engineering, the most important values are selected such as body mass index, hip ratio etc., as well as logarithmic values and then the best artificial neural network model is trained. The proposed model is developed using quadratic polynomial terms with a literature-based space-cost function (r > 0.98), provided the best model with a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 1.5% and coefficient of determination $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{0 . 9 2}$ outperforming conventional works.

title: Towards Solving Large QUBO Problems Using Quantum Algorithms: Improving the LogQ Scheme
authors: Yagnik Chatterjee, Jérémie Messud
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The LogQ algorithm encodes Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO) problems with exponentially fewer qubits than the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA). The advantages of conventional LogQ are accompanied by a challenge related to the optimization of its free parameters, which requires the usage of resourceintensive evolutionary or even global optimization algorithms. We propose a new <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\log Q$</tex> parameterization that can be optimized with a gradient-inspired method, which is less resource-intensive and thus strengthens the advantage of LogQ over QAOA for large/industrial problems. We illustrate the features of our method on an analytical model and present larger scale numerical results on MaxCut problems.

title: Improving Hardware Requirements for Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computing by Optimizing Error Budget Distributions
authors: Tobias V. Forster, Nils Quetschlich, Mathias Soeken, Robert Wille
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Despite significant progress in quantum computing in recent years, executing quantum circuits for practical problems remains challenging due to error-prone quantum hardware. Hence, quantum error correction becomes essential but induces significant overheads in qubits and execution time, often by orders of magnitude. Obviously, these overheads must be reduced. Since many quantum applications can tolerate some noise, end users can provide a maximum tolerated error, the error budget, to be considered during compilation and execution. This error budget, or, more precisely, its distribution, can be a key factor in achieving the overhead reduction. Conceptually, an errorcorrected quantum circuit can be divided into different parts that each have a specific purpose. Errors can happen in any of these parts and their errors sum up to the mentioned error budget-but how to distribute it among them actually constitutes a degree of freedom. This work is based on the idea that some of the circuit parts can compensate for errors more efficiently than others. Consequently, these parts should contribute more to satisfy the total error budget than the parts where it is more costly. However, this poses the challenge of finding optimal distributions. We address this challenge not only by providing general guidelines on distributing the error budget, but also a method that automatically determines resource-efficient distributions for arbitrary circuits by training a machine learning model on an accumulated dataset. The approach is evaluated by analyzing the machine learning model's predictions on so far unseen data, reducing the estimated space-time costs for more than 75% of the considered quantum circuits, with an average reduction of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5. 6 \%}$</tex>, including cases without improvement, and a maximum reduction of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 7. 7 \%}$</tex>.

title: Deep Learning based Skin Disease Classification with Preprocessing and Confidence Thresholding
authors: Sk. Khaleelullah, A. V. N. Pravallika, Bakuna Amulya, Arrabothu Sheerisha Reddy, Godhala Harika Reddy
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Skin diseases are among the most common medical conditions in the world, and in order to avoid complications, they must be diagnosed as soon as possible. Conventional diagnostic techniques are subjective, time-consuming, and frequently constrained by the availability of skilled dermatologists. In order to automatically classify skin diseases from dermatological images, this study suggests a deep learning-based system that makes use of convolutional neural networks (CNNs). To improve input quality, important preprocessing methods like image resizing, normalization, and artifact removal are used. The model’s classification accuracy surpasses 85% when tested on publicly accessible datasets (ISIC, HAM10000). Furthermore, by highlighting ambiguous predictions, a confidence thresholding mechanism is added to increase reliability. By lowering human error and facilitating early skin condition detection and treatment, this method seeks to help dermatologists make diagnoses more quickly and consistently.

title: A Hybrid Deep Learning and Ensemble Framework for Real-Time Phishing Website Detection Using Optimized Feature Selection
authors: Prabavathi. T, Mathan Kumar. M
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Phishing is a severe issue connected with security that allows to exploit social engineering in order to induce users to give information about sensitive data through false websites when they are tempted by some trick. The common technologies deployed in the detection process such as the black list-filtering and heuristic-based detections fail to identify the new or modern obfuscated attacks most of the time especially in real-time. To address these drawbacks, part of this paper proposes a hybrid detection framework, which combines deep learning and ensemble machine learning models with reliable feature selection so as to avoid such drawbacks. This framework employs content-based features as well as URL-based features the dimensionality reduction and feature-ranking techniques of the information gain, and the Principal component analysis (PCA) and the particle swarm optimization (PSO) to optimize the detection malware performance. Our stacking model, to be stronger and as effective as possible in terms of success in classification, therefore constitutes a conjugation of the functions of the recurrent neural networks (RNNs) and the ensemble classifiers, among which the Random Forest and the XGBoost. Typical practical phishing computer network attacks benchmark shows that the proposed system has superb detection capability with a maximum of 99.2 percent accuracy rates with low false positive rates and latencies to enable the system to find real-time uses. This paper illustrates how smart feature engineering and model fusion have been taken into account during the development of the phishing site defense.

title: TinyLLaMA-based Expert System for IoT Device Security in Application-Specific Domains
authors: Roshani Parmar, Nagendra Gajjar
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The rapid development of Internet of Things (IoT) equipment in domains such as smart homes, agriculture, healthcare services, and industry has intensified concerns about security weaknesses and context-aware safety strategies. This article introduces a lightweight AI-based expert assistant Fine-Tuning TinyLlama model, which recommends appropriate authentication methods, identifies possible attacks, and adapts the authentication Method to specific IoT applications and Device contexts. The system operates as a domain-specific advisory tool, rather than directly enforcing security measures in the field, which enables flexible integration into various IoT environments. According to the application and device parameters, an accurate context-driven response was produced using a custom-built dataset and a fine-tuning process. Performance evaluation demonstrated that the system learned effectively, producing high-quality predictions with a final perplexity of 2.41 and accuracy of 85.71%. The suggested assistant’s lightweight design makes it especially suitable for deployment in conditions with limited resources while maintaining flexibility in different IoT domains. The results demonstrate how it can be integrated by integrating AI models in IoT security infrastructure.

title: Autonomous Monitoring of Mental Health on Digital Media Platforms Using Multimodal AI
authors: S. Srikanth Reddy, R.M. Noorullah, Shaik Ruksana Begam
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: In the digital age, where individuals increasingly express their thoughts and emotions through various digital media platforms, the need for effective monitoring of mental distress indicators has become paramount. This research paper proposes a novel approach to autonomously monitor mental health in digital media platforms using hybrid multi-modal artificial intelligence (AI) techniques. The proposed system integrates natural language processing (NLP) and audio analysis to capture and analyze diverse forms of digital content, including text and audio, for indications of mental health states. Leveraging advanced machine learning algorithms, the system aims to identify patterns, sentiments, and behavioral cues associated with mental health conditions. The proposed system demonstrated high effectiveness, achieving 88% accuracy in text sentiment classification and 87% accuracy in audio emotion recognition, highlighting its potential for real-world deployment. Furthermore, the paper explores ethical considerations and privacy concerns related to deploying such technology on digital platforms. Through empirical evaluation and case studies, the efficacy and feasibility of the proposed approach are assessed, demonstrating its potential as a valuable tool for early detection and intervention in mental health disorders within the digital sphere. This research contributes to the burgeoning field of user monitoring by presenting a comprehensive framework for autonomous tracking that can enhance mental health awareness, support, and intervention strategies in the digital age, making the digital world a safer place.

title: Is Circuit Depth Accurate for Comparing Quantum Circuit Runtimes?
authors: Matthew Tremba, Paul Hovland, Ji Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Although quantum circuit depth is commonly used to approximate circuit runtimes, it overlooks a prevailing trait of current hardware implementation: different gates have different execution times. Recognizing the potential for discrepancies, we investigate depth's accuracy for comparing runtimes between compiled versions of the same circuit. In particular, we assess the accuracy of traditional and multi-qubit depth for (1) predicting relative differences in runtime and (2) identifying compiled circuit version(s) with the shortest runtime. Finding that circuit depth is not accurate for either task, we introduce a new metric, gateaware depth, that weights gates' contributions to runtime using an architecture's average gate execution times. Using average gate times allows gate-aware depth to capture variations by gate type without requiring exact knowledge of all gate times, increasing accuracy while maintaining portability across devices of the same architecture. Compared to traditional and multiqubit depth, gate-aware depth reduces the average relative error of predictions in task (1) by 68 and 18 times and increases the average number of correct identifications in task (2) by 20 and 43 percentage points, respectively. Finally, we provide gate-aware depth weight configurations for current IBM Eagle and Heron architectures.

title: Quantum Advantage in Computational Chemistry?
authors: Hans Gundlach, Keeper Sharkey, Jayson Lynch, Victoria Hazoglou, Kung-Chuan Hsu, Carl Dukatz, Eleanor Crane, Karin Walczyk, Marcin Bodziak, Johannes Galatsanos-Dueck, Neil Thompson
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: For decades, computational chemistry has been posited as one of the areas in which quantum computing would revolutionize. However, the algorithmic advantages that fault-tolerant quantum computers have for chemistry can be overwhelmed by other disadvantages, such as error correction, processor speed, etc. To assess when quantum computing will be disruptive to computational chemistry, we compare a wide range of classical methods to quantum computational methods by extending the framework proposed by Choi, Moses, and Thompson [1]. Our approach accounts for the characteristics of classical and quantum algorithms, and hardware, both today and as they improve. We find that in many cases, classical computational chemistry methods will likely remain superior to quantum algorithms for at least the next couple of decades. Nevertheless, quantum computers are likely to make important contributions in two important areas. First, for simulations with tens or hundreds of atoms, highly accurate methods such as Full Configuration Interaction and high-order Coupled Cluster are likely to be surpassed by quantum phase estimation in the coming decade. Secondly, in cases where quantum phase estimation is most efficient, moderately accurate classical techniques, such as Møller-Plesset, could be surpassed in ten to fifteen years if the technical advancements for quantum computers are favorable. Overall, we find that in the next decade or so, quantum computing will be most impactful for highly accurate computations with small to medium-sized molecules, whereas classical computers will likely remain the typical choice for calculations of larger molecules.

title: Random Forest Classifier for Real-Time Monitoring and Analysis of IoT Devices in View of Energy Efficiency and Security
authors: Binod Kumar, N Indumathi, Kumar Gaurav, Neetu Anand, Binita Roshima Hinz, Shrikant Upadhyay
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The usage of IoT devices has increased dramatically in recent years, with a variety of different applications from automated systems to smart homes. Nonetheless, the security and energy efficiency of these devices remain crucial challenges. In this paper it was suggested and simulated many secure and resource-efficient techniques for devices attached to the Internet of Things using Jupiter Notebook. It started by examining the security concerns with IoT devices, including the possibility of infiltration, data theft, and device piracy. Then created a secure communication protocol utilizing the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) to encrypt as well as decode data flows here between IoT devices and also the server. By ensuring that only authorized parties could access the data sent by the IoT, this raises the overall security of the system. In order to properly decide on the security and energy-saving strategies management for all of these devices, a data set that is directly connected to the significant variables and measurements of IoT devices that have been installed within the Jupiter notebook software platform has been collected. This study examines the significance of IoT device security measures and how hackers have recently been employing various forms of honorability to circumvent general security.

title: Enhancing EBSD Analysis Accuracy for Materials with Similar Crystal Structures via ChI-Scan and T-EBSD: Application to Semiconductor Failure Analysis
authors: Derrick Tan, Binghai Liu, Lei Zhu, Hsieh Chia Lun, Chey Ka Man, Cambridge Kon Tua Voon, Xiaomin Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: Accurate phase identification in materials with similar crystal structures is a significant challenge in semiconductor failure analysis. Conventional Electron Backscatter Diffraction (EBSD) often yields ambiguous results in such cases, hindering accurate microstructural characterization. This paper presents an enhanced approach that leverages the high spatial resolution of Transmission-EBSD (T-EBSD) on thin samples with elemental composition data from Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS), processed via the ChI-Scan technique, to overcome crystallographic ambiguities. We demonstrate the effectiveness of this combined methodology through case studies involving Copper (Cu) and Silver (Ag) thin films, which share the Face-Centered Cubic (FCC) structure, and Cu/Tin (Sn)/Cu3Sn intermetallic compounds (IMCs) in solder bumps. Results show that the integrated T-EBSD and ChI-Scan approach significantly improves phase differentiation and mapping accuracy compared to conventional methods. This enhanced capability provides a more reliable understanding of material microstructures, crucial for investigating failure mechanisms and optimizing semiconductor device reliability.

title: Quantum Reupload Units: A Scalable and Expressive Approach for Time Series Learning
authors: Léa Cassé, Sabarikirishwaran Ponnambalam, Bernhard Pfahringer, Albert Bifet
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We propose a single-qubit Quantum Machine Learning (QML) model for time series forecasting, built around the concept of a Quantum Reupload Unit (QRU), a hardwareefficient quantum circuit architecture with shallow depth. The proposed model demonstrates enhanced predictive power compared to variational methods such as quantum circuits (VQC), parameterized quantum circuits (PQC), and quantum residual blocks (QRB). The proposed QRU outperforms classical learning models such as Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) and Long-Short Term Memory (LSTM) with the same number of parameters. The novelty of this approach is its ability to model temporal patterns without relying on an extensive memory state, which reduces resource demands while preserving forecast accuracy. The expressivity of the model is evaluated through Fourier spectral decomposition. We analyze the trainability of our model using the absorption witness metric. We benchmarked the proposed model on the Mackey-Glass chaotic time series and the real-world river level dataset from TAIAO. The proposed model consistently exhibits enhanced expressivity over both of the datasets. These results highlight the significance of QRUs as promising candidates for learning models that can be conveniently deployed on noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) hardware.

title: Performance Evaluation of Reconfigurable Tunnel Field-Effect Transistors at Varying Temperature
authors: Akshatha Bhat, Bhaskar Awadhiya, Yashwanth Nanjappa, Sachin Agrawal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: This study evaluates the temperature sensitivity of reconfigurable TFETs, positioning them as a promising candidate for future devices by comparing their performance at different temperatures. The device was analyzed at three temperatures $(250 \mathrm{~K}, 300 \mathrm{~K}$, and 350 K) with a focus on carrier concentration, energy band diagrams, electric fields, surface potentials, current-voltage characteristics, and subthreshold swing. Simulation results indicate that reconfigurable TFETs maintain significant tunneling barriers in the OFF state and narrow tunneling barriers in the $O N$ state, unaffected by temperature variations. While the ON -state current improves with rising temperatures, elevated temperatures introduce challenges such as increased leakage currents and ambipolar behavior. Additionally, subthreshold swing improves at lower temperatures. Reconfigurable TFETs demonstrate potential in mitigating random dopant fluctuation limitations; however, further optimization is required to address temperaturedependent leakage currents and enhance operational parameters for ultra-scaled devices.

title: Svayam: A Self-Adaptive Extensible CEP framework for the Cloud-Edge Continuum
authors: Olaf Markus Link, Sukanya Bhowmik
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Traditional complex event processing (CEP) systems focus on extracting information out of simple events in the input event streams to detect complex event patterns. In the context of CEP, a computing unit that executes a complex data transformation task is called an operator. Typically, a CEP system consists of an operator graph that could be distributed over the cloud-edge continuum. However, an operator graph distributed over heterogeneous nodes comes with its own set of challenges. In fact, the nodes of an operator graph are typically subjected to dynamically changing workloads. Unbalanced load distributions across heterogeneous nodes may lead to processing overloads in individual operators that do not have enough resources to properly adapt to an increasing workload. As a result, a framework that can detect and adapt to dynamically changing workload in real time across the various nodes of the cloudedge continuum becomes paramount. To this end, the goal of this work is to propose a new extensible self-adaptive CEP framework with load regulatory features that help operators continue working even in face of an overload, thus facilitating the deployment of operators in a heterogeneous and/or resourcelimited environment.

title: Active Disturbance Rejection Control for a Self-Driving Racecar
authors: Andres Hoyos, Ximena Quevedo, Camilo Cortes, Santiago Triana, Sohel Anwar, Andres Tovar, Alvaro Gutiérrez, Jaime Arcos-Legarda
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: Self-driving cars are dynamically complex systems whose behavior is highly sensitive to operating and environmental conditions. At racing speeds, aerodynamic effects, tire slip and grip, and heat accumulation significantly alter dynamics, making control a challenging task under high model uncertainty and limited knowledge of vehicle behavior. This paper addresses this challenge using the Active Disturbance Rejection Control (ADRC) framework. A path-planning strategy based on camera perception generates reference signals for two parallel ADRCs: one regulating forward velocity and the other controlling ego-vehicle heading. The controller was developed for the Indy Autonomous Challenge (IAC) on the Dallara AV-21 platform and validated using the official IAC simulator, Ansys VRXperience, which replicates both vehicle dynamics and sensor suites. The proposed approach leverages the disturbance estimation and rejection capabilities of ADRC and its Extended-State Observer (ESO), requiring only minimal model information. Testing on the simulator shows that the controller achieves consistent performance at speeds up to 70 m/s (157 mph) on the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, demonstrating its robustness for realistic high-speed autonomous racing scenarios.

title: Decentralized Deep Learning for Lithographic Hotspot Detection in IC Design
authors: Tahani Aladwani, Maria Pantazi-Kypraiou, George Rafael Goudroumanis, Olympia Axelou, George Floros, Christos Anagnostopoulos
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: As the feature size of integrated circuits (ICs) continues to shrink, lithographic hotspots have become a critical challenge in IC design and manufacturing yield. Consequently, Lithography Hotspot Detection (LHD) at the post-OPC stage has garnered significant attention, aiming to identify potential patterning failures before transferring designs onto silicon wafers. In recent years, deep learning (DL) techniques have demonstrated superior performance in detecting previously unseen hotspot patterns, offering faster and more accurate detection compared to traditional methods such as pattern matching. However, existing DL-based approaches typically rely on centralized training, where all hotspot and non-hotspot data must be aggregated on a single server. This assumption is increasingly unrealistic, as semiconductor manufacturing companies are often unwilling to share sensitive layout data with third parties due to privacy and intellectual property concerns. This reluctance to share data is one of the primary reasons for the limited availability of updated benchmark datasets, with only ICCAD 2012 and ICCAD 2019 publicly accessible to date. To address these challenges, we propose a federated learningbased hotspot detection framework, which enables multiple design companies to collaboratively train a shared model without exposing their local data. This approach bridges the gap between data privacy requirements and the need for generalizable models that can support LHD across diverse sources. Our work pioneers the application of federated learning in the semiconductor manufacturing domain. We evaluate our approach against a centralized training baseline. Experimental results show that federated training achieves performance comparable to centralized training in terms of accuracy, precision, recall, specificity, and balanced accuracy-highlighting its potential for real-world deployment in privacy-sensitive IC design environments.

title: Twiddle: Twirling and Dynamical Decoupling, and Crosstalk Noise Modeling
authors: Hila Safi, Christoph Niedermeier, Wolfgang Mauerer
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Crosstalk remains a major source of correlated error in quantum systems, yet lacks a precise, community-wide definition - hindering systematic analysis and mitigation. This paper introduces a model-driven approach to crosstalk characterisation through three architecture-inspired noise models: (1) simultaneous two-qubit gate execution, (2) shared qubit interference, and (3) proximity-induced noise from shared control or readout hardware. These models act as both diagnostic tools and building blocks for crosstalk-aware quantum programming. We assess their impact across a broad benchmark suite - quantum simulation, Grover's algorithm, and fault-tolerant primitives like surface, Shor, and Steane codes - and evaluate two mitigation techniques: dynamical decoupling and Pauli twirling. While both are discussed in literature, only dynamical decoupling consistently enhances fidelity across noise types. Our work links low-level noise effects to high-level software engineering, underscoring the role of hardware-software co-design in scalable quantum computing. Model-based, hardware-aware design flows and composable noise abstractions improve error mitigation and program portability. Integrating such strategies into the toolchain is essential for building resilient quantum programs under realistic noise conditions.

title: Towards Quaternionic Description of Semiconductor Quantum Dots Based Electronics
authors: Wojciech Nowakowski, Krzysztof Pomorski, Eryk Hałubek
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The quaternionic description of semiconductor single-electron devices is given in the single-electron regime. The conversion scheme of complex value Hamiltonian into a quaternion is formulated for the case of single-electron semiconductor qubit and many electrostatically interacting qubits. In particular, the quantum evolution operator is presented in quaternion form for the case of non-interacting quantum bodies.

title: A Network Design Framework for Classical-to-Quantum Evolution
authors: Haitham H. Esmat, Beatriz Lorenzo, Savo Glisic
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We present a framework for developing quantum networks that enables a gradual transition from classical to fully quantum communication infrastructures. The proposed framework is based on the incorporation of a quantum overlay network on top of the classical network infrastructure, which can be incrementally expanded in alignment with technological advancements, market demand, and available investment. Central to this approach is the concept of an intermittent quantum IQ network, wherein only a subset of network links is quantum-secured, forming a spatially intermittent quantum network (sIQ network). Furthermore, the selection of such links can change over time, leading to the realization of a space-time intermittent quantum network (stIQ network), offering flexibility and scalability in the deployment of quantum communication technologies.

title: MRI-Based Segmentation of Uterus and Tumor in Endometrial Cancer using Machine Learning and Deep Learning
authors: J Angeline, J Bethanney Janney
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Endometrial Cancer (EC) is one of the common types of uterine cancer and continues to be a significant cause of cancer-related illness and death. Advanced-stage of EC often exhibits limited responsiveness to treatment. Current diagnostic methods for EC are expensive, time-intensive, and not universally accessible. In order to avoid this, an automated system for segmentation of tumor is required for early diagnosis which will benefit the patients and radiologists. The automated model enables faster and more accurate detection of uterine and tumor regions in MRI scans, which can assist radiologists in identifying EC at earlier stages. In this work, automated model is developed for segmentation of uterine and tumor using Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). 136 images of sagittal T2WI images, Axial Diffusion-Weighted Image (DWI), and axial T2 - weighted image (T2WI) which is divided into stage IA and IB. Deep Learning (DL) and Machine Learning (ML) based segmentation techniques is used for segmenting uterus and tumor. ML segmentation techniques include Otsu segmentation, region growing, and edge detection. CNN based segmentation is done using U-Net architecture and Visual Geometry Group (VGG) 16 as its backbone. The Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) was employed to quantitatively assess the overlap between the segmented uterine and tumor regions. On the test sets, the trained model achieved average DSC of 96.4% and 91.8% on axial T2WI, 95.2% and 91.5% on axial DWI, 96.1% and 89.7% on sagittal T2WI for the uterus and tumor regions respectively. Therefore, DL based segmentation better results than ML based segmentation techniques. Incorporating additional imaging modalities such as Positron Emission Tomography (PET) or Computed Tomography (CT) could provide a more comprehensive view of the tumor and surrounding tissues, leading to more accurate segmentation and better treatment planning.

title: Efficient QAOA Architecture for Solving Multi-Constrained Optimization Problems
authors: David Bucher, Daniel Porawski, Maximilian Janetschek, Jonas Stein, Corey O'Meara, Giorgio Cortiana, Claudia Linnhoff-Popien
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel combination of constraint encoding methods for the Quantum Approximate Optimization Ansatz (QAOA). Real-world optimization problems typically consist of multiple types of constraints. To solve these optimization problems with quantum methods, normally, all constraints are added as quadratic penalty terms to the objective, which expands the search space and increases problem complexity. This work proposes a general workflow that extracts and encodes specific constraints directly into the circuit of QAOA: One-hot constraints are enforced through <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$X Y$</tex>-mixers that restrict the search space to the feasible sub-space naturally. Inequality constraints are implemented through oracle-based Indicator Functions (IF). This paper focuses on the numerical benchmarks of the combined approach for solving the Multi-Knapsack (MKS) and the Prosumer Problem (PP), a modification of the MKS in the domain of electricity optimization. To this end, we introduce computational techniques that efficiently simulate the two presented constraint architectures. Since <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$X Y$</tex>-mixers restrict the search space, specific state vector entries are always zero and can be omitted from the simulation, saving valuable memory and computing resources. We benchmark the combined method against the established QUBO formulation, yielding a better solution quality and probability of sampling the optimal solution. Despite more complex circuits, the time-to-solution is more than an order of magnitude faster compared to the baseline methods and exhibits more favorable scaling properties.

title: Autocallable Options Pricing with Integration-Based Exponential Amplitude Loading
authors: Francesca Cibrario, Ron Cohen, Emanuele Dri, Christian Mattia, Or Samimi Golan, Tamuz Danzig, Giacomo Ranieri, Hanan Rosemarin, Davide Corbelletto, Amir Naveh, Bartolomeo Montrucchio
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We present a comprehensive quantum algorithm tailored for pricing autocallable options, offering a full implementation and experimental validation. Our experiments include simulations conducted on high performance computing (HPC) hardware, along with an empirical analysis of convergence to the classically estimated value. Our key innovation is an improved integration-based exponential amplitude loading technique that reduces circuit depth compared to state-of-the-art approaches. A detailed complexity analysis in a relevant setting shows a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 50 x$</tex> reduction in T-depth for the payoff component relative to previous methods. These contributions represent a step toward more efficient quantum approaches to pricing complex financial derivatives.

title: Toolchain for Experiment Tracking in Iterative Quantum Software Development
authors: Otso Kinanen, Mahee Gamage, Vlad Stirbu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: As quantum software engineering (QSE) matures, practitioners are adopting classical software engineering practices. This paper proposes a quantum experiment tracking infrastructure that aids quantum researchers in making informed decisions while developing quantum software incrementally and iteratively. By leveraging tools and best practices from classical machine learning communities, we provide a mature environment for quantum software practitioners to enhance their practices. Our approach involves collecting a comprehensive quantum provenance dataset from each experiment execution for analysis and decision-making. To validate our approach, we developed an experimental environment where a program was iteratively developed on quantum simulators and an IQM computer, and we demonstrate how the development workflow backed by the tracking infrastructure meets expectations for quantum experiment reporting.

title: Detection of Surface Spins Causing Flux Noise in Quantum Devices Using Electron Spin Resonance
authors: Dustin T. Hassenmayer, Patrick M. Lenahan, Jason T. Ryan, Stephen J. Moxim
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The improvement of quantum computing technologies relies on the reduction of flux noise that contributes to decoherence. Recent work has shown that the majority of flux noise is due to impurities and defects on the surface of the qubits [1], [2]. Electron spin resonance (ESR) is a prime candidate to detect these defects, but lacks the sensitivity and ability to provide information on the physical location of the defects. We report upon ESR measurements utilizing a non-resonant probe integrated within a semiconductor wafer probing station which could be used to detect paramagnetic defects believed to contribute to flux noise in quantum devices. Our approach greatly enhances ESR's sensitivity and provides a high spatial resolution on the surface of unaltered fully processed wafers and devices at room temperature. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method to detect defects on the surface of materials with a spin sensitivity improvement of roughly $10,000 × compared to classical ESR. The integration of a non-resonant probe into a standard semiconductor wafer probing setup has already been shown to be able to obtain a 2D map of unpaired spins on the surface of samples [3]. The technique offers a pathway for characterization of the defects which contribute to flux noise, which would provide critical insight into reducing decoherence mechanisms.

title: Label-Free Adherent Cell Counting Based on Deep Learning
authors: Zuhua Yu, Qiya Hao, Yuanyuan Sun, Hui Tian
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Accurate quantitative analysis of cells is a central task in biomedical research, including drug screening and disease diagnosis. However, the automated, high-precision counting of label-free adherent cells remains highly challenging due to their inherent overlapping and heterogeneity in size and morphology. To address this challenge, this study proposes a novel deep learning network, termed FMUNet. The network's encoder employs a hybrid architecture to better fuse global and local features, and it innovatively integrates a Feature Fusion Module (FFM) and a Multi-Scale Decoder (MSD) to significantly enhance counting accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that FMUNet outperforms existing mainstream methods on both the public LiveCell (phase-contrast) dataset and a self-developed bright-field dataset.

title: Simulation of Quantum Transduction Strategies for Quantum Networks
authors: Laura d'Avossa, Caitao Zhan, Joaquin Chung, Rajkumar Kettimuthu, Angela Sara Cacciapuoti, Marcello Caleffi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The Quantum Internet would likely be composed of diverse qubit technologies that interact through a heterogeneous quantum network. Thus, quantum transduction has been identified as a key enabler of the Quantum Internet. To better study heterogeneous quantum networks, the integration of a quantum transducer component into quantum network simulators has become crucial. In this paper, we extend SeQUeNCe, an opensource, discrete-event simulator of quantum networks, with a quantum transduction component along with auxiliary hardware device models and protocols. Moreover, we explore two strategies for transmitting quantum information between superconducting nodes via optical channels, with a focus on the impact of quantum transduction on the transmission process. The performance of these strategies is analyzed and compared through simulations conducted using SeQUeNCe. Our results align with theoretical predictions, offering simulation-based validation of the strategies and providing a path to accurate, larger-scale simulations of heterogeneous quantum networks.

title: Stroke Prediction using Advanced Machine Learning Algorithms
authors: S. Sujiya, Aravindhan M, Arunpandiyan M, Arumuganathan M
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Since stroke continues to be one of the top causes of death and disability globally, its onset prediction so that it can be treated promptly is extremely crucial. This presents a novel integrated machine learning approach named Hybrid Feature Optimized Random Forest (HFORF) to improve stroke prediction accuracy. This methodology is driven by statistical feature selection and metaheuristic optimization. HFORF actively chooses the most significant demographic and clinical characteristics with a two-stage strategy—mutual information ranking first, then optimization with the Grey Wolf Optimizer—whereas conventional methods use static datasets and linear classifiers. A Random Forest classifier chosen for its stability and interpretability is trained with the features. The model outperforms the classifiers in a test on a publicly available stroke dataset with 95.6% recall, 96.3% accuracy, and 94.8% precision. The findings demonstrate that the HFORF approach offers a drastic improvement in the reliability of stroke predictions and can be useful for actual clinical decision support systems.

title: 180 Days After EIP-4844: Will Blob Sharing Solve Dilemma for Small Rollups?
authors: Suhyeon Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Ethereum has adopted a rollup-centric roadmap to scale its network while preserving both security and decentralization. Rollups are layer 2 scaling solutions that process transactions off-chain while posting summarized data on-chain to maintain security and reduce costs. Posting data on-chain remains expensive, which led to the introduction of blobs via EIP-4844 that offer a cost-effective solution for data availability (DA). Although blobs significantly reduce DA costs compared to traditional calldata, many cost-sensitive small rollups struggle to fully utilize the fixed blob capacity. Blob sharing, which allows multiple rollups to collaboratively utilize a single blob, has been proposed as a solution to these challenges. In this paper, we empirically analyze nearly six months of data to assess the effectiveness of blob sharing. Our simulation results demonstrate that blob sharing can lower overall costs by approximately $\mathbf{8 0 \%}$ to 99%. These findings imply that the benefits of blob sharing are even greater than initially expected, providing strong incentives for both small and big rollups to actively collaborate in its adoption.

title: Overload-Resistant Flexible Strain Sensor Based on Stacked Silver Microsheets
authors: Junhao Shen, Zewen Gan, Jiajie Cui, Shaohua Zuo, Fuwen Shi, Tao Wang, Hengchang Bi, Xing Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: Reliability is essential for flexible strain sensors. However, the physical mechanism underlying the sensor suffering an overload condition remains unclear. This work fabricated strain sensors featuring multi-layer silver microsheet (AgMS) stacks using the Langmuir-Blodgett (LB) technique. Unlike conventional crack-based sensors, these sensors, after experiencing overload, maintain a consistently low resistance, thereby demonstrating outstanding overload resistance. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was employed to examine the microstructure of the sensing layer following cyclic overload testing, unveiling a novel strategy for enhancing overload resistance in flexible strain devices driven by the slip mechanism of the stacked microsheets.

title: Rotation Invariant Trash Recognition in Recycling Robots
authors: Seyed Ali Mousavi Fard, Seyed Saeed Hayati
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: Visual robots, leveraging robotic and computer vision techniques, play a crucial role in waste management and recycling due to their speed and accuracy. However, neural networks employed for trash recognition often struggle with classifying rotated images, undermining the reliability of recycling robots. In this paper, the application of rotation-invariant image classification models in recycling robots is explored. A transformer-based model, called RIFormer, is utilized to address this limitation. RIFormer is compared with state-of-the-art models like MobileNetV2, ResNet18, and Vision Transformer (ViT) to evaluate its effectiveness in recognizing rotated images at various angles, thereby enhancing the accuracy and reliability of recycling robots. The models were trained on the Augmented TrashNet Dataset, containing 10,000 samples, over 100 epochs. Experimental results demonstrate that RIFormer achieves a superior accuracy of $97 \%$, significantly outperforming other models, which fail to exceed $92 \%$. Additionally, RIFormer exhibits robustness against rotations, unlike its counterparts. This demonstrates that rotation-invariant models like RIFormer are more suitable for practical robotic applications.

title: From Questions to Knowledge: Chatbots as Learning Partners
authors: Ulises Tamez-Duque, Rita Salazar, Zita Valdés
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: Novel technologies based on artificial intelligence (AI) provide strategies for experimental projects in education. A technologically based education project for a laboratory setting is discussed including its conception, development, implementation, and evaluation of the integration of one personalized chatbot in an on-site education context. Discussion resulting from this experimental trial includes a positive outcome suggesting practical support for both students and faculty. This resulted in a successful preliminary approach using a chatbot as an assistant for laboratory application for a Mexican private high school education scenario.

title: Leveraging Fault Isolation Techniques in Failure Mechanism Determination of Digital Circuit-Related Failures
authors: John Clark Arollado, Ber-Riel Malimban, Joshua Michael Valencia
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: Failure analysis involving digital circuitry of a device poses challenges on uncovering failure mechanisms hidden in the covers of overlapping interconnects, along with the integration density. In die-level failure analysis, the identification of potential location of the defect are being done with fault isolation tools. These tools help in narrowing down circuits and/or components that can be contributing to the device failure. With the use of right fault isolation tools and leveraging on their capabilities, these will enhance the success rate of identification of failure mechanisms hidden in the digital circuitry. In addition, this success will also help the process owners for their investigation and recurrence prevention, which will help improve the quality of a product.

title: Nanoelectrical Fault Isolation with Multi-Modulations by Atomic Force Microscopy
authors: Fangfang Zhao, Wanxin Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: High resolution at nanometer scale in physical, mechanical and electrical properties make Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) an essential technique in fault isolation for semiconductor device failure analysis. With shrinkage in device dimension and increase in circuitry complexity, the requirements for both sample preparation and measurements at device level become more stringent. In this paper, we will use Conductive AFM as an example to systematically discuss how to overcome the challenges and enhance AFM capability with multi-modulations for advanced technology nodes.

title: Refined MobileNet for Automated Skeletal Age Assessment via Bone Depth and Length Analysis
authors: Jaisharma. K, N. Deepa, Devi. T
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Precise bone age determination is essential in the diagnosis of pediatric growth disturbances and the evaluation of skeletal maturity. In this paper, propose an enhanced MobileNet-based deep-learning network to classify bone age groups for hand X-ray images by predicting two physiological features, bone depth and bone size. The proposed model 3 has special functional layers to make use of the length and width characteristics, and dense as well as projection layers to estimate the depth. The model takes 224×224 standardized images as input and is trained with the Adam optimizer followed by early stopping to avoid overfitting. Experimental results show the model can learn anatomy relevant features with MAE and training loss of 24.37 months and 996, respectively. Comparison with the state-of-the- art results demonstrates that although with the higher MAE, proposed method achieves the state-of-the-art loss while demanding less computational overhead and no extra clinical data. Visual explanations from intermediate layers validate the model’s attention over biologically salient areas. Although the model has limitations such as region-specific data and smaller epochs, it consists of a general framework for scalable, explainable and efficient bone age assessment with a potential for a further adaptation for various ethnic groups and multimodal clinical environments.

title: A Double Selection Entanglement Distillation-Based State Estimator
authors: Joshua Carlo A. Casapao, Ananda G. Maity, Naphan Benchasattabuse, Michal Hajdušek, Akihito Soeda, Rodney Van Meter, David Elkouss
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: With the advent of practical quantum communication networks drawing closer, there is a growing need for reliable estimation protocols that can efficiently characterize quantum resources with minimum resource overhead requirement. A novel approach to this problem is to integrate an estimator into an existing network task, thereby removing the need for an additional characterization protocol. In this work, we show that the measurement statistics of a double selection distillation protocol alone can be used to efficiently estimate the Bell-diagonal parameters of the undistilled states, as well as the resulting distilled states after additional post-processing. We also demonstrate that this novel estimator outperforms the previously proposed distillation-based estimator in terms of resource complexity.

title: Symbolic Hamiltonian Compiler for Hybrid Qubit-Boson Processors
authors: Ethan Decker, Erik Gustafson, Evan McKinney, Alex K. Jones, Lucas Goetz, Ang Li, Alexander Schuckert, Samuel Stein, Gushu Li, Eleanor Crane
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum simulation of the interactions of fermions and bosons - the fundamental particles of nature - is essential for modeling complex quantum systems in material science, chemistry and high-energy physics and has been proposed as a promising application of fermion-boson quantum computers, which overcome the overhead encountered in mapping fermions and bosons to qubits. However, compiling the simulation of specific fermion-boson Hamiltonians into the natively available fermion-boson gate set is challenging. In particular, the large local dimension of bosons renders matrix-based compilation methods, as used for qubits and in existing tools such as Bosonic Qiskit or OpenFermion, challenging. We overcome this issue by introducing a novel symbolic compiler based on matrix-free symbolic manipulation of second quantised Hamiltonians, which automates the decomposition of fermion-boson second quantized problems into qubit-boson instruction set architectures. This integration establishes a comprehensive pipeline for simulating quantum systems on emerging qubit-boson and fermion-boson hardware, paving the way for their large-scale usage.

title: Optimized Deep Learning for Breast Cancer Detection using APO Algorithm
authors: Vijaya Kumar T, Rajasekaran P, Kaviya D S, Kavin Kumar V, Prithivirajan C M, Ragul B
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Deep learning has revolutionized Medical Image Classification, significantly improving the precision and reliability of disease diagnosis. This study presents an optimized Deep Learning framework for Breast Cancer Detection using the Arctic Puffin Optimization (APO) algorithm. APO was employed to fine-tune critical hyperparameters of deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs), effectively balancing exploration and exploitation, accelerating convergence, and reducing training time. The proposed APO-CNN model was evaluated on a high-resolution mammogram dataset, achieving a classification accuracy of 99.64%, outperforming conventional optimization approaches. Experimental findings demonstrate that APO not only enhances model precision but also reduces overfitting and improves generalization, making it highly suitable for real-world clinical deployment. By integrating APO into Deep Learning frameworks, this work provides a scalable and adaptable solution that supports radiologists in early and accurate diagnosis, contributing to improved clinical decision-making. Furthermore, APO’s optimization strategy strengthens the interpretability of CNN models, fostering greater trust in AI-driven healthcare solutions. Future research will explore APO’s applicability across broader medical imaging domains, extending its impact beyond breast cancer classification.

title: Quantum Control of Spin-Qubits with Spintronic Devices
authors: Md Fahim F. Chowdhury, Mohamad Niknam, Louis-S. Bouchard, Jayasimha Atulasimha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We propose and experimentally demonstrate a technique for achieving quantum control of spin qubits by utilizing localized magnetic fields generated by nanomagnets and skyrmions. The implementation of precise, localized control fields is critical to minimizing gate errors and cross-talk between neighboring qubits. In our theoretical work, we explored the use of nanomagnets and divergent and convergent magnetic skyrmions to generate a control field capable of manipulating spin qubits with high fidelity. Skyrmions, which resemble 3D hedgehog structures, offer advantages in standard semiconductor processes due to their 2D nature. Our simulations show that skyrmion configurations can provide gate fidelities above 99.9 % for singlequbit gates, while significantly reducing cross-talk in neighboring qubits compared to proximal nanomagnets. Expanding on this theoretical foundation, we experimentally demonstrate coherent quantum control of a nitrogen vacancy (NV) center in diamond using microwave fields from a nanoscale magnet, driven by a surface acoustic wave in lithium niobate. We observe highcontrast Rabi oscillations and control over the Rabi frequency by varying acoustic power. This approach, based on nanoscale magnets, provides a pathway to highly localized, energy-efficient quantum control and could replace thermally noisy microwave circuits, contributing to the scalability of quantum computing and sensing with NV defects and other spin qubits.

title: QAL: System-Level Integration of Quantum Accelerators
authors: Ralf Ramsauer, Wolfgang Mauerer
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum computing is often treated as an experimental add-on: it is often loosely coupled to classical infrastructure through high-level interpreted languages, cloud-based orchestration and physical measurement hardware. However, future deployments in both high-performance computing (HPC) and embedded environments will demand tighter integration for lower latencies, stronger determinism, and architectural consistency. We propose a vertically integrated quantum systems architecture that treats quantum accelerators as peripheral system components. A central element is the Quantum Abstraction Layer (QAL), introduced at the kernel level of the operating system. This design enables real-time, low-latency, and high-throughput interaction between quantum and classical resources and opens the door for robust scheduling, resource management, and cross-stack optimisation. Kernel-space integration is not merely a technical curiosity—it is a necessity. For HPC, it enables scalable, heterogeneous workloads; for embedded systems, it provides a foundation for future quantum deployments far beyond scripting-based control interfaces. We present early-stage results including a virtual QPU model integrated into a QEMU-based prototype system. The architecture is validated through functional emulation and time-accurate FPGA simulations, enabling realistic evaluation of hybrid system performance and quantum advantage scenarios. Our work lays the groundwork for a system-level co-design methodology tailored for the next generation of quantum-classical computing.

title: Scalable Kernel Integrity Monitor
authors: Jun-Yu Lai, Jui-An Chang, Yu-Sung Wu, Ying-Dar Lin, Chia-Mu Yu, Wei-Bin Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Dependable and Secure Computing (DSC)
abstract: The use of virtual machines in cloud data centers has become the de facto architecture for hosting AI applications. As these applications increasingly process vast amounts of data and interact with the physical world, ensuring the integrity of their underlying computing environment, specifically, the operating system kernel, becomes essential. To address this, we propose an integrity monitoring system for guest VM kernels. Our approach leverages virtual machine introspection and utilizes Volatility3 [1] to map the kernel modules. The monitor transparently inspects the OS kernels of all VMs on a server. Experimental results show that it enhances kernel security with minimal performance overhead on the host.

title: Assessing VQLS for Fluid Dynamics on a Hybrid Quantum-HPC Stack
authors: Muralikrishnan Gopalakrishnan Meena, Chao Lu, Eduardo Antonio Coello Pérez, Amir Shehata, Seongmin Kim, Kalyana Chakravarthi Gottiparthi, In-Saeng Suh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Recent advances in quantum linear solvers offer a promising direction for accelerating extreme scientific computations such as fluid dynamics. However, the deep and complex circuits required by many quantum algorithms limit their practical use on current quantum hardware. The Variational Quantum Linear Solver (VQLS) presents a viable alternative for near-term quantum devices (NISQ), and initial efforts have explored its application to select fluid dynamics problems. In this work, we evaluate the use of VQLS for canonical fluid dynamics problems, aiming to identify pathways for generalizing its implementation across a broader class of systems. We analyze the impact of various circuit ansatz and classical optimizers on solution quality and convergence behavior. Furthermore, we assess the algorithm's feasibility within a hybrid quantum–high-performance computing (HPC) framework by porting it to QFw, a state-of-the-art quantum-HPC software stack. <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup><sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>This manuscript has been authored by UT-Battelle, LLC, under contract DE-AC05-00OR22725 with the US Department of Energy (DOE). title: A Review of Artificial Intelligence in Finance: Driving the Next Wave of Industry Innovation
authors: Aparna Krishna Bhat, Gokulram Krishnan
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The rapid advancement of artificial intelligence (AI) is reshaping financial services by improving operational efficiency, enhancing decision-making, and elevating customer satisfaction. AI applications span investment management, risk assessment, fraud detection, and customer service, with predictive analytics and automation driving measurable improvements. For instance, AI-powered pattern recognition strengthens investment decisions, while advanced risk models enable more accurate detection of loan defaults and credit risks. Similarly, AI chat-bots and virtual assistants provide round-the-clock customer support, significantly improving user experience. Despite these opportunities, the adoption of AI in finance presents pressing challenges. Concerns around data security, privacy, and the lack of transparency in deep learning– driven decision-making raise critical questions of trust, accountability, and regulatory compliance. This paper contributes by systematically examining the applications, benefits, and limitations of AI in financial services, highlighting the trade-offs between innovation and governance. Our findings emphasize the need for a multidisciplinary framework that integrates technological innovation with robust regulatory oversight and ethical safeguards. By outlining current applications and identifying future trends, the study provides actionable insights into how financial institutions can strategically adopt AI solutions while mitigating risks.

title: Scalable Hardware Maturity Probe for Quantum Accelerators via Harmonic Analysis of QAOA
authors: Chinonso Onah, Kristel Michielsen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: As quantum processors begin operating as tightly coupled accelerators inside high-performance computing (HPC) facilities, dependable and reproducible behaviour becomes a gating requirement for scientific and industrial workloads. We present a hardware-maturity probe that quantifies a device's reliability by testing whether it can repeatedly reproduce the provably global optima of single-layer Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) circuits. Using harmonic-analysis techniques, we derive closed-form upper bounds on the number of stationary points in the p=1 QAOA cost landscape for broad classes of combinatorial-optimization problems. The bounds yield an exhaustive yet low-overhead grid-sampling scheme whose outcomes are analytically verifiable. The probe integrates reliability-engineering notions-run-to-failure statistics, confidence-interval estimation, and reproducibility testing-into a single, application-centric benchmark. The proposed method links analytic guarantees to empirical performance and supplies a standardised dependability metric for hybrid quantum-HPC (QHPC) workflows.

title: TD3 based Reinforcement Learning for News Article Recommendation
authors: Swathi Edem, Shanmukhi Rama Gundala, Isha Padhy
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Personalized news recommendation is a challenging task due to the highly dynamic nature of online news and evolving user preferences. Traditional recommendation techniques such as collaborative filtering and content-based methods struggle with cold-start issues and limited adaptability. In this work, we systematically evaluate four reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms Q-Learning, Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO), Deep Q-Learning (DQN), and Twin Delayed Deep Deterministic (TD3) on the Microsoft News Dataset (MIND). The recommendation task is modeled as a sequential decision-making process, where the RL agent optimizes long-term engagement through adaptive policy learning. Experimental results demonstrate that the TD3 algorithm achieves superior performance, with 95.1% accuracy, 93.2% precision, and 92.5% F1-score, outperforming the other approaches in terms of stability and reward maximization. The contributions of this study include: (i) a comparative benchmark of RL algorithms for news recommendation, (ii) formulation of a TD3-based framework tailored for continuous decision-making in recommendation tasks, and (iii) empirical evidence highlighting TD3’s effectiveness in mitigating overestimation bias and improving recommendation quality. These findings establish TD3 as a promising direction for building scalable, adaptive news recommender systems.

title: Industry Ready Engineering Graduate for Africa
authors: Samuel Eneje, Linus Idoko, Osita Omeje, George Ihenacho, Daniel Okojie
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: The employability of engineering graduates in Africa has raised significant concerns, with many lacking the practical skills required to meet the dynamic demands of industry. As industries across the continent call for urgent solutions to bridge this persistent skills gap, research has increasingly turned its focus to academic institutions, seeking ways to better align engineering education with industrial expectations. This study investigates how African higher education institutions can enhance the competencies of engineering graduates to produce industry-ready professionals. Using a qualitative, literature-based methodology, over 22 peer-reviewed articles published mainly between 2014 and 2024 are analysed through the lenses of Distributed Cognition and Cognitive Apprenticeship, applying thematic and critical discourse analysis to explore power dynamics and institutional influences on graduate preparedness. The research produces a bespoke industry-readiness template, detailing key qualities and institutional strategies needed to align graduate skills with technological and industrial realities. Emphasis is placed on fostering learning environments that support technological adaptation, experiential learning, and collaboration with industry partners. Ultimately, the study advocates for standardized curricula aligned with Engineering Education 4.0, ensuring African graduates emerge as competent, confident, and resourceful engineers ready to contribute to local and global innovation.

title: Fault Location of Distribution Network Based on AIPSO Algorithm and Edge Computing Architecture
authors: Xujin Hao, Chenguang Zhu, Qunwei Gao, Jie Cui, Shiwei Zhao, Junyang Guan, Haohua Wu, Pengxiang Zhao, Renqi Xing
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Aiming at the complex topology of low-voltage distribution network and the difficulty in ensuring the accuracy of fault section location caused by the access of distributed generation (DG), this paper proposes an intelligent fault location method based on adaptive immune particle swarm optimization algorithm (AIPSO) based on edge computing architecture. The spatiotemporal synchronous acquisition and distributed processing of fault information are realized through edge computing terminals, and a local and global fitness function model based on binary coding is constructed. By utilizing immune selection operators to dynamically adjust the concentration of particle populations and combining nonlinear mutation mechanisms to enhance the algorithm's global search capability, the traditional particle swarm optimization algorithm's tendency for premature convergence is solved. The simulation experiment is based on the IEEE 33 node distribution network model, and the experimental results show that the algorithm improves the convergence speed by 50% compared to the BPSO algorithm. The average positioning accuracy in noisy fault scenarios reaches about 92.5%, and the accuracy is improved by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 \sim 30 \%$</tex> compared to the BPSO algorithm. This provides a strong theoretical basis and technical support for the intelligent operation and rapid fault diagnosis of low-voltage distribution networks.

title: Enhancing Cybersecurity and Green Communication in 5G Networks: Challenges and Sustainable Solutions
authors: Ibrahim Ali Kh Shati, Mohamed Farid Soliman Gernaz, Abdulati Ibrahim Omar Abdullah, Ahmed Salah Aldeen Sahab
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Image and Signal Processing and Analysis (ISPA)
abstract: 5G networks represent a transformative advancement in telecommunications, offering ultra-reliable low-latency communication (URLLC), enhanced mobile broadband (eMBB), and massive machine-type communication (mMTC). However, these advancements introduce significant cybersecurity and sustainability challenges due to expanded attack surfaces, new threat vectors, and rising energy demands. This paper examines these challenges and proposes solutions, including advanced encryption mechanisms, AI-driven intrusion detection systems, blockchain-based authentication, and zero-trust frameworks. To strengthen validity, the paper references benchmark datasets (e.g., CICIDS 2017, UNSWNB15) and empirical studies from 5G testbeds that demonstrate quantifiable energy savings and intrusion detection accuracy. Additionally, the discussion extends to 6G innovations such as native AI integration, Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS), and semantic communications, positioning sustainability and security as core design principles.

title: Real-Time DCZ Gate Control by Bayesian Optimization with Forgetting
authors: Yudai Sato, Takayuki Kawahara
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Silicon spin qubits are a promising platform for large-scale quantum computing because of their compatibility with advanced semiconductor fabrication technology. However, charge noise remains a major challenge since it causes timedependent drifts in qubit frequency and exchange interactions through electric field fluctuations. These drifts in control parameters are one obstacle to achieving the high-fidelity quantum operations required for quantum error correction. In this work, we propose a Bayesian optimization (BO) framework for the adaptive calibration of quantum gate parameters in silicon qubits. In addition, to address the impact of charge noise, which exhibits a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 / f$</tex>-like power spectral density, we incorporate a forgetting mechanism into the Gaussian process model used during optimization. Our simulations on a realistic silicon quantum dot system show that BO-based method improves gate fidelity by 0.266% and reduces calibration iterations by 36.9% compared to random search. Compared to standard BO, our modified method achieves a further fidelity gain of 0.008% and a 9.23% reduction in iterations. These results highlight the potential of BO-based calibration for robust quantum gate implementation under realistic noise conditions.

title: Optimized GKP State for Bosonic Channel Sensing
authors: Thinh Le, Jianqing Liu, Jiapeng Zhao, Eneet Kaur
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Bosonic quantum computation harnesses the infinite-dimensional Hilbert space of harmonic oscillators, offering scalable architectures with inherent error correction advantages over qubit-based systems. Despite their potential, bosonic modes encounter significant challenges from prevalent noise sources, particularly photon loss and dephasing, which degrade quantum coherence. Among bosonic error-correcting codes, the Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill (GKP) code stands out for its ability to correct small phase-space displacements, enabling applications in quantum communication, sensing, and computation. While ideal GKP states require infinite squeezing and are unphysical, the finite squeezing approximate GKP states have been experimentally realized, though their performance depend critically on the squeezing level and measurement strategies. This work addresses a central challenge: how to optimize the squeezing parameter of approximate GKP states and the local oscillator (LO) phase in homodyne detection to maximize precision in estimating bosonic loss-dephasing channel parameters. To address this question, we introduce an adaptive optimization framework guided by classical Fisher information (CFI) and quantum Fisher information (QFI). Numerical simulations demonstrate that this adaptive protocol consistently converges to optimal parameter configurations, determining optimized squeezing levels and LO phases. By offering a practical approach to highprecision quantum channel parameter estimation, this framework has broad implications, from quantum metrology to enabling robust quantum communication systems.

title: EGCR-Net: Edge-Guided Cross-Region Network for Semi-Supervised Soldering Defect Detection
authors: Yaoyi Cai, Dan Huang, ZhiXun Li, Yunfeng Ma, Shuai Jiang, Zekai Yao, Min Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Surface defects in the printed circuit boards (PCBs) manufacturing process can affect product quality, thereby compromising the stability and reliability of the equipment. The ambiguity of defect boundaries and the insufficiency of annotated samples severely limit the detection performance of defect detection models. To address the above challenges, a semi-supervised segmentation network named EGCR-Net is proposed, which leverages a feature enhancement module and a cross-attention mechanism to enable effective multi-scale feature interaction under limited sample conditions, thereby improving the accuracy of solder defect segmentation. First, a memory module is introduced to store normal features and support anomaly comparison, thereby alleviating the problem of limited annotated samples. Second, a boundary-enhanced prompt (BEP) module is designed, which uses the Laplace operator to enhance the edge response of blurred defects. Third, a cross-region focus (CRF) module is proposed, which uses a cross-attention mechanism to capture long-distance context dependencies. The latter two modules work together to optimize the localization of defect boundaries, effectively addressing the detection challenges posed by blurred boundaries. We constructed the SolderPCB dataset, covering seven common solder defects, to evaluate real-world performance. The dataset will be publicly released after being organized. The experimental results show that EGCR-Net performs better than the current state-of-the-art methods in welding defect detection tasks and has been successfully deployed in automated PCB inspection lines to achieve quantitative detection of solder joint defects. In a real industrial environment, this method achieves an accuracy rate of 99%, effectively meeting standardized measurement requirements.

title: Low-Resolution Quantized OFDM Receiver in LEO Satellite IoT: Ergodic Achievable Rate Analysis and Power Allocation
authors: Zhuo Zhang, Youyang Xiang, Zhiyuan Tan, Xiantao Cheng, Feng Wang, Lidong Zhu
abstract: The explosive growth of Internet of Things (IoT) terminals poses dual challenges for wide-area access and system overhead. Satellite networks provide global coverage but face stringent transmit power constraints due to limited onboard energy and long-distance propagation. Low-resolution Analog-to-Digital Converters (ADCs) can reduce terminal complexity, yet their coarse quantization introduces nonlinear distortion that conventional power allocation cannot effectively handle. This letter develops an analytical model and proposes a quantization distortion-aware power allocation algorithm for OFDM-based satellite IoT downlink using low-resolution ADCs. Leveraging Bussgang decomposition and Price theorem, we model quantization distortion and derive an upper bound on the ergodic achievable rate. Based on this bound, we propose a power allocation algorithm combining the Lagrangian multiplier method and gradient projection, subject to total transmit power and spectral constraints. Simulation results confirm that the proposed algorithm achieves near-optimal ergodic achievable rate with more stringent constraints compared to general optimization method. This work provides a resource-efficient framework for large-scale satellite IoT connectivity.

title: Enhancing UAV Search under Occlusion using Next Best View Planning
authors: Sigrid Helene Strand, Thomas Wiedemann, Bram Burczek, Dmitriy Shutin
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Search and rescue missions are often critical following sudden natural disasters or in high-risk environmental situations. The most challenging search and rescue missions involve difficult-to-access terrains, such as dense forests with high occlusion. Deploying unmanned aerial vehicles depends on their ability to capture clear views of the ground, necessitating a robust search strategy to optimize camera positioning and perspective. This work presents an optimized planning strategy and an efficient algorithm for the Next Best View problem in occluded environments. Two novel optimization heuristics, a geometry heuristic, and a visibility heuristic, are proposed to enhance search performance by selecting optimal camera viewpoints. Comparative evaluations in both simulated and real-world settings reveal that the visibility heuristic achieves greater performance, identifying over 90% of hidden objects in simulated forests and offering 10% better detection rates than the geometry heuristic. Additionally, real-world experiments demonstrate that the visibility heuristic provides better coverage under the canopy, highlighting its potential for improving search and rescue missions in occluded environments.
