title: Scalable and Optimal Security Allocation in Networks Against Stealthy Injection Attacks
authors: Anh Tung Nguyen, Sribalaji C. Anand, André M. H. Teixeira
abstract: This paper addresses the security allocation problem in a networked control system under stealthy injection attacks. The networked system is comprised of interconnected subsystems which are represented by nodes in a digraph. An adversary compromises the system by injecting false data into several nodes with the aim of maximally disrupting the performance of the network while remaining stealthy to a defender. To minimize the impact of such stealthy attacks, the defender, with limited knowledge about attack policies and attack resources, allocates several sensors on nodes to impose the stealthiness constraint governing the attack policy. We provide an optimal security allocation algorithm to minimize the expected attack impact on the entire network. Furthermore, under a suitable local control design, the proposed security allocation algorithm can be executed in a scalable way. Finally, the obtained results are numerically validated through using Erdős-Rényi random graphs for generality.

title: Enhanced Operational Stability of Flexible Carbon Nanotube Thin Film Transistors Using Low-temperature Post-treatment
authors: Haitao Zhang, Xiongfeng Zou, Jian Hu, Hui Wang, Li Xiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Materials for Electron Devices
abstract: Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have been extensively investigated as channel materials for flexible electronics, owing to their inherent flexibility, high carrier mobility, ultrathin body, and solution-based, low-temperature processibility. However, achieving robust operation of CNT thin-film transistors (TFTs) under repeated bias cycling in air, a crucial requirement for complex and large-scale circuits, remains a challenge. In this work, we present a low-temperature hexamethyldisilazane (HMDS) post-treatment (150°C) to enhance the robustness of flexible, bottom-gated CNT TFTs. This treatment significantly reduces device hysteresis and improves threshold voltage (V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sub>) stability under repeated bias cycling, decreasing the relative standard deviation (S<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">r</sub>) of V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sub> from 136% to 34.1% and from 77.3% to 4.23% under different measurement modes. The mechanisms underlying this V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sub> stability enhancement are primarily attributed to a significant reduction in device surface traps: (1) prolonged 150°C post-treatment in a vacuum oven promotes the desorption of oxygen and water molecules from the active layer and dielectric surface; (2) HMDS reacts with polar hydroxyl groups on the device surface, generating hydrophobic, non-polar methyl groups, thereby reducing surface charge accumulation; and (3) the hydrophobic nature of the HMDS layer on the device surface contributes to insulating the device from ambient oxygen and water molecules.

title: LearnRouter: A Reinforcement Learning-Based Routing for Opportunistic Mobile Networks using Multi-Armed Bandit Approach
authors: Aanchal Phutela, Shiva Koshta, Sujata Pal, Srinivas Sampalli
abstract: Efficient routing protocols are required in opportunistic networks due to the inherent challenges of sporadic connectivity, transmission delays, and dynamic network topologies. In these networks, information is forwarded and disseminated among smart devices based on opportunistic contacts driven primarily by network dynamics and user mobility. This paper introduces LearnRouter, a dynamic reinforcement learning-based routing algorithm designed to improve the message delivery ratio while minimizing end-to-end delay in opportunistic networks. Existing routing protocols use static strategies or fixed replication schemes, leading to resource utilization and high message drop rates. LearnRouter addresses these challenges by incorporating the multi-armed bandit framework and utilizing the Upper Confidence Bound algorithm to make more intelligent and data-driven forwarding decisions. The proposed approach enables the protocol to adapt continuously to network changes while balancing the trade-off between exploration and exploitation. The simulation results show that LearnRouter surpasses end-to-end delay and message delivery ratio in comparison with Direct Delivery, Spray and Wait, CBR, SimRouter, RL-Prophet, and K-DQLR in opportunistic and dynamic environments.

title: QSimBench: An Execution-Level Benchmark Suite for Quantum Software Engineering
authors: Giuseppe Bisicchia, Alessandro Bocci, José García-Alonso, Juan M. Murillo, Antonio Brogi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Reproducibility and comparability remain fundamental challenges in the empirical evaluation of Quantum Software Engineering (QSE) tools. These challenges arise from the intrinsic probabilistic behavior of quantum programs and the variability introduced by quantum hardware and simulator backends. While existing quantum benchmarks typically offer only static circuit definitions, they often leave researchers responsible for data generation and execution, hindering the creation of standardized and reproducible experiments. In this paper, we introduce QSimBench, a novel, open-source benchmark suite and accompanying Python library designed to address these limitations. QSimBench provides over 20 million precomputed shot-level execution traces: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> measurements each, across <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 4}$</tex> quantum algorithms, multiple circuit sizes (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4-15$</tex> qubits), and six Qiskit-based backends including both ideal and noise-injected simulations. Each configuration includes not only detailed measurement histories but also the original circuit in OpenQASM, the backend's noise model, and configuration metadata, ensuring full transparency and enabling in-depth analysis. QSimBench empowers researchers to conduct scalable, reproducible, and statistically rigorous evaluations of QSE tools, such as those for monitoring, orchestration, and statistical post-processing, without the need for expensive or difficult-to-reproduce quantum executions. The benchmark is distributed with a lightweight Python API that facilitates fast data retrieval, flexible sampling strategies, and seamless integration into experimental pipelines. QSimBench is publicly available, aiming to foster collaborative and reproducible research within the quantum software community.

title: Quantum-Inspired Trust Scoring for Zero Trust Security: A Simulation-Based Approach
authors: Shengjie Xu, Yi Qian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: This paper introduces a quantum-inspired trust scoring system that enhances Zero Trust security architectures by leveraging principles from quantum computing. Our approach utilizes quantum-inspired superposition and entanglement to create a more nuanced and dynamic trust evaluation framework. We present a simulation-based validation of this approach, demonstrating three key advantages: (1) enhanced granularity in trust representation through superposition of multiple trust states, (2) improved modeling of trust relationships through emergent correlation from quantum-inspired entanglement, and (3) better adaptability to complex trust scenarios through dynamic trust evolution. While our system conceptually supports a multi-dimensional trust framework, the current implementation models trust as a single quantum-inspired state per entity, with multi-dimensional extensions discussed as future work. Our simulation results show that the system effectively maintains stable trust scores for normal behavior, rapidly detects security threats, and models trust relationships between entities, making it a promising solution for modern Zero Trust environments.

title: TShape: Rescuing Machine Learning Models from Complex Shapelet Anomalies
authors: Hang Cui, Jingjing Li, Haotian Si, Quan Zhou, Changhua Pei, Gaogang Xie, Dan Pei
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: Time series anomaly detection (TSAD) is critical for maintaining the reliability of modern IT infrastructures, where complex anomalies frequently arise in highly dynamic environments. In this paper, we present TShape, a novel framework designed to address the challenges in industrial time series anomaly detection. Existing methods often struggle to detect shapelet anomalies that manifest as complex shape deviations, which appear obvious to human experts but prove challenging for machine learning algorithms. TShape introduces a patch-wise dual attention mechanism with multi-scale convolution to model intricate sub-sequence variations by balancing local, fine-grained shape features with global contextual dependencies. Our extensive evaluation on five diverse benchmarks demonstrates that TShape outperforms existing state-of-the-art models, achieving an average 10 % F1 score improvement in anomaly detection. Additionally, ablation studies and attention visualizations confirm the essential contributions of each component, highlighting the robustness and adaptability of TShape to complex shapelet shapes in time series data.

title: Multipurpose Networked Control System Based on Arduino Uno and Modbus RTU RS-485
authors: Helman Enrique Sarmiento P., Luis Francisco Combita A.
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a multipurpose networked control system using Arduino and Modbus RTU over RS-485 communication. The system enables robust and scalable industrial automation and remote monitoring by leveraging the reliability of RS-485 and the standardized Modbus RTU protocol. The versatility, open-source programming, and low cost of Arduino Uno are some of the features we took into account to select it as the micro-controller of the system. The paper discusses system architecture, communication strategies, software implementation, and performance evaluation.

title: Quantum-Inspired Optimization and QAOA Validation for Cost-Effective Fertilizer Allocation in Precision Agriculture
authors: Chia-Ho Ou, You-Wei Kan, Masayuki Ohzeki, Chih-Yu Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Effective fertilizer allocation enhances agricultural productivity and sustainability. Traditional heuristics often cause nutrient imbalance and excess cost. This study introduces a quantum-inspired Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO) model solved by the Compal GPU Annealer (CGA). Experiments on radish, cabbage, and rice demonstrated 8-20% cost savings over greedy heuristics. A small-scale Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) validation using IBM Qiskit confirmed quantum algorithmic compatibility.

title: Comparative Study of AI Models for Automated Tuberculosis Detection Using Image Processing Techniques
authors: Asim Yash Khakha, Ramesh Chandra Poonia
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Tuberculosis is a critical global health issue, particularly in resource-limited regions where early and accurate diagnosis is important and is in need so that the treatment is effective and the control transmission is controlled. The known diagnostic methods, such as sputum smear microscopy and nucleic acid amplification tests are costly, time-consuming, and require trained professionals. Due this in some cases it is inaccessible in many regions. Deep learning-based automated TB detection offers a promising alternative by enhancing diagnostic efficiency through medical imaging analysis. This study presents a comparative evaluation of five deep learning models, InceptionResNetV2, DenseNet, VGG16, ANN, and a custom CNN, trained on a dataset of $\mathbf{3, 0 0 8}$ chest radiograph images, evenly distributed between TB-positive and normal cases. The dataset underwent advanced preprocessing techniques, pixel normalization, and data augmentation. The hyperparameter tuning process was applied, which optimized the learning rates, dropout rates, convolutional filter sizes, and batch sizes to enhance model performance. The models were assessed using accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, sensitivity, specificity.. Experimental results indicated that the custom CNN achieved the highest classification accuracy (99.51). The superior performance of the custom CNN over other models is attributed to optimized feature extraction, effective preprocessing, and structured hyperparameter tuning. A comparative analysis with previous studies highlights how this approach mitigates dataset limitations and improves model interpretability, and the potential of AI-driven TB detection, enhancing future diagnostic efficiency by improving model generalizability and deployment in real-world healthcare settings.

title: Where Should I Deploy My Contracts? A Practical Experience Report
authors: Cătălina Lazăr, Gabriela Secrieru, Emanuel Onica
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Blockchain networks provide a reliable trust anchor to decentralized applications (DApps) backed by smart contracts. The Ethereum ecosystem now encompasses most blockchain networks that provide compatible support for smart contracts code. Recently, many Ethereum Layer 2 (L2) rollup solutions emerged, meant to scale the base Layer 1 (L1) network, consequently decreasing transaction fees and diversifying the usage scenarios. Furthermore, the number of blockchain providers that offer access to the network infrastructure for both L1 and L2 continuously increases. A developer is faced with a multitude of deployment options and must weigh between the gains in costs and the losses in trust that are still an issue with L2. A decisive factor in this trade-off can be the use case itself, depending on its security requirements. Still, the evaluation of costs and performance cannot be ignored and should rely on set of measurable metrics, although choosing the right metrics can be complicated. In this practical experience report, we explore the relevance of several such metrics in choosing between different providers and rollups. For this purpose, we perform evaluations for two use cases of DApps: a voting DApp with high security demands, suited for L1 deployment, and a cost-sensitive supply chain DApp, where L2 can be an option. We analyze a set of basic metrics by comparing these between two highly used access providers, Alchemy and Infura, for the L1 deployment case, and between two of the most popular rollups, Arbitrum One and OP Mainnet (Optimism), for the L2 deployment scenario.

title: Enhancing Data Visualization Interpretation through Fine-Tuned VLMs: A Comparative Analysis
authors: Mohit Kulkarni, Neel Sachin Munot, Piyanshu Mohite, Yogesh Magar, K. S. Wagh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: The interpretation of data visualizations, such as charts, plots, graphs, and other graphical representations, is a crucial component of data-driven decision-making across domains such as business intelligence, scientific research, healthcare, and education. As these visualizations play an essential role in simplifying complex datasets, the need for automating their analysis and explanation has grown significantly. Vision Language Models (VLMs) have emerged as powerful tools for multimodal tasks, excelling in bridging visual and textual modalities. However, their application to the domain of data visualization interpretation remains underexplored. This paper addresses this gap by presenting a comparative analysis of three fine-tuned VLMs, evaluating their ability to comprehend and generate descriptive insights from graphical data. Three state-of-the-art VLMs were fine-tuned to enhance their capability to interpret and generate descriptive insights from these visualizations. Leveraging advanced techniques to systematically adapt the models to this specialized domain and evaluate their performance using quantitative metrics such as ROUGE, BLEU, and BERT score. Our findings underscore the potential of VLMs to automate the textual interpretation of data visualizations. This research contributes to advancing multimodal model learning by demonstrating the adaptability of VLMs to nontraditional visual data, paving the way for applications in automated reporting, accessibility tools, and educational platforms. The study provides a foundation for future exploration into developing robust, versatile models for data visualization interpretation and beyond.

title: Measurement-Based Variational Quantum Imaginary Time Evolution
authors: Kübra Yeter-Aydeniz, Nora Bauer, George Siopsis
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum computing encompasses a variety of computation models, including gate-based (GB), topological, quantum annealing, and measurement-based (MB). MB performs computation through single-qubit measurements on a highly entangled cluster state and is proposed to offer some practical advantages on near-term quantum hardware in terms of circuit depth. In this work, we propose MB-VQITE, which leverages the MB model for solving optimization problems using the variational quantum imaginary time evolution (VQITE) algorithm. We apply MB-VQITE to the molecular docking problem, which is relevant in pharmaceutical research. We perform direct comparisons between the MB and GB computing paradigms on IBM Cleveland quantum hardware and perform optimization procedures on noisy simulators. We find that MB-VQITE outperforms GB-VQITE on current quantum hardware by reducing circuit depth, thus decreasing noise to allow for smoother optimization.

title: A Comparative Study of All-Photonic and Memory-Based Quantum Repeaters and Networks
authors: Chuen Hei Chan, Charu Jain, Ezra Kissel, Wenji Wu, Edwin Barnes, Sophia E. Economou, Inder Monga
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Developing and deploying advanced Quantum Repeater (QR) technologies will be necessary to scale quantum networks at longer distances. Depending on the error mitigation mechanisms adopted to suppress loss and errors, QRs are typically classified into “memory-based” or “all-photonic” QRs, and each type of QR may be best suited for a specific type of underlying quantum technology, a particular scale of quantum network, or a specific regime of operational parameters. Modeling and simulation of quantum repeaters and networks can help in understanding the relative performance and resource requirements of different types of QRs, identify tradeoffs of alternative quantum network architectures, optimize quantum hardware, and assist in the design of a robust control plane. This paper introduces a quantum repeater simulation toolkit based on NetSquid, which includes component models and protocols to study advanced quantum repeater networks. We present our initial research findings on modeling and simulation of “allphotonic” entanglement-based QRs and “memory-based” first generation trapped ion QRs. We study the relative performance and resource requirements of these two different types of QRs and networks. The performance metrics include entanglement generation rate and fidelity between the endpoints of the network. For fair comparison of resource requirements of different types of QRs, entanglement generation rate is normalized by the total number of matter qubits involved.

title: AI Assurance Needs a Systems Engineering Approach
authors: Robin Bloomfield, John Rushby
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: As systems become increasingly composed of AI/ML elements, the focus of assurance tends to shift from “safe use of AI” to “safe AI.” In this position paper, we argue this is opposite to what is required and urge a systems engineering approach.

title: PIL Implementation of a Fuzzy Energy Management Strategy for an Electric Vehicle with Battery and Supercapacitor
authors: Cristhian Narvaez, Juan Rodriguez, Jose Vuelvas, Juan D. Valladolid, Luis G. Marin
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: This paper presents the embedded implementation of a fuzzy logic-based multivariable energy management strategy for a hybrid storage system in electric vehicles (EVs), composed of a lithium-ion battery and a supercapacitor. The control system is designed to optimize power distribution based on driving demand and the state of charge of the storage devices. The approach aims to improve battery lifespan, reduce energy losses, and enhance overall system efficiency. The control algorithm is deployed on an ESP32 microcontroller using the Model-Based Design (MBD) methodology and tested in a Processor-in-the-Loop (PIL) configuration. The strategy was validated under standardized driving cycles (WLTCclasse3, ARTEMIS, and UDDS), achieving superior performance in cost minimization-reaching values as low as 72.159 in UDDS and 90.971 in WLTCclasse3-while also preserving higher final SoC values and minimizing unintended energy charged to the battery, indicating effective and robust energy management.

title: Quantum Machine Learning for Intrusion Detection on Noisy Quantum Computers
authors: Franco Cirillo, Christian Esposito
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) play a fundamental role in safeguarding digital infrastructures against cyber threats. Quantum Machine Learning (QML) presents a promising frontier in this domain, offering potential computational speedups and improved management of complex datasets. However, its practical deployment is currently limited by the constraints of Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) devices. This work explores the application of various QML approaches, specifically Quantum Support Vector Classifiers (QSVC), Variational Quantum Classifiers (VQC), and hybrid quantum-classical neural networks for anomaly detection tasks. The models were fine-tuned and benchmarked using the ToN_IoT dataset, with performance assessed on IBM's noisy quantum simulators to evaluate their behavior under realistic noise conditions. Results indicate that the Pegasos-QSVC model outperformed others, reaching an accuracy of 93.05% and an F1 score of 93.73%. Through a comparative analysis of different circuit architectures, this study identifies strategies to improve the robustness of QML systems, emphasizing their emerging potential in cybersecurity scenarios.

title: Metaheuristic Algorithms for Feature Selection and Classification in Breast Cancer Detection: A Comprehensive Framework
authors: Maedeh Kiani Sarkaleh, Hossein Azgomi, Azadeh Kiani-Sarkale
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: Early detection of breast cancer significantly increases treatment success rates and reduces mortality. Leveraging image processing and pattern recognition techniques for automatic tumor detection in mammography images minimizes human error and accelerates the diagnostic process. This paper presents a comprehensive review of the application of metaheuristic algorithms for feature selection and classification in breast cancer detection and proposes a general framework for their integration. The proposed framework includes preprocessing, feature extraction, feature selection through optimization algorithms, and classification to enhance detection accuracy. The review discusses the potential of the framework for enhancing the effectiveness of breast cancer detection systems and offers an optimized solution for efficient and accurate diagnosis.

title: Physically-Aware Qubit Reuse for Optimized Quantum Circuit Compilation Using Machine Learning
authors: Gopika Kizhuvettil, Georgios Ioannou, Siyuan Niu, Samah Mohamed Saeed
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Recently developed quantum computers support mid-circuit measurements, allowing qubit measurement, resetting, and reuse during the execution of quantum circuits. This capability opens new opportunities for optimizing quantum circuit compilation, particularly in the context of Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum devices. This paper explores the role of machine learning in integrating mid-circuit measurements into the compilation process, focusing on strategies to minimize errors. Specifically, we propose a reinforcement learning method to enable physically-aware qubit reuse and a machine learning method to support physically-aware synthesis-based qubit reuse. We conduct an extensive experimental evaluation to demonstrate the effectiveness of our methods using various quantum algorithms executed on an IBM quantum computer.

title: Assessing Concentration Levels in Interactive Digital Tests Through Portable EEG Technology
authors: Pérez-Gómez Laura J., Ceballos-Cancino Héctor Gibrán, Morán-Mirabal Luis Fernando, Torres-Rodríguez Sergio Noé, Ruiz-Ramírez Jessica Alejandra
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: The increasing prevalence of hybrid education has underscored the need for strategies to evaluate student concentration across both in-person and remote settings. Within Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) contexts, monitoring attention during various learning tasks has been identified as a critical factor influencing academic outcomes. Although prior research has demonstrated the utility of electroencephalography (EEG) for assessing mental states, the application of low-cost, portable EEG devices for concentration monitoring in educational environments remains limited.This study aimed to examine the feasibility of using EEG signals recorded from a Muse 2 Headband to distinguish between tasks requiring different levels of concentration. A total of forty-one participants completed a series of digital tasks while EEG data were collected. The dataset was processed and analyzed using three machine learning algorithms: Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, and KNearest Neighbors. The objective was to classify concentration versus non-concentration states based on EEG features and selfreported focus levels. The Random Forest model achieved the highest classification accuracy, outperforming comparable methods and supporting the validity of using the Muse 2 Headband as a real-time, cost-effective tool for concentration assessment in HCI-driven educational scenarios. These findings suggest that portable EEG devices may serve as effective instruments for tracking concentration in hybrid learning environments. Their integration could offer timely feedback to students and educators, contributing to improved academic performance. Future work will explore multimodal approaches by combining EEG data with other physiological signals to enhance the robustness of concentration assessment models.

title: A Measure-and-Prepare Framework for Arbitrary Quantum Gate Excision and its Applications
authors: Tian-Fu Chen, Yu-Hung Pan, Ting-Hsun Chi, Po-Hung Chen, Dah-Wei Chiou, Jie-Hong R. Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The wire-cutting technique has been recently developed to partition a large quantum circuit into smaller subcircuits, enabling distributed computation across multiple quantum devices with limited capacity. In this work, we generalize the standard wire-cutting method—which can be interpreted as excising an identity operation—to a broader framework that allows the excision of arbitrary unitary gates. We propose a general measure-and-prepare approach to realize this extension, which allows a quantum gate to be excised from a circuit significantly more efficiently than by cutting all the wires surrounding the gate, leading to exponential savings in classical computational cost with respect to the number of wires involved. As an application, we employ this framework for the classical simulation of near-Clifford quantum circuits by excising non-Clifford gates from the circuit and efficiently simulating the remaining Clifford subcircuit in polynomial time. Experimental results demonstrate the superiority of our method over the prior wire-cutting technique in emulating near-Clifford circuits.

title: End-to-End EEG Emotion Recognition via Adaptive Frequency Filtering and Sequential Denoising
authors: Asfak Ali, Jotiraditya Banerjee, Vyacheslav Gulvanskii, Dmitrii Kaplun, Ram Sarkar
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Image and Signal Processing and Analysis (ISPA)
abstract: In this paper, we address the challenge of noisy electroencephalogram (EEG) signals in emotion recognition by introducing a unified, end-to-end denoising and classification framework that operates across both frequency and time domains. First, we design an Adaptive Frequency Filter (AFF) module that learns to suppress spectral noise while preserving emotion-relevant frequency components; this filtering is performed as an integral layer within the neural architecture, ensuring seamless gradient-based optimization. To further refine temporal signal integrity, we incorporate a two-layered Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) denoiser: the first LSTM layer captures coarse temporal dependencies and removes bulk noise, and the second layer targets finer residual artifacts, thereby enhancing the sequential features fed to the classifier. To guide the network toward both classification accuracy and parsimonious frequency utilization, we propose a novel Multi-Objective Learning Loss (MOLL), which combines label-smoothed categorical cross-entropy with an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{1}$</tex> - based regularization on the learned frequency mask-encouraging sparsity and robustness across emotional states. We validated our approach on the widely used WESAD, SWELL and SEED emotion datasets, performing better in comparison with state-of-the-art baselines. We tested our model on different devices and found that it can run in real-time, with inference times as low as 22 ms on GPUs and under 130 ms on edge devices like Raspberry Pi 5, making it suitable for real-world emotion recognition applications. The code materials for the following work will be available at: https://github.com/praetorian2710/EEG-Emotion-Recognition-via-Adaptive-Frequency-Filtering-and-Sequential-Denoising

title: Phase Estimation and Predictive Control for a Hybrid Beamforming System
authors: Andrés Pantoja, Carlos A. Viteri-Mera, Omar Valenzuela-Portilla, Angie Cuastumal-Ceballos
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: We implement a hybrid beamforming system prototype with a novel closed-loop phase control strategy. The system consists of two radio-frequency (RF) chains connected to an antenna, and two analog phase shifters. Unlike conventional open-loop architectures, the proposed method integrates a dual-layer estimator with a generalized proportional-integral observer (GPIO) and a Kalman filter to predict individual phase shifter states from a single aggregated phase measurement. This estimation is combined with a filtered Smith predictor to compensate delays introduced by signal processing during phase acquisition. Control strategies, including a typical baseline and the proposed predictive controller, are implemented and evaluated in MATLAB/Simulink on a real-time platform employing software-defined radios and a microcontroller-based data acquisition system. Experimental results show superior performance of the combined estimation and prediction framework in terms of steady-state error, noise attenuation, and tracking precision. These findings open a new direction for closed-loop control in hybrid RF beamforming, with potential applications in cost-efficient MIMO (multi-input multi-output) architectures.

title: Effective Localization Method for Autonomous Mobile Robot Using Ultrawideband Ranges
authors: Sy-Hung Bach
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Informatics (ICCRI)
abstract: Autonomous mobile robots (AMRs) are increasingly employed in various domains, including smart homes, smart factories, and smart hospitals, thereby creating a growing demand for accurate and cost-efficient localization solutions. This paper proposes a high-accuracy and cost-effective localization method for AMRs based solely on ultrawideband (UWB) ranging measurements. In contrast to conventional approaches that either estimate only position or rely on expensive sensor configurations, the proposed method enables a reliable estimation of both the AMR's position and heading angle using only distance measurements from two tags to fixed anchors. Simulation and experimental results validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, highlighting its strong potential for practical applications in indoor environments.

title: Federated Deep Learning for DDoS Detection in IoT: Case Studies, Challenges, and Practical Insights
authors: Prajwalasimha S N, Nilesh Shelke, Dilip Kumar Jang Bahadur Saini, Rajeshwar Balla, J. Sebastin Nixon, Amit Pimpalkar
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The growing intensity and complexity of Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks present vital security threats to Internet of Things (IoT) networks. Centralized solutions to DDoS detection are hampered by scalability, latency, and privacy issues, requiring decentralized and smart solutions. Federated Deep Learning (FDL) has emerged as a viable paradigm, facilitating collaborative model training without revealing raw data. This paper introduces a systematic case study-based investigation of FDL in IoT DDoS detection with a focus on its applications, challenges, and implications. We examine various case studies from a range of IoT environments industrial IoT, smart homes, and critical infrastructure and analyze how FDL is effective against developing attack patterns. Critical issues including heterogeneous data distribution, adversarial robustness, communication overhead, and real-time adaptability are examined and some solutions discussed. Our results reflect the excellence of FDL in providing high detection accuracy with maintained privacy and scalability. We also present future research directions in combining blockchain, reinforcement learning, and quantum computing to provide immunity to FDL-based DDoS detection systems. This research is a worthy reference for researchers as well as practitioners in promoting next-generation intelligent and decentralized IoT security architectures.

title: Moveless: Minimizing QEC Qverhead on QCCDS via Versatile Execution and Low Excess Shuttling
authors: Sahil Khan, Suhas Vittal, Kenneth Brown, Jonathan Baker
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: One of the most promising paths towards large scale fault tolerant quantum computation is the use of quantum error correcting codes. The majority of popular codes are stabilizer codes, in which error information is extracted via the repeated execution of a set of commuting stabilizer measurement circuits and then decoded. Just like every other quantum circuit, these circuits must be compiled to hardware in a way to minimize the total physical error introduced into the system, for example either due to high latency execution or excessive gates to meet connectivity limitations of the target hardware. However, unlike arbitrary quantum circuits, all syndrome extraction circuits have several common properties, for example they have a bipartite connectivity graph, consist only of commuting subcircuits, and have a set of ancilla which are indistinguishable between measurement rounds, among others. For the most part, compilation methods have aimed at being generic, able to map any input circuit into executables on the hardware, and therefore cannot appropriately exploit these properties and result in executables which have higher physical error. In the case of modular trapped ion systems, specifically QCCDs, this corresponds to the insertion of excessive shuttling operations necessary to realize arbitrary qubit interactions. We propose a compilation scheme explicitly tailored for the structural regularity of quantum error correction code physical circuits, with the primary objective of minimizing circuit latency from shuttling operations. Our compiler's success is predicated on several key observations: 1. only ancilla or data (but not both) should be shuttled, 2. stabilizers can be executed in any order meaning we can dynamically modify circuit execution on a per-cycle basis 3. ancilla are indistinguishable meaning any can be selected to begin a stabilizer measurement and since only ancilla are shuttled, we retain a fixed-point mapping between cycles, and 4. QCCD hardware limits the number of parallel operations equal to the number traps in the system bounding the rate of stabilizer measurement meaning fewer ancilla are necessary and can be easily reused. Our resulting compiler, leads to QEC circuits which are on average <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.38 \times$</tex> faster to execute (by up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.24 \times$</tex>) and therefore incur lower physical error. For codes with good decoders, e.g. the color code and surface code, these improvements lead to up to two orders of magnitude of improvement in logical error rates with realistic physical error rates.

title: Harnessing Deep Learning for Early Detection of Leaf Diseases in Diverse Crops of South Canara
authors: K Jothimani, Poojalakshmi, M Rajeshwari, Anirudha B G Somayaji
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Agriculture in the South Canara region plays a crucial role in the local economy, with various crops such as areca nuts, pepper, jackfruit, and cashew. Early detection of leaf diseases is essential to maintain crop yields and ensure sustainability despite the challenges posed by pests and climate change. This study employs advanced image processing techniques and evaluates multiple pre-trained convolutional neural network (CNN) models, including ResNet, VGG, and Inception, to identify leaf diseases at an early stage. Among these, ResNet demonstrated the highest accuracy, making it the most effective model for disease classification. The research also suggests appropriate treatments for diseased leaves and recommends suitable pesticides for healthy plants. In addition, class-wise performance variations were observed, highlighting the challenges of distinguishing visually similar diseases. Our objective is to establish a reliable system that empowers farmers through timely interventions, ultimately enhancing agricultural productivity in the region.

title: Solving Constrained Combinatorial Optimization Problems with Variational Quantum Imaginary Time Evolution
authors: Xin Wei Lee, Hoong Chuin Lau
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Solving combinatorial optimization problems using variational quantum algorithms (VQAs) has emerged as a promising research direction. Since the introduction of the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA), numerous variants have been proposed to enhance its performance. QAOA was later extended to the Quantum Alternating Operator Ansatz (QAOA+), which generalizes the initial state, phase-separation operator, and mixer to address constrained problems without relying on the standard Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO) formulation. However, QAOA+ often requires additional ancilla qubits and a large number of multi-controlled Toffoli gates to prepare the superposition of feasible states, resulting in deep circuits that are challenging for near-term quantum devices. Furthermore, VQAs are generally hindered by issues such as barren plateaus and suboptimal local minima. Recently, Quantum Imaginary Time Evolution (QITE), a groundstate preparation algorithm, has been explored as an alternative to QAOA and its variants. QITE has demonstrated improved performance in quantum chemistry problems and has been applied to unconstrained combinatorial problems such as MaxCut. In this work, we apply the variational form of QITE (VarQITE) to solve the Multiple Knapsack Problem (MKP), a constrained problem, using a Max-Cut-tailored ansatz. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first attempt to address constrained optimization using VarQITE. We show that VarQITE achieves significantly lower mean optimality gaps compared to QAOA and other conventional methods. Moreover, we demonstrate that scaling the Hamiltonian coefficients can further reduce optimization costs and accelerate convergence.

title: Orbital-Rotated Fermi-Hubbard Model as a Benchmarking Problem for Quantum Chemistry with the Exact Solution
authors: Ryota Kojima, Masahiko Kamoshita, Keita Kanno
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum chemistry is a key target for quantum computing, but benchmarking quantum algorithms for large molecular systems remains challenging due to the lack of exactly solvable yet structurally realistic models. In particular, molecular Hamiltonians typically contain <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$O\left(N^{4}\right)$</tex> Pauli terms, significantly increasing the cost of quantum simulations, while many exactly solvable models, such as the one-dimensional Fermi-Hubbard (1D FH) model, contain only <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$O(N)$</tex> terms. In this work, we introduce the orbital-rotated Fermi-Hubbard (ORFH) model as a scalable and exactly solvable benchmarking problem for quantum chemistry algorithms. Starting from the 1D FH model, we apply a spin-involved orbital rotation to construct a Hamiltonian that retains the exact ground-state energy but exhibits a Pauli term count scaling as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$O\left(N^{4}\right)$</tex>, similar to real molecular systems. We analyze the ORFH Hamiltonian from multiple perspectives, including operator norm and electronic correlation. We benchmark variational quantum eigensolver (VQE) optimizers and Pauli term grouping methods, and compare their performance with those for hydrogen chains. Furthermore, we show that the ORFH Hamiltonian increases the computational difficulty for classical methods such as the density matrix renormalization group (DMRG), offering a nontrivial benchmark beyond quantum algorithms. Our results demonstrate that the ORFH model provides a versatile and scalable testbed for benchmarking quantum chemistry algorithms under realistic structural conditions, while maintaining exact solvability even at large system sizes.

title: From Chaos to Security: Quantum Image Encryption in the Age of Cyber Threats
authors: Alireza Rezaei
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: Quantum computing poses an unparalleled threat to the conventional methodologies of image encryption through its capability for mathematical-based security breaking. This paper discusses the integration of chaos theory with quantum mechanics in the development of robust algorithms for image encryption, considering the inherent vulnerabilities of classical approaches. We start with the basics of chaos theory and its implications in cryptography, emphasizing sensitivity regarding initial conditions and the unpredictability of chaotic systems. Then, we reviewed some of the existing quantum image encryption techniques and their limitations. Our analysis elucidates the potential of chaos-driven quantum algorithms for key generation and image scrambling to enhance security metrics such as key sensitivity, entropy, and unpredictability. We further discuss the performance of such algorithms in resistance against different attack vectors and their application domains, including healthcare, military, and digital rights management. The paper concludes by pointing out the directions of future research, hence calling for further development of sophisticated chaotic maps to integrate them into practical quantum image encryption solutions. The study points out that chaos-based quantum image encryption has strong potential to defend against evolving cyber threats.

title: Understanding the Affective, Perceptual, and Analytical Learning Outcomes for Undergraduate Engineering Ethics Pedagogy
authors: Minha R. Ha, Shaimaa Ali
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: Engineering ethics education aims to equip engineering students with a diverse set of skills and attributes to addresses complex ethical challenges that arise in engineering work. The targeted competencies in the literature effectively shift the focus from individualistic, rationalistic view of engineer behaviours to the distributed influence from multiple actors on decisions that enhance or hinder ethical engineering. However, there is room to articulate and develop student competencies in synthesizing knowledge and recommendations regarding the impact of engineering, in order to inform decisions towards ethical engineering. To facilitate student reflections, improve the course, and examine the developmental journeys of engineering students completing a course in engineering ethics, an online survey was administered. Data included students' conceptualizations of an engineer's responsibility, descriptions of key motivators and expectations related to the being an ethical engineer, the descriptions of self-recognized changes that were most meaningful, the sequence of such changes and their connection to the course elements. As an example of using empirical data to test and ground the pedagogical assumptions and learning theories in engineering ethics education. Thematic analysis of perspective and ability changes point to potential threshold concepts unique to engineering ethics teaching and learning. Implications for teaching and further studies of threshold concepts are discussed.

title: How Gender Shapes Career Choices: A Study of High School Students in Japan
authors: Yutaro Ohashi, May Kristine Jonson Carlon, Jeffrey S. Cross
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: Despite a strong push from the government to encourage female high school students to enroll in university STEM courses, Japan is still woefully lagging behind in terms of women participation in STEM. This study investigates factors influencing career decisions among Japanese high school students, focusing on gender differences and the under-explored roles of digital media and family economic situation. A questionnaire survey conducted in 2023 with 107 male and 108 female students revealed significant gender disparities. Females showed a stronger preference for vocational schools and nursing fields, while males leaned towards science, engineering, and agriculture. Notably, female students were more significantly influenced by digital media (e.g., SNS, websites) for career research compared to males. Furthermore, household finances emerged as a more critical influencing factor for female students, with some citing economic reasons for their career paths or selecting public universities due to family financial burdens. Parental influence also varied, with mothers having a stronger impact on daughters, sometimes even dissuading them from STEM careers. These findings underscore the necessity of comprehensive interventions considering financial support, digital media's role, and gender attitudes within families and society to foster informed career choices, especially for promoting female participation in STEM fields.

title: Pixel - Perfect Blood Typing: Revolutionizing Detection with Deep Learning
authors: S. Kavitha, J.V. Anchitaalagammai, S. Murali, K Sudharshini, S Zahara Hashmi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Blood typing is a practical medical diagnostic tool, previously dependent on invasive analysis and costly hardware. In this work, we present a new non-invasive blood typing technology based on a deep learning and image processing framework that is both accurate and convenient. The process uses near-infrared light to capture Photoplethysmography (PPG) signals, which are analyzed using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to identify blood groups with 96% accuracy. The technique offers a low-cost, scalable, and portable alternative, suitable for resource-limited clinical settings. While the result suggests a promising alternative to traditional methods, variations in PPG signals and variability in datasets need to be further explored to make it more reliable. By minimizing these variables, this study assists in the development of efficient, AI-based, non-invasive blood typing technology, which can result in effective point-of-care diagnosis.

title: Fraudulent Firm Classification in External Financial Audits using Machine Learning
authors: Satish Bhambri, Arun Kumar, Ravi Patneedi, Mrinal Chaudhary
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: This study investigates the application of machine learning techniques to classify fraudulent firms in external audits, addressing the increasing complexity of financial fraud detection. The novelty lies in the integration of Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) for feature selection and the evaluation of ten state-of-theart classifiers, including J48 and Bayes Net, using comprehensive performance metrics such as accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and AUC. Data from 989 firms across 14 sectors were analyzed. The results demonstrate that J48 and Bayes Net achieved the highest accuracy (94%) and robust sensitivity (91%), highlighting their effectiveness in fraud detection. This research contributes to audit planning by proposing a decision-support framework that optimizes resource allocation and enhances fraud detection efficiency. Future work will focus on ensemble methods and big data technologies to further improve scalability and applicability.

title: Comparison between Semantic(Rules-Based) Query and Keyword Based Query in Neo4j Graph Database
authors: Nang Nandar Tun, Nyo Nyo Yee
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Culture holds a significant place within a nation, and the people of Myanmar possess a unique culture and rich literary tradition. In today’s information era, the ability to comprehend and extract relevant data is crucial. Information Retrieval (IR) helps users find information matching their needs efficiently. Traditional keyword-based queries often fail to capture semantic meaning, leading to inaccurate results. Semantic queries, leveraging rule-based conversion, provide enhanced accuracy by analyzing relationships between words and concepts. This paper compares the accuracy of semantic query (rules-based conversion) and keyword-based query results in the Neo4j graph database, using Myanmar’s cultural heritage as a case study. The system, developed in PHP, integrates Stanford NLP for POS tagging, cosine similarity for pattern matching, and a structured rule set for semantic processing. The study evaluates 60 test queries, demonstrating a $99 \%$ accuracy rate for semantic queries compared to $69 \%$ for keyword-based queries. These findings highlight the benefits of semantic search over traditional keyword-based approaches, particularly for structured data retrieval in graph databases. The proposed approach is scalable for enterprise applications, supporting dynamic rule expansion and real-time query processing.

title: Local Optimization of Quantum Circuits
authors: Jatin Arora, Mingkuan Xu, Sam Westrick, Pengyu Liu, Dantong Li, Yongshan Ding, Umut A. Acar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Recent advances in quantum architectures and computing have motivated the development of new optimizing compilers for quantum programs or circuits. Even though steady progress has been made, existing quantum optimization techniques remain asymptotically and practically inefficient. Because many global quantum circuit optimization problems belong to the complexity class QMA (the quantum analog of NP) [51], it is not clear whether efficiency guarantees can be achieved. In this paper, we present an algorithm that achieves efficiency by aiming at a form of local optimality rather than global optimality. Our local-optimization algorithm cuts a circuit into subcircuits, optimizes each subcircuit with the specified oracle optimizer, and melds the subcircuits by optimizing across the cuts lazily as needed. To prove efficiency, we show that, under some assumptions, the main optimization phase of the algorithm requires a linear number of calls to the oracle optimizer. Our empirical results show that our local-optimization algorithm can outperform existing optimizers significantly, by more than an order of magnitude on average. Perhaps surprisingly, the algorithm achieves these improvements without noticeable degradation in optimization quality. These results show that local optimization can be effective for optimizing quantum circuits.

title: AutoFairML: An Automated Middleware for Fairness Auditing in Real-world AI Pipelines
authors: Dimitrios Tomaras, Vana Kalogeraki, Christos Varytimidis, Evangelos Anagnostopoulos, Rahul Nair, Elizabeth M. Daly, Jakub Marecek, Dimitrios Gunopulos
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: The great proliferation of Artificial Intelligence in a wide variety of application domains has produced an imminent need to interpret the output of such models, especially for evaluating their fairness. Such domains may include human resources management for evaluating individual and group fairness, advertising and financial technologies, where fairness can have significant impact. However, existing tools like AIF360 and AIX360, although important for helping practitioners in industrial AI pipelines, have significant shortcomings. Such tools suffer from poor scalability and developers cannot directly benefit from, since there is no middleware available to support and take advantage of modern AI infrastructures. In this work, we present AutoFairML, an automated middleware able to leverage existing tools to detect bias in AI/ML models, examine trade-offs between different measures of fairness, certify their fairness a priori and provide explanations for the models. This represents a significant improvement in the usability and the real-world applicability of specialized fairness and explainability toolkits such as AIF360 and AIX360. Our experimental evaluation using real-world pipelines and data highlights its merits in terms of practicality and efficiency.

title: 5G-Integrated Data Dissemination and Multi Interface Communication Architecture for Enhanced VANETs
authors: S Maheswari, Shaik Javed Parvez, V. Seedha Devi, T. Anuradha, C. K. Snruthi, A Jose Anand
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: In the realm of Vehicular Ad-hoc Networks (VANETs), the integration of $\mathbf{5 G}$ technology has been explored to enhance data dissemination and network performance. Previous studies have introduced various approaches, such as authentication-based protocols and clustering techniques, to improve security and efficiency in 5G-enabled VANETs. For instance, an Authentication-based Medium Access Control (AMAC) protocol was proposed to ensure privacy and reliability in vehicular communications. Additionally, clustering methods have been employed to manage data dissemination effectively in dynamic vehicular environments. The current study advances these developments by proposing a novel data dissemination approach that leverages vehicle characteristics, trajectory estimation, and collision avoidance mechanisms. This approach is further enhanced by integrating 5G communication technology and implementing a multi-interface architecture with a best-interface selection algorithm. The use of the OMNeT++ simulator demonstrates that this combination not only improves data reliability and dissemination efficiency but also addresses potential single points of failure in Vehicle-to-Infrastructure (V2I) communication. This holistic strategy contributes to the development of more robust and eco-friendlier VANETs, offering innovative solutions to enhance Intelligent Transport Systems (ITS) for safer and more efficient transportation.

title: Design of Neural Network Accelerator Based on Phase-Change Memory
authors: Jingrui Wang, Hongmei Xu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: With the rapid development of deep learning technologies, the computational complexity and data storage requirements of neural network models have surged dramatically. The “memory wall” problem caused by the separation of computation and storage in the traditional von Neumann architecture has become increasingly prominent, severely restricting the performance and energy efficiency of neural network accelerators. As a novel non-volatile memory technology, Phase Change Memory (PCM) features high storage integration, low power consumption, and high-speed read/write capabilities, offering a new approach to addressing the aforementioned challenges. This paper employs the LeNet-5 convolutional neural network model to conduct multi-dimensional performance tests between PCM and traditional DRAM architectures. The designed configurable convolution kernel module (fil_core) consists of four major components: multiply-accumulate operations, storage arrays, control logic, and accumulators. Experimental results demonstrate that compared with the traditional DDR architecture, the PCM accelerator exhibits significant advantages in key metrics such as operation time and power consumption.

title: The Innovative Method for Analyzing Package Protectability with Ball-on-Ring and Ball-on-Plate
authors: Yi-Chen Wang, Milly Lin, Mike Chiang, Jun-Cheng Liao, Jim Faull, Chong-Leong Gan, Cyane Tsai
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: The objective of this research is to devise a methodology to combine the electrical and mechanical test to enhance the sensitivity of the traditional mechanical test and check the protectability of a package to the chips. The inception of this research begins with the issue of the substrate (SBT) found dent cases that have the failure mode showing the BE (backend) package electrical test failure. The failure analysis shows the package has a dent on SBT and no package crack. However, the chip, which is presumed to be protected by the packaging, and the bottom die already exhibited a crack situation that resulted in the electrical failure. This means that the die crack is more sensitive to external force than the package crack, and the normal package strength test which tests the package and shows a crack, would not be suitable for simulating the real SBT dent failure cases, since the die will break prior to the package breaks although the dies are protected by package molding and SBT. Therefore, to simulate and check how the die is protected by the package rather than just check the package strength, a new method will be needed. To simulate the real failure mode, Ball-on-Ring (BOR) and Ball-on-Plate (BOP) tests were adopted in this work for inducing different stress types and be capable of doing the electrical test. Failure analysis and virtual simulation were applied to validate BOR and BOP to see which was close to the real failure and selected as the main evaluation method. In this study, an innovative method that combined physical and electrical tests was performed to investigate the package protectability to die based on the BOR and BOP methods. This novel method will help provide a quantitative result for estimation and assess the correlated issues on similar package products in the future.

title: Remote Health Monitoring System with AI Analysis
authors: S. Suhasini, Sterlin Rani D, Jaiganesh D, Kruthick M S, Deepak Chowdary K
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The demand for continuous and reliable patient monitoring has intensified with the growing need for timely healthcare interventions. Conventional monitoring methods often cause delays in detecting abnormalities, resulting in higher health risks. To address these limitations, this paper presents an advanced AI-driven patient monitoring system that integrates temperature, heart rate, near-infrared (NIR), and respiration sensors for continuous assessment of vital parameters. A novel digital twin framework is developed to generate a virtual representation of the patient’s health status, enabling dynamic tracking and predictive health risk evaluation. Experimental validation demonstrates that the proposed system achieves accurate real-time monitoring with over detection accuracy and successfully predicts early risk conditions, reducing intervention delays by compared to traditional methods. The system provides intuitive, color-coded health indicators green (stable), yellow (caution), and red (risk) facilitating quick decision-making by both patients and healthcare providers. These outcomes highlight the significance of integrating AI and digital twins in proactive health management, offering a scalable, personalized, and efficient solution that improves patient outcomes and supports data-driven clinical decisions.

title: LLM Safety and Context Fallacies
authors: Shaun Feakins, Ibrahim Habli, Phillip Morgan
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: This position paper argues that the assurance of LLMs is particularly prone to a ‘Context Fallacy'. We define the context fallacy as the assumption or presumption that practices that hold true for different contexts - either time or operational contexts - can, will or do apply to LLMs. We introduce examples of the context fallacy and briefly suggest future research directions to ameliorate this issue.

title: Quantum Circuit Design for Decoded Quantum Interferometry
authors: Natchapol Patamawisut, Naphan Benchasattabuse, Michal Hajdušek, Rodney Van Meter
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Decoded Quantum Interferometry (DQI) is a recently proposed quantum algorithm for approximating solutions to combinatorial optimization problems by reducing instances of linear satisfiability to bounded-distance decoding over superpositions of quantum states. A central challenge in realizing DQI is the design of a decoder that operates coherently on quantum superpositions. In this work, we present a concrete quantum circuit implementation of DQI, with a focus on the decoding subroutine. Our design leverages a reversible Gauss-Jordan elimination circuit for the decoding stage. We analyze the circuit's depth and gate complexity and validate its performance through simulations on systems with up to 30 qubits. These results establish a concrete foundation for scalable implementations of DQI and open the door to future algorithmic refinements and hardware-level realizations.

title: Implementing Slack-Free Custom Penalty Function for QUBO on Gate-Based Quantum Computers
authors: Xin Wei Lee, Hoong Chuin Lau
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Solving NP-hard constrained combinatorial optimization problems using quantum algorithms remains a challenging yet promising avenue toward quantum advantage. Variational Quantum Algorithms (VQAs), such as the Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE), typically require constrained problems to be reformulated as unconstrained ones using penalty methods. A common approach introduces slack variables and quadratic penalties in the QUBO formulation to handle inequality constraints. However, this leads to increased qubit requirements and often distorts the optimization landscape, making it harder to find high-quality feasible solutions. To address these issues, we explore a slack-free formulation that directly encodes inequality constraints using custom penalty functions, specifically the exponential function and the Heaviside step function. These steplike penalties suppress infeasible solutions without introducing additional qubits or requiring finely tuned weights. Inspired by recent developments in quantum annealing and thresholdbased constraint handling in gate-based algorithms, we implement and evaluate our approach on the Multiple Knapsack Problem (MKP). Experimental results show that the step-based formulation significantly improves feasibility and optimality rates compared to unbalanced penalization, while reducing overall qubit overhead.

title: An Efficient Approach for the Classification of Brain Tumor Using Region Attention-based Dilated Densenet Strategy
authors: K C Manoj, D. Anto Sahaya Dhas
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Brain and nerve-related cancers are one of the main death causes of cancer worldwide. The abnormal cell growth affects the functioning of the neurological system and it frequently creates severe health issues. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is a commonly utilized approach for diagnosing these brain tumors, yet evaluating MRI by medical experts faces challenges because of variations in time constraints. It is more challenging to automatically identify the types of brain tumor due to the complexity of shape, texture, variability, size, and location of lesions. Classifying brain tumor types from the MRI is also crucial in conventional methods. Hence, an efficient deep learning-based classification scheme for the recognition of brain tumor types is implemented to solve these difficulties. The relevant MRI images are gathered from the relevant database, which provides detailed information on brain structures. Collected images are fed to the Region Attention-based Dilated DenseNet (RA-DD) network to categorize the brain tumors. DenseNet architecture helps in capturing complex patterns in MRI images of brain tumors. By integrating attention mechanisms and dilated convolution with DenseNet, the proposed model achieves higher classification accuracy for diverse brain tumor types. Finally, the classification performance of the implemented approach is evaluated and the capability of the classification approach is validated with existing baseline models.

title: HB-YOLO: A Multi-Scale Detection Model for Maize Pests in Complex Agricultural Environments
authors: Jiahai Dai, Huimin Li, Jing Zhang, Hongwei Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Accurate maize pest detection is essential for sustainable crop management. However, existing detectors struggle with significant scale variations and complex backgrounds in field conditions. To address these challenges, we propose HB-YOLO, an enhanced YOLOv8n-based framework. Specifically, a Hybrid Convolutional-ECA Block (HCE-Block) is introduced to improve multi-scale feature extraction and suppress background interference via parallel convolutions with diverse receptive fields and Efficient Channel Attention. Additionally, a Bidirectional Selective Feature Pyramid Network (Bi-SFPN) strengthens multi-level feature fusion through bidirectional crossscale interactions and adaptive channel selection, refining semantic and spatial representations. Extensive experiments show that HB-YOLO achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$93.5 \% \text{mAP} {@} 0.5$</tex> on the self-built MaizePest-6 dataset, outperforming YOLOv8n by 2.5 %, while reducing parameters by 23.3 %. On the IP102 benchmark, it further achieves improvements of 3.6 % in both <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{mAP} {@} 0.5$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{m A P} {@} 0.75$</tex>, highlighting its superior robustness and generalizability for practical pest monitoring applications.

title: Deep Learning-based Early Lung Cancer Detection using AlexNet
authors: Vayyana Sankar C, S. Sudha
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Lung cancer remains one of the number one killers among cancer diseases, and it has barely been diagnosed early anywhere in the world. The most important factor for a patient’s survival is early and accurate diagnosis. Collaborative efforts between humans and AI, especially with the employment of machine learners and deep neural networks, have registered remarkable success in medical image analysis for lung cancer detection from CT scans. The paper outlines a deep learning model that relies on AlexNet (a famous convolutional neural network) to classify CT images of smoker lungs as cancerous or non-cancerous. In the suggested technique, after the images go through the preprocessing stage, i.e. including resizing and grayscale conversion, AlexNet then classifies them. Carrying out a set of parallel tests with Logistic Regression, Random Forest Classifier, and LightGBM were the classical machine learning models utilized. The gist of the experimental results which AlexNet achieved the highest accuracy of [insert value] % and the lowest error rate compared with other models is given. The human–AI systems like AlexNet are the perfect carriages for the action of faster, reliable, and non-invasive lung cancer detection. Moreover, the research highlights the synergy of human–AI as a leading force in cancer diagnosis and screening innovations.

title: Pulse-Level Simulation of Crosstalk Attacks on Superconducting Quantum Hardware
authors: Syed Emad Uddin Shubha, Tasnuva Farheen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Hardware crosstalk in multi-tenant superconducting quantum computers poses a severe security threat, allowing adversaries to induce targeted errors across tenant boundaries by injecting carefully engineered pulses. We present a simulation-based study of active crosstalk attacks at the pulse level, analyzing how adversarial control of pulse timing, shape, amplitude, and coupling can disrupt a victim's computation. Our framework models the time-dependent dynamics of a three-qubit system in the rotating frame, capturing both always-on couplings and injected drive pulses. We examine two attack strategies: attacker-first (pulse before victim operation) and victim-first (pulse after), and systematically identify the pulse and coupling configurations that cause the largest logical errors. Protocol-level experiments on quantum coin flip and XOR classification circuits show that some protocols are highly vulnerable to these attacks, while others remain robust. Based on these findings, we discuss practical methods for detection and mitigation to improve security in quantum cloud platforms.

title: Insulator Detection Incorporating Pruning Technology
authors: Shengpan Gao, Xin An
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Due to the high distance of overhead transmission lines from the ground, it is difficult for inspection personnel to accurately judge the operating status of insulators relying solely on the naked eye and experience, with the possibility of missed inspections and false inspections, resulting in low work efficiency. An insulator defect detection algorithm integrating pruning technology is proposed, and the original detection head is replaced with the LSCD-LQE detection head to improve the detection accuracy of the model. The LAMP pruning algorithm is used to prune the model, removing redundant channel information, further reducing the number of parameters and computational load, and compressing the model size. Experimental results on the UPID dataset show that, compared with the baseline model YOLOv10s, the improved model achieves a 1.1% increase in the mAP50 metric, with the number of parameters reduced by 33.8% and the floating-point operations decreased by 67%. Therefore, this model is fully capable of meeting the practical application and deployment requirements for transmission line inspection.

title: AI-Native Joint Communication and Computation in 6G Networks and Beyond
authors: Aydin Sezgin, Hayssam Dahrouj, Robert-Jeron Reifert
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: This tutorial provides a broad vision of artificial intelligence (AI)-native joint communication and computation for the sixth generation of wireless networks (6 G) and beyond, emphasizing the integration of AI into modeling, resource allocation, and decentralized management. We begin by revisiting traditional radio access network (RAN) architectures, cloud/edge architectures, and multi-cloud networks so as to establish the foundational system model of the networks under consideration. Building on this foundation, we define a joint communication and computation provisioning architecture for next-generation wireless networks. Focusing on multi-tier computing, we then explore how AI-driven decision-making enhances latency-sensitive applications across the cloud-edge continuum, by shedding light on timely multiple access mechanisms, e.g., rate-splitting multiple access (RSMA) and cooperative non-orthogonal multiple access (Co-NOMA). Such a cross-layer approach is especially poised to enable distributed intelligence, laying the groundwork for end-to-end AI in communication and computation. The tutorial afterward examines the synergistic benefits of AI-native hybrid networks, focusing on joint and distributed resource allocation schemes. The tutorial progresses from a single-cell deep learning framework for robust delay minimization to a multi-cell interference-limited setting, ultimately leading to a federated learning approach for distributed resource management. Throughout the tutorial, we provide comprehensive modeling, analysis, and optimization of the exemplified multi-tier networks, addressing their applications, enabling technologies, and the mathematical methodologies required for their systematic design. A major highlight of this tutorial is the crucial role of AI in spearheading joint communication and computation resource management toward seamlessly enabling future decentralized 6G networks and beyond.

title: Value Stream Mapping & Discrete Event Simulation in a Learning Factory: An Education 5.0 Approach to Teach Digital Lean Manufacturing Principles
authors: Pablo Segura, Erick Ramírez-Cedillo, David Romero, Russel Bradley, Ciro A. Rodriguez, Brian Anthony
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: This paper presents an Education 5.0 strategy that integrates Value Stream Mapping and Discrete Event Simulation within a Learning Factory environment to enhance the teaching of Digital Lean Manufacturing principles. By analyzing the case of the FrED Factory, a dedicated learning factory to produce a custom low-cost extrusion system, students were able to simulate production processes, identify sources of waste, and evaluate system performance considering real-world issues. This approach fosters a holistic, digital, and data-driven mindset in engineering students, equipping them with the digital and analytical skills needed to manage modern manufacturing systems in alignment with Industry 5.0 objectives.

title: Is Digital Fault Sensor Secure Against Multiple Fault Injection?: A Case Study on Ro-Based LFI Sensor Against Double-Spot Laser Attack
authors: Shungo Hayashi, Junichi Sakamoto, Tsutomu Matsumoto
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: Laser fault injection (LFI) is known as the most powerful fault attack due to its high precision and repeatability. Building sensor circuits on IC chips is one of the promising countermeasures to protect assets inside the IC chips from LFI. We focus on digital LFI sensors that can be built using only logic circuits. Digital LFI sensors indirectly monitor analog quantities such as voltage and temperature, which are perturbed by laser irradiation, via the signal delay fluctuation, and it has the advantage that it's easy to design and calibrate since it's completely composed of digital circuits such as ring oscillators. While sensors are a promising approach to countermeasures, their evaluation against multiple fault injection is still immature. This paper proposes a disturbance concealment attack (DCA) on digital LFI sensors, which prevents digital LFI sensors from detecting attacks using a dual-spot laser. The DCA analogously cancels the signal delay disturbance of one LFI by using the second LFI. We experimentally demonstrated that the proposed attack reduces the laser detection rate of a digital LFI sensor to 26.6% and completely disables the sensor at some irradiation points. We also discuss the generality of the proposed method and its possible countermeasures.

title: From Ideal to Noisy: Adapting Property-Based Testing for Real-World Noisy Quantum Computers
authors: Gabriel Pontolillo, Asmar Muqeet, Shaukat Ali, Mohammad Reza Mousavi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum software testing is essential for the quality assurance of quantum programs. However, existing techniques face many challenges, such as constructing test oracles and distinguishing genuine faults from noise-induced errors.
