Propertybased testing is a promising solution for dealing with the test oracle issue, which verifies general properties rather than requiring inputs and outputs. However, its effectiveness in noisy quantum environments has not been studied. To this end, we evaluate the feasibility of applying property-based testing in noisy quantum computers by integrating it with a state-of-the-art machine learning-based noise mitigation method called QOIN. Our results show that on average, QOIN mitigates noise for individual circuits, though it may introduce outliers. Crucially, this does not guarantee property preservation: we show that some properties align better with QOIN, while others remain closer under unmitigated noise. To address this, we apply a hybrid approach that selectively applies QOIN during property-based testing. We show that this hybrid approach improves alignment with the ideal execution and significantly reduces false positives in assertion outcomes across most executed mutants. This provides a solid foundation for applying property-based testing to noisy quantum systems.

title: Optimization of HVAC (Heating Ventilation and Air Conditioning Systems) using Machine Learning
authors: Manisha Kishor Bhole, Pankaj Hiraman Zope, Poonam J. Patil
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: HVAC system is one of the largest contributors to building total energy consumption with both high cost and sustainability concerns. HVAC systems are responsible for indoor thermal comfort provision and indoor air quality provision but through their traditional control techniques—rule-based, and model-based control strategies that are not capable of addressing the complexity and dynamics of real building environments. The shortcoming of these approaches causes inefficiencies, excessive energy consumption, and suboptimal control performance. Introduce a model-based Reinforcement Learning (RL) method that combines a neural network-based system approximation with Model Predictive Control (MPC). Our approach learns the internal system dynamics of the HVAC system with a neural network and then applies MPC with a random-sampling shooting method to learn optimal control policies. With a learned model instead of direct interaction, our method dramatically decreases the number of training samples needed for convergence. In addition, impose safety constraints by limiting control actions to within pre-defined safe ranges and bounding rapid changes using prior knowledge to ensure stable and reliable system behavior. Validate our suggested method using Energy Plus, a widely used building energy simulation software, on a two-zone data center case study. Our findings confirm the feasibility of model-based reinforcement learning for intelligent HVAC control, with energy savings, enhanced efficiency, and enhanced safety on actual building applications.

title: Artificial Intelligence and Radar-Enhanced Audio-Visual Speech Recognition for the Next Generation of Communication Technologies
authors: Nour Ghadban, Hira Hammed, Elem Miranda, Mostafa Elsayed, Qammer H. Abbasi, Muhammad Ali Imran, Julien Reboud, Jonathan Cooper, Julien Le Kernec
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Integrating advanced AI and speech recognition technologies is crucial for effective human-device communication. This research introduces a novel approach combining radar with audio-visual sensors, enhancing current capabilities. Using radar for subtle facial motion cues and AI-driven feature selection improves data processing and system efficiency. This integration boosts speech recognition accuracy, inference time, and reliability while enhancing human-device interface responsiveness. Experimental evaluations show the radar-enhanced system achieves an inference time of 25.623 milliseconds and $87.2 \%$ accuracy, surpassing existing methods. This advancement marks a new era in communication technologies, enabling next-generation systems with unmatched efficiency, precision, and user engagement across applications. This work highlights AI and radar-enhanced technologies’ transformative potential in reshaping human-device interaction.

title: Reconfiguration of Applications in Cloud-Edge Multi-Clusters
authors: Marta Patiño-Martínez, Ainhoa Azqueta-Alzúaz, Aitor Agirre
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Edge computing is used today to implement many industrial applications, such as augmented reality, healthcare, and autonomous vehicles. Part of an application runs in the cloud to compute aggregated values coming from different edge devices or to perform some processing that cannot be executed at the edge due to the usage of resource-constrained devices at the edge. This computing model in which an application is distributed in several heterogeneous clusters is also known as the computing continuum. The computing continuum poses several challenges such as device heterogeneity, communication overhead and data movement needs, orchestration and adaptation, among others being the distributed execution of applications in this set-up a challenge itself. Node failures, cluster failures, lack of connectivity and resources are common problems. In this paper, we analyze the behavior of one popular Kubernetes multi-cluster framework, Karmada, during reconfiguration due to cluster failures or lack of resources, which parameters can be configured and how applications are reconfigured and the overhead of the reconfiguration.

title: Feature Selection of Scattering Coefficients for Water Leakage Classification: mRMR Vs ANOVA
authors: Erick Axel Martinez-Ríos, Rogelio Bustamante
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Image and Signal Processing and Analysis (ISPA)
abstract: Detecting water leakages is crucial to prevent water loss, scarcity, and contamination. Early detection is challenging due to dynamic water consumption, sensor uncertainty, and underground pipe networks. Machine learning has been widely applied for leak detection using two main approaches: feature extraction and deep learning. Feature extraction requires expert knowledge or trial and error, while deep learning demands large datasets, extensive training, and high computational resources. The wavelet scattering transform offers features for classification by producing a time-shift invariant and deformation-stable signal representation, reducing within-class variance. However, it can generate numerous coefficients, complicating classifiers, and lacks established parameter-setting guidelines. This work uses vibration data transformed via the wavelet scattering transform and selects features for water leakage classification in looped and branched networks. Two feature selection methods, oneway analysis of variance and minimum redundancy maximum relevance, were compared. The ten most important features from each method were trained on a support vector machine. Results show that variance-based selection yields higher accuracy for the looped network (88.75 percent), while both methods achieve 96.25 percent for the branched network.

title: Blockchain-Assisted Secure IoT Transmission using Homomorphic Encryption and Distributed Consensus
authors: Anguraju Krishnan, Rajesh Arunachalam
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The speedy development of the Internet of Things (IoT) needs safe and efficient and scalable data transmission systems that can resist privacy violation and inefficiency within the network. The paper introduces a blockchain-based IoT transmission framework that inculcates Paillier Homomorphic Encryption (PHE) to end-to-end data transmission security as well as Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT) consensus mechanism as a low-latency trust establishment methodology. The model has been written in Python and tested with the Intel Lab IoT Sensor Dataset. The proposed system has an average success rate in secure data encryption of up to 99.97 percent and acceptable percentages of bit error with tolerance limits on all packet lengths (1 KB and above) as depicted in experimental results, thus with low computation needs (3.2 ms encryption, 3.4 ms decryption) and moderate memory consumption (120 KB). The network performance analysis proves that smaller block sizes (5 KB) provide 245 Tx/s throughput using 0.2 J energy, thus, being utilized in real-time IoT operation. PBFT protocol achieves high levels of latency (90 ms) and finality (1.1 s) reduction than the Proof-of-Work and Proof-of-Stake, and uses up to 96 percent less energy than PoW. Using homomorphic encryption with lightweight consensus is a good compromise between security, scalability, and achievable energy efficiency that fits well in next-generation IoT deployments where trust, privacy, and performance are of utmost importance.

title: On the Impact of Classical and Quantum Communication Networks Upon Modular Quantum Computing Architecture System Performance
authors: Pau Escofet, Abhijit Das, Sahar Ben Rached, Santiago Rodrigo, Jordi Domingo, Fabio Sebastiano, Masoud Babaie, Batuhan Keskin, Edoardo Charbon, Peter Haring Bolívar, Maurizio Palesi, Elena Blokhina, Bogdan Staszewski, Avishek Nag, Artur Garcia-Sáez, Sergi Abadal, Eduard Alarcón, Carmen G. Almudéver
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Modular architectures are a promising approach to scaling quantum computers beyond the limits of monolithic designs. However, non-local communications between different quantum processors might significantly impact overall system performance. In this work, we investigate the role of the network infrastructure in modular quantum computing architectures, focusing on coherence loss due to communication constraints. We analyze the impact of classical network latency on quantum teleportation and identify conditions under which it becomes a bottleneck. Additionally, we study different network topologies and assess how communication resources affect the number and parallelization of inter-core communications. Finally, we conduct a full-stack evaluation of the architecture under varying communication parameters, demonstrating how these factors influence the overall system performance. The results show that classical communication does not become a bottleneck for systems exceeding one million qubits, given current technology assumptions, even with modest clock frequencies and parallel wired interconnects. Additionally, increasing quantum communication resources generally shortens execution time, although it may introduce additional communication overhead. The optimal number of quantum links between QCores depends on both the algorithm being executed and the chosen inter-core topology. Our findings offer valuable guidance for designing modular architectures, enabling scalable quantum computing.

title: Localization Method for Flash Failure Using Non-Destructive Backside Analysis
authors: Noor Iza Atiqah Supaat, Azizul Hakem Zulkifli, Liew Chik Hooi
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: In Failure Analysis (FA), there are various failure types and fault isolation techniques. Most of the functional type of failures consists of cases such as Scan, Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC), flash, Static Random Access Memory (SRAM), timing and etcetera. This technical paper will focus on Non-Volatile Memory (NVM) flash failure to discover localization method for the failure using non-destructive backside analysis. This paper will also focus on the challenges associated with failure analysis techniques used to precisely locate failure sites, particularly in terms of reducing overall effort and time. Additionally, it will address the risks introduced by the repackaging process, which is intended to save time and reduce the complexity of physical failure analysis. Several case studies presented in this paper illustrate how backside analysis conducted during the Electrical Failure Analysis (EFA) phase contributes to effective defect localization within the semiconductor device.

title: The Future of Quantum Computing for Energy Geosciences
authors: Divakar Vashisth, Rohan Sharma, Tapan Mukerji, Mrinal K. Sen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The computational demands of geoscientific workflows are rapidly increasing in both complexity and scale, pushing the limits of classical computing. Quantum computing has emerged as a promising paradigm to address some of these challenges. This paper surveys the growing intersection between quantum computing and energy geosciences, highlighting recent developments and initiatives. To illustrate the practical relevance of this emerging field, we present a case study on seismic traveltime inversion using a variational quantum circuit. In this example, a hybrid quantum-classical workflow is used to reconstruct velocity models from noisy traveltime data, demonstrating how quantum circuits can solve geophysical inverse problems. While modest in scale, the study offers insights into the formulation and implementation of quantumassisted inversion. As quantum hardware advances and algorithmic frameworks mature, quantum computing is poised to become a transformative tool in the computational landscape of energy geosciences.

title: Skin AI - Virtual Dermatologist
authors: Kandi Jyothsna, V. Sai Vinay Reddy, D. Lokesh, D. Krishna Chaitanya, K. Sivakrishna, L. Priyanka
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Skin cancer accounts for millions of diagnoses every year and is currently a major threat to health systems globally. Since it is a leading malignancy worldwide, a correct and early diagnosis is needed to improve chances of survival; more importantly, proper early-stage treatments would reduce the risk of severe morbidity as well as curtail healthcare spending. This paper introduces Skin AI, an Artificial Intelligence (AI)-based solution that uses Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to address the challenges of skin cancer detection and classification. The system utilizes the MNIST dataset for skin cancer imagery, providing a reliable and efficient method for identifying various conditions, including melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, and benign lesions. The proposed framework integrates advanced data augmentation techniques to enhance model robustness, along with explainable AI features to enhance trust and transparency in clinical decision-making. Furthermore, it incorporates telemedicine integration, enabling remote diagnosis and improving access to dermatological care, particularly in underserved and rural areas. The solution is designed with a focus on precision, scalability, and usability, ensuring it meets the practical needs of both clinicians and patients. This study provides a comprehensive overview of the development process, including data preprocessing, model architecture, and optimization strategies, along with performance metrics such as accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity. Additionally, the potential impact of Skin AI as a transformative tool is discussed, emphasizing its role in democratizing dermatological care, reducing diagnostic disparities, and bridging critical gaps in global healthcare accessibility.

title: Bridging Worlds: Preparing Students for Hybrid, Quantum-Classical Computing through, Industry-Academic Collaboration
authors: Monica VanDieren, Ramin Ayanzadeh, Daniel Justice
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We highlight the importance of industry-academic partnerships in quantum education showcasing collaborations between NVIDIA, CMU, and CU Boulder. This presentation demonstrates CUDA-Q Academic designed to enable students to develop hybrid skillsets required by the quantum industry, for example to leverage AI and HPC for circuit optimization and large-scale simulations. Our competency-based learning approach focuses on elements like scalability, performance monitoring, heterogeneous architectures,and quantum concepts. It also fosters essential dispositions for working with rapidly advancing technology, such as adaptability and inventiveness. CUDA-Q's qubit-agnostic nature allows students to implement and optimize quantum-classical algorithms within practical contexts without being tied to specific hardware. All creative-commons-licensed educational materials presented will be shared with attendees to implement in their own environments. Notably, most materials require only a CPU, and those that require GPU can be run on free or low-cost cloud services, making it accessible to institutions with limited hardware resources.

title: AiGuard: AI-Powered Gas Station Intelligent Monitoring Platform
authors: Mingxuan Zhang, Xiao Wu, Gantao Xiao, Rong Li, Tingquan He
abstract: As the final link in the fuel supply chain, gas stations integrate transportation, storage, and retail operations. From a consumer technology perspective, safety, efficiency, and service are key determinants of gas station usability and ensure smooth fueling processes. To boost the intelligent management and control capabilities of gas stations, this paper presents AiGuard, an AI-driven supervision platform designed to enhance safety management, improve service quality, and optimize operational efficiency at gas stations. It integrates existing algorithms for object detection, real-time tracking, and pose estimation with a purpose-designed model for interactive behavior recognition, enabling comprehensive analysis of key gas station zones like the fuel unloading area, forecourt, convenience store, and financial office. The platform enhances safety through real-time monitoring and early hazard detection, improves service quality by reducing waiting time and transactional errors, and increases operational efficiency through intelligent scheduling and compliance tracking. To the best of our knowledge, AiGuard is the first comprehensive platform to provide full-site monitoring and intelligent management for gas station operations, offering a practical and scalable solution for future consumer-oriented smart stations.

title: Subtle Spectral Difference Discriminative Deep Metric Learning with Spectral Center Construction for Hyperspectral Target Detection
authors: Dehui Zhu, Yuetian Lu, Ping Zhong, Bo Du, Liangpei Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Detection of targets for hyperspectral images (HSIs) persists as a fundamental task in remote sensing image processing. Exploring the discriminative ability of deep Siamese networks to distinguish targets from backgrounds is the mainstream method for target detection in HSIs. Nevertheless, these methods enhance the discriminative ability of networks by learning the separability distance between the target and the overall backgrounds, where the backgrounds are considered as a single category. As a result, they may struggle to effectively suppress backgrounds with solely subtle spectral differences from the target, resulting in a limited separability performance, and the inability to accurately detect the targets. To alleviate this problem, we propose a novel subtle spectral difference discriminative deep metric learning-based target detector for HSIs (denoted as S<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>D<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>ML) in this work. The proposed S<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>D<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>ML constructs a deep metric learning framework embedded with a discriminative constraint to learn a deep metric feature space for addressing limited separability, in which the subtle feature differences between targets and different ground objects can be distinguished. In addition, we investigate a new multi-block sparse representation score-based strategy to obtain sufficient samples and spectral centers of backgrounds for training the S<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>D<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>ML framework. Finally, the detection of targets is executed within the learned metric space. A comprehensive suite of experiments is rigorously conducted on four benchmark datasets, and the results indicate that the S<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>D<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>ML achieves superior performance in HSIs target detection.

title: Course-Level Clustering to Enhance Dropout Prediction Accuracy
authors: Yuan Lu, Soonja Yeom, Riseul Ryu, Soo-Hyung Kim
abstract: Accurately identifying students at risk of failing or dropping out has become a key focus in higher education, where early intervention is essential for improving academic outcomes and retention. While many predictive models have been developed, their generalisability across different courses and learning contexts remains limited. This study explores whether clustering techniques can enhance the performance and adaptability of predictive models in educational data mining. Using the Open University Learning Analytics Dataset (OULAD), K-means clustering was applied to cluster courses based on behavioural, demographic, and academic features. Five machine learning models—logistic regression, random forest, neural networks, LightGBM, and support vector classifier—were trained both on the full dataset as a benchmark, and within each cluster. Cluster-based models consistently outperformed baseline models. The average AUC improved from 0.80 to 0.86 (+7.3%), and mean F1-scores increased from 0.66 (baseline) to 0.78 (best cluster-based model). The highest cluster-specific F1-score achieved was 0.88 using LightGBM. This improvement result from grouping courses with similar behavioural and demographic patterns, allowing models to learn context-specific risk factors more effectively. Clustering also uncovered distinct engagement profiles, such as consistently low activity, sporadic participation, and sustained high interaction, that enhanced model interpretability and allowed for more targeted identification of at-risk students. These findings highlight how segmenting courses by shared behavioural and demographic features can significantly improve both the performance and applicability of predictive models in diverse educational environments.

title: A New Anhysteresis Curve for Magnetic Materials
authors: Alexander Sauseng, Klaus Roppert, Manfred Kaltenbacher
abstract: This paper introduces a new anhysteresis curve for electromagnetic simulations such as transformers, rotating machines, or magnetic devices. Unlike existing anhysteresis curves, the introduced curve has several advantages, including continuous differentiability, smoothness for numerical solvers, and characterization using four parameters, each responsible for a specific magnetization region. The new anhysteresis curve is validated by fitting various magnetic materials, and its accuracy is compared to well-known curves such as the (double) Langevin function, the inverse tangent function, and the hyperbolic tangent function. Inverting the constitutive law in magnetics, containing the proposed anhysteresis curve, is also in the scope of this paper because b-based finite element formulations, such as the magneto(quasi)static vector potential formulation, require the inverse material relation.

title: Referring Remote Sensing Image Segmentation via Multi-Scale Spatially-Guided Joint Prediction
authors: Tianxiang Zhang, Zhaokun Wen, Bo Kong, Kecheng Liu, Yisi Zhang, Peixian Zhuang, Jiangyun Li
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Referring Remote Sensing Image Segmentation (RRSIS) is critical for text-guided environmental monitoring, land cover classification, precision agriculture, and urban planning, requiring precise segmentation of objects in remote sensing imagery guided by textual descriptions. This task is uniquely challenging due to the considerable vision-language gap, broad coverage of remote sensing imagery with diverse categories and small targets, and the presence of clustered, unclear targets with blurred edges. To tackle these issues, we propose STDNet, a novel framework designed to bridge the vision-language gap, enhance multi-scale feature interaction, and improve fine-grained object differentiation. Specifically, STDNet introduces (1) the Spatial Multi-Scale Correlation (SMSC) for improved vision-language feature alignment, (2) the Target-Background TwinStream Decoder (T-BTD) for precise distinction between targets and non-targets, and (3) the Dual-Modal Object Learning Strategy (D-MOLS) for robust multimodal feature reconstruction. Extensive experiments on the benchmark datasets RefSegRS and RRSIS-D demonstrate that STDNet achieves state-of-the-art performance, effectively dealing with the core challenges of RRSIS with enhanced precision and robustness. Consequently, it is envisaged that the proposed STDNet model will be an advantage in the RRSIS task. Datasets and codes are available at https://github.com/wzk913ysq/STDNet.

title: Emotion Transition Recognition Using Multimodal Physiological Signal Fusion
authors: Zifan Wang, Lilin Jie, Zhengxiu Li, Junhua Li, Hao Chen, Congxuan Zhang
abstract: Most existing emotion recognition studies rely on discrete stimulus paradigms under controlled laboratory conditions, failing to capture the inherently dynamic and transitional nature of emotional states encountered in real-world operational environments. To address this gap, we propose a novel approach for emotion transition recognition using multimodal physiological signal fusion. Thirty participants, including 10 licensed pilots and 20 non-pilots controls, were recruited to view 48 video stimuli de-signed to elicit six distinct emotional transitions. We introduce a two-stage progressive recognition framework to enhance performance in emotional transition modeling. In Stage I, differential entropy features extracted from EEG signals are integrated with Big Five personality traits to construct an occupation-based trait classification model, capturing cognitive-emotional patterns associated with occupational background and providing individualized priors. In Stage II, we develop the temporal spatial embed ding bidirectional cross-attention fusion network (TSE-BCAF), which employs parallel convolutional modules to extract deep spatial features from multimodal EEG and EOG signals. These features are fused via a bidirectional cross-attention mechanism to model inter-modal interactions, then processed by a Trans former-based temporal encoder to capture the evolving dynamics of emotional transitions. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly outperforms unimodal and state-of-the-art multimodal baselines in both accuracy and robustness. The findings highlight the potential of our approach for real-world applications in aviation psychology and other high stakes domains requiring adaptive emotional regulation.

title: Solving Storage-Integrated Long-Term Unit Commitment With Guaranteed Bounds on Sub-Optimality
authors: Songjie Feng, Wei Wei, Zhongjie Guo, Zhaoyang Dong, Shengwei Mei
abstract: Long-term unit commitment (LTUC) plays an important role in power system planning and production simulation, especially when seasonal volatility of renewable generation and ultra-long-term energy storage are taken into account. Solving LTUC exactly is challenging due to the large number of binary variables. This paper proposes a tractable method to obtain a near-optimal solution to LTUC with a guaranteed bound on its sub-optimality. The proposed method first constructs a lower bound by formulating a relaxed unit commitment (UC) problem in which binary variables are replaced by continuous ones, and a family of valid inequalities is introduced to strengthen the relaxation. A general framework for generating such inequalities is developed by exploiting the specific structural properties of single-unit operational constraints. Subsequently, by fixing the seasonal energy storage levels at the optimal solution of the relaxed UC problem, a feasible LTUC solution is constructed through sequential short-term UC optimization with look-ahead augmentation, which provides an upper bound for the true optimum. The sub-optimality is measured by the gap between the lower and upper bounds. Numerical tests demonstrate that the monthly or annual UC problems of practically-sized power systems can be solved on a laptop in hours with an optimality gap of less than 1.5%.

title: CALI: A Comprehensive Multi-Type, Multi-Unit Appliance Load Identification Framework
authors: Wenbin Yu, Louyang Yu, Gaozhenyang Wang, Zhengju Ren, Konglin Zhu, Hanmiao Cheng, Yadang Chen, Alex X. Liu
abstract: In smart home services, non-intrusive load monitoring (NILM) is critical for enabling efficient energy management and intelligent control. However, most existing NILM methods are limited to recognizing single appliances of the same type, with insufficient attention to scenarios involving the concurrent operation of multiple appliance types or multiple units of the same type. Moreover, publicly available datasets rarely support such comprehensive conditions, limiting progress in real-world applications. To address these challenges, this study proposes a comprehensive appliance load identification framework. An offset-overlay strategy is employed to simulate realistic usage patterns where multiple identical appliances are operated simultaneously by residents with similar behaviors, resulting in a comprehensive multi-type and multi-unit (CMTMU) dataset. A statistical mapping module is developed to enhance appliance sequence feature representation. Within the GCUNet encoder, a gated convolutional attention module is introduced to extract multi-scale features via down-sampling and residual learning. Finally, a hybrid model combining single-appliance state identification with correction and compensation algorithms is used for accurate appliance quantity identification. The experimental results show that the proposed method achieves improvements of 5.15%, 15.76%, and 14.72% in precision, recall, and F1 score, respectively, compared to existing approaches. This framework supports fine-grained load analysis and strengthens the applicability of NILM in practical smart energy systems.

title: Physicochemical Dynamics and Site-Specific Crosslinking at Cellulose Nanocrystal Interfaces for Multifunctional Material Design
authors: Joseph Batta-Mpouma, Gurshagan Kandhola, Jaspreet Kaur, Jae-Woon Lim, Kalindu Perera, Hoon Seonwoo, Joshua Sakon, Jin-Woo Kim
abstract: Cellulose nanocrystals (CNCs) have emerged as versatile nanomaterials with exceptional mechanical, optical, and surface-chemical properties that enable their integration into diverse composite systems. This mini-review summarizes key strategies for engineering CNC-based composites through covalent, non-covalent, and hybrid crosslinking mechanisms, highlighting how these interactions govern material structure and performance. In addition to conventional bulk composites, recent work has also explored their use in interfacial and surface-assembled systems. These approaches are finding utility across multiple application spaces, particularly in biomedical, packaging, and functional material design. Taken together, these developments underscore CNCs' versatility as multifunctional building blocks and their capacity to drive next-generation material innovation.

title: Analyzing Common Electronic Structure Theory Algorithms for Distributed Quantum Computing
authors: Grier M. Jones, Hans-Arno Jacobsen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: To move towards the utility era of quantum computing, many corporations have posed distributed quantum computing (DQC) as a framework for scaling the current generation of devices for practical applications. One of these applications is quantum chemistry, also known as electronic structure theory, which has been poised as a “killer application” of quantum computing. To this end, we analyze five electronic structure methods, including the unitary coupled-cluster singles and doubles (UCCSD), unitary pair coupled-cluster doubles (UpCCD), unitary pair coupled-cluster with generalized singles and doubles (UpCCGSD), separable pair approximation plus generalized singles (SPA+GS), and local unitary cluster Jastrow (LUCJ) ansätze. The key benefit of these methods is that they can be found in common packages, such as Tequila and ffsim, that interface easily with the Qiskit Circuit Cutting addon. Herein, we highlight the challenges and aptitude of the aforementioned electronic structure methods for distribution using quasiprobability simulation with local operations (LO). The key findings of our work are that many of these algorithms cannot be efficiently parallelized using LO, and new methods must be developed to apply electronic structure theory within a DQC framework.

title: Quantum State Transfer between Heterogeneous 3D QPUs
authors: Joey Yaker, Alessandro Reineri, Alexander Romanenko, Anna Grasselino, Tanay Roy, Yu-Chiu Chao, Jens Koch, Yao Lu, Silvia Zorzetti
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We present detailed analyses and microwave simulations of a quantum interconnect architecture that couples two distinct three-dimensional quantum processing units (QPUs): (i) a two-cell superconducting radio-frequency (SRF) cavity coupled to multiple transmon qubits and (ii) a waveguide-based cavity hosting a planar circuit with transmons and resonators. The modules are linked via a low-loss superconducting coaxial cable, which serves as a quantum bus. Finite-element electromagnetic simulations are performed to optimize coupling strengths and mode frequencies for high-fidelity quantum state transfer between cavities. These simulation results provide a comprehensive blueprint for the experimental realization of a flexible quantum interconnect architecture, coupling heterogeneous QPUs.

title: Quantum Tree Generator Improves Qaoa State-of-the-Art for the Knapsack Problem
authors: Paul J. Christiansen, Lennart Binkowski, Debora Ramacciotti, Sören Wilkening
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel approach to the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA), specifically tailored to the knapsack problem. We combine the recently proposed quantum tree generator as an efficient state preparation circuit for all feasible solutions to the knapsack problem with the framework of Grover-mixer QAOA to form the first representative of Amplitude Amplification-mixer QAOA (AAMQAOA). On hard benchmark sets with up to 20 knapsack items, we demonstrate our method's improved performance over the current state-of-the-art Copula-QAOA. However, for larger instance sizes, both approaches fail to deliver better outcomes than greedily packing items in descending value-to-weight ratio, at least for the considered circuit depths. For sufficiently high circuit depths, however, we can prove that AAM-QAOA will eventually be able to sample the optimal solution.

title: Trust-Weighted Sentiment and Environmental Analysis for Theatre Rating using DistilBERT and IoT Sensors
authors: L. Selvam, T. Mary Little Flower, R. Santhana Krishnan, J. Relin Francis Raj, G. Ram Sankar, A. Vegi Fernando
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: This research presents a novel Deep Learning-based framework for evaluating movie theatres within a specific locality by integrating sentiment analysis of user reviews with environmental sensor data. The primary objective is to address the limitations of traditional theatre review systems that rely solely on subjective opinions, by introducing an objective, data-driven, and multidimensional evaluation mechanism. This system is significant in enhancing transparency, trustworthiness, and real-time monitoring capabilities for both customers and theatre management. Overall sentiment classification is achieved using a fine-tuned DistilBERT model, which captures the general polarity of user feedback, while a SpanBERT-based Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis (ABSA) model is employed to analyze sentiments on specific features such as seating comfort, snack quality, air conditioning performance, and cleanliness. Environmental quality is measured using a network of reliable sensors: the PMS5003 and MQ135 modules measure indoor air quality levels, the BME280 sensor captures temperature and humidity for assessing AC effectiveness, and sound pressure level meters monitor noise conditions within the premises. Cleanliness is assessed through image-based detection using YOLOv8 and cross-verified through textual review sentiments. A trust-weighted scoring mechanism is incorporated by evaluating review metadata such as length, verification status, and recency to give more weight to credible user inputs. The collected data from all modalities are normalized, scored based on ideal thresholds, and aggregated through a weighted formula to derive a comprehensive theatre rating. The system is rigorously validated using real-time sensor calibration and cross-validation techniques, ensuring accuracy, consistency, and actionable insights. This integrated approach offers a significant advancement in smart urban entertainment analytics and service optimization.

title: Hybrid Grey Wolf-Blue Whale Optimization for Data-Driven Inventory and Shipping Forecasting
authors: K. S. Wagh, Shreya Naik, Riya Golikere, Divya Bhat, Gauri Shinde
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: We propose a new hybrid framework, using GWO and BWO together for improving machine learning models developed to predict shipping duration. After pre-processing the DataCo dataset, feature scaling was added, and missing data and outliers were eliminated. Several classifiers were used, such as KNN, Decision Tree, and Random Forest. To fine-tune such models further, GWO was used for global exploration and optimizing parameters such as inventory allocation and transportation strategies, whereas BWO excelled at local exploitation, enhancing the precision of prediction. Hybridizing the GWOBWO optimizer balances the strengths of each to explore and exploit the given space when addressing multi-parameter dependencies within supply chain logistics. Experiment results showed substantial improvement in predictive accuracy and robustness over using a single optimization technique. A variant of GWO (RW_GWO) increased the accuracy of model trained using Decision tree from $90.32 \%$ to $91.74 \%$ by refining feature selection through random walks whereas IGWO increased the accuracy of model trained using Random Forest from 86.43% to 92% by identifying the most influential features, thereby boosting its accuracy. Additionally, the hybrid GWO-BOA optimizer further improved model efficiency by balancing global exploration and local exploitation. This kind of hybrid strategy is therefore scalable and adaptive, enabling advancements in predictive capabilities toward optimizing supply chain management for resource allocation and reduction of delays and inefficiency.

title: Cyber Threat Intelligence Detection and Response System using QNN Model with Flask Interface, Email, and Twilio Mobile Alerts
authors: Shaik Shakila Bhanu, J. David S Kumar, Chinna Veeraiahgari Mabuchan, Godala Sunanda, Dudekula Lakshmi, Shaik Rehana
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The growing sophistication and frequency of cyber threats demand intelligent, real-time solutions capable of detecting evolving attack patterns. This paper introduces a modular Cyber Threat Intelligence Detection and Response System that integrates a Quantum Neural Network (QNN) model with a Flask-based web interface and real-time alert mechanisms. Leveraging quantum computing principles such as superposition and entanglement, the QNN model improves anomaly detection accuracy and generalization in high-dimensional network data. Trained using PyTorch and evaluated on labeled intrusion datasets, the model achieved a detection accuracy of 96.85%, outperforming traditional classifiers such as Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Deep Neural Networks (DNN). The system includes a user-friendly interface that supports secure CSV uploads, threat visualization, and activity logging. Real-time alerts are delivered via SMTP-based email and Twilio SMS, ensuring that security teams receive immediate notifications of suspicious activity. Designed with modular components for detection, alerting, and logging, the architecture promotes scalability and ease of integration with enterprise environments. Although currently deployed on a classical simulation of quantum hardware, the system demonstrates significant potential for future implementation in real-world Security Operations Centers (SOCs). This work contributes a practical, quantum- enhanced cybersecurity solution that bridges cutting-edge machine learning research with operational security needs.

title: Neural Architecture Search for Quantum Autoencoders
authors: Hibah Agha, Samuel Yen-Chi Chen, Huan-Hsin Tseng, Shinjae Yoo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: In recent years, machine learning and deep learning have driven advances in domains such as image classification, speech recognition, and anomaly detection by leveraging multilayer neural networks to model complex data. Simultaneously, quantum computing (QC) promises to address classically intractable problems via quantum parallelism, motivating research in quantum machine learning (QML). Among QML techniques, quantum autoencoders show promise for compressing highdimensional quantum and classical data. However, designing effective quantum circuit architectures for quantum autoencoders remains challenging due to the complexity of selecting gates, arranging circuit layers, and tuning parameters. This paper proposes a neural architecture search (NAS) framework that automates the design of quantum autoencoders using a genetic algorithm (GA). By systematically evolving variational quantum circuit (VQC) configurations, our method seeks to identify high-performing hybrid quantum-classical autoencoders for data reconstruction without becoming trapped in local minima. We demonstrate effectiveness on image datasets, highlighting the potential of quantum autoencoders for efficient feature extraction within a noise-prone, near-term quantum era. Our approach lays a foundation for broader application of genetic algorithms to quantum architecture search, aiming for a robust, automated method that can adapt to varied data and hardware constraints.

title: A Deep Learning Approach for Plant Disease Detection
authors: C. Venkatesh, L. Sivayamini, T. Sandhya, K. Santhosh Naik, P. Raja Rajeswari, T. Sohith Yadav, Venkata Dasu, Ch. Nagaraju
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Agriculture evolved as one of the world’s largest and most significant strategic sectors. In developing countries such as India, the global population is predicted to grow dramatically in the future years. Crops such as mango and sweet orange have a large economic and cultural impact on India. However, plant diseases are now a major global issue, producing food shortages in many countries. Plant diseases impair agricultural productivity and, if not diagnosed, can lead to food shortages, threatening global security and small-scale farmers’ livelihoods. Early diagnosis of such crops is critical for avoiding and controlling plant diseases, as well as making informed agricultural decisions. Identifying these diseases accurately is critical for enhancing agricultural production. Traditional agricultural disease detection methods are time-consuming, expensive, and frequently result in false diagnosis. There is a need for an automated approach to detect leaf disease. The emergence of deep learning algorithms has presented a possible solution to this challenge, as they have exhibited outstanding accuracy and efficiency across a variety of sectors. As a result, a deep learning-based method for detecting mango and sweet orange plant diseases is proposed in this work. The proposed system aims to identify plant diseases. It utilizes a dataset size of 50 leaf disease images from the Kaggle database, which are pre-processed by resizing for uniformity. A Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) with ResNet is then used to classify the leaf type, such as mango or sweet orange, and segment the images to detect abnormalities. Finally, the effectiveness of this system is evaluated by using parameters such as accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, MSE, and PSNR. The proposed system obtained an accuracy of 98.43%.

title: Dynamic Software Product Lines for Run-Time Adaptations in Quantum Software
authors: Samuel Sepúlveda, Ricardo Pérez-Castillo, Mario Piattini
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Hybrid quantum-classical software systems are emerging as a practical means to exploit quantum computing within existing software stacks. However, such systems operate in highly dynamic environments, where quantum hardware fidelity, queue latency, and cloud costs fluctuate rapidly. Current Quantum Software Product Line (QSPL) approaches support design-time variability but lack mechanisms for run-time selfadaptation, limiting their applicability in operational contexts. This position paper aims to substantiate a Dynamic Software Product Line (DSPL) approach that enables run-time selfadaptation and automatic reconfiguration of hybrid quantumclassical software. The approach leverages solver-based multiobjective optimization to dynamically select configurations that balance fidelity, latency, and cost. We propose an explicit mapping of the DSPL components, run-time variability model, monitoring engine, and reconfiguration engine into the MAPE-K cycle. An illustrative scenario in the domain of logistics route optimization demonstrates the practical applicability of the approach. The example shows how the system continuously monitors operational metrics and adapts algorithm and back-end configurations to maintain service quality and cost-efficiency in response to environmental changes. The main implication of this work is that it serves as a preliminary foundation for run-time self-adaptation in hybrid quantum-classical software.

title: An Approach for Detecting Reverse Shell Attacks Based on Process Log Analysis*
authors: Luciano Hanna El Adji, Luís Felipe Ignácio Cunha, Raphael Carlos Santos Machado
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: Reverse shell attacks represent a critical postexploitation technique that bypasses firewall restrictions to establish persistent system access. This work addresses host-level reverse shell detection through three primary contributions. First, we present a comprehensive and publicly available dataset containing 436 reverse shell payloads with automatically generated ground truth. Second, we establish a quantitative baseline using Linux Audit System process logs that defines the limitations of pattern-matching approaches, achieving 100% precision but only 38.99% recall. Finally, we develop a reproducible experimental framework enabling standardized comparisons of future detection techniques. Our analysis reveals that missed payloads primarily involve diverse interpreters and utilities not covered by traditional heuristic patterns. These findings justify the need for more adaptive detection approaches and provide a fundamental basis for advancing research toward more effective detection methods.

title: Qubit-Width-Aware Grover Adaptive Search for Combinatorial Optimization Problems
authors: Takuto Moriya, Masashi Tawada, Nozomu Togawa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: To address the qubit overhead of encoding objective function values on Grover adaptive search, we propose a qubit-width-aware algorithm that reduces the number of qubits by scaling the dynamic range, without compromising solution quality. Specifically, we analyze the trade-off between accuracy and performance under hardware constraints. Simulations on the Personalized Course Selection Problem (PCSP), a realistic scheduling task with preferences and constraints, demonstrate that our method reduces qubit usage by up to 7 qubits while maintaining the original success rate.

title: Short-Term Rainfall Prediction from Satellite Images Using Convolutional-LSTM Models
authors: Mohammad Javad Rafiei Dastjerdi, Farsad Zamani Boroujeni, Pouya Derakhshan Barjoei, Fatemeh Davami
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: Short-term rainfall prediction is a meteorological forecast aimed at accurately predicting rainfall intensity within the next few hours for a specific region. Previous methods were predominantly based on extrapolating weather radar images. However, with advancements in satellite-based remote sensing and machine learning techniques, artificial intelligence has gained attention in this domain. This study introduces a model combining Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and an encoder-decoder architecture. Using the IMERG dataset from NASA’s meteorological satellites, the model offers precise short-term predictions for the next three hours. A comparison with the improved Convcast baseline model demonstrates an average improvement of 5% across six evaluation metrics. Specifically, there is a $\mathbf{2. 1 \%}$ improvement in accuracy and 8.4% improvement in the success ratio.

title: DBN-LSTM: A Hybrid Deep Learning Architecture for Adaptive Interpolation of Coupled Spatio-Temporal Signals
authors: Xuefang Sun, Xinchi Zhu, Lina Du, Guangjian Gao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: The presence of missing data in high-dimensional time series critically degrades data quality and compromises subsequent analyses. Traditional imputation methods are often inadequate as they fail to capture the complex, coupled spatiotemporal dependencies inherent in such data. To address this challenge, we propose the DBN-LSTM model, a novel framework that employs a hybrid architecture. This architecture integrates a Deep Belief Network (DBN) to extract deep cross-sectional correlations and a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network to capture temporal dependencies. Evaluated on a high-dimensional dataset with intrinsic spatio-temporal characteristics under missing rates of 10% to 20%, our model achieves a Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of 0.12-0.133 and a Coefficient of Determination <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(R^{2})$</tex> exceeding 0.93. The proposed framework significantly outperforms established baseline models, thereby providing a robust solution for imputing data characterized by complex spatio-temporal dependencies.

title: FedColab: Federated Collaborative Learning for Teacher-Student Knowledge Distillation
authors: Wenhao Li, Christos Anagnostopoulos, Kevin Bryson
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) is an efficient distributed learning paradigm for training machine learning models across distributed clients’ data. However, the heterogeneity in clients’ computational capacities poses significant challenges in distributed model training. One promising solution is knowledge distillation, which requires balancing global uniformity with client-level personalization. To address this challenge, we propose a federated collaborative learning teacher-student heterogeneous knowledge distillation framework coined FedColab. In our framework, students are matched with teachers based on knowledge distribution similarity, uniformization trends, and complementarity. Students improve their performance by learning from both their designated teacher and peer models, while teachers adjust their FL optimization process based on feedback from students, ensuring alignment with the collective student population. Experimental results demonstrate that the distillation mechanism in FedColab significantly enhances the performance of model aggregation in heterogeneous and distributed learning environments.

title: Google’s VRP Free Algorithm Evaluation Study and its Use in Small and Medium Transportation Problems
authors: Antonios Balikos, Athanasios Pantopoulos, Athanasios Lois, Apostolis Xenakis, George Floros, Kostas Kolomvatsos, Athanasios Ziliaskopoulos
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Vehicle routing is one of the oldest, yet critical, problems of the logistics sector. Globalization and the rise of e-commerce as well as technological advances have allowed the development of a profitable routing software market, which has recently attracted the attention of technology giants. Among the plethora of routing software alternatives, Google’s open source optimization suite, OR-Tools, looks particularly promising, providing a useful and affordable optimization tool for small and medium sized logistic companies and applications. The goal of this paper is to scientifically evaluate the accuracy, and performance of OR-Tools suite by examining the quality of its solution results in a set of capacitated vehicle routing problems with delivery time windows, also known as capacitated vehicle routing problem with time-windows (CVRPTW) or VRPTW. A comparative analysis is conducted by solving Solomon’s VRPTW problems for a small (25 customers), medium (50 customers), and large (100 customers) number of customers with OR-Tools and comparing the results with the known optimal solutions for a fixed maximum solution time and varied number of available vehicles. Additionally, in this paper we demonstrate a real case of application of the OR-Tool tools to a real problem concerning the online distribution of dairy products. But given the very nebulous definition of the online character of a problem, ORTool does not include online VRP algorithms. For this reason, we will convert the solution of the classic stationary VRP using OR-Tools into a solution for Online VRP.

title: Comparing Accuracy and Precision of Random Forest and K-Nearest Neighbors for Brain Tumor Classification
authors: Anitha P, Ajay Kishore M T, Prakash N, Kanimozhi J.K, Kalyanasundaram P, Geetha R
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The study evaluates the efficiency of random forests (RF) and K-niches neighbors (KNN) algorithms in classification of brain tumors from MRI images. Materials and methods: Group 1 K-approaches represent the neighborhood algorithm, while group 2 represents the random forest algorithm. Both models were tested by the MR dataset with brain tumor images, and their performance was analyzed using classification classes accuracy and accuracy. Results: Random forest algorithm improved KNN algorithm, achieved classification accuracy of 94.00% compared to 91.00% for KNN. Due to his learning method, RF demonstrated better strength and reduced overfitting. This study confirms that random forest algorithm is more effective than algorithms to the best neighbors for classifying brain tumor, making it a better approach to medical image analysis.

title: Cost Optimization Techniques for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing Environments
authors: Yugandhar Suthari, Zinkal Thakker, Sangeetha Govindarajan, Nithya Krishnan, Vishvanatha Raju, Siva Koteswara Rao Katta
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: By providing on-demand access to computing resources, cloud computing has completely changed the way IT services are delivered. On the other hand, businesses have a lot of problems with inefficient resource allocation and higher operating costs due to its pay-as-you-go pricing model and their unpredictable workloads. In this study, we compare overcommitment, workload consolidation, containerization, predictive auto-scaling, spot instances, and reserved instances to find the most cost-effective ways to improve resource allocation in cloud environments. The research also explores machine learning-based methods for demand forecasting and adaptive scheduling to improve cost efficiency. Through experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets, the proposed framework demonstrates significant savings in cloud ownership costs, achieving up to 24.6% reduction, while maintaining system reliability and meeting performance and SLA requirements. The findings provide valuable insights for practitioners seeking to balance cost-efficiency and performance in cloud infrastructures. This work contributes to advancing cost optimization strategies, particularly for organizations with dynamic workloads, and suggests future research in serverless and edge computing models.

title: Construction Method of Radar Echo Equivalent Model of Plasma Flow Field Coated Target
authors: Liang Man, Hao-chuan Deng, Ze-hao Yao, Bing-hui He
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: The plasma flow field has the motion characteristics of non-uniform distribution, while the difference between the plasma flow field velocity and the target body velocity is ignored when the electromagnetic characteristics of the plasma flow field are extracted and analyzed, resulting in spectral broadening and one-dimensional range aberration defocusing in the radar measurement process. In this paper, based on the radar echo signal processing method and the characteristics of the velocity distribution of the plasma flow field, an equivalent model for the analysis of the plasma flow field echo is established, and the causes of the frequency modulation phenomenon of the moving plasma and the defocusing phenomenon of the target's one-dimensional range profile are simulated.

title: Quantum Large Language Model Fine-Tuning
authors: Sang Hyub Kim, Jonathan Mei, Claudio Girotto, Masako Yamada, Martin Roetteler
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We introduce a hybrid quantum-classical deep learning architecture for large language model fine-tuning. The classical portion of the architecture is a sentence transformer that is powerful enough to display significant accuracy for complex tasks such as sentiment prediction. The quantum portion of the architecture consists of parameterized quantum circuits that utilize long-range connections between qubits. We analyze the performance of the hybrid models for various settings of hyperparameters, including the number of qubits, the depth of the quantum circuits, learning rate, number of reuploading steps, etc. Based on a screening study of main effects, we show an overall improvement in prediction accuracy over a comparable classical baseline, with a trend of increasing accuracy with number of qubits. We observe up to 3.14% improvements in accuracy over classical architectures of comparable model size, within the set of hyperparameters probed in this study. We demonstrate the contribution of each module in our architecture through ablation studies. Our studies are based on finite shot-counts and include simulations based on noisy quantum gates.

title: Biomedical Sensing via Wearable Technology: A Novel Circular Slotted Antenna
authors: Regina S, Vasuki S, Savita S, Suvedha B, Thya J, Swetha S
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: This paper outlines the design and simulation of a two-slotted circular patch microstrip antenna optimized for wearable medical applications. It operates within the 10–25 GHz frequency range. The proposed antenna achieves multiple resonances at 19.186 GHz, 20.06 GHz, and 23.46 GHz, enabling compatibility with emerging 5G-enabled wireless medical telemetry systems. The antenna is fabricated on a silicon rubber substrate (ε<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">r</inf> = 2.9–4 at 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup> Hz), chosen for its flexibility, thermal stability, biocompatibility, and durability, making it suitable for integration into accessories, clothing, or medical devices. Simulation results using CST software demonstrate a return loss of –44.44 dB at 23.46 GHz, VSWR values below 1.14, and peak gains of up to 8.05 dB, confirming excellent impedance matching and high radiation efficiency. The E-plane and H-plane radiation patterns exhibit stable performance across all operating frequencies, with omnidirectional characteristics in the H-plane. The proposed design combines multiband operation, compactness, and high performance, offering a promising solution for next-generation wearable antennas in healthcare monitoring, implantable devices, and other biomedical applications requiring reliable high-speed data transmission.

title: Parallel K-Means Clustering for Customer Segmentation in Predictive Marketing Using OpenMP, MPI, and CUDA
authors: Tulasi Raman R, Christopher Columbus C, Abinaya R, Rajeev Sekar, Akilesh S, Muhammad Kifayathullah K A
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Predictive marketing is vital for developing effective marketing strategies by utilizing consumer data to anticipate behaviors and optimize decision-making. This research employs k-means clustering on a dataset comprising 2 million supermarket transactions to identify distinct customer segments, which can enhance marketing efforts, driving sales and customer loyalty. A significant aspect of the research involves evaluating k-means clustering through parallel processing techniques such as OpenMP, MPI, and CUDA. By analyzing various performance metrics across different processing methods, the proposed method identifies the most efficient strategy for large-scale predictive marketing. The implementation of parallel processing notably reduces clustering time, facilitating real-time decision-making and quicker execution of personalized marketing initiatives. The resultant customer insights enable businesses to launch targeted campaigns, boosting engagement and fostering loyalty. The highest speedup of 44.38 times was achieved with the CUDA implementation. This research provides a framework for integrating high-performance computing into predictive marketing, ensuring scalability and efficiency in managing large datasets.

title: A U-Net Based Image Stitching Detection and Segmentation for Image Stitching Assessment
authors: Ali Farhad Tavasoli, Farbod Razzazi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: Image stitching is an efficient technique for creating a single, seamless image by combining multiple semi-overlapping images. While numerous studies have explored various methods and algorithms for this technique, Assessing the stitching procedure by identifying stitching boundaries remains a significant challenge. Given the proven capabilities of deep learning methods in diverse fields, this research addresses the identification of stitching boundaries using these methods. The primary objective is to automatically detect stitching boundaries and classify images into “stitched” and “normal” categories using deep learning techniques. In this context, deep convolutional neural networks, specifically Efficient Net and U-Net, were employed for classification and segmentation of stitching boundaries. The results demonstrate classification with $97.81 \%$ accuracy and segmentation.

title: Ship Detection in SAR Images using Morphological Operations
authors: Atefeh Soleymani Moghadam, Gholamreza Akbarizadeh
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: The detection and identification of ships in Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) images is a significant challenge in the fields of environmental monitoring and maritime security. This paper examines advanced methods for ship detection using SAR data. Initially, it addresses the analysis of the imaging and signal characteristics of SAR images, along with the challenges related to noise and weather conditions. Subsequently, machine learning and deep learning algorithms are explored for the identification and classification of ships in these images. The results obtained from experiments demonstrate the high accuracy of these algorithms in identifying ships under various conditions. Finally, this study provides recommendations for improving the performance of ship detection systems and their potential applications in monitoring maritime activities and border security.

title: Partial Federated Primal-Dual Optimization for Network-Based Android Malware Detection
authors: Mohammad Mashreghi, Mohammad Hossein Badiei
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: The proliferation of Android devices has led to a surge in malware attacks, posing significant threats to user privacy and security. Traditional machine learning approaches for malware detection often require centralized data collection, which raises privacy concerns and may not be scalable given the distributed nature of user data. Federated Learning (FL) offers a decentralized solution by enabling devices to collaboratively train a global model without sharing raw data. However, conventional FL methods like Federated Averaging (FedAvg) face significant limitations in communication efficiency, partial client participation, and non-convex optimization. These challenges result in increased overhead, unstable model updates, and reduced robustness, particularly in real-world applications like malware classification. In this study, we utilize a federated primal-dual optimization approach to enhance communication efficiency and model convergence in FL by leveraging the Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM). Unlike traditional optimization methods for FL, ADMM is well-suited for solving non-convex composite optimization problems with non-smooth regularizers, making it robust to data heterogeneity and dynamic client participation. We evaluate our proposed method on widely used benchmark Android malware classification datasets (e.g. Malgenome, Drebin, and Tuandromd). Experimental results demonstrate that our algorithm outperforms traditional FL approaches (e.g. FedAvg and FedProx) in terms of accuracy, F1 score, AUC score, and false positive rate (FPR).

title: Electrical Fault Isolation on Dislocation Failures Present on SiC-4H Substrate and Physical Analysis by FIB Alignment
authors: Pietro Paolo Barbarino, Giuseppe Anastasi, Massimiliano Astuto, Roberta Ricciari
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: In recent years, silicon carbide (SiC) has become one of the most important wide bandgap semiconductors (WBG) for the realization of high-power devices. SiC has many better physical characteristics than Si and is therefore preferred to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Si}: \text{SiC}$</tex> has a band gap of 3.26 eV versus 1.12 eV, which means it can operate at higher temperatures, ensuring greater temperature stability of the devices; it has a much higher breakdown electric field, making it preferred for devices that are designed for breakdown voltages higher than the limits of Si; it has a saturation rate about twice, making it more suitable for devices that will have to work at high frequencies and high electric fields; it has higher thermal conductivity which ensures better heat dissipation and thermal stability. Finally, SiC has a better resistance to radiation than Si, making it more suitable for applications in extreme environments. Those results are very important for the green economy because they made it possible to increase the power output of the devices, reduce their power dissipation, and shrink their size. Among all these positive aspects, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{S i C}$</tex> presents a problem related to the purity of the epitaxial layer, where defects such as nuclei, microtubules, and dislocations can create issues for the proper functioning of the device. This document presents a sequence between fault isolation and physical analysis that allows for quick responses on the nature of the points indicated by fault isolation and enables the identification of killer dislocations that compromise the proper functioning of the device.

title: Iterative Quantum Annealing for Job Shop Scheduling with a Directed Graph Representation
authors: Rebecca Casati, Thomas Giudici, Pietro Torta, Enrico Prati
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: A promising use of quantum computers lies in the logistics and scheduling of industrial problems, such as space mission planning, maritime management, and many others. This field is expected to provide useful applications for quantum computing at the current stage of hardware development. Quantum annealing techniques have been proposed to solve scheduling problems, along with many other optimization problems. In this work, we test quantum annealing and hybrid techniques based on the D-Wave hardware to solve scheduling problems in the framework of job shop scheduling (JSP), which consists of optimally assigning operations to certain resources, while satisfying specific constraints and minimizing the total scheduling time, known as timespan. We devised an iterative algorithm that produces valid schedules for decreasing timespan values. We implemented a refined iterative variable pruning technique, which significantly reduces the number of spin variables in the corresponding Ising model, whose low-energy configurations are sampled by using the D-Wave Hybrid Solver Service. Our novel iterative algorithm leverages a directed acyclic graph (DAG) representation of partial or complete solutions of the JSP instance, which enables an efficient update of the feasible processing time windows for each operation. This approach leads to significantly improved results compared to the standard state-of-the-art applications of quantum annealing for the JSP. Remarkably, we can often prove the absolute optimality of the obtained solution, namely that a more efficient schedule within a shorter timespan can not exist.

title: Comprehensive Multi-Modal Characterization and Analysis of OLED Panels Across the Full Scale
authors: Jiamei Song, Xiaokang Hu, Weixin Chen, Jiashi Zhou, Chunyang Zhang, Xing Chao
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: This work introduces an innovative workflow aimed at achieving multi-modal characterization and analysis of active-matrix organic light-emitting diode (AMOLED) displays across the full scale from micrometers to nanometers. By integrating Laser Plasma-Focused Ion Beam (Laser PFIB) and Gallium-based Focused Ion Beam (Ga FIB) technologies, we have achieved efficient disassembly and analysis of packaged display panels. Furthermore, we employed the integration of Differential Phase Contrast (iDPC) techniques within Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) to obtain high signal-to-noise ratio and high-contrast images of the barrier layer. For the Low-Temperature Polycrystalline Silicon Thin-Film Transistor (LTPS-TFT) layers, we utilized Differential Phase Contrast (DPC) technology to achieve nanoscale grain imaging and statistical analysis. The workflow presented herein not only aids in failure analysis but also holds significant value for reverse engineering studies.

title: The Junior Mobile Engineering Classes for Youth Engineering Education Operated by Hanyang University and Hyundai Mobis as Part of Their Corporate Social Responsibility Activities
authors: Jung Hoon Choi, Book Kee Hwang, Byung Kwon Lee
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: Since 2014, Hanyang University and Hyundai Mobis have operated the Junior Mobile Engineering Class by visiting schools and science event venues nationwide that require youth engineering education with a 12-ton trailer equipped with scientific equipment as part of their role as a university and company contributing to society. The Junior Mobile Engineering Classes are operated in two forms. First, it is a program conducted as a single event, where schools or science event venues interested in engineering education are visited to perform engineering related experiments and plays. Second, it is a program that systematically and continuously provides education related to the school curriculum by visiting schools and institutions that want continuous engineering education every month. The contents of the Junior Mobile Science Class, based on the STEAM education concept developed by Hanyang University's Discovery Centre for Science and Technology for Young Scientist, are systematically organized to enable students to understand through experiments how the scientific principles in textbooks are applied to technology and engineering. Especially, the contents of this Junior Mobile Engineering class are designed to inspire students' imagination and creativity by providing them with understanding of engineering and predicting future technologies & engineering. Surveys conducted on students who participated in these Junior Mobile Engineering classes showed that their understanding and interest in engineering increased significantly. In addition, Regarding Hyundai Mobis, which is participating in the joint operation, we could see a very positive change in its image as a company that contributes to society.

title: Blockchain-Based Framework for Secure and Transparent E-Voting Using Ethereum: An Alternative to Traditional EVMs
authors: Vaishnav Pradeep Menon, Aluru Sai Tharshith, Priyanshu Aryan, Kirti S. Pande, S Kamatchi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: The solution offered by Blockchain technology fixes electronic voting problems by tackling the vulnerabilities of Votes, eliminating transparency problems, and improving EVM machine scalability issues. This study creates a dual voting system that unites Ethereum smart contracts for both protected candidate enrollment and voting confirmation along with authentication functions and election results counting. This framework incorporates an oversight feature for election officials who can monitor votes live so they can verify operations while improving both security and transparency. The Ganache implementation of the prototype required $\mathbf{3 8 7, 9 5 7}$ gas units for each vote to maintain decentralization as well as optimize resource usage. This frame- work links blockchain innovation to offline voting procedures to create an operable solution that substitutes standard voting technologies. Future developments will include work on both scalability improvements and user accessibility enhancements together with the integration of zero-knowledge-proof technology to guarantee voter privacy at the operational level of this framework.

title: Secure Simulation of BB84 and E91 Quantum Cryptography Protocols
authors: Jithendra Kukutla, Bandaru Pavani, Nandavaram Venkata Madhavi, Janapala Madhavi Latha
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Quantum computing is advancing rapidly and thus is a major challenge to traditional schemes of cryptographies like RSA, and ECC that get their security on computational difficulty. In order to counter this challenge, a paradigm change to be proposed is quantum cryptography which is based on the application of the rules of quantum mechanics to a conditional security. In the paper, a design and implementation of an interactive simulation platform, which models two seminal quantum key distribution (QKD) protocols, namely, BB84 and E91, is proposed. Formulated with a modular architecture in Streamlit, the system allows users to simulate the transmission into qubit, visualize key pre-processing, study the quantum bit error rate (QBER) and detect any eavesdropping through CHSH inequality. The platform will be used to include functionality of real-time graphical dashboards, user authentication, and a comparative analysis segment to systematically review classical and quantum-related cryptographic methods. The effects of noise levels, adversarial interference on the QBER and key generation rates are verified, and this serves to confirm the resilience of quantum systems against eavesdropping. The tool can be used as an educational and a research tool since it offers an intuitive interface to learn the quantum concepts related to superposition or entanglement and simultaneously takes the user through the protocol functionality in different security regimes. The findings attest to the increased security capabilities of quantum cryptographic systems, thus making them a valid option in the future communication network during the post-quantum era.

title: Intrusion Detection for Security Enhancing using Machine Learning Algorithm
authors: M. Manikandan, S. Sudhakar, T. Gobinath, M. Kumar, P. Rajasekaran, N. Murugeswari
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: While Software-Defined Networking (SDN) stands out as an exceptional network management technique due to its adaptability and flexibility, these very strengths make it particularly vulnerable to security threats such as Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks. When it comes to SDN frameworks, the most significant obstacles are related to identifying and mitigating DDoS attacks.
