This article explores the use of Echo State Networks (ESNs), an algorithm specifically adapted for Software-Defined Networking (SDN) environments, to detect Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks. It is a type of Recurrent Neural Network (RNN), in which the sequential data is processed efficiently that is very much needed to analysis the network traffic. The other conventional RNNs like simple RNN, Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network, Gated Recurrent Units (GRUs) and Bidirectional RNNs are extremely slow and challenging to train because of disappearing or expanding gradient problem. To assess the ESN algorithm's effectiveness, expanded this approach by incorporating flow features designed to improve DDoS detection. Thoroughly examined this proposed DDoS detection method using various simulation parameters and compared its results against other algorithms. The ESN consistently demonstrated superior performance, achieving better F-score, recall, precision, and accuracy values. Notably, it an impressive 97.78% average success rate, clearly highlighting its efficacy in identifying and preventing DDoS attacks. This research underscores the significant role ESNs can play as a cybersecurity tool, representing a considerable advancement in safeguarding SDN networks from DDoS threats.

title: QubiCML: ML-Powered Real-Time Quantum State Discrimination Enabling Mid-Circuit Measurements
authors: Neel R Vora, Yilun Xu, Akel Hasim, Neelay Fruitwala, Nam Nguyen, Haoran Liao, Jan Balewski, Abhi Rajagopala, Kasra Nowrouzi, Qing Ji, K. Brigitta Whaley, Irfan Siddiqi, Phuc Nguyen, Gang Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: This work presents QubiCML, a novel FPGA-based system engineered for real-time, in-situ discrimination of two- and three-level quantum states (quitrits) in superconducting quantum processors. Accurate and low-latency identification of quantum states is a critical enabler for scaling quantum computing, particularly as higher-dimensional systems such as qutrits are explored to increase information density, circuit depth, and gate expressivity. QubiCML integrates a lightweight, multi-layer neural network directly into FPGA hardware to classify the qutrit states <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\vert g\rangle,\vert e\rangle$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\vert f\rangle$</tex> with high fidelity and minimal latency. Traditional state discrimination methods rely on offline post-processing, resulting in delays incompatible with the short coherence times of superconducting qubits. QubiCML overcomes this bottleneck by performing all inference operations within the FPGA fabric itself, achieving full quantum state discrimination within 66 ns (with softmax) or 40 ns (without softmax). The system supports fast reconfiguration via BRAM-stored parameters, enabling compatibility with varying quantum hardware and dynamic calibration environments. Additionally, we propose FPGA-friendly techniques for data normalization and fixed-point quantization to eliminate the overhead of floating-point and division operations—further optimizing the architecture for real-time deployment. We evaluate QubiCML on in-house superconducting hardware across multiple qubits and qutrits. The system achieves up to 97 % average accuracy for qutrits and up to 99 % for two-level systems, using readout windows as short as 650-750 ns. These results establish QubiCML as one of the first practical implementations of real-time qutrit state discrimination, marking an essential step toward mid-circuit measurements, dynamic feedback, and advanced error correction in higher-dimensional quantum computing.

title: CoT-MT: Chain-Of-Thought Guided Multi-Granularity Temporal Question Answering With Kg-Augmented Llms
authors: Yi Wang, Zhaoyun Ding, Sheng Zhang, Lehai Xin
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Our study introduces CoT-MT, an innovative framework for multi-granularity temporal question answering that integrates chain-of-thought (CoT) reasoning with knowledge graph augmentation. This method addresses the limitations of existing temporal knowledge graph question answering (TKGQA) tasks, including insensitivity to mixed temporal granularities, inadequate handling of complex queries requiring multi-hop reasoning, and outdated knowledge in large language models, by incorporating knowledge graphs into CoT reasoning to provide learnable contextual information. Furthermore, we conduct experiments on the largest multi-granularity temporal QA dataset MultiTQ, and the experimental results have demonstrated the effectiveness of our approach.

title: Semantic Segmentation of Brain Tumors Using an Enhanced U-Net Architecture: A Novel Layering Approach and Innovative Framework
authors: Hirad Tajvar, Soheil Fakheri, Mohammad Reza Yamaghani, Azamossadat Nourbakhsh
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: Getting the tumor area in the brain correctly divided is very important, since it helps doctors in treatment plans and also makes patient recovery better. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), particularly advanced architectures like U-Net, have garnered significant attention due to their outstanding capability in processing and segmenting medical images. In this study, an efficient approach for brain tumor segmentation in MRI images is proposed by leveraging transfer learning, the Superpixel technique, and introducing a novel layering scheme in the U-Net architecture. This method is designed to precisely identify complex boundaries and the irregular structures of tumors. The experiments were conducted using a publicly available and reliable dataset from Kaggle. Following data preprocessing, a semantic segmentation algorithm based on the U-Net model was employed. U-Net has become a popular choice in medical image processing owing to its advantages such as high accuracy, fast processing speed, and minimal requirements for large datasets or sophisticated hardware. By utilizing this model alongside transfer learning and modifications in the coding layers, the proposed method achieved an impressive accuracy of 99.67% in brain tumor identification. This level of accuracy surpasses that of similar studies in the field. The result shows high potential of this approach in improving early tumor detection precision and give more effective treatment for patients.

title: ESD Robustness and Failure Analysis of Cascode GaN MIS-HEMTs Under Component-Level Test
authors: Chen-Wei Su, Ming-Dou Ker, Jui-Sheng Wu, Chih-Yi Yang, Edward Yi Chang
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: This study investigates the electrostatic discharge (ESD) robustness of cascode GaN MIS-HEMTs (metal-insulator-semiconductor high electron mobility transistors) at the component level. The experimental results revealed unstable tolerance to Human Body Model (HBM) ESD stress in the Gate-to-Source zapping configuration, indicating a potential design vulnerability. The study analyzed the correlation between transmission line pulse (TLP), HBM, and ESD gun tests to assess consistency across different standards. Failure analysis was conducted to identify the locations in the G-S path that are most susceptible to ESD stress.

title: An Efficient Hybrid Classical Quantum Algorithm for Mixed-Integer Constrained Optimization
authors: Amit Surana
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Widely used quantum optimization algorithms such as quantum annealing and quantum approximate optimization algorithm (QAOA) for quadratically unconstrained binary optimization (QUBO) problems cannot systematically and efficiently handle constraints and mixed discrete and continuous decision variables. To address this, we present a novel hybrid classicalquantum approach which combines classical alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) with QAOA. Compared to conventional penalty-based method, this approach avoids quantization of continuous variables, eliminates the need for additional qubits to capture constraints on a quantum device and leads to reduced QAOA circuit depth suitable for near term implementation. We illustrate the efficacy of our approach on several constrained mixed integer optimization problems.

title: Simulation Algorithm for Depth Images of Imaging LiDAR
authors: Yu Zhai, Ziyi Zhang, Sen Xie, Chunsheng Tong, Liming Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: To address the scarcity of high-quality, multiperspective depth image data in LiDAR target recognition research, this paper proposes a parametrically programmable simulation algorithm for imaging LiDAR depth images. The algorithm constructs a 3D target set based on the Princeton Shape Benchmark model library, achieving precise control over target pose and position through Euler angle rotations and translations, while supporting multi-target occlusion modeling. Its core employs a triangular mesh projection sampling mechanism: after calculating the projection boundary of the target mesh, sampling is performed according to resolution and field-of-view angle; depth is back-calculated via plane equations, and occlusion is resolved using a maximum distance criterion; to address multi-target edge depth aliasing, Canny edge detection is introduced as a quality control module for depth maps; a LiDAR noise model is concurrently incorporated to approximate real noise characteristics. Experiments demonstrate that this framework generates depth images with arbitrary target combinations, full pose angle coverage, high edge clarity, and multiple noise levels, exhibiting significant advantages over real data in enhanced scene scalability, precise parameter controllability, and rich sample diversity. It provides a standardized evaluation benchmark and large-scale controllable training data for LiDAR system optimization, image enhancement, and target recognition algorithms.

title: Network Simulation Bridge: Bridging Distributed Applications with Network Simulation Platforms
authors: Harikrishna Kuttivelil, Lakshmi Krishnaswamy, Nayan Bhatia, Katia Obraczka
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: In an increasingly interconnected world where connected devices have become ubiquitous and the remote and distributed tools and services accessed on these devices have become pervasive, the responsive modeling and simulation of underlying networks is critical in the research and development of connected systems. While capable network simulators exist to model such networks, connecting applications in development to these network simulators is non-trivial and existing solutions are not universally available on all computing platforms without having to port the entire application over to the network simulator platform. NSB - the Network Simulation Bridge - is a platform, application- and network simulator-agnostic open-source tool that allows researchers and developers to more easily integrate network simulation back-ends into their application front-ends, allowing for more holistic modeling of their systems. In this tutorial, we will provide an overview of NSB and its features and packages. We will cover its design, implementation and usage with two well-known network simulator backends - OMNeT++ and ns-3. Using step-by-step hands-on demonstrations, we will provide both high-level tutorials on quick and easy integration of applications with $O M N e T++$ and ns-3 network simulation using NSB’s helper packages and low-level tutorials on how to use the provided programming interfaces to manually integrate NSB into network simulation back-ends for more specialized use cases. Through this tutorial, our goal is to disseminate NSB to the distributed computing research and practitioner communities as a tool that will facilitate the development, testing and validation of distributed applications. NSB will allow researchers and developers of connected applications with various levels of experience in network simulation to more realistically observe the behavior and evaluate the performance of their distributed applications as they communicate using the underlying network.

title: Multi-head Attention based Deep Learning Framework for Identifying Distributed Denial of Service Attacks
authors: Aryamaan Rajesh Chaurasia, Vishnu Nedungatt, Mahendra Pratap Singh, Shyam Lal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: The increasing frequency and sophistication of Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks pose severe threats to network security, necessitating more advanced detection mechanisms. Traditional detection methods, which rely on statistical analysis and classical machine learning, often struggle to generalize due to their reliance on handcrafted features. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a Multi-head Attention Distributed Denial of Service Network (MADDoSNet), a deep learning-based framework that leverages a multi-head attention mechanism to effectively analyze sequential network traffic and identify attack patterns. Multi-head attention enables the model to focus on multiple aspects of network behavior simultaneously, improving feature extraction and anomaly detection in complex, high-dimensional data. Following an extensive evaluation on the ISCX2012 dataset, the proposed MADDoSNet demonstrates superior detection accuracy compared to state-of-the art models. Key performance metrics such as precision, recall, F1-score, and AUC confirm its effectiveness in distinguishing normal and malicious traffic. Moreover, we assess the computational efficiency of MADDoSNet, highlighting its trade-offs in terms of inference speed and resource consumption. Our findings underscore the potential of attention-based deep learning frameworks in cybersecurity, particularly in mitigating evolving network threats.

title: Machine Learning Classification for Attack Trace Detection in Smart Home Enabled IoT Devices
authors: P Sivanesan, Sompalli Mohan Krishna Bhavani Prasad, Naidu Sree Nayana, Bathula Sai Teja, Anand J V
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Smart homes increasingly rely on interconnected Internet of Things (IoT) devices, offering convenience and automation but raising significant security concerns. Machine learning-based anomaly detection system is proposed to identify malicious activities in smart home networks. The system leverages the BoT-IoT dataset, reflecting real-world IoT botnet traffic, for training and evaluation. Machine learning algorithms utilized, namely Random Forest, Decision Tree, AdaBoost, Artificial Neural Network (ANN), LSTM, and Autoencoder. These algorithms effectively identify a variety of attacks, including data exfiltration, keylogging, OS Fingerprint, UDP Anomalies and service scanning. Data preprocessing to balance the trade-off between attack and normal class instance is incorporated using SMOTE (Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique). Subsequently, this is followed by mapping features to domain specific knowledge is done. Final model optimization and recommendation engine is used which identifies the severity score of anomalies. Random Forest provides the highest accuracy, and also handles class imbalance problem with high scores of Macro precision, Macro recall and Macro F1 score.

title: Deadline and Security-Aware Workflow Scheduling in the Public Cloud Environment
authors: Xinhuan Jiang, Yun Wang, Xiaoze Zhu, Xiumei Tian
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Currently, an increasing number of workflow applications are being deployed in the public cloud environment. One of the most critical challenges for cloud service providers is to optimize the execution costs of workflows while simultaneously meeting the quality service requirements of users, such as security and deadlines. Nevertheless, prior research on the optimization of workflow execution cost ignored the importance of security and deadlines, which are actually essential for user satisfaction. This paper proposes a workflow scheduling algorithm (SACO) that aims to meet deadlines and security needs while also reducing execution costs, using a method inspired by ant colony optimization (ACO). In SACO, we propose a resource selection strategy that is both deadline and security-aware. This strategy involves the combination of idle time slots to select the most suitable resources for tasks in the task scheduling sequence. Furthermore, we design a method that reorders the task scheduling sequence by incorporating pheromone and heuristic information from tasks (such as probabilistic upward rank and security level). It aims to expand the search space and further reduce the costs of workflow execution. The results indicate that the SACO algorithm is generally superior to the comparison algorithms in terms of optimizing execution costs and meeting workflow deadlines.

title: Efficient Gaussian State Preparation in Quantum Circuits
authors: Yichen Xie, Nadav Ben-Ami
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Gaussian states hold a fundamental place in quantum mechanics, quantum information, and quantum computing. Many subfields, including quantum simulation of continuousvariable systems, quantum chemistry, and quantum machine learning, rely on the ability to accurately and efficiently prepare states that reflect a Gaussian profile in their probability amplitudes. Although Gaussian states are natural in continuousvariable systems, the practical interest in digital, gate-based quantum computers demands discrete approximations of Gaussian distributions over a computational basis of size <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2^{n}$</tex>. Because of the exponential scaling of naive amplitude-encoding approaches and the cost of certain block-encoding or Hamiltonian simulation techniques, a resource-efficient preparation of approximate Gaussian states is required. In this work, we propose and analyze a circuit-based approach that starts with singlequbit rotations to form an exponential amplitude profile and then applies the quantum Fourier transform to map those amplitudes into an approximate Gaussian distribution. We demonstrate that this procedure achieves high fidelity with the target Gaussian state while allowing optional pruning of small controlled-phase angles in the quantum Fourier transform, thus reducing gate complexity to near-linear in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathcal{O}(n)$</tex>. We conclude that the proposed technique is a promising route to make Gaussian states accessible on noisy quantum hardware and to pave the way for scalable implementations on future devices. The implementation of this algorithm is available at the Classiq library: https://github.com/classiq/classiq-library.

title: Revolutionizing IC Package Decapsulation with Microwave-Induced-Plasma (MIP) System
authors: Muhamad Hafiz bin Mahmud, Muhamad Hafiz bin Rasul Kalanjiam, Huey Lin Ong, Jiaqi Tang
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: Failure analysis is a collective steps and procedures used to discover the root cause of a failed semiconductor integrated circuit (IC). Amongst the many challenges faced during failure analysis, 2 challenges will be highlighted as the objectives in this study. The first is to preserve the Nickel-plating layer on the lead finger during sample preparation for repackaging process. The current methods of using acid or laser tend to damage this layer which later hinders the ability for wire bonding during repackaging. For the second, the copper wires in a stacked-die IC tend to be damaged during Film Over Wire (FOW) removal with acid etching which causes the IC to fail electrical tests and disrupts the whole failure analysis work flow. With the methodology of using the Microwave Induced Plasma (MIP) system, the desired outcomes for both objectives could be produced with the predefined setting in the system which uses the mixture of oxygen and argon gas to form a plasma effluent that can selectively remove organic materials such as mold compound filler and polymeric materials but remains the inorganic materials such as metals. The novelty in this study is seen in the ability of the MIP to expose the lead fingers while preserving the condition of the Ni-plating layer for repackaging purpose and also seen in the ability to remove the FOW material completely while maintaining the copper wires connectivity in a stacked-die ICs. By achieving the 2 objectives, failure analysis can be continued without any obstacles and the root cause of the failures can be effectively addressed.

title: Photovoltaic Power Prediction Based on Snowmelt Optimization and VMD-PC-BILSTM
authors: Zijian Zhang, Zhuofu Deng, Li Feng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Given the problems of signal nonstationarity, lack of physical constraints, and parameter optimization that easily fall into local optimality in photovoltaic power prediction, a photovoltaic power prediction method based on Snowmelt Optimization Algorithm and Variational Mode Decomposition-Physics-Based Constraint-Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (SAO-VMD-PC-BiLSTM) is proposed. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$K$</tex>-means algorithm is used to cluster photovoltaic data into different weather conditions; the original power sequence is decomposed into multiple Intrinsic Mode Functions(IMFs) using Variational Mode Decomposition (VMD) to reduce signal non-stationarity; Physics-Based Constraint Layer (PC) is designed to embed irradiance, temperature and power boundary constraints to ensure that the prediction results conform to physical characteristics; a Bidirectional LSTM (BiLSTM) is constructed to capture time series features; and the Snow Ablation Optimizer (SAO) is introduced to optimize the physical constraint weights and network hyperparameters globally. The experiment used actual data from a photovoltaic power station in Hebei Province. The proposed method has significantly improved prediction accuracy and stability, providing reliable technical support for high-proportion photovoltaic access to the grid.

title: Classically Enhanced CV-MDI-QKD
authors: Anjali Dhiman, Ryan Aguinaldo, Robert Malaney
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Continuous variable (CV) measurement-deviceindependent (MDI) quantum key distribution (QKD) offers a more robust method to achieve unconditionally secure communications relative to standard CV-QKD. Here, we propose a novel implementation of CV-MDI-QKD that is tolerant to noise and channel loss across a broad range of operational conditions, where a fraction of the optical reference pulses, normally used for local local oscillator construction, is sacrificed for classical communication throughput. We demonstrate that our new protocol enables seamless inclusion of optical classical communication in satellite channels at surprisingly with minimal compromise to the quantum communication performance. Simulation results show that the cost of classical-quantum multiplexing to the QKD key rate as a function of the parameters in many settings is almost negligible. This trade-off implies that high-bandwidth classical communication can be achieved for “almost-free,” and further opens a scalable path for enhancements in the emerging quantum internet.

title: Feature Difference Guided Subpixel Matching for 6D Object Pose Estimation
authors: Yuan Gao, Yuan Gao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Given a single RGB image, we introduce a model-based approach for estimating the 6D pose of unseen objects without any object-specific or task-specific training. Existing methods typically establish 2D correspondences between query and template images at patch centers using ViT. However, these methods often yield inaccurate pose estimates due to deviations between patch centers and the projections of real 3D points. To address this issue, we introduce Feature Difference Guided Subpixel Matching for 6D Object Pose Estimation, a novel approach that: 1) models differences between the template and query images using a feature difference offset prediction module, leveraging local joint features; and 2) refines match locations via subpixel feature search within these regions, resulting in more accurate subpixel-level 2D-3D correspondences. Experimental results on seven datasets from the BOP benchmark demonstrate that our method outperforms existing training-free RGB-based approaches and can be seamlessly integrated with rendering-based refinement methods, advancing the state-of-the-art in RGB-only 6D pose estimation.

title: Privacy-Enhanced Social Proximity Matching Protocols for Decentralized Online Social Networks
authors: Vishakha Salunkhe, Mayuri Satpute, Mayuri Shahir, Roshani V. Pawar
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Online Social Networks (OSNs) have experienced significant growth in recent years, provides central platform for digital communication and social interaction. Although it’s popularity, OSNs raise serious privacy and security concerns, majorly when it comes to sharing personal information and perform profile matching. Although current OSNs allow users to restrict access to their data, they often lack mechanisms to address privacy concerns involving shared or intersecting data from multiple users. Some existing solutions attempt to facilitate user connections through shared attributes; however, these methods frequently expose sensitive profile information to unknown parties results in compromised user’s privacy. To resolve these limitations, a novel model proposed that incorporates neighborhood structures and introduces an asymmetric social proximity measure to more accurately capture the relationship between users. Building on this framework, two privacy-preserving matching protocols are designed that offer different levels of privacy protection while minimizing the risk of information leakage. The proposed protocols evaluated through rigorous analysis of computational and communication costs. In addition to this, it is validated using their effectiveness using real-world social network datasets and extensive simulations, measuring their performance in terms of computation overhead, communication complexity, execution time, and energy consumption. The results demonstrate that this approach offers improvement in privacy and efficiency compared to existing methods.

title: eSLIM++ - An Efficient Subjective Logic Implementation in C++ Providing Easy-to-Use Python Interfaces
authors: Thomas Wodtko, Thomas Griebel, Michael Buchholz
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Multisensor Fusion and Integration for Intelligent Systems (MFI)
abstract: In recent years, subjective logic has gained significant attention for applications in reasoning under uncertainties. By explicitly considering the evidence in each statement or trust, it provides a second-order probability framework that also relates closely to the Dempster-Shafer theory of evidence. Despite theoretical richness, its practical adoption remains limited due to the lack of efficient yet accessible implementations. However, lowering the barrier to the reproducibility of current research findings is key to boosting progress in applying subjective logic to solve contemporary questions. With this work, we present our novel eSLIM++ library, which aims to close this gap between state-of-the-art contributions to subjective logic and their application in real-world scenarios. The library's efficient C++ and CUDA-compatible implementation makes it suitable for evaluating large-scale and complex decision processes. Additionally, Python interfaces provide easy-to-use, low-barrier access that allows for rapid development and evaluation and provides comprehensive examples on a smaller scale. eSLIM++ is publicly available and open-source. It enables researchers and the community to extend its functionality and deploy subjective logic in modern applications such as object tracking and autonomous systems.

title: Multi-Tenant Job Scheduling in Quantum Data Centers
authors: Eneet Kaur, Ramana Kompella, Reza Nejabati
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum data centers represent one of the most viable and practical solutions for scaling quantum computational capabilities. Beyond the challenges posed by hardware, their performance heavily depends on architectural and orchestration strategies, especially when supporting multiple concurrent jobs competing for limited resources. In this work, we address the problem of scheduling multiple quantum computing jobs within a hierarchical architecture. Job execution costs are modeled in terms of local and non-local gates, where non-local operations incur higher overhead due to higher overhead on network resources. We propose a constraint-aware, resource allocation algorithm. We evaluate job reordering heuristics—based on qubit count, circuit depth, and hybrid strategies—that improve scheduling efficiency. Simulation results show that strategic job ordering and resource placement can reduce overall execution cost.

title: Monte Carlo Qudit Stabilizer Sampling with Pauli Frames
authors: Adeeb Kabir, Yipeng Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We demonstrate that Pauli frames, a mathematical object used to efficiently sample qubit stabilizer circuits, can be used to efficiently sample qudit circuits of any prime dimension. Quantum error correcting codes are a central object of study in fault-tolerance quantum computing, which is necessary to realize useful universal quantum computing. Stabilizer codes belong to a large class of well-understood quantum codes that are crucially efficiently simulable on classical hardware using the so-called tableau representation. Popular simulation software like Stim exclusively studies and characterizes qubit codes, which entails repeatedly sampling a noisy quantum circuit with Pauli frames. We highlight the key differences (and fundamental similarities) between qubit and qudit stabilizer tableaus. It then teaches how Pauli frames generate batches of samples given a qudit tableau via two guided examples: one with a random measurement outcome but no noise, and one with a single noise gate.

title: Evolution and Applications of Codeless AI Model Generation Tools for AI-Driven Education
authors: Sang Tae Kim, Yeon Kyu Kim, Ju Won Park, Ki Su Kim, Tae Ho Kim
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: Codeless or no-code AI model generation tools have evolved from Automated Machine Learning (AutoML) to no-code AI platforms, significantly lowering the barrier to AI development. Traditionally, building AI models required extensive programming skills and domain expertise. However, the emergence of AutoML facilitated automated training and optimization, enabling non-experts to leverage machine learning through platforms such as Google AutoML and Microsoft Azure ML. Furthermore, advancements in drag-and-drop code-free AI tools, including Google Vertex AI, IBM Watson AutoAI, and DataRobot, have made AI model development more intuitive. The integration of generative AI has further streamlined model creation, allowing AI models to be built and optimized using natural language inputs, as demonstrated by tools such as ChatGPT API, OpenAI Codex, and Google Bard. Code-free AI tools have broad applications across various industries, enterprises, startups, SMEs, the public sector, and education. Notably, in the education sector, these tools enable educators, students, and administrators to integrate AI-driven solutions without requiring programming expertise, thereby enhancing accessibility and innovation. Despite their advantages, codeless AI tools face challenges related to limited customization for complex AI models, data quality and ethical concerns, and the high costs of cloud-based AI solutions. Future advancements in generative AI are expected to expand the capabilities of these tools, while more user-friendly interfaces will drive broader adoption among non-technical users. Additionally, enhanced AI regulations and ethical frameworks will contribute to greater reliability and transparency in AI models. As code-free AI model generation tools continue to evolve, they are expected to play a crucial role in automating AI development and enhancing accessibility. Their widespread adoption across academic fields, startups, SMEs, and the public sector will contribute to making AI development more inclusive and efficient, fostering innovation across various domains.

title: Servicing Demands between Multiple Pairs of Nodes on Heterogeneous Quantum Networks
authors: Anoop Kumar Pandey, Bheemarjuna Reddy Tamma, M V Panduranga Rao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Future quantum networks are likely to be heterogeneous both in functionality and quality of service. In this work, we present a routing protocol that takes into account this heterogeneity. While functional heterogeneity can be on several aspects, we divide the quantum computers and repeaters on a quantum network into two classes-those that can perform general-purpose quantum computing, including complex error correction routines and those that can only perform basic operations like entangled pair generation and Bell State Measurements. In terms of quality of service, we categorise the quantum nodes as per the probability of successfully, which we call the node reliability, executing a quantum operation and the expected time taken to do so. The routing protocol that we propose seeks to maximise the reliability of sharing EPR pairs between different nodes of a quantum network, with a minimum guaranteed threshold of fidelity and, optionally, a time constraint. We provide simulation results that indicate the effectiveness of the protocol in achieving these objectives.

title: Collision-Aware Autonomous Driving System
authors: Mahdi Seyfipoor, Mohadeseh Parvizi, Siamak Mohammadi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: This paper introduces an advance Collision Avoidance System (CAS) for autonomous vehicles, designed to predict potential collision risks within short time horizons. The system combines CNN-base detection and estimation, filter-based tracking techniques, and optimization methods to enhance prediction accuracy and decision making. A dynamic bicycle motion model is utilized to predict the vehicle’s future states, including grip levels, to address uncertainties and instability inherent in real-world driving conditions. The system employs a Kalman filter with a linear motion model for collision prediction with a single ahead vehicle. To solve occlusion problem, the Intersection over Union (IoU) and Multi Hypothesis Tracking (MHT) are applied. Experimental demonstrate that the proposed system improves accuracy by $\mathbf{3}-\mathbf{5} \boldsymbol{\%}$ compared to state-of-the-art models, while increases collision avoidance success rate by $5 \%$. Additionally, grip estimation minimizes the risk of skidding and instability, enhancing the overall safety and stability of self-driving in real-world conditions.

title: Mapping out the Quantum Channel zoo
authors: Ben Booker, Tianshun Gao, Anne Que, Yuxuan Wan, Lumi Xu, Sujeet Bhalerao, Felix Leditzky
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: This talk presents the Quantum Channel Zoo, a website collecting useful mathematical and information-theoretic facts about various quantum channels. It was created as part of an undergraduate research project conducted at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign. A quantum channel is a mathematical model for noise in a quantum system that hinders quantum communication. A large number of mathematical properties of quantum channels are known, but these are often scattered across the literature. The Quantum Channel Zoo aims to consolidate this knowledge, providing a centralized and easily accessible resource for researchers. Each entry provides the channel's mathematical representations (Kraus operators, Choi state), key properties (entanglement-breaking, degradability), and references to primary literature. We will describe the pedagogical structure of the Illinois Mathematics Lab project that enabled undergraduate students with a background in linear algebra to engage with research literature at the frontier of quantum information science and synthesize it into a public resource. We will present the current scope of the database, including the types of channels documented and the mathematical properties catalogued. Finally, we will briefly discuss the project's technical implementation using ZooDb and its open-source accessibility on GitHub, and demonstrate how new channels can be contributed to the zoo. This talk should be of interest to educators seeking to involve undergraduates in active research as well as researchers in quantum information science who can benefit from or contribute to this evolving resource.

title: Novel Thick Low K Via PFIB Delayering Methodology Development
authors: Benjamin Lo Yuen Sum, Andy Hsu, Guoyu Lan, Toby Chen, Yin Kai Tsai, Vino Hao, Hsiu Li Ssang, Alan Ling
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: Xenon+ plasma focused ion beam (Xe+ PFIB) delayering is gaining popularity for precise back-end copper metallization delayering in the Failure Analysis (FA) process. However, challenges with surface flatness remain, particularly in thick low-k (LK) interlayer dielectrics (ILD) and Vias. Conventional PFIB delayering methods using delayering gas (high copper etch selectivity) can lead to uneven etching rates between highdepth LK copper Vias and ILD, causing the copper Vias to etch faster and form over-etching holes. This can result in issues such as nanoprobing failure and metal short or open. The over-etch unevenness can affect up to few ultralow k (ULK) metal or Via layer when comparing the LK Via region to the LK non-Via region in delayering area, depending on the technology node. To address this, a novel methodology was developed that combines the PFIB delayering gas, tungsten (W) deposition and PFIB oxide etching gas in the PFIB system. This method uses a cycle technique to planarize the surface, improving evenness, reducing processing time and eliminating the risks associated with PFIB delayering gas over etching or lapping process overlapping. This paper will discuss the specific effects of using single PFIB delayering gas and oxide etching gas on thick LK copper Vias, LK ILD and ULK layers. Real FA case results will be discussed to highlight the efficiency of this method, demonstrating successful nanoprobing and comparing the benefits of PFIB with conventional parallel lapping on thick LK Via layers.

title: Message from the Artifact Evaluation Co-Chairs ISSREW 2025

abstract: On behalf of the Organizing Committee, it is our great pleasure to welcome you to the Artifact Evaluation Track of the 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering ISSRE 2025, taking place in São Paulo, Brazil.

title: Message from the Fast Abstracts Co-Chairs ISSREW 2025
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: We are delighted to welcome you to the Fast Abstracts track at ISSRE 2025. Our goal for this track is to bring together researchers and practitioners in Software Reliability Engineering SRE who are pushing boundaries—whether through early-stage ideas, ongoing work, critical reflection, or lessons learned from real-world systems. The contributions in this track aim not only to report results, but also to spark conversations about what reliability means in practice and what challenges lie ahead.

title: Towards an Interpretable Science of Deep Learning for Secure Software Engineering: A Causal Inference View
authors: Denys Poshyvanyk
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: Neural Code Models (NCMs) are rapidly progressing from research prototypes to commercial developer tools. As such, understanding the capabilities and limitations of such models is becoming critical. However, the abilities of these models are typically measured using automated metrics that often only reveal a portion of their real-world performance. While, in general, the performance of NCMs appears promising, currently much is unknown about how such models arrive at decisions or whether practitioners trust NCMs' outcomes. In this talk, I will introduce doCode, a post hoc interpretability framework specific to NCMs that can explain model predictions. doCode is based upon causal inference to enable programming languageoriented explanations. While the theoretical underpinnings of doCode are extensible to exploring different model properties, we provide a concrete instantiation that aims to mitigate the impact of spurious correlations by grounding explanations of model behavior in properties of programming languages. doCode can generate causal explanations based on Abstract Syntax Tree information and software engineeringbased interventions. To demonstrate the practical benefit of doCode, I will present empirical results of using doCode for detecting confounding bias in NCMs as well as detecting code smells in the code generated by state-of-the-art NCMs, such as CodeLlama and Mistral. Finally, I will showcase results of our recent work on how causal inference can be used in the context of secure software engineering research.

title: Typical Solutions of Multi-User Linearly-Decomposable Distributed Computing
authors: Ali Khalesi, Mohammad Reza Deylam Salehi
abstract: We solve, in the typical-case sense, the multi-sender linearly-decomposable distributed computing problem introduced by tessellated distributed computing. We model real-valued encoders/decoders and demand matrices, and assess structural fidelity via a thresholded graph edit distance between the demand support and the two-hop support of the computed product. Our analysis yields: a closed-form second-moment (Frobenius) risk under spike-and-slab ensembles; deterministic links between thresholded GED and norm error; a Gaussian surrogate with sub-exponential tails that exposes explicit recall lines; concentration of GED and operator-norm control; and a compute-capped design with a visible knee. We map the rules to aeronautical and satellite networks.

title: MoAnimate: Bridging the Motion-Oriented Latent Representation Gaps in Human Video Animation
authors: Haipeng Fang, Sheng Tang, Zhihao Sun, Ziyao Huang, Juan Cao, Fan Tang, Yongdong Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Human animation strives to bring static characters to life. Existing methods produce high-quality outcomes for single-frame animation; however, they often fail to maintain satisfactory temporal consistency, especially in facial and hand movements. This limitation arises from commonly used motion modules that do not explicitly model inter-entity relationships. In this work, we introduce MoAnimate, a Motion-oriented Human Animation framework designed to improve inter-entity consistency. Specifically, we extract motion flows from driving videos and transfer them to align the shape of character. During initialization, we propose a motion-oriented latent refinement that optimizes low-frequency subbands to regulate the layout of visual objects along flow trajectories, while preserving random high-frequency subbands to accommodate appearance variations. During denoising, we further introduce a motion-oriented entity attention module to enable direct and efficient interaction among entities within a coordinated subspace. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method significantly enhances temporal consistency, particularly the visual consistency of the entities.

title: Magnetic Field Prediction of PM Motor Based on An Improved Numerical U-Net Neural Network with Output Linear Activation Function
authors: Wenguang Ke, Long Chen, Tong Ben, Zeyu Min, Bo Yin, Yongjian Li
abstract: To overcome computational inefficiency, post-processing limitations, and weak generalization in conventional U-Nets for permanent magnet motor field prediction, this paper proposes an improved numerical U-Net model. The approach replaces the output sigmoid activation with a linear function and utilizes numerical 2D arrays instead of images to facilitate direct value extraction. Generalization is enhanced through a dual-path encoder structure incorporating a dedicated excitation input channel and Dropout layers, facilitating concurrent multi-angle predictions. Computational acceleration is achieved via optimized convolution kernels. Validated on Prius PM motor vector field data, the model demonstrates an 11% accuracy increase, training speeds 1.5 times faster, and prediction speeds 1.3 times faster than standard U-Nets. Additionally, it achieves an average flux density error of below 4%, with single-field computation speeds 15 times faster than those of finite element methods.

title: HFSD Workshop Keynote: ISSREW 2025
authors: Rafael Maiani de Mello
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: Over the past two decades, the software engineering research community has increasingly focused on investigating the human and social aspects of the field. Not rarely, investigations on social aspects still raise controversial opinions on relevance and validity. Besides, it is no secret that sampling and recruiting human participants remain a cornerstone issue. Despite these obstacles, it is undeniable that shifting focus to human-centered investigations led the field to mature in qualitative research, also helping to bridge the gap between research and practice. More recently, the surge in Generative AI has significantly impacted software engineering research,accounting for a substantial share of scientific publications since 2023Ȕ although it has so far only timidly addressed qualitative research. In this keynote, we will engage in a bold yet smooth and open discussion about the current potential of Generative AI to support human-centered studies in Software Engineering, considering the different stages of the research process.

title: Parallel Path Following Control of Maritime Autonomous Surface Ships With Dual Podded Propulsion System
authors: Lingfeng Li, Zhouhua Peng, Anqing Wang, Haodong Liu, Tieshan Li
abstract: This paper presents a parallel path following control scheme for cyber-physical maritime autonomous surface ships (MASSs) equipped with dual-podded propulsion systems. Specifically, an artificial MASS system is constructed using a deep neural predictor with a dual-time deep learning architecture, expanding the path following problem into the virtual space by integrating virtual-reality interaction. Then, based on information provided by the artificial MASS system, a parallel control law with integral action is formulated through computational experiments to ensure accurate tracking of the predefined path by the actual MASS. After that, the derived parallel control law is utilized to simultaneously drive the actual and artificial system during parallel execution. Stability analysis proves that the closed-loop control system is input-to-state stable, and all signals are uniform ultimate bounded. Notably, unlike the existing parallel path following methods that employ generalized forces as control inputs, the proposed approach directly regulates both of the rotational speed and pod angle, thereby enhancing the feasibility in practice. Simulation results are provided to illustrate the efficacy of the proposed approach for an MASS subject to environmental disturbances.

title: Photonic Integrated Circuits for Angle-of-Arrival and Frequency Estimation
authors: Hannah I. Sinigaglio, Michael Gehl, Janusz Murakowski, Timothy Creazzo, Dennis W. Prather
abstract: This paper demonstrates concurrent spatial and spectral signal classification using two photonic integrated circuits (PICs) implemented in a 30-element Ka-band (26.5-40 GHz) antenna array. The received signals are coherently up-converted to the optical-domain using lithium niobate phase modulators. The up-converted RF signal is beamformed in a star-coupler PIC to instantaneously image angle-of-arrival to a single output channel that is amplified and input to an arrayed waveguide grating (AWG) PIC, which instantaneously channelizes the RF frequency into increments of approximately 1 GHz. A switching scheme is used to calibrate the AWG as well as alternate between frequency and beam location measurement. This work implements these devices in a radiometer that can localize RF beams both spatially and spectrally with minimal latency and computational requirements. Future applications will include advanced wireless communications and sensing.

title: Performance Enhancement of DFIG Wind Farms via FACTS Filter Compensators
authors: Mohammad K. AbuHamdah, Adel M. Sharaf, Hamed H. Aly
abstract: The increasing integration of wind energy systems into power grids has raised concerns related to power quality and stability, mainly due to harmonic distortions and reactive power compensation. This work introduces a novel Switched Filter Compensator (SFC) from the Flexible AC Transmission System (FACTS) devices family, employing Insulated Gate Bipolar Transistor (IGBT) switches and advanced Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) control techniques. The proposed SFC is specifically designed to enhance the performance of Doubly Fed Induction Generator (DFIG) wind farms by mitigating power quality issues. The proposed work is tested and validated using MATLAB/Simulink software. The simulations show significant reductions in Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) and improved power quality via varied load types, including induction motors, nonlinear loads, and R-L loads. The device’s versatility extends to maintaining stability under open and short-circuit faults and diverse load scenarios, making it applicable to real-world renewable energy systems. The proposed design offers superior adaptability, robustness, and efficiency in addressing power quality challenges, as evidenced by a comparative analysis with existing literature work, which highlights the filter’s advantages in mitigating harmonic distortions and stabilizing voltage. This study underscores the role of FACTS devices in enhancing grid stability and integrating renewable energy, paving the way for more resilient and efficient power systems. Results show a 42% reduction in reactive power, a 69% reduction in current THD, and around 10 ms recovery from grid voltage disturbances.
