title: Old Rules in a New Game: Mapping Uncertainty Quantification to Quantum Machine Learning
authors: Maximilian Wendlinger, Kilian Tscharke, Pascal Debus
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: One of the key obstacles in traditional deep learning is the reduction in model transparency caused by increasingly intricate model functions, which can lead to problems such as overfitting and excessive confidence in predictions. With the advent of quantum machine learning offering possible advances in computational power and latent space complexity, we notice the same opaque behavior. Despite significant research in classical contexts, there has been little advancement in addressing the black-box nature of quantum machine learning. Consequently, we approach this gap by building upon existing work in classical uncertainty quantification and initial explorations in quantum Bayesian modeling to theoretically develop and empirically evaluate techniques to map classical uncertainty quantification methods to the quantum machine learning domain. Our findings emphasize the necessity of leveraging classical insights into uncertainty quantification to include uncertainty awareness in the process of designing new quantum machine learning models.

title: Making Neural Networks More Suitable for Approximate Clifford+T Circuit Synthesis
authors: Mathias Weiden, Justin Kalloor, John Kubiatowicz, Costin Iancu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Machine Learning with deep neural networks has transformed computational approaches to scientific and engineering problems. Central to many of these advancements are precisely tuned neural architectures that are tailored to the domains in which they are used. In this work, we develop deep learning techniques and architectural modifications that improve performance on reinforcement learning guided quantum circuit synthesis-the task of constructing a circuit that implements a given unitary matrix. First, we propose a global phase invariance operation which makes our architecture resilient to complex global phase shifts. Second, we demonstrate how augmenting data with small random unitary perturbations during training enables more robust learning. Finally, we show how encoding numerical data with techniques from image processing allow networks to better detect small but significant changes in data. Our work enables deep learning approaches to better synthesize quantum circuits that implement unitary matrices.

title: Addressing Infrastructure for Engineering Education in Africa
authors: Daniel Okojie, Samiel Eneje
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: Engineering education in African Higher Education Institutions (HEIs) has been widely criticized for poor infrastructure, which significantly undermines the quality of graduate engineers produced. The deteriorating state of facilities poses a major barrier to effective teaching and learning. This study adopts a socio-cultural perspective to investigate evidence of infrastructural decay in African HEIs offering engineering training and explores how other institutions globally have addressed similar challenges. Using a qualitative, desk-based approach, the study applies the Technological Determinism (TD) framework divided into processes, people, structures, and culture to analyze literature and propose solutions. Findings will lead to a proposed technological transformation model, aligning TD components with key institutional reforms: structures as disruptive innovations, people as HEIs, processes as indigenization of engineering, and culture as engineering culture. The study concludes that transforming engineering infrastructure through a synergy of these interdependent components is crucial for improving educational quality and student outcomes across Africa's HEIs.

title: A Software Package for Detecting Anomalies in User Authentication
authors: Maria Lapina, E. A. Mary Anita, Alexey Vechkanov, Marina Tokmakova, Vitalii Lapin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Anomaly detection is a very important tool for various applications such as intrusion detection, fraud, malfunction, system health monitoring and event detection in IoT devices. Recently, user authentication has become an extremely popular topic in information security research environments. The definition of user authentication is formulated as the process of verifying the identity declared by the user for a system object. Authentication is a method used to distinguish between true or false authentication requests. There are many methods used to authenticate a user that can identify valid users in protected resources. This article discusses various methods for analyzing abnormal user behavior in information systems, namely such methods as machine learning, neural networks, hybrid methods. Based on the analysis of system logs in the Astra Linux operating system, a software package has been developed to identify anomalies when trying to authenticate users.

title: I. Engineering Holistic Sustainability Through Social Responsibility
authors: Murugavel T, Manivannan Kaliappan, N.R. Sheela
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: Social responsibility in engineering is a vital aspect of the profession, encompassing ethical considerations and practical applications aiming to benefit not only humans but also all other life forms and ecosystems as well. This paper attempts to stress the importance of the social responsibility for engineers who play a great role in shaping the future of the world. This means how they should ensure the equitable distribution of technology, bridging the digital divide, and actively engaging local communities in project planning are crucial. In other words, they should move beyond mere regulatory compliance, demanding a proactive commitment to sustainable, equitable, and safe technological development. Though environmental education is already made mandatory as part of the education system in India, as mandated by the Supreme Court of India its effectiveness is still a question. Hence, as an alternative, integrating the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) within any curriculum offers multifaceted advantages for learners. By cantering curriculum design around global challenges like environmental issues, gender parity, and the fight against poverty, educators can craft lessons and activities that at the same time hone language proficiency and deepen awareness of critical world issues. This paper explores ways and means through which the SDGs are incorporated into the curricula for engineers and technologists, like the materials that may be used, making learners develop critical thinking processes and find solutions to the existing problems. Moreover, direct learning, interactive learning approaches such as group discussions, presentations, and projects empower students to investigate SDG-related themes and articulate their perspectives in their respective courses, fostering both subject competence and a sense of global citizenship. In this context this paper takes a case study in Indian context and analysis how the renewable energy is affecting an endangered species Great Indian bustard (Ardeotis nigriceps) to extinction and in the process stresses the need for the engineers to have a holistic approach and in the process guarantee an environmentally sustainable ecosystem to all.

title: Vector Annealing, a Quantum-Inspired Technique: Benchmarking Performance Against Quantum and Simulated Annealing within the BACQ Framework
authors: Stephane Louise
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: In this paper, we aim to compare Vector Annealing (VA), a quantum-inspired metaheuristic introduced by NEC, with other metaheuristics. For this comparison, we utilize Quantum Annealing (QA), as implemented by D-Wave, and the conventional Simulated Annealing (SA) as a reference point for the capabilities of classical hardware with classical algorithms. The applications used for performance evaluation are two important benchmark programs designed to assess quantum hardware. This comparison is relevant because, for benchmarking purposes, it is valuable to have reference points between classical and quantum computing. It is widely thought that quantum computers will take some time to reach the level of relevance currently held by classical computing. This research, focusing on the Q-Score benchmark and Maximum Cardinality Matching (MCM) problems -both part of the MetriQs/BACQ benchmarking initiative- demonstrates this point. Through this work, we also trace the evolution from VA 2.0 to VA 3.0. While VA 2.0 already showed a significant advantage over both QA and SA in constrained problems, VA 3.0 introduces substantial optimizations and overcomes previous limitations in unconstrained problems. This advancement highlights the potential of VA 3.0. Furthermore, this work paves the way for the comprehensive testing of VA within the context of the MetriQs/BACQ quantum benchmark, an application-oriented French benchmarking initiative for quantum computers.

title: Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm on Different Qubit Systems
authors: Seongmin Kim, In-Saeng Suh, Eduardo Antonio Coello Perez, Ryan Landfield, Michael Sandoval, Josh Cunningham, Thomas Beck, Heidi Nelson-Quillin, Erica Stump
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Solving optimization problems is critical across many research domains, but the high dimensionality of parameter spaces often poses significant challenges. The Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) has emerged as a promising approach for accelerating optimization in the Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) era by leveraging both classical and quantum computational resources. However, its performance can vary depending on the underlying quantum hardware architecture. In this work, we evaluate the performance of QAOA on different quantum hardware platforms, specifically, superconducting transmon qubits and trapped-ion qubits, targetting real-world optimization problems formulated as fully connected Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO) instances. We evaluate both the solution quality and time-to-solution using dense QUBO matrices. Furthermore, we show that large-scale problems, such as a 100-bit QUBO instance, can be effectively tackled by integrating quantum computing with high-performance computing (HPC) resources. This study provides practical insights into the strengths and limitations of different qubit technologies and advances the application of quantum computing in solving real-world optimization problems.

title: A Framework for Transforming Engineering Educators Towards Student-Centred Learning
authors: Khairiyah Mohd-Yusof, Umi Solehah Radzali, Syed Ahmad Helmi, Fatin Aliah Phang
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: In a rapidly evolving global context, engineering graduates are expected to possess both technical acumen and essential 21st-century competencies. Student-centred learning (SCL) has emerged as a critical approach to meet these expectations, yet its implementation remains challenging for engineering educators rooted in traditional, teacher-centred paradigms. This study investigates the transformation of engineering educators' teaching conceptions from teachercentred to student-centred paradigms, emphasizing the roles of training, educational ecosystems and personal values. Drawing on a hermeneutic phenomenological approach, the study employed interviews and classroom observations of three engineering lecturers over one semester. The resulting framework identifies three key dimensions-training, ecosystem, and values-that influence the transition. Findings offer practical insights for institutions aiming to foster sustainable adoption of SCL.

title: Polyimide Removal Approach on Redistribution Layer of WLCSP Package Using Microwave Induced Plasma
authors: Wan Nurul Asmak Binti Wan Hasnizam, Siew Ming Lim
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: This paper describes a method for removing the polyimide layer on top of the redistribution layer (RDL) using microwave-induced plasma (MIP) for Wafer Level Chip Scale Packaging (WLCSP). This method will help to prevent over-etching and artifact from happening on RDL metal traces. When it comes to finding a defect, especially for IV curve that shows open, visual inspection will become the most important step and need to be done thoroughly to see if there is any presence of microcrack at the RDL metal trace. Smaller package size increases the difficulty of finding the defect using a high-power scope due to poor imaging resolution. In this paper, the inspection of RDL metal trace was done using scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The elimination of polyimide was carried out through the use of MIP by adjusting two things which are the oxygen flow rate and the number of etching cycles.

title: Visual-Servoing Control Assessment for a 2DOF Flexible Joint Robot Based in LQR
authors: Manuel Alejandro Páez Frías, Tatiana Manrique
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: This paper assesses the integration of artificial vision into the real-time control loop of a two-degree-of-freedom flexible joint robot (FJR) from QUANSER®, emphasizing image processing and hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) control using an LQR strategy. The primary objective is to assess the viability and performance of a low-cost visual system when integrated into a robot's control loop. The assessment involves comparing the visual servoing system's performance against that of a traditional controller with encoders in the loop to validate precision and consistency. The camera employed represents only 11% of the encoders' cost, reinforcing its potential as a truly low-cost alter-native for avoiding technological obsolescence from the encoders. The evaluated visual-servoing system is tested experimentally using LQR for set-point tracking, parametric robustness, and disturbance rejection. The results indicate that while visual-servoing control enables real-time operation, it remains more susceptible to latency and disturbances than controllers with encoders in the loop. Nevertheless, the visual system demonstrates promising adaptability for industrial automation, particularly in dynamic production environments -a crucial characteristic of Industry 5.0.

title: From Static to Quasi-Dynamic: Reconsidering Scheduling and Memory in SDF Compilers
authors: Pedro Ciambra, Anaëlle Cloarec, Hervé Yviquel, Mickaël Dardaillon, Maxime Pelcat
publish: 2025 IEEE/SBC 37th International Symposium on Computer Architecture and High Performance Computing Workshops (SBAC-PADW)
abstract: Synchronous Dataflow (SDF) is a popular Model of Computation (MoC) for signal processing applications, thanks to its static analizability and provably deadlock-free execution. SDF compilers have traditionally prioritized static schedulers for their low runtime latency, particularly for signal processing and embedded systems. However, the conventional static technique of converting of multi-rate graphs to single-rate equivalents introduces scalability challenges through exponential graph growth and lost coarse-grained symmetry information. We revisit the idea of runtime scheduling for static dataflow and explore a tradeoff between latency, binary size and compilation time.Our approach introduces a specialized “quasi-dynamic” runtime scheduler and memory manager that leverages static topology information to precompute buffer sizes and allows out-of-order execution of actor firings, while thread assignment and memory allocation are handled at runtime through the OpenMP runtime and standard allocation primitives (malloc). By preserving multi-rate actor relationships, we avoid the node explosion inherent to single-rate conversion and improve the feasibility of SDF for a previously unreachable class of workloads. Comparative analysis of the current prototype against the Preesm static scheduler on the degridder radio astronomy application show, on average, 12.2x compilation time speedup and 4.4x smaller binary sizes, while only suffering 1.4x slowdown.

title: Cascaded Dual U-Net (CD-UNet) Approach For Lane Detection in Autonomous Driving
authors: T Akshwin, N Nalini, Vinay Deep Jaiswal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Lane detection is a critical component of autonomous driving systems, providing essential information for vehicle navigation and safety. This paper presents a new approach to lane detection using a Cascaded Dual U-Net (CD-U-net) model defined by us, which leverages the strengths of convolutional neural networks to improve accuracy and robustness in varied driving conditions. Our method uses Decoder and Encoder architecture by incorporating advanced feature extraction techniques to better capture lane markings and road boundaries. The proposed model is trained and evaluated on a diverse dataset of road scenes, demonstrating superior performance in terms of accuracy and loss function. Experimental results indicate that our approach effectively handles challenging scenarios such as lane occlusions, varying lighting conditions, and different road types. This work advances state-of-the-art in lane detection for autonomous driving, offering a more reliable and adaptive solution for realworld applications.

title: DuqueXII: a Robotics-Based Approach for Mitigating Domestic Accidents in Early Childhood
authors: Leffer Trochez, Jorge Lopez-Jimenez, Nicanor Quijano
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: Domestic accidents remain a leading cause of injury in early childhood, particularly within home and daycare environments. This paper presents DuqueXII, a robotic platform designed to support early detection and prevention of such incidents through real-time sensing and intelligent inference. The system combines a Pan-Tilt-Zoom (PTZ) camera with computer vision algorithms and a network of environmental sensors to monitor proximity, temperature, sound, and flame presence. DuqueXII features full 360-degree mobility, articulated head movement, and RGB LED indicators for intuitive state and alert signaling. Built on a hybrid ROS2-based architecture, it is optimized for responsive real-time operation. The robot was showcased during an outreach event at the university, where its functionality was demonstrated to children in a controlled environment, providing qualitative validation of its safety, engagement, and monitoring capabilities. We describe the design, implementation, and pre-liminary evaluation of DuqueXII, highlighting its potential for deployment in domestic and childcare settings.

title: A Unified Incentive Framework for Analysing Fees and Rewards in Distributed Ledgers
authors: Luigi Vigneri, Darcy Camargo, Olivia Saa, Andrew Cullen
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: The rapid advancements in distributed ledger technology (DLT) have produced novel systems combining high throughput, low latency and smart contract programmability. However, designing robust incentives schemes for such advanced protocols remains a critical challenge. Weaknesses in existing incentives schemes, particularly in reward distribution and incentive alignment, can hinder protocol adoption and long-term sustainability. In this paper, we propose a unified framework for comprehensive analysis of a wide range of DLTs. Our framework extends existing methodologies for studying transaction fee mechanisms by incorporating reward distribution among multiple actors involved in the consensus process, addressing critical gaps in the literature. We introduce a categorisation of incentive mechanisms and apply the above framework to the modern consensus protocols of Sui and IOTA, offering comparisons with more ‘traditional’ systems including Ethereum and Bitcoin.

title: Implementation of Random Forest and Convolutional Neural Network for EEG-Based Epileptic Seizure Detection
authors: Priyanka Soni, Linesh Raja, Vaibhav Bhatnagar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: This research studies the detection of epileptic seizures by the use of electroencephalogram (EEG) signals, a critical task in medical diagnosis that is greatly affected by machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) techniques. Epilepsy is a neurological condition that affects more than 50 million people worldwide, as reported by the World Health Organization. Epilepsy is consistent with the third Sustainable Development Goal (SDG), which is “Good health and well-being.” This work uses machine learning-based Random Forest classifiers based on tuning parameters and deep learning-based Convolutional Neural Network approaches to identify time-series data representations of EEG signals. The goal of this study is to find the best algorithm for handling structured and unstructured EEG data in the real world by comparing Random Forest (RF) and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for EEG-based seizure detection. This study used publicly available epileptic seizure recognition data points from the UCI Machine Learning Repository of EEG signal time series. The preprocessed data fed to the classifiers Random Forest (RF) and Convolutional Neural Network, which achieved accuracies of 96.48 and 79.78, respectively. In terms of precision, recall, sensitivity, and accuracy, the RF classifier outperformed the CNN. These findings help to improve automated seizure detection, enhance clinical decision-making, and connect with SDG health goals. In the end, the study shows that traditional machine learning methods that work with structured EEG data are effective. It also shows that deep learning architectures need to be optimized to make them work better.

title: Quantum Computing-Enabled Contingency Analysis for Power Systems
authors: Yuqi Jiang, Zhiding Liang, Yan Li, Qiang Guan, Ganesh Kumar Venayagamoorthy
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The rapid development of quantum computing has provided a ground-breaking tool for solving problems that are insurmountable on classical computers. In the power system domain, quantum computing is still in the nascent stage, with limited but ongoing studies. The Quantum Approximation Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) has been applied in solving several NPhard problems and can be further studied to address challenging problems in power systems. Key applications include contingency analysis, optimal power flow, and unit commitment, among others. With the significant integration of renewable energy, the intermittent nature of renewable energy introduces substantial volatility to the system. An overhead contingency analysis is required to evaluate the possible system outage scenarios, which will identify critical contingencies to maintain system stability. However, the contingency analysis is a prototypical NP-Hard problem, requiring substantial classical computation resources. In this work, QAOA is developed for the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N-k$</tex> contingency analysis on line contingency as well as the general contingency scenarios, with the aim of minimizing the shedding of the power load while ensuring the power flow constraints. A tailored objective function is developed to encode the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N-k$</tex> contingency condition as well as the power flow loss constraints into a problem Hamiltonian for QAOA computation. The developed method is verified on IEEE 9- and 14-bus systems compared with classical methods as the baseline. In addition, a QAOA parameter study including the number of QAOA parameters, the number of repetitions of the quantum circuits execution, and the number of iteration steps of the classical optimization algorithm, is conducted to offer insights for the parameter tuning under different problem sizes. This work is anticipated to establish a quantum framework for solving critical and complex power system problems in the Noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) era.

title: Decentralized Secure Data Sharing for Government Systems using Blockchain and IPFS
authors: Rambala Sri Veera Aliveni Sindhu Mahija, P Krishna Prasad
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: In the digital era, governments are increasingly digitizing citizens' data, requiring secure mechanisms for data sharing across organizations and departments. Addressing vulnerabilities associated with centralized storage and third-party authentication servers, which are susceptible to attacks and misuse by malicious actors, a novel approach leveraging IPFS and Blockchain is proposed. This method eliminates reliance on centralized servers, ensuring security through decentralized storage and verification mechanisms. Data requesters generate private keys and encrypt multiple attributes before storing them in IPFS, with the resulting hash code recorded on Blockchain for verification. Data owners authenticate requesters by comparing hash codes stored on Blockchain, utilizing Blockchain's tamper-resistance, as any data alteration causes hash discrepancies, preserving data integrity. The system employs ECC for key generation and encryption, with an alternative lightweight algorithm, CHACHA20, proposed to optimize computational efficiency. To enhance authentication, address proof documents are integrated, and smart contracts coded in Solidity manage data storage and retrieval within the Blockchain. This solution provides a secure and efficient framework for government data sharing, mitigating risks associated with traditional centralized systems.

title: Smart Street Pole and Mitigation of Clogging in Drainage System
authors: Shashank T S, Shreekesh S, Shantika Prashanthkumar Shet, Sanjay R, Tanuja H, Satish B A
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Urban areas are rapidly expanding with the need for intelligent infrastructure to tackle issues related to environmental monitoring and drainage. This paper describes an IoT-enabled dual-purpose device that consists of a Smart Street Pole and a Drainage Clogging Detection Unit. The Smart Pole collects data on temperature, humidity, air quality, and noise while also enabling real-time monitoring and uploading data to the cloud. The Drainage Clogging Detection Unit collects motion sensor data combined with GPS location sensors to detect clogging in drainage and provide location data via LoRa. The experimental results show reliable sensor accuracy, reliable communication range (200m LOS), and reliable clogging response time. The proposed system provided a scalable and cost-effective solution for real-time urban infrastructure surveillance and monitoring, which has several additional benefits such as predictive maintenance and integration into smart networking cities.

title: Short Video Content Generation and Style Transfer Method Based on Generative Adversarial Networks
authors: Yangchen An, Xiaozhen Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenges of style inconsistency and insufficient personalization in short video content generation by proposing a novel method based on Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN). The proposed approach integrates style modeling and user preference control within a unified deep generative architecture, achieving a coherent combination of stylistic diversity, semantic consistency, and personalized expression. The model adopts an enhanced U-Net structure augmented with a style encoder and a user preference controller, and is trained end-to-end using adversarial learning and multi-objective loss functions. Extensive experiments conducted on the constructed ShortVid-Pref-500 dataset demonstrate that the proposed model outperforms baseline methods across multiple metrics, including structural similarity, style consistency, video perceptual quality, and user preference alignment. In particular, significant improvements are observed in preference matching accuracy and naturalness of stylization. The results validate the model's adaptability and scalability in personalized short video generation tasks. This work not only introduces a structurally innovative framework but also provides a controllable and interpretable paradigm for creative video generation, expanding the frontier of generative multimedia content creation.

title: Emotion Recognition of Shadow and Social Personalities using IoT-Enabled Video Analytics
authors: Praveen Kulkarni, Rajesh T M, Naresh P, A. Naresh, Pasupala Mahesh, C.Nagesh
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Accurate interpretation of human emotions is critical for applications in mental health monitoring, adaptive human–computer interaction, and personalized content delivery. This study presents a novel framework for analyzing shadow personality and social personality traits using integrated IoT-based sensing and video analytics. The framework captures and processes multi-source behavioral and visual cues, enabling robust, real-time personality-linked emotion detection under variable environmental conditions. Advanced feature extraction techniques, multimodal data fusion, and optimized classification strategies are employed to enhance recognition accuracy. The proposed approach achieved a classification accuracy of 94.6

title: Adaptive PID Control Using RBF Neural Networks for Parallel Manipulators
authors: Kevin David Ortega Quiñones, Carlos Andrés Mesa Montoya, Daniela Buitrago Largo, Germán A. Holguín
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: Although adaptive control has been widely studied in nonlinear robotic systems, many traditional formulations rely on adaptive laws derived from the gradient algorithm, whose slow convergence can compromise tracking accuracy and system stability. This work presents a methodological proposal based on the design and implementation of an adaptive controller using radial basis function neural networks (RBFNN), applied to 2RRR-type parallel manipulators with partially known dynamics. The strategy is based on the use of auxiliary variables to avoid explicit acceleration computation, and on the incorporation of leakage terms and sliding mode control to ensure the exponential convergence of estimation and tracking errors to a bounded set. As part of the analysis, a comparative scheme is developed between the classical controller and the proposed approach, evaluating their performance through metrics such as root mean square error (RMSE), mean absolute error (MAE), and standard deviation, over predefined trajectories. The experimental results show an improvement in the system's precision and robustness under perturbations, supporting the relevance of the adaptive approach over conventional schemes in fine tracking tasks.

title: Probabilistic Representation of Commutative Quantum Circuit Models
authors: Richard Yu, Jorge Ramirez Osorio, Elaine Wong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: In commuting parametric quantum circuits, the Fourier series of the pairwise fidelity can be expressed as the characteristic function of random variables. Furthermore, expressiveness can be cast as the recurrence probability of a random walk on a lattice. This construction had previously been applied to the group composed only of Pauli- <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Z$</tex> rotations. In this paper, we generalize this probabilistic strategy to any commuting set of Pauli operators. To this end, we can leverage an algorithm that uses the tableau representation of Pauli strings to yield a unitary from the Clifford group that, under conjugation, simultaneously diagonalizes our commuting set of Pauli rotations. Furthermore, we fully characterize the underlying distribution of the random walk using stabilizer states and their basis state representations. This would allow us to tractably compute the lattice volume and variance matrix used to express the frame potential. Together, this demonstrates a scalable strategy to calculate the expressiveness of parametric quantum models.

title: Cutting FLOPs Overhead with SNT and LReSuMe: A Noise-Tolerant Spiking Classifier
authors: Qixuan Li, Lei Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Spiking neural networks (SNNs) operate with discrete spikes, naturally aligning with temporal data and offering sub-milliwatt operation. Their accuracy, however, can collapse when spike timing is perturbed by sensor or environmental noise. We address this vulnerability with two innovations. First, this study introduces a Sensitive Noise-Threshold (SNT), a learnable variable firing threshold that adapts online to the local noise statistics, suppressing spurious spikes while preserving salient ones. Second, this study proposes the Limited Remote Supervised Method (LReSuMe), a lightweight gradient-free rule that supports online learning and enhances spike intensity at the target time. Compared with an equivalently-sized <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$400 \times 10 \text{ANN}$</tex>, the single-layer SNN in this study requires 18% fewer floating-point operations (FLOPs) for inference (6610 vs 8029 FLOPs per sample) and 90% fewer FLOPs for weight update (1200 vs 12030 FLOPs per sample). Despite a marginal 5% drop in peak accuracy, the SNN is 52.79% more accurate than the ANN when 250 random pixels are corrupted, demonstrating a substantial robustness gain under severe noise conditions. These results, obtained entirely in software, indicate that the SNT + LReSuMe framework delivers robust, low-resource online learning; mapping the design onto an FPGA is left as ongoing work for energy-constrained vision sensors.

title: Room-Temperature Emulation of Single-Electron Devices
authors: Artur Michalak, Eryk Halubek, Krzysztof Pomorski, Maciej Dolecki, Wojciech Nowakowski, Aleksander Zak
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: In this work, we present a classical analog system that emulates position-based semiconductor qubits in one-, two-dimensional, and circular geometries, operating at room temperature. We report certain agreement between experimental results and simulations for linear Wannier qubits, rings (which we call semiconductor rotons), and planar qubits based on two-dimensional rectangular potential minima.

title: A Quantum Search Method for Quadratic and Multidimensional Knapsack Problems
authors: Sören Wilkening, Andreea-Iulia Lefterovici, Lennart Binkowski, Marlene Funck, Michael Perk, Robert Karimov, Sándor Fekete, Tobias J. Osborne
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Solving combinatorial optimization problems is a promising application area for quantum algorithms in real-world scenarios. In this work, we extend the “Quantum Tree Generator” (QTG), previously proposed for the 0-1 Knapsack Problem, to the 0-1 Quadratic Knapsack Problem (QKP) and the Multidimensional Knapsack Problem (MDKP). The QTG constructs a superposition of all feasible solutions for a given instance and can therefore be utilized as a promising state preparation routine within amplitude amplification to produce high-quality solutions. Previously, QTG-based search was tested on the 0-1 Knapsack Problem, where it demonstrated the potential for practical quantum advantage, once quantum computers with a few hundred logical and fully connected qubits are available. Here, we evaluate the algorithm's performance on QKP and MDKP against the classical solver Gurobi. To facilitate large-scale evaluations, we employ an advanced benchmarking technique that enables runtime predictions for instances with up to 2000 variables for QKP and up to 1500 variables and 100 constraints for MDKP. Our results indicate that QTG-based search can produce high-quality solutions with competitive runtimes for QKP. However, its performance declines for MDKP, highlighting the challenges quantum algorithms face when tackling highly constrained optimization problems.

title: On-Chip Optical Pulse Modulation for Scalable Superconducting Quantum Computers
authors: Ryosuke Matsuo, Hidehisa Shiomi, Jun Shiomi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: This poster proposes an on-chip optical pulse modulation system for scalable superconducting quantum computers. Towards the scalable design, qubit control systems need to be located in the cryogenic environment to reduce the number of interconnections across the room temperature and the cryogenic regions. The cryogenic CMOS-based qubit control system is a promising approach, yet it is a bottleneck that exhausts the cooling capacity of the dilution refrigerator. In order to eliminate this bottleneck while providing the ability to control multiple quibits with a minimum necessary number of interconnections, this poster extends the RoF (Radio-over-Fiber) system where optical signals are directly fed from the Room Temperature (RT) region to a PD (PhotoDetector) mounted near the transmon qubit through low-loss and high-speed fibers. Unlike the conventional RoF system, the proposed system employs cryogenic silicon photonics-based modulators in the intermediate part for executing gate operations individually at each transmon qubit with a minimum necessary number of fibers across the RT and the cryogenic regions. Evaluation results show that the proposed system eliminates the power consumption by 79.5% compared with the cryogenic CMOS-based design. The proposed system achieves comparable gate fidelity to the control system generating fully customized RF pulses in the RT environment.

title: Automated Defect Detection in Package Physical Components Using Deep Learning Architecture-ResNeXt-101 with ATSS
authors: M. Z. Azlan, W. S. Lim, S. Chandra Mohan, T. H. Chor
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenges of defect detection in package physical components through manual inspection, which relies on operator evaluation. Human fatigue, resulting in eye strain and discomfort, often leads to fluctuating outcomes, diminished accuracy, and an increased risk of overlooking defects. This variability in human judgment causes inconsistent quality control and limits the effectiveness of data collection for gross screening. To overcome these issues, we present the development and validation of an automated defect detection system using Deep Learning Model supported by ResNeXt-101-ATSS. This method was specifically tailored for High Volume Manufacturing (HVM) environments. Our study evaluates the system's accuracy and success rate, demonstrating its effectiveness in enhancing quality control processes and ensuring more consistent and reliable defect detection.

title: Enhancing Biomedical Engineering Education: The Impact of Integrated Professional Internships Shaped by Academia and Industry Partnerships
authors: Agustín E. Carvajal-Rivera, Raúl Villarreal-Lara
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: The Biomedical Engineering field is rapidly evolving according to technological needs in healthcare and requires professionals with outstanding knowledge, abilities, and competencies. Integrating Professional Internships into undergraduate Biomedical Engineering programs is strongly believed to significantly impact students' skills and competency development, thereby enhancing their professional perspectives, opportunities, and growth. This paper aims to test the impact of professional internships on students' skill and competency development, career prospects, and industry readiness from the perspectives of employers, stakeholders, and students. By analyzing data from surveys on competency levels of Biomedical Engineering students (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{n} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{1 0 0}$</tex> out of 180) who participated in professional internships, this longitudinal study explores how these experiences, planned and executed by academia and industry partners, enhance technical skills, problem-solving abilities, and real world application understanding. The analysis included both descriptive statistics and advanced statistical analyses such as ANOVA and chi-square tests. The findings revealed that students who participated in Professional Internships were significantly more likely to receive job offers <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(p$</tex>-value <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.0011)$</tex> compared to their peers who had other experiences. Additionally, ANOVA results indicated that Professional Internships contributed significantly to the development of specific competencies (SBI0300, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p}=0.0012$</tex> and SBI0500, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p}=\mathbf{0. 0 0 0 1}$</tex>), which are critical for diagnosing problems and managing medical technology. Experience satisfaction and academic performance (GPA) showed no significant differences, suggesting internships did not negatively impact academic achievements. These results underscore the importance of industry-academia collaborations in providing meaningful and practical experiences that prepare Biomedical Engineering students for professional challenges. When these internships are embedded within the curriculum, students demonstrate better preparedness for their careers compared to peers who opted for other experiential learning opportunities. This study provides robust evidence that professional internships substantially enhance employability and competency development in the rapidly evolving field of Biomedical Engineering.

title: Grover's Algorithm for Image Edge Detection
authors: Pulak Ranjan Giri, Kazuhiro Saito
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Grover's algorithm is one of the most significant quantum algorithms, enabling the search for a marked element in an unsorted database quadratically faster than classical search algorithms. We utilize Groves's algorithm to detect the edges of a digital image faster than any classical edge detection methods. The high success probability of our method in detecting image edges, compared to most existing quantum edge detection methods, makes it a more suitable candidate for use in the presence of noise on current quantum devices. We implemented our model for the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \times 2$</tex> blocks of the image using a two-qubit Qiskit circuit with the QASM simulator and the noisy IBM Sydney(fake) device, making it suitable for most of the current NISQ devices.

title: Multi-Modal AI for Cyber-Physical Threat Detection in Smart Cities: A Unified Framework for Video, Audio, and Network Data
authors: Prajwalasimha S N, Sumathi D, Nilesh Shelke, Amit Pimpalkar, Dilip Kumar Jang Bahadur Saini, Rajeshwar Balla
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The growing convergence of physical and digital infrastructures in smart cities has brought sophisticated cyber-physical threat vectors that cannot be solved effectively with unimodal or siloed security solutions. This work presents UMTD-Net, a new Unified Multi-Modal Threat Detection framework that harnesses the respective strengths of video, audio, and network telemetry data for end-to-end cyber-physical threat detection in smart city settings. UMTD-Net integrates Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) based spatio-temporal video analysis, spectrogram-based Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) based acoustic anomaly detection, and Transformer (TM) based sequential network traffic behavior modeling. The new architecture uses a cross-attention-based fusion layer to dynamically merge modality-specific embedding’s, allowing real-time, context-aware threat reasoning across domains. Extensive evaluations on benchmark datasets—UCF-Crime (video), UrbanSound8K (audio), and TON_IoT (network)—establish UMTD-Net's state-of-the-art performance with 96.8% overall detection accuracy, 93.2% F1-score, and a decision latency of less than 55ms, significantly outperforming state-of-the-art unimodal baselines. The framework is also scalable to deploy at scale across edge-cloud infrastructures, and can be applied to real-time surveillance, public safety, and critical infrastructure protection. This work is the first to integrate multi-modal AI for cyber-physical threat intelligence, and offers a scalable, generalizable, and explainable foundation for autonomous urban cybersecurity in the smart and connected city era.

title: Efficient Lightweight Trust Model and Traffic-Aware Clustered Routing in Internet of Things (IoT) Guided Vehicular Ad-Hoc Networks
authors: Govindaraj Ramkumar
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Vehicular Ad hoc Network (VANETs) plays a significant part in the field of smart communication which includes safety communication and traffic awareness. Due to the huge number of devices achieving maximum accuracy and security becomes a complicated task and it is under an open research area in vehicular communication. Overcome such a drawback in this article, an efficient lightweight trust model with traffic aware clustering and routing is developed in the internet based vehicular communication. The core modules of this process are network and attack model construction, cluster head selection with cluster formation, cluster dis election, cluster adoption, vehicles routing and efficient lightweight trust model. This proposed model is simulated in NS2 software and the parameters which are calculated for the performance findings are total trust value, anomaly detection ratio, computation cost and communication cost calculation. As compared with the existing methods this proposed model achieve maximum trust value which helps to maximize the performance of the vehicular communication.

title: Data-Driven Approach for Water Quality Monitoring in Aquaculture using IoT
authors: Akshaya B S, Aswiga D P, Kaarthik kumaran T S, Abinaya N S
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: India’s aquaculture sector, expanding at an annual growth rate of 6–7%, plays a vital role in food security and economy. However, large-scale farming and intensive aquaculture practices have led to the decline in the water quality and increase in the aquatic diseases, making water quality management a critical challenge. A data-driven IoT-based framework is proposed to monitor and manage key parameters of pond water in real-time. The system integrates Arduino UNO, Raspberry Pi, sensors, and a webcam to measure temperature, pH, and turbidity. Temperature and pH data are collected using temperature and pH sensors through Arduino, while the Raspberry Pi processes the data and performs image-based turbidity analysis using Laplacian variance techniques. The collected data is transmitted to the ThingSpeak cloud platform, enabling remote monitoring. A fuzzy logic-based decision-making model evaluates deviations from optimal ranges 26– 33°C for temperature, 7.5–8.5 for pH, and turbidity thresholds based on image variance. When a deviation is detected in the processed data, the system automatically activates and notifies the user through email alerts (SMTP). This data-driven approach, integrating IoT, cloud computing, and intelligent decision-making, enhances aquaculture sustainability by ensuring early risk detection, reducing manual intervention, and optimizing resource utilization. The proposed system demonstrates the potential of AIoT-driven smart aquaculture, paving the way for scalable, cost-effective, and environmentally sustainable fish farming practices.

title: Netravani : AI based System for Translating Eye Movements into Speech
authors: Shashikiran S, Srinivas Babu N, Kirana B V, S V Darshan Patil, Pramod R, Shravan Kumar Gogi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Visually impaired people continue to struggle with making sense of the world around them and interpreting social signs, often exacerbated by the expense and internet requirement of current aid technologies. This work presents NETRAVANI, a low- cost AI powered smart glasses system designed to provide real-time assistive to visually impaired. The system integrates object detection, optical character recognition (OCR), facial emotion recognition, and text-speech-conversion having wearability, and compactness in mind. Developed using Raspberry Pi, embedded vision models, speech synthesis tools. Netravanni functions completely offline, enabling effortless operation in remote and low – resources environments. By translation visual and emotional cues into audio feedback, Netreavani increases autonomy impairments and fosters, more meaningful human interactions. The proposed system the facial emotion recognition module is able to achieve approximately 70% accuracy at 8 FPS inference speed, and the scene description module achieves BLEU-1 ≈ 0.65 and METEOR ≈ 0.52. By providing real-time context-sensitive audio feedback, NetraVaani provides an inexpensive, accessible, and offline assistive tool for enhancing social interaction and environmental perception in visually impaired users.

title: A Fractional and Stochastic Model for Axonal Microtubule Bundles Under Dynamic Loading
authors: P M Promince, P A Gowri Sankar, R Madhanraj, P. R. Sivaraman, G Karthikeyan, K. Karthikkumar
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Traumatic axonal injury is a key feature of diffuse brain trauma, often caused by structural failure in axonal microtubule bundles under mechanical stress. Existing models typically assume simple viscoelastic behavior and deterministic rupture thresholds, limiting their ability to represent biological variability and time-dependent damage. This study introduces an improved computational model that incorporates fractional-order viscoelastic damping and probabilistic rupture based on both strain magnitude and rate. A two-dimensional network formulation is used to simulate load redistribution and spatially heterogeneous failure, capturing rupture cascades across microtubule bundles. The enhanced model shows significantly greater energy dissipation and more realistic damage progression compared to the original model. It predicts nonlinear and rate-sensitive rupture patterns consistent with experimental findings. Simulation results across various loading conditions demonstrate the model’s ability to reproduce key features of microstructural damage, such as delayed failure onset, progressive degradation, and sensitivity to dynamic strain inputs. This work advances the modeling of axonal injury and offers a framework for more accurate prediction of brain tissue response under traumatic loading.

title: A Study of Sentiment Analysis on Distance Learning from Textual Data using Natural Language Processing
authors: Md. Anikur Rahaman, KBM Tahmiduzzaman, Md Mynul Islam, Tasriful Haque, Tazwar Mahmud, Julias Caeser Joy Bose
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Online learning is a hot trend due to it being user-friendly and flexible, so it is important to understand people's perspectives towards on-line learning. To do so, they analyze 16,530 tweets regarding online education using natural language processing (NLP) tools. Our aim is to identify the key components of views toward distance learning, positive, negative and neutral After preprocessing the data and applying Text Blob to check, Linear Regression, Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Decision Tree Classifier are employed as machine learning models for sentiment classification. On the other hand, in overall accuracy the best performer was Linear Regression model with 88% score. Based on the findings, user's attitude is more expressed positively towards online learning like it is flexible and convenient to learn while negative reviews instigated due to the lack of real interaction and digital divided. Policymakers and academic institutions can develop digital education policies to fulfil the needs of the learner which have been identified in this study The study contributes to reaching a consensus on sentiment analysis research in the field of education and broadening insights into the public debate surrounding online learning.

title: Marine Chlorophyll Prediction and Driver Analysis Based on LSTM-RF Hybrid Models
authors: Zhouyao Qian, Yang Chen, Baodian Li, Shuyi Zhang, Zhen Tian, Gongsen Wang, Tianyue Gu, Xinyu Zhou, Huilin Chen, Xinyi Li, Hao Zhu, Shuyao Zhang, Zongheng Li, Siyuan Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Marine chlorophyll concentration is an important indicator of ecosystem health and carbon cycle strength, and its accurate prediction is crucial for red tide warning and ecological response. In this paper, we propose a LSTM-RF hybrid model that combines the advantages of LSTM and RF, which solves the deficiencies of a single model in time-series modelling and nonlinear feature portrayal. Trained with multi-source ocean data (temperature, salinity, dissolved oxygen, etc.), the experimental results show that the LSTM-RF model has an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 5 3 8 6}$</tex>, an MSE of 0.005806, and an MAE of 0.057147 on the test set, which is significantly better than using LSTM (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}=\mathbf{0. 0 2 0 8}$</tex>) and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R F}\left(\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}=\right. 0.4934)$</tex> alone, respectively. The standardised treatment and sliding window approach improved the prediction accuracy of the model and provided an innovative solution for high-frequency prediction of marine ecological variables.

title: Nano-Probing Technique for Stuck-at Fault of System on Chip (SoC)
authors: Xixiong Wei, Xinyi Lin, Shilu Zhou, Na Mei, Shuai Wang, Minqiang Peng, Keqing Ouyang
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: As the semiconductor industry progresses toward Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI), traditional failure analysis techniques are increasingly challenged to address subtle resistive failure mechanisms such as transition faults, bridging defects, and slow-to-rise/fall anomalies. Nano-probing (NP), an advanced technique combining scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with nanoscale electrical probing, has emerged to overcome these limitations. Among NP methodologies, Electron Beam Absorbed Current (EBAC) is widely employed for path-level local fault isolation, while Conductive Atomic Force Microscopy (C-AFM) enables transistor-level fault localization. Stuck-at faults (SAFs), a dominant contributor to yield loss in modern semiconductor manufacturing, become increasingly critical as integrated circuits (ICs) grow in logical complexity and physical scale. Although SAF localization is typically achieved through Design-for-Testability (DFT) diagnostic tools, these tools only provide probabilistic identification of suspected nets and cells. This paper demonstrates the application of NP technology to SAF diagnosis through three case studies, highlighting its superior spatial resolution, quantitative defect characterization capability, and compatibility with DFT-guided workflows.

title: Revolutionizing Battery Maintenance Through IoT-based Inverter Monitoring for Smart Energy Systems
authors: Ragapreeti D, T D Subha, Mohanalakshmi S, Poojashree T, Rakshitha J, Divya S
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Maintaining distilled water levels in inverter batteries is critical for achieving peak efficiency and lifespan. This study describes a smart monitoring system that uses an Alert Works Spot Water sensor to detect the presence of distilled water in lead-acid batteries. The solution streamlines the notification process by delivering SMS alerts to both customers and service providers, avoiding the need for frequent human checks. Furthermore, the system calculates the available backup time based on real-time load conditions, resulting in an accurate and dynamic projection of power availability during outages. The estimated backup information is accessible through a mobile application, providing consumers with a streamlined interface for battery health monitoring. This technology improves battery reliability, lowers maintenance efforts, and minimizes efficiency loss due to low water levels by combining IoT-based tracking, real-time data processing, and remote notifications. The suggested system substantially advances smart energy management for home and business power backup solutions.

title: Support Vector Classification and Regression Using an Adaptive Quantum-Classical Dual Kernel
authors: Dhana Phassadawongse, Stephen John Turner
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: This paper introduces a generalized quantum-classical dual kernel learning method for Support Vector Machines (SVMs), extending its application to both classification and regression tasks. Our method combines quantum and classical kernels via an adaptively weighted linear combination, forming a dual kernel learning technique that outperforms models relying solely on either kernel type. In this paper, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on several real-world datasets in terms of classification accuracy and for regression, high <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex>-score and low Root Mean Square Error (RMSE). Furthermore, we evaluate the dual kernel model on both ideal and noisy quantum backends using the IBM Qiskit toolkit. Under ideal conditions, the dual kernel method consistently maintains superior performance compared to purely classical or quantum kernels. While the presence of noise may affect performance, the dual kernel still achieves results that are competitive with the best individual kernels, underscoring its robustness and practical viability in real-world applications.

title: Design Space Exploration based on Q-Learning for 2D Bin-packing Problems
authors: Maria Pantazi-Kypraiou, George Rafael Goudroumanis, Tahani Aladwani, Athanasios Tziouvaras, George Stamoulis, Christos Anagnostopoulos
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Reinforcement learning has proven a useful technique for solving problems that rely on decision-making. One famous problem that attracted a lot of attention in the past years is the 2D bin packing, that has several real-world applications in diverse verticals. In this work we leverage Q-Learning (QL), a standard reinforcement learning algorithm to optimise an agent’s decision-making on a 2D bin packing environment. Our goal is to explore the QL design space by assessing the technique’s sensitivity to several parameters and to identify its efficiency under different 2D bin packing configurations. To this end, we set up 3 distinct 2D bin packing configurations, and we exhaustively train QL agents using different hyperparameters. We discuss the results we obtain and we provide useful insights on how the the QL behaves in various scenarios, highlighting its strengths, limitations, and potential for generalisation in other optimisation problems as well.

title: Parametric Stability Analysis for Circuit Quantum Electrodynamical Hardwares
authors: M. Gabriela Boada G., Andrea Delgado, Jose Morales Escalante
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The transmon qubit, essential to quantum computation, exhibits disordered dynamics under strong parametric drives, critical to its control. We present a combined theoretical and numerical study of stability regions in circuit QED using Floquet theory, focusing on the appearance of Arnold tongues that distinguish stable from unstable regimes. Starting from simple Josephson circuits and progressing to full multimode qubit-cavity systems, we show how time-dependent modulation maps the dynamics to Mathieu-type equations, revealing thresholds for parametric resonances. Perturbative corrections capture effects like higher harmonics and weak nonlinearities. Simulations validate these predictions and expose sensitivity to fabrication parameters. These findings inform thresholds for readout fidelity, amplifier gain, and multi-qubit gate stability.

title: A Review of Intelligent Machine Learning Methods for the Diagnosis of Parkinson’s Disease Using Handwriting Changes
authors: Siamak Hadadi, Soodabeh Poorzaker Arabani, Mohammad Reza Yamaghani
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: Parkinson’s disease is a progressive neurological disorder characterized by a gradual onset of symptoms, including changes in the nervous mechanisms of the body and a decrease in dopamine levels. As there is currently no cure for Parkinson’s, the disease can have a significant impact on a patient’s life if left uncontrolled, both in terms of cost and disruption. Early diagnosis poses a challenge but can significantly influence disease management and improve the patient’s quality of life. Researchers have explored the potential of using machine learning techniques to diagnose the disease in its early stages by analyzing changes in patients’ handwriting, and it has been observed that the handwriting of Parkinson’s patients is smaller and tighter. This study investigates various data collection methods, pre-processing techniques, feature extraction approaches, feature selection methods, dimensionality reduction, and models employed by different researchers, evaluating their respective results.

title: Extended Kalman Filter for State of Charge Estimation in Lead-Acid Batteries
authors: Andrés M. Holguin Berrocal, Martha L. Orozco-Gutierrez, José M. Ramirez-Scarpeta
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: This paper presents an approach to estimate the State of Charge (SoC) for commercial batteries, by the Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) technique. The second-order equivalent Thevenin model is used to represent the behavior of a Lead-Acid battery, which is parameterized by experimental tests. The test-bed to develop the EKF technique consists of a FL12260 Valve Regulated Lead-Acid (VRLA) battery, a Sepic/Zeta power converter to Charger/Discharger the battery, a microcontroller board, and Hall effect sensors of current. The effectiveness of the EKF method is tested in three scenarios, pulses of current and constant discharge. Moreover, the EKF technique is compared with the Coulomb Counting technique, and the results demonstrate EKF method resilience against measurement noise. The EKF technique is often used for Lithium technologies, but in this work the usefulness of this technique to estimate the SoC in Lead-Acid batteries is confirmed.

title: Analysis of FPGA Based Power Efficient Arithmetic Logic Unit for AI Based Processor Using LVCMOS IO Standard
authors: Chandrashekhar Patel, Linesh Raja, Vishal Sharma, Pragya Vaishnav
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Arithmetic Logic Units (ALUs) play a critical role in AI-based processors, performing essential arithmetic and logical operations required for various AI computations. However, the energy consumption of ALUs can significantly impact the overall power efficiency of AI processors. This study presents an analysis of power-efficient ALUs designed specifically for AI-based processors. The research focuses on investigating novel design techniques and optimizations to minimize power consumption in ALUs while maintaining high performance. This study explores the integration of LVCMOS technology into ALU designs. LVCMOS IO standards offers advantages such as low power consumption, high-speed operation, and compatibility with deep submicron process technologies. By leveraging these benefits, the research aims to develop power efficient ALUs specifically tailored for AI workloads. The proposed research work aligns with SDG goal 7 - Affordable and Clean Energy as it is reducing the power consumption in digital circuit by implementing LVCMOS IO standard.

title: Ontology to compare nanoparticles: Quantum dots (QDs), polymer dots (PDs) and gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) in cancer diagnosis
authors: Poonam Singh, Pragya Vaishnav
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Cancer nanotechnology is advancing and producing voluminous amounts of data, which are becoming increasingly difficult to coordinate. The solution for such problems is the ontology. An ontology is a knowledge-based structure of semantic web technology. It is the formal language that represents the specific domain. In this paper, we discuss the development and design of nano-particles Ontology and their implementation in Onto4ALL using well-defined ontology design principles. Onto4ALL is a free ontology graphical editor open-source platform that can be used to design and implement domain models and knowledge-based applications. Automated learning works efficiently on standardized data. The diverse data produced by experiments performed in cancer nanotechnology research can be standardized. These standardized data can be used to develop applications for diagnosing, detecting, and treating cancer. Ontology provides a common vocabulary and structure, which is the basic requirement for creating a knowledge framework that can be further shared. In this work, we create an ontology that provides domain knowledge nanotechnology for cancer detection for welfare use.

title: A Machine Learning Approach for Early Prediction of Chronic Kidney Disease
authors: T. Kalpana, R. Thamilselvan, P. Vijayakumar, Anie H Syndhiya, Gobinath M, Madhubalan C N
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is a progressive disease, it is often asymptomatic until later stages, which makes early diagnosis difficult for effective treatment and better outcomes. Ultimately, implementing machine learning for early prediction of CKD, can help clinicians make a timely diagnosis to lessen the effects of CKD on patients and health service systems through effective early intervention. In this study, a clinical dataset consisting of patient attributes (e.g., blood pressure, serum creatinine, other indicators, etc.) was preprocessed using missing data handling and normalization. Five supervised learning algorithms (Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machines (SVM), Decision Trees, Random Forest, K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN)) were evaluated in terms of performance accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and ROC-AUC Overall, Random Forest classifier was found to provide the best performance with all around better accuracy and better generalization than all other models. These results provided evidence that machine learning–based decision support systems are capable of accurately predicting CKD at earlier stages, encouraging better treatment plans and decreasing long-term costs across the healthcare system.

title: Interpretable Random Forest-Based Intrusion Detection System for Real-Time Network Anomaly Detection
authors: Pradeep Kumar Bamandla, T. Sampath Kumar
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: In the face of increasing complexity and frequent changes in the profile of new forms of cyber threats, advanced and zero-day attacks are often undetectable by the traditional intrusion detection systems (IDS). This research presents a real-time, interpretable IDS based on the Random Forest algorithm, targeting the identification of anomalies in network traffic with high accuracy. The proposed model is essentially trained on an almost balanced dataset, with traffic instances classified as normal or anomalous, thereby ensuring solid generalization and low bias. Evaluation of the performance of the proposed solution with respect to various classification metrics: accuracy (99.78 percent), precision (0.998), recall (0.998), and F1-score (0.998), attests to its exceptional reliability. Furthermore, an ROC and PR curve analysis with an AUC and AP score of 1.00 signifies nearly perfect separability. In order to enhance interpretability, feature importance analysis and principal component analysis (PCA) were applied to greater visual and statistical understanding of the model's decision-making process. It presents a reliable, interpretable, and high-performance AI-based IDS for real-time applications in dynamic networks.

title: Hybrid CNN-Transformer Model with Multi-Frequency Analysis for Robust Fake Image Detection
authors: Botla Ramarao, J Nagaraju, Jagadeesh Thati, Kistam Gopi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The emergence of advanced generative models, including GANs and diffusion-based techniques, has significantly increased the spread of manipulated images, presenting a serious concern for digital forensics and content authenticity. Traditional detection approaches often fall short when it comes to handling diverse forgery types and lack the ability to provide meaningful interpretation of results. In this work, we introduce a comprehensive detection framework that combines Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Vision Transformers (ViTs) with Multi-Frequency Feature Analysis and a Self-Supervised Anomaly Detection mechanism. The CNN component is responsible for identifying fine-grained texture anomalies, while the transformer architecture captures broader contextual inconsistencies across the image. A novel Multi-Frequency Feature Module (MFFM) is designed to harness both spatial and frequency domain information, improving sensitivity to subtle alterations. To enhance the system’s adaptability, especially to unseen forgeries, a Self-Supervised Anomaly Detection (SSAD) module is integrated to model natural image distributions without the need for extensive labeled data. Experimental evaluation on multiple publicly available datasets—such as DeepFake, FaceForensics++, and GAN-generated samples—shows that the proposed method outperforms existing solutions in terms of accuracy, robustness, and generalization. Additionally, the framework supports interpretability, making it highly suitable for practical deployment in detecting synthetic media content.

title: Breaking the Single-Sided Limitation: New Gel Technology Achieves Two-Sided Decapsulation
authors: Chun Wei Ko, Yu Hao Chen, Benjamin Lo
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: Current sample preparation methods for decapsulation are limited to single-sided access. When the back side is decapsulation and sealed with a compound, it cannot be reopened for further analysis, posing challenges when both front side probing and back side electrical fault analysis (EFA) are required. Dual-sided decapsulation is necessary to address these cases. However, direct front side decapsulation after die pad removal leaves the die suspended, supported only by bond wires, which significantly increases the risk of sample preparation failure and may compromise the analysis. This paper presents a novel approach that utilizes a specialized gel (Epoxy Bond 110) to stabilize the die during front side decapsulation, preventing structural risks. The gel is also transparent to infrared (IR) light, enabling circuit observation from the back side, facilitating dual-sided decapsulation. Despite the advantages, challenges arise during the gel application due to the need for heating. Improper temperature control or the presence of air bubbles within the gel can lead to uneven distribution, resulting in image distortion due to varying refractive indices. To address this, we propose applying the gel to a minimal area or outside the observation zone, ensuring die stabilization while minimizing imaging artifacts. This method reduces the risk of missing critical details and maintains imaging quality even in the presence of air bubbles.
