abstract: In collaboration with Tel Aviv University (TAU), the Israeli Quantum Computing Center (IQCC), and Quantum Machines (QM), we present a practical educational lab for calibrating and controlling Transmon qubits using real superconducting hardware. This lab bridges theory and practice, empowering academic institutions to integrate pulse-level quantum experimentation into their curriculum.

title: Improving Generalization in Federated Learning for Steady-State Visual Evoked Potential Classification and Its Application in Soft Gripper
authors: Rao Wei, Changchun Hua, Jiannan Chen, Dianrui Mu, Jing Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Conventional cross-subject electroencephalogram (EEG) signal identification frameworks require centralized aggregation of all subjects’ data for feature extraction, which inherently poses substantial risks of data privacy breaches. In response to this critical issue, the present study delves into the classification of steady-state visual evoked potential (SSVEP) signals with an emphasis on data privacy preservation. First, we design a federated learning framework (FedGF) consisting of a central server and multiple clients, where the server generates global features and coordinates distributed training across clients, while retaining subject-specific raw data locally to ensure privacy protection. Then, to enhance model generalizability, FedGF employs data-free knowledge distillation (DFKD) to achieve knowledge transfer across clients through global feature learning. Extensive experiments on two public datasets (Dataset 1 ‘session01’ and 2 ‘session02’) and one private dataset (Dataset 3) demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method over baseline approaches, achieving performance improvements of 0.52%, 0.65%, and 0.53%, respectively. Finally, we develop a novel smart soft gripper with thermochromic capabilities and seamlessly integrate it with the trained network, demonstrating robust performance in daily grasping tasks. The source code is available at https://github.com/raow923/FedGF.

title: Dependency-Aware Dynamic Priority Scheduling for Online Multi-DAG Task Offloading in Mobile Edge Computing
authors: Haolin Liu, Guizhong Zheng, Zhiquan Liu, Shujuan Tian, Yanchun Li
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) revolution has led to unprecedented data generation, necessitating a shift from traditional centralized computing to more decentralized approaches. To address the challenges of data processing closer to the source, the paradigm of Mobile Edge Computing (MEC) has emerged. It facilitates task offloading to nearby edge servers, thereby reducing delay and enhancing privacy. However, limited computation resources at the edge necessitate intelligent resource allocation through effective scheduling to maintain Quality of Service (QoS). Typically, a task comprises multiple subtasks with inherent dependencies, some of which are locally dependent and unsuitable for offloading. In subtask scheduling, one must account for both inter-subtask and local dependencies, deploying different subtask types to near-optimal computing devices, whether edge servers or User Equipment (UEs). This requirement presents significant challenges to scheduling strategies. Furthermore, since task offloading requests are inherently online, without prior task information before their arrival, improper scheduling can result in resource wastage and increased delays. To tackle these challenges, we formulate the Online Multi-DAG task Scheduling with Dependency awareness (OMSD) problem within a DAG-MEC framework. This problem is modeled as an Integer Linear Programming (ILP) problem and proven to be NP-hard. We propose a Dynamic Priority List Scheduling (DPLS) algorithm to address this problem effectively. Our algorithm strategically determines subtask execution order by evaluating upward and downward ranks, task volume, and contention levels. Simulation results demonstrate that DPLS significantly outperforms existing benchmark algorithms regarding mean task completion time, server load balance, and maximum task completion time, offering a robust solution to the OMSD challenge in MEC environments.

title: Hadamard Eigenvectors with Misty States
authors: Lia Yeh, Mary Ganey, Prabhav Gudapati, Ginger Jia, SeungHwan Jung, Yisakor Melke, Sudha Swain, Christina Naylor, Ethan Parr, Amy Pezzoni, Carla Gehlhausen, Daphne John, Greg Beutler, John Phillips, Kevin Moist, Rachel Zhao, Rebekah Randall, Vickie Houlihan, Colleen Rock, Scout Winchester, Adrian German
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The misty states formalism is a set of rewriting rules (with strict syntax and acting on a small set of carefully selected quantum gates) with operations no more complicated than the rules of basic arithmetic. Introduced in 2017 by Terry Rudolph, this formalism (i.e., syntactic rules plus gates) is universal, the reason being a remarkable mathematical result due to Yaoyun Shi, leveraging another powerful result from Alexei Kitaev. Here we show that the formalism is powerful (robust) enough to handle correctly quantum gates and states for which (although well-formed) it has not been specifically designed.

title: Robust Fixed-Time Sliding Mode Control for DC/DC Converters With Varying Exponential Coefficient
authors: Xiaoning Shen, Guangxin Liu, Xinpo Lin, Jianxing Liu, Yijie Wang, Jose I. Leon, Leopoldo G. Franquelo, Ligang Wu
abstract: In this paper, a novel disturbance observer-based sliding mode control scheme with fixed-time convergence mechanism is proposed to regulate the output voltage of dc-dc buck converters. Firstly, to assure that the convergence time of the voltage tracking process is independent of the initial state, a new varying exponential coefficient fixed-time sliding mode controller (VECFxTSMC) is proposed in the outer loop of dc-dc buck converters. The designed varying exponential coefficient increases when the system trajectory is distant from the origin to improve the convergence speed and decreases when the system trajectory is near the origin to assure the robustness. Compared with conventional fixed-time sliding mode controllers (FxTSMC), the proposed one not only assures a fixed-time convergence of system trajectory but also further enhances the robustness and dynamic performance of the system without increasing chattering, thus the performance of buck converters can be further enhanced. Then, a fixed-time disturbance observer (FxTDO) is designed in combination with the proposed VECFxTSMC to estimate the unknown lumped disturbances and enhance the disturbance rejection ability of buck converters. Finally, a set of comparative experiments between conventional methods and the proposed method are implemented based on dc-dc buck converters, and the experimental results verify the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed strategy.

title: Boosting Geometric Invariants for Discriminative Forensics of Large-Scale Generated Visual Content_supp1-3633580.pdf
authors: Shuren Qi
abstract: Generative artificial intelligence has shown great success in visual content synthesis such that humans struggle to distinguish between real and synthesized images. Forensic research seeks to reveal artifacts in such generated images, ensuring information security or improving generation capability. In this regard, the robustness and interpretability are important for the trustworthy purpose of forensic tasks. However, typical forensic models and their underlying data representations rely on empirical learning algorithms, which cannot effectively handle the high robustness and interpretability requirements beyond experience. As an effective solution, we extend the classical geometric invariants to the forensic research of large-scale generated images. Invariants are handcrafted representations with robust and interpretable geometric principles. However, their discriminability is far from the large scale of today’s forensic tasks. We boost the discriminability by extending the classical invariants to the hierarchical architecture of convolutional neural networks. The resulting overcompleteness allows for an automatic selection of task-discriminative features, while retaining the previous advantages of robustness and interpretability. From generative adversarial networks to diffusion models, the forensic with our boosted invariants demonstrates state-of-the-art discriminability against large-scale content diversity. It also exhibits high efficiency on training examples, intrinsic invariance to geometric variations, and better interpretability of the forensic process.

title: HYBRIDSERVE: Efficient Serving of Large AI Models with Confidence-Based Cascade Routing
authors: Leyang Xue, Yao Fu, Luo Mai, Mahesh K. Marina
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Giant Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) are central to modern cloud-based AI services but are extremely energyintensive to serve - often exceeding their training cost - due to the need for large GPU clusters to host model partitions and replicas. Existing methods trade off either energy efficiency or inference accuracy. We present HYBRIDSERVE, a hybrid DNN serving system that leverages multiple model sizes - from small to giant - and routes requests based on confidence estimates. By prioritizing smaller, energy-efficient models for confident queries, HYBRIDSERVE reduces reliance on giant model replicas while preserving accuracy. A dataflow planner further optimizes model placement and replication to maximize throughput. Experiments show that HYBRIDSERVE reduces energy consumption by up to $19.8 \times$ over state-of-the-art serving systems, while achieving the same accuracy as the largest model alone.

title: Uncertainty-Aware PCA Revisited_supp2-3633868.txt
authors: Lukas Friesecke
abstract: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is perhaps the most popular linear projection technique for dimensionality reduction. We consider PCA under the assumption that the high-dimensional data points are equipped with Gaussian uncertainty. Several approaches to such uncertainty-aware PCA have been developed recently in the visualization community. Since PCA is a discontinuous map, a small uncertainty in the data points can result in a huge uncertainty in the projected points. We show that the uncertainty of the data points also creates uncertainty in the eigenvectors of the covariance matrix that defines the PCA projection. We present a closed-form expression to quantify eigenvector uncertainty. Based on this, we propose a 3D glyph that supports the decision whether existing solutions for uncertainty-aware PCA are sufficient, or whether a more expensive sampling-based approach is required. We apply our approach to several test data sets.

authors: Bruno Fonseca
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: The introduction of AI into the developer workflow has fundamentally changed the conversation around productivity, but merely adopting tools is not enough. Drawing on insights from the 2025 DORA State of AI-assisted Software Development report, this keynote argues that AI is an amplifier that magnifies an organization's pre-existing technical and cultural capabilities. It will show why the greatest returns on AI investment come not from the models themselves, but from the maturity of the underlying software delivery system. We will explore a real-world transformation, using the journey of Unico IDTech https://unico.io as a prime example. This story demonstrates how creating a robust and consistent engineering structure Dev Prime coupled with a radical shift to user-centric monitoring SLOs and reliability engineering created the necessary high-quality Platform foundation. When this foundation is present-characterized by clear governance, healthy data ecosystems, and foundational practices-AI's benefits such as throughput and organizational performance gains are dramatically amplified. This session provides technology leaders with a clear, data-driven mandate: to maximize the value of AI, you must first invest in and rationalize your foundational structure, treating your internal platform as the critical enabler for sustainable AI-driven excellence.

title: Diagnosis of Acute Respiratory Disease Using AI in Small Towns and Villages
authors: K Thanuja, S Meghana, Ha Preethi, Supriya Hanchinal, Mp UshaRani, H Anwar Basha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Infectious acute respiratory diseases, such as pneumonia, bronchitis, and acute respiratory infections, pose significant global health challenges, disproportionately affecting rural and underserved populations. Limited healthcare facilities and lack of specialized medical practitioners lead to delayed or inaccurate diagnoses, increasing patient risk. This paper explores the potential of Artificial Intelligence (AI) technologies, such as MobileNetV2, to analyze chest X-ray images for rapid and accurate diagnoses, even in resource-constrained settings. AIpowered chatbots enable symptom analysis and remote medical consultations, addressing critical healthcare gaps. The effectiveness of the proposed AI system was evaluated using a dataset of chest X-ray images, achieving an accuracy of $94 \%$ in diagnosing respiratory diseases. These findings demonstrate the potential of AI-driven healthcare solutions to improve early diagnosis and accessibility, particularly in underserved regions.

title: Rodent Models in Biomedical and Biotechnological Research Training: A Literature Review
authors: Juan Sebastián Sánchez-Gómez, Zaida Liliana Cardenas Contreras, Adrian Rios, Maria Larrondo-Petrie, Libis Valdez-Cervantes, Luis Alberto Cruz Salazar, Sonia Garcia
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: There is a growing concern about the limited integration of laboratory animal models in academic training programs in biomedicine and biotechnology, particularly in countries like Colombia. Understanding how animal models are used in research training is essential to ensure scientific advancement while upholding ethical standards and promoting animal welfare. This study employed the PRISMA methodology to conduct a rigorous and reproducible literature review on the use of rats and mice in research-oriented educational processes. A total of 105 scientific articles from 36 countries were identified, primarily published between 2022 and 2025, with the United States and Europe contributing the most. The literature revealed five thematic trends: the application of the 3Rs (Replacement, Reduction, and Refinement); the importance of robust experimental design; bioethical oversight through institutional committees; practices for ensuring laboratory animal welfare; and the role of educational training. Findings also show that animal models are indispensable in biomedical fields such as physiology, immunology, pharmacology, and behavioral science. However, their integration into academic curricula, especially in South America, remains uneven, with Brazil leading regional contributions and Colombia lagging. Less than 10% of studies proposed alternative models such as artificial intelligence, which remains a topic of ongoing debate. The review highlights significant disparities in educational curricula, both geographically and across disciplines. It concludes that while virtual tools offer complementary support, hands-on experience with animal models remains essential in health sciences education. There is a pressing need for curriculum reform and policy development to standardize the ethical and effective use of laboratory animals in academic settings. Ensuring alignment with international standards and preparing competent professionals with ethical awareness, experimental design knowledge, and practical skills will strengthen future research, improve public health responses, and address emerging biomedical challenges responsibly and sustainably.

title: Influence of School Discrimination on the Emotional Stability of Autistic Adolescents in a STEM Environment at a Private School in Milagro, Ecuador
authors: Vivian Coromoto Rojas, Gilberto Antonio Veliz, Edwuin Jesùs Carrasquero
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: The present research aims to evaluate the levels of discrimination toward students with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) at a private educational unit in Ecuador, as well as to raise awareness in the educational community about the specific abilities and needs of these students. To support the study, various learning theories were employed, such as Bandura's social learning theory and self-efficacy, Piaget's experiential learning, and the theory of mind proposed by Cohen, Leslie, and Frith. These provided a robust, multidimensional theoretical framework guiding method selection, addressing both processes of observation and imitation and the importance of self-efficacy and emotional interpretation in inclusive educational contexts. A mixed-methods approach was adopted, integrating qualitative and quantitative techniques to obtain a comprehensive, detailed view of the phenomenon. Data collection included semistructured interviews with two teachers specialized in basic education. Additionally, surveys were applied to 34 adolescents aged 14 and 15, of whom 3 have ASD. The study's results revealed that negative peer attitudes—shaped by lack of knowledge, stereotypes, scarcity of resources, and limited personalized support—constitute the most significant risk factors for school discrimination. It is concluded that immediate intervention strategies must be implemented through collaborative methodologies and teacher training programs to foster an inclusive and respectful school environment.

title: Network-Integrated Decoding System for Real-Time Quantum Error Correction with Lattice Surgery
authors: Namitha Liyanage, Yue Wu, Emmet Houghton, Lin Zhong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Existing real-time decoders for surface codes are limited to isolated logical qubits and do not support logical operations involving multiple logical qubits. We present Deconet, a first-of-its-kind decoding system that scales to thousands of logical qubits and supports logical operations implemented through lattice surgery. Deconet organizes compute resources in a network-integrated hybrid tree-grid structure, which results in minimal latency increase and no throughput degradation as the system grows. Specifically, Deconet can be scaled to any arbitrary number of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$l$</tex> logical qubits by increasing the compute resources by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$O(l \times \log (l))$</tex>, which provides the required <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$O(l)$</tex> growth in I/O resources while incurring only an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$O(\log (l))$</tex> increase in latency-a modest growth that is sufficient for thousands of logical qubits. Moreover, we analytically show that the scaling approach preserves throughput, keeping Deconet backlog-free for any number of logical qubits We report an exploratory prototype of Deconet, called Deconet/Helios, built with five VMK-180 FPGAs, that successfully decodes 100 logical qubits of distance five. For 100 logical qubits, under a phenomenological noise rate of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 1 \%}$</tex>, the Deconet/Helios has an average latency of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.40 \mu ~\mathrm{s}$</tex> and an inverse throughput of 0.84 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mu$</tex> s per measurement round.

title: Enhancing H. 264 Video Compression for Remote Photoplethysmography using Saliency-Guided Preprocessing
authors: Mehdi Moghimi, Hadi Grailu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: Remote photoplethysmography (rPPG) has emerged as a non-contact and efficient method for physiological monitoring, particularly for heart rate estimation. However, the large size of rPPG-based video data presents significant challenges in storage and bandwidth, especially when using standard compression algorithms like H.264, which often degrade the fidelity of physiological signals and visual quality. This paper introduces a saliency-guided preprocessing approach that strategically applies Gaussian blur to non-essential video regions while preserving critical areas for heart rate estimation. The proposed method enhances the effectiveness of H. 264 compression, achieving an average file size reduction of $24.9 \%$ compared to unpreprocessed videos while maintaining high video quality, as evidenced by minimal differences in PSNR and SSIM values. Notably, the method preserved heart rate estimation accuracy based on rPPG signals, achieving an average accuracy of $96.48 \%$, closely matching the performance of uncompressed videos $(96.56 \%)$. These findings demonstrate the proposed method’s ability to balance compression efficiency with the preservation of critical physiological data and video quality, offering a practical and promising solution for efficient video storage and transmission in medical applications.

title: Qubit Health Analytics and Clustering for HPC-Integrated Quantum Processors
authors: Xiaolong Deng, Laura Schulz, Martin Schulz
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum computing in supercomputing centers requires robust tools to analyze calibration datasets, predict hardware performance, and optimize operational workflows. This paper presents a data-driven framework for processing calibration metrics. Our model is based on a real calibration quality metrics dataset from our in-house <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0}$</tex>-qubit NISQ device and for more than 250 days. We apply detailed data analysis to uncover temporal patterns and cross-metric correlations. Using unsupervised clustering, we identify stable and noisy qubits. We also validate our model using GHZ state experiments. Our study provides health indicators as well as hardware-driven maintenance and recalibration recommendations, thus motivating the integration of relevant schedulers with HPCQC workflows.

title: Global Frontiers in Engineering Education: Leveraging Problem-Based Learning for Innovation and Impact
authors: Zanele Nqobile Hadebe, Rendani Wilson Maladzhi, Mbuyu Germain Ntunka
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: In response to accelerating global technological and societal challenges, engineering education must adopt transformative strategies to develop innovative, adaptable, and industry-ready graduates. Problem-Based Learning (PBL) has emerged as an effective pedagogy for fostering critical thinking, creativity, and interdisciplinary collaboration. With the rise of Industry 4.0 technologies, including automation, data analytics, and IoT. There is growing interest in enhancing PBL by integrating these digital tools. However, the impact of such integration on learner engagement and preparedness remains underexplored. This systematic review synthesizes evidence from studies published between 2020 and 2025, drawn from academic databases including IEEE Xplore, Google Scholar, Semantic Scholar, Crossref, and Scopus. It examines how the incorporation of Industry 4.0 technologies into PBL frameworks affects engineering students' engagement, motivation, and technological problem-solving abilities. The central research question is: How does integrating Industry 4.0 tools into PBL curricula influence student engagement and preparedness compared to traditional PBL models? Findings indicate that embedding Industry 4.0 tools in PBL significantly boosts student engagement by enhancing the authenticity, interactivity, and industrial relevance of learning experiences. Students exposed to these technologies demonstrate improved confidence, advanced problem-solving skills, and greater readiness for contemporary engineering challenges. The review also identifies best practices, common barriers, and contextual factors affecting implementation. This study points out the transformative value of technologyaugmented PBL in engineering education. It calls for the development of adaptive, digitally enriched PBL models to equip future engineers with the competencies needed to drive innovation and address complex global problems. We discuss the implications for educators and policymakers.

title: Driving Digital Innovation: How Industry Partners are Reshaping Engineering Education
authors: Linus Idoko, Daniel Okojie, Samiel Eneje
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: Engineering education is rapidly evolving due to technological advancements and the demand for industry-ready professionals. While academia has long emphasized theory, digital technologies highlight the need for stronger collaboration with industry to bridge the skills gap and drive innovation. This paper explores how such partnerships transform engineering education by enhancing curricula, boosting employability, and fostering entrepreneurship. Using case studies from Stanford University with Google, the University of Sheffield with RollsRoyce, and the Indian Institute of Technology with Tata Consultancy Services, the study analyses partnership models and institutional records to assess their impact on innovation, engagement, and learning outcomes. Findings show that industry-academic collaborations enrich curricula and research, improve graduate readiness, strengthen faculty development, and expand entrepreneurial opportunities. By aligning education with industry needs, these partnerships create responsive, innovative learning environments that equip students for the digital era. Expanding such collaborations is vital to sustaining a skilled, adaptable workforce and advancing the modernization of engineering education.

title: Outcomes From an International Year of Quantum K-12 Educational Leadership Conference
authors: Angela M. Kelly, Dominik Schneble, Tzu-Chieh Wei
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: This report chronicles an education leadership conference to promote precollege quantum information science and technology (QIST) education in U.S. high schools during the International Year of Quantum Science and Technology in 2025. The goal of the conference was to inform K-12 school leaders about quantum ideas, the research landscape in the field, QIST curricular development, and the need for QIST education and workforce preparation strategies to meet the needs of emerging quantum industries. The conference was attended by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N=154$</tex> school district leaders, educational partners, and Stony Brook University faculty, researchers, and leadership. A sample of school district participants (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N=45$</tex>) reported strong interest in implementing QIST learning opportunities for their students but also reported a lack of resources to do this on their own. They valued higher education QIST expertise in providing professional development for teachers and informal outreach experiences for secondary students. Qualitative data from interviewed participants provided insights on short-term school district challenges in implementing QIST instruction, suggesting that research universities should take a more prominent role in designing and providing QIST outreach activities for precollege students and teachers.

title: Generative Modeling of Measurement Data for Quantum Parameter Adaptation
authors: Chen-Yu Liu, Samuel Yen-Chi Chen, Kuan-Cheng Chen, Wei-Jia Huang, Wei-Hao Huang, Yen-Jui Chang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum Parameter Adaptation (QPA) has emerged as a promising approach for leveraging quantum neural networks (QNNs) to generate classical parameterefficient fine-tuning (PEFT) parameters, enabling quantum enhanced fine-tuning of large language models (LLMs). However, the practical implementation of QPA is hindered by the need for an extremely large number of quantum measurement shots, posing a significant challenge in realworld quantum computing environments. To address this issue, this work introduces Generative Interpolation (GI), a method inspired by frame generation in video data, where missing measurement probabilities are interpolated using a neural network-based generative model. By treating quantum measurement probabilities as analogous to video frames, GI estimates unmeasured basis state probabilities, significantly reducing the required quantum measurements. Empirical results demonstrate that incorporating GI into QPA reduces the quantum measurement shot requirement to just 2.5 % of the original count while achieving superior fine-tuning performance. This method not only enhances QPA efficiency but also establishes a broader connection between classical deep learning techniques and quantum measurement reconstruction. The proposed generative framework has the potential to extend to variational quantum algorithms, offering a pathway toward reducing quantum measurement overhead in hybrid quantum-classical computing paradigms.

title: Application-Driven Benchmarking of the Traveling Salesperson Problem: a Quantum Hardware Deep-Dive
authors: Amine Bentellis, Benedikt Poggel, Jeanette Miriam Lorenz
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The potential analysis of the capabilities of quantum computing, especially before fault tolerance at scale, is difficult due to the variety of existing hardware technologies with a wide spread of maturity. Not only the result of computations, but also the very process of running quantum-enhanced algorithms differ from provider to provider. The study includes a comparative analysis of various hardware architectures with the example of the Traveling Salesperson Problem, a central class of combinatorial optimization. It highlights what steps are necessary to run real-world applications on quantum hardware, showcases how the providers and various technologies differ and presents results in the relative efficiency of exemplary quantum algorithms on neutral atom-based, ion trap and superconducting hardware, the latter including both gate-based and annealing devices. This is an important step in advancing the understanding of quantum computing capabilities from an application standpoint - agnostic to the underlying qubit technology and projecting results into the future to judge what further developments on the application side are necessary.

title: Solving Fluid and Diffusion Dynamics Problems Using Physics-Informed Neural Networks and the Lattice Boltzmann Method
authors: Cristian Esteban Peña Velandia, Eduardo Mojica-Nava
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: This work presents a comparative study on the use of Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) combined with the Lattice Boltzmann Method (LBM) for solving direct and inverse problems in fluid dynamics. Building on previous formulations such as the BGK model under the single relaxation time framework (SRT-LBM), we reproduced and implemented hybrid PINN-LBM approaches and contrasted them with stan-dard PINNs. Classical benchmark problems, including cavity flow, Kovasznay flow, and the Taylor-Green vortex, were used as test cases. The results confirm that integrating LBM terms into the PINN loss function improves prediction accuracy and training stability compared to conventional PINNs. While the present study is limited to synthetic data, it provides an independent validation of recent methods and highlights the potential of PINN-LBM schemes, with future work directed toward validation with real data and automated hyperparameter tuning.

title: AI for Clean Water: Predicting Potability with Machine Learning
authors: Karumuri Akhila, Maridu Bhargavi, Akash Ajay
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Access to safe drinking water is a huge global problem, with contamination being a major danger to public health. This study proposes a machine learning framework for predicting potability of water using its physicochemical properties, allowing rapid and scalable assessment of water quality attributes. Pre-processing of the Kaggle water potability dataset, made up of 3,276 samples with 9 inputs, was done through mean imputation and Min–Max normalization as a strategy to address missing values and standardized features. The five supervised models, consisting of Logistic Regression (LR), Support Vector Machine (SVM), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Random Forest (RF), and Gradient Boosting (GB), were explored and evaluated. The experimental results showed that GB was the finest, attaining an accuracy of 86%, significantly more than other models, and better than previously claimed. This machine learning framework set forth will be beneficial for automated and data-driven water quality monitoring. However, the practical challenges of an imbalanced dataset and not using any microbiological characteristics were recognized and would be planned for in future work by conducting further experimentation on expanded dataset sample sizes and evolving to hybrid models with complex features.

title: Energy-Aware Deep Learning on GPUs through Parameter Sharing and Mixed Precision Training
authors: Roblex Nana Tchakoute, Claude Tadonki
publish: 2025 IEEE/SBC 37th International Symposium on Computer Architecture and High Performance Computing Workshops (SBAC-PADW)
abstract: The design of Deep Learning models increasingly relies on advanced techniques such as parameter sharing and mixed precision training to handle computational and memory costs. Although effective in theory, their practical impact on system-level performance, energy consumption, and memory subsystem behavior is complex and interdependent. This paper presents a performance/energy trade-off analysis of the aforementioned techniques through an empirical case study. We benchmark a diverse suite of six models, including a direct comparison of DistilBERT (conventional) and ALBERT (parameter-sharing) on a multi-GPU NVIDIA A100 platform. Our analysis across FP32, TF32, and mixed BF16 precisions reveals two key findings. First, contrary to its smaller parameter count, ALBERT is empirically up to 2.2× slower and triggers up to ~ 3× higher GPU memory footprint than DistilBERT; an effect that we attribute to its deep conceptual unrolling that led to many memory activations and thereby incurs an important overhead. Second, while mixed BF16 precision provides an average training speed-up of ~ 2.1×, the benefits are strongly model-dependent. Using an empirical Throughput-per-Watt (Samples/Joule) efficiency metric, we show that compute-bound models like TinyLlama are more energy efficient, whereas CNNs show marginal improvements, which we link to implicit TF32 acceleration in their FP32 baseline via the cuDNN library.

title: Rule-Based Hardware-Configurable Static Analysis for Quantum Programs
authors: Yi-Ting Chen, Lauren Capelluto, Ryan Shaffer, Jeffrey Heckey
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The rapid evolution of quantum hardware necessitates an adaptable static analysis framework for validating quantum programs. In this work, we introduce SHARP, a rule-based static analysis framework designed for OpenQASM that decouples hardware-specific constraints from the validation engine. By employing a rule-based approach, SHARP allows quantum computing services to validate programs against evolving instruction set architectures (ISAs) without having to modify the core analysis engine. SHARP achieves this by ingesting ISA descriptions as standalone data, making the validation engine resilient to hardware updates. Furthermore, the framework employs an analysis-driven validation mechanism that enables multi-stage validation, simplifying rule construction and enhancing extensibility. We demonstrate how SHARP supports hardware-specific validation tasks and discuss its impact on quantum software development, including language decoupling, program-level constraint validation, and feature access control. Our findings suggest that SHARP provides a path toward a scalable and maintainable programming interface for quantum computing.

title: An Intelligent System for Prediction of Medicine based Leaf using Pretrained Deep Learning
authors: Himanshu Kumar Diwedi, Anuradha Misra, Amod Kumar Tiwari
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The foundation of Indian Ayurveda and herbal medicines are medicinal plants, but proper identification is essential to their safe and efficient usage. There is an urgent need for trustworthy, automated identification methods due to the growing demand for herbal medicines worldwide. A strong deep learning-based model for classifying medicinal plants from leaf photos is presented in this work. Systematic data collection, preprocessing, feature extraction, selection, model training, and evaluation are all part of the methodology. Nearly 4,000 photos from 74 species were utilized in the collection. A SoftMax layer was employed for classification, and the VGG16, ResNet50, and ResNet152 architectures were deployed with transfer learning to initialize parameters. The suggested model performs better than the MobileNetV2-Softmax and InceptionV2-Softmax classifiers, according to fivefold cross-validation findings, with accuracies of 98.41%, 99.46%, and 97.10%, respectively. These findings highlight the model’s accuracy, effectiveness, and usefulness for quickly and accurately identifying medicinal plants and disseminating knowledge.

title: Correctness proof for a Ring-Learning-with-Errors Multi-Authority Ciphertext-Policy Attribute-Based Encryption Scheme
authors: Jack Loughridge, Charuka Herath, Yogachandran Rahulamathavan, Chaminda Hewage, Imtiaz Khan, Lewis Kemp, Simon Bourne, Ali Shahaab
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: The advent of quantum computing poses a significant threat to traditional cryptographic algorithms, including RSA, Diffie-Hellman, and Elliptic Curve Cryptography, due to the capabilities of quantum algorithms like Shor’s algorithm. Post-quantum cryptography (PQC) has emerged to address these challenges, with lattice-based cryptography (LBC) being a prominent candidate. LBC, underpinned by hard mathematical problems like Learning with Errors (LWE) and Ring-LWE (RLWE), offers robust security against quantum and classical adversaries. In parallel, Ciphertext-Policy Attribute-Based Encryption (CPABE) has become a critical tool for enabling fine-grained access control in data-sharing scenarios, such as secure cloud storage and IoT. While existing CP-ABE implementations rely on bilinear pairings vulnerable to quantum attacks, lattice-based CPABE schemes provide a quantum-resistant alternative. Despite their potential, these schemes face challenges in computational efficiency, collusion resistance, and implementation correctness. Our contributions include a detailed mathematical breakdown of one of the state-of-the-art (SOTA) lattice-based CP-ABE schemes and a novel correctness proof for the same scheme.

title: The Economics of Airline Safety: Cost vs Care
authors: Priya Kate, Lakshmi Madireddy, Aryan Sontakke
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Although safety comes at a very high cost, it is amongst the most vital aspects in the airline industry. The airline companies are forced to invest in new technology, training of pilots, general maintenance, and observing safety standards. On the one hand, they also strongly need to reduce expenses and stay profitable in a rapidly growing market. This discussion examines how airline companies play the balancing game between safety rules and economic requirements. It examines the difference in attitudes towards safety in full-service and budget airlines, and how the attitude towards finances influences safety procedures. The review also discussed recent cases when the cost-cutting measures could have led to safety shortcomings. The results indicate that all airlines to which one can travel obey the rules, but some can be compromised when they run out of money. Another ethical issue in the essay is whether saving money is always more important than saving lives. These developments are not running as subtly, and as we become increasingly aware of the same, our analysis has served to indicate that there is a necessity to have more innovative policies and long-term investments that keep adding value to the economy and safety.

title: Security Resilience Evaluation of Mqtt-Based Iot Brokers Considering Denial of Service Attacks
authors: Valdir J. Silva, Diego R. Gomes, Eduardo F. Felix, Bruno A. De Jesus, Milton V. M. Lima, Fernando Aires
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: The usage of IoT devices is increasing in various environments such as hospitals, homes, and agriculture. Consequently, many devices with vulnerabilities are being introduced into these contexts. Within this ecosystem, the MQTT communication protocol stands out, with the broker playing a crucial role in managing communication and data exchange between connected devices. A broker acts as an intermediary between devices that publish and consume data, making it an ideal target for denial-of-service (DoS) attacks. The main objective of this paper is to evaluate the behavior of some of the most widely used MQTT brokers in scenarios involving denial-of-service attacks. Three MQTT brokers were analyzed: EMQX, Mosquitto, and VerneMQ. The evaluation was conducted using specific metrics such as response time, CPU usage, and RAM usage. The brokers were subjected to DoS attacks, including Flooding CONNECT, PayloadBased Flooding, and QoS-Based Flooding. The results indicated that the Mosquitto broker presented the best average CPU and memory performance and better response time metrics for Payload-Based Flooding and QoS-Based Flooding attacks in most requests. Conversely, EMQX exhibited better performance in response time metrics during the Flooding CONNECT attack.

title: Graph Neural Network-Based Predictor for Optimal Quantum Hardware Selection
authors: Antonio Tudisco, Deborah Volpe, Giacomo Orlandi, Giovanna Turvani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The growing variety of quantum hardware technologies, each with unique peculiarities such as connectivity and native gate sets, creates challenges when selecting the best platform for executing a specific quantum circuit. This selection process usually involves a brute-force approach: compiling the circuit on various devices and evaluating performance based on factors such as circuit depth and gate fidelity. However, this method is computationally expensive and does not scale well as the number of available quantum processors increases. In this work, we propose a Graph Neural Network (GNN)based predictor that automates hardware selection by analyzing the Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) representation of a quantum circuit. Our study evaluates 498 quantum circuits (up to 27 qubits) from the MQT Bench dataset, compiled using Qiskit on four devices: three superconducting quantum processors (IBM-Kyiv, IBM-Brisbane, IBM-Sherbrooke) and one trappedion processor (IONQ-Forte). Performance is estimated using a metric that integrates circuit depth and gate fidelity, resulting in a dataset where 93 circuits are optimally compiled on the trappedion device, while the remaining circuits prefer superconducting platforms. By exploiting graph-based machine learning, our approach avoids extracting the circuit features for the model evaluation but directly embeds it as a graph, significantly accelerating the optimal target decision-making process and maintaining all the information. Experimental results prove <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 4. 4 \%}$</tex> accuracy and an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 5. 5 \%}$</tex> F1 score for the minority class, effectively predicting the best compilation target. The developed code is publicly available on GitHub (https://github.com/antotu/GNN-Model-Quantum-Predictor).

title: A Quad-port CSRR-loaded Rhombus-shaped MIMO Patch antenna for 5G NR Applications
authors: Rajani Veluvolu, Pathakamuri Hemanth Sai, Jalli Mahesh Babu, Madala Sujan Kumar, Nagandla Sai Sujith, Lingisetty Vishnu Sai, Chirukuri Naga Phaneendra
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: A novel quad-port CSRR-loaded rhombus-shaped MIMO patch (QCRMP) antenna has been proposed for $\mathbf{5 G}$ NR applications. The QCRMPA consists of a shared radiator directly excited by four feeding ports placed $\mathbf{9 0}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}$ to minimize mutual coupling and high isolation. QCRMPA has total dimension of $32 \times 32 \times 1.6 \mathrm{~mm}^{3}$. The QCRMPA demonstrates strong isolation $\gt 17 \mathrm{~dB}$ between all the ports across 5 G n77/n78 band (3.3-4.2 GHz) with pattern diversity. It offers a bandwidth $\left(S_{11}\lt -10 \mathrm{~dB}\right)$ of 900 MHz with a gain of 6 dBi at resonating frequency of 3.6 GHz. The QCRMP antenna has a high total efficiency of $65 \%$ to $70 \%$ across $3.3-4.2 \mathrm{GHz}$. The diversity performance is assessed with an ECC $\lt 0.15$ and a DG $\gt 9.5$ across the $\mathbf{n 7 7}$ band.

title: Classification of ECG Signals Using Deep Neural Network for Diagnosis of Atrial Fibrillation Disease
authors: Mohammad Reza Yamaghani, Azamossadat Nourbakhsh, Razieh Abedi Rad, Siamak Hadadi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: The present study was conducted to design a new system based on deep neural networks to classify cardiac signals into two groups, healthy and sick, in diagnosing the common complication of Atrial Fibrillation. We used the PhysioNet/CinC Challenge 2017 database including 5050 N signals and 738 AF disease signals. After pre-processing and data addition, we used the time-frequency display (scalogram) of the signals to separate the healthy signals from the patient. To learn the model, reinforcement learning based on the Ensemble Averaging method was used on three pre-trained models of AlexNet, GoogleNet, and ResNet1. By comparing the results of the proposed model with three pre-trained models AlexNet, GoogleNet, and ResNet1, and evaluating its performance with criteria such as Accuracy, Precision, Recall, F1-Score, and ROC chart, the accuracy of the proposed model is 90.29%, which is the best accuracy among Other deep networks that have been pre-trained individually. The information of the confusion matrix shows that 784 samples of healthy people and 816 samples of sick people were correctly diagnosed and 172 samples were wrongly diagnosed, which performed better compared to pre-trained models.

title: Time-Varying Functional Connectivity for Scalable Observability in Microservice Architectures
authors: Giles Winchester, George Parisis, Luc Berthouze
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Microservices have transformed software architecture through the creation of modular and independent services. However, they introduce operational complexities in service integration and system management that makes swift and accurate anomaly detection and localisation challenging. Prior works on fault localisation within microservice architectures have seen the use of causal inference to infer dependencies between microservices during a fault. However, they scale poorly to real world deployments due to their reliance on computationally expensive causal inference. Furthermore, such approaches often rely on the onset of a fault being known, or on anomaly detection approaches that do not consider the dependencies between microservices. In this paper we explore the use of functional connectivity to efficiently infer statistical relationships between microservice metrics at runtime and to detect changes within microservice deployments. We demonstrate that such structural changes can be indicative of faults which in turn can be used to locate candidates for root cause analysis without incurring the significant overheads of causal inference approaches, achieving state-of-the-art localisation performance.

title: Research on Reliability Analysis Method of Complex Electronic System Under Stochastic Uncertainty Based on Generalized Stochastic Petri Net
authors: Yanchun LU, Jingrun ZHANG
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: In order to accurately describe the uncertainty in lifetime distribution and dynamic correlative behaviors of components in complex electronic systems, this paper proposes a reliability modeling method for complex electronic systems based on Generalized Stochastic Petri Net (GSPN). The simulation analysis is conducted using the simulation software independently developed by CEPREI, aiming to overcome the shortcomings of fault trees, such as insufficient dynamic capture capability, poor display of dynamic details, and state space explosion in quantitative analysis. Furthermore, the effectiveness and correctness of this method are verified through case studies, providing a theoretical basis and decision support for improving the performance of complex electronic systems.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning Model for Runoff Forecasting Based on CNN and LSTM
authors: Yaru Wu, Dong Wang, Qingwen Deng, Xiaoyu Ye
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Runoff prediction is critical for urban flood control, water resource optimization, and disaster risk management. To improve prediction accuracy, this study proposes a daily runoff prediction method integrating improved adaptive noise-complete ensemble empirical mode decomposition (ICEEMDAN), permutation entropy (PE) screening, and wavelet hard threshold denoising. First, ICEEMDAN decomposes the original runoff series into multiple intrinsic mode function (IMF) components, effectively addressing modal aliasing in traditional decomposition methods and achieving precise multi-scale decomposition. Next, permutation entropy quantifies each component's complexity, enabling wavelet hard threshold denoising of noise-dominated components to suppress high-frequency noise while preserving key hydrological features. The processed data then feeds into an ICEEMDAN-CNN-LSTM hybrid model, which uses IMF components and residual data from the previous year as input. This architecture combines CNN's spatial feature extraction with LSTM's long-term temporal dependency capture, significantly enhancing prediction accuracy for non-stationary runoff series. Experimental results from Lanzhou and Malong stations show the model's superior performance over traditional LSTM and CNN-LSTM models, achieving Nash-Sutcliffe efficiency coefficients (NSE) of 0.9809 and 0.9856, respectively, with significant reductions in MAPE, RMSE, and MAE. This study demonstrates that the proposed model not only enhances prediction accuracy but also shows excellent cross-site applicability, offering reliable technical support for flood control and water resource management in complex basins.

title: Benchmarking Fidelity Metrics of Quantum Computers
authors: Shubdeep Mohapatra, Hrushikesh Pramod Patil, Ji Liu, Huiyang Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum computers are susceptible to noise or errors, and it is critical to quantify the impact of noise acting on a quantum circuit. The density matrix-based fidelity, referred to as DM Fidelity, aka Uhlmann fidelity, provides a measure that quantifies the closeness between a noise-free density matrix and its noisy density matrix. However, DM Fidelity is computationally expensive, since density matrices require full-state tomography, and also necessitates noise-free results. Consequently, different metrics have been proposed to estimate the noise impact of a quantum circuit. In this paper, we study the commonly used metrics, including Hellinger Fidelity, Total Variational Distance (TVD), Estimated Success Probability (ESP), Probability of Successful Trials (PST), Clifford-based Fidelity Estimation, purity measure using either CSWAP or Classical Shadows, and Shadow Overlap, and show how well these metrics correlate to DM Fidelity. We also identify certain regions and conditions where one metric correlates with DM Fidelity better than others. The metrics are computed with a noise simulator using noise models derived from IBMQ quantum computers on the SupermarQ benchmarks. Among the aforementioned metrics, our results show that ESP and PST have the highest correlation with DM Fidelity: ESP has a Spearman correlation of 0.88, signifying a positive nonlinear correlation, while PST has a Pearson correlation of 0.92, signifying a positive linear correlation. Accurate fidelity estimation has many applications. In our paper, we present an application in quantum error mitigation. We show that using fidelity metrics that correlate well with DM Fidelity is more effective than using other metrics. In particular, our results on real IBM Quantum hardware show that Reliability Based Zero Noise Extrapolation (RZNE), using ESP/PST achieves a fidelity (Hellinger) improvement of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.44 x / 7.83 x$</tex> over the baseline without error-mitigation. Using other metrics like Clifford fidelity which has a Spearman Correlation of 0.73 to DM Fidelity, would be less effective: RZNE with Clifford fidelity shows a fidelity improvement gain of 4.31x.

title: MAQAN: India's Quantum Network Testbed
authors: Vaibhav Pratap Singh, Anurag Dutt, Ashutosh Kumar Singh, Foram Shingala, Sajimon P. C., Yashwant Reddy, Abhishek Singh Rao, Mohd. Razin Ashfaque, Natarajan Venkatachalam, Aneesh Kumar K. B., Haribabu P, Sudarsan S D, Anil Prabhakar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Metro Area Quantum Access Network (MAQAN) is India's 1st Quantum Network testbed established at Chennai, India. MAQAN supports a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5}$</tex>-node topology with indigenously designed control electronics to support Coherent One-Way (CoW) and Differential Phase Shift (DPS) QKD protocols. The testbed supports both a hardware key distillation and a software Key Distillation Engine (KDE), enabling a modular architecture. The testbed is managed through a proprietary software-defined network-enabled “DARPAN-Q” application. The testbed enables independent QKD use case development through an ETSI-compliant key manager.

title: Secure Quantum Circuit Compilation Methodology for Untrusted Compilers
authors: Subrata Das, Swaroop Ghosh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The success of quantum circuits in providing reliable outcomes for a given problem depends on the gate count and depth in near-term noisy quantum computers. A circuit (that implements a given function) with a low gate count and short depth is more likely to give a correct solution than the circuit variant with a higher gate count and depth. As such, quantum circuit compilers that decompose high-level gates to native gates of the hardware and optimize the circuit play a key role in quantum computing. However, the quality and time complexity of the optimization process can vary significantly especially for practically relevant large-scale quantum circuits. As a result, third-party (often less-trusted/untrusted/unreliable) compilers have emerged, claiming to provide better and faster optimization of complex quantum circuits than so-called trusted compilers. However, untrusted compilers, with their varying adversarial motives ranging from semi-honest to malicious can pose severe security risks such as counterfeiting the sensitive intellectual property (IP) embedded within the quantum circuit. We propose an obfuscation technique for quantum circuits using randomized reversible gates to protect them from such attacks during compilation. The idea is to insert a small random circuit into the original circuit and send it to the untrusted compiler. Since the circuit function is corrupted, the adversary (i.e., an untrusted compiler) may get incorrect IP. However, the user may also get incorrect output post-compilation (even though highly optimized). To circumvent this issue, we concatenate the inverse of the random circuit in the compiled circuit to recover the original functionality. We demonstrate the practicality of our method by conducting exhaustive experiments on a set of benchmark circuits and measuring the quality of obfuscation by calculating the Total Variation Distance (TVD) and Degree of Functional Corruption (DFC) metrics. Our method achieves TVD of up to 1.92, indicating substantial functional corruption, and performs at least <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 x$</tex> better than a previously reported obfuscation method. We also attained a DFC as low as −0.75, approaching the −1 score that represents maximal functional corruption, further ensuring the robustness of our proposed method against counterfeiting. We also propose a novel adversarial reverse engineering (RE) approach and show that the proposed obfuscation is resilient against RE attacks. The proposed technique introduces minimal degradation in fidelity (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 1 \%$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 3 \%$</tex> on average).

title: Detecting Brain Tumor and Alzheimer Disease by Federated Contrastive Pretraining
authors: Insol Rajasekar S, Balakrishnan D, Mohankumar M, Vaishnanvi K, Suthi G, Manju M S
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Advancements in artificial intelligence( AI) and medical imaging have significantly bettered the opinion of complex neurological conditions similar to brain excrescences and Alzheimer’s diseases. Still, traditional deep literacy models, including Convolutional Neural Networks( CNNs) and Deep Neural Networks( DNNs), face critical challenges related to data Privacy, computational costs, and Representation Learning across different datasets. To address these issues, this study introduces Federated Contrastive Pretraining(FCP), a new approach that integrates Federated Learning(FL) with Contrastive Learning to enhance Privacy- conserving medical AI. FCP enables AI models to be trained across multiple hospitals without participating in raw case data, icing compliance with GDPR and HIPAA regulations. Using SimCLR and MoCo-grounded Contrastive Learning, FCP reduces Hospital-specific impulses and improves model Representation Learning. Experimental results demonstrate that FCP significantly enhances individual delicacy( from 85 to 95% and 95 to 98%) while reducing computational costs and icing strong Privacy protection. Likewise, Explainable AI(XAI) ways, similar to Grad-CAM, give interpretability, allowing medical professionals to validate AI predictions effectively. The proposed approach presents a scalable and Privacy-conserving result for AI-driven medical diagnostics, particularly in brain excrescence and Alzheimer’s disease discovery.

title: Leveraging Constant-Q Transform in Lightweight Neural Network Framework Integrated with Spectral Folding for Artificial Bandwidth Extension
authors: Mert Can Oener, Murtiza Ali, Louis Debes, Abid Bashir, Mohammed Krini, Karan Nathwani
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Image and Signal Processing and Analysis (ISPA)
abstract: Artificial Bandwidth Extension (ABE) improves narrowband (NB) speech by restoring high-frequency components crucial for intelligibility and naturalness. We introduce a method integrating the constant-Q Transform (CQT) in a lightweight neural architecture framework. Departing from short-time Fourier transform (STFT) pipelines, our technique exploits CQT's logarithmic spacing and finer low-frequency resolution to better align with human audition. During preprocessing, NB bins are extracted from wideband (WB) recordings, then stacked and masked to produce a WB-shaped input, while targets derive from the CQT of the WB signals. A compact Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), MLP <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }_{\text{CQT }}$</tex>, is trained to estimate the full WB magnitude spectrum. Phase is recovered through spectral folding with an inverse CQT (iCQT), enabling time-domain reconstruction. Evaluations on the TIMIT dataset show that MLP <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }_{\text{CQT }}$</tex> outperforms Gaussian Mixture Models (GMMs) and STFT-based models in objective and subjective metrics, validating improvements in speech quality.

title: Impacts of RBB Topology on Blockchain Scalability
authors: Jeffson Celeiro Sousa, Bruno Evaristo, Antonio Mateus de Sousa, Ismael Ávila, Rayan G. Lima
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: Decentralized Digital Identity (DDI) solutions are constantly evolving, and national-scale blockchain networks are beginning to develop their solutions. This article discusses the performance impact of the Indy Besu DDI framework deployed on the Rede Blockchain Brazil (RBB).

title: Subject-Independent EEG Signals Classification in Motor Imagery Based Brain-Computer Interface Systems Using Transfer Learning
authors: Reyhaneh Amoozgar, Hamidreza Hosseinzadeh
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: In motor imagery-based brain-computer interface (BCI) systems, a major challenge in classifying EEG signals independently of individuals is the significant inter-subject variability, which causes models trained for one person to perform poorly for others. These differences stem from physiological and structural characteristics of the brain, as well as behavioral and cognitive factors such as concentration and fatigue. This study aims to design a model capable of effectively classifying EEG signals from new subjects without requiring retraining. To achieve this, the model utilizes data from multiple subjects (source domain) to classify EEG signals for new subjects (target domain) by identifying and transferring shared features across individuals. To address this challenge, a comprehensive framework is proposed that maps data from both domains to a common space. This mapping is achieved through domain-specific transformations that align the domains in a latent space. To enhance the transfer process, an algorithm for selecting and weighting key samples is introduced, utilizing graphs and geometric relationships between samples. This method amplifies the influence of important samples while reducing the effect of less significant ones. The proposed algorithm first extracts features using the RCSP method and maps the data to the shared space. Finally, the model is trained using a support vector machine (SVM) and achieves an accuracy of $84.43 \%$, demonstrating the effectiveness of this approach.

title: Testbed Protocol for Adaptive Superdense Coding in Distributed Quantum Networks
authors: Syed Emad Uddin Shubha, Tasnuva Farheen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Distributed quantum networks require robust protocols for high-capacity, noise-resilient communication between spatially separated nodes. Superdense coding, which leverages shared entanglement to transmit two classical bits per qubit, is a key primitive for benchmarking such networks. However, entanglement degradation from channel noise and decoherence poses major challenges for achieving scalable throughput in practical environments. We introduce a testbed protocol for adaptive superdense coding in distributed quantum networks (DQNs), integrating the five-qubit error correction code with a global, feedback-driven purification routine. By continuously monitoring quantum discord (QD) and entanglement of formation (EoF) via dedicated pilot pairs, our protocol dynamically tunes purification parameters to counteract amplitude and phase damping, while avoiding the loss of entangled pairs inherent to traditional schemes. Simulation results demonstrate that this hybrid quantum-classical approach enhances channel fidelity and throughput under realistic noise, providing a scalable testbed for distributed quantum error correction strategies and hybrid control in next-generation quantum networks.

title: Towards Spin Squeezing in a High Optical Depth Ensemble of Cold Cs Atoms
authors: Hariprasad Madathil, Shengzhi Wang, Francisco Elohim Becerra
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We are currently working on a platform for preparing spin-squeezed states in a large atomic ensemble through quantum measurement backaction. Our approach involves using the birefringence interaction of a light probe with an atomic ensemble that is prepared in a superposition of the clock states within the ground state manifold of cesium atoms. To enhance the atom-light interaction and increase the fidelity of state preparation, we will utilize a high optical depth (OD) ensemble along with shot noise-limited polarimetry. We are currently working on increasing the OD by increasing the optical power for laser cooling and trapping by introducing a tapered amplifier into the setup. We expect that this platform will enable efficient generation of spin squeezing in a large atomic ensemble.

title: Comparative Analysis of Torchvision Object Detection Models
authors: Naga Madhurya Peram, Anil Vijarnia, Sunil Netra, Satish Bhambri
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Object detection sits at the core of contemporary computer vision, powering everything from security cameras to driverless cars. In this work, we put Torchvision’s latest detection models under the microscope, while Comet’s rocksolid experiment-tracking keeps score. Drawing on the finely annotated Penn-Fudan Pedestrian dataset, we guide the reader through every step-weight initialization, data wrangling, training routines, and evaluation protocols-examining each model’s knack for adaptation and generalization. A battery of trials teases apart the strengths and shortcomings of marquee architectures such as Mask RCNN, Fast RCNN, Faster RCNN, and RetinaNet. Key yardsticks-mean Average Precision, mean Average Recall, and the trusty F1 score-are logged and visualized in painstaking detail with Comet, revealing each network’s quirks and capabilities. The discussion then turns pragmatic, outlining best practices for deployment and lifecycle management and leaning on Comet’s artifact logging to streamline the hand-off from lab to production. Altogether, the study offers a clear, end-to-end framework that equips researchers and engineers to navigate the real-world maze of object-detection tasks with confidence.

title: Design and Implementation of ‘Sortino’: An IoT based Smart Waste Sorting System
authors: Eric Blancaflor, John Darryl Doydoy, Yvan Kent Rodriguez, Gabriel Tomagos, Donn Enrique Moreno, Mideth Abisado
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Informatics (ICCRI)
abstract: This study presents the design and implementation of Sortino, an intelligent Raspberry Pi-based waste sorting system to improve waste management practices in a university environment. By leveraging deep learning and IoT technologies, Sortino automates waste classification into biodegradable, plastic, and metal using a YOLOv81 object detection model. The system processes real-time image input through a camera module, classifies the waste via TensorFlow-integrated web app built with Blazor, and actuates servo motors to deposit waste into appropriate bins. A REST API facilitates communication between the web app and Raspberry Pi. To promote responsible waste disposal, a gamified rewards system allows users to earn and redeem points through QR code scans. Functional and usability testing, including a System Usability Scale (SUS) evaluation, demonstrated positive user feedback and reliable performance. Sortino provides a scalable solution for promoting sustainability and environmental awareness within academic institutions.

title: Dggn: Efficient and Robust Emotion Recognition in Conversation With Dual Graph Gps
authors: Yunfeng Han, Dequn Zhao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: The purpose of Emotion Recognition in Conversations (ERC) is to accurately identify the emotional state expressed in conversation content. In current conversation emotion recognition methods, most methods focus on contextual information centered around the speaker, but often encounter challenges when faced with incomplete or misleading semantic information. This article proposes a novel Dual Graph GPS Networks (DGGN) framework, which aims to integrate discourse structure information and speaker context information. Our DGGN consists of two modules: the GPSone module is responsible for analyzing the discourse dependency structure between dialogues, and the GPStwo module is responsible for analyzing the dependency structure between speakers, and then fusing the two information through the interaction module. The experimental results on MELD, DailyDialog, and EmoryNLP datasets show that DGGN outperforms the existing best baseline in terms of performance. In addition, this method greatly reduces the training time, demonstrating the efficiency and robustness of the model.

title: Efficient Cloud-Edge Fault Diagnosis in High-Speed Trains leveraging Dynamic Neural Inference
authors: Yunpu Wu, Paul Allen, Gareth Tucker, Lai Wei, Xia Lei
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: High-speed train fault diagnosis systems face significant challenges in achieving both rapid response and reliable detection under computational and communication constraints. While cloud computing offers substantial computational resources, the limited communication bandwidth and potential instability of train-to-ground networks make it impractical to continuously transmit all sensor data to remote servers. Conversely, edge computing alone is restricted by the computational resources available on-board. This paper proposes an efficient fault diagnosis method based on cloudedge collaboration leveraging dynamic neural inference. The proposed approach features a dynamic inference mechanism that intelligently allocates computational tasks between edge and cloud resources based on sample complexity, along with TernP Networks, a lightweight architecture specifically designed for multi-channel sensor signals through positional normalization, partial convolution, and point-wise convolution. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves improved accuracy and reduced latency while significantly reducing data transmission requirements, with the majority of cases being successfully processed at the edge. The dynamic framework demonstrates significant potential for realworld deployment in high-speed rail systems where reliable, real-time fault diagnosis is essential for operational safety.

title: Case Study of Electro Optical Probing Application on MTR Based MBIST Failures
authors: Yvan Lv, Ryan Xiao, Guang Lu, Haijiao Bian, Ang Li, Qian Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: An optimized workflow is presented for two common failure types occurring in Static Random Access Memory (SRAM) with failures in the Memory Built-in SelfTest (MBIST). The first involves failures in single bits, adjacent bits, or clusters of bits. These defects usually originate at the physical locations of the failed bit-cells and can be effectively analyzed through bitmap diagnosis and standard Electrical Failure Analysis (EFA) techniques, such as Photon Emission Microscopy (PEM) and Dynamic Analysis by Laser Stimulation (DALS). The second category includes failures affecting one or more bit lines or word lines, often implicating multiple suspected blocks in the upstream or downstream circuitry of the bit-cell array. In such cases, PEM and DALS may not provide sufficient resolution to accurately identify the failure location or mode (e.g., stuck-at, slow edge, or delay faults), potentially resulting in inconclusive Physical Failure Analysis (PFA) outcomes. Because of the difficulty in localizing this second type, an additional technique of Electro-Optical Probing (EOP) can be employed for further isolation. This study demonstrated that a customized test pattern may be necessary in EOP due to the limited test-loop length which occurs in test patterns converted from Automated Test Equipment (ATE) systems.

title: Stacked Autoencoder with Machine Learning for Anomaly Detection in Industrial Internet of Things
authors: AKM Ahasan Habib, Mohammad Kamrul Hasan, Shayla Islam, Rosilah Hassan, Thippa Reddy Gadekallu, Xue Yu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) electronics devices may have security vulnerabilities as a consequence of anomalies in the transmission of data in the system. Therefore, to ensure the dependability and ongoing operation of HoT electronics devices, it is essential to identify anomaly data properly. Similar studies that have previously been conducted either employ semisupervised strategies to improve detection performance by leveraging the minimal amount of labelled data or unsupervised ways to learn from unlabeled data. In this paper, we propose an organizational structure to identify such attacks to address these problems. A stacked autoencoder (SAE) system was used to create false occurrences of minority class data. To improve the model's generalizability and handle a variety of attack scenarios, the constructed classes correct for data imbalances. When several machine learning (ML) techniques were examined, the Random Forest (RF) model continuously produced better results, with an accuracy of 100%. Particularly vulnerable to dimensionality improvements were conventional techniques like Logistic Regression (LR), which saw an F1-score decline of 60% when its primary features were same. This study demonstrates the significance of comprehending two datasets, data features, and algorithmic performance, and how they may affect ML effectiveness. By emphasizing the vital necessity of thorough ML model hyperparameter tuning and feature selection, especially for models susceptible to dimensionality reduction, this investigation will improve cybersecurity in IIoTs.

title: Comparing OpenFace and Deep Learning Models for Deception Detection in Video Calls
authors: Laslo Dinges, Marc-André Fiedler, Ayoub Al-Hamadi, Dmitri Bershadskyy, Joachim Weimann
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Image and Signal Processing and Analysis (ISPA)
abstract: In remote deception detection scenarios, where data are scarce, modalities are restricted to audio and video, and facial cues are subtle and highly individual, modeling expressions via Action Units (AUs) offers a focused and interpretable approach. This paper investigates why many methods still rely on OpenFace for AU prediction and compares the performance of CNN-based AU prediction across different scenarios. For this study, we acquired a new dataset collected in a controlled setting where participants were instructed to deceive during mock online sales meetings. For comparison, we also use the Real-life Trial dataset. We first demonstrate that our CNN-based approach outperforms OpenFace on the EmotioNet AU dataset. When used as a feature set for deception detection, the CNN approach also performs better on the challenging, in-the-wild data of the Real-life Trial. However, OpenFace, that covers also AUs not included within EmotioNet, performs better in the semi-controlled mock sales meeting scenario.

title: A Deep Learning Approach to Tea Leaf Disease Identification using EfficientNet-B5
authors: N. Sudhir Reddy, L. Manjunath, K. M. V Madan Kumar, D Kiran Kumar, Muralidhar Vejendla, S. Kanakaprabha
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Tea is the most consumed drink in the world and cultivation of tea is prone to many leaf diseases that greatly determine the yield and the quality. These diseases need to be detected timely and correctly to sustain production of tea. The study is task-oriented and is aimed at predicting and classifying the diseases of tea leaves through the deep learning approach and using EfficientNet-B5 models, mainly, the EfficientNet-B5 because it is the most accurate out of the rest and uses fewer resources. An extensive data of tea leaf images was assembled that includes both disease and healthy samples of some common tea plant diseases including blister blight, gray blight, red rust and algal leaf spot. The EfficientNet-B5 is a model which relies on transfer learning to achieve better result through fine-tuning.
