The model obtained 96.8 percent classification accuracy, which is high by any standards and better than ResNet50 and InceptionV3 on both the precision and the recall. The method also worked on real-time scenarios on mobile and edge devices, proving that it can be deployed in the agricultural environment. As seen in the results, EfficientNet-B5 is able to offer a lightweight, but robust model to solve the automated detection of tea leaf disease and would be a practical tool at the disposal of farmers and other agricultural specialists to allow them to monitor the health of crops and take remedial action in time.

title: Federated Quantum Kernel-Based Long Short-Term Memory for Human Activity Recognition
authors: Yu-Chao Hsu, Jiun-Cheng Jiang, Chun-Hua Lin, Wei-Ting Chen, Kuo-Chung Peng, Prayag Tiwari, Samuel Yen-Chi Chen, En-Jui Kuo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: In this work, we introduce the Federated Quantum Kernel-Based Long Short-term Memory (Fed-QK-LSTM) framework, integrating the quantum kernel methods and Long Shortterm Memory into federated learning. Within Fed-QK-LSTM framework, we enhance human activity recognition (HAR) in privacy-sensitive environments and leverage quantum computing for distributed learning systems. The DeepConv-QK-LSTM architecture on each client node employs convolutional layers for efficient local pattern capture, this design enables the use of a shallow QK-LSTM to model long-range relationships within the HAR data. The quantum kernel method enables the model to capture complex non-linear relationships in multivariate time-series data with fewer trainable parameters. Experimental results on RealWorld HAR dataset demonstrate that Fed-QK-LSTM framework achieves competitive accuracy across different client settings and local training rounds. We showcase the potential of Fed-QK-LSTM framework for robust and privacy-preserving human activity recognition in real-world applications, especially in edge computing environments and on scarce quantum devices.

title: Fungal Species Classification Using MixNet-Lite: A Lightweight Deep Learning Approach
authors: R. Mahalakshmi Priya, M. Sumathi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Health care, agriculture, and environmental monitoring rely heavily on fungal classification. The challenge of accurate classification is hampered by variables such as limited datasets, inconsistent image quality, and computational constraints. Using MixNet-Lite for fungal species classification, this study presents a lightweight deep learning model. The quality of images is enhanced through grayscale conversion, resizing, and histogram equalization during preprocessing. With the help of the De-Fungi dataset, the model predicts fungal images into five classes while addressing imbalances within the classes. With significantly fewer parameters, MixNet-Lite outperforms VGG16 ($66 \%$) and DenseNet ($56 \%$) in experiments. With its efficiency, it is an ideal choice for portable medical devices and low-power agricultural tools. Compared to MixNet-Lite, MixNet-Lite has superior feature extraction, reduced computational cost, and is adaptable to a wide range of imaging environments. A further enhancement of performance will be achieved through Explainable AI (XAI) and data augmentation techniques.

title: Availability Evaluation of UAV-Based Surveillance System with Edge-Cloud Integration
authors: Ivson Borges, Gustavo Callou, Paulo Maciel
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: Ensuring the availability and resilience of UAV(Unmanned Aerial Vehicle)-based surveillance systems is essential for applications like environmental monitoring, emergency response, and infrastructure protection. These systems rely on edge-cloud integration to process tasks in real time, introducing challenges in fault tolerance and robustness. This paper proposes a stochastic modeling approach to assess the availability of UAV infrastructures that offload data to edge servers under centralized cloud coordination. Reliability Block Diagrams (RBDs) and Continuous-Time Markov Chains (CTMCs) are used to represent system behavior across redundancy strategies and operational scenarios. The models are validated through a real-world testbed, enhancing the credibility of the results. Additionally, new architectures are proposed based on availability importance indexes, considering both hot and cold standby redundancies. The results indicate consistent availability gains and reduced downtime, supporting the approach's effectiveness in guiding the design of resilient UAV surveillance systems.

title: Bone Tumor Detection using Radiographic Images
authors: Khaleelullah Shaik, M. Srikanth, V. Arun, A. Poojitha, V. Shiva Reddy
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Bone tumors are abnormal cell growths within bone tissue and may be benign or malignant, with the latter capable of rapid progression and metastasis. Early and accurate detection significantly improves treatment outcomes and survival rates. Traditional diagnostic approaches rely on radiographic imaging such as X-rays and MRI, which are manually interpreted by radiologists—a process that can be time-consuming and prone to error. This study presents a fully automated bone tumor detection system based on Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), which learn complex visual patterns directly from medical images without manual feature engineering. The proposed model preprocesses X-ray images, extracts relevant features, and classifies them as tumor or non-tumor. Experimental results demonstrate that the CNN-based system achieves high diagnostic accuracy, significantly reduces interpretation time, and enhances early detection capabilities. These outcomes underscore the model’s potential as a robust clinical decision support tool, contributing to faster diagnosis, more precise treatment planning, and improved patient care.

title: Evaluation of Tracking Algorithms for Automated Strain Analysis on Fascial Tissue
authors: Mirko Halbe, Oliver Wetter, Torben Wallenstein, Jan-Philipp Schulze, Jörg Höer
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Image and Signal Processing and Analysis (ISPA)
abstract: The development of detailed fascial tissue models is an essential aspect in research of medical suture failure. These models can be created on the basis of tensile test data and require accurate deformation measurement. Typically, this is done by applying colored dots or a speckle pattern to simplify the tracking with digital image correlation (DIC). This method leads to time-consuming preparation of the test objects and a computationally intensive analysis. This paper presents an alternative approach to automated strain analysis, using opensource tracking algorithms to measure the deformation of natural textures on fascial tissue. As part of the evaluation, a straindependent error in the displacement of individual tracking points was identified using artificial videos of idealized stretched fascial textures. By automating and simplifying the deformation measurement, the described approach enables researchers to easily investigate various different fascial tissue samples in order to generate more characteristic data and improve existing models.

title: A Bert-based Model with Tsk Fuzzy Neural Network for Ai Comments Detection*
authors: Tianshuo Liu, Qiye Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: With the advancement of large language models (LLMs) and chatbot technologies, the application of AI-generated text on social media has become increasingly popular. Therefore, the detection of AI comments has become important. Traditional AI text detection methods are mainly applied to long texts like academic writings. To make up for this deficiency, our study focuses on comments, which are relatively short texts. We propose two BERT-based models with Takagi-Sugeno-Kang fuzzy neural network (TSK FNN) to detect AI-generated comments on social media platforms. The first model is just a TSK FNN (BERT-TSK for short), which uses BERT features extracted from the hidden layers and the sentiment value of each comment (obtained by the sentiment analysis model from Hugging Face) as inputs, and the second is a BERT-TSK hybrid model (BERT-TSK-H for short), which embeds TSK FNN into BERT hidden layers for jointly training. The study compares the performance of our proposed two models with the fine-tuned BERT model on Chinese and English comment datasets. The experimental results show that the proposed hybrid model BERT-TSK-H outperforms BERT-TSK and the fine-tuned BERT model in terms of most of the metrics, Accuracy, Precision, Recall and F1-score on the two datasets.

title: A Cyber-Physical Approach to Multilingual Content Generation with Sentiment Awareness for Intelligent E-Commerce Marketing
authors: Jun Yang
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: This study aims to solve the problem of the multilingual sentiment perception and content generation in cross-border e-commerce and proposes a new cross-lingual generation framework TASG (Translation-Aware Sentiment Generation) that integrates language perception and sentiment control. The model consists of four core modules: multilingual sentiment alignment embedding module (MSAE), cross-lingual consistency loss function, sentiment control generation module, and adversarial optimization mechanism. The MSAE module aligns the sentiment semantic features of the source language and the target language through a joint embedding mechanism. This operation can ensure cross-lingual sentiment consistency. The sentiment control module adopts a dynamic gating mechanism to achieve hierarchical injection in the decoding stage. This operation enhances the continuity and context adaptability of sentiment expression. The adversarial mechanism introduces a language discriminator to obtain a language-independent but sentiment-preserving shared representation through game training. This module can improve cross-lingual generalization ability of the model. The effectiveness has not been verified. The model is tested on three datasets: Amazon multilingual reviews, WMT sentiment corpus, and EComm-CNJP e-commerce product descriptions. The evaluation indicators are evaluated from five dimensions: sentiment recognition accuracy (SA), translation quality (BLEU), sentiment consistency (EAS), marketing adaptability (MFS), and zero-shot transfer capability (CGR). The experimental results show that the average emotion recognition accuracy of the TASG model in the English-German, English-French and Chinese-Japanese language pairs reaches 85.77%. In the multilingual emotion controllable generation task, the BLEU-4 score is improved by 11.4%, and the EAS score is improved by an average of 14.3%. This fully verifies the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

title: Survey and Implementation of a Modular Machine Learning Framework for Real-Time Network Anomaly Detection
authors: S Adolphine Shyni, B Kaderavan, Mohamed Sarfras R, Jeremiah J, Aslam Javeed M, Abhishek G
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Traditional log analysis solutions that rely on static rule-based systems are becoming insufficient due to the increased complexity of cyber threats and network infrastructures. This paper introduces a real-time, flexible, and lightweight network log analysis framework that uses unsupervised machine learning approaches to identify unusual activity, including zero-day. To extract important indicators, including flow duration, packet ratios, and time-based metrics, the suggested framework makes use of feature engineering and packet sniffing. Without the use of labelled datasets, an Isolation Forest model is trained to detect anomalies in this data. A React-based frontend dashboard is also integrated into the framework to visualize log traffic and threats in real time. Our technique provides an open-source, scalable, and user-friendly solution in contrast to current solutions that are either resource-intensive or lack intelligent detection capabilities. According to preliminary evaluations, the framework exhibits good accuracy and reactivity, making it appropriate for implementation in both business and educational settings. By integrating interactive analysis and intelligent anomaly detection in a real-time pipeline that respects privacy, our framework offers a workable substitute for signature-based detection methods.

title: Distributed Log-driven Anomaly Detection System based on Evolving Decision Making
authors: Zhuoran Tan, Qiyuan Wang, Christos Anagnostopoulos, Shameem P. Parambath, Jeremy Singer, Sam Temple
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Effective anomaly detection from logs is crucial for enhancing cybersecurity defenses by enabling the early identification of threats. Despite advances in anomaly detection, existing systems often fall short in areas such as post-detection validation, scalability, and effective maintenance. These limitations not only hinder the detection of new threats but also impair overall system performance. To address these challenges, we propose CEDLog, a novel practical framework that integrates Elastic Weight Consolidation (EWC) for continual learning and implements distributed computing for scalable processing by integrating Apache Airflow and Dask. In CEDLog, anomalies are detected through the synthesis of Multi-layer Perceptron (MLP) and Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) using critical features present in event logs. Through comparisons with update strategies on large-scale datasets, we demonstrate the strengths of CEDLog, showcasing efficient updates and low false positives.

title: Median Filtering Detection Techniques in Images
authors: Saurabh Agarwal, Ki-Hyun Jung
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Informatics (ICCRI)
abstract: The median filter (MF) plays a crucial role in digital image processing for noise reduction but also presents challenges in digital forensics by obscuring manipulation traces. This paper reviews traditional feature extraction-based and modern deep learning-based techniques for detecting median filtering. Traditional methods leverage statistical inconsistencies, whereas deep learning models learn manipulation artifacts directly from data. The study also highlights the limitations under compression and low-resolution conditions and suggests directions for future research using prominent datasets like UCID and BOSSBase.

title: A Multi-Criteria Selection of IoT Devices For Federated Learning with Non-IID Data
authors: Hajar El Hammouti, Mustafa Kishk, Ahmed Elzanaty
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) has emerged as a distributed learning paradigm where models are trained locally on devices. Under FL, only model parameters are transmitted to a central server in charge of building the global model. As a result, the privacy of the users is preserved. However, the practical deployment of FL poses a number of challenges. In particular, the large dimensions of FL models, along with the complex operations it employs, result in communication bottlenecks and high energy consumption. One way to reduce communication and energy costs is via user selection. In this context, we design a multi-criteria selection framework for user selection in a heterogeneous and non-independent-and-identically-distributed (non-IID) data environment. The proposed framework involves three selection criteria, including the achievable data rates of devices, their energy consumption, and their statistical data distribution. Our experimental results show that the multicriteria selection framework saves around $60 \%$ of the consumed energy when compared to a selection based on data rate only, and $30 \%$ when compared to a selection scheme that minimizes the energy only.

title: Leveraging NeuroEvolution for Network Discovery in C-V2X Communication
authors: Anuja Nair, Sudeep Tanwar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: We present a neuroevolution of augmenting topologies (NEAT)-based network discovery (ND) within the cellular vehicle-to-everything (C-V2X) communication. Efficient ND is required for efficient resource allocation (RA), which is one of the significant challenges of C-V2X communication. Efficient ND can be performed by efficient device discovery (DD) to classify the cellular and vehicle users in the C-V2X environment as optimal or non-optimal. Hence, only optimal users with strong signals, high throughput, and low interference can participate in the RA process, improving the system’s overall throughput and sum rate. We compare the average sum rate achieved by the NEAT algorithm and state-of-the-art approaches. Furthermore, we perform a comparative assessment of the time complexity of NEAT in contrast to other state-of-the-art techniques employed for RA. These techniques confine the simple graph matching, brute force, and Hungarian algorithm. Our results show that NEAT achieves an average sum rate of $12.8 \mathrm{bps} / \mathrm{Hz}$, compared to $8.5 \mathrm{bps} / \mathrm{Hz}$ for random resource allocation (RRA), demonstrating a 50.6% improvement in throughput. Additionally, NEAT maintains an $O(N)$ time complexity, significantly outperforming brute force $O(N!)$ and the Hungarian algorithm $O\left(N^{3}\right)$, making it a scalable solution for large-scale V2X networks.

title: KuaiRand Short Video LLM-Explainable Recommendation System with User Emotion Drift
authors: Chengjun Liu, Yinuo Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: With the rapid development of short video platforms, the problem of user sentiment drift and cold start of new content has become a dual challenge that the recommendation system needs to solve urgently. In this work, we propose a short video recommendation system that integrates new measurable interpretations provided by a large language model (LLM). In specific, the proposed approach leverages the LLM for model enhancement and explanations generation on the basis of the existing “recall-sorting” recommendation framework. To this end, we make two contributions: (A) A multimodal-LLM recall module to address the cold-start recommendation problem of new videos. To overcome the absence of visual information available in the original KuaiRand dataset, we employ the cover image manually crawled from the Internet, extract the semantic vector of the image and text from the visual pre-training model CLIP to construct a Prompt or RAG input to LLM to rate the new video and achieve recommendation of the new content with zero user interaction. (B) To address the user sentiment drift challenge, we exploit the user feedback sequence provided by KuaiRand to map the 12dimensional behavioral feedback to an implicit emotional trajectory, and we incorporate the LLMRank Prompt module to sense the user's emotional trajectory during feedback, facilitating ranking of emotional sentiment of the candidate videos, while generating an explanation text. These two modules create an LLM interpretive recommendation system for content and emotion modeling, offering a new perspective to short video platforms toward the dual challenge of the cold start and sentiment drift issues across user behavior and associated content. The system outperformed existing approaches in terms of new video recall accuracy and user emotion-aware rearranging performance in experiments on the KuaiRand dataset.

title: Implementing Inquiry-Based Learning with Engineering Approach in Secondary Education: the Impact of External Collaboration on Enhancing Empathy and Defining Issues
authors: Yasutaka Ueda, Daichi Kudo, Maiko Eguchi, Takuo Sakai, Itaru Kourakata
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: Inquiry-based learning (IBL) has been promoted in Japanese secondary education since 2021 to develop problemsolving skills. Uchino Junior High School (JHS) started IBL in 2023, but challenges arose in fostering student agency and supporting teachers in adopting a facilitative teaching role, attributed to a lack of “empathy” in the design thinking process as a key factor impeding the effective “definition” of inquiry issues. The program was revised in 2024, integrating an engineering approach and enhancing external collaborations to promote empathy and proactive student engagement. This study examines the effects of enhanced external collaboration and the integration of an engineering approach in the 2024 IBL program at the JHS. The analysis focuses on two core objectives: (1) fostering students' sense of agency to actively participate in IBL, and (2) empowering teachers to effectively facilitate the inquiry process. Additionally, the study explores the factors that influenced success or difficulties in meeting these objectives. The results of this study highlighted the effect of integrating an engineering approach and engaging experts early in the IBL process to enhance students' empathy and improve their ability to define inquiry topics. Additionally, early expert involvement stimulated inquiry activities and enabled teachers to act as colearners alongside students. On the other hand, the findings of this study also pointed out a limitation whereby students' selfgenerated questions were not sufficiently internalized as personal issues, resulting in inquiry outcomes that remained at the level of general information compilation. To address this challenge, the study further proposed key findings for the successful implementation of engineering approach-integrated IBL. The study also emphasizes adopting a systematic, engineering-based problem-solving approach to help traditionally trained teachers advance IBL practices.

title: Sentiment Analysis of Evaluations and Correlation with Enrollment and Ratings in Online Courses
authors: Monika Vishwakarma, Suparn Padma Patra
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: By enabling globally available high-quality learning, Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) have transformed education. Evaluating course performance and guiding next enrollment depend much on user feedback and ratings. Using sentiment analysis, this paper investigates student comments on Python-related courses on Udemy in connection to two main performance criteria: course ratings and enrollment. We discovered a weakly positive association between sentiment and enrollment ($\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}=\mathbf{0. 0 0 3}$) by extracting sentiment polarity scores and doing regression analysis, but a greater link with course evaluations ($\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{0. 0 3 1}$). This implies that while mood has minimal effect on enrollment rates, it greatly affects how students see and score a course. These results show how sentiment analysis could help to better online course offers and grasp student comments.

title: Can AI Outsmart Firewall Errors? A Study on LLMs for Anomaly Generation and Detection
authors: Chang-Sheng Lee, Ling-Jyh Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Dependable and Secure Computing (DSC)
abstract: Modern network security relies on firewalls to block advanced cyber threats. Managing large firewalls with thousands of rules is difficult, and rule anomalies can weaken protection. Traditional algorithms detect these anomalies with speed and accuracy, but Large Language Models (LLMs) offer reasoning abilities that may reveal hidden patterns beyond fixed rules. This paper evaluates state-of-the-art LLMs for two tasks: generating firewall datasets with anomalies and detecting those anomalies. Although these models are built for general-purpose reasoning, they struggle with the structured logic required in firewall management. Future work should focus on adapting their reasoning capabilities to fit real-world firewall tasks.

title: Depth-Based Matrix Classification for the HHL Quantum Algorithm
authors: Mark Danza, Sonia Lopez Alarcon, Cory Merkel
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Under the nearing error-corrected era of quantum computing, it is necessary to understand the suitability of certain post-NISQ algorithms for practical problems. One of the most promising, applicable and yet difficult to implement in practical terms is the Harrow, Hassidim and Lloyd (HHL) algorithm for linear systems of equations. An enormous number of problems can be expressed as linear systems of equations, from Machine Learning to fluid dynamics. However, in most cases, HHL will not be able to provide a practical, reasonable solution to these problems. This paper's goal inquires about whether problems can be labeled using Machine Learning classifiers as suitable or unsuitable for HHL implementation when some numerical information about the problem is known beforehand. This work demonstrates that training on significantly representative data distributions is critical to achieve good classifications of the problems based on the numerical properties of the matrix representing the system of equations. Accurate classification is possible through Multi-Layer Perceptrons, although with careful design of the training data distribution and classifier parameters.

title: AI-Driven Reliability Through Anomaly Detection System in Industry 4.0
authors: Igor Wiese, George da Silva B. Souza, Jairo Souza, Leo Fernandes, Maria Eduarda T. S. Ikeda, Daniel Oliveira dos Santos, Ismael Trindade Fraga, Renato Torres Pinto, Erick Barboza, Baldoino Fonseca, Márcio Ribeiro
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: In the Industry 4.0 landscape, ensuring data reliability is a critical challenge. This paper presents a novel approach to detecting production anomalies and providing actionable, context-aware explanations. We aim to help the process and quality assurance teams understand the production anomalies. To achieve this, we implemented a real-time data architecture for RFID manufacturing and built an anomaly detection system based on two algorithms, Isolation Forest and Local Outlier Factor, to identify production anomalies. We leverage two Large Language Models (LLMs), Phi-4 and Llama 3.2, enriched with historical production data, to generate explanations for the identified anomalies. Our findings demonstrate high performance between the detection algorithms. More importantly, expert evaluations confirm that LLMs, particularly Phi-4, can produce technically detailed and actionable explanations about the anomaly cases, thereby enhancing operational decision-making.

title: Single-pixel fiber spectrometer based on all-fiber acousto-optic tunable band-rejection filter
authors: Ligang Huang, Hailin Zhou, Shunli Liu, Wei Huang, Lei Gao, Yujia Li, Tao Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: A single-pixel fiber spectrometer is proposed and experimentally demonstrated based on the all-fiber acousto-optic tunable band-rejection filter in cladding-etched single-mode fiber (SMF). The fiber spectrometer has a wavelength measurement range of 100 nm, a wavelength resolution of ~6 nm, and a limit spectrum measurement time of 1 ms/frame, which is utilized in experimental observation of the transient spectrum of fast tunable lasers. The proposed fiber spectrometer has the potential to integrate multiple cladding-etched SMFs to achieve hyperspectral imaging and can be developed as a miniaturized, low-cost and fast spectral measurement device for applications in spectral imaging, astronomical detection, gas sensing, and the characterization of dynamic optoelectronic devices.

title: GRPCI: Harnessing Temporal-Spatial Dynamics for Graph Representation Learning
authors: Xiang Wu, Rong-Hua Li, Zhaoxin Fan, Kai Chen, Yujin Gao, Hongchao Qin, Guoren Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering
abstract: Temporal interactions form the crux of numerous real-world scenarios, thus necessitating effective modeling in temporal graph representation learning. Despite extensive research within this domain, we identify a significant oversight in current methodologies: the temporal-spatial dynamics in graphs, encompassing both structural and temporal coherence, remain largely unaddressed. In an effort to bridge this research gap, we present a novel framework termed Graph Representation learning enhanced by Periodic and Community Interactions (GRPCI). GRPCI consists of two primary mechanisms devised explicitly to tackle the aforementioned challenge. Firstly, to utilize latent temporal dynamics, we propose a novel periodicity-based neighborhood aggregation mechanism that underscores neighbors engaged in a periodic interaction pattern. This mechanism seamlessly integrates the element of periodicity into the model. Secondly, to exploit structural dynamics, we design a novel contrastive-based local community representation learning mechanism. This mechanism features a heuristic dynamic contrastive pair sampling strategy aimed at enhancing the modeling of the latent distribution of local com munities within the graphs. Through the incorporation of these two mechanisms, GRPCI markedly augments the performance of graph networks. Empirical evaluations, conducted via a temporal link prediction task across five real-life datasets, attest to the superior performance of GRPCI in comparison to existing state of-the-art methodologies. The results of this study validate the efficacy of GRPCI, thereby establishing a new benchmark for future research in the field of temporal graph representation learning. Our findings underscore the importance of considering both temporal and structural consistency in temporal graph learning, and advocate for further exploration of this paradigm.

title: GSSA Modeling and Excitation Optimization for Adjacent Coils in Dynamic Wireless Power Transfer Systems
authors: Tianlu Ma, Zhaozheng Zhu, C. Q. Jiang, Sheng Ren, Weisheng Guo, Teng Long
abstract: Dynamic wireless power transfer (DWPT) technology can achieve charging for devices on the move, like automated guided vehicles, which can dramatically improve their working efficiency. In this paper, the generalized state-space averaging (GSSA) model of the DWPT system is established, where the state equations are derived in accordance with the equivalent circuit, and then all state variables are separated into sine and cosine items using the Fourier series. The established model reveals that the maximum efficiency points of the DWPT system are correlated with the phase differences between currents of two adjacent transmitting coils at different mutual inductance conditions. As a result, the system's efficiency can be optimized by adjusting the phase differences of transmitting currents. Finally, numerous simulations and experiments are conducted to verify the GSSA model. The results prove the high accuracy of the model, and the efficiency calculation errors are less than 0.21% and 2.38% when the phase differences are 0 and -89 degrees, respectively. The model exhibits only a one-degree error in tracking the maximum efficiency point when the receiver is located 5 cm away from the reference position. Additionally, the closed-loop experiments demonstrate that the efficiency optimization is achieved by tuning the Tx current's phase.

title: Conformal Phased-Array Antenna Design for Enhanced LEO-to-GEO Inter-Satellite Communications
authors: Ümit Güler, Tansu Filik, Alper Çabuk
abstract: This study presents the design of a Conformal Phased-Array Atenna (CPAA) for cube-shaped Low Earth Orbit (LEO) Remote Sensing (RS) satellites, aimed at enhancing Inter-Satellite Link (ISL) communication with Geostationary Earth Orbit (GEO) satellites. The analysis is carried out for Ka-band operation at 26.5 GHz, assuming a transmission-oriented link with single linear polarization under a narrowband array factor model. Various array geometries are evaluated, positioned on different surfaces with varying inter-element and inter-layer spacing. A design algorithm is proposed to optimize directivity, Side-Lobe Levels (SLL), and Half Power Beam Width (HPBW) while maintaining a fixed number of antenna elements. By strategically placing conformal arrays at the cube’s corners, rather than using a single-surface configuration, the communication window between LEO and GEO satellites is extended by up to 45.6%, while significantly reducing the SLL and enhancing the Field Of View (FOV). Additionally, the study examines the impact of inter-element and inter-layer spacing on beam sharpness and directivity. The methodology and findings are generalizable to smaller LEO satellite platforms, where element placement and conformal integration would be scaled accordingly. The findings demonstrate the potential of the proposed system to enhance ISL efficiency, providing a scalable and adaptable solution for future satellite constellations while enabling adaptive beamforming for dynamic space environments.

title: Integrated Sensing and Covert Communications with RIS Adaptive and Non-Adaptive Modes
authors: Jia Zhang, Dengfeng Zhang, Ke Liu, Jiande Sun, Min Li, Shihao Yan
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: In this work, we consider an integrated sensing and covert communication (ISACC) system with a finite blocklength L aided by a reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) with N elements. Specifically, with the aid of RIS, a transmitter Alice is to sense the potential existence of a target, and she is also probabilistically trying to send information to a receiver Bob covertly (i.e., trying to hide her transmissions from a warden Willie). Meanwhile, Willie is to detect whether Alice is sensing the target only or conducting ISACC. We consider two RIS operation modes, i.e., a non-adaptive mode, where RIS employs a common beamforming vector regardless of whether Alice performs sensing-only or ISACC transmissions, and an adaptive mode, where RIS dynamically switches between two beamforming vectors tailored to the transmission type. For each mode, we formulate and solve an optimization problem that jointly determines Alice’s power allocation fraction ρ for covert information signals and RIS beamforming vectors to maximize the effective covert communication throughput, while satisfying sensing and covertness constraints. Our examination shows that in the non-adaptive mode, the optimal ρ decreases with the blocklength L, the number of RIS elements N, or Alice’s transmit power Pa, reflecting a stronger trade-off between covert throughput and sensing reliability. In contrast, in the adaptive mode, the optimal solution is ρ∗ = 1, indicating that Alice can fully rely on RIS adaptivity to conceal covert transmissions by switching its beamforming vectors. Numerical results further demonstrate a significant covert communication throughput gain of the adaptive mode over the non-adaptive mode, which increases with both N and Pa, highlighting the importance of RIS adaptivity in the ISACC systems.

title: Feistel-PUF: Sequential Obfuscation-Based Machine Learning Attack Resistant Physical Unclonable Function for IoT Device Security Authentication
authors: Gang Li, Liangxiao Zhao, Ziyu Zhou, Pengjun Wang, Xuejiao Ma, Yuejun Zhang, Zhenghe Wang
abstract: Device authentication protocols based on a strong physical unclonable function (PUF) show promise for enhancing Internet of Things security. However, a strong PUF is vulnerable to machine learning (ML) attacks. This paper proposes a Feistel structure sequential obfuscation-based PUF (Feistel-PUF) to resist ML attacks. When the PUF is obfuscated by the Feistel structure, the challenge-response relationship resembles that of sequential logic circuits. Specifically, each response depends on both current and historical challenges, thereby significantly increasing the complexity of the challenge-response mapping. Experimental results showed that even with 1 million collected challenge response pairs, the prediction accuracies of ML attacks on Feistel-PUF remained at approximately 50%. Notably, the obfuscation process excluded response data, thereby preserving the randomness, reliability, and uniqueness of PUF with negligible performance degradation. The Feistel structure was iteratively reused for sequential obfuscation processing, maintaining constant and minimal hardware overhead. We propose a novel approach that combines the Feistel-PUF with an authentication protocol. This system synchronizes obfuscation parameters during the initial registration phase and implements dynamic updates throughout the authentication process. This approach allows the obfuscation structure to be made public, thereby overcoming the reliance on structure or algorithm secrecy in traditional dynamic challenge obfuscation schemes. The security of the protocol was confirmed by subjecting it to ProVerif verification and security analysis.

title: Open/Closed-Loop Active Learning for Data-Driven Predictive Control
authors: Shilun Feng, Dawei Shi, Yang Shi, Kaikai Zheng
abstract: An important question in data-driven control is how to obtain an informative dataset. In this work, we consider the problem of effective data acquisition of an unknown linear system with bounded disturbance for both open-loop and closed-loop stages. The learning objective is to minimize the volume of the set of admissible systems. First, a performance measure based on historical data and the input sequence is introduced to characterize the upper bound of the volume of the set of admissible systems. On the basis of this performance measure, an open-loop active learning strategy is proposed to minimize the volume by actively designing inputs during the open-loop stage. For the closed-loop stage, a closed-loop active learning strategy is designed to select and learn from informative closed-loop data. The efficiency of the proposed closed-loop active learning strategy is proved by showing that the unselected data cannot benefit the learning performance. Furthermore, an adaptive predictive controller is designed in accordance with the proposed data acquisition approach. The recursive feasibility and the stability of the controller are proved by analyzing the effect of the closed-loop active learning strategy. Finally, numerical examples and comparisons illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed data acquisition strategy.

title: Robust Secret Image Sharing Against Malicious Shadow Images by Reusing Polynomial Coefficients with Hash Function
authors: Lizhi Xiong, Siqi Wang, Ching-Nung Yang, Zhangjie Fu, Chunqiang Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: In a (k, n)-threshold secret image sharing (SIS) scheme, a secret image is encoded into n shadow images and distributed to the corresponding participants, enabling lossless reconstruction with any k correct shadow images. This inherent fault tolerance allows up to n–k shadow images to be lost or corrupted. However, in real-world scenarios, all shadow images are susceptible to malicious tampering, cropping, or noise during transmission and storage, making it difficult to guarantee the availability of k intact shadows. Robust secret image sharing (RSIS) schemes have been proposed to address this issue, yet existing methods often suffer significant degradation in reconstruction quality as the attack strength increases, revealing limitations in their robustness. To address these issues, we propose an RSIS scheme against malicious shadow images by Reusing Polynomial Coefficients with hash function (RSIS-RPC), which provides both malicious shadow detection and error correction capabilities. The correction capability improves with the degree of coefficient reuse, where greater reuse provides stronger resilience to pixel corruption. However, as more coefficients are reused, the size of the generated shadow images increases correspondingly, resulting in higher storage requirements. This trade-off between robustness and efficiency makes the proposed scheme adaptable to diverse application scenarios requiring secure and resilient image sharing. Experimental results and analyses demonstrate that the proposed scheme achieves superior robustness compared to existing schemes.

title: Angle Estimation of Retrodirective Cross-Eye Jammer Based on Joint-Transmit-and-Receive-Beam Synthesis and Complex-Monopulse-Ratio Vector
authors: Tiancheng Lv, Renli Zhang, Weixing Sheng, Yubing Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Retrodirective cross-eye jamming (RCJ) is a self protection technique that induces severe angular deception in monopulse radar. An angle estimation method of the RCJ system based on the joint-transmit-and-receive-beam synthesis and complex-monopulse-ratio vector (JTRBS-CMRV) is proposed. First, the effect of the two-element RCJ system on the monopulse phased array-radar (MPAR) is analyzed, the result indicates that the consistent phase responses of the transmit-and-receive-beam on the two jamming paths induce a large angle estimation error in MPAR. Second, based on the flexibility of forming transmit and receive beams with various weights in digital array radar, a joint transmit-and-receive-beam weight synthesis problem is formulated to counteract the phase shift caused by RCJ, such that the jamming signals are effectively accumulated in the sum beam and cancelled out in the difference beam, and the angle estimation error is mitigated. The transmit-and-receive-beam weights of JTRBS CMRV are solved via the interior-point method. Finally, utiliz ing the sparsity characteristic of the RCJ parameters, the RCJ angle is estimated using the CMRV obtained from simultaneously formed monopulse beams steering at different directions. Simulation results are given to demonstrate the performance of JTRBS CMRV. JTRBS-CMRV effectively mitigates the monopulse angle measurement error induced by RCJ via joint-transmit-and-receive beamsynthesis, and estimates the RCJ angle precisely under various geometric relationships between DAR and RCJ.

title: Energy Efficiency Maximization in Recycling Wireless Powered Underground Sensor Networks
authors: Shuqi Tang, Yu Zhang, Miaoran Peng, Liuchang Yang, Tao Jiang
abstract: Wireless Powered Underground Sensor Networks (WPUSNs) extend the lifetime of underground Internet of Things (IoT) through Radio Frequency (RF) harvesting technology. However, severe transmission attenuation and dynamic Quality of Service (QoS) requirements often lead to energy imbalance and waste issues in WPUSNs. To address the challenges, we introduce a recycling mechanism that enables nodes to harvest energy from each other, thereby proposing the recycling WPUSN. Under this framework, the time allocation strategy is key to balancing energy harvesting and transmission performance. We take time slot as the optimization variable and formulate an energy efficiency maximization problem under heterogeneous QoS constraints. To solve this nonconcave fractional programming problem, we develop a Quadratic Transform-based Projected (QTP) Algorithm, which iteratively applies Karush–Kuhn–Tucker (KKT) conditions and projection operations to approximate the optimal solution. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method improves energy efficiency performance by 17.454% and converges 70 times faster compared with the commercial optimization solvers. The proposed recycling WPUSN opens up new prospects for sustainable underground environmental monitoring.

title: Deep Learning Techniques for Text-based Emotional Response Generation: A Systematic Review
authors: Germán Lescano, Juan Manuel Rodriguez, Rosanna Costaguta
abstract: This work presents a systematic literature review of deep learning techniques for text-based emotional response generation, a particular topic in the area of emotional dialogue systems. In particular, this work focus on systems that support text-based interaction where the system detects the user's emotion and responds accordingly. We have scouted over 6000 articles for this review, selecting 74 of them and reviewing them to identify datasets, methods, evaluation techniques, and challenges in the area. Our analysis points out an overwhelming bias toward researching these problems in English and Chinese, with few to no resources for other languages. Although several methodologies are proposed in the literature, including Seq2Seq and Conditional Variational Autoencoders, more recent research has been focused on the Transformer architecture. It is recognized that there are manual metrics that do not have an equivalent to automatic metrics, and there are variations in human evaluation results in comparison to modern automated metrics. With this paper, we aim to summarize the state-of-the-art of deep learning techniques for emotional response generation while identifying open research questions.

title: Outage Probability Analysis of RIS-Assisted UAV Communications with Direct Link and ISI
authors: Ashraf Al-Rimawi, Arafat Al-Dweik, Ridha Hamila, Ala Gouissem
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: This work considers a non-terrestrial network where unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) communicate with a base station (BS) via a high-altitude platform (HAP)-mounted reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS). In such configurations, the existence of obstacles blocking the direct link (DiL) between the UAV and BS depends on the positions of the HAP and UAV, which can vary over time. Therefore, the existence of the DiL is random. If the DiL exists, the large structures in urban areas may reflect the transmitted signals, forming a strong DiL. Due to the difference in distances, UAV-HAP-BS and UAV-BS, the signals from the two links may arrive at the receiver with different time delays, introducing intersymbol interference (ISI). Therefore, this work evaluates the impact of ISI on RIS-assisted UAV communications, where an analytical framework is developed to characterize the effects of ISI on the signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) and outage probability. Monte Carlo simulation results validate the analytical results, revealing that a strong DiL can reduce the performance gains provided by RISs, especially with a limited number of reflectors. Consequently, integrating ISI mitigation techniques with RIS deployment is crucial to avoid performance degradation.

title: DRL-Based Optimization for FSO-based UAV Systems With XP-HARQ and Adaptive Rate/Power Control
authors: Tien H. Do, Hoang D. Le, Thang V. Nguyen, Ngoc T. Dang, Anh T. Pham
abstract: This paper addresses the growing demand for ultra-reliable low-latency communications (URLLC) in free-space optics (FSO)-based unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) systems. Notably, we propose an FSO-based UAV framework that employs cross-packet hybrid automatic repeat request (XP-HARQ) combined with adaptive rate/power control. In this design, the UAV’s long-term transmit power is minimized by jointly adjusting the transmission rate and power across XP-HARQ transmissions. To solve the optimization problem under stringent URLLC constraints, we leverage deep reinforcement learning (DRL). The performance metrics, including average transmit power, achievable throughput, and energy efficiency, are analytically characterized over time-varying UAV-to-UAV channels. Simulation results corroborate the superiority of the proposed system using XP-HARQ over conventional ARQ/HARQ schemes in FSO systems and quantify the transmit power required under different URLLC demands. Finally, we investigate the impact of imperfect channel state information (CSI) on system performance, highlighting practical design considerations.
