title: QSeer: A Quantum-Inspired Graph Neural Network for Parameter Initialization in Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm Circuits
authors: Lei Jiang, Chi Zhang, Fan Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: To mitigate the barren plateau problem, effective parameter initialization is crucial for optimizing the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) in the near-term Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) era. Prior physicsdriven approaches leveraged the optimal parameter concentration phenomenon, utilizing medium values of previously optimized QAOA parameters stored in databases as initialization for new graphs. However, this medium-value-based strategy lacks generalization capability. Conversely, prior computer-sciencebased approaches employed graph neural networks (GNNs) trained on previously optimized QAOA parameters to predict initialization values for new graphs. However, these approaches neglect key physics-informed QAOA principles, such as parameter concentration, symmetry, and adiabatic evolution, resulting in suboptimal parameter predictions and limited performance improvements. Furthermore, no existing GNN-based methods support parameter initialization for QAOA circuits with variable depths or for solving weighted Max-Cut problems. This paper introduces QSeer, a quantum-inspired GNN designed for accurate QAOA parameter prediction. First, we propose a quantum-inspired input data normalization technique to ensure a consistent input scale and mitigate the influence of varying feature magnitudes. By integrating key physics-informed QAOA principles, such as parameter concentration, symmetry, and adiabatic evolution, this approach enhances QSeer's training stability and convergence. Second, we encode Max-Cut edge weights as edge attributes in QSeer's GNN framework, enabling parameter prediction for QAOA circuits solving both unweighted and weighted Max-Cut problems. Third, we incorporate the circuit depth <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p$</tex> as an input, allowing QSeer to generalize parameter predictions across different QAOA depths. Compared to prior physics- and computer-science-driven methods, QSeer improves the initial approximation ratio and convergence speed of QAOA circuits across diverse graphs by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 \% \sim 68 \%$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 \times \sim 10 \times$</tex>, respectively. The source code is publicly available at https://github.com/UnchartedRLab/QSeer.

title: Quantum Boltzmann Machines Using Parallel Annealing for Medical Image Classification
authors: Daniëlle Schuman, Mark V. Seebode, Tobias Rohe, Maximilian Balthasar Mansky, Michael Schroedl-Baumann, Jonas Stein, Claudia Linnhoff-Popien, Florian Krellner
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Exploiting the fact that samples drawn from a quantum annealer inherently follow a boltzmann-like distribution, annealing-based Quantum Boltzmann Machines (QBMs) have gained increasing popularity in the quantum research community. While they harbor great promises for quantum speed-up, their usage currently stays a costly endeavor, as large amounts of QPU time are required to train them. This limits their applicability in the NISQ era. Following the idea of Noè et al. [1], who tried to alleviate this cost by incorporating parallel quantum annealing into their unsupervised training of QBMs, this paper presents an improved version of parallel quantum annealing that we employ to train QBMs in a supervised setting. Saving qubits to encode the inputs, the latter setting allows us to test our approach on medical images from the MedMNIST data set [2], thereby moving closer to real-world applicability of the technology. Our experiments show that QBMs using our approach already achieve reasonable results, comparable to those of similarly-sized Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), with a markedly smaller numbers of epochs than these classical models. Our using parallel annealing grants it a speed-up of almost 70% compared to regular annealing-based BM execution.

title: CleanQRL: Lightweight Single-File Implementations of Quantum Reinforcement Learning Algorithms
authors: Georg Kruse, Rodrigo Coelho, Andreas Rosskopf, Robert Wille, Jeanette Miriam Lorenz
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: At the interception between quantum computing and machine learning, Quantum Reinforcement Learning (QRL) has emerged as a promising research field. Due to its novelty, a standardized and comprehensive collection for QRL algorithms has not yet been established. Researchers rely on numerous software stacks for classical Reinforcement Learning (RL) as well as on various quantum computing frameworks for the implementation of the quantum subroutines of their QRL algorithms. Inspired by the CleanRL library for classical RL algorithms, we present CleanQRL, a library that offers singlescript implementations of many QRL algorithms. Our library provides clear and easy to understand scripts that researchers can quickly adapt to their own needs. Alongside ray tune for distributed computing and streamlined hyperparameter tuning, CleanQRL uses weights&biases to log important metrics, which facilitates benchmarking against other classical and quantum implementations. The CleanQRL library enables researchers to easily transition from theoretical considerations to practical applications.

title: Quantum Circuit Optimization for the Fault-Tolerance Era: Do We Have to Start from Scratch?
authors: Tobias V. Forster, Nils Quetschlich, Robert Wille
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum computing has made significant advancements in the last years in both hardware and software. Unfortunately, the currently available Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) hardware is still heavily affected by noise. Many optimization techniques have been developed to reduce the negative effects thereof, which, however, only works up to a certain point. Therefore, scaling quantum applications from currently considered small research examples to industrial applications requires error-correction techniques to execute quantum circuits in a fault-tolerant fashion and enter the Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computing (FTQC) era. These error-correction techniques introduce dramatic qubit overheads, leading to the requirement of tens of thousands of qubits already for toy-sized examples. Hence, quantum circuit optimization that reduces qubit overheads when shifting from the NISQ to the FTQC era is essential. This raises the question, whether we need to start from scratch, or whether current state-of-the-art optimization techniques can be used as a basis for this. To approach this question, this work investigates the effects of different optimization passes on a representative selection of quantum circuits. Since hardly any tools to automatically design and evaluate FTQC quantum circuits exist yet, we utilize resource estimation to compare the (potential) benefits gained by applying NISQ quantum circuit optimization to estimated FTQC resource requirements. The Results indicate that, indeed, the estimated resource requirements for FTQC can be improved by applying NISQ quantum circuit optimization techniques. At the same time, more detailed investigations show what techniques lead to more benefits for FTQC compared to others, providing guidelines for the transfer of NISQ optimization techniques to the FTQC era.

title: Harnessing IoT and Sensor Fusion for Fatigue Risk Mitigation in Trucking
authors: Kalathiripi Rambabu, Maheen Fathima, Palpunuri Meghana, Peddigari Meghana
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Road safety is seriously threatened by driver fatigue, a serious and widespread problem in the heavy vehicle transportation sector. Truck drivers frequently experience fatigue, reacts slowly sometimes, and which increases percentage of accidents as a result of their rigorous schedules, long driving hours, and innate stress. Our project focuses on creating an IoT-enabled fatigue detection system that is intended to reduce these risks because we recognize the pressing need for creative solutions. Our system uses state-of-the-art sensor technology, real-time eye tracking, to precisely identify early indicators of driver fatigue. In dire circumstances, our system will check the driver fatigue and alert the driver and specially focused on heavy vehicles. This project's main goals are to create a prototype that alert driver in the time of drowsiness via Internet of Things integration, and eventually help make the roads safer for heavy vehicle drivers and also to reduce the accidents. To reduce accidents and save lives, we hope to develop a system that prevent fatigue-related incidents through through detecting the eyes.

title: Multi-Scale Feature Adaptive Fusion: Unsupervised Monocular Depth Estimation Based on Dynamic Network
authors: Wenteng Cao, Yuqin Song, Wenzhuo Gao, Yinzhe Lyu, He Gao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Monocular depth estimation is of great significance in fields such as autonomous driving. Existing unsupervised algorithms rely on convolutional neural networks or fixed structured Transformers, leaving room for improvement in feature capture flexibility and multi-scale fusion effectiveness. This paper proposes an unsupervised algorithm based on an adaptive pyramid Transformer and a dynamic cascaded fusion network: the encoder adopts an adaptive pyramid Transformer, which generates multi-scale features through the progressive contraction pyramid structure of PVT, and combines adaptive windows and dynamic transfer windows self-attention to flexibly capture local and global information, addressing the issue of insufficient adaptability of fixed windows to complex scenes; the decoder is a dynamic cascaded fusion network, which enhances detail recovery ability through deformable upsampling, strengthens global integration with a progressive feature fusion pyramid module, and improves feature processing specificity through dynamic convolution. Experiments on the KITTI dataset show that this method, while maintaining a relatively small parameter scale, outperforms mainstream unsupervised algorithms in terms of accuracy, especially in the clarity of object boundaries and the recognition of small targets, verifying the effectiveness of the adaptive feature extraction and dynamic fusion mechanism.

title: XR-STNet: Xception Recurrent-based Swin Transformer Model for Gastric Cancer Detection
authors: Mubashir Hussain S M, Mohan. A
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Gastric cancer is one of the leading causes of cancer-related mortality in worldwide that necessitates the early and accurate detection model. Traditional detection techniques have the issues in capturing complex tissue structures and diverse visual characteristics of gastric lesions. The advancements in medical imaging and deep learning make the automated diagnostic systems with enhanced outcomes. Thus, in this research, a novel gastric cancer detection framework is proposed with data acquisition from publicly available datasets. The acquired images are fed into the pre-processing using Wavelet-Guided Filter for removing noise by preserving features like edges and textures. Finally, the disease detection is employed using the XceptionRecurrent-based Swin Transformer (XR-STNet) model. The proposed XR-STNet approach replaces the Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) layer with a hybrid XceptionRecurrent module. The XceptionRecurrent module integrates depth-wise separable convolutions of Xception for efficient spatial feature extraction and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) units for capturing sequential dependencies for enhancing the feature representation. Thus, the proposed XR-STNet architecture significantly improves the model’s ability to detect finer patterns associated with gastric cancer.

title: Towards Quantum Machine Learning for Malicious Code Analysis
authors: Jesus Lopez, Saeefa Rubaiyet Nowmi, Viviana Cadena, Mohammad Saidur Rahman
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Classical machine learning (CML) has been extensively studied for malware classification. With the emergence of quantum computing, quantum machine learning (QML) presents a paradigm-shifting opportunity to improve malware detection, though its application in this domain remains largely unexplored. In this study, we investigate two hybrid quantumclassical models - a Quantum Multilayer Perceptron (QMLP) and a Quantum Convolutional Neural Network (QCNN), for malware classification. Both models utilize angle embedding to encode malware features into quantum states. QMLP captures complex patterns through full qubit measurement and data reuploading, while QCNN achieves faster training via quantum convolution and pooling layers that reduce active qubits. We evaluate both models on five widely used malware datasets -API-Graph, EMBER-Domain, EMBER-Class, AZ-Domain, and AZ-Class, across binary and multiclass classification tasks. Our results show high accuracy for binary classification <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 5 - 9 6 \%}$</tex> on API-Graph, 91-92% on AZ-Domain, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 7 \%}$</tex> on EMBER-Domain. In multiclass settings, accuracy ranges from 91.6-95.7% on API-Graph, 41.7-93.6% on AZ-Class, and 60.7-88.1% on EMBER-Class. Overall, QMLP outperforms QCNN in complex multiclass tasks, while QCNN offers improved training efficiency at the cost of reduced accuracy.

title: Dynamic Decision Support Framework for Smart Home Security
authors: Youssef Yamout, Shahrear Iqbal, Mohammad Zulkernine
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Dependable and Secure Computing (DSC)
abstract: Smart homes face evolving cybersecurity threats, requiring adaptive defense strategies. Existing frameworks for defending smart homes provide static optimization approaches for security controls that fail to address the dynamic nature of threats and often overlook usability factors impacting user adoption. This work presents a framework that outperforms static security optimization approaches, reducing successful attacks by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{7 0 - 7 8 \%}$</tex> across a diverse user profile portfolio while maintaining acceptable usability levels. The framework uses time-dependent modeling that adapts to evolving threats and varying user preferences. We incorporate realistic dynamics of smart home security by modeling attack patterns with varying temporal characteristics and security control effectiveness. The framework quantifies usability impacts through user satisfaction, technical capability, and compliance rates. We experiment across six user profiles (security-focused, usability-focused, balanced, elderly, tech-enthusiast, and family home) to demonstrate that the framework consistently finds optimal security-usability tradeoff positions compared to static optimization. For most profiles, the framework improvement in overall reward metrics despite moderate decreases in user satisfaction, showcasing its ability to balance security with usability constraints. The framework is a significant advancement in smart home security that provides adequate protection and maintains high security standards while preserving essential usability.

title: Hybrid Quantum-Classical Transfer Learning Model for Credit Risk Assessment with Reduced Quantum Overhead and Enhanced Minority Class Prediction
authors: Parvathy Gopakumar, Rubell Marion Lincy G, Salvatore Sinno, Shruthi Thuravakkath, Bhavika Bhalgamiya
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We propose an efficient application of the hybrid quantum-classical transfer learning model to improve the performance of credit risk classification. The Quantum Transfer Learning (QTL) model presented in this study consists of a frozen classical feature extractor and a quantum refinement layer which is trained on the features extracted from the real-world credit risk dataset. For baseline comparison, we evaluated a standalone Quantum Neural Network (QNN) that was trained directly on the credit risk dataset. Our experimental evaluations on a real-world normalized credit risk dataset reveal that the proposed QTL model significantly outperforms the standalone QNN and achieves results on par with the classical neural network.

title: Applications of Pattern Recognition and Computer Vision in Smart Grid Data Management Using Machine Learning
authors: Hossein Shahinzadeh, Farshad Ebrahimi, Azamossadat Nourbakhsh, Mahtab Bagheri, Amirafshin Zamani, Fatemeh Afzoon
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: The rapid digitalization of smart grids has led to an exponential increase in heterogeneous data, encompassing real-time sensor streams, advanced metering infrastructure, and high-resolution visual inspection records. Efficient management and intelligent utilization of this data are critical to ensuring grid reliability, operational security, and long-term sustainability. Recent advances in pattern recognition, computer vision, and machine learning have introduced powerful tools to address the challenges associated with big data in modern power systems. This paper provides a comprehensive review of the integration of these techniques for smart grid data management. First, the structural architecture and data landscape of smart grids are outlined, establishing the foundation for advanced analytics. Next, the principles of pattern recognition and computer vision are examined, emphasizing their role as enabling technologies. Special attention is given to machine learning methods—including clustering, neural networks, and deep learning—that support anomaly detection, predictive maintenance, and load forecasting. Furthermore, applications of computer vision in automated visual inspections, UAV-based monitoring, and security surveillance are discussed, demonstrating the growing synergy between visual analytics and intelligent learning models. Finally, critical challenges such as data privacy, computational scalability, and real-time processing constraints are analyzed, along with emerging opportunities arising from edge computing, explainable AI, and hybrid ML–CV frameworks. The review concludes that the convergence of pattern recognition, computer vision, and machine learning is essential for enhancing smart grid resilience, sustainability, and autonomous decision-making capabilities.

title: Connectivity-Aware Synthesis of Quantum Algorithms
authors: Christoph Fleckenstein, Florian Dreier, Gregor Aigner, Michael Fellner, Reinhard Stahn, Martin Lanthaler, Wolfgang Lechner
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We propose a versatile method for implementing quantum algorithms that simultaneously minimizes gate count and circuit depth. Central to our approach are Parity Twine chains-CNOT-based building blocks tailored to hardware connectivity. This technique surpasses existing state-of-the-art methods in executing key quantum algorithms, including the Quantum Fourier Transform and the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm, across various quantum hardware architectures such as linear chains, square grids, hexagonal lattices, ladders, and fully connected systems.

title: SDN-Based Entanglement Routing Strategy in Smart Power Grids Using Reinforcement Learning
authors: Nicholas Skjellum, Mohamed Shaban, Muhammad Ismail
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Entanglement distribution in power grids can enable distributed quantum sensing and entanglement-based quantum key distribution, resulting in improved fault detection, real time diagnostics, provable security, etc. To distribute entanglements between remote endpoints, intermediate nodes also contribute by performing entanglement swapping to establish entangled states between these endpoints. In a power-grid network, existing routes may vary in performance over time due to unexpected traffic loads and changes in link quality. These conditions threaten the throughput of network-wide entanglement distribution. To maintain the throughput of entangled states, a quantum-enabled network needs to select ideal entanglement routes with high success rates for distribution while minimizing latency. To achieve this goal, we propose a software-defined networking (SDN) architecture that separates the data plane (responsible for entanglement distribution) from the control plane (responsible for route selection), enabling centralized monitoring and control of the quantum network. The control plane collects real-time metrics, including node resources (e.g., available qubits) and link conditions (e.g., noise levels and throughput rates). Leveraging this global network view, we implement a reinforcement learning (RL) agent within the SDN control plane to dynamically identify optimal entanglement distribution paths. Simulation results on the IEEE-14 bus power grid demonstrate that our RL-based routing strategy achieved a 100 % success rate in fulfilling entanglement distribution requests.

title: Optical Communication in the Mirror of Radio Technology: Analogies, Challenges and Teaching Concepts for Emerging Information Technology in Transport Systems
authors: Oliver Michler, Sven Grunwald
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: The rapid digitization of transport sector demands a new generation of engineers proficient in diverse wireless communication technologies. This paper presents a teaching framework developed at TU Dresden's Institute of Transport and Communication Systems (ITVS-TUD), which integrates analytical analogies between traditional radio frequency and emerging optical wireless technologies such as VLC and LiFi. By combining theoretical foundations, experimental laboratory exercises and application-oriented projects within an interdisciplinary, real-world context. This approach enhances students' understanding of complex communication systems relevant to future mobility scenarios. Key pedagogical strategies include comparative learning, hands-on experimentation reflection, fostering critical thinking and cross-technology transfer skills. The developed methods prove a scalable, transferable model for engineering education that aligns with the challenges of Industry 4.0, smart mobility and dynamic networked environments. This work underscores the importance of interdisciplinary, digital and experiential learning in preparing engineers to actively shape sustainable and secure transportation solutions for tomorrow.

title: Machine Learning-Driven Analysis for Parkinson’s Disease Detection Through Vocal Feature
authors: Hl Chethan Kumar, S Kiran, J Suriya Prakash
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Parkinson’s disease (PD) is a progressive neurological condition marked by symptoms like tremors, rigidity, and slowed movement, which greatly impacts everyday living. Timely and precise diagnosis is essential for efficient disease management. This research investigates machine learning methods for detecting Parkinson’s disease through vocal traits, emphasizing important features such as pitch frequency (Fo), jitter, shimmer, and noise-to-harmonics ratio (NHR). This research employs Principal Component Analysis (PCA) for dimensionality reduction, experimenting with various PCA component counts $(5,10$, and 15) over different training and testing data splits $(80 / 20,70 / 30$, and $60 / 40)$ to evaluate performance, while various classification algorithms such as SVM, Random Forest, XGBoost, and CatBoost are assessed. The results indicate that the CatBoostClassifier reaches the highest accuracy of $97.4 \%$ using a 5 -component PCA and an 80/20 train-test division. This study highlights the significance of choosing the best algorithms and data processing methods to improve diagnostic precision. The findings indicate the promise of machine learning for non-invasive, early detection of PD, providing essential insights for clinical use and forthcoming studies. Explore the code behind this study at “https://github.com/chethankumarhl/parkinson_detection_ml_pca”.

title: GUIDE - GNN based Unified Incident Detection for Microservices Application Deployments
authors: Anurag Dutt, Doseok Jang, Joao Nadkarni, Kai Su, Anshul Gandhi
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Microservices deployments in the real-world present significant challenges in detecting and localizing performance bottlenecks due to their scale, complexity, and dynamic interactions. This paper presents GUIDE, a GNN-based framework for unified incident detection and bottleneck localization, leveraging multisource telemetry and a customizable incident trigger warning mechanism. Specifically, GUIDE employs a novel integration of Graph Attention Networks, temporal embeddings, and an expert classifier to predict and localize bottlenecks efficiently in practice. Evaluation results on real-world traces collected from Observea live, cloud-native platform-show that GUIDE achieves an F1score of 87% for anomaly detection and 84% for bottleneck localization, outperforming existing baselines. Additionally, GUIDE’s incident trigger warning mechanism achieves an $\mathbf{F 1}$-score of $\mathbf{8 5} \boldsymbol{\%}$, ensuring early and accurate detection of system failures.

title: Prediction of Heart Disease Through Machine Learning Approach
authors: Jay Parakash Sharma, Prabavathi. T
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Heart disease is one of the greatest causes of death in the world and therefore it is of utmost importance that proper and reliable early detection systems are put in place. Traditional diagnosis would be tedious and waste a lot of time depending on clinical skills, and there is bound to be delay in resource- constrained settings. The paper in question proposes a machine learning-hybrid model that could be the beginning of predicting heart disease at its very early stages on information provided by clinical decisions. The algorithm means the complex data preprocessing, characterization of features by a repetitive elimination process, and testing multiple constrained models like a Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM), and a Thomson bunched amalgamation. The UCI Cleveland Heart Disease Data performs cross-validation with 10-fold validation of performance. Of all the individual models, the accuracy of the stacked ensemble was larger 91.4 percent and the Area Under the Curve (AUC) was 95.0 percent. Explainable AI (XAI) approaches (e.g. SHAP and LIME) are added to make the process of the model decisions more transparent and to make the decisions explainable by the clinicians. The proposed framework can be useful in a clinical setting by making accurate, scalable, and interpretable predictions of risks of dealing with heart diseases.

title: A Review of Current Research in Automatic Fetal Brain Segmentation from MRI Using Deep Learning
authors: Nazanin Valaee, Vajiheh Sabeti
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: Segmentation of fetal brain components in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is crucial for understanding brain development and diagnosing neurological disorders. The rapid advancement of deep learning techniques from 2022 to 2024 has significantly addressed challenges such as motion artifacts, limited availability of imaging data, and the rapidly changing anatomy of the developing brain. This paper provides a comprehensive review of the latest deep learning techniques applied to fetal brain segmentation in MRI. We examine various approaches and architectures, including U-Net, Fully Convolutional Networks (FCNs), and ensemble models, discussing their strengths, limitations, and challenges in segmenting critical brain areas such as white matter, gray matter, and cerebrospinal fluid. Additionally, we elucidate key factors affecting the performance of these methods, including dataset quality, preprocessing techniques, and performance metrics. Through a comparative analysis of recent methods, we identify key developments in the field and propose future research directions that could enhance the task of fetal brain segmentation.

title: Quantum Paths: A Quantum Walk Approach
authors: Claudio Pellitteri, Marcello Caleffi, Angela Sara Cacciapuoti
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The quantum switch, a process enabling a coherent superposition of different orders of quantum channels, has garnered significant attention due to its ability to enable noiseless communications through noisy channels, such as entanglementbreaking channels. However, its practical implementation and scalability remain challenging. In contrast, the spatial superposition of quantum channels is more accessible experimentally and has been shown to enhance channel capacity, although it does not match the performance of the quantum switch. In this work, we present preliminary theoretical results demonstrating that, by applying tools of the quantum random walk framework to the spatial superposition of channels, it is possible to replicate the output of a quantum switch. These findings suggest a promising and more feasible route to emulate the quantum switch, offering both practical advantages and interpretative clarity.

title: Reliability Analysis of <1 MHz Frequency-Dependent TDDB Lifetime in High-k/Metal Gate MOSFETs
authors: Chang Liu, Meng Hua Wang, Niu Yi Sun, Dan Yang, Na Mei, Keqin Ouyang
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: This paper investigated high-k/metal gate planar MOS transistors of N/P type and explored their time-dependent dielectric breakdown (TDDB) and stress-induced leakage current (SILC) characteristics under DC and AC operating conditions. It is found that for n-type transistors, the TDDB lifetime is lower than that in the DC condition at low frequencies AC, as the frequency increases, the lifetime exceeds the DC condition. For p-type transistors, the inflection point of the TDDB lifetime-frequency curve appears at a lower frequency. The reason is that when the stress signal frequency is low and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{a}+\text{Vg}$</tex> bias is applied to the gate, holes are trapped in the interface layer (IL), which continuously damages the IL and causes the TDDB lifetime of NMOS transistors to be lower than the DC state at low frequencies. After the frequency increases, due to the shortening of the stress time (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{T}_{\text{stress}}$</tex>) and the relaxation time (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T_{\text{relex}}$</tex>), the charging and discharging process of the oxide is inhibited, and the number of holes trapped in the IL layer decreases. As a result, the TDDB lifetime of nmos at 1 MHz exceeds the DC state. For PMOS transistors, since the hole barrier at the interface between the high- K material and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SiO}_{2}$</tex> is much higher than the electron barrier, it is difficult for holes from the IL material to migrate into the high-K material to form a charged center, thus reducing the damage to the gate at low frequencies.

title: Cutreg: a Loss Regularizer for Enhancing the Scalability of Qml Via Adaptive Circuit Cutting
authors: Maniraman Periyasamy, Christian Ufrecht, Daniel D. Scherer, Wolfgang Mauerer
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Whether QML can offer a transformative advantage remains an open question. The severe constraints of NISQ hardware, particularly in circuit depth and connectivity, hinder both the validation of quantum advantage and the empirical investigation of major obstacles like barren plateaus. Circuit cutting techniques have emerged as a strategy to execute larger quantum circuits on smaller, less connected hardware by dividing them into subcircuits. However, this partitioning increases the number of samples needed to estimate the expectation value accurately through classical post-processing compared to estimating it directly from the full circuit. This work introduces a novel regularization term into the QML optimization process, directly penalizing the overhead associated with sampling. We demonstrate that this approach enables the optimizer to balance the advantages of gate cutting against the optimization of the typical ML cost function. Specifically, it navigates the trade-off between minimizing the cutting overhead and maintaining the overall accuracy of the QML model, paving the way to study larger complex problems in pursuit of quantum advantage.

title: The Multi-Modal Anomaly Detection Method for Microservices Based on VGAE-Transformer
authors: Caiyin Shao, Xiangyu Zhou, Zimo Zhang, Chiyu Tao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: With the widespread adoption of microservices architecture in modern distributed systems, anomaly detection and diagnosis have become key research challenges. Traditional anomaly detection methods typically rely on unimodal data, making it difficult to comprehensively capture the complex interactions and dynamic dependencies between service instances. On the other hand, graph-based anomaly detection methods have shown great potential in modeling complex networks and capturing system evolution patterns. However, their practical applicability is constrained by the lack of predefined graph structure data. To address this issue, this paper proposes a multimodal data anomaly detection method (VTMAD) that combines Variational Graph Autoencoders (VGAE) and Transformer. The method first maps the multimodal data into a unified representation of feature matrices and adjacency matrices, then captures the system's complex feature representations using VGAE. The Transformer is utilized to enhance the modeling of global dependencies and multimodal interactions. Finally, anomaly detection is performed by identifying reconstruction errors based on the adjacency matrix to locate potential system anomalies. Experimental results on two publicly available datasets demonstrate that the method achieves an average F1 score of 0.974, validating its outstanding performance in multimodal data anomaly detection.

title: Enhancing the Trainability of Variational Quantum Circuits with Regularization Strategies
authors: Jun Zhuang, Jack Cunningham, Chaowen Guan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: In the era of noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ), variational quantum circuits (VQCs) have been widely applied in various domains, demonstrating the potential advantages of quantum circuits over classical models. Similar to classic models, VQCs can be optimized by various gradient-based methods. However, the optimization may get stuck in barren plateaus initially or trapped in saddle points during training. These gradient-related issues can severely impact the trainability of VQCs. In this work, we propose a strategy that regularizes model parameters with prior knowledge of the training data and Gaussian noise diffusion. We conduct ablation studies to verify the effectiveness of our strategy across four public datasets and demonstrate that our method can improve the trainability of VQCs against the above-mentioned gradient issues.

title: Automatic Configuration Protocols for Optical Quantum Networks
authors: Amin Taherkhani, Andrew Todd, Kentaro Teramoto, Rodney Van Meter, Shota Nagayama
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Before quantum networks can scale up to practical sizes, there are many deployment and configuration tasks that must be automated. Currently, quantum networking testbeds are largely manually configured: network nodes are constructed out of a combination of free-space and fiber optics before being connected to shared single-photon detectors, time-todigital converters, and optical switches. Information about these connections must be tracked manually; mislabeling may result in experimental failure and protracted debugging sessions. In this paper, we propose protocols and algorithms to automate two such manual processes. First, we address the problem of automatically identifying connections between quantum network nodes and time-to-digital converters. Then, we turn to the more complex challenge of identifying the nodes attached to a quantum network's optical switches. Implementation of these protocols will help enable the development of other protocols necessary for quantum networks, such as network topology discovery, link quality monitoring, resource naming, and routing. We intend for this paper to serve as a roadmap for near-term implementation.

title: Tailored Quantum Device Calibration with Statistical Model Checking
authors: Filip Mazurek, Marissa D'Onofrio, Andrew Van Horn, Jiyong Yu, Kavyashree Ranawat, Jungsang Kim, Kenneth R. Brown
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum devices require precisely calibrated analog signals, a process that is complex and time-consuming. Many calibration strategies exist, and all require careful analysis and tuning to optimize system availability. To enable rigorous statistical evaluation of quantum calibration procedures, we leverage statistical model checking (SMC), a technique used in fields that require statistical guarantees. SMC allows for probabilistic evaluation of properties of interest, such as a certain parameter's time to failure. We extend the SMC for Processor Analysis (SPA) framework, which uses SMC for evaluation of classical systems, to create SPA for Quantum calibration (SPAQ) enabling simplified tuning and analysis of quantum system calibration. We focus on a directed acyclic graph-based calibration optimization scheme and demonstrate how to craft properties of interest for its analysis. We show how to use SPAQ to find lower bounds of time to failure information, hidden node dependencies, and parameter threshold values and use that information to improve simulated quantum system availability through calibration scheme adjustments.

title: Improved Tumor Segmentation and Classification in Breast Histopathology using Modified U-Net and Novel Self-Supervised Learning Techniques
authors: Sangishetti Karunakar, P Praveen
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The histopathological diagnosis of breast cancer based on imaging is one of the most important and yet most demanding tasks since the similarity between classes is high and the structure of tumor areas varies. Such common convolutional frameworks and current self-supervised learning (SSL) approaches are unable to pick up fine-grained morphological details in order to distinctly segment and classify. This article introduces a new two-phase system where a Context-Aware Dilated U-Net (CAD-U-Net) model is proposed along with a Structure-Preserving Self-Supervised Learning (SP-SSL) direction which are applied to breast histopathology issues. The proposed CAD-U-Net has replaced residual fusion block with dilation and an attention mechanism to bear greater sensitivity of boundary and be able to represent multi-scale feature. At the same time, SP-SSL likewise implements a new pretext task of patch-wise geometric restoration to pretrain the encoder without any manual labels. Manually-collated experiments on a subsample of breakhis data show that it has greatly outperformed U-Nets and contrastive SSL baselines in segmentation accuracy (Dice score: 0.912) and classification capability (F1-score: 0.938). The architecture under consideration has a strong generalization over magnification levels, and reduces false positives by 17 %. These findings emphasise the superiority of the dual-phase learning method to enhance diagnostic accuracy in the actual clinics.

authors: Yan Liu, Ting Zhang, Mingsheng Fang, Ruolan Wang, Anli Yang, Hao Dong, Lei Pan, Bing Yang, Ke Xiao, Zhihong Mai

title: Probabilistic Trajectory GOSPA: A Metric for Uncertainty-Aware Multi-Object Tracking Performance Evaluation
authors: Yuxuan Xia, Ángel F. García-Fernández, Johan Karlsson, Yu Ge, Lennart Svensson, Ting Yuan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Multisensor Fusion and Integration for Intelligent Systems (MFI)
abstract: This paper presents a generalization of the trajectory general optimal sub-pattern assignment (GOSPA) metric for evaluating multi-object tracking algorithms that provide trajectory estimates with track-level uncertainties. This metric builds on the recently introduced probabilistic GOSPA metric to account for both the existence and state estimation uncertainties of individual object states. Similar to trajectory GOSPA (TGOSPA), it can be formulated as a multidimensional assignment problem, and its linear programming relaxation—also a valid metric—is computable in polynomial time. Additionally, this metric retains the interpretability of TGOSPA, and we show that its decomposition yields intuitive costs terms associated to expected localization error and existence probability mismatch error for properly detected objects, expected missed and false detection error, and track switch error. The effectiveness of the proposed metric is demonstrated through a simulation study.

title: AI-Augmented Data Privacy Risk Assessment Framework for Smart Governance Applications
authors: Bharath Kishore Gudepu, Praveen Kumar Pemmasani, Krishna Chaitanya Gonugunta, B. Jegajothi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: With the rapid digitalization of public services, privacy concerns in smart governance ecosystems have escalated, necessitating robust and interpretable risk assessment frameworks. This paper presents PrivacyX-Net, an AI-augmented architecture designed for automated multi-dimensional privacy risk evaluation from policy documents. The framework begins by encoding annotated clauses using a fine-tuned Privacy-Bert, which captures domain-specific contextual semantics. These representations are structured into a hierarchical graph, where a Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) models inter-clause relationships. A Risk-Aware Attention Layer fuses outputs from both the semantic and graph-based streams to amplify high-risk contexts. Finally, a multi-label classifier predicts granular privacy risk scores across dimensions such as data collection, information sharing, data retention, and user control. The model was validated on the OPA-PolicyPrivacy dataset, achieving an F1-score of 0.89 and a Hamming loss of 0.061, outperforming existing baselines such as LSTM (F1 = 0.81) and GCN+BERT (F1 = 0.86). Extensive ablation studies and efficiency evaluations confirmed the effectiveness and scalability of the proposed architecture. Additionally, the model offers interpretability through attention visualization, supporting transparency in governance-driven decision-making. PrivacyX-Net thus enables automated, modular, and explainable privacy risk assessment, contributing significantly to the development of accountable digital infrastructures.

title: Analyzing Technology Ecosystem Business Models: A Predictive Modelling Approach
authors: Nandan Shrinivas Chebbi, Roshan Balaji Mahashabde, Bharath Masthi Shrinivas, Prashasth Kishore Makam, Sandeep Kumar, V Kiran
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: In the rapidly changing landscape of technology, companies are devoting an increasing amount of their resources to developing product ecosystems that collaborate to deliver enhanced consumer experiences and strengthen their business models. As opposed to traditional standalone solutions, these ecosystems are intended to facilitate everyday tasks, increase user engagement, and provide seamless integration, all of which ensure a steady stream of revenue and dedicated customer base. This analysis provides an overview of the many ecosystem models that are now transforming the technology industry. An examination of ecosystems that help businesses maintain long-term revenue sustainability and high customer retention rates is provided by the model analysis, along with insights into how ecosystems may enhance user experience by being more connected, straightforward, and user-friendly. Technology ecosystems’ quantitative effects are lacking, which makes it difficult to comprehend how they affect long-term revenue sustainability and customer retention. It is challenging to understand how technological ecosystems impact long-term revenue sustainability and customer retention due to the lack of measurable consequences. Through the use of multiple linear regression, this study illustrates the ecosystem business models’ long-term revenue and customer retention. The study visualized the relationships of the technology ecosystem with an accuracy of 90-99%. This shows how to measure ecosystem impact and gives firms data-driven insights to improve their ecosystem initiatives.

title: New Key Rate Bound for High-Dimensional BB84 with Multiple Basis Measurements
authors: Trevor N. Thomas, Walter O. Krawec
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: In this paper we derive a new bound on the secret key-rate of the High Dimensional BB84 protocol operating with multiple mutually unbiased bases (MUBs). To our knowledge, our proof is the first for this protocol that is both general (in that it can handle arbitrary, asymmetric channels), and also the first that derives a bound on the quantum min entropy for general attacks, without relying on post selection techniques or the asymptotic equipartition property. Because of this, our new result shows that far more optimistic key-rates are possible for a low number of signals, even in general channels. Furthermore, our proof methods may be broadly applicable to other protocols relying on multiple measurement bases and we prove several technical lemmas that may have independent interest. We evaluate our new bound and compare to prior work, showing that higher key-rates are possible in several operating scenarios. We also show some interesting behavior of the protocol when faced with asymmetric noise.

title: Method for Efficient GPU Light Field Content Generation Based on Diffusion Model
authors: DongHao Lu, ShuJun Xing, BinBin Yan, XinZhu Sang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of 3D display technologies, demand is increasing for high-quality, wide-angle, and multi-scene light field content. Traditional generation methods, which typically rely on dense camera arrays or large-scale image acquisition, incur high costs, limited flexibility, inefficient workflows, and poor detail reconstruction. To address these challenges, we propose a novel diffusion-based framework for converting planar images into light field images. Our approach leverages a pre-trained diffusion model to synthesize dense multi-view video sequences from sparse inputs (e.g., two images). These sequences are reconstructed into a high-fidelity 3D scenes via 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS), followed by shear-based rendering to extract continuous dynamic views. Finally, the rendered sequences are encoded into light field images for glasses-free 3D displays. Experimental results show that with only two input images, our method achieves SSIM <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.809$</tex> and PSNR <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=27.92$</tex>-comparable to 3DGS, while surpassing INGP-Base by 20.72% (SSIM) and 7.71% (PSNR), and exceeding M-NeRF360 by 2.27% in SSIM. This demonstrates our approach's ability to generate high-quality light field content from sparse inputs, significantly reducing acquisition time and costs while preserving fine details. The proposed framework offers a scalable solution for 3D content generation and advances practical applications of autostereoscopic displays.

title: Visible Photonic Component Development for Trapped-Ion Quantum Computing
authors: Elliot Lehman, Molly Krogstad, Molly P. Andersen, Sara Campbell, Kirk Cook, Bryan DeBono, Christopher Ertsgaard, Azure Hansen, Duc Nguyen, Adam Ollanik, Daniel Ouellette, Michael Plascak, Justin T. Schultz, Johanna Zultak, Nicholas Boynton, Christopher DeRose, Michael Gehl, Nicholas Karl
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Trapped-ion quantum computers, leveraging a quantum charge-coupled device (QCCD) architecture, have world-class performance in the field of quantum computing, offering high fidelities and all-to-all connectivity [1]. While systems have advanced over the last decade, much work remains to scale quantum computers to fault-tolerance. Providing scalable light delivery is one key challenge. Current systems utilize engineered bulk- and fiber-optic-based light delivery systems, external to the vacuum chamber, to deliver arrays of beams to ions. However, fundamental optical limitations preclude the use of such systems when scaling beyond thousands of qubits. Integrated photonic-based beam delivery offers a potential solution, with encouraging proof-of-concept demonstrations from the photonics and quantum communities [2]–[5]. Quantinuum and Sandia National Labs have partnered to accelerate the development of integrated photonics for trapped-ion quantum computing applications, working towards photonic components supporting high-fidelity operations. Here, we present development of photonic integrated components designed to deliver laser light to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Ba}^{+}$</tex> qubits, utilizing a low-loss, high-confinement, trap-integrable PECVD SiN platform. In order to demonstrate two-qubit gates at 532 nm, we developed low loss, tight bend waveguides, efficient edge couplers, and asymmetric multimode interference (MMI) splitters, along with beam-forming grating out-couplers delivering gaussian beams at the ion plane. For quantum state preparation and measurement (SPAM) applications at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{4 9 3 ~ n m}$</tex>, we demonstrate fabrication-tolerant splitters and low-crosstalk gratings. Measured component performance shows promise for future trap-integrated demonstrations.

title: Weaknesses of the ANEES and New Calibration Measures for Multivariate Predictions
authors: Markus Walker, Marcel Reith-Braun, Uwe D. Hanebeck
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Multisensor Fusion and Integration for Intelligent Systems (MFI)
abstract: Reliable quantification of uncertainty is crucial for trustworthy predictions in estimation theory and machine learning. However, existing credibility and calibration measures, such as the widely used averaged normalized estimation error squared (ANEES), often exhibit limitations when applied to biased model predictions. In this paper, we systematically review the ANEES and its alternatives, analyze their strengths and weaknesses, and highlight cases where standard measures fail to detect miscalibration. Building on recent advances in calibration measures, we propose two new measures: the generalized uncertainty calibration error and its normalized version. These measures unify and extend the concepts of estimator credibility and regression calibration to multivariate settings. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate the characteristics of credibility and calibration measures, including the proposed measures, and their applicability to regression models.

title: An Affordable AI-Driven Adaptive Learning Framework for Rural Indian Schools
authors: Linta Venugopal, A. Hency Juliet
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: India's conventional education system is largely teacher-centered, built around a standardized curriculum that forms the core of classroom instruction. While modern teaching methods are gradually being adopted to improve accessibility, rural schools continue to face significant hurdles, including limited infrastructure and a shortage of qualified teachers. These challenges often undermine the effectiveness of traditional educational approaches. Although digital tools have enhanced engagement and teaching quality in urban settings, rural areas still struggle with access and implementation. To bridge this gap, the current research proposes a cost-effective adaptive learning framework that integrates reinforcement learning and Explainable AI (XAI). This system is designed to support personalized learning, increase accessibility, and enhance instructional efficiency, even in resource-constrained environments. By offering AI-driven learning paths, offline access, and intelligent teacher support features, the framework aims to make education more inclusive and impactful for rural students. This paper outlines the system's key components, underlying methodology, and its potential to transform learning experiences and outcomes in underserved regions.

title: Dynamic Solutions for Hybrid Quantum-HPC Resource Allocation
authors: Roberto Rocco, Simone Rizzo, Matteo Barbieri, Gabriella Bettonte, Elisabetta Boella, Fulvio Ganz, Sergio Iserte, Antonio J. Peña, Petter Sandås, Alberto Scionti, Olivier Terzo, Chiara Vercellino, Giacomo Vitali, Paolo Viviani, Jonathan Frassineti, Sara Marzella, Daniele Ottaviani, Iacopo Colonnelli, Daniele Gregori
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The integration of quantum computers within classical High-Performance Computing (HPC) infrastructures is receiving increasing attention, with the former expected to serve as accelerators for specific computational tasks. However, combining HPC and quantum computers presents significant technical challenges, including resource allocation. This paper presents a novel malleability-based approach, alongside a workflow-based strategy, to optimize resource utilization in hybrid HPC-quantum workloads. With both these approaches, we can release classical resources when computations are offloaded to the quantum computer and reallocate them once quantum processing is complete. Our experiments with a hybrid HPC-quantum use case show the benefits of dynamic allocation, highlighting the potential of those solutions.

title: Residue Number System (RNS) Based Distributed Quantum Multiplication
authors: Bhaskar Gaur, Himanshu Thapliyal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Multiplication of quantum states is a frequently used function or subroutine in quantum algorithms and applications, making quantum multipliers an essential component of quantum arithmetic. However, quantum multiplier circuits suffer from high Toffoli depth and T gate usage, which ultimately affects their scalability and applicability on quantum computers. To address these issues, we propose utilizing the Residue Number System (RNS) based distributed quantum multiplication, which executes multiple quantum modulo multiplication circuits across quantum computers or jobs with lower Toffoli depth and T gate usage. Towards this end, we propose a design of Quantum Diminished-1 Modulo <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(2^{\mathrm{n}} + 1)$</tex> Multiplier, an essential component of RNS based distributed quantum multiplication. We provide estimates of quantum resource usage and compare them with those of an existing non-distributed quantum multiplier for 6 to 16 qubit sized output. Our comparative analysis estimates up to 46.018% lower Toffoli depth, and reduction in T gates of 34.483% to 86.25%.

title: Parametric Analysis using Pearson Heat Map on Ultrasonic Welding of PMMA Polymer Deployed for Structural Applications
authors: Ganesha G C, S Arungalai Vendan, M Chaturvedi, S Theodore Chandra
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The investigation is carried out on Polymethyl methacrylate, to understand the feasibility of ultrasonic signal being applied for its joining. The three key parameters such as Pressure, Amplitude and weld time were varied in three levels and experiments were carried out based on design of experiments. The welded samples were subjected to destructive testing, majorly focusing on evaluating the tensile and yield strength respectively. Pearson’s heat map was used to understand the correlation between the process parameters and the strength. The results emphasize that weld time dictates the Tensile Strength (Mpa) and Yield Strength (Mpa) predominantly followed by marginal impact created by other two parameters. However, it is imperative to optimize these parameters in order to arrive at requisite strength and quality as per the acceptable standards. The outcome of the study may be leveraged upon by the application engineers for their respective research verticals.

title: Towards X-Ueq: User-Driven Development of Experience Questionnaire
authors: Cosimo Miraglia, Roberto Filippi, Marco Cuerq, Domenico Schillaci, Paola Panarese, Stefania Colonnese
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Image and Signal Processing and Analysis (ISPA)
abstract: Immersive (XR) technologies are rapidly expanding, but their evaluation poses significant challenges. Standard User Experience (UX) questionnaires, such as the UEQ, fail to capture immersive qualities, while presencespecific tools, such as the PQ, are often verbose and, when used in combination, risk inducing survey fatigue. This paper addresses this methodological gap by proposing a comprehensive, user-driven framework for the development of integrated evaluation tools. We illustrate this framework through the case study of the development of the eXtended User Experience Questionnaire (X-UEQ), a novel 12-item module. Its six dimensions-perceived realism, agency, sensory engagement, interface quality, active exploration, and selfevaluation of performance-are theoretically grounded in established presence models and empirically derived from a qualitative study with 25 participants. The main contribution is twofold: a replicable, user-centered methodology and the resulting validation-ready tool that provides a necessary bridge between traditional usability evaluation and immersive presence evaluation.

title: Smart Kidney Health Analyzer using CT Imaging and Symptom Insights
authors: Ch.Mukesh, B.Sasaank, B.Duggireddy, R.Lalitha Karthik, P.Sai Sri Vatsa
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: This project further develops the diagnostic potential of kidney disease detection through the combination of deep learning approaches with patient-generated symptom knowledge and an intuitive interface. Expanding on previous studies employing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and InceptionV3 architecture for the classification of CT images, this study presents a multi-modal methodology that integrates imaging information with clinical symptoms to enhance diagnostic accuracy and contextual awareness. The model is created to categorize kidney conditions as normal, cysts, tumors, and stones using a selected and enriched set of CT scan datasets, in addition to examining symptom inputs based on a formalized knowledge base. The InceptionV3 model, with its ability to perform deep feature extraction, was trained with categorical cross-entropy loss and tested against metrics of accuracy, precision, and recall. To facilitate accessibility and real-time interaction, Incorporated Gradio as a front-end interface so that users clinicians and patients alike could enter symptoms, upload CT images, and obtain diagnostic feedback. This hybrid system highlights the potential of merging AI-driven imaging with patient-specific data for smarter, faster, and more complete kidney health analysis. Future work will concentrate on further symptom dataset enlargement and the system’s deployment into clinical environments to support real-time decision-making.

title: Model Predictive Integrated Control for Six-DOF Unmanned Aerial Vehicles
authors: Nguyen Hoang Viet, Tran Le Thang Dong, Nguyen Vu, Nguyen Quang Vinh
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Informatics (ICCRI)
abstract: This study proposes a Model Predictive Control (MPC)-based Integrated Guidance and Control (IGC) scheme for a fixed-wing Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) with six degrees of freedom (6DOF). The nonlinear UAV dynamics are linearized around a steady-level flight condition to facilitate controller design. Within this framework, the MPC controller is tasked with tracking a moving target following a threedimensional sinusoidal trajectory. The proposed approach leverages the predictive nature and constraint-handling capabilities of MPC to ensure accurate trajectory tracking under actuator limitations and dynamic flight conditions. Comparative simulation results demonstrate that the MPC-based IGC system significantly outperforms conventional PID control in terms of tracking precision, responsiveness, and robustness. These findings underscore the potential of MPC for advanced UAV guidance and control, and establish a foundation for future developments incorporating sensor noise, external disturbances, and optimal parameter tuning.

title: Search Space Partition Using an Ising Machine for Capacitated Vehicle Routing Problem
authors: Eiji Kawase, Shuta Kikuchi, Hideaki Tamai, Shu Tanaka
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: In this study, we proposed a method using an Ising machine to support a mathematical programming solver in order to partition the search space for large-scale combinatorial optimization problems, especially for the capacitated vehicle routing problem. As a method for partitioning the search space, we use the constrained maximum cut problem (CMC), which allows for efficient embedding and is easy to solve on the Ising machine. By using CMC, it is possible to partition the search space for solutions as subproblems within the feasible space of the master problem. In order to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed method, experiments were carried out using multiple instances. The results indicated that feasible solutions to the master problem can be obtained quickly using the proposed method.

title: Entanglement Routing Over Networks With Time Multiplexed Repeaters
authors: Emily A. Van Milligen, Eliana Jacobson, Ashlesha Patil, Gayane Vardoyan, Don Towsley, Saikat Guha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum networks will enable long-distance entanglement distribution through repeater nodes capable of both generating external Bell pairs with their neighbors—independently and identically distributed (i.i.d.) with probability p—and performing internal Bell State Measurements (BSMs), which succeed with probability q. These probabilities depend on the specific experimental parameters of the network. While global link state knowledge can maximize entanglement generation rates between any two consumers, it is often impractical due to the network's dynamic nature. This work evaluates a multipath routing protocol based on local link state knowledge, designed for time-multiplexed repeaters that can perform BSMs across different time steps. We employ simulations across various network topologies to characterize how consumer placement and network topology influence the utility of dynamic and static routing strategies. Results show that increasing the time multiplexing block length, k, enhances the average entanglement generation rate, though at the cost of higher initial latency. When a step-function memory decoherence model is introduced—where qubits are stored in quantum memory for a time that follows an exponential distribution—an optimal k emerges. As p decreases or the average memory lifetime increases, this optimal k grows, reflecting a trade-off where the advantages of time multiplexing must be balanced against the heightened risk of losing previously established entangled pairs.

title: Freely assembled multifunctional acoustofluidic devices based on flexible printed circuit boards
authors: Shaoshuai Han, Di Lian, Linjin Wu, Boyu Zhao, Jiayang Wang, Yi Fang, Peiyao An, Ning Li, Yue Li, Jun Ren, Dongfang Liang, Xin Yang, Zhenlin Wu
abstract: Surface acoustic wave (SAW)-based acoustofluidics has shown great potential for manipulating micro- and nanoparticles, enabling applications such as acoustic centrifugation and particle patterning. However, conventional SAW devices fabricated through photolithography and metal deposition suffer from long processing times and lack structural tunability after fabrication. In this study, a functionally tunable acoustofluidic device based on a flexible printed circuit board (FPCB) is proposed. By mechanically clamping interdigital electrodes (IDEs) on the FPCB to a piezoelectric substrate and incorporating an impedance-matching network, efficient SAW excitation is achieved. The device enables rapid enrichment of polystyrene (PS) particles ranging from 500 nm to 5 μm. Moreover, controlled patterning of 10 μm particles is realized using a magnetically attached rotating fixture, which adjusts the acoustic wave propagation direction on the substrate to excite different acoustic modes. This modular and reconfigurable FPCB-SAW device offers an adaptable platform for rapid functional validation of SAW systems and facilitates broader applications of acoustofluidic technology.

title: Doctoral Symposium Keynote: ISSREW 2025
authors: Marco Vieira
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: Embarking on a PhD is both an intellectual mission and a personal journey. In this keynote, I will share lessons learned from supervising and mentoring doctoral students from diverse cultural, gender, and disciplinary backgrounds, highlighting the ups, downs, and turning points that shape the path to a PhD. We will explore what a PhD really means beyond the diploma: learning how to ask the right questions, navigating setbacks and rejections, building resilience, and ultimately discovering joy in the process of research. Drawing on stories from my own students, we will discuss strategies for selecting a research direction, working effectively with advisors and peers, and maintaining balance throughout the process. The goal is to provide practical advice, candid reflections, and encouragement so that doctoral students not only succeed in earning their PhD but also learn how to enjoy the journey.

title: The NQCCs UK Quantum Hackathon : Developing the UK Quantum Computing Workforce and user Community
authors: Daisy Shearer
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The UK's National Quantum Computing Centre hosts an annual hackathon aimed at early-career quantum computing developers to give them the opportunity to work on real-world use cases provided by quantum computing end users across a variety of sectors . The event aims to investigate quantum solutions for industry-provided use-case problems across different sectors and application domains; help create an active quantum computing community spanning the whole value chain from quantum computing providers, to quantum developers and end users; enhance connectivity between quantum computing providers and end-users, enabling discussions on both opportunities as well as limitations of current technology; and increase awareness of quantum computing and potential use cases to research students and early-career scientists (Masters, PhD and Postdoc level). Since 2022, the UK Quantum Hackathon has brought together 247 participants to develop 47 industrial use case problems with access to 15 quantum computing providers. In this poster, we present our learnings and recommendations from the past four years for hosting cross-sector quantum hackathons to maximise the benefits for each stakeholder group involved. We also outline a variety of considerations for best practices, including: 1) embedding responsible and ethical quantum computing practices, 2) ensuring quantum hackathons are accessible and equitable, and 3) defining measurable goals and outcomes for each stakeholder group.

title: Enabling High-Impact Quantum Public Engagement, Through A UK-Wide Collaboration
authors: Daisy Sherrer
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Public engagement with quantum technologies is crucial for fostering public awareness, understanding and trust, as well as building a future quantum workforce. This is underscored by the United Nations� proclamation of 2025 as the International Year of Quantum Science and Technology, with the stated aim “to use the occasion of 100 years of quantum mechanics in 2025 to help raise public awareness of the importance and impact of quantum science and applications on all aspects of life.” To mark this occasion, the UK's National Quantum Computing Centre brought together a consortium of fifteen institutions to showcase quantum science and technology research and innovation from across the UK. This consortium came together to develop public engagement demonstrations for 'The Quantum Zone' exhibit at the Royal Society's Summer Science Exhibition 2025. These demos showcased quantum concepts and components, as well as quantum technologies and examples of their applications. By taking a collaborative approach to the exhibit, the group was able to take part in a large-scale public engagement activity, allowing resource requirements to be shared across multiple institutions. It also enabled over 160 quantum researchers and professionals to access quantum-specific public engagement training, laying the groundwork for the establishment of a quantum outreach community of practice in the UK. Over the course of six days, the exhibit enabled 7871 “meaningful interactions” with members of the UK public visiting the Summer Science exhibition. This talk will discuss the process of planning, managing, delivering and evaluating the Quantum Zone exhibit. We will share our key findings on best practices, lessons learned and future work in this area.
