title: Rethinking Fluid Antennas for ISAC: A Systematic Review and a Novel Air-Ground Collaborative Framework
authors: Mengru Wu, Shizhen Lai, Weidang Lu, Bo Zhao, Lei Guo, Arumugam Nallanathan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Fluid antennas (FAs) have emerged as a promising technology for enhancing the performance of integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems owing to their flexible antenna positions. This paper provides a comprehensive review of FA-enabled ISAC for showcasing the significant potential of FAs in enhancing ISAC systems. On this basis, we propose an innovative air-ground collaborative framework that incorporates FAs to tackle complex tasks involving sensing for data acquisition, communication for information exchange, and computation for data processing. In this framework, the collaboration relationship between unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and an FA-equipped remote base station (BS) is explored to complete the complex tasks. Specifically, multiple UAVs sense ground targets by transmitting radar signals. Upon receiving radar echoes, each UAV processes sensing data in collaboration with the BS by offloading a part of the sensing data to the BS. To facilitate cooperation, we utilize the radar estimation rate to characterize sensing performance and design a synergistic algorithm to coordinate the positions of FAs, the receive beamforming of the BS, computation resource allocation, task offloading ratios, and UAV deployment to minimize the average task completion delay in data processing, subject to sensing performance requirements. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed scheme outperforms several baselines in terms of the average task completion delay.

title: High Gate Reliability and Breakdown Voltage p-GaN HEMTs Based on Post-Annealing-Free Oxygen Plasma Treatment
authors: Zifeng Qu, Jiachen Duan, Ang Li, Xuanming Zhang, Hao Tian, Jingyue Wu, Qiyi Guo, Qiyuan Zhang, Yizhou Jiang, Ningyu Luo, Xiaodong Zhang, Guohao Yu, Chao Long, Wen Liu, Huiqing Wen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Device and Materials Reliability
abstract: This work presents an enhancement-mode (E-mode) p-GaN HEMT that significantly improves gate reliability and breakdown voltage through a post-annealing-free oxygen plasma treatment (GOPT). This method forms a GaOxN1x interfacial layer beneath the gate metal, increasing the gate breakdown voltage from 13.8 V to 24.8 V and reducing the gate leakage current by three orders of magnitude at VGS=8 V, compared to conventional Schottky p-GaN gates. Time-dependent gate breakdown (TDGB) testing predicts a maximum safe operating gate voltage of 9.2 V for a 10-year lifetime with a 63% failure probability. The fabricated GOPT p-GaN HEMTs show excellent off-state drain breakdown performance, with a voltage of up to 2940 V at a gate-to-drain distance of 28 5m. This approach offers a simplified fabrication process with superior performance in both gate reliability and high-voltage capability, establishing GOPT p-GaN HEMTs as a promising candidate for highperformance, high-reliability power electronics.

title: Agent-Q: Fine-Tuning Large Language Models for Quantum Circuit Generation and Optimization
authors: Linus Jern, Valter Uotila, Cong Yu, Bo Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have achieved remarkable outcomes in complex problems, including math, coding, and analyzing large amounts of scientific reports. Yet, few works have explored the potential of LLMs in quantum computing. The most challenging problem is to leverage LLMs to automatically generate quantum circuits at a large scale. Fundamentally, the existing pre-trained LLMs lack the knowledge of quantum circuits. In this paper, we address this challenge by fine-tuning LLMs and injecting the domain-specific knowledge of quantum computing. We describe Agent-Q, an LLM fine-tuning system to generate and optimize quantum circuits. In particular, agentQ implements the mechanisms to generate training data sets and constructs an end-to-end pipeline to fine-tune pre-trained LLMs to generate parameterized quantum circuits for various optimization problems. Agent-Q provides <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 4, 0 0 0}$</tex> quantum circuits covering a large spectrum of the quantum optimization landscape: 12 optimization problem instances and their optimized QAOA, VQE, and adaptive VQE circuits. Based thereon, Agent-Q fine-tunes LLMs and constructs syntactically correct parametrized quantum circuits in OpenQASM 3.0. We have evaluated the quality of the LLM-generated circuits and parameters by comparing them to the optimized expectation values and distributions. Experimental results show superior performance of Agent-Q, compared to several state-of-the-art LLMs and better parameters than random. Agent-Q can be integrated into an agentic workflow, and the generated parametrized circuits with initial parameters can be used as a starting point for further optimization, e.g., as templates in quantum machine learning and as benchmarks for compilers and hardware.

title: An Efficient Way of Detecting Stress by Using PPG Signals Data
authors: Chanagond Jambagi, A P Pooja
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Stress has become a prevalent issue in daily life, often arising from challenging situations that can adversely affect mental health and lead to chronic conditions such as diabetes, heart disease, and kidney failure. As a natural response, stress encourages us to confront various threats or obstacles, however, our coping mechanisms significantly influence our overall health and well-being, making effective stress management essential for a balanced life. Recent advancements in stress detection have highlighted photoplethysmography (PPG) as an effective non-invasive method. The Dataset containing physiological signals data such as temperature, heart rate, respiratory rate, and galvanic skin response data, alongside self-reported stress levels. The collected data underwent preprocessing to structure it for analysis, followed by feature extraction to identify key physiological patterns relevant to stress classification. A multinomial Naïve Bayes classifier was then applied to categorize stress levels based on these features, achieved an impressive accuracy of $99.21 \%$ in stress classification. These findings underscore the significance of these metrics in predicting stress.

title: Next-Gen Health Monitoring: Personalized Insights with Passive Sensing
authors: S. Pavithra, S Sivasakthiselvan, PM. Kavitha
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: In this paper, the author proposes a personalized and non-invasive Personalized Health and Infusion Management Device that would enable continuous monitoring of vital signs, including body temperature, heart rate (measured through PPG), ECG, and blood pressure, by tracking Pulse Transit Time (PTT). The system is constructed on the Arduino platform and can combine and stream real-time data on a locally available reader. Correlations of PTT with robust negative data above 0.85 in systolic, 0.72 in diastolic, and 0.81 in mean arterial blood pressure were confirmed in 25 subjects and thus pointed on the validity of the regression-based blood pressure estimates regression model. Their temperature recording registered <0.5 percent error concerning a digital thermometer, and the heart rate was within acceptable deviation ranges. Its low price (~4400 INR), modular design, and future possibilities (cloud connectivity and AI-based diagnostics) make the device a relevant breakthrough in the field of personal health monitoring in general and poor rural communities in particular. These results prove the potential of the system to lower the number of visits to hospitals, facilitate the detection of health abnormalities at an early stage, and facilitate telemedicine applications that can be scaled.

title: Creative and Arts-Based Practices to Engage Young Girls in STEM - Preliminary Insights from a Qualitative Study
authors: Claudia Maria Cutrupi, Paloma Diaz, Francesco Faenza, Letizia Jaccheri, Claudia Canali, Ignacio Aedo, Vasileios Koulountzos, Cristina Galani
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: The underrepresentation of women and girls in STEM is a global issue influenced by various social, cultural, and institutional factors, including gender stereotypes, limited engagement opportunities, and insufficient support from educators. Early interventions are essential, and teachers require effective tools and strategies for delivering STEM education that is both enjoyable and inclusive. The TechLARP Erasmus+ project aims to upskill prospective and current STEM educators in genderinclusive and arts-based approaches to deliver engaging STEM education to children and youth. This paper presents the results of good practices currently in place to engage children and young students in STEM through arts-based approaches. We identified various interventions, their contributions, requirements, and challenges they address. We conducted 30 semi-structured interviews with stakeholders involved in implementing technology-related interventions using arts-based approaches, most of which were run in European countries. We analyzed the interviews to identify the main themes that could inspire the design of future interventions. The research offers preliminary insights into key characteristics to consider when designing engaging and inclusive STEM experiences. The study revealed diverse, creative approaches-such as design thinking, role-playing, embodied learning, and maker spaces-that effectively engage young learners. It also highlighted common factors in scalability, replicability, skill development, and collaboration between stakeholders. These findings address two key issues: the need for teacher training in gender-inclusive STEM education and the development of strategies to boost girls' interest and skills in STEM. Future steps of this research will include an in-depth analysis of the results in comparison to the relevant literature on current practices. These will help design extensive guidelines to support educators in implementing arts-based practices.

title: Learning to Learn With Quantum Optimization Via Quantum Neural Networks
authors: Kuan–Cheng Chen, Hiromichi Matsuyama, Wei–hao Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithms (QAOA) promise efficient solutions to classically intractable combinatorial optimization problems by harnessing shallowdepth quantum circuits. Yet, their performance and scalability often hinge on effective parameter optimization, which remains nontrivial due to rugged energy landscapes and hardware noise. In this work, we introduce a quantum meta-learning framework that combines quantum neural networks, specifically Quantum Long Short-Term Memory (QLSTM) architectures, with QAOA. By training the QLSTM optimizer on smaller graph instances, our approach rapidly generalizes to larger, more complex problems, substantially reducing the number of iterations required for convergence. Through comprehensive benchmarks on Max-Cut and Sherrington-Kirkpatrick model instances, we demonstrate that QLSTM-based optimizers converge faster and achieve higher approximation ratios compared to classical baselines, thereby offering a robust pathway toward scalable quantum optimization in the NISQ era.

title: AgroPredict: Crop Yield Prediction using Logistic Regression and Random Forest
authors: Srividhya S, Shreyans Jain H, Vandan Jain, Anmol Rajput, S. Palanikumar, K. Mamatha
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: This paper describes a machine learning-based analysis of crop yield prediction across the states of India using a Logistic Regression and Random Forest classifiers. The analysis relied on an openly available dataset containing information about the different crops, states, years, area, and production. The data was cleaned, and featurization was performed before classifying the crop yields into "High" or "Low". The models were trained on the dataset and evaluated using common classification metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. The empirical results showed that logistic regression achieved an accuracy of 99.82% which was higher than the Random Forest Classifier, achieving 99.47%. Although their accuracy is displayed as being different, the Logistic Regression provides a better tradeoff between the precision and recall, being both effective and interpretable enough for use in the real world. Therefore, machine learning techniques such as logistic regression and random forest provide a considerable potential for reliable crop yield forecasts, and thus improved agricultural planning and decision-making.

title: Engineering Ethics in Experimental Research: A South-South Perspective on Deliberative Strategies and Institutional Management
authors: Nomcebo H. Mthombeni, Olatundi Mukaila Iyiola, Pfano Mashau, Renadani Wilson Maladzhi
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: As engineering innovations continue to reshape modern society particularly in fields such as nanotechnology, energy systems, and smart infrastructure, ethical considerations in experimental research have become increasingly complex, especially within the African context where regulatory systems are still evolving, resources for oversight are limited, and socioenvironmental vulnerabilities heighten the stakes of technological experimentation. The study aims to address this gap by conducting a comparative analysis between the Durban University of Technology (DUT) in South Africa and the University of Ibadan (UI) in Nigeria. This analysis aims to enhance ethics governance and deliberative strategies for experimental engineering research. The comparative analysis will provide valuable insights for improving ethical practices and decision-making processes in both institutions. The study employs a qualitative methodology based on ethics committee reports, faculty interviews, and curriculum audits from both institutions. Findings reveal that ethical risk is often overlooked in experimental work involving engineered materials, prototype testing, energy systems, and environmental interventions. The absence of formal ethical review for such research not only exposes institutions to reputational risk but also limits the development of ethically conscious engineers.

title: A Practical Framework for Assessing the Performance of Observable Estimation in Quantum Simulation
authors: Siyuan Niu, Efekan Kökcü, Sonika Johri, Anurag Ramesh, Avimita Chatterjee, David E. Bernal Neira, Daan Camps, Thomas Lubinski
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Simulating dynamics of physical systems is a key application of quantum computing, with potential impact in fields such as condensed matter physics and quantum chemistry. However, current quantum algorithms for Hamiltonian simulation yield results that are inadequate for real use cases and suffer from lengthy execution times when implemented on near-term quantum hardware. In this work, we introduce a framework for evaluating the performance of quantum simulation algorithms, focusing on the computation of observables, such as energy expectation values. Our framework provides end-to-end demonstrations of algorithmic optimizations that utilize Pauli term groups based on <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex>-commutativity, generate customized Clifford measurement circuits, and implement weighted shot distribution strategies across these groups. These demonstrations span multiple quantum execution environments, allowing us to identify critical factors influencing runtime and solution accuracy. We integrate enhancements into the QED-C Application-Oriented Benchmark suite, utilizing problem instances from the opensource HamLib collection. Our results demonstrate a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 7. 1} \boldsymbol{\%}$</tex> error reduction through Pauli grouping methods, with an additional 37.6% improvement from the optimized shot distribution strategy. Our framework provides an essential tool for advancing quantum simulation performance using algorithmic optimization techniques, enabling systematic evaluation of improvements that could maximize near-term quantum computers’ capabilities and advance practical quantum utility as hardware evolves.

title: Optimizing State Preparation for Variational Quantum Regression on NISQ Hardware
authors: Frans Perkkola, Ilmo Salmeperä, Arianne Meijer-van de Griend, C.-C. Joseph Wang, Ryan S. Bennink, Jukka K. Nurminen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The execution of quantum algorithms on modern hardware is often constrained by noise and qubit decoherence, limiting the circuit depth and the number of gates that can be executed. Circuit optimization techniques help mitigate these limitations, enhancing algorithm feasibility. In this work, we implement, optimize, and execute a variational quantum regression algorithm using a novel state preparation method. By leveraging ZX-calculus-based optimization techniques, such as Pauli pushing, phase folding, and Hadamard pushing, we achieve a more efficient circuit design. Our results demonstrate that these optimizations enable the successful execution of the quantum regression algorithm on current hardware. Furthermore, the techniques presented are broadly applicable to other quantum circuits requiring arbitrary real-valued state preparation, advancing the practical implementation of quantum algorithms.

title: LEP-QNN: Loan Eligibility Prediction Using Quantum Neural Networks
authors: Nouhaila Innan, Alberto Marchisio, Mohamed Bennai, Muhammad Shafique
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Predicting loan eligibility with high accuracy remains a significant challenge in the finance sector. Accurate predictions enable financial institutions to make informed decisions, mitigate risks, and effectively adapt services to meet customer needs. However, the complexity and the highdimensional nature of financial data have always posed significant challenges to achieving this level of precision. To overcome these issues, we propose a novel approach that employs Quantum Machine Learning (QML) for Loan Eligibility Prediction using Quantum Neural Networks (LEP-QNN). Our innovative approach achieves an accuracy of 98 % in predicting loan eligibility from a single, comprehensive dataset. This performance boost is attributed to the strategic implementation of a dropout mechanism within the quantum circuit, aimed at minimizing overfitting and thereby improving the model's predictive reliability. In addition, our exploration of various optimizers leads to identifying the most efficient setup for our LEPQNN framework, optimizing its performance. We also rigorously evaluate the resilience of LEP-QNN under different quantum noise scenarios, ensuring its robustness and dependability for quantum computing environments. This research showcases the potential of QML in financial predictions and establishes a foundational guide for advancing QML technologies, marking a step towards developing advanced, quantum-driven financial decision-making tools.

title: Trade-Off Between Communication Rounds and Local Rounds in Federated Learning
authors: Vinit Hegiste, Tatjana Legler, Martin Ruskowski
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) enables collaborative model training without sharing raw data, making it crucial for privacy-sensitive applications. However, optimizing the tradeoff between communication rounds and local rounds poses a challenge, especially in industrial scenarios with a limited number of clients. Unlike conventional FL setups with many participants, industrial FL often involves only a few clients, requiring an efficient balance between CRs and LRs to maximize model performance within a fixed training budget. This study systematically evaluates the impact of varying CRs and LRs while keeping the total number of training iterations constant. Using the CIFAR100 dataset and DenseNet-121, we compare FL training from scratch against pre-trained models initialized with ImageNet weights. Our results reveal that FL can achieve comparable accuracy across varying CR-to-LR ratios when the total number of training iterations is fixed. Specifically, non-pretrained models achieved a peak accuracy of $\mathbf{5 4. 6 1 \%}$, whereas pre-trained models reached $83.67 \%$, surpassing centralized DenseNet-121 training without augmentation $(82.62 \%)$. Furthermore, we examine the influence of non-IID client data distributions, highlighting that strategic class allocation improves FL performance in industrial applications. These insights provide practical guidelines for configuring FL systems under resource constraints.

title: Quantum-Enhanced Nature-Inspired Scheme for Secure Energy-Aware Routing in IoT WSNs
authors: Kurri Rajani, M Archana, Bandi Rambabu, M Mounika
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The integration of the Internet of Things with Wireless Sensor Networks introduces complex challenges related to energy efficiency and data security, particularly in the context of emerging quantum threats. This paper proposes the Quantum-Enhanced Nature-Inspired Routing Algorithm (QENI-RA), a secure and energy-aware routing framework designed for large-scale IoT-WSNs. QENI-RA leverages a hybrid optimization strategy that combines quantum-behaved particle swarm optimization, chaotic Lévy flight exploration, and Sobol sequence-based initialization to dynamically select energy-optimal cluster heads and multi-hop paths. Security is reinforced through a dual-layer cryptographic scheme that integrates BB84-based quantum key distribution for key exchange and Kyber lattice-based encryption for data confidentiality, offering resilience against both classical and quantum adversaries. Extensive simulations conducted using NS-3 across network sizes ranging from 50 to 5,000 nodes demonstrate that QENI-RA reduces average energy consumption by 17.6%, extends network lifetime (time to first node death) by 24.3%, and improves the packet delivery ratio by 9.8%, compared to state-of-the-art quantum-inspired protocols such as QBER and QPSOFL. Furthermore, the proposed framework incurs only a 3.4% throughput overhead while maintaining high levels of security. These findings position QENI-RA as a robust and scalable solution for secure, sustainable routing in next-generation IoT sensor networks.

title: Secure IoT Voting System with Fingerprint Authentication and Real-Time Monitoring
authors: Yasmin M, Sharmila S, Swathi S, Sujitha S, Renuka G, Thirisha P
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Traditional voting can be modernised through the use of electronic voting to enhance its openness, security, and accessibility in government, university, and organisational voting. This paper proposes the development of a secure automated voting system that utilises features such as IoTs, biometric authentication, and cloud integration to eliminate the possibility of manual errors and voting fraud. Conventional systems are prone to tampering in the election process due to poor identity verification and the inability to prevent duplicate votes. In this electronic voting system, fingerprint authentication is carried out using the ESP32 microcontroller to limit voting to registered voters, ensuring that every voter can vote only once and cannot impersonate another voter. Votes are locally buffered in EEPROM and sent using a web API to Google Sheets in the cloud, where they can be tracked remotely. The LCD screen provides instant feedback, and the automation of the Blynk IoT platform enables remote tracking of vote counting, member registration, and system data reset.

title: Federated Learning with Channel Forecasting and DenseNet-based Model Optimization for 6G-Enabled Pervasive Applications
authors: Umamaheswari S K, K. Baalaji
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The advent of sixth generation (6G) networks heralds a transformative shift in pervasive applications by enabling ultra-fast, low-latency, and energy-efficient communication for massive distributed data processing. In this context, Federated Learning (FL) has emerged as a compelling solution for privacy-preserving model training across distributed edge devices. However, the effectiveness of FL in real-world scenarios remains limited due to the lack of user participation incentives and inefficient device selection strategies. To address this, we propose a novel FL framework that combines a one-sided matching theory-based incentive mechanism to encourage active user engagement by aligning user preferences and system rewards. The main significance of the work is to enhance learning efficiency under volatile communication conditions, we introduce device-to-device (D2D) collaboration and channel state prediction using Echo State Networks (ESNs) to anticipate and mitigate poor network links. For model optimization, we adopt a lightweight DenseNet-based architecture that runs locally on user devices, offering efficient feature extraction while maintaining high predictive accuracy and low computational overhead. This setup significantly reduces the training time and energy footprint, making it suitable for latency-sensitive, resource-constrained 6G environments. Comprehensive performance evaluations demonstrate that our approach achieves superior convergence time reduction and energy consumption savings compared to traditional FL schemes, while also ensuring fair utility distribution among users.

title: Confidence Analysis with Recognised Text of Viva Responses using RoBERTa and Stacking Classifier
authors: Samudrala Sai Santhoshi Haneesha, Peeta Basa Pati
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: This study addresses the challenge of assessing the confidence levels of students or candidates based on speech, which is converted to text for analysis. Understanding confidence from speech converted into text helps create customized feedback and improve how performance is assessed and supported. The process involves extracting key details and patterns from the text that indicate how confident an individual sounds, making the evaluation clearer and more accurate. To analyze the confidence levels, advanced text representations called embeddings, such as BERT and RoBERTa, were used to capture the meaning and context of the speech. These embeddings were then processed using various machine learning models to predict confidence levels. The best results were observed using staking classifier of two models together, Random Forest and Naöve Bayes, which improved prediction generalization and resilience by utilizing the advantages of both models, which gave an accuracy of $\mathbf{9 2 \% . T h i s}$ method has a significant practical impact on feedback systems, educational personalization, and HR interview ratings of candidate confidence, all of which improve hiring and training initiative choices.

title: A Federated Learning Approach with Spiking Neurons and Clustering for Smart Meter Data
authors: Ubaid Ahmed, Ahsan Raza Khan, Rao Naveed Bin Rais, Anzar Mahmood, Sajjad Hussain, Ahmed Zoha
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Residential smart meters data is essential for load flow analysis and demand-supply balance in smart grids. However, centralized load forecasting methods compromise consumer privacy and lead to high communication overhead due to the transmission of sensitive data. Federated learning (FL) addresses these concerns by enabling decentralized model training. However, traditional FL models rely on computationally intensive architectures, such as Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, which are not suitable for resource-constrained devices. Additionally, a single global FL model fails to account for diverse household consumption patterns, resulting in suboptimal forecasting performance. To overcome these challenges, we propose a novel federated averaging (FedAvg) approach based on integrate-and-fire (IF) spiking neurons for short-term load forecasting (STLF). Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) provide event-driven, energy-efficient processing, reducing computational complexity and communication costs. In addition, we introduce a parameter-based clustering mechanism that leverages the statistical properties of model updates to group households with similar consumption patterns. Our method enhances model aggregation and effectively captures user-specific consumption patterns. Experimental results on a real-world dataset of 18 homes demonstrate that our FedAvg-IF model reduces RMSE by approximately $74 \%$ and MAE by $82 \%$ compared to the FedAvgLSTM model. The introduction of the clustering mechanism (FedAvg-IF-C) further decreases communication costs by about $89 \%$ and computational time by $61 \%$, respectively.

title: Empowering AI-Driven Entrepreneurship: The Synergistic Role of Machine Learning
authors: Anshu Latiyan, Sachin Ghai, Rakesh Kumar, Bijay Kumar Paikaray
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is playing a key role in transformation of entrepreneurial landscape, empowering businesses to outperform, innovate and grow unprecedentedly. Entrepreneurship driven by artificial intelligence enables businesses to open new opportunities by making strategic choices, refining operations and automating processes. However, with all its benefits, usage of artificial intelligence poses significant difficulties for organizations, including issues related to data privacy, compliance and requirement for skilled labor. With this paper, this research explores the two-fold impact of artificial intelligence in startup culture, its capacity to foster growth and innovation, as well as the obstacles that deter its adoption. The strategy is built on four key pillars: startups, challenges, enablers, and AI technologies. In the current business world, artificial intelligence is playing an important role in entrepreneurship. It offers both the opportunities and challenges that impacts economy and growth of enterprises. The research also examines at how machine learning is changing entrepreneurship by enabling better decision making, enhancing the ability to recognize opportunities, and speeding company expansion. The result indicate that AI tools are becoming indispensable for present business owners. The key research outcomes provide useful insights for researchers, entrepreneurs, and policymakers who want to better comprehend and encourage AI-driven initiatives. The findings of this paper will positively support the discussion of use of artificial intelligence in building the future of entrepreneurship, providing suggestions for founders, policy builders and researchers to steer this ever-emerging field effectively. Also, AI tools are increasingly indispensable for contemporary business owners.

title: Methodology for Analyzing Competency-Based Learning: An Approach Based on Active Methods and Artificial Intelligence
authors: Andreia Leles, José Roberto Cardoso, Sandra G. Puga, Amanda M. Da Silva, Eduardo G. V. Cruz
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: Active teaching methods and adaptive learning are used in engineering education to encourage competency development. Although learning analysis must be based on competencies to monitor the progress of each student, little is known about the relationship between active methods and competency development. Since it is difficult to track active methods that guide students and teachers through the teaching-learning process, we aimed at creating an educational approach to map and correlate competencies, providing recommendations for learning objects, enabling adaptive learning through artificial intelligence. We hypothesized it is possible to track the active methods used and the related competencies based on the recommendation of learning objects. First, we defined the analysis of competencybased learning as its theme, exploring the relationship between competencies, active methods and learning objects. The Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) method was used to map competencies, as it clarifies which active methods develop which competencies. The Open University dataset was used to train AI models. A learning object recommendation strategy was proposed, making it possible to trace the competencies and active methods used. The AI-based recommendation guides adaptive learning by course, class, or student. The use of the AHP method was promising, simplifying the recommendation system. The performance of the AI models was efficient, predicting learning objects in an adaptive way according to student profile. This is the first study that focused on competencies and traceability according to teaching method. Real data from universities can further improve our model that has been validated by research data.

title: Speech-to-Text Forced Alignment Benchmark
authors: Yunbin Deng, Fred Richardson, John Steinberg, Pedro Torres-Carrasquillo
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Image and Signal Processing and Analysis (ISPA)
abstract: The speech community has established open benchmarks for various aspects of speech processing. However, a comprehensive benchmark for time alignment of speech and corresponding transcripts, known as forced alignment, is notably absent. This paper provides a thorough study of this problem. The key contributions are: 1) An extensive evaluation and comparison of forced alignment algorithms; 2) A study of the robustness of alignment methods against channel variation and additive noise; 3) Investigation of forced alignment on long conversational telephone speech audios. 4) Exploration of forced alignment in low-resource languages. The key findings are: 1) Neural aligners demonstrate nearly equivalent accuracy as Hidden Markov Model (HMM) approaches for short utterances; 2) The Connectionist Temporal Classification (CTC) segmentation approach shows significant robustness; 3) Enlarging the CTC window size significantly improves the CTC alignment accuracy of long audio segments; 4) Off-the-shelf models don't generalize well to conversational telephone speech data and lower-resource languages. Forced alignment of long conversational audio and lower-resource languages remains a challenging problem.

title: Benchmarking Adaptive Genetic Pulse-Level Optimization on Standard Quantum Algorithms
authors: William Aguilar-Calvo, Santiago Núñez-Corrales
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Noise in current quantum hardware (NISQ devices) poses a major obstacle by degrading gate operations and overall circuit fidelity toward FTQC. Traditional quantum error correction (QEC) is effective but resource-intensive, requiring several extra qubits and operations beyond the reach of near-term devices. Quantum error mitigation (QEM) offers a complementary path by reducing the impact of error prior to full correction. We present an adaptive pulse-level QEM using genetic algorithms to dynamically adjust control pulses in real-time, improving algorithm fidelity without modifying the logic structure of a quantum circuit. By targeting pulse parameters directly, this method reduces the impact of various noise sources, improving algorithm resilience in quantum circuits. To demonstrate the effectiveness of our methodology, we apply our protocol to five key quantum algorithms, including Bernstein-Vazirani, DeutschJozsa, Grover's search, Quantum Fourier Transform (QFT), and its inverse (IQFT). Experimental results show that our pulse-level optimization strategy provides a flexible and efficient solution for increasing fidelity during the noisy execution of quantum circuits. Our work contributes to advance error mitigation techniques, essential for robust quantum computing, which will increasingly require HPC infrastructure as quantum systems scale.

title: Real-Time Hand Gesture Recognition using CNNs for Intuitive Vehicle Control
authors: Abinith N, Arunkarthick M, Dharun M, Abinaya N S
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The paper presents a novel hand gesture-based vehicle control system that aims to improve driving by making it possible to operate a variety of vehicle functions in an intuitive and effective manner. Addressing the limitations of traditional physical interfaces that can lead to driver distraction, the proposed system uses a two stage Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for robust hand gesture recognition. The system uses a camera to capture the real-time hand images. The acquired images are used to detect the palm at stage one and fingers landmark points are detected at stage two. The detected landmarks are used to identify the hand-gesture. The robot command is generated for the corresponding detected gesture. Five robot commands namely, forward, backward, left, right and stop are generated and transmitted to the robot. Experimental results demonstrate that the robot commands are generated with a high accuracy of 95.28%. It enables a user-tunable and potentially safer alternative to traditional interfaces for remote operated vehicles.

title: Personalized Educational Video Recommendations in Cyber Physical Systems for Children
authors: Lucky Harichandan, Sasmita Kumari Nayak, Satyabrata Lenka
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Educational video recommendations play a crucial role in engaging children and enhancing learning outcomes, particularly in adaptive, technology-enabled classrooms. However, their effectiveness is often hindered by the cold-start problem, where minimal user interaction history limits personalization. To address this challenge, we propose a cross-domain Neural Collaborative Filtering (NeuMF) model that transfers user preference knowledge from the MovieLens-100K dataset of child-appropriate films to a simulated Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS)-based educational video domain. By learning shared latent representations between both domains, the model provides accurate recommendations even in sparse-data scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate strong performance across multiple metrics—RMSE (0.5800), Precision@5 (0.6750), Recall@5 (0.7600), F1-score (0.7150), Accuracy (0.6650), and NDCG (0.9300)—highlighting the model’s potential for delivering adaptive, context-aware educational content to young learners in real time.

title: Clique Detection Using Symmetry-Restricted Quantum Circuits
authors: Maximilian Balthasar Mansky, Tobias Rohe, Jonas Stein, Dmytro Bondarenko, Linus Menzel, Claudia Linnhoff-Popien
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We show the application of permutation-invariant quantum circuits to the clique problem. The experiment asks to label a clique through identification of the nodes in a larger subgraph. The permutation-invariant quantum circuit outperforms a cyclic-invariant alternative as well as a standard quantum machine learning ansatz. We explain the behavior through the intrinsic symmetry of the problem, in the sense that the problem is symmetric under permutation of both the feature and the label.

title: A Framework for Data Classification Integrating Autoencoder and Granular Computing
authors: Ziqian He, Liyong Zhang, Wei Lu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Granular Computing (GrC) and Autoencoder have demonstrated strong potential in data classification. However, existing GrC frameworks often suffer from limited feature extraction capabilities and struggle to efficiently process high dimensional data. To address these limitations, this paper proposes an innovative unified computational framework that seamlessly integrates autoencoders with GrC methods, aiming to enhance high-dimensional data classification. The proposed framework comprises three core layers: an autoencoder layer, a hyperspherical layer, and a classifier layer. The autoencoder layer reduces the dimensionality of high-dimensional inputs by learning low-dimensional latent representations through an encoding-decoding mechanism, preserving essential nonlinear features. The hyperspherical layer introduces a hyperspherical information granulation mechanism, guided by a multi-granularity loss function to further organize and refine the data representation. Finally, the structured data is classified using a fully connected classifier. This end-to-end framework enables joint training of feature extraction, granulation, and classification components, significantly boosting classification performance and effectively addressing the challenges posed by high-dimensional data, while also ensuring strong adaptability across diverse data environments and maintaining robust generalization to unseen or complex classification tasks.

title: Building Student Understanding of Quantum Information Science and Engineering Through Projects on Applications to Medical Technologies
authors: Jessica L. Rosenberg, Nancy Holincheck
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Medical technologies, including quantum machine learning (QML) and quantum sensing, represent transformative tools for addressing some of the most pressing challenges in healthcare and drug discovery today. We discuss the ways that these topics engage the interest of high-school, undergraduate, and graduate students in understanding quantum information science and engineering. We describe how students built their understanding of these areas through a research project that allowed them to gain an understanding of the technology, its limitations, and the associated ethical considerations. We also consider the challenges of building this kind of work into the curriculum and of bringing students with interests in the biological and medical areas into quantum science and engineering.

title: Compiler Design for Hardware Specific Decomposition Optimizations, Tailored to Diamond NV Centers
authors: Folkert de Ronde, Stephan Wong, Sebastian Feld
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Advances in quantum algorithms as well as in control hardware designs are continuously being made. These quantum algorithms, expressed as quantum circuits, need to be translated to a set of instructions from a defined quantum instruction-set architecture (ISA), which are executed by the control hardware. These translations can be done by a compiler, targeting different qubit technologies. Specifically for diamond NV centers, no compiler exists to perform this translation. Therefore, in this paper we present a compiler designed for quantum computers utilizing diamond NV center specific instructions, such as direct carbon control and partial swaps, to reduce execution times and gate count. Additionally, our compiler adds on top of general compilers by allowing classical instructions to perform state tomography and measurement-based operations. The output of the compiler is tested in a diamond NV center specific simulator. Comparing a general compiler output with the diamond NV center specific output of our compiler while applying decoherence and depolarization noise showed reduced noise effects due to diamond specific decomposition. The compiler was also tested to perform state tomography and measurement-based operations, which showed to be functional. Our results show that we have successfully created a compiler with integrated classical and quantum instructions support, which can improve circuit execution fidelity by utilizing diamond specific optimizations.

title: Avoiding Convergence Stagnation in a Quantum Circuit Evolutionary Framework Through an Adaptive Cost Function
authors: Bruno O. Fernandez, Rodrigo Bloot, Marcelo A. Moret
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Binary optimization problems are emerging as potential candidates for useful applications of quantum computing. Among quantum algorithms, the quantum approximate optimization algorithm (QAOA) is currently considered the most promising method to obtain a quantum advantage for such problems. The QAOA method uses a classical counterpart to perform optimization in a hybrid approach. In this paper, we show that the recently introduced method called quantum circuit evolutionary (QCE) also has potential for applications in binary optimization problems. This methodology is classical optimizer-free, but, for some scenarios, may have convergence stagnation as a consequence of smooth circuit modifications at each generation. To avoid this drawback and accelerate the convergence capabilities of QCE, we introduce a framework using an adaptive cost function (ACF), which varies dynamically with the circuit evolution. This procedure accelerates the convergence of the method. Applying this new approach to instances of the set partitioning problem, we show that QCE-ACF achieves convergence performance identical to QAOA but with a shorter execution time. Finally, experiments in the presence of induced noise show that this framework is quite suitable for the noisy intermediate-scale quantum era.

title: Diagnosis Analysis of AXI Logic Build in Self-Test Failure on SoC Product
authors: Li Tian, Huan Wang, Shijun Zheng, Haijiao Bian, Jianli Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: This System-on-Chip (SoC) designs have become increasingly complex, integrating various function components or Intellectual Property (IP) within a chip through Advanced eXtensible Interface (AXI) [1]–[7]. The AXI bus provides an openstandard, on-chip interconnect specification that enables efficient IP reuse, flexibility, compatibility, high bandwidth, and low latency [8]. It defines a point-to-point protocol between two interfaces: a manager and a subordinate. In our SoC product, Logic Build in Self-Test (LBIST) was implemented on both the manager and subordinate sides respectively[9], with corresponding AXI LBIST pattern executed on Automated Test Equipment (ATE). Diagnosis analysis could localize failed FIFO cell in manager or subordinate when a failure was detected by LBIST pattern. This paper presents AXI bus LBIST hardware structure and test sequence, outlines the diagnosis flow for AXI LBIST failures, and demonstrates diagnosis accuracy through two real cases. Establishing AXI LBIST diagnosis capability in FA lab significantly improved Key Performance Indicators (KPIs): success rate increased from 50% to nearly 100% and analysis time was reduced from 90 days to 45 days. Built in SelfTest (BIST) structure and diagnosis enabled quick and easy root cause isolation for failed FIFO cells compared to traditional SoC functional analysis. However, now it must still be performed manually, and current AXI LBIST diagnosis was limited in narrowing down suspicions for controlling signals in AXI bus.

title: Transforming Lung Cancer Diagnosis and Therapy with AI and Deep Learning: Current Insights and Future Prospects
authors: Tejas Gawande, Sneha Bansod
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Lung cancer is considered to be one of the most lethal malignancies, and the protection and individual approach to the treatment are the key clinical issues. The recent development in the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Deep Learning (DL) has shown the potential of revolution in the diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), radiomics, and genomics are all techniques that allow automated extraction of features on imaging and molecular data, and allow earlier detection, precise risk stratification and personalized treatment plans. Uses of AI in medicine are in computer-aided pulmonary nodule detection, biomarkers discovery, treatment response prediction, and clinical decision support. In spite of these developments, issues of model interpretability, privacy of data, cross-population validation and ethical factors have limited clinical use on a large scale. This paper will survey existing AI-based approaches to detecting and treating lung cancer and its clinical implications, limitations in practice, and future opportunities. The combination of multimodal data, explainable AI, and federated learning can be used to build better precision in oncology in the future and make AI a dependable instrument in the improvement of lung cancer outcomes.

title: High Output SoC-Based Ion Shuttling Waveform Generator Using Cubic Splines
authors: Tiamike Dudley, Joshua Goldberg, Daniel Lobser, Daniel Stick, Jim Plusquellic
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Surface ion traps have lithographically defined electrode geometries that can be accurately simulated to calculate the voltages needed to store and transport ions, an enabling capability for trapped-ion quantum computing. While these voltage waveforms can be described explicitly as a voltage for each time step, they can be represented more compactly using cubic splines with coefficients calculated from the explicit target waveform. An FPGA would then calculate voltages on-the-fly based on these coefficients with a simple addition loop, sending these values as the input to digital-to-analog converters. Using cubic spline interpolation also increases the flexibility of the control system by simplifying the calibration offsets and time-scaling of waveforms without requiring additional explicit samples. In this paper we show that a single RF system-on-chip can be used to control 100 DAC channels, and propose a system-level architecture that uses scatter gather direct memory access and a highly compact custom data structure to store and generate voltage control waveforms in real-time.

title: Game-based Power Allocation in Wireless Networked Control Systems
authors: Zhikai Chen, Lei Feng, Zhixiang Yang, Xuesong Qiu, Sheng Hong
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: In the realm of the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT), ultra reliable and low latency communication (URLLC) enforces strict performance demands on wireless networked control systems (WNCS). This is aimed at ensuring that these systems can sustain consistent performance under all conditions. Nevertheless, communication environments are dynamic and unpredictable, posing difficulties in guaranteeing the quality of service (QoS) necessary for URLLC during control operations. This paper proposes a non - cooperative game model, considering the interactions between users and the base station. We design a distributed power allocation algorithm aimed at maximizing the overall utility of both cellular communications and device - todevice (D2D) communications. The simulation results effectively verify the proposed scheme, highlighting its superiority in both communication and control performance.

title: Enhancing Quantum Software Development Process with Experiment Tracking
authors: Mahee Gamage, Otso Kinanen, Jake Muff, Vlad Stirbu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: As quantum computing advances from theoretical promise to experimental reality, the need for rigorous experiment tracking becomes critical. Drawing inspiration from best practices in machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI), we argue that reproducibility, scalability, and collaboration in quantum research can benefit significantly from structured tracking workflows. This paper explores the application of MLflow in quantum research, illustrating how it enables better development practices, experiment reproducibility, decision making, and cross-domain integration in an increasingly hybrid classical-quantum landscape.

title: AdaptCV: Semantic-Aware Resume Optimizer for Improved ATS Compatibility
authors: Mythili R, Sharvesh R, Kavin R, Rahul M S, Sagana Shree M S
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: In the current competitive job landscape, customizing tailoring resumes to particular job descriptions is essential for obtaining conversations. Nonetheless, numerous job hunters find it challenging to enhance their CVs for Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) and aligning them with specific role demands. AdaptCV is an AI-driven flexible resume creator that connects this divide by utilizing the finest open-source models and Generative AI technologies. The suggested platform allows users to generate customized, ATS-compatible resumes designed for specific job descriptions. AdaptCV examines job listings to identify essential keywords, abilities, and credentials, which are effortlessly embedded within the user’s CV. The proposed AdaptCV system offers immediate insights recommendations for enhancing content, layout, and keyword effectiveness, making certain that the final resume result meets industry standards. Moreover, AdaptCV adjusts to different professional requirements by providing adjustable resume templates and adaptable tone modifications, guaranteeing the end result aligns with the audience sector and viewers. The uniqueness of the suggested solution is found in its emphasis on ATS optimization, guaranteeing resumes succeed in automated evaluation procedures, while preserving a organic and through the automation of keyword embedding and formatting, AdaptCV helps users save considerable time and energy in the process of applying for a job. AdaptCV enables individuals seeking employment by boosting their opportunities of securing interviews via customized, refined, and analytics-based resume enhancement. AdaptCV displays demonstrated outcomes of 91% precision when assessed against the alternatives conventional LLM frameworks. Due to its flexibility and focus on employment potential, the tool emerges as a crucial asset in the techno job market.

title: Analysis of the Development Model of Peking University College of Engineering: A Study Based on Diffusible Innovation Experience
authors: Yongmei Li, Huiling Duan
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: The reestablishment of Peking University College of Engineering (PKU COE) in 2005 marked a strategic initiative to advance interdisciplinary research and industrialize fundamental scientific achievements by integrating the university's strengths in liberal arts, sciences, and medicine. A milestone was reached in December 2024 with the formal establishment of the PKU Faculty of Engineering, which optimized disciplinary structures, enhanced talent cultivation systems, and catalyzed transformative advancements in engineering science. This study systematically examines the PKU COE's institutional philosophy, reform strategies, and key achievements over the past two decades, emphasizing its role in fostering innovation-driven engineering education. By employing a mixed-methods approach that combines historical analysis and case studies, the research highlights how the PKU COE addresses challenges and leverages opportunities under the “New Engineering Education” framework, particularly amid the rise of new quality productive forces. Findings reveal that PKU's model-characterized by resource integration, interdisciplinary collaboration, and industry-academia synergy-offers a replicable paradigm for global engineering education. The study concludes with actionable insights for adapting this model to diverse institutional contexts while balancing disciplinary specialization and emerging technological demands.

title: Post-Exploitation Unveiled: Analyzing RAT Behaviors in a Realistically Simulated Enterprise Network
authors: Shohei Hiruta, Yuki Umemura, Masaki Kubo, Nobuyuki Kanaya, Takahiro Kasama
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Dependable and Secure Computing (DSC)
abstract: A Remote Access Trojan is widely used a type of malware that enables an attacker to control compromised systems remotely. While many studies focus on RAT infection methods and inherent capabilities, post-exploitation activities that occur after the initial infection and command and control are seldom discussed due to difficulties of observation. This paper presents a dedicated analysis environment designed for the long-term observation of RAT post-exploitations within a simulated multi-host enterprise network. Our environment imposes no time constraints on RAT execution and supports on-demand collection of diverse artifacts, enabling detailed monitoring from initial C2 connection to termination of activity. We conducted experiments using 41 samples from 7 RAT families collected over six-months and analyzed the observed post-exploitations in terms of tactics, techniques, and corresponding artifacts, as well as C2 communications. The contributions of this paper include the design of a long-term analysis environment and empirical insights into contemporary RAT post-exploitations.

title: Optimizing Compilation for Distributed Quantum Computing via Clustering and Annealing
authors: Ruilin Zhou, Jinglei Cheng, Yuhang Gan, Junyu Liu, Chen Qian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Efficiently mapping quantum programs onto Distributed quantum computing (DQC) are challenging, particularly when considering the heterogeneous quantum processing units (QPUs) with different structures. In this paper, we present a comprehensive compilation framework that addresses these challenges with three key insights: exploiting structural patterns within quantum circuits, using clustering for initial qubit placement, and adjusting qubit mapping with annealing algorithms. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our methods and the capability to handle complex heterogeneous distributed quantum systems. Our evaluation shows that our method reduces the objective value at most 88.40% compared to the baseline.

title: A Quantum Annealing Approach to $k$-NN
authors: Sutapa Samanta, Dagen Wang, Todd M.W. Hodges, Andras Ferenczi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO) formulation for solving the classical <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex>-Nearest Neighbors (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex>-NN) problem and demonstrate its efficacy. We use a quantum annealer for solving the QUBO. We tested the model on a dataset containing 1,000 text documents. Our model was able to predict the “class” of a test document accurately. Our findings highlight the promise of QUBO-based methods for scalable, hybrid quantum-classical machine learning.

title: LogWF: Anomaly Detection for Distributed Systems Based on Log Workflow Mining
authors: Teng Li, Shengkai Zhang, Yebo Feng, Jiahua Xu, Yaxuan Xie, Wei Qiao, Jianfeng Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Modern distributed systems generate fragmented, heterogeneous logs that challenge traditional anomaly detection methods relying solely on event counts or sequential patterns. We propose LogWF, a novel workflow graph-based approach that addresses these limitations by explicitly modeling spatiotemporal relationships in distributed system execution. Our method first extracts structured event templates and constructs a three-dimensional tensor (time × host × template) through FastText embeddings and Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) weighting, followed by tensor decomposition for dimensionality reduction. By mining temporal invariants via Linear Temporal Logic and model checking with McScM, we build node-specific workflow graphs that capture event transition probabilities. These subgraphs are unified through adjacency matrix fusion and breadth-first traversal to form a comprehensive system-wide workflow graph. A Graph Convolutional Neural Network with self-attention pooling then performs wholegraph anomaly detection, preserving structural patterns while emphasizing critical nodes. The framework shows exceptional robustness against log noise (maintaining $\gt0.988 \mathrm{~F} 1$ at $30 \%$ duplication/loss) and scalability (0.935 F1 with 500-node graphs), significantly reducing false positives through explicit modeling of distributed system execution paths. This work advances log analysis by transforming fragmented logs into interpretable workflow graphs that simultaneously encode temporal, spatial, and semantic relationships for precise diagnosis of anomalies.

title: Pharma Supply Chain Management
authors: Ishank Gangwar, Srichandan Sobhanayak, Anita Sahoo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Annotation. This study explores the possibilities of reconfiguration. Pharmaceutical supply chain (PSC) through improvement Adopting manufacturing technologies and patientcentric delivery models. Critically reviewing academic aspects and using industry literature, this study identifies and categorizes different types. PSC models provide systems-based ideas. Oriented approach to operations research. The results highlight several Limitations of existing PSC models. Current definitions focus primarily on production and patient consumption and Many mathematical models lack comprehensive concepts of structure, behavior, and health. Limited by lack of details on supply chain boundary conditions, existing operations, and new production technologies. This study employs a systematic review of academic and industry literature, categorizing Pharmaceutical Supply Chain (PSC) models based on structure, behavior, and operational constraints. A structured framework is developed to analyze PSC reconfiguration, incorporating mathematical modeling and economic evaluation techniques. Key findings reveal limitations in current models, particularly in capturing end-to-end supply chain complexities and integrating emerging manufacturing technologies. Our results highlight the need for holistic models that consider supply chain costs, total cost of ownership, and patient-centric delivery innovations. The proposed framework provides practical insights for optimizing PSC operations and enhancing resilience.

title: Real-Time Air Handwriting Recognition Using Dynamic Gesture Segmentation and Deep Learning: A Novel Framework for Human-Computer Interaction
authors: Seyed Mojtaba Mirzadeh, Pirooz Shamsinejad, Mohammad Zare, Reza Javidan
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: Air handwriting recognition has gained significant attention due to its potential in enabling natural and contactless human-computer interaction. However, challenges such as real-time processing, multi-character composition, and segmentation of continuous gestures remain unresolved. This paper introduces a novel framework for real-time air handwriting recognition, leveraging dynamic hand gesture segmentation and a lightweight Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture. Utilizing the MediaPipe framework for hand tracking and the EMNIST dataset for training, our system captures finger trajectories, processes them into normalized 2D arrays, and predicts characters with high accuracy. A unique feature of our approach is the use of hand-closing gestures (e.g., forming a fist) as a dynamic segmentation mechanism, enabling seamless word formation without the need for artificial constraints like virtual boxes. Empirical results demonstrate 95% training accuracy and 91% test accuracy on the EMNIST dataset, with a real-time latency of 0.72 seconds. Furthermore, our system dynamically caches recognized characters, allowing users to compose words naturally until a termination gesture or button press is detected. Despite these advancements, challenges such as skewed inputs from various writing tools highlight the need for adaptive preprocessing techniques. This work bridges the gap between single-character recognition and practical word-level applications, offering valuable insights for future HCI systems. The proposed framework not only enhances the accuracy and usability of air handwriting recognition but also provides a robust foundation for real-world deployment in diverse environments.

title: Research on Mobile Robot Path Planning Using an Improved ABC Integrating Multiple Search Strategies
authors: Jiamin Liao, Junjie Du
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: This paper addresses the problems of premature convergence, insufficient diversity, and limited path quality in mobile robot path planning within complex environments. It proposes an Improved Artificial Bee Colony algorithm with MultiStrategy Search and Hierarchical Management (MTABC). The MTABC algorithm integrates mechanisms such as multi-strategy hierarchical search, adaptive neighborhood crossover, and quality-based hierarchical food-source management, significantly enhancing both global and local optimization capabilities, increasing solution diversity, and improving path smoothness. On a MATLAB simulation platform, comparative experiments with the traditional ABC algorithm, the HIABC algorithm, and the IACO-ABC algorithm demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms existing mainstream approaches in path length, convergence speed, and global optimality. Experimental results validate the MTABC algorithm's effectiveness and practicality in boosting path planning efficiency and solution quality, offering new ideas and technical references for mobile robot path planning.

title: Byzantine-Resilient Federated Learning: Evaluating MPC Approaches
authors: Yasin Abdullah, Mohammed B. Alshawki, Peter Ligeti, Wissem Soussi, Burkhard Stiller
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a paradigm shift for collaborative machine learning to preserve data privacy. However, without considering the security measures through relevant cryptographic mechanisms, the collaborative process is vulnerable to various attacks. This paper evaluates the strength and scalability of Semi2k protocol for secure Multi Party Computation (MPC) under two major attacks, namely label-flipping and min-max attacks. We established a controlled simulations involving various numbers of malicious clients and MPC nodes. Our result showed that Semi2k offers limited protection against min-max attacks, showing no advantage over non-MPC setups in short training runs. However, it significantly improves accuracy under label-flipping attacks at 500 iterations, though overall accuracy declines with more malicious clients. Longer training improves resilience to label-flipping but increases communication overhead. Communication costs grow linearly with participants, highlighting a trade-off between scalability and efficiency.

title: The Future of Smart Grids: Revolutionizing Energy Distribution with Advanced IoT, and Renewable Integration
authors: S. Avinash, J.C. Vinitha, S. Sree Dharinya, B Anni Princy, V.R. Kavitha, V. Samuthira Pandi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Smart grids, which integrate modern Internet of Things (IoT) technology and renewable energy sources to boost efficiency, sustainability, and dependability, are poised to bring about a dramatic shift in the future of energy distribution. Intelligent grids are expected to bring about this shift. Focusing on the role of the Internet of Things (IoT) in enabling real-time monitoring and control, as well as the incorporation of renewable energy to support a low-carbon future, this research investigates the potential for smart grids to change the energy sector. This study gives insights into how smart grids can be efficiently deployed to satisfy the growing energy needs of society by studying the technological breakthroughs, obstacles, and benefits of smart grids. Specifically, the study’s focus is on smart grids. The research highlights the essential role that smart grids play in aiding the shift towards a more sustainable and resilient energy infrastructure by conducting an in-depth analysis of case studies, pilot projects, and industry trends all around the world. Providing recommendations for policymakers, industry stakeholders, and utilities to exploit the full potential of smart grids in determining the future of energy distribution, the findings contribute to the continuing discourse on the strategic development and implementation of smart grid technologies. Both of these topics are currently being discussed.

title: Failure Analysis of High-Voltage SiC MOSFETs with Manufacturing Defects Related to Fabrication Processes
authors: Jian Zhou, Ronghao Li, Chao Li, Yuebo Liu, Shaohua Yang, Canxiong Lai, Xiaowei Xu, Haoran Wang, Xuanlong Chen, Zongbei Dai, Liang Fang
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: Silicon carbide (SiC) metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistors (MOSFETs) leverage the superior intrinsic properties of SiC as a wide bandgap semiconductor, making them highly competitive for high-voltage and high-temperature applications compared to Si-based MOSFETs and IGBTs. The development of SiC MOSFETs with enhanced voltage resistance has been a key focus for manufacturers. However, manufacturing defects remain significant challenges to achieving robust and reliable commercial products. This study presents a failure analysis of two high-voltage SiC MOSFETs, designated as Failed SiC MOSFETs #1 and #2, both in the R&D stage and exhibiting manufacturing defects related to fabrication processes. Systematic failure analysis revealed that contamination during manufacturing and misoperation during the bonding process likely contributed to the leakage current observed between the Gate-Source in both Failed SiC MOSFETs #1 and #2.

title: RT-V2V: Real-Time Vehicle-to-Vehicle Communication for Traffic Alert Broadcasting Using GPCR
authors: Dasika.M. Adithya, V. Jishnu Samrat, S. Adnan, S Thangam
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Most people are not aware that intelligent transportation systems are emerging in the current world to change the connection of cars and their reaction to flowing and standing traffic. This work profiles VANETs, which is the modern technology in automotive engineering, enabling vehicles to communicate in real-time with the goal of improving road safety and flow of traffic. In this project, the simulation of dynamic traffic involving communication between vehicles is done in the OMNeT++ simulation environment implemented with humaninspired Veins module through the Vehicle-toVehicle (V2V) data transfer in vehicular networks by using traffic EA messages including messages for traffic alerts, accident warnings, and road status etc. The simulation uses SUMO for traffic which can encode vehicles to change their paths and behavior according to data. Some of the important aspects of the VANET project consist of given the evaluation of its communicating protocols, estimating the message dissemination methods, and determining the efficiency of the network under varying traffic condition. This project shows how VANETs can successfully overcome the existing traffic problems and prevent accidents through the analysis of how the cars interact and exchange information. The outcomes are designed in the hope of assisting in the provision of improved safety and efficiency enhancements for transport and infrastructure to support the platform for smart cities and the integration of autonomous vehicle systems.

title: Integrating Reconfigurable Accelerators with Quantum Computing
authors: FNU Pratibha, Parth Ganeriwala, Naveed Mahmud
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: In hybrid quantum-classical (HQC) computing, the coherent execution of algorithms on quantum and classical resources is a critical challenge. Most HQC algorithms involve iterative exchanges of data between quantum and classical processors, causing system bottlenecks and leading to high latency in applications. In this paper, we propose a novel framework that unifies quantum and reconfigurable resources for HQC algorithms, to mitigate system bottlenecks and latency. The proposed framework integrates Field-Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) with quantum processing units (QPUs) for deploying HQC algorithms. Classical subroutines of the algorithms are accelerated on FPGA fabric using a high-throughput processing pipeline, while quantum subroutines are executed on QPUs. High-level software is used to seamlessly facilitate workload distribution and data exchange between classical and quantum processors. To evaluate the proposed framework, an HQC algorithm, namely variational quantum classification and MNIST dataset are used as a test case. The results demonstrate that the FPGA pipeline achieves up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \times$</tex> improvement in runtime compared to the baseline of a state-of-the-art quantum software framework running on a server-grade CPU.

title: Improvement and Practice of the Test Method for Chip Pulling Test of Flip Chips
authors: Jinling Lan, Xing Jin, Bin Wang, Xiaoqiang Wang, Rui Tang, Haoxi Fu
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: Flip chip technology, as an important innovation in the field of semiconductor packaging, has received extensive attention and application in recent years. Currently, flip chip pull-off test is one of the methods for evaluating the reliability of flip chip technology. However, during the testing process, there is a phenomenon of substrate bending, which leads to a decrease in the reliability of the test. To address this issue, this paper explores an innovative method to effectively improve the substrate bending phenomenon. By comparing the test results of two test approaches before and after improvement using samples of the same batch and model, and by using the COMSOL model constructed, the changes in substrate stress during the testing process of the two test approaches before and after improvement can be determined. Due to the consistency between the simulation results and the test results, the accuracy and reliability of the improved approach are verified. Therefore, this approach is a more advantageous flip chip pull-off test approach.
