title: Transfer Learning-Enabled System for Drone Medicine Delivery Based on Spatio-Temporal Remote Sensing Data in Edge Cloud Networks
authors: Abdullah Lakhan, Tor-Morten Grønli, Ahmet Soylu, Ghulam Muhammad, Qurat-ul-ain Mastoi, Huaming Wu
abstract: These days, satellite remote sensing data is employed for different drone applications. The main goal is to provide imaginary information about electromagnetic locations and patterns of geolocations insight into Earth. The Internet of Drone Things (IoDT) exploits remote sensing data to deliver medicine from source to destination. However, many existing medicine delivery systems based on drones need longer execution times and more efficiency in delivering medicine to the right destinations. This paper presents transfer learning, which empowers a spatiotemporal remote sensing data training system for medicine delivery in edge cloud networks based on IoDT applications. The objective is to deliver the medicine to the original destination with the highest score and process all drone tasks based on their given deadlines. We present the offloading spatiotemporal training and scheduling (OSPTS) algorithm methodology that completes the data collection process and medicine delivery in different locations. Therefore, we solve the problem as a combinatorial problem and find the optimal solution based on searching and convolutional neural networks (CNN). Transfer learning and convolutional neural networks are sub-schemes of the OSPTS that train the remote sensing data on edge nodes and point clouds for optimal medicine delivery. Simulation results show that the OSPTS obtained the highest score for medicine delivery in the correct position with less processing time than existing systems.

title: Fractional Domain Waveform Design for Covert Downlink Communication with Signal Overlay in Integrated Satellite-Terrestrial Networks
authors: Zhaoqi Wang, Peiyuan Zhou, Xiqing Liu, Yafei Zhao, Mugen Peng, Yuanwei Liu
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Integrated satellite-terrestrial networks (ISTNs) provide crucial support for ubiquitous connectivity, whereas the inherent openness poses significant security threats. Covert communication that achieves intrinsic protection by concealing transmission behavior has become an ideal solution. This work studies a downlink covert satellite communication scenario under signal overlay. Existing research mostly carries out optimizations in the power domain. However, since waveforms serve as the physical carriers of information, their design critically impacts the covert communication performance via different adjustability to channel state information (CSI). Specifically, blindly enhancing demodulation reliability does not necessarily lead to better covert capacity and may even be counterproductive. OFDM is vulnerable to carrier frequency offset, while OTFS lacks the flexibility to accommodate CSI, resulting in difficulties applying existing candidate waveforms. In light of this, we propose a nimble waveform named orthogonal fractional dual index multiplexing (OFDIM) tolerant of fractional delay and Doppler. It enables common modulation schemes through integer indices and creates a fractional domain resilient to CSI. The closed-forms of the maximum covert transmit power, reliability, and spectral efficiency are derived. Fractional indices are optimized to improve the performance based on CSI. Simulations validate the theoretical analysis and demonstrate the benefits of the fractional domain in covert communication. Additionally, OFDIM incorporates a complementary security mechanism where the indices can act as dynamic ciphers and guarantee certain security even if the communication behavior is exposed.

title: Kurtosis-Based Spectral Index Guided Adaptive Speed Estimation for Bearing Fault Diagnosis Under Nonstationary Conditions
authors: Linhao Peng, Fang Liu, Yongjian Sun, Siliang Lu, Yongbin Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Equal angular interval sampling (EAISP) is currently one of the primary approaches used for bearing fault diagnosis under variable-speed conditions. Accurate acquisition of rotational speed is a prerequisite for this method. Hardware-based speed measurement and algorithm-based speed estimation are the two most commonly employed approaches. The former requires high-precision sensors such as encoders, which are costly and sensitive to environmental factors. The latter relies on a specific algorithm model and requires high data quality, resulting in limited generality and scalability. This study explores a hybrid approach that combines hardware-based measurement with algorithmic speed estimation. In this method, a single Hall sensor with low accuracy but low cost and strong environmental adaptability is used to initially perform a rough measurement of rotational speed. Then, a method named kurtosis-based spectral index guided Polynomial Approximation (KSIGPA) is proposed to achieve an accurate estimation of the rotational speed. Simulation and experiment verify that this strategy is between the existing hardware-based speed measurement and algorithm-based speed estimation, and it has a good application prospect in the scenarios where only rough speed can be obtained and it is impossible or inconvenient to install high-precision sensors.

title: Iterative Neural Rollback Chase-Pyndiah Decoding
authors: Dmitry Artemasov, Oleg Nesterenkov, Kirill Andreev, Pavel Rybin, Alexey Frolov
abstract: The paper deals with iterative decoding of turbo product codes (TPC). We propose a transformer neural network (NN)-assisted rollback scheme, in which the NN identifies and suppresses extrinsic updates that are likely to introduce decoding errors. Experiments with turbo product code based on (256, 239) extended BCH codes demonstrate that the proposed method improves the bit error rate of Chase-Pyndiah (CP) decoding with p = 6 by approximately 0.145 dB, significantly outperforming conventional CP decoding with p = 7, without modifying the CP decoding pipeline, thereby simplifying integration into existing systems.

title: Hybrid Demodulation Scheme-Enabled Beamforming Design for Integrated Sensing and Communication Systems
authors: Jiale Wang, Ruoyan Ma, Yifan Guo, Guolei Zhu, Qi Wang, Jie Lian, Yingmin Wang
abstract: Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) is a promising technique for establishing an effective Internet of Things (IoT) network, utilizing the same hardware and resource block for both sensing and communication functions. In this study, we propose a hybrid demodulation scheme-enabled ISAC beamforming design to enhance sensing capabilities. Our study delves into the combined effects of diverse users’ demodulation schemes and sensing power constraints on the design of transmit beamforming for multi-user communication and multi-target sensing. We formulate three optimization problems for beamforming design which tackle user-target discrimination, user-target overlap, and a general hybrid scenario. In particular, in the hybrid scenario, we incorporate the type of communication receivers as an optimized variable and introduce additional sensing power constraints to enhance sensing performance in terms of beampattern and time waveform without compromising communication performance. To effectively tackle these optimization challenges, we introduce a hierarchical convex relaxation framework considering user-target pairing. Simulation results illustrate that the proposed beamforming approach improves sensing performance while maintaining communication performance, surpassing traditional designs under different user-target directional distributions.

title: SEV-Field: ACrop Field Extraction Framework for High-Resolution Imagery via Semantic Segmentation and Boundary Connection
authors: Lingyuan Zhao, Qun Wang, Kuang Zhou, Zifei Luo, Bo Yang, Yan Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Accurate crop field boundary extraction from high resolution remote sensing imagery is crucial for agricultural management. However, fragmented boundaries and limited model transferability, particularly in areas with complex terrain and smallholder farming, remain major challenges. This study introduces SEV-Field, a framework combining semantic segmentation, edge detection, and boundary post-processing to address these issues. The framework uses a Swin Transformer model for semantic segmentation to delineate field extents and the EDTER model for edge detection. A Vector Boundary Connection and Extent Filtering (VBC-EF) method is then applied to reconnect fragmented boundaries and enhance connectivity. Evaluated on high-resolution Jilin-1 satellite imagery in Yibin, China, SEV-Field achieved a mean intersection over union (mIoU) of 0.92 for field extent and 0.83 for boundary. Additionally, the framework demonstrated a 10% improvement in boundary connectivity, measured by average path length similarity (APLS), after post-processing. Cross-regional validation across multiple Chinese provinces and satellite sources (Jilin-1, Sentinel-2) confirmed the framework ' s strong transferability, achieving an mIoU of 0.90 in Meishan (Sichuan) and 0.86 in Yulin (Shaanxi) without retraining. SEV-Field effectively addresses boundary discontinuity and generalizes across diverse geographical and imaging conditions, offering a scalable solution for precision agriculture.

title: A New Hyperchaotic Map Based on Discrete Second-Order Memristor: Dynamics Analysis, Encryption Application, and DSP Implementation
authors: Xingce Liu, Dongsheng Yang, Yinghua Yang, Ping Yuan, Yating Lin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs
abstract: At present, little research has been done on discrete second-order memristors, while research has focused on discrete first-order memristors. To investigate the memory characteristics of discrete second-order memristors and their influence on chaotic maps, a new discrete second-order memristor is proposed, and its memory characteristics are investigated. Subsequently, a novel four-dimensional hyperchaotic mapping(4D-HM) is obtained by coupling it with the traditional chaotic mapping. Then, the chaotic characteristics of hyperchaotic map is investigated by the Bifurcation diagram, Lyapunov exponents (LEs) and the phase diagram of the 4D-HM. It is worth mentioning that the phenomenon of coexistence of attractors has been discovered in the 4D-HM. This feature makes the 4D-HM more suitable for many chaotic based engineering applications. Therefore, the 4D-HM is applied to the field of image encryption. To demonstrate the security and reliability of the encryption scheme, the simulation results of the scheme are analyzed. Finally, the process of theoretical analysis of the 4D-HM is demonstrated by DSP implementation. Because of its complex dynamical characteristics, the 4D-HM has great potential application value.

title: LightTR+: A Lightweight Incremental Framework for Federated Trajectory Recovery
authors: Hao Miao, Ziqiao Liu, Yan Zhao, Chenxi Liu, Chenjuan Guo, Bin Yang, Kai Zheng, Huan Li, Christian S. Jensen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering
abstract: With the proliferation of GPS-equipped edge devices, huge trajectory data are generated and accumulated in various domains, driving numerous urban applications. However, due to the limited data acquisition capabilities of edge devices, many trajectories are often recorded at low sampling rates, reducing the effectiveness of these applications. To address this issue, we aim to recover high-sample-rate trajectories from low-sample-rate ones enhancing the usability of trajectory data. Recent approaches to trajectory recovery often assume centralized data storage, which can lead to catastrophic forgetting, where previously learned knowledge is entirely forgotten when new data arrives. This not only poses privacy risks but also degrades performance in decentralized settings where data streams into the system incrementally. To enable decentralized training and streaming trajectory recovery, we propose a <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Light</u>weight incremental framework for federated <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">T</u>rajectory <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">R</u>ecovery, called LightTR+, which is based on a client-server architecture. Given the limited processing capabilities of edge devices, LightTR+ includes a lightweight local trajectory embedding module that enhances computational efficiency without compromising feature extraction capabilities. To mitigate catastrophic forgetting, we propose an intra-domain knowledge distillation module. Additionally, LightTR+ features a meta-knowledge enhanced local-global training scheme, which reduces communication costs between the server and clients, further improving efficiency. Extensive experiments offer insight into the effectiveness and efficiency of LightTR+.

title: Fast Weighted Transforms for Linear Convolution
authors: Yile Xing, Donglong Chen, Hong Yan, Ray C.C. Cheung
abstract: Convolution is fundamental in digital signal processing across many applications. Existing works enable N-point linear convolution via N-point right-angle circular convolution (RCC) based on weighted transforms, effectively removing the need for zero padding. However, these methods are constrained by their choice of weights, which impacts the complexity of weight-related multiplications at the start of the transform and the end of the inverse transform. This limitation leads to either reduced accuracy or increased complexity in weighted Fourier transform (WFT)-based convolution, as well as restricted transform lengths in weighted Fermat number transform (WFNT)-based convolution. In this work, we address these challenges by merging the multiplications by weights into the butterfly structures with arbitrary power-of-2 radix for both WFT and WFNT. We also propose an extraction method to accommodate negative and complex numbers. Our work ensures that weights do not increase complexity, thereby improving accuracy and reducing complexity in WFT-based convolution, while allowing for a broader range of transform lengths in WFNT-based convolution.

title: Modelling the Differential Dermal Potential using Finite Difference model based Kalman Filter
authors: Somali Nandy, Ratna Ghosh, Bhaswati Goswami
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Differential Dermal Potential (DDP) signals are being used recently with significant success for monitoring and evaluating various human conditions like restfulness, hypertension, posture change and also cognitive load. Hence, innovative models of this signal can be used with advantage in further studies. It is known that Kalman Filter (KF) models have been successfully used to represent various time-series signals including biosignals like speech, ECG and EEG signals. This paper proposes a new variant of the KF model termed as the finite difference based KF (KF-FD) model. Its novelty lies primarily in the formulation of the underlying finite difference based state space (FD-SS) model derived from the stochastic polynomial form of the time-series signals obtained in the pre-established stochastic autocorrelation function-zero crossing lag (ACF-ZCL) model. In this paper, the proposed KF-FD model of DDP signals is compared with the conventional Linear Prediction Coefficients (LPC) based KF model (KF-LPC) of these signals. Restfulness is a crucial yet often overlooked component of overall well-being, influencing cognitive function, emotional stability, and physical health. This study further explores the assessment of restfulness of human subjects based on the characteristics of the estimated parameters from both KF models of the DDP signals. The results demonstrate that while the parameters of the KF-LPC model can identify the initial shift to restfulness of a subject, the parameters of the proposed KF-FD model can reliably and quantifiably differentiate the stages of rest.

title: Human-Centric Smart Energy Optimization and Automation System
authors: Chaya P, Amitha K N, Ananya Bindu N, Chintana G, Hamsa Suresh
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The rapid growth in energy consumption within modern infrastructure underscores the need for intelligent, automated systems capable of adapting to environmental and occupancy variations in real time. This paper presents a human-centric smart energy optimization and automation framework that integrates real-time human detection using a pre-trained machine learning model, light intensity measurement through LDR (Light Dependent Resistor) sensors, temperature monitoring, and fire hazard detection with automated mitigation. The proposed system autonomously regulates electrical devices such as lighting, fans, and water pumps, thereby minimizing human intervention. Experimental evaluation demonstrates its ability to achieve up to 30% reduction in unnecessary energy usage compared to conventional control methods, while ensuring occupant safety and comfort. The modular design further enables scalability for diverse smart building applications, supporting sustainable and efficient energy management.

title: On Selecting Paths for End-to-End Entanglement Creation in Quantum Networks
authors: Anoosha Fayyaz, Prashant Krishnamurthy, Kaushik P. Seshadreesan, David Tipper, Amy Babay
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Optimal routing is a fundamental challenge in quantum networking, with several approaches proposed to identify the most efficient path for end-to-end (e2e) entanglement generation between pairs of nodes. In this paper, we show that prior entanglements - entanglements generated in a previous network cycle but not yet utilized - are an important consideration in optimal path selection due to the dynamic nature of quantum networks. Specifically, we investigate whether a longer path with pre-existing entanglements can outperform a shorter path that starts from scratch. We account for key quantum constraints, including noisy entanglement generation and swapping, fidelity decay, probabilistic operations, and link discarding upon swap failure. Simulations reveal that longer paths with prior entanglements can establish e2e entanglement faster than shorter paths under certain conditions. We further introduce the notion of entanglement diversity, where multiple paths can be used to improve performance - either by selecting the first successful path to minimize time or using both paths to enhance fidelity through distillation. These findings highlight the importance of incorporating prior entanglements into path selection strategies for optimizing quantum communication networks.

title: An Innovative Liver Tumor Diagnosis Framework with Generative AI and Trans-Cascaded Unet++
authors: Sholingapuram Dharaneswar, B. P. Santosh Kumar
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The liver tumour is one of the prelevant cancers in the world. Computed Tomography (CT) images are essential for the automatic detection of liver tumors. It serves as a useful substitute for time-consuming manual procedures and guarantees the presentation of precise and trustworthy clinical evaluation. However, a major obstacle in segmenting liver tumours is their intrinsic disparity, which is further complicated by the hazy boundaries in imaging features. The medical diagnosis of liver cancer depends on the precise segmentation of liver tumours, which could help doctors in choosing the most appropriate action while assessing the success of the operation. However, the high sensitivity and low precision of deep learning make diagnosis more difficult because of higher false-positive rates. The inability of detection algorithms to properly comprehend the anatomy from a broader viewpoint leads to the incorrect identification of lesions, resulting in false positives. Therefore, it is necessary to address the variety of issues like high-intensity levels raised by the standard liver tumour diagnosis paradigm. Hence, an efficient deep learning–based liver tumor diagnosis framework is implemented in this work. Firstly, necessary images required for the observation are collected from the standard database. subsequently, Transformer-Cascaded Unet++ (T-CasUNet++) is used for performing segmentation in the collected images. This helps in extracting essential long-range dependencies in the images, enabling it to accomplish superior segmentation accuracy, especially for slight structures and unreliable object shapes in clinical images. Once, the images are segmented, they it is subjected to the lung tumour diagnosis phase. In this phase, Generative Adversarial Network with Attention Mechanism (GAN-AM) is used to execute liver tumour diagnosis by focusing on significant tumor characteristics like fine structures and texture details, which helps in better diagnosis. Finally, a liver tumour diagnosis outcome is obtained from GAN-AM. Later, multiple validations is implemented in the suggested liver tumor diagnosis model over classical methods to validate its effectualness in different validation conditions. And the outcomes disclose that the designed model gained an accuracy of 96 %, leading to rapid and improved diagnosis of liver tumours.

title: ViT-ResNet Assessment of Breast Density from MRI
authors: Meysam Khalaj, Arvin Arian, Ala Torabi, Nasrin Ahmadinejad, Masoumeh Gity, Seyedeh Nooshin Miratashi Yazdi, Mohammad Pooya Afshari, Melika Sadeghi Tabrizi, Hamid Soltanian-Zadeh
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: Breast density is a significant risk factor for breast cancer, with higher fibroglandular tissue (FGT) ratios correlating to increased cancer risk. Traditional mammography has limited sensitivity in dense breasts, prompting the use of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) as a supplemental tool due to its higher sensitivity and three-dimensional (3D) imaging capabilities. While 3D deep learning models are often employed for breast density assessment, they are computationally expensive, requiring specialized and costly hardware. To address these challenges, this study proposes a lightweight two-dimensional (2D) hybrid deep learning model, ViT-ResNet, for efficient breast density classification using MRI, with improved performance. The proposed model combines the strengths of convolutional neural networks (CNNs), which excel at extracting local features, with vision transformers (ViTs), which capture global contextual information, achieving a balance of computational efficiency and robust performance. The model was trained and validated on a dataset of 654 MRI scans, using the 40th, 50th, and 60th percentile slices to represent diagnostically relevant regions. It achieved an average accuracy of $81.7 \%$ across ten iterations, with precision, recall, F1 score, and Cohen’s kappa of $86.1 \%, 78.3 \%, 80.8 \%$, and 0.738, respectively. In the iteration with the highest accuracy, the model achieved an accuracy of $84.8 \%$, a precision of $89.2 \%$, a recall of $81.5 \%$, an $F 1$ score of $84.1 \%$, and a Cohen’s kappa of 0.784. Compared to prior studies utilizing 3D approaches that required multiple GPUs, this work demonstrates improved performance and computational efficiency, achieving effective results with a single GPU and showcasing the potential of a 2D strategy for breast density classification using MRI.

title: Design and Implementation of a Secure Blockchain-based E-Voting Architecture with Zero-Knowledge Proofs and Smart Contracts
authors: N Shanmuga Priya, Gopinath M, Gunaseelan. V, Guruganesh K
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: This paper presents a new decentralized e-voting architecture designed to create tamper-proof, transparent, and secure election systems using the blockchain and smart contracts. The solution uses a permissioned blockchain structure that is private and Hyperledger Fabric-based in an effort to improve scalability and privacy while retaining the inherent features of decentralization. A zero-knowledge proof (ZKPs) based novel authentication method is implemented to provide eligibility checking and safeguard the privacy of the voter. The smart contracts are aimed at automating ballot tallying, publishing results, and checking their validity. The system is also resistant to traditional channels of attack such as denial-of-service, vote tampering, and voting redundancies based on its distributed ledger and consensus algorithms. A light-weight online interface has been implemented in an effort to promote usability and accessibility, thereby showing an unproblematic voter experience. Experimental results have now made it feasible to deploy the system in organizational and government voting applications, thereby testing its effectiveness within these settings. This method represents a tangible step towards an entirely reliable digital democracy.

title: LoRa-Driven Deep Learning System for Real-Time CNC Machine Monitoring and Predictive Maintenance
authors: Monish. P, Mohammed Siddik. J, Dharanitharan. J, Sathishkumar. B. R
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Modern manufacturing systems include cyber-physical systems (CPS) and Industrial IoT (IIoT) for predictive analytics, while mechanization characterized the first industrial revolution. Using deep learning-based prognostics for Remaining Useful Life (RUL) estimate and LoRa for long-range, low-power wireless communication, this study introduces a real-time CNC lathe machine monitoring system. While traditional wired networks have limitations about scalability, maintenance, and reliability, LoRa's sub-GHz operation, chirp spread spectrum (CSS) modulation. Sensor nodes provide structured telemetry packets to a LoRa gateway for cloud-hosted analytics, integrating microcontroller-based LoRa transceivers for edge data collecting. In order to capture multi-dimensional temporal correlations in sequential sensor streams for prognostics, LSTM and GRU recurrent neural networks are used. The gated memory architecture of LSTM allows for deep sequence modelling, while GRU lowers computing overhead for inference in real time. In line with Industry 4.0 requirements, the framework facilitates predictive maintenance scheduling, reduces unscheduled downtime, and makes scalable, IIoT-ready CNC monitoring possible with minimal operating costs.

title: Leveraging Attention U-Net in Generative Adversarial Networks for Satellite to Map Image Translation
authors: M Rithani, R S SyamDev, M M Sri Vathsan, Sowrish V K
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Generating realistic map images from satellite imagery is a challenging task in computer vision. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages an attention-based U-Net architecture within a conditional generative adversarial network (cGAN) framework. Spatial and channel-wise attention blocks are integrated within a U-Net architecture to selectively focus the network on translating geospatially salient features. Extensive experiments on the Pix2Pix dataset of satellite and map image pairs demonstrate that our attention-enhanced cGAN model synthesizes maps that are more accurate and realistic than baseline cGAN approaches. Quantitative results show that our model achieves a PSNR of more than 2 dB and a 0.05 higher SSIM compared to cGAN. Furthermore, the FID score is reduced by 15% over the baseline, indicating the enhanced realism of the generated maps. This work provides both quantitative and qualitative results which highlight the merits of using attention to guide the image translation process.

title: Educational Cyber-Physical System for Future Engineering Education
authors: Ganesh Selvaraj, Gayathri P, Thilagavathy J, Kowshika R
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: As engineering education continues to grow, integrating emerging technologies into the learning process is paramount to meet the demands of modern industries. This paper developed an Educational Cyber-Physical System (ECPS) designed to link the gap between theoretical knowledge and practical application in future engineering education. The proposed system supports a wide range of engineering disciplines, including mechanical, electrical, civil, and computer engineering, allowing for multidisciplinary applications. By combining artificial intelligence (AI), augmented reality (AR), and the internet of things (IoT), students can investigate different engineering systems in a dynamic yet regulated setting. The ECPS framework enables real-time feedback, personalized learning paths, and collaborative problem-solving, fostering a deeper connection between theory and practice. The proposed work is that an AI-powered computer assistant will automatically oversee every step of the student education process, enabling prompt modifications in response to the student's development. The assistant's capacity to gather thorough data on every student activity within the programme is essential to this procedure, especially when it comes to monitoring pedagogical actions in real-time and making any necessary adjustments. This makes efficient use of ECPS to accumulate all pertinent records and extract pertinent information. This article looks at a particular instance of real-world work where students from two different places work together in a combined learning setting.

title: Safe Path Planning via Multi-Objective Distributional Reinforcement Learning
authors: Yuanhao Wang, Weihao Xia, Kunpeng Ouyang, Jianxin Lin, Huachuan Wang, Guo Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Ensuring safe and efficient trajectory planning in dynamic marine environments poses fundamental challenges for autonomous platforms. We propose a novel reinforcement learning framework that integrates distributional value estimation with continuous control under formal safety constraints. By incorporating Implicit Quantile Networks into an actor-critic architecture, our method captures uncertainty over return distributions while generating stochastic policies in continuous spaces. Safety is enforced through differentiable control barrier functions embedded into the critic's objective, and multiobjective training stability is achieved via conflict-averse gradient descent. Experiments in simulated marine scenarios demonstrate improved safety compliance and competitive performance relative to baseline methods, offering a generalizable paradigm for riskaware decision-making in real-time navigation systems.

title: A Spatial-Physics Informed Model for 3D Spiral Sample Scanned by SQUID Microscopy
authors: J. Senthilnath, Jayasanker Jayabalan, Zhuoyi Lin, Aye Phyu Phyu Aung, Chen Hao, Kaixin Xu, Yeow Kheng Lim, F. C. Wellstood
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: The development of advanced packaging is essential in the semiconductor manufacturing industry. However, non-destructive testing (NDT) of advanced packaging becomes increasingly challenging due to the depth and complexity of the layers involved. In such a scenario, Magnetic field imaging (MFI) enables the imaging of magnetic fields generated by currents. For MFI to be effective in NDT, the magnetic fields must be converted into current density. This conversion has typically relied solely on a Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) for magnetic field inversion; however, the existing approach does not consider eddy current effects or image misalignment in the test setup. In this paper, we present a spatial-physics informed model (SPIM) designed for a 3D spiral sample scanned using Superconducting QUantum Interference Device (SQUID) microscopy. The SPIM encompasses three key components: i) magnetic image enhancement by aligning all the “sharp” wire field signals to mitigate the eddy current effect using both in-phase (I-channel) and quadrature-phase (Q-channel) images; (ii) magnetic image alignment that addresses skew effects caused by any misalignment of the scanning SQUID microscope relative to the wire segments; and (iii) an inversion method for converting magnetic fields to magnetic currents by integrating the Biot-Savart Law with FFT. The results show that the SPIM improves I-channel sharpness by 0.3% and reduces Q-channel sharpness by 25%. Also, we were able to remove rotational and skew misalignments of 0.3° in a real image. Overall, SPIM highlights the potential of combining spatial analysis with physics-driven models in practical applications.

title: Integrated Computer Vision and Robotic Control System with KUKA IIWA Manipulator: A ROS2-PyBullet Framework
authors: Juan P. Escobar V., Mauricio Holguín L, German A Holguín L
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: This paper shows the development and implemen-tation of an integrated computer vision and robotic control system utilizing a KUKA IIWA manipulator for autonomous detection, localization, and approach to specific targets. The system addresses a visual servoing task in which the robot detects a target and positions the end-effector precisely above it. The framework is decomposed into independent ROS2 nodes that handle everything from physics simulation to data logging. The system demonstrates effective perception and motion accuracy in a virtual environment, using a modular robotic architecture and providing a reproducible platform for testing vision-based manipulation strategies.

title: Digital Twin of a Mecanum Mobile Robot in ROS-Gazebo
authors: Laura Valentina Vanegas Torres, Carlos Andrés Mesa M., Germán A Holguin L.
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: This paper presents the development and validation of a Digital Twin for a mobile platform with Mecanum wheels. The kinematic and dynamic models are derived using inverse kinematics and the Euler-Lagrange formulation. The four DC motors are modeled via grey-box identification, while the platform's global dynamics are represented by a MIMO ARX model. The Digital Twin is implemented in ROS and Gazebo, integrating a CAD model. Validation is performed through repeated K-fold cross-validation and trajectory comparisons using Root Mean Square Error (RMSE). Results demonstrate a strong correlation between the physical robot and its digital twin, confirming the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Transforming Engineering Education with Competitive Programming, Gamified Learning, and AI-Driven Innovation
authors: Luis H. González-Guerra, Maria Yolanda Burgos-Lopez, Christian E. Coronado Mondragon
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: Students currently enrolled in higher education programs in this technological era need a learning framework that boosts their motivation and promotes creative thinking, allowing them to develop disciplinary and interdisciplinary competencies throughout their courses. For Computer Science students, cultivating problem-solving competency is essential through enhancing mathematical and algorithmic thinking rather than merely learning a programming language. The most effective way to acquire this competency is through practice. Computer Science students should be motivated by a learning strategy that enhances their potential and encourages active engagement in the learning process through appropriate activities. Gamification involves integrating game design elements and principles into non-game environments to boost user engagement, motivation, and learning outcomes. By incorporating game-like features into students' activities, gamification seeks to transform tasks into enjoyable and rewarding experiences. Active learning is an instructional approach that actively involves students in their educational journey. Instead of passively absorbing information, students are encouraged to engage directly with the material. This method fosters collaboration, critical thinking, and problem-solving skills, empowering learners to take charge of their education. Generative AI functions as an intelligent tutor, enhancing courses by enabling students to consult and support one another in their learning journey. This collaborative approach fosters a more interactive and enriching educational experience. Competitive programming empowers students to tackle problem-solving challenges using advanced programming algorithms, all within a motivating environment. During competitions, participants encounter real-world problems that enable them to apply their learning in a practical setting. This experience reinforces their existing knowledge and encourages them to explore deeper solutions as they strive to solve problems as effectively as possible. The integration of these approaches offers students a dynamic, well-rounded learning experience. It equips them with essential tools to thrive in academic and professional environments, ensuring long-term success. This study aims to evaluate the learning outcomes of integrating active learning, gamification, generative AI, and competitive programming as a cohesive approach to developing computer science students' skills.

title: Quantifying the Gap Between FPGA and ASIC Implementations of a Surface Code Decoder
authors: Junichiro Kadomoto, Werner Florian Samayoa, Prasoon Ambalathankandy, Jan Erik R. Wichmann, Kentaro Sano
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Achieving fault tolerance in quantum computing demands sophisticated control systems, and their development is advancing rapidly. To keep pace with fast-moving qubit technology, these systems are typically prototyped on field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs)-reconfigurable devices that can adapt to a wide range of qubit counts and connectivity patterns, as well as to various error-correction codes. Nevertheless, application-specific integrated circuits (ASICs)-despite being fixed after fabrication and incurring substantial non-recurring engineering costs-ultimately offer higher performance. This paper presents a case study of the error decoder, a core control system component, and quantitatively compares its FPGA and ASIC implementations. The results offer guidance for future control system design.

title: Evaluating Collaboration Competencies in Real-World Industry Settings: A Case Study
authors: Edber Galindo-Cota, Felipe Hernández-Rodríguez
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: The Tecnologico de Monterrey's new educational model emphasizes Challenge-Based Learning (CBL) and the evaluation of key competencies, particularly Collaboration. This competency aims to enhance students' skills in engaging with diverse teams and effective communication, essential for professional integration. The Tec Semester Internships program provides seventh-semester students with immersive experiences in real-world industry settings, placing them in interdisciplinary teams across various stages of the production chain. This study assesses the impact of these internships on developing students' collaboration skills, exploring how industry engagement influences this competency. Throughout the 17-week internship, students tackle a challenge in four stages: observing the current status, diagnosing improvement opportunities, proposing solutions, and analyzing results. An industry mentor assesses students through qualitative and quantitative feedback, while students submit a reflective article on their team interactions and role in goal achievement. The findings indicate a significant improvement in adaptability and teamwork, thereby shortening the learning curve for students transitioning into engineering roles. Participants report enhanced teamwork, responsibility, and professional growth. In conclusion, the Tec Semester Internships provide a hands-on approach to essential competency development, offering valuable preparation for engineering graduates. The findings also suggest that universities could replicate this approach to improve skill development for professional integration across diverse sectors.

title: A Comprehensive Review of Infant Cry Audio Signal Analysis and Recognition using Machine Learning Approaches
authors: S. S. Suganya, G. Ravishankar
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: This paper reviews recent research on interpreting and classifying infant cry signals, focusing on data collection, machine learning methods, and signal processing techniques. Since crying is a baby’s main form of communication, accurate interpretation is essential to identify needs such as hunger, discomfort, or illness. Challenges include noise, variability, and limited labeled data. The review highlights current approaches and their limitations, aiming to guide the development of reliable cry-based monitoring systems. This paper looks at how newly built Neural Network (NN) architectures are used in newborn cry research. It also looks at how preprocessing, feature extraction (e.g., Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC), Spectrograms), and classification using algorithms like K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN), Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) are currently done. They evaluate recent advancements, highlighting both the achievements and shortcomings of data collection, tagging, and model performance. This project aims to focus future research on creating a reliable, real-time infant monitoring system to assist caretakers and healthcare providers in making urgent choices.

title: Novel Framework for Event-Based Video Compression Preserving Event Characteristics
authors: Christian Frank, Jan Bauer
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Image and Signal Processing and Analysis (ISPA)
abstract: This paper presents a novel framework for real-time compression of event-based video streams, explicitly designed to allow for the preservation of intrinsic event data characteristics. Our method systematically separates compression into three modular stages: Entropy coding, event prediction, and adaptive event filtering. Both entropy coding and event prediction are lossless, ensuring exact signal reconstruction, while controlled, application-adaptive filtering introduces targeted lossiness only when necessary. A dynamic backpressure mechanism adjusts the filtering based on real-time bandwidth constraints, event stream complexity or application feedback. We demonstrate a prototypical software implementation, proving the framework's effectiveness on a publicly available event dataset, achieving lossless compression ratios exceeding <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 \times$</tex> with minimal latency and complexity. To assess downstream impact, we also evaluate the effect of lossy filtering on a state-of-the-art event-based semantic segmentation task.

title: Smart Assistive Stick with GPS and Heart Rate Monitoring
authors: N. Vigneshwari, Aadhishwaran K, Aravind P, Chris J Allen
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: This paper presents a multipurpose assistive system designed to improve the safety, mobility, and independence of visually impaired individuals. The device integrates two core modules: real-time obstacle detection and emergency response. In the first module, ultrasonic sensors detect obstructions within a 5–35 cm range, with an ATmega328 microcontroller activating a buzzer for immediate alerts. Additional awareness is provided through a Light Dependent Resistor (LDR) that monitors ambient brightness and a moisture sensor that detects slippery surfaces, while an RF transmitter–receiver pair aids in locating misplaced sticks. The second module, developed using an ESP32 microcontroller, enables rapid emergency communication by combining a GPS unit, a push button for manual activation, and a MAX30102 heart rate sensor for continuous BPM monitoring. Each device is uniquely registered and transmits real-time BPM and GPS coordinates to a remote server, which relays critical information to caregivers and hospitals when required. Experimental results confirm reliable obstacle detection, effective environmental sensing, and robust emergency data transmission. By integrating embedded sensing, IoT-based communication, and health monitoring, the proposed system delivers a cost-effective assistive solution and provides a foundation for future advancements in intelligent mobility aids.

title: Quantum Time Capsules
authors: Qasim Bedford, Shashvat Shukla
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We introduce Quantum Time Capsule, a website designed to raise awareness about quantum computing and its implications for information security. Our website allows users to create time capsule messages by encrypting text using the RSA cryptosystem and then discarding the private key. As a result, the messages are effectively locked away as they are beyond current decryption capabilities. However, quantum computers will be able to break RSA encryption and make these messages readable once again. This creates a personal connection to quantum computing and its progress, as users are led to imagine a future when their messages can finally be accessed. This paper explains the theory behind quantum time capsules, the design of our website, and the project's public engagement strategy.

title: Contextual Feature Extraction from User Reviews for Electric Car Recommendation using BERT
authors: P. Ebby Darney, Syedhalifathima Jamin S, R. Santhana Krishnan, A. Meena, J. Relin Francis Raj, S. Thanga Anushya
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The increasing diversity and availability of electric vehicles (EVs) have made the decision-making process for prospective buyers more complex. Conventional recommendation systems often rely on numerical ratings or structured data, failing to leverage the full context of user-generated reviews. Existing systems struggle to understand the underlying sentiment, intent, and opinion nuances expressed in natural language feedback. Additionally, static content-based or collaborative filtering models are limited in the ability to capture dynamic and contextual features from unstructured textual data. These limitations result in suboptimal recommendations and reduce the relevance of suggestions provided to end-users. To address these challenges, this work presents a sentiment-aware EV recommendation framework that leverages a BERT-based transformer model to extract deep contextual representations from user reviews. The system processes unstructured text to classify sentiment and integrates this output with a recommendation module for generating personalized EV suggestions. The methodology combines textual understanding with preference mapping, thereby improving recommendation precision. Preprocessing techniques ensure clean and normalized input, while the architecture is optimized through fine-tuning of transformer layers and application of dropout for generalization. Key features of this work include the use of pre-trained deep language models for sentiment mining, integration of review-level sentiment into recommendation logic, and application of robust evaluation metrics such as F1-score and RMSE. The proposed system provides meaningful and relevant EV suggestions that reflect user sentiments and real-world experiences.

title: Transfer Learning LinkNet with SegNet for Waste Sorting
authors: S.Sasirekha, P.Kavitha, S.Kamalakkannan
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: To make the cities more sustainable and less damaging to the environment, they should control their rubbish accordingly. Sorting trash into biodegradable and non-biodegradable categories requires a lot of time and effort; otherwise, errors occur frequently when done manually. This research paper provides a hybrid deep learning system which combines Modified LinkNet and Enhanced SegNet and a transfer learning approach to achieve the goal of automated waste classification using high accuracy. The improved SegNet has the ability to clearly differentiate garbage objects on complex backgrounds, unlike the modified LinkNet that uses EfficientNet/MobileNet transfer learning techniques to classify objects. A trained and tested model was trained using over 2,500 labelled images consisting of the TrashNet and TACO datasets. The data was supplemented to strengthen it. Based on the experiment findings, this model is 98 per cent accurate, 97 per cent precise, 96 per cent recall, and 98 per cent specific, which is greater compared to the standard CNN, VGG-16, and ResNet-50 architectures. The analysis conducted by ROC indicated that the AUC equals 0.98, and it is a good indicator that the model is very well able to distinguish between various types of data. The training-validation curves indicated that overfitting was not taking place too much. Being able to leverage the advanced method in relation to smart waste systems that can make the use of rubbish sorting scalable, sustainable, and efficient in real time is a promising idea. The future research will be done on the improvement of categorizing different types of waste and real-time usage optimization on edge devices.

title: A Method for Enhancing Invocation Capabilities in Tool Calling with LLM-as-a-Judge System
authors: Yinglei Shang, Chunlei Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: The paradigm of using large models as evaluators (LLM-as-a-Judge) has shown potential in multiple tasks, but has not been fully explored in tool invocation scenarios, especially for enhancing invocation capabilities. To solve this problem, this paper proposes a method based on LLM-as-a-Judge, which integrates the advantages of different large models by building robust evaluation criteria to significantly reduce the impact of error evaluation of a single model. Research has found that: 1) methods that perform well in reasoning tasks are difficult to directly transfer to tool calling scenarios; 2) Through iterative generation and evaluation criteria guided multiple generation strategies, multiple model capabilities can be effectively integrated to enhance evaluation stability. Our experiments on the benchmark dataset of four types of tool calling show that the proposed method outperforms the baseline model in both accuracy and robustness.

title: Efficient and Safe Planner for Automated Driving on Ramps Considering Unsatisfication
authors: Qinghao Li, Zhen Tian, Xiaodan Wang, Jinming Yang, Zhihao Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Automated driving on ramps presents significant challenges due to the need to balance both safety and efficiency during lane changes. This paper proposes an integrated planner for automated vehicles (AVs) on ramps, utilizing an unsatisfactory level metric for efficiency and arrow-cluster-based sampling for safety. The planner identifies optimal times for the AV to change lanes, taking into account the vehicle’s velocity as a key factor in efficiency. Additionally, the integrated planner employs arrow-cluster-based sampling to evaluate collision risks and select an optimal lane-changing curve. Extensive simulations were conducted in a ramp scenario to verify the planner’s efficient and safe performance. The results demonstrate that the proposed planner can effectively select an appropriate lane-changing time point and a safe lane-changing curve for AVs, without incurring any collisions during the maneuver.

title: Research on Cell Image Segmentation Algorithm Based on Improved U-Net Model
authors: Sixing Rong, Tianji Zheng, Lin Xing, ChiaHua Chang, Zhenglin Li, Bingcai Wei, Wang Yu, Wenjun Yu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: To address cellular image segmentation challenges like blurred cell boundaries, overlapping cell identification difficulties, and false segmentation of vacuolated cells, this paper proposes a CB - U - Net model based on an improved U - Net architecture. The model integrates a Convolution Block Attention Module (CBAM) to enhance key features and suppress background noise via dual - dimensional attention mechanisms across channels and spatial dimensions. Experimental results on the CX22 cell dataset show that CB - U - Net significantly improves segmentation performance. It achieves an average intersection over - union ratio (MIoU) of 89.68%, accuracy (A) of 91.23%, and precision <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{P})$</tex> of 84.35%, with improvements of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$15.33 \%, 14.67 \%$</tex>, and 17.78% respectively compared to the baseline U - Net. Subjective evaluations confirm the model's robustness in segmenting blurred cell nuclei and precise recognition of vacuolated cells. This study provides a reliable solution for high precision biological cell image segmentation and offers new insights for applying attention mechanisms in biomedical applications.

title: Quantum Kernel Anomaly Detection Using AR-Derived Features from Non-Contact Acoustic Monitoring for Smart Manufacturing
authors: Takao Tomono, Kazuya Tsujimura
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The evolution of manufacturing toward Smart Factories has highlighted critical challenges in equipment maintenance, particularly the reliance on numerous contact sensors for anomaly detection, resulting in escalating sensor and computational costs. This study investigates the application of quantum kernels to enhance anomaly detection using non-contact sensors. We hypothesized that quantum computing's expressive power could effectively discriminate among multiple anomaly types using fewer sensors. Our experimental setup involved detecting and classifying anomalies from two distinct manufacturing equipment: a conveyor and a chain belt machine using a single directional microphone positioned at varying distances (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0-3 ~\mathrm{m}$</tex>). Audio data was processed through Autoregressive (AR) models to extract coefficient features, which were then mapped into quantum feature space using quantum kernels for one-class SVM classification. Results demonstrated that quantum kernel implementations maintained near-perfect accuracy and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F} 1$</tex>-scores (consistently <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{> 0. 9 2}$</tex>) across all distances, while classical approaches showed significant performance degradation beyond the 0 m position. Feature space visualization revealed that quantum kernels effectively separated different anomaly types into distinct quadrants within a two-dimensional representation, enabling not only detection but also classification of multiple equipment failures. Specifically, under the third and fourth features space, conveyor anomalies consistently appeared in the second quadrant, while chain belt anomalies clustered in the fourth quadrant. This study demonstrates that quantum kernel methods enable significant anomaly detection in noisy factory environments using fewer non-contact sensors, representing an important step toward realizing quantum-enhanced smart factories with reduced infrastructure requirements and improved maintenance efficiency.

title: Digital Currency and Blockchain
authors: Kuehn, A Uwe
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: The huge increase in devices connected to the Internet worldwide created the Internet of Things. Digitalization has become increasingly important. Blockchain technology as part of IoT and crypto values are traded in stock exchange markets. Governments and banks are working on digital currencies based on these technologies. In our research, we want to figure out, what future payment systems could look like and present a prototype for a specific use case “selling data from an IoT sensor network data stream”. We present a high-frequency and secure data and money exchange system.

title: Gesture Sign Translator using CNN
authors: Muruga Radha Devi, R Shobana Lakshmi, K Anuratha, Gopika K, Aishwarya R S, Janani A
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: We propose an on-device gesture sign translator for ISL that uses a lightweight spatiotemporal CNN with few-shot personalization and edge inference (Android phone or Raspberry Pi). Unlike prior systems that require cloud GPUs or large datasets of single signers, this system runs fully offline, adapts to a new user with ≤10 samples per class using feature-space prototypes, and performs phrase-level translation (short multi-sign sequences) with real-time latency (<120 ms/frame). Output is text + TTS in English/Tamil/Hindi. We also add privacy- preserving training (federated-style local updates simulated across devices) and explainability via Grad-CAM on the hand region.

title: Heart Rate Forecasting Using Ultra-Wideband Radar with Sequence-to-Sequence Model
authors: Minh H. Pham, Farzan M. Noori, Md Zia Uddin, Jim Torresen
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Image and Signal Processing and Analysis (ISPA)
abstract: Heart dysfunction can be very dangerous and directly associated with the risk of fatality. Therefore, automatic heart rate monitoring is important for detecting a heart abnormality early and providing timely intervention. The development of advanced sensor technology allows continuous tracking of the heart rate, as well as providing more health-related data sources, which could further improve the forecasting performance. In this study, we investigate the use of recent heart rate values and Ultra-Wideband (UWB) data in the last 20s to predict the next 10s of heart rate. Data were collected from 20 participants performing different activities. We examine the forecasting by using only a heart rate sensor (uni-modality) and by using heart rate sensor and UWB together (multi-modality). Three levels of activity were included in the study: resting (rest), lying after doing exercises (lying-abnormal) and lying after full recovery (lying-normal). A multi-modality Sequence-to-Sequence (Seq2Seq) model has a 10-percent quantile losses of 5.20 for rest activity, 4.92 for lying-abnormal activity, and 4.24 for lying-normal activity. With the lowest loss, Seq2Seq outperforms Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA), Error Trend and Seasonality (ETS), Transformer and Temporal Fusion Transformer (TFT) in forecasting heart rate in the three activity levels. Our results point to a new direction in multimodal prediction of heart rate to assist healthcare, using deep learning approaches.

title: Benefit for the Probing Pad Preparation Using Green/UV Laser
authors: Chia Siang Chang, Benjamin Lo Yuen Sum
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: During failure analysis, probing the inner circuit is a method used for fault localization. There exists a passivation layer above the metal trace, which blocks the probe needle from landing on the metal trace. Passivation removal is a key process before performing the probe analysis. Common methods include using a Reactive Ion Etcher (RIE) or a Focused Ion Beam (FIB) to expose the metal trace and make Pt deposition. Using RIE will etch the entire passivation layer on the die surface, making further circuit edits inconvenient. Using FIB will result in longer analysis times. To address this, green/UV laser could be a better way to remove passivation in certain areas. Using a laser could reduce the analysis time and allow for localized circuit edits. This paper will discuss how to remove passivation using green/UV laser and the benefits compared to other methods.

title: A Proposal for Multilevel Mathematics Curriculum Innovation Using Interactive Unity Simulations
authors: Carlos Astengo Noguez, Lorena B. Martínez Elizalde
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: This article examines the necessary transformation in mathematics education for engineering programs within a rapidly evolving technological landscape. It argues that advanced topics such as quaternions, bilinear algebras, spectral theory, complex analysis, among others, traditionally reserved for graduate-level courses, should now be introduced at the undergraduate level, especially if future engineers are expected to design and solve real-world problems in fields such as robotics, artificial intelligen…

title: Extended Poster Abstract: Graph Matching Trotterization for CTQW Circuit Simulation
authors: Mostafa Atallah, Daniel Dilley, Igor Gaidai, Alvin Gonzales, Zain H. Saleem, Rebekah Herrman
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We present a novel algorithm that converts CTQWs on arbitrary graphs into efficient quantum circuits through graph matching decomposition. Our approach decomposes the target graph into a set of matchings, where a matching is a collection of disjoint edges that can be implemented exactly using multi-controlled rotation gates. The overall CTQW evolution is then approximated via Trotterization over these matchings. We validate our approach through comprehensive comparison with Pauli decomposition methods across all connected isomorphic 8-vertex graphs, demonstrating comparable accuracy across all test cases. Our matching decomposition achieves reduced gate counts compared to Pauli decomposition for approximately 33% of all connected 8-vertex graphs, with particular advantages for graphs that decompose into small numbers of matchings or contain many disjoint edges. Our matching decomposition provides a valuable alternative pathway for implementing CTQW-based algorithms on near-term gate-based quantum devices while maintaining the fundamental quantum advantages of walk-based computation.

title: Software Reliability Forecasting Using Anomalies in Profiles of Resource Usage
authors: Vitor S. Montes, Caio G. Herrera, Thiago J. O. Durães, Alexandre C. B. Delbem, Simone R. S. Lopes de Souza, Paulo Sergio Lopes de Souza
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: Assessing software reliability in production environments presents unique challenges, particularly for autonomous and black-box systems operating under unpredictable workloads. Traditional testing techniques, while effective in controlled settings, often fall short in capturing the dynamic behavior that lead to latent faults in real-world deployments. This paper presents Tricorder, a novel software reliability approach for failure forecasting, based on continuous observation of resource utilization during software execution. Tricorder collects resource usage profiles and analyzes them by applying unsupervised clustering based on Normalized Compression Distance (NCD), which groups data sets, allowing for highlighting anomalous behaviors. The approach is fully black-box, generalizable across platforms, and applicable to distinct domains. Experimental validation demonstrates that the approach can forecast failures by identifying hidden faults under diverse runtime conditions, supporting automated, low-overhead reliability monitoring during post-deployment and maintenance activity.

title: Green Sphere – Automatic Plant Watering System with ML Integration
authors: K. R. Kayalvizhi, E Caron Joan, B Danusri
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Effective water management in agricultural environments is an extremely difficult problem, particularly when conventional irrigation approaches are used, leading to under-watering or over-watering, thus ensuring a waste of Natural Resources. To address low-cost remote and automatic irrigation practices, we present GreenSphere, an automatic plant watering system that incorporates Internet of Things (IoT) sensors and machine learning (ML) to make irrigation decisions in real-time. Utilizing an ESP32 microcontroller, GreenSphere deployed sensor readings of the environmental conditions, including soil moisture, temperature, humidity, light, and water levels. A Random Forest model was trained, producing a 99.8% accuracy rating for optimal irrigation time, while periodic rule-based decisions received. In regard to pump operation, tests showed the accuracy of timing was within ±3%, and that the pump was consuming nominal energy. With respect to farmer adoption, GreenSphere demonstrated feasible use in small-scale farms, urban gardening, and as an educational platform for students. The sustainability attributes of GreenSphere provide low-cost, modular, and sustainable attributes to contribute towards more efficient resource use and help to align with the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals.

title: Predicting the Impact of Parameter Adjustments on Cellular Networks
authors: Yongqian Sun, Qingliang Zhang, Yu Luo, Mingjie Li, Shenglin Zhang, Xiaolei Hua, Renkai Yu, Xinwen Fan, Lin Zhu, Junlan Feng, Dan Pei
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: Cellular networks are critical infrastructure for user equipment to access the Internet. Given the spatio-temporal dynamics of user distribution and traffic demand, operators adjust parameters such as transmission power (TP) and cell individual offset (CIO) to enhance network stability and service quality, However, predicting the impact of such adjustments is challenging due to limited historical adjustment data and complex metric dependencies. We propose PIPCell, a two-phase predictive framework. In phase one, PIPCell uses a closed-form multiplier from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T P$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$C I O$</tex> domain knowledge to calibrate adjustmentfree Workload predictions from pre-trained Transformers. In phase two, a causal graphical model organizes multiple pretrained Transformers to capture inter-metric dependencies and propagate adjustment effects. Experiments on real-world dataset from China Mobile show that PIPCell outperforms the best baseline by up to 25.8 % in RMSE and 59.0 % in sMAPE, demonstrating PIPCell's potential for proactive and data-efficient cellular network optimization.

title: Evaluating pVSQA for Large-Sized Constrained Optimization on Quantum Simulator
authors: Takeru Ota, Tatsuhiko Shirai, Mikio Morita, Koichi Kimura, Yutaka Takita, Nozomu Togawa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: This study investigates the graph partitioning problem as a constrained combinatorial optimization problem and evaluates the effectiveness of the Postprocessing Variationally Scheduled Quantum Algorithm <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathbf{p V S Q A})$</tex> on the instances of up to 30 qubits. We executed pVSQA using Fujitsu's highperformance quantum simulator in a single-node configuration and compared its performance with the conventional Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA). Experimental results on various instances show that pVSQA consistently outperforms QAOA in terms of feasibility and optimality, successfully obtaining optimal solutions even for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 0}$</tex>-qubit instances. The study also demonstrates that Fujitsu's quantum simulator is effective for the stable execution of large-scale quantum circuits.

title: A Knowledge-Driven Graph Network For Traffic Flow Prediction
authors: Chenxu Li, Guanlei Zhangx, Yansong Liu, Mengjun Yin, Wenjing Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: As an important research topic in the field of intelligent network management, network traffic prediction has received considerable attention in recent years. Effective traffic prediction has become a challenging problem. This paper proposes a KGN knowledge-driven deep learning method for graphical convolutional networks for traffic flow prediction with multiple factors. In the method, our innovative idea is to design a knowledge-data dual-driven feature extraction scheme that fuses the knowledge representation of external factors into a graph convolutional network. We evaluated KGN with a heterogeneous data set containing log data and used several sequence prediction datasets from other application domains for additional comparison. Experimental results show that our method outperforms several state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Prediction of Brain Tumor Disease using Machine Learning
authors: Karthik P, Anuradha Kumari Pal, B M Moulya, Chaitra C M, Indu A S
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Because of their complexity as well. brain tumors require to be recognized early in order to elevate the outcomes for patients. Conventional approaches might be subjective and slow. To assist we developed a website where patients may enter their symptoms to assess whether MRI is required and upload scans for tumor detection. We assembled a sizable MRI dataset and used preprocessing methods like augmentation and normalization to enhance the image quality. To extract essential information for precise classification, we employed CNNs and deep learning. Our trained model achieved high tumor detection accuracy, outperforming conventional techniques. This method might help with early diagnosis. The remaining research will concentrate on expanding the dataset and improving the model.

title: AnemiaX: A Predictive Intelligence Model for Hematological Health
authors: K. Malarkodi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Population-wide data suggests anaemia is a blood-based medical condition which affects millions globally through its red blood cell or haemoglobin deficiencies that result in fatigue and weakness and subpar physical functioning. Identifying anemia early on remains essential for both preventing dangerous medical consequences and enhancing care results. The research introduces AnemiaX as a predictive model for anemia that includes Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) with Logistic Regression as hybrid components in its machine learning methodology. We utilized a Kaggle public dataset of hematological measurements including hemoglobin and MCV as well as MCH and serum ferritin together with RBC count for which we performed comprehensive preprocessing steps and applied feature engineering and hyperparameter optimization. The Light GBM model identified non-linear relationships within the data along with feature interactions which Logistic Regression used to add interpretability and generalization abilities during modeling. The performance benchmarks of AnemiaX manifested through a 93.67% accuracy alongside a 93.49% F1-score and 96.31% AUC-ROC metric surpassed the capabilities of SVM, Random Forest and standalone LightGBM models. AnemiaX shows strong potential to function as a dependable screening system and medical decision-making tool for anemia diagnosis.

title: A Discussion on UDU Kalman Filters and Measurement Underweighting
authors: James S. McCabe
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Multisensor Fusion and Integration for Intelligent Systems (MFI)
abstract: The Kalman filter has long been known to exhibit numerical instability caused by finite precision arithmetic, and this has motivated algorithmic innovations surrounding factorized covariance representations. The UDU factorization has found widespread use in practical applications, yet it inherently requires a hidden approximation when coupled with measurement underweighting via the assumption that a suboptimal gain is equal to the optimal Kalman gain. This paper introduces a new UDU measurement update algorithm that analytically matches the well-known Joseph form.

title: A Web-based Intelligent Framework for Early Facial Melanoma Detection using Deep Learning
authors: Prakash P, Rajasekaran T, Sobika M, Sabarish M, Sivanesh T, Sri Sanjay S A
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Melanoma is one of the deadliest types of skin cancer that spreads quickly. When it first appears, it typically presents as small facial lesions that are easily overlooked or may even seem like harmless patches of skin. Many cases are not detected until they reach more advanced stages, which is why dermatological care is often overlooked and can be difficult to cure. This research presents a simple, web-based system that can detect facial melanoma in real-time using standard photos captured by smartphones and webcams. The technology is lightweight and user-friendly. It uses the precision-detecting You Only Look Once (YOLOv8) system to identify moles and also has a compact Convolutional Neural Network(CNN) that classifies each mole as either benign or malignant. This system's success is due to its ability to handle everyday, non-clinical photos, unlike many other systems that rely on clinic-based dermoscopic images. Using 1,500 labeled images of facial moles, the tests achieved an accuracy of 99.3%, with precision and recall scores that exceeded 93%. Mobile devices can display the model at roughly 25 frames per second, making it a viable option for screening in real-time. Moreover, the site provides information on warning signs of melanoma to boost awareness and promote early medical consultation. With its exceptional accuracy, speed, and accessibility, it offers a useful way to detect early stages of melanoma well before clinical trials, far beyond the typical open clinic setting.

title: Metriq-Gym: Unified Benchmarking Framework for Quantum Computers
authors: Alessandro Cosentino, Changhao Li, Vincent Russo, Daniel Strano, Nathan Shammah, William J. Zeng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: As quantum hardware continues to advance across a growing landscape of vendors, it is increasingly important to evaluate device capabilities for specific computational tasks. However, cross-platform benchmarking remains challenging due to diverse hardware architectures, proprietary access interfaces, and the lack of standardized benchmarking frameworks. We introduce metriq-gym, an open-source Python framework designed to facilitate both system-level and application-level benchmarking of quantum devices across multiple providers. The metriq-gym framework offers a unified workflow for executing a suite of community-driven benchmarks, enabling consistent comparisons across heterogeneous quantum platforms. In this poster, we provide an overview of the metriq-gym architecture and demonstrate its capabilities through a curated set of benchmark results obtained from several leading quantum hardware systems.

title: Potential of Distributed Circuits for Mitigating Quantum Image Noise
authors: Yayu Mo, Mitchell A. Thornton, Sanjaya Lohani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The rapid advancement of quantum information science is reshaping communication technologies, yet it also introduces unique challenges, particularly from quantum noise channels that significantly degrade circuit-based quantum image encodings. Here, we design and investigate a distributed quantum circuit architecture to mitigate channel noise effects in quantum-based representations of classical images. We evaluate the approach across multiple noise models using the structural similarity index measure (SSIM) and demonstrate that increasing the number of quantum circuit nodes significantly enhances image quality. Our results highlight the potential of distributed quantum circuits to support scalable and resilient quantum image processing.

title: Federated Deep Learning for Privacy Preserving Diagnosis of Skin Diseases using Mobile Devices
authors: Jeniston Moses J, Sophia S
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Skin diseases are among the most prevalent health conditions globally, and timely diagnosis is critical for effective treatment. However, conventional AI-based dermatological systems depend on centralized image storage, raising serious concerns over data security, patient privacy, and compliance with regulations such as GDPR. This work presents a privacy-focused diagnostic framework leveraging federated deep learning on mobile devices, enabling local training of lightweight convolutional neural networks (CNNs), specifically MobileNetV3, without transferring raw images to a central server. Privacy is further reinforced through the integration of differential privacy and secure aggregation, ensuring that sensitive health data remains confined to user devices. The HAM10000 dataset, containing over 10,000 dermatoscopic images, is partitioned under non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) conditions to simulate real-world variability. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that the proposed model achieves an accuracy of 87.2%, F1-score of 0.85, and AUC of 0.91, while reducing communication bandwidth by approximately 35% compared to traditional approaches. These results highlight the feasibility of delivering secure, accurate, and communication-efficient dermatological diagnosis on smartphones.
