The proposed federated learning paradigm offers a scalable and regulation-compliant mobile health (mHealth) solution, paving the way for equitable access to dermatological care, especially in resource-limited or remote settings.

title: Enhancing Professional Development for Educators and Students: Strategies for Future-Ready Learning
authors: Donnalyn Cabaces
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: In today's rapidly evolving educational landscape driven by global interconnection, labor demands, and technology advancements, the demand for future-ready learning has increased. This prompted the educational institutions to prepare the students and the educators through enhancement of professional development for them to meet the challenges of the 21st century. Educator's professional development traditionally include attendance and participation to seminars, workshops and trainings. Future-ready learning on the side of the students include the creativity, critical thinking, communication, digital literacy, adaptability, collaboration and life-long learning skills and competencies which are very essential. The main objective of this paper is to determine the different professional development strategies and trends for both educators and students to achieve a future-ready learning environment. It also aims to identify the approaches that foster creativity, critical thinking, communication, digital literacy, adaptability, collaboration and life-long learning skills and competencies. It also aims to recommend strategies that may transform the existing practices to meet the challenges of an educational landscape. This review article employed qualitative approach to gather, evaluate and synthesize existing literature on enhancing professional development both for educators and students to achieve a future-ready learning environment. The research literatures were critically analyzed, evaluated and synthesized to determine common strategies, effective approaches and gaps between them and the current strategies employed in educational institutions. Embracing innovative approaches integrated with technological advancement and shifting to future-ready learning will ensure to prepare educators and students to face the rapid changing world and global challenges.

title: Engineering Ethics in Experimental Research: A South-South Perspective on Deliberative Strategies and Institutional Management
authors: Nomcebo H. Mthombeni, Olatundi Mukaila Iyiola, Pfano Mashau, Renadani Wilson Maladzhi
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: As engineering innovations continue to reshape modern society particularly in fields such as nanotechnology, energy systems, and smart infrastructure, ethical considerations in experimental research have become increasingly complex, especially within the African context where regulatory systems are still evolving, resources for oversight are limited, and socioenvironmental vulnerabilities heighten the stakes of technological experimentation. The study aims to address this gap by conducting a comparative analysis between the Durban University of Technology (DUT) in South Africa and the University of Ibadan (UI) in Nigeria. This analysis aims to enhance ethics governance and deliberative strategies for experimental engineering research. The comparative analysis will provide valuable insights for improving ethical practices and decision-making processes in both institutions. The study employs a qualitative methodology based on ethics committee reports, faculty interviews, and curriculum audits from both institutions. Findings reveal that ethical risk is often overlooked in experimental work involving engineered materials, prototype testing, energy systems, and environmental interventions. The absence of formal ethical review for such research not only exposes institutions to reputational risk but also limits the development of ethically conscious engineers.

title: Fundamentals of Caching Layered Data objects
authors: Agrim Bari, Gustavo De Veciana, George Kesidis
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: The effective management of the vast amounts of data processed or required by modern cloud and edge computing systems remains a fundamental challenge. This paper focuses on cache management for applications where data objects can be stored in layered representations. In such representations, each additional data layer enhances the “quality” of the object’s version, albeit at the cost of increased memory usage. This layered approach is advantageous in various scenarios, including the delivery of zoomable maps, video coding, future virtual reality gaming, and layered neural network models, where additional data layers improve quality/inference accuracy. In systems where users or devices request different versions of a data object, layered representations provide the flexibility needed for caching policies to achieve improved hit rates, i.e., delivering the specific representations required by users. This paper investigates the performance of the Least Recently Used (LRU) caching policy in the context of layered representation for data, referred to as Layered LRU (LLRU). To this end, we develop an asymptotically accurate analytical model for LLRU. We analyze how LLRU’s performance is influenced by factors such as the number of layers, as well as the popularity and size of an object’s layers. For example, our results demonstrate that, in the case of LLRU, adding more layers does not always enhance performance. Instead, the effectiveness of LLRU depends intricately on the popularity distribution and size characteristics of the layers.

title: Lower Bounds for the Communication Costs of Distributing Quantum Fourier Transform on Clique Networks
authors: Ali Ebnenasir
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: This paper investigates asymptotic lower bounds for the communication costs of distributing Quantum Fourier Transform (QFT) on clique networks of quantum machines. We first show that determining lower/upper bound communication complexity is closely related to the number of machines whose qubit capacity becomes full at different stages of QFT. Subsequently, we provide lower and upper bounds on the number of full machines during the execution of distributed QFT. These bounds help us determine the lower bound of the number of nonlocal operations that should be performed during distribution of QFT on clique networks. We initially analyze the lower bound on communication complexity for the case where machines have capacity two; i.e., each quantum machine can hold at most two qubits. We show that, in this case, the lower bound is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Omega\left(n^{2}\right)$</tex>, where <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n$</tex> denotes the number of input qubits. Considering the existing quadratic upper bound in related work, our lower bound result implies that the existing upper bound is actually tight when machine capacity is two. This is a significant theoretical boundary for developers of distribution compilers. We also show that if machine capacity <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$c>2$</tex> is a fixed fraction of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n$</tex>, then the lower bound becomes linear.

title: Transformative Learning in Engineering: Insights from Active Learning Workshops
authors: Syed Ahmad Helmi Syed Hassan, Tengku Zulaikha Malim-Busu, Khairiyah Mohd-Yusof
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: Student-Centered Learning (SCL) approaches have significantly enhanced educational outcomes. In engineering undergraduate programs within Washington Accord member countries, incorporating SCL methodologies into Teaching and Learning is mandatory to meet accreditation standards and achieve course learning outcomes. However, implementing SCL in engineering curricula presents notable challenges, particularly for educators accustomed to traditional lecture-based teaching who lack the necessary knowledge, skills, and pedagogical beliefs. This study, part of a broader effort to improve engineering education in Indonesia, investigates the effects of two online active learning workshops featuring 116 engineering educators from two universities in Central Java, conducted over three half-day sessions. The workshop design drew on Needham's Constructivist instructional model, including interactive, thought-provoking activities and practical sessions. Participants documented their learning experiences in online journals, which were thematically analyzed. Four main themes emerged regarding the effectiveness of the workshop: learning content, instructional design, facilitation support, and engagement experience. The participants' shift toward SCL, as evaluated using Mezirow's Transformative Learning Theory, indicated that they had reached the first six of ten transformative learning phases. The findings suggest that the workshops effectively promoted the adoption of SCL and enhanced participants' knowledge and confidence in applying active learning strategies in their classrooms.

title: Real-Time Aerial Image Deblurring and Detection with a Lightweight Ghost Module
authors: Lingyue Guo, Jun Cao, Weiping Wang, Zixin Wang, Shukai Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are increasingly deployed for real-time perception tasks such as surveillance and tracking. However, the captured images often suffer from motion blur due to platform instability and high-speed movement, significantly degrading the performance of downstream vision algorithms. To address this challenge, we propose a lightweight and effective deblur-detect pipeline for UAV scenarios. Specifically, we enhance the MIMO-UNet deblurring backbone by replacing its Shallow Convolutional Module (SCM) with a Ghost module-inspired GhostSCM block, improving feature representation efficiency while reducing model complexity. The modified deblurring model is followed by YOLO11n for object detection. We conduct comprehensive evaluations on a motion-blurred version of the VisDrone dataset under varying blur intensities. Experimental results demonstrate that our method consistently delivers high-quality deblurring performance, achieving excellent PSNR and SSIM scores across various blur levels. Moreover, our deblur-detect pipeline yields the highest detection accuracy with minimal computational overhead, achieving a favorable balance between accuracy and speed. These results highlight the potential of lightweight deblurring modules to improve robustness in UAV vision systems operating under real-world motion degradation.

title: Enhancing Robustness in Coverless Image Steganography with Diffusion Models
authors: N.G. Bhuvaneswari Amma, Banjot Singh Kullar, Ayush Pathak, Shekhar Chhaba
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Despite recent developments in image steganography, many steganography techniques continue to rely heavily on bit manipulation or deep learning models alongside cover images, making them vulnerable to various types of attacks, such as steganalysis and noise-induced distortions. These methods often suffer from robustness limitations because slight modifications to the cover images—such as compression, scaling, or noise addition—can easily corrupt the hidden message. Additionally, these techniques generally require high computational resources due to the complexity of deep learning models, making them less practical for real-time or resource-constrained environments. In the proposed approach, a fixed definition model and new open-source tools of stable diffusion, such as Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) for efficient model adaptation and ControlNet for structural guidance, are used to ensure greater control over image generation while maintaining high fidelity to the hidden data. These technologies provide additional control and diversity in container image production, which improves the overall system. Recent advances have used text prompts as keys in Coverless Image Steganography (CIS) via diffusion models; nevertheless, this technique has drawbacks, such as vulnerability when private prompts are guessed, difficulty in supplying semantically different public prompts, and the possibility of prompt leakage during transmission. This paradigm solves the key drawbacks of existing cover-based techniques, resulting in considerable improvements in security, robustness, and control, all without requiring model retraining.

title: A New Hybrid Quantum-Classical Algorithm for Solving the Unit Commitment Problem
authors: Willie Aboumrad, Phani R V Marthi, Suman Debnath, Martin Roetteler, Evgeny Epifanovsky
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Solving problems related to planning and operations of large-scale power systems is challenging on classical computers due to their inherent nature as mixed-integer and nonlinear problems. Quantum computing provides new avenues to approach these problems. We develop a hybrid quantum-classical algorithm for the Unit Commitment (UC) problem in power systems which aims at minimizing the total cost while optimally allocating generating units to meet the hourly demand of the power loads. The hybrid algorithm combines a variational quantum algorithm (VQA) with a classical Benders-type heuristic. The resulting algorithm computes approximate solutions to UC in three stages: i) a collection of UC vectors capable meeting the power demand with lowest possible operating costs is generated based on VQA; ii) a classical sequential least squares programming (SLSQP) routine is leveraged to find the optimal power level corresponding to a predetermined number of candidate vectors; iii) in the last stage, the approximate solution of UC along with generating units power level combination is given. To demonstrate the effectiveness of the presented method, three different systems with 3 generating units, 10 generating units, and 26 generating units were tested for different time periods. In addition, convergence of the hybrid quantum-classical algorithm for select time periods is proven out on IonQ's Forte system.

title: 6G-DTauth: Distributed Token-Based Authentication for Resilient 6G Networks with LEO Satellites
authors: Jeng-Shin Huang, Kuan-Hsien Tu, Jie-Yu Luo, Min-Chih Hsu, Chi-Yu Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Dependable and Secure Computing (DSC)
abstract: Low-Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites are poised to play a vital role in future 6G networks by enabling ubiquitous coverage in remote and extreme environments. While LEO satellites offer inherent resilience against physical attacks, their reliance on wireless backhaul links and centralized network infrastructure introduces vulnerabilities to disruptions, particularly during targeted attacks or infrastructure failures. To address this, we propose 6G-DTAuth (6G Distributed Tokenbased Authentication), a distributed authentication framework that enables secure and reliable User Equipment (UE) communication even in the absence of the serving network (SN), home network (HN), or centralized control. 6G-DTAuth encapsulates UE-related context in a secure token generated during standard authentication with the HN. This token allows decentralized reauthentication and context recovery at the SN and base station (BS) during network disruptions. We implement and evaluate 6G-DTAuth using UERANSIM and free5GC, demonstrating its effectiveness, minimal overhead, and strong security properties. Our result shows that 6G-DTAuth can maintain service continuity and defend against MITM, replay, DoS, and token manipulation attacks, offering a practical path toward resilient 6G satelliteintegrated networks.

title: Assessing the Influence of Global Cross-Cultural Collaboration in Capstone Design Projects on Engineering Education
authors: Joseph Davis Thekinen, Liang Lydia Qian, Alex Ramirez Serrano, Yanhui Wang, Qiao Sun
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: In today's interconnected world, engineering education must prepare students to collaborate across cultures, disciplines, and geographies. This study investigates the impact of cross-cultural collaboration on student learning outcomes in joint capstone design projects comprising students from two universities: one based in Canada and the other in China. The research focuses on how in-person team bonding activities enhance collaboration effectiveness and project performance. Students worked in mixed teams to complete real-world engineering design challenges (in the areas of robotics, automation, and thermo-fluids among other), involving concept development, engineering analysis, prototyping, and presentations. While most collaboration occurred virtually through digital platforms, students from the Canadian university traveled to visit students in the Chinese university during the Fall semester for face-to-face interaction with teammates and mentors. Similarly, Chinese students traveled to Canada at the end of the Winter term. Surveys and performance metrics were collected before and after the in-person visit to assess changes in collaboration quality and learning experience. Results indicate that virtual-only interactions, though convenient, limit rapport and communication depth. In contrast, in-person engagement significantly improved team cohesion, reduced communication-related anxiety, and enhanced participation. Notably, student team academic performance as measured by progress presentation scores improved relative to the class average following the in-person visit. The findings offer practical insights for global engineering educators, demonstrating the value of blending virtual tools with in-person experiences to enhance teamwork and project outcomes.

title: Implementing Credit Risk Analysis with Quantum Singular Value Transformation
authors: Davide Veronelli, Francesca Cibrario, Emanuele Dri, Valeria Zaffaroni, Giacomo Ranieri, Davide Corbelletto, Bartolomeo Montrucchio
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The analysis of credit risk is crucial for the efficient operation of financial institutions. Quantum Amplitude Estimation (QAE) offers the potential for a quadratic speedup over classical methods used to estimate metrics such as Value at Risk (VaR) and Conditional Value at Risk (CVaR). However, numerous limitations remain in efficiently scaling the implementation of quantum circuits that solve these estimation problems. One of the main challenges is the use of costly and restrictive arithmetic that must be implemented within the quantum circuit. In this paper, we propose using Quantum Singular Value Transformation (QSVT) to significantly reduce the cost of implementing the state preparation operator, which underlies QAE for credit risk analysis. We also present an end-to-end code implementation and the results of a simulation study to validate the proposed approach and demonstrate its benefits.

title: Analyzing Student Engagement in Online Learning: A Clickstream-based Approach to Measuring Cognitive Presence
authors: B. Moganapriya, F. Mary Harin Fernandez
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Cognitive presence measurement is still extremely difficult in online educational environments because of the lack of automation, scale, and timeliness in measurement techniques. This project aims to combine discourse semantics and student interaction behavior in developing a strong dual-modality system to reliably infer cognitive presence. The proposed method employs a Hidden Markov Model (HMM) to simulate sequential patterns of behavior that are learned from discrete clickstream data. The Community of Inquiry model categorizes asynchronous forum discussion into cognitive presence stages by applying a BERT-based transformer model. To output an overall, time-varying cognitive presence profile, a Bayesian fusion method combines the probability of semantic classes with stages of behavior across time. To confirm the experiment, a Massive open online course (MOOC) was adopted, which contained over 1.2 million click activities and 15,000 message in the forum. The approach outperforms both baseline and unimodal methods, obtaining a macro-F1 measure of 96.2% and a stable correlation with academic performance (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.81). Temporal trajectory analysis showed that there were significant shifts in the cognitive stages of learners, which were aligned with their patterns of success.

title: Secure and Efficient Urban Parking Solution: A Blockchain-Integrated Smart Parking Management System
authors: S A Kalaiselvan, R. Kesavan, V.Sivaraman, K.T.Anand, C.Jehan, S.Sangeetha
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: In increasing limited space and congestion, the parking vehicle management is important in the smart cities. The existing method often fails in smart parking solutions such as security, and energy efficiency. The suggested Smart Parking Management System enhances user experience, security, and parking efficiency in order to address this issue. This proposed system begins with registering and authenticating the user via mobile app and user accounts are secured. To analyse the real-time availability of spaces, the sensors in the parking zone employed to found the whether the spaces or occupied or available. Before sending the collected sensor data to the cloud for safe blockchain storage, it first pre-processed to remove irrelevant information. Afterthought, booking the parking area the smart contracts is taken care of payments for ensuring the smooth transaction process. Flowingly, parking assignments using dynamic space allocation algorithms using Reinforcement methods based on the past data and user behavior. The user data protection and unauthorised used activity is detected using federated learning method and multi-factor security methods. Users get notifications when spots become available, and the system continuously learns to enhance the upcoming parking experiences. The advanced smart parking management system gradually improves the user satisfaction. Overall this innovative method surpasses the existing methods in the light of effectiveness, security, and a sustainable urban environment.

title: CluE: Cluster, Sample & Eliminate - Bayesian Block Elimination for Pure-Exploration with Non-binary Rewards and Limited Budget
authors: Shameem A Puthiya Parambath, Wenhao Li, Christos Anagnostopoulos, Dimitris Korobilis
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: We introduce CluE (Cluster, Sample & Eliminate), a novel approach tailored for pure-exploration bandit problems with limited budget. Several problems in machine learning, including dynamic pricing and dynamic model pruning are conceptualized as pure-exploration dynamic assignment problems constrained by budgets. Given a high-dimensional action space and exploration budget, CluE operates by first discretizing the action space into a manageable set of discrete actions and then clustering these actions. The algorithm proceeds in phases, selectively sampling from the most promising cluster and refining choices to the optimal action within that cluster. Suboptimal clusters are eliminated at the end of each phase based on confidence bounds estimates. We have conducted extensive testing in federated learning and logistics, demonstrating that CluE substantially lowers the misidentification probability compared to leading elimination-based algorithms in pure-exploration settings.

title: Open Failure Localization of Advanced Packaging by Terahertz Time Domain Reflectometer
authors: Xuanlong Chen, Weili Li, Gaoming Shi, Guanghui He, Lili Ma, Chao Li, Xiao Luo, Xiaoling Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: As the high interconnect density package develops fast and the feature size scaling, the resolution of conventional TDR is not sufficient for fault localization. To solve the issue, optoelectronic sampling terahertz TDR or EOTPR is introduced with a spatial resolution of 5 µm, makes it possible to distinguish faults in microbump, TSV, C4 bump, organic substrate, etc. Open reference sample of 2.5D package integrating SoC processer and HBM was investigated by terahertz TDR, the results demonstrate that time of flight for 35 µm microbump is on the order of 0.2ps, TSV and C4 bump can also be distinguished. Real case study of FCBGA and stacked die packaged BGA shows terahertz TDR is a powerful tool for failure localization.

title: Efficient Fine-tuning of Large Models under 4GB VRAM with Power-saving Strategies
authors: Dong Dong, Mingshu Zhai, Hui Zeng, Chengzhang Wu, Jidong Zhai
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: The rapid advancement of large-scale artificial intelligence models has substantially propelled the progress in technologies such as natural language processing and computer vision. However, when it comes to deploying these models onto edge devices with constrained memory and the necessity for continuous learning, challenges in model fine-tuning and performance optimization emerge. In response to this, this paper proposes a lightweight multi-objective resource tradeoff optimization strategy. This approach employs a dual-mode optimization of unit cache optimality and unit energy optimality to refine the paging structure subject to fine-tuning, freeze a fraction of weights at a fine granularity, and devises an adaptive pipeline parallel method tailored to the big.LITTLE architecture of edge devices. Experimental results demonstrate that this method effectively and stably updates weights within the end-side hardware under limited memory and power supply conditions, thus presenting a viable and efficient solution for fine-tuning large models on edge devices with a video memory of merely 4 GB or less.

title: Balancing Efficiency and Accuracy in Intrusion Detection: Systematic Feature Reduction with PCA and SHAP
authors: Aditya Mote, Anup Ingle, Ketki P. Kshirsagar, Rameez Shamalik, Gajanan Vishwanath Ghuge, Arati V. Deshpande
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: This study quantifies how systematic feature reduction affects detection quality and computational cost for three tree-based classifiers (Decision Tree, Random Forest, and XGBoost) on the NSL-KDD intrusion-detection benchmark. Principal Component Analysis and SHAP-based feature ranking were applied to produce subsets of 30, 20, 15, 10, 5, and 3 features from the original 41. For each subset, models were optimized using Optuna and evaluated on training time, prediction latency, accuracy, and weighted F1 score. Results indicate that XGBoost sustains the greatest robustness under aggressive reduction: an F1 of 0.9962 with all features and 0.9700 with only three features, while achieving approximately a 70 percent reduction in training time at extreme reduction levels. Decision Tree exhibited the lowest inference latency but experienced larger performance loss below ten features. Random Forest maintained competitive F1 values but incurred substantially higher training overhead at moderate to high dimensions. These findings provide guidance for deploying intrusion-detection models in resource-constrained settings, highlighting trade-offs between detection fidelity and computational burden and informing choices for real-time monitoring applications.

title: PDF Extraction Chatbot using Transformers
authors: V.P. Ramakrishna, Naveen C, A.Yovan Felix, G Revathy
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Findings show how system lets users find necessary details in uploaded PDF documents through effective performance. System leverages NLP methods with FAISS search and modern embedding technology to deliver accurate results to user inquiries. The process begins by using PyMuPDF to get text from PDF documents then adds Tesseract OCR to decode images or scans. SentenceTransformer transforms documents into sentences before using deep learning models to understand their meaning. The system creates a FAISS index to store embeddings and does quick comparisons between huge datasets. Users enter their search terms through simple platform and system returns text selections that best match their query. People find the project easy to use because they can upload PDFs and enter their search terms using basic Streamlit interface. System turns static PDF documents into an interactive knowledge base that makes data easier for users to access. The platform handles various document tasks including academic research and business analytics due to its integrated machine learning and natural language processing tools plus simple user interface. System combines NLP technology with PyMuPDF to process text and OCR to extract information. It also uses Sentence Transformer and FAISS.

title: Koopman-Based Control for Constant Power Loads
authors: Vladimir Toro, Duvan Tellez-Castro
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: This paper proposes a data-driven control strategy based on the Koopman operator for a direct current generator that supplies a constant power load through an RLC transmission line. The output voltage dynamics of the system are governed by a nonlinear differential equation that exhibits three distinct equilibrium points. To address the inherent nonlinearity, the system dynamics are lifted into a higher-dimensional linear space using the extended dynamic mode decomposition algorithm. A model predictive control strategy is then designed based on this linear predictor. The Koopman-based framework enables eigenvalue analysis of the lifted state matrix, providing deeper insights into system behavior. Simulation results show that the proposed controller achieves effective regulation compared to a nonlinear controller, while reducing computational effort.

title: Deep Learning-Based Inverse Design of Electromagnetic Metamaterials
authors: Miao Guo, Jiayi Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Electromagnetic metamaterials, endowed with subwavelength structures that grant them exceptional electromagnetic modulation capabilities, have been widely applied in fields such as antenna design, radar stealth, and terahertz devices. Traditional design methods, which rely heavily on repeated iterations of numerical simulations and expert experience, suffer from low efficiency and inadequate precision. To address this limitation, this paper proposes a high-precision inverse design model, MMFR-Net. By integrating image data and numerical data, the model leverages a cross-modal attention mechanism and gated multimodal units to achieve effective information fusion, thereby significantly reducing errors. Experimental results demonstrate that MMFR-Net outperforms conventional methods in prediction accuracy, with the average error controlled below 5%. Four sets of simulation validations further confirm the model' s effectiveness and physical feasibility. In conclusion, MMFR-Net markedly improves the precision of metamaterial inverse design through multimodal fusion, providing an efficient and accurate modeling approach for the intelligent design of metamaterials.

title: Performance and Sensitivity of Replicator Dynamics in the Optimization of Interconnected Microgrids
authors: Sara Melo, Germán Obando, Andrés Pantoja
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: Replicator Dynamics (RD), a class of evolutionary game theory algorithm, offer a promising avenue for distributed optimal power dispatch in Interconnected Microgrids (IMGs). The practical efficacy of RD is linked to the tuning of its operational parameters. This paper presents a comprehensive performance evaluation focusing on the sensitivity of an RDbased dispatch algorithm to its key parameters: the penalty coefficients associated with the barrier functions used to enforce system constraints, and the gain that modifies the velocity of the dynamics. Through simulations on a modified IEEE 30-bus and 7 -microgrid test systems, we analyze the trade-offs associated with parameter selection, benchmarking against a centralized quadratic programming approach. We provide detailed insights into identifying effective parameter ranges, quantifying their influence on solution accuracy, constraint adherence, convergence speed, and overall computational efficiency. Scalability assessments up to 75 IMGs further underscore the algorithm's robustness and computational advantages when parameters are properly selected, offering a guidance for real-world implementation.

title: Higher-Order Portfolio Optimization with Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm
authors: Valter Uotila, Julia Ripatti, Bo Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Portfolio optimization is one of the most studied optimization problems at the intersection of quantum computing and finance. In this work, we develop the first quantum formulation for a portfolio optimization problem with higherorder moments, skewness and kurtosis. Including higher-order moments leads to more detailed modeling of portfolio return distributions. Portfolio optimization with higher-order moments has been studied in classical portfolio optimization approaches but with limited exploration within quantum formulations. In the context of quantum optimization, higher-order moments generate higher-order terms in the cost Hamiltonian. Thus, instead of obtaining a quadratic unconstrained binary optimization problem, we obtain a higher-order unconstrained binary optimization (HUBO) problem, which has a natural formulation as a parametrized circuit. Additionally, we employ realistic integer variable encoding and a capital-based budget constraint. We consider the classical continuous variable solution with integer programming-based discretization to be the computationally efficient classical baseline for the problem. Our extensive experimental evaluation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0}$</tex> portfolio optimization problems shows that the solutions to the HUBO formulation often correspond to better portfolio allocations than the classical baseline. This is a promising result for those who want to perform computationally challenging portfolio optimization on quantum hardware, as portfolio optimization with higher moments is classically complex. Moreover, the experimental evaluation studies QAOA's performance with higher-order terms in this practically relevant problem.

title: LD3DGS-SLAM: Long-Distance Monocular SLAM with 3D Gaussian Splatting and GNSS-Aided Localization for UAVs
authors: Dongdong Li, Tao Yang, Yilin Wang, Haidong Qin, Shixiong Fan, Shuanghan Zhang, Yidan Zhang, Jing Li
abstract: Integrating neural rendering with simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) has shown great promise for achieving high-precision localization and photorealistic scene reconstruction. However, the dynamic perspectives of uncrewed aerial vehicles (UAVs), compounded by Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) signal interference and the accumulation of localization errors, pose significant challenges to existing monocular simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) methods in complex environments. To address these limitations, we propose LD3DGS-SLAM, a novel framework that integrates monocular SLAM, GNSS, and 3D Gaussian splatting (3DGS) [1] to enhance UAV-based localization and mapping. The system integrates traditional geometric feature-based localization with the multiview synthesis capability of 3D Gaussian rendering, achieving a breakthrough in accuracy while enhancing robustness. First, we construct a multisensor fusion graph optimization model that tightly integrates GNSS and monocular vision data, effectively mitigating the cumulative drift typical of traditional SLAM pipelines. Afterward, we introduce a 3D Gaussian-based mapping strategy that incrementally refines a dense scene representation using SLAM-generated point clouds, fusing geometric and texture information to reconstruct highly accurate and detailed maps. To further enhance localization performance in GNSS-denied scenarios, we develop a dynamic frame interpolation and tracking approach based on 3D Gaussian rendering. By synthesizing novel viewpoints, this method improves observation matching and strengthens loop closure detection, enabling robust relocalization in large-scale environments. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed framework, we implement a UAV test system and evaluate its performance on both the publicly available TUM [2] dataset and a self-collected aerial dataset spanning several kilometers. Experimental results show that LD3DGS-SLAM achieves a state-of-the-art average localization error of only 0.8 meters using just a monocular camera, even during long-range flight missions exceeding tens of kilometers and altitudes up to 500 meters. Overall, LD3DGS-SLAM effectively addresses the limitations of monocular SLAM in aerial scenarios, providing a robust, accurate, and cost-effective localization solution for urban air mobility and aerial Internet of Things (IoT) applications.

title: Relative Entropy-based Training of Quantum Neural Networks
authors: Subhadeep Mondal, Amit Kumar Dutta
abstract: Quantum neural networks (QNNs) are gaining attention as versatile models for quantum machine learning, but training them effectively remains a challenge. Most existing approaches, such as quantum multi-layer perceptrons (MLPs), use fidelity-based cost functions. While well-suited for pure states, these measures are less reliable when inputs and outputs are mixed states—a situation common in learning quantum channels. In this work, we introduce a training framework built on a relative entropyinspired cost function. By quantifying the directional divergence between learned and target states, relative entropy provides a more informative and principled measure than linear fidelity, naturally capturing both spectral and eigenvector differences in mixed states. This approach preserves the completely positive (CP) structure of the network, supports efficient back-propagation in layered QNN configurations, and achieves improved accuracy and convergence over fidelity-based training. These results highlight entropy-based optimization as a promising path toward scalable, robust, and noise-resilient quantum learning.

title: Lightweight and Efficient Authentication Scheme for Secure Intra/Inter-Domain Communications in the Internet of Drones
authors: Xi Chen, Chunqiang Hu, Hui Xia, Pengfei Hu, Jiguo Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: With the widespread adoption of the Internet of Drones (IoD) in sectors such as logistics, power, and agriculture, its impact is steadily extending to economic, social, and technological domains, thereby accelerating the development of the low-altitude economy and low-altitude networking. However, in these application scenarios, a large volume of sensitive data must be transmitted over open or insecure wireless channels, exposing IoD to severe security and privacy threats, including key leakage, identity forgery, and physical tampering attacks. Moreover, the inherent limitations of drones in terms of computational and communication resources render conventional security mechanisms based on computationally expensive public-key cryptography impractical for low-altitude networking environments. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a lightweight and efficient intra/inter-domain authentication scheme tailored for low-altitude networks. The proposed scheme integrates fractional-order Chebyshev chaotic maps, physically unclonable functions with error-correcting code, and hash functions to achieve mutual authentication and session key establishment within a domain. Furthermore, a proxy-based credential conversion mechanism is introduced to enhance inter-domain authentication efficiency while significantly reducing the storage burden on drones. Security analysis demonstrates that the scheme can withstand various common attacks, while performance evaluation further validates its advantages in reducing computational and communication overhead.

title: Design Optimization of a Spoke-Type Permanent Magnet Motor for Torque Performance Improvement
authors: Kang Ma, Ye Liu, Zhuoran Zhang, Zhaoxu Zhu, Haitao Wang
abstract: This paper introduces an optimized spoke-type interior permanent magnet (IPM) motor featuring a flux-concentrating rotor, which can be used to reduce leakage magnetic flux and increase efficiency. The output torque is increased by improved PM utilization ratio. Then, an improved Taguchi iterative optimization method coupled with finite element analysis (FEA) is applied to optimize structural parameters by rationally narrowing the range of variables. Compared to the initial spoke-type and U-type motors, the optimal flux-concentrating motor can obtain higher airgap flux-density in main flux path without additional magnet material usage. This is made possible by elevation of working point of the PMs and reduction of the PM leakage magnetic flux. In addition, a comprehensive analysis of the optimal motor, including open-circuit characteristics, load characteristics, temperature distribution, and mechanical integrity, has been carried out to validate the rationality of the optimal scheme. The results show that the proposed scheme can increase the output torque by up to 25% and the efficiency by 1% with a fairly small raise in torque ripple. Finally, two 3000r/min 10 kW prototypes are fabricated to validate the superiority of the proposed design.

title: Distributed Privacy-Preserving Reinforcement Learning via Sparse Matrix Encryption for IoT
authors: Tong Ji, Yanjie Liang, Yunting Tao, Fanyu Kong, Chunpeng Ge, Baodong Qin, Jia Yu
abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) has been increasingly adopted in IoT systems for tasks such as resource allocation and control. However, in privacy-critical and resource-constrained environments, existing privacy-preserving RL schemes suffer from high computational cost, slow convergence, and limited scalability due to the use of homomorphic encryption or differential privacy. We propose a distributed privacy-preserving Q-learning framework that enables secure and efficient policy updates across multiple clients. Each client independently trains a local Q-table and encrypts it using a sparse matrix transformation combined with additive secret sharing of structured perturbations. The encrypted Q-tables are uploaded to a cloud server for aggregation and averaging without decryption. The encrypted global Q-table is then returned and decrypted locally using the inverse sparse matrix. Experimental results on four benchmark environments (CartPole-v1, MountainCar-v0, Acrobot-v1, and LunarLander-v3) show that our scheme achieves up to 92% reduction in computation time compared to the FHE-based method, while maintaining comparable reward performance and faster convergence.

title: The complete weight distribution of a family of irreducible cyclic codes of dimension two
authors: Gerardo Vega, Félix Hernández
abstract: An important family of codes for data storage systems, cryptography, consumer electronics, and network coding for error control in digital communications are the so-called cyclic codes. This kind of linear codes are also important due to their efficient encoding and decoding algorithms. Because of this, cyclic codes have been studied for many years, however their complete weight distributions are known only for a few cases. The complete weight distribution has a wide range of applications in many research fields as the information it contains is of vital use in practical applications. Unfortunately, obtaining these distributions is in general a very hard problem that normally involves the evaluation of sophisticated exponential sums, which leaves this problem open for most of the cyclic codes. In this paper we determine, for any finite field IFq, the explicit factorization of any polynomial of the form xq+1-c, where c ∈ IFq*. Then we use this result to obtain, without the need to evaluate any kind of exponential sum, the complete weight distributions of a family of irreducible cyclic codes of dimension two over any finite field. As an application of our findings, we employ the complete weight distributions of some irreducible cyclic codes presented here to construct systematic authentication codes, showing that they are optimal or almost optimal.

title: PerCE: Hierarchical Perturbation-Based Counterfactual Explanations for Multivariate Time Series Classification
authors: Betül Bayrak, Kerstin Bach
abstract: Counterfactual explanations provide intuitive insights into AI model decisions by showing minimal changes needed to alter predictions. However, generating plausible counterfactuals for multivariate time series remains challenging due to complex temporal dependencies, inter-channel correlations, and the need to preserve physiologically realistic patterns, particularly in safety-critical domains like healthcare. This paper presents a novel framework for generating plausible counterfactual explanations for multivariate time series classification, demonstrated on 12-lead ECG data. Our approach employs a hierarchical perturbation strategy guided by permutation-based feature importance, operating at both segment and channel levels to handle temporal dependencies and channel correlations inherent in time series. By anchoring counterfactuals to existing instances from the target class, we enrich plausibility while maintaining minimal modifications. Our evaluation demonstrates significant improvements over the baseline method: 98% validity (vs. 65%), 43% reduction in required modifications, and 75% improvement in proximity to original instances. This work contributes: (I) a perturbation-based explanation approach combining instance-based and importance-guided generation for time series, (II) comprehensive evaluation metrics tailored for multivariate time series, and (III) empirical validation on medical data where interpretability is crucial for clinical adoption.

title: CO2 (Co-Compliance Officer): An LLM-based Ontology-Driven Methodology for Generating Knowledge Graphs and AI Compliance Checking
authors: Venkata Sai Prathyush Turaga, Timea Pahi, Simon Tjoa, Sima Siami-Namini, Akbar Siami Namin
abstract: With the advent of Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology and immense transitions to industry, it is important to regulate and establish standards for this fascinating technology. As a result, AI-powered applications need to be checked for compliance with AI regulations. Although compliance checks have been extensively discussed by the research community and industry, AI compliance checks and verification still need to be explored, and pitfalls need to be identified. This paper aims at automating the extraction of AI regulations using the knowledge graph and the ontology defined for legal documents. The paper first reports the initial effort to create knowledge graphs for legal documents (e.g., the EU AI Act) using different language models trained in general textual documents where general approaches in extracting Named-Entity Recognition (NER) are employed. Triplets in the form of <Subject-Predicate-Object> are extracted followed by enhancement achieved through augmenting NER tags by information captured using dependency parsers. The paper then presents a methodology called Co-Compliance Officer (CO2) where Large Language Models (LLMs) are employed to build knowledge graphs and NER which are solely for parsing and extracting legal documents. The LLM ontology is then used to create effective tags that are specifically designed to extract legal documents and the relationships between legal entities. The created knowledge graphs are then used to perform several verification analysis on legal documents, including inconsistency checks and violations. The results indicate that Large Language Models (LLMs) can be helpful in compliance checking of legal documents, in particular, the documents created for AI compliance checking.

abstract: It is our great pleasure to introduce the workshops held in conjunction with the 36th IEEE International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering ISSRE 2025. Workshops have long been an integral part of ISSRE, offering an interactive forum for presenting early-stage research, discussing emerging challenges, and fostering collaboration across academia, industry, and government.

authors: N/A
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: IEEE Quantum Week 2025 Workshops provide forums for group (i.e., 20-50 participants) discussions on QCE25 topics in quantum research, practice, education, and applications. Workshops provide opportunities for researchers, practitioners, scientists, engineers, entrepreneurs, developers, students, educators, programmers, and newcomers to exchange and discuss scientific and engineering ideas early before they have matured to warrant a conference or journal publication. In this manner, an IEEE Quantum Week workshop serves as a forum for common interests or as an incubator for a scientific community to form a research roadmap or share a research agenda. Workshops are the key to sustaining, growing, and evolving IEEE Quantum Week in the future. Note: IEEE Quantum Week is a multidisciplinary quantum computing venue.

title: Spatial Hierarchical Protein-Protein Interaction Site Prediction Using Squeeze-and-Excitation Capsule Networks
authors: Weipeng Lv, Changkun Jiang, Jianqiang Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: The discovery of protein-protein interaction (PPI) sites is vital for exploring the principles of PPIs. Developing computational approaches to predict PPI sites can effectively compensate for biological experiments, which are mostly time-consuming and vulnerable-to-noise. In recent years, deep learning has been used to predict PPI sites, by considering the contextual information of target amino acid residues and using a local protein sequence to represent the targets. However, traditional deep-learning techniques, e.g., DNNs and CNNs, disregard important spatial hierarchies contained in the features of protein sequences, leading to their failure to effectively distinguish interaction sites from different residue regions. In this work, we design MSE-CapsPPISP, a new deep-learning model to address PPI site prediction with spatial hierarchies. The key idea of MSE-CapsPPISP is to take into account the hierarchical relationships between the features of protein sequences. We characterize the hierarchical relationships by designing a tailored Capsule Network, which is a novel type of neural network with vector neurons. Moreover, to make the network representation more robust, MSE-CapsPPISP uses multi-scale CNNs to extract multi-scale features of protein sequences and Squeeze-and-Excitation blocks to recalibrate the features. The validation results show that MSE-CapsPPISP outperforms the baseline CNNs-based architecture DeepPPISP and other existing competing schemes in the four key metrics of F1, MCC, AUROC, and AUPR.

title: Insider's Guide to Advocating for K-12 Quantum Science
authors: Mark Newburn
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Many advocates of quantum science hope to build a quantum-aware workforce by introducing quantum science concepts at the pre-college level. Formal K-12 education systems operate under a complex set of policies, rules, and even laws that can create significant barriers to entry. Quantum advocates will need to adopt strategies successfully used by advocates of other STEM content to gain entry into K-12 education. This talk will provide some background on how formal K-12 systems determine which content gets taught during the limited minutes of a school day. Next, I will present possible strategies for incorporating quantum science into both informal and formal K-12 education. Finally, I will cover recent progress in integrating quantum computing into new college and K-12 computer science frameworks, academic standards, and curriculum guides.)
