title: A Comprehensive Review of Students' Wellbeing in Engineering Education
authors: Sachin Batra, Sushma Shekhar Kulkarni
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: Engineering education is characterized by high academic demands, intense workloads, and rigid pedagogical structures, often leading to significant stress and reduced wellbeing among students. This systematic review synthesizes empirical research from 45 scholarly studies published between 2014 and 2024, focusing on the multifaceted nature of student wellbeing in engineering programs. Using the PRISMA 2020 framework, the review identifies five core dimensions of wellbeing namely, psychological, academic, emotional, social, and physical; and examines their antecedents (e.g., academic workload, institutional support), outcomes (e.g., academic performance, persistence), and mediating/moderating variables (e.g., self-efficacy, coping strategies, mindfulness, social support). Theoretical models including Self Determination theory, the Job Demands-Resources model, Conservation of Resources theory, Theory of Planned Behavior, and the Transactional Model of Stress underpin several studies, though nearly half articles lacked explicit theoretical grounding. The findings reveal critical gaps in longitudinal analysis, theoretical integration, and institutional policy assessment. A conceptual framework is proposed to guide future research and inform educational policy and practice. The review highlights the urgent need to integrate wellbeing into engineering education, aiming to support students' overall growth and academic success

title: A Quantum Approach for Optimal Transient Control in Network-Based Epidemic Models
authors: Deborah Volpe, Giacomo Orlandi, Mattia Boggio, Carlo Novara, Lorenzo Zino, Giovanna Turvani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Effective epidemic control is crucial for mitigating the spread of infectious diseases, particularly when pharmaceutical interventions such as vaccines or treatments are limited. Nonpharmaceutical strategies, including mobility restrictions, are key in reducing transmission rates but require careful optimization to balance public health benefits and socioeconomic costs. Quantum computing is emerging as a powerful tool for solving complex optimization problems that are intractable for classical methods and can thus be leveraged to handle mobility restrictions. This article presents a new approach to optimizing epidemic control strategies using quantum computing techniques. We focus on non-pharmaceutical interventions, particularly mobility restriction, modeled as a discrete-time network epidemic process based on the susceptible-infected-susceptible and sus-ceptible-infected-removed frameworks. The control problem is formulated as a combinatorial optimization task, inherently NPhard due to the binary nature of intervention decisions. To tackle this computational complexity, we derive a Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization representation of the control problem, enabling its efficient solution via quantum computing resources. Our methodology is validated through numerical simulations on realistic case studies, showcasing the potential of quantum algorithms for enhancing epidemic control strategies. These findings pave the way for leveraging quantum optimization in broader applications of networked dynamical systems, demonstrating its viability for complex decision-making processes in public health management.

title: Qwerty: A Basis-Oriented Quantum Programming Language
authors: Austin J. Adams, Sharjeel Khan, Arjun S. Bhamra, Ryan R. Abusaada, Travis S. Humble, Jeffrey S. Young, Thomas M. Conte
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum computers have leaped from the theoretical realm into a race to large-scale implementations. This is due to the promise of revolutionary speedups, where achieving such speedup requires designing an algorithm that harnesses the structure of a problem using quantum mechanics. Yet many quantum programming languages today require programmers to reason at a low level of physics notation and quantum gate circuitry. This presents a significant barrier to entry for programmers who have not yet built up an intuition about quantum gate semantics, and it can prove to be tedious even for those who have. In this paper, we present Qwerty, a new quantum programming language that allows programmers to manipulate qubits more expressively than gates and trace programs without bra-ket notation. Due to its novel basis type and easy interoperability with Python, Qwerty is a powerful framework for high-level quantum-classical computation.

title: The Influence of Cognitive Bias in Social Media Marketing on Consumer Buying Behavior
authors: Sudheer Nandi, Preetha Subrahmanyan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: This paper presents the Bias-Driven Marketing Influence Framework (BDMIF), for the analysis of the influence of social proof, scarcity and anchor biases on consumers’ decisions. A survey with 500 users of social media as our population indicated that $80 \%$ of them were served with social proof strategies and results from PLS-SEM indicated that [there was] a $65 \%$ improvement on the purchase intention brought about by scarcity strategies. Anchoring biases forced up sales of high-priced products by $42 \%$ - a perfect testimony of the influence of psychological cues. But this created issues of transparency and trust as potential ethical issues for commerce. Therefore, the studies bring out the need to increase the effectiveness of marketing as well as maintaining ethical practice. Specific suggestions are given on how to create relevant responsible and bias conscious campaigns and that they should avoid the misuse of psychological appeals when implementing digital marketing strategies.

title: Project-based Learning and the CDIO Syllabus to Connect Materials Science Classes with Real-world Applications
authors: Joseph A. Bozo, John Lino Ávila, Jenefer Díaz, Alexis Tejedor De León
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: This paper provides an overview of the promotion of hard and soft skills through curriculum planning for Materials Science, using the CDIO (Conceiving-Designing-Implementing-Operation Processes) as criteria. This planning has as a common denominator that engineering students, in their academic and professional training, must be able to operate authentic engineering project systems to connect what is discussed in the classroom with its connection to the specific needs of the external world. The Materials Science course plays a fundamental role in the development of new agro-industrial products for the aquaculture industry, taking the Panamanian context as a reference, for example. On the one hand, and on the other, there is a need to consider the growing focus on sustainability, so that students can research, develop, and propose new products that reduce the environmental impact of local and regional aquaculture. In this regard, this study presents the agro-industrial evaluation of mango (Mangifera indica) peels in the pellet production process for aquaculture. Pellets were used to feed Gray Tilapia (Oreocrhomis niloticus) fingerlings for over a month. It is worth noting that when discussing environmental issues in the classroom, we students were able to conduct tests and analyses, which was crucial to ensuring the safety and efficacy of the developed product. This also allowed us to assist in the optimization of production processes in the aquaculture industry, ranging from raw material selection to process design aimed at minimizing waste and maximizing efficiency. This participatory approach, which brings together the internal and external aspects of the classroom, allowed us to interact with potential project beneficiaries, as well as with other projects and research groups, such as the 2023 Ibero-American Researchers' Night organized by the Organization of Ibero-American States, where we were able to share the main findings, opportunities, and challenges with the participating community. In short, Materials Science provides a solid foundation for addressing challenges and opportunities, such as the aquaculture industry, giving students opportunity to contribute to the development of new, more efficient and sustainable agro-industrial products. Given the results obtained in the manufacturing process of this potential alternative feed for aquaculture species, and considering the maintenance of fry fed exclusively with the same feed, it is necessary to continue this project from a scalability and funding perspective.

title: Ethics by Design: Integrating Moral Frameworks in the Digital Age
authors: Devesh Kumar, Ankush Choudhary, Kundan, Akshay Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: This paper examines how six ethical frame-works—Utilitarianism, Deontological Ethics, Virtue Ethics, Care Ethics, Social Contract Theory, and Pragmatic Ethics—address emerging challenges in AI and digital technologies. The analysis reveals that effective ethical governance requires an integrated approach combining multiple frameworks: deontological principles establish boundaries, utilitarian considerations guide optimization within these constraints, and virtue ethics provides contextual wisdom for implementation. Through systematic evaluation across AI development, privacy protection, and platform governance, the research demonstrates that while individual frameworks offer valuable perspectives, an integrated approach better addresses complex technological challenges. This research provides practical guidelines for developing responsible AI systems and governance frameworks, emphasizing the importance of cultural sensitivity and adaptive implementation in technological ethics.

title: Is Circuit Cutting Scalable for Practical Quantum Applications?
authors: Songqinghao Yang, Prakash Murali
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Circuit cutting allows quantum circuits larger than the available hardware to be executed. Cutting techniques split circuits into smaller subcircuits, run them on the hardware, and recombine results through classical post-processing. Circuit cutting techniques have been extensively researched over the last five years and it been adopted by quantum companies, like IBM, as part of their scaling roadmap. We examine whether current circuit cutting techniques are practical for orchestrating executions on fault-tolerant quantum computers. We conduct a resource estimation-based benchmarking of important quantum applications and different types of circuit cutting techniques. Our applications include practically relevant algorithms such as Hamiltonian simulation, kernels such as quantum Fourier transform and more. To cut these applications, we use IBM's Qiskit cutting tool. We estimate resources for subcircuits using Microsoft's Azure Quantum Resource Estimator and develop models to determine qubit counts and the quantum and classical runtime needs of circuit cutting. We demonstrate that while circuit cutting works for small-scale systems, the exponential growth of the quantum excution runtime and the classical post-processing overhead as the qubit count increases renders it impractical for larger quantum systems with current implementation strategies. As we transition from noisy quantum hardware to fault-tolerance, our work provides useful guidance for the design of quantum software and runtime systems.

title: Integrated Airbag for Motorcycles
authors: Manikandan J, Mangaiyarkarasi V, Sheik Mukthar P, Harissh M, Naveen M
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Motorcycle or two-wheeler riders are mostly vulnerable to severe injuries during accidents as compared to four-wheeler users due to the lack of physical protection. The goal of this project is to create an integrated airbag system that will increase rider safety by quickly inflating an airbag when it detects a collision. In order to detect abrupt deceleration, skidding, or tipping, the system makes use of an MPU6050 sensor module, which continuously measures acceleration and angular velocity and also ultrasonic sensors to detect the object nearby. Sensor data is processed by the Arduino Uno microcontroller, which then compares it to the predetermined threshold. Within milliseconds of detecting a crash, the microprocessor sends a signal to a relay-controlled CO₂ inflator, which inflates the airbag and reduces impact injuries by acting as a cushion. A Li-Po battery powers the system, allowing it to function independently even when there are power outages. For powering Arduino we use a power adapter. The main objective of this project is to achieve a minimum severity during an accident of a two-wheeler.

title: Secure Data Search in Edge Computing using Deep Learning
authors: B S Anupama, N R Sunitha, N B Ashuthosh, B L Sechan, R Sneha, Mohammed Ajmal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: In today’s rapidly evolving business landscape, imperative for technological innovation and advancements in knowledge production is indisputable. Our proposed work addresses this critical need by focusing on enhancing data privacy and operational efficiency within business environments. Delved into data security measures to mitigate risks associated with handling sensitive information in systems, safeguarding user data on edge servers, and optimizing search engine performance for non-intrusive applications like Internet of Things and time-sensitive operations. Primary objective is to leverage edge computing to establish secure data mining, harness edge storage for swift responses, and minimize latency, particularly crucial for processing time-sensitive data. Through testing, we transferred 100 files to both cloud and edge devices, revealing superior performance by edge device. For instance, transfer time for a single file was a mere 0.004 seconds on edge compared to 1 second on cloud. Our work seamlessly integrates cloud, edge, and data creation components. Utilizing facial recognition data comprising 100 encrypted images stored on edge devices, our system efficiently processes user requests. End-to-end encrypted data transmission occurs, with the cloud handling search queries sent to the edge, which houses the encrypted data. Results are sent to clouds after decryption, guaranteeing improved technological progress through data security and search effectiveness. Our strategy, which combines secure connection protocols, client-based search engines, and encryption methods, emphasizes how important our application is to advancing technology.

title: NeuroFusion: A Hybrid CNN and Cuckoo Search Model for Enhanced Alzheimer’s Disease Detection
authors: D. Roja Ramani, Lakshmi, Santhosh Krishna B V, Chempavathy B, Bhaskar S V, Soja Rani S
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by deficiencies in memory and cognitive function, and primarily afflicts aging individuals. It is difficult to detect early due to the result of less sensitive nature of traditional imaging methods. This paper introduces NeuroFusion, a new hybrid model of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Cuckoo search Optimization (CSO) for enhancing the accuracy of AD detection based on MRI data. There are several well-known design issues with CNNs: they are naturally prone to overfit and it is difficult to find good hyperparameters. Tackle these problems in NeuroFusion by utilizing CSO to fine-tune hyperparameters (e.g., learning rate, kernel size, dropout rates) via bio-inspired stochastic search State-Of-the-art accuracy (96.52%) on the ADNI dataset is reported for the model, surpassing the traditional CNNs (92%) and machine learning methods (e.g., SVM: 83%). It is also highly interpretable in the clinical context by integrating explainable AI (XAI) methods.

title: Exploring Beamforming Solutions Using Recursive Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm
authors: Bidisha Dhara, Monika Agrawal, Sumantra Dutta Roy
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) is a promising quantum algorithm for solving combinatorial optimization problems. In this work, we explore the Recursive QAOA (RQAOA) approach, which improves upon the standard QAOA by successively reducing the problem size, to optimize sensor configuration for beamforming with the objective of maximizing the Signal-to-Interference-plus-Noise Ratio (SINR). We present a series of experiments across various setups, including different numbers of sensors and a range of optimizers. Additionally, we compare the obtained SINR with the maximum achievable SINR to assess the efficiency of the algorithm.

title: Spatially Varying IR Leakage Estimation and Removal for RGB-IR Imaging
authors: Katarina Tolja, Donik Vršnak, Marko Subašić, Sven Lončarić
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Image and Signal Processing and Analysis (ISPA)
abstract: In recent years, various studies have focused on developing and refining image-processing pipelines for RGB-IR imagery. In this paper, we address a central bottleneck in such pipelines: the removal of infrared (IR) contamination from the RGB channels. The IR crosstalk leakage leads to colour degradation, desaturation, and hue shifts, especially under high IR illumination. We study the spatial characteristics of this crosstalk in controlled laboratory conditions across diverse illumination intensities, and introduce a lightweight U-Net-based convolutional model with a task-specific loss that prioritizes spatially challenging, IR-contaminated pixels. Building on the standard linear contamination hypothesis, our model predicts per-channel coefficients that can integrate with conventional ISP stages, while adapting the correction to spatial outliers such as radial vignetting and edge artefacts.

title: From PREVENTion to REACTion: Enhancing Failure Resolution in Naval Systems
authors: Maria Teresa Rossi, Leonardo Mariani, Oliviero Riganelli
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: Complex and large industrial systems often misbehave, for instance, due to wear, misuse, or faults. To cope with these incidents, it is important to timely detect their occurrences, localize the sources of the problems, and implement the appropriate countermeasures. This paper reports our experience with a state-of-the-art failure prediction method, PREVENT, and its extension with a troubleshooting module, REACT, applied to naval systems developed by Fincantieri. Our results show how to integrate anomaly detection with troubleshooting procedures. We conclude by discussing a lesson learned, which may help deploy and extend these analyses to other industrial products.

title: Deep Learning based Prediction and Classification of Periodontal Disease Through Transfer Learning with ResNet121
authors: D. Prameen, R. Dhanapal
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Dental plague leads to several bacterial diseases which includes caries (tooth decay), periodontitis (Gum diseases), tooth erosion and oral cancer. Hence detection and classification of the dental plague is becoming prevalent to maintain the dental health among healthcare professional. Among multiple dental diseases, periodontal disease is increasing its attention due to its severity among multiple peoples. Traditionally, periodontal disease is identified manually by dental professional and it leads to several challenge time consuming procedures probing force and difference among examiner. However, accurate diagnosis and classification of the disease becomes mandatory. Thus many computer vision approaches using machine learning architecture has been employed but it leads to generalization issues. To combat those challenges, a new deep learning model entitled as transfer learning architecture using pre-trained ResNet 121 model is designed to detect and classify the periodontal diseases through skip connection is designed in this article. Model is training is carried out with periodontal X-ray images dataset. Initially dataset is preprocessed using noise filtering approach, normalization approach and contrast enhancement approach to enhance the image for detection and classification process. Preprocessed image is projected to graph cut segmentation approaches for disease segmentation. Segmented regions are processed in the different layer of the ResNetarchitecture. Especially transfer learning architecture incorporates residual connections to provide learned feature to the periodontal segmented images. Those learned features is projected to the periodontal segmented images to extract the hierarchical features and represents its outcomes in form feature map. Next, feature map is employed to the fully connected layer composed of the activation function to linearize the disease feature and Softmax function uses naïve bayes classifier for periodontitis disease detection and classification and loss function uses cross entropy to reduce over fitting and underfitting issues of the model. Experimental analysis of the proposed model is performed using training data of the benchmark dataset considered as periodontal x ray dataset which is classifies the disease into stages such as early periodontitis, mild periodontitis and severe periodontitis. Model exhibits better processing capabilities compared to the conventional approaches. Further performance analysis of the model is performed using test data of the dataset on establish confusion matrix to compute the model accuracy. On those analyses, it is proved that proposed model exhibits detection and classification accuracy of 98.2% which is considered to higher that conventional approaches.

title: Comparative Study of Machine Learning-based SoC Estimation Techniques for Hardware-Integrated Li-ion Battery Management Systems
authors: Srinidhi J, Sakthimugesh Durai S, Roshni S, Harish Raghavan, Jaisiva S, Jeevitha Kandasamy
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Due to the prevalent growth of the electric vehicle (EV) technology, the lithium-ion batteries have seen a growing higher demand because they are efficient and reliable. State of Charge (SoC) estimation is of great importance in ensuring battery lifetime, safety and performance. Prior error accumulation Traditional SoC approach based on Coulomb Counting (CC) and Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) are susceptible to error buildups due to accumulating errors. The research challenge introduces a hardware integrated SoC estimation model which integrates machine learning methods, such as Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) and involves mainstream techniques. The hybrid model being proposed runs on an embedded hardware platform in order to be able to estimate in real-time with great preciseness. This integration of ANN increases flexibility to battery aging as well as other different conditions of operation and EKF introduces robustness in changing environments. MATLAB simulation and hardware verification shows that the proposed system becomes more accurate and efficient. The developed work is the contribution to battery management technologies and the expansion of EVs to the larger market due to the estimation reliability of SoC.

title: Minimum Fisher Information Fitting for Mixtures of Directional Distributions
authors: J. Cameron Helmuth, Kyle J. DeMars
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Multisensor Fusion and Integration for Intelligent Systems (MFI)
abstract: Recently, a useful approach to probability density function (PDF) fitting has been developed. The distribution is approximated as a Gaussian mixture, and the parameters are determined by minimizing the Fisher information subject to constraints derived from any known characteristics of the PDF to be approximated. The Fisher information can be evaluated in closed form by posing it in terms of square-root mixtures. This paper extends the approach to distributions on the hypersphere. A closed form expression for the Fisher information of a mixture of von Mises-Fisher distributions is derived, and the approach is demonstrated in an example.

title: AI-Powered Fruit Ripeness Detection using Color and Texture Features for Automated Sorting Systems
authors: P. Malathi, Nithishkumar R, Poodharshini R, Prabhakaran R
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Fruit ripeness must be automatically detected in agriculture to increase sorting efficiency and quality because manual and simple sensor-based approaches are slow and prone to errors. It uses advanced image processing and machine learning (ML) approaches to analyze RGB, HSV, and Lab* color and texture data; Gray-Level Co-occurrence Matrix (GLCM); and Local Binary Pattern (LBP) in regulated illumination. These features are combined to create a supervised classifier, such as a Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). On conveyor belts, quickly recognize and differentiate between various fruit maturity stages. The test's findings confirm that the proposed system performs better than both existing systems (78.2% and 85.6%), with an overall accuracy of 94.7%. The technique achieves 93.8%, 94.5%, and 94.1% precision, recall, and F1-score, and distinguishing between close ripening stages prevents classification errors. It is an efficient option for innovative agricultural quality assurance and sorting systems, as it increases automation, lowers human error, and permits flexibility for multiple fruit types.

title: Evaluating Homotopic Bayesian Conditioning for Collision Avoidance Path Planning
authors: William N. Fife, Kyle J. DeMars
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Multisensor Fusion and Integration for Intelligent Systems (MFI)
abstract: Generating dynamically feasible trajectories that avoid obstacles is a major challenge in path planning. As an alternative to traditional optimization methods, one may consider conditioning a collection of trajectories-represented as a probability density function-on a likelihood function that encodes a collision avoidance objective. This framework, developed previously, offers both a natural representation of uncertainty for robustness and does not require a dense discretization of the trajectory history near obstacles. Differing from the original implementation, this work develops a homotopic Bayesian solution to the same problem to avoid reliance on algorithmic convergence. The method is applied to a planar, spacecraft rendezvous scenario and shown to provide collision avoidant trajectories while retaining the smooth dynamical flow of the prior.

title: Learning-Based Quantum Compilation: Translating QASM to QIR with CodeBERT
authors: Sharmin Afrose, Vicente Leyton-Ortega, Travis Humble
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We propose a learning-based approach to quantum compilation by translating OpenQASM to Quantum Intermediate Representation (QIR) using a fine-tuned CodeBERT model. Trained on 10,000 synthetic QASM-QIR pairs, the model captures code semantics while addressing QIR verbosity and the 512-token limit via a custom token compression scheme. Finetuning was performed on the Frontier supercomputer, with results showing syntactic correctness and stable validation loss reduction. Our method moves toward enabling flexible, language-modeldriven quantum software tools. It also introduces syntax error handling and the possibility of incorporating classical control constructs, addressing limitations in existing rule-based compilers like qBraid-QIR. While the current model has been validated on quantum-only circuits, we propose future evaluations on hybrid quantum-classical examples. This poster will provide architecture insights, compression examples, training loss plots, and QIR outputs. Our work highlights the potential for scalable, adaptable compilation in future quantum toolchains.

title: Blockchain-Based Framework for Smart Grid Energy Trading
authors: Prateek Rath, Srichandan Sobhanayak, Anita Sahoo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Smart grids integrate IoT devices and advanced communication technologies, enabling decentralized energy trading and optimizing energy management. However, widespread adoption faces challenges related to privacy, security, transparency, and scalability, which hinder the trust and efficiency required for such systems. Blockchain technology, particularly Ethereum, offers a promising solution by providing a decentralized and immutable ledger combined with smart contract capabilities for automated, trustless transactions. This study presents a blockchain-driven framework tailored for energy trading within IoT-enabled smart grids, focusing on privacy-preserving mechanisms, secure and tamper-proof transactions, and scalable solutions to handle high-frequency trading efficiently. The proposed system includes key operational phases, such as user registration, transaction validation, and block creation, ensuring robust data integrity and trust. By leveraging Ethereum’s decentralized platform, this framework promotes real-time monitoring, automated settlements, and secure energy trading while addressing scalability challenges through hybrid blockchain models. The proposed approach not only enhances energy management efficiency but also provides a sustainable and transparent pathway for the future of decentralized energy markets.

title: Quantum Autoencoder for Multivariate Time Series Anomaly Detection
authors: Kilian Tscharke, Maximilian Wendlinger, Afrae Ahouzi, Pallavi Bhardwaj, Kaweh Amoi-Taleghani, Michael Schrödl-Baumann, Pascal Debus
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Anomaly Detection (AD) defines the task of identifying observations or events that deviate from typical - or normal - patterns, a critical capability in IT security for recognizing incidents such as system misconfigurations, malware infections, or cyberattacks. In enterprise environments like SAP HANA Cloud systems, this task often involves monitoring high-dimensional, multivariate time series (MTS) derived from telemetry and log data. With the advent of quantum machine learning offering efficient calculations in high-dimensional latent spaces, many avenues open for dealing with such complex data. One approach is the Quantum Autoencoder (QAE), an emerging and promising method with potential for application in both data compression and AD. However, prior applications of QAEs to time series AD have been restricted to univariate data, limiting their relevance for real-world enterprise systems. In this work, we introduce a novel QAE-based framework designed specifically for MTS AD towards enterprise scale. We theoretically develop and experimentally validate the architecture, demonstrating that our QAE achieves performance competitive with neural-network-based autoencoders while requiring fewer trainable parameters. We evaluate our model on datasets that closely reflect SAP system telemetry and show that the proposed QAE is a viable and efficient alternative for semisupervised AD in real-world enterprise settings.

title: A Broad Review of Machine Learning-Driven Approaches for Detecting and Mitigating Cyber Security Threats
authors: D. Ruban Thomas, C. Arul Stephen
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The increasing sophistication and volume of cyber threats pose significant challenges to traditional defense mechanisms, necessitating more adaptive and intelligent solutions. This survey critically reviews machine learning (ML)-driven approaches for cybersecurity threat detection and mitigation, focusing on the limitations of current supervised and semi-supervised methods. While effective for known attacks, these models often fail to detect zero-day exploits, struggle with high-dimensional network data, and depend heavily on labeled datasets, which are often incomplete or insecure. To address these challenges, this review explores advanced unsupervised learning techniques such as deep clustering, autoencoders, and generative adversarial networks (GANS) that can extract hidden patterns from unlabeled traffic and improve anomaly detection. The paper’s key contribution lies in identifying research gaps and proposing a novel direction: integrating unsupervised learning with federated and reinforcement learning frameworks to build scalable, privacy-preserving, and adaptive security systems. This study highlights the potential of such integration to enable proactive and resilient cyber defense mechanisms, offering a significant advancement in intelligent cybersecurity solutions.

title: Monolithic Crystal Preclinical Tomography Detector Design with Sparse SiPM Matrix
authors: Edward Mubanga, Davies Mubita, Ngula Walubita, Bibhuti Bhusan Dash, Utpal Chandra De, Sudhansu Shekhar Patra
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: PET, Positron Emission Tomography, a cutting-edge technique, were combined in this work to produce better detector sensitivity and spatial resolution. This strategy was referred to as a dual-modality approach. PET is a cutting-edge imaging method that has completely transformed the area of medical diagnosis. With the use of this extraordinary technology, medical personnel are able to see the inner workings of the human body in real time, which provides them with crucial insights into a variety of illnesses and ailments. When PET scans are performed, just a trace quantity of radioactive material is used. A multimodal PET/SPECT detector and SiPM array that makes use of LYSO crystals was the major aim that needed to be designed and constructed. The creation of a collaborative detector that is capable of detection for both SPECT and PET modalities is presented in this paper. For the purpose of maximising the efficiency of the detector's design and evaluating its performance, Monte Carlo simulations were carried out using the program Geant4. For the purpose of the phantoms, the design was carried out in Geant4, more precisely in accordance with the NU 4-2008 standard established by the NEMA.

title: Predictive Diagnosis of Breast Cancer Tissues using Machine Learning Approaches
authors: Peter Jose P, A. Manimuthu, Anandaraj M D, R. Sangeetha, V. Pradeep
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The second most common cancer and the second most deadly form of cancer among women is breast cancer, with an early detection being a major factor in improving the rates of survival. The last many years have seen a number of most exciting developments in the machine learning (ML) community that have the potential to immediately impact the accuracy and reliability of breast cancer diagnoses. In this paper, we present and apply the new tools these bright minds have developed to the most important problem breast cancer detection and, at the same time, funding a new human resource model for doing so in a timely and cost-effective manner. Our study is concerned not just with the direct issue of improving breast cancer detection but also with the bigger question of how well these new ML tools might work in the overall context of healthcare diagnostics.

title: Harnessing Quantum Inspired Extreme Learning for Molecular Property Prediction
authors: Payal D. Solanki, Anh Pham
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: In this paper, we explore the performance of the quantum-inspired Quantum Extreme Learning Machine (QELM) for molecular property prediction using regression. Specifically, we investigate how quantum-inspired techniques like Tensor Networks (TNs) such as the Time-Dependent Variational Principle (TDVP) with Matrix Product States (MPS) can be utilized for the QELM algorithm. We applied the QELM technique to predict activity (ACT) values based on molecular descriptors from the Merck Molecular Activity Challenge (MMACD) dataset. Overall, the results show that TNs can balance performance and accuracy in simulating quantum dynamics, allowing the simulation of datasets with a high number of features. This study underscores the potential of tensor networks as quantum-inspired algorithms to enhance the capability of quantum machine learning algorithms to study datasets with large numbers of features.

title: Hybrid Quantum-Classical Multi-Party Computation
authors: Videet Acharya, Prateek Talwar, Kunal Korgoankar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Multi-Party Computation allows multiple participants to jointly compute a function using their respective inputs while maintaining the confidentiality of those inputs and avoiding a single point of vulnerability or failure. This paper presents a framework (or architecture) for a hybrid Quantum-Classical Multi-Party Computation (QAMPC) protocol, which uses classical methods to generate player shares and shadow shares, while quantum techniques handle the masking of shares and the reconstruction process. Quantum masking enables the reuse of shadow shares even if an eavesdropper is present. The proposed architecture, incorporating quantum masking, enhances the performance and security of the MPC protocol. Overall, this study offers a pathway for developing practical quantum-classical hybrid protocols for MPC.

title: Quantum-Assisted Learning of Time-Dependent Parabolic PDEs
authors: Nahid Binandeh Dehaghani, Ban Tran, A. Pedro Aguiar, Rafal Wisniewski, Susan Mengel
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We present a hybrid quantum-classical framework for solving general time-dependent parabolic partial differential equations (PDEs) using quantum variational circuits. Building on the QPINN approach, this method applies broadly to parabolic PDEs. To demonstrate its effectiveness, we focus on the 1D and 2D heat equations as representative examples and analyze its performance under constrained quantum resources. Our results show that the framework can accurately capture spatiotemporal dynamics, offering a promising direction for quantum-assisted scientific computing.

title: Quantum Babel: Breaching the Notational and Conceptual Divide of Physics and Mathematics to Build Quantum Intuition in Computer Science Students
authors: Anila Mjeda, Hazel Murray
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum computing poses unique challenges for computer science students due to the field's reliance on mathematical formalism, abstract physical concepts, and unfamiliar notation. While computer science students are typically proficient in algorithmic thinking and systems design, they often lack the background in quantum mechanics and linear algebra necessary to navigate the field's conceptual landscape. This mismatch can result in a form of disciplinary dissonance, a ‘Quantum Babel', where understanding breaks down due to divergent cognitive and notational frameworks. This paper proposes a layered, analogy-driven pedagogical framework that re-contextualizes quantum concepts using metaphors and structures familiar to CS learners. Grounded in cognitive load theory and analogical reasoning, the approach aims to reduce extraneous cognitive load through metaphorical scaffolding. For example, the quantum Hamiltonian is recast as an operating system task scheduler, facilitating intuitive understanding of time evolution and energy landscapes in quantum systems. We present a series of conceptual mappings and illustrative examples that enable learners to build quantum intuition using analogies drawn from classical computing domains such as signal processing, debugging, and resource scheduling. Our goal is to foster quantum intuition in learners without requiring a deep background in physics, supporting the emergence of a new generation of quantum-literate computer scientists. This work contributes to the growing field of quantum software engineering education and lays the foundation for empirically validated, cross-disciplinary teaching tools.

title: Covert Entanglement Generation Over Bosonic Channels
authors: Evan J. D. Anderson, Michael S. Bullock, Ohad Kimelfeld, Christopher K. Eyre, Filip Rozpędek, Uzi Pereg, Boulat A. Bash
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We explore covert entanglement generation over the lossy thermal-noise bosonic channel, which is a quantummechanical model of many practical settings, including optical, microwave, and radio-frequency (RF) channels. Covert communication ensures that an adversary is unable to detect the presence of transmissions, which are concealed in channel noise. While covert communication of classical bits is well studied, covert quantum communication and entanglement generation remain largely unexplored. Here, we first show that a square root law (SRL) for covert classical secret communication over the lossy thermal-noise bosonic channel, defining the optimal rate and covert capacity <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{\text{sec }}$</tex>. The achievable construction relies on position-based coding, sequential decoding, and quadrature phase-shift keying. Furthermore, we adapt the code used in covert secret communication to show that a square root law (SRL) for covert entanglement generation similar to that for classical: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{\text{EG}} \sqrt{n}$</tex> entangled bits (ebits) can be generated covertly and reliably over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n$</tex> uses of a bosonic channel. We report a single-letter expression for optimal <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{\text{EG}}$</tex> as well as an achievable method. We additionally analyze the performance of covert entanglement generation using single- and dual-rail photonic qubits for varying channel parameters. Despite a performance gap compared to the optimal strategy, these encodings may be more practical for physical implementation.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Content Caching and Sharing using Hierarchical Federated Learning
authors: Umamaheswari S K, K. Baalaji
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The rapid escalation of wireless data demand, fueled by the widespread adoption of smart devices and the surge in multimedia consumption, presents critical challenges to the scalability of current wireless network infrastructures—particularly regarding bandwidth limitations, storage constraints, and latency management. To address these issues, content caching and Device to Device (D2D) communication have gained traction as efficient methods for mitigating traffic congestion during network peak times. This study explores adaptive caching mechanisms by considering user mobility behaviors and content popularity trends to make informed caching decisions. A novel caching strategy based on Hierarchical Federated Learning (HFL) is introduced to enhance user Quality of Experience (QoE), maintain data privacy, and reduce reliance on centralized systems and backhaul infrastructure. The proposed framework is empirically compared with three baseline methods: Collaborative Filtering with Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD), Reinforcement Learning (RL), and conventional Federated Learning (FL). Experimental evaluations demonstrate that the HFL based model delivers superior performance in terms of cache hit rate, latency reduction, and overall scalability making it a viable approach for next generation wireless networks such as 5G and beyond. The proposed HFL based framework achieved up to 15% higher cache hit rate and 12% lower latency compared to existing methods, demonstrating its potential for scalable and privacy preserving content delivery in 5G networks.

title: Improving RFI Classification with Efficient-SelfNet: A Comparison of CNN, ResNet, and ViT Models
authors: A Arthitha, P P Kaviya, S Meenakshi, P Suresh Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Classification of interference in the RFI is essential for a better and reliable performance improvement of wireless communication systems. The work proposes the use of Efficient-SelfNet which will further help to improve the classification process of the RFI. Four state-of-art models CNN, Resnet with self-attention, ViT, Efficient-SelfNet, are compared here. Self-attention mechanism, used in ResNet and EfficientNet, enables models to grasp long-range dependencies and focus on relevant features by adaptivity, thus enhancing interference patterns classification ability under diverse conditions. The experiment results are shown that, for different metrics such as precision, recall, $\mathbf{F 1}$-score, and accuracy; the model, Efficient-SelfNet, outperforms all the others. Furthermore, analysis of confusion matrices shows that it is more robust and effective. This underlines the importance of attention mechanisms in improving RFI classification and their potential for real-world applications, including interference suppression and spectrum management.

title: Cloud-Deployed CNN-BiLSTM Hybrid Model for Automated Tumor Segmentation in Histopathological Images
authors: N. Venkatesh, Karthik Jeyapal, S. Rajalakshmi, Narasimhan Dasarathy, Velmurugan V, Srimathi S
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Seamless tumor segmentation of histopathological images determines successful plan of cancer treatment and diagnosis. In this paper, suggests an idea of a cloud-based hybrid Deep Learning (DL) approach which combines the Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) with the Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) cells to address both spatial and sequential dependencies within the histological patches. The model was tested on a simulated tumor segmentation dataset ${\color{red}\text{has}}$ have 200 labeled images with class-level annotations. The suggested CNN-BiLSTM model registered a Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) of 0.906, Intersection over Union (IoU) of 0.828, Accuracy of 0.915, Precision of 0.911, Recall of 0.901, and an F1-score of 0.906. Comparison of performance of the CNN-BiLSTM with that of baseline models: U-Net, ResNet, SegNet, and CNN, shows that it was consistently better on all the other modules of performance. The architecture of the model was implemented through a cloud-based API, providing the ability to perform the inference remotely and scale into the digital pathology pipelines. These findings support the usability of hybrid model on robust identification of tumor regions and its utility toward improving automated histopathological analysis.

title: Dynamic Circuit Compilation for Sparse Qubit Connectivity
authors: Sumeet Shirgure, Siyuan Niu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: In this work, we show how dynamic circuit compilation methods can transform a densely connected circuit into an ancilla-mediated, sparsely connected dynamic circuit that includes mid-circuit measurement and feedforward operations. This sparse connectivity is better suited to current quantum hardware, which often has limited qubit connectivity. Compared to compilation methods focused on unitary circuits, our method can reduce both circuit depth and the additional CNOTs required to execute non-adjacent qubit interactions.

title: AI – Driven Conversational Platform for Native Languages
authors: Kavita Sultanpure, Jay Daftardar, Harsh Dange, Aryan Desai, Krushna Datir, Archit Darade
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: India's linguistic diversity, with over 700 native languages, represents a significant hurdle for equal access to AI technologies since conversational systems are mostly still quite English-centric. This research proposes a multilingual, open-domain conversational AI platform designed for Indian users that supports ten major languages, including Hindi, Tamil, Bengali, Telugu, Marathi, Gujarati, Kannada, Malayalam, Punjabi, and English. The system operates upon Sarvam AI Services, and integrates Google Gemini Pro. As such the system allows for seamless engagement across text, voice, document analysis, web search, and live screen sharing. The platform keeps conversations culturally sensitive and contextually relevant, because it exhibits strong management of multi- faceted Indic scripts, code-mixing, plus regional accents. An audio system exhibited increased accuracy with more natural voice synthesis and experimental evaluations validate the OCR- based processing of documents consistently across varied real-world use cases. The main contribution of this work is its development of a scaling and culturally adaptive framework that is for multilingual AI, which will enable inclusive access to education, healthcare, governance, and business services in India for its extensive population and advance the design of conversational AI systems that are localized, multimodal, socially just in consideration to users, and bridge the digital language barrier.

title: Ultra-Low pA-Level Noise EBIC and RCI of High Impedance Samples
authors: Willy Lim, Benoît Dagon, René Hammer, Grigore Moldovan
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: Nanoprobing imaging equipment for Electron Beam Absorbed Current/Resistive Contrast Imaging (EBAC/RCI) and Electron Beam Induced Current (EBIC) techniques is widely used in the semiconductor industry for process control and development. As components of electronic devices become smaller, the impact of electron beam irradiation becomes more severe, and the use of low beam acceleration voltages coupled with low beam current is recommended to avoid transistor damage [1]–[2]. Necessity for lower beam current leads to much reduced nanoprobing imaging signals, and thus lower overall signal-to-noise ratio. In this article, we describe the development of a novel pA noise-level amplifier for RCI and EBIC measurements of high impedance samples. A peak-to-peak noise level of 3 pA is shown here with this new amplifier. We compare experimental performance of this novel low noise amplifier to an established reference amplifier and illustrate the gained benefits and new limits for RCI measurements.

title: Enhancing Network Security: A Comparative Analysis of Machine Learning, Ensemble Methods, and Federated Learning for Intrusion Detection
authors: Tirupati Yesuraju, Shaik Masthan Vali, Shaik Sameer, Shaik Shabbir, Singavaram Riyaz
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The growth in complexity of cyberattacks is a major hindrance to the security of the current network infrastructures. Conventional IDS (typically based on signature- or rule-based IDS) are usually poor performers against zero-day attacks and have to be frequently updated manually. The paper aims to compare machine learning (ML), ensemble learning and federated learning (FL) as the strategies to optimize IDS in scalability and data privacy limitations. Based on the Modern Secure Computing Anomaly Dataset (MSCAD), several supervised classifiers such as Decision Tree, Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machine, and Gradient Boosting were benchmarked with ensemble methods namely Bagging, Boosting and Stacking. Moreover, an FL framework that is privacy-prestanding was deployed to determine the effects of intrusion detection in a distributed environment using many nodes. Stacked ensembles models performed best with a given accuracy score of 96.3%, and FL model was also performing comparatively well with an accuracy score of 94.5%. The results reveal that federated approaches coupled with ensemble approaches can eventually achieve scalability, accuracy, and privacy-preserving IDS solutions which have practical potentials of application in IoT, industry, and multi-organizational networks.

title: Object Detection and Pose Estimation in Point Cloud using PPF and Gated Convolution
authors: Reza Javanmard Alitappeh, Mehdi Ghoreyshi, Nima Mahmoudi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: This paper presents innovative solutions for object detection and matching in 3D point clouds, leveraging Point Pair Features (PPF) descriptors and a novel deep learning model. Both approaches demonstrate robustness against noise and partial occlusion while maintaining low computational costs, making them suitable for real-time object recognition in cluttered environments. The PPF-based method involves preprocessing point clouds, clustering objects, and matching through the calculation of PPF descriptors for each object and the target. The proposed deep learning model introduces a lightweight architecture that combines Gated Convolution and Multi-Layer Perceptrons (MLPs) to detect objects, utilizing skeletal representations of the point cloud as input. Comprehensive evaluations on two point cloud datasets highlight the effectiveness of both methods in object detection and pose estimation tasks.

title: Education for Sustainability Through Challengebased Learning: the Understanding of Sustainability as a Transversal Competence
authors: Jorge Membrillo-Hernández, Mariana E. Elizondo-García, Gabriela Ortíz-Martínez, Juan de Dios Torralba-Pérez
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: Education for sustainable development requires innovative pedagogies to equip students with the competencies to address complex environmental challenges. This study examines the use of ChallengeBased Learning (CBL) to foster an understanding of sustainability as a transversal (cross-cutting) competence among undergraduates at a private university in Mexico, within a global sustainability context. An extensive literature review highlights the importance of real-world, collaborative learning in developing critical thinking, problem-solving, and cooperative skills essential for sustainability. Over two semesters, the CBL intervention engaged students in addressing real-world challenges, including energy consumption, waste management, water conservation, pollution control, and plastic reduction. Students <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathbf{N} \boldsymbol{\approx} \mathbf{1 5 0})$</tex> worked in teams to develop 36 original projects targeting these issues. A mixed-methods approach was employed to evaluate outcomes, including pre- and post-surveys of sustainability knowledge and skills, as well as qualitative reflections. Results showed statistically significant gains in students' self-reported sustainability competencies, including a 48 % increase in understanding of sustainability concepts and a 53 % improvement in their ability to propose practical environmental solutions. Additionally, 80 % of students agreed that CBL made sustainability more tangible and personally meaningful than traditional classes. The results of this study revealed that CBL is an effective pedagogy for sustainability education, bridging theoretical knowledge with practical action and fostering the holistic competencies needed to advance sustainable development.

title: Towards Efficient Hybrid Quantum-Classical Learning Models
authors: Aaron McCollum, Sharatchandra Varma Bogaraju, James McLaughlin, Abdelkerim Amari, Sunish Kumar Orappanpara Soman
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: With the limitations of current noisy intermediate scale quantum (NISQ) devices, there is a need for hybrid quantum-classical learning models to operate more efficiently within existing hardware constraints. The design of cost-effective hybrid quantum-classical learning systems is therefore imperative for various applications, including biosignal processing in the healthcare sector. This motivates the investigation into the reduction of computational complexity of a hybrid quantumclassical neural network. We propose a new hybrid model combining a quantum neural network (QNN) with a binary neural network (BNN), known as quBNN, with the aim to reduce model complexity. For benchmarking, we consider a classical multilayer perceptron (MLP) and a standard nonbinarised version of quBNN that combines a QNN with an MLP, named as quilp. We evaluated all models on a multi-class dataset containing multimodal biosignals. We find that quMLP can outperform the classical MLP with minimal additional complexity, while quBNN maintains performance comparable with the classical MLP, with reduced computational complexity. We apply pruning and quantisation techniques to the QNN within the proposed quBNN model, aiming to further reduce its complexity. This compression yields substantial reductions in parameter and quantum gate count when compiled for quantum hardware, albeit with performance degradation.

title: Revisiting Gradient Staleness: Evaluating Distance Metrics for Asynchronous Federated Learning Aggregation
authors: Patrick Wilhelm, Odej Kao
publish: 2025 IEEE/SBC 37th International Symposium on Computer Architecture and High Performance Computing Workshops (SBAC-PADW)
abstract: In asynchronous federated learning (FL), client devices send updates to a central server at varying times based on their computational speed, often using stale versions of the global model. This staleness can degrade the convergence and accuracy of the global model. Previous work, such as AsyncFedED, proposed an adaptive aggregation method using Euclidean distance to measure staleness. In this paper, we extend this approach by exploring alternative distance metrics to more accurately capture the effect of gradient staleness. We integrate these metrics into the aggregation process and evaluate their impact on convergence speed, model performance, and training stability under heterogeneous clients and non-IID data settings. Our results demonstrate that certain metrics lead to more robust and efficient asynchronous FL training, offering a stronger foundation for practical deployment.

title: An ML-Based Quantum Advantage Calculator
authors: Miguel Paredes Quiñones, Ítalo Santana, Diego Noble
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We developed a quantum-advantage predictor tool which uses machine learning models to determine when and at what cost a computational problem can be feasibly executed on gate-based quantum computers. We trained the models on data from Quantum Resource Estimators. Our ML-based tool aims at demonstrating a more realistic calculation of running times by considering not only QRE results but also the classical computational effort in running circuits into a quantum hardware (e.g., transpilation, algorithm preparation, solution encoding/decoding, etc.). The proposed tool is divided into two main sections: advantage may happen based on by year or by hardware evolutions for a determined problem and hardware specification. In both sections, a user can select a set of input parameters to verify the resulting runtimes and costs of quantum and classical parts to determine if quantum advantage will be achievable. Our application demonstrates that, despite limited information from vendors, we can still obtain accurate predictions to determine the realization of quantum advantage.

title: LLM-powered Smart Spaces with Multi-agent User-centric Adaptation
authors: Alaa Saleh, Mazen Hassaan, Qiyang Zhang, Sasu Tarkoma, Susanna Pirttikangas, Lauri Lovén
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: The increasing integration of Large Language Models (lLMs) into smart environments has driven the need for adaptive, user-centric AI solutions that enhance personalized experiences. This study introduces a multi-agent system that dynamically adjusts environmental settings based on real-time user preferences. By leveraging agentic AI within a computing continuum, our framework employs personalized LLM agents that negotiate with smart building agents to optimize temperature, humidity, and lighting conditions while maintaining energy efficiency. Using the AutoGen framework, our system orchestrates structured agent interactions to ensure seamless coordination and decision-making. We evaluate various LLMs, including GPT-4o, Gemini-2.0-Flash, Claude-3.5-Sonnet, and SmolLM2, in terms of precision, computational efficiency, and resource utilization. Results demonstrate that GPT-4o and GPT-4o-mini achieve the highest precision while minimizing resource overhead, whereas other models exhibit inefficiencies in execution speed and agent coordination.

title: Brain-Computer Interfaces and Neuroengineering
authors: Khushita Shende, Praveen Kumar, Harshada Gole, Palash Gourshettiwar, Disha Bhajipale, Rutuja Shelke
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Brain computer interfacing has undergone enormous developments in the last decade, becoming specialized tools for neurorehabilitation via direct interaction between the brain and external devices. Being recognized as non-invasive methods, EEG-based BCIs are increasingly utilized in clinical settings. This review stresses developments in areas of acquisition of brain signals, adaptive algorithms, and neural interface technologies. Another spectrum of BCI application is in stroke rehabilitation, recovery of motor functions, Parkinson's disease, and decoding of handwriting from brain activity. The integration of machine learning and deep learning methods has optimized signal classification ability while reducing setup times, particularly using transfer learning approaches. Further discussion in this review encompasses implantable solutions such as the Stentrode and key surgical considerations. Other key issues tackled within this review are system reliability, individual differences, and ethics. The paper finally notes imminent opportunities for BCI technologies to strongly enter into widespread personalization in neuroengineer

title: Deep Learning Based Algorithm for Detecting Abnormalities in Gangplank State
authors: Mingjie Zhu, Li Mou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Coal mine synthesized mining interface has the problems of complex environment and various machines will cover each other, for the existing target detection methods in coal mine underground target recognition there are high computational cost and poor detection effect, this paper proposes an efficient target recognition algorithm of the abnormal state of the guard plate to strengthen the safety of the coal mine production and operation. The algorithm is improved based on YOLOv8n by first redesigning the convolution module using SCConv, and proposing a lighter C2f-SCConv convolution module to replace the C2f module in the YOLOv8 backbone, thus limiting feature redundancy and enhancing feature representation; In addition, the deformable attention mechanism DAttention is incorporated into the original algorithm to extract features with lower complexity; Finally the addition of the P2 detection head enhances the capture of fine-grained features. The experimental results show that the performance of the improved model is significantly improved compared to the commonly used models such as YOLOv5s, Faster R-CNN, and SSD. Relative to the base model mAP@0.5 and mAP@0.5:0.95 improved by 2.6% and 2.7%, respectively. The algorithm improves the performance while ensuring that the number of parameters does not increase additionally, to meet the accuracy and timeliness requirements of the task of detecting abnormal targets in the state of the guard plate.

title: AI and Human Cognition: A CognitiveComputational Synergy
authors: K Kanishthika, T S Akarsh Velan, J Umamageswaran
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence is not just reshaping industries but also reshaping how we think and solve problems, profoundly influencing the fabric of human cognition. The psychological implications of convenience go far beyond just that, revealing an often-blighted double-edged sword. As AI liberates more potential by easing complicated jobs, increasing accuracy, and offering intelligent solutions, it develops some serious risks by suppressing critical thinking and worsening mental health issues. In this paper, we propose the AI-Human Cognition Framework; a model designed to redefine AI’s role as a cognitive enhancer rather than a replacement. Active participation comes through modular scaffolding for structured support, an adaptive interface for personalized engagement, and dynamic feedback loops for continuous cognitive refinement through two-way diagnostics. The paradigm guarantees that AI promotes intellectual resilience rather than passive dependence by being based on ethical concepts including transparency, user agency, and cognitive well-being. It is with this integration of AI and mutual learning that the approach envisions a future where AI enhances human reasoning, fosters mental resilience, and leads to an integrated and trusting human-technology partnership.

title: Direct Entanglement Ansatz Learning (DEAL) with ZNE on Error-Prone Superconducting Qubits
authors: Ziqing Guo, Steven Rayan, Wenshuo Hu, Ziwen Pan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum combinatorial optimization algorithms typically face challenges owing to complex optimization landscapes featuring numerous local minima, exponentially scaling latent spaces, and susceptibility to quantum hardware noise. In this study, we introduce Direct Entanglement Ansatz Learning (DEAL), wherein we employ a direct mapping from quadratic unconstrained binary problem parameters to quantum ansatz for cost and mixer Hamiltonians, which improves the convergence rate towards the optimal solution. Our approach exploits a quantum entanglement-based ansatz to effectively explore intricate latent spaces and zero-noise extrapolation (ZNE) to mitigate the randomness caused by crosstalk and coherence errors. Our experimental evaluation demonstrates that DEAL increases the success rate compared to the classic quantum approximation optimization algorithm while controlling the error variance. In addition, we demonstrate the capability of DEAL to provide near-optimum ground energy solutions for traveling salesman, knapsack, and maxcut problems, which facilitates novel paradigms for solving relevant NPhard problems and extends the self-contained practical applicability of quantum optimization using noisy quantum hardware.

title: Research on Automatic Segmentation Method of Tunnel Cable Accessory Point Clouds
authors: Nan Zhang, Ya Dai, Nianxia Han, Weizhou Xu, Fengju Zhu, Chao Ye
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Urbanization and growing power demand underscore the importance of cable accessory laying quality, but manual inspection is subjective, inaccurate, and risk-prone, while poor records hinder fault diagnosis. To address these challenges, an automatic segmentation algorithm specifically designed for point cloud data of cable laying areas in three-dimensional tunnel scenarios is proposed. The algorithm integrates multiple key steps, including the removal of tunnel inner wall point clouds to eliminate interference, precise segmentation of cable point clouds from complex backgrounds, and accurate extraction of the cable laying area for subsequent parameter analysis. Experimental results validate the high accuracy of the proposed method: in the three key processes of cable laying, the F1-scores for cable segmentation reach 0.961,0.972, and 0.955 respectively; for the four core parameters (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mu_{\mathrm{i}}-\mu_{4}$</tex>) of the laying area, the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{F}1$</tex>-scores range from 0.947 to 0.976. These results demonstrate that the algorithm can provide reliable data support for the digital quality verification of cable laying, effectively overcoming the limitations of traditional manual methods.

title: Stability Analysis of Dynamic On-State Resistance in Multiple-GaN Cascode Configuration
authors: Surya Elangovan, Stone Cheng, Edward Yi Chang, Chang-Ching Tu, Yi-Kai Hsiao, Tejender Singh Rawat, Hao-Chung Kuo
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: This paper presents the development and double-pulse testing (DPT) of a multi-GaN cascode configuration for high-power applications. The setup integrates four GaN MISHEMTs in series with low-voltage Si MOSFETs. Electrical characterization including output, transfer, and blocking voltage measurements-was performed at room temperature. The cascode switch exhibits a low static on-state resistance of 80 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{m} \Omega$</tex>, a blocking capability of 400 V, and a positive threshold voltage of 1.8 V. The stability of the dynamic on-state resistance (Rds-on) was evaluated using double-pulse testing (DPT) in inductive load circuits, focusing on its dependence on voltage, frequency, and temperature during switching. The tests were conducted with a fixed drain current (Ids) of 6 A and 10 A. Under hard-switching conditions, hot electron injection into surface and buffer traps resulted in a minimal increase in dynamic R <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$_{\text {DS-ON }}$</tex>, with no significant degradation observed even under extreme switching scenarios. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the cascode configuration, encompassing development cascode packaging, static characterization, GaN paralleling effects and dynamic stability performance evaluations.

title: Robust Wafer Map Defect Detection Under Mislabeled Patterns by Pattern Updating Through Neural Networks
authors: Hanwen Li, Nagarajan Raghavan
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: Wafer map defect detection is now a crucial process in semiconductor manufacturing. The result of wafer map defect detection can be used as guidance to improve future reliability and yield in the wafer fabrication process. Most previous works assume that the wafer map data's patterns are all clearly and correctly labeled. However, it should be noted that in many real-world cases, the patterns are often mislabeled and not correct, which will negatively affect the effectiveness of wafer map defect detection. In this work, firstly, we use two types of noise, symmetric noise and pair noise to simulate the real-world mislabeling scenarios in the wafer map defect detection process. Then we propose a robust method for wafer map defect detection under mislabeled patterns, a pattern updating technique is used to rectify the mislabeled pattern. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated by experiments on a real-world wafer map dataset.

title: Intelligent Earthquake Detection: Optimizing Seismic Monitoring with Random Forest and AdaBoost
authors: R Nancy Deborah, S Alwyn Rajiv, R Akchay Kumar, M Kathiravan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: The catastrophic damage inflicted by earthquakes creates a necessity for advanced systems of detection to reduce the loss of life and destruction to infrastructure. This research presents a machine learning-based earthquake detection system that exploits the use of Random Forest and AdaBoost algorithms for the purposes of accuracy and timeliness in detection. The challenges of traditional methods like Naive Bayes which assume independent features have been resolved with this new approach for handling highly complex and highdimensional data seismic data. This is through intense preprocessing, noises being reduced and features extracted and used in distinguishing seismic events from background noise. Performance is evaluated using accuracy, precision, recall and F1-score to ensure robust and reliable detection. This novel method advances the state-of-the-art in earthquake monitoring and provides a vital early warning tool that assists disaster preparedness and response initiatives.

title: Secure Localization in Wireless Sensor Networks: Advancing Techniques for Resilient and Reliable Node Positioning
authors: Devershi Pallavi Bhatt, Roshmeet Chakraborty, Alka Chaudhary
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) are comprised of many sensor nodes which are deployed over a region to capture and gather information of the environment and utilize the data for several applications. These networks are very important in areas like environmental monitoring, healthcare, military activities, and industrial systems. One major problem that exists in WSNs is locating the unknown nodes as efficiently as possible since the whole concept of these networks is to locate these unknown nodes with respect to known anchor nodes. The proposed research will emphasize secure localization, an important concern with the possibility of adversaries taking advantage of or compromising the satellites’ location, thus disturbing the integrity and the working of the network. The development of WSN is as a result of advancement in microelectromechanical systems (MEMS), digital electronics, and wireless communication. This development made it possible to manufacture small, powerful, and efficient sensor nodes. In this paper, we analyze the currently available secure localization algorithms, point out the issues associated with them, and provide new solutions for these problems. This work seeks to increase the stability and dependability of WSNs by designing efficient approaches for secure node placement for their effective use in diverse modern systems. This study advances SDG Goals 11 and 13 by improving secure localization methods in wireless sensor networks, hence providing robust and dependable node placement for sustainable urban infrastructure and climate-adaptive smart cities.

title:
Application of D
