title: Time-to-Lie: Identifying Industrial Control System Honeypots Using the Internet Control Message Protocol
authors: Jacob J. Williams, Matthew Edwards, Joseph Gardiner
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: The convergence of information and operational technology networks has created previously unforeseen security issues. To address these issues, both researchers and practitioners have integrated threat intelligence methods into the security operations of converged networks, with some of the most valuable tools being honeypots that imitate industrial control systems (ICS). However, the development and deployment of such honeypots is a process rich with pitfalls, which can lead to undiagnosed weaknesses in the threat intelligence being gathered. This paper presents a side-channel method of covertly identifying ICS honeypots using the time-to-live (TTL) values of target devices. We show that many ICS honeypots can be readily identified, via minimal interactions, using only basic networking tools. In a study of over 8,000 devices presenting as ICS systems, we detail how our method compares to an existing honeypot detection approach, and outline what our methodology reveals about the current population of live ICS honeypots. In demonstrating our method, this study aims to raise awareness of the viability of the TTL heuristic and the prevalence of its misconfiguration despite its presence in literature.

title: TUBO: A Tailored ML Framework for Reliable Network Traffic Forecasting
authors: Zhihang Yuan, Leyang Xue, Waleed Ahsan, Mahesh K. Marina
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Network operation optimization through traffic forecasting holds great promise but faces key challenges due to the complex and bursty nature of traffic patterns. While deep learning models outperform traditional statistical methods in time series forecasting, they remain unreliable for network traffic due to limited adaptability to traffic fluctuations and diverse patterns. We present TUBO, a novel machine learning framework tailored for reliable traffic demand matrix (DM) forecasting. TUBO comprises two core components: a burst processor that isolates and predicts sudden traffic spikes, and a model selector that dynamically chooses the most suitable forecasting model from a diverse pool based on input characteristics and uncertainty estimation. This enables TUBO to deliver accurate, robust, and uncertainty-aware predictions. Evaluations on three real-world datasets (Abilene, GEANT, and CERNET) show that TUBO improves forecasting accuracy by up to $10 \times$ and achieves $\mathbf{9 4 \%}$ accuracy in burst occurrence prediction. As a downstream application, we apply TUBO to proactive traffic engineering (TE) and demonstrate throughput gains of $\mathbf{9} \times$ and $\mathbf{3} \times$ over reactive TE and the best prior proactive TE approach, respectively.

title: Quantum Top Arms Identification in Multi-Armed Bandits
authors: Xuchuang Wang, Yu-Zhen Janice Chen, Matheus Guedes De Andrade, Mohammad Hajiesmaili, John C.S. Lui, Don Towsley
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We investigate the top-<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$m$</tex> arm identification problem in a quantum multi-armed bandit (MAB) setting. Given <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$K$</tex> arms whose rewards follow Bernoulli distributions with unknown means, the objective is to return the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$m$</tex> arms with the largest means with confidence at least <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1-\delta$</tex>. Many practical tasks-e.g., selecting the best <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$m$</tex> routing paths in a quantum network or the best <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$m$</tex> quantum circuits for a given computation-fit naturally into this framework. We introduce Q-GapE, an elimination-based algorithm that queries each arm through a weak quantum oracle. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{Q}$</tex>- GapE attains the query complexity guarantee <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\tilde{O}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(1 / \Delta_{k}^{(m)}\right) \log (1 / \delta)\right)$</tex>, where <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta_{k}^{(m)}$</tex> denotes the gap between arm <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex>'s mean and the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$m$</tex>-th largest mean. Compared with the best classical-oracle bound, this result offers a quadratic quantum speed-up. Extensive simulations confirm that <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{Q}-\text{GapE}$</tex> consistently outperforms leading classical MAB algorithms in both query complexity and running time. These findings highlight the potential of quantum bandit algorithms to deliver substantial efficiency gains over their classical counterparts.

title: An Optimized Multimodal Deep Learning Framework for Sentiment Classification using CNN-BiLSTM with FastText and GloVe Embeddings
authors: Kartheeban K, Sri Ram Ganesh M, C. Priya, Sundaram M K
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Multimodal Sentiment Analysis (MSA) is an advanced artificial intelligence technique that integrates text and image data to improve sentiment awareness, especially in practical scenarios where sentiment is conveyed through images alongside words. MSA proposes a feature extraction model from Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and text classification from Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) networks. For better comprehension of words from text, word representations such as FastText and GloVe are utilized, wherein FastText provides enhanced out-of-vocabulary word handling with subword-level representation. The model also includes attention mechanisms to focus the model onto the most descriptive image and text input areas. Employed since the dataset is 1,428 labeled instances, each a combination of an image, a caption for the image, and a positive or negative sentiment label. Preprocessing techniques such as image normalization and text tokenization are applied to pre-process the data into trainable form. Comparative experiment shows the peak accuracy is at 90%, which best performance is that CNN-BiLSTM constructed with FastText embedding, having exceeded the stand-alone CNN, stand-alone LSTMs, as well as all other model hybrids. It attests to the power of consolidating multimodal information and then deriving superior, state-of-the-art sentiment prediction. This has clear, immediate practical relevance across social surveillance, personalized recommendatory systems, emotive human-computer interactions, and social monitoring content control, among real-world applications. Future progress may include the use of transformer models, best practices for multimodal fusion optimization, and balance of cultural as well as contextual bias with regard to emotional understanding.

title: Quantum Adaptive Excitation Network with Variational Quantum Circuits for Channel Attention
authors: Yu-Chao Hsu, Kuan-Cheng Chen, Tai-Yue Li, Nan-Yow Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: In this work, we introduce the Quantum Adaptive Excitation Network (QAE-Net), a hybrid quantum-classical framework designed to enhance channel attention mechanisms in Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). QAE-Net replaces the classical excitation block of Squeeze-and-Excitation modules with a shallow Variational Quantum Circuit (VQC), leveraging quantum superposition and entanglement to capture higher-order inter-channel dependencies that are challenging to model with purely classical approaches. We evaluate QAE-Net on benchmark image classification tasks, including MNIST, FashionMNIST, and CIFAR-10, and observe consistent performance improvements across all datasets, with particularly notable gains on tasks involving three-channel inputs. Furthermore, experimental results demonstrate that increasing the number of variational layers in the quantum circuit leads to progressively higher classification accuracy, underscoring the expressivity benefits of deeper quantum models. These findings highlight the potential of integrating VQCs into CNN architectures to improve representational capacity while maintaining compatibility with nearterm quantum devices. The proposed approach is tailored for the Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) era, offering a scalable and feasible pathway for deploying quantum-enhanced attention mechanisms in practical deep learning workflows.

title: LSTM based Neural Models For COVID-19 and Future Pandemic Surveillance in Smart Cities
authors: Aakash S, Sophia S
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The COVID 19 pandemic has exposed the critical need for intelligent, adaptive surveillance mechanisms within the digital infrastructure of smart cities. This study introduces a Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) based neural network model designed to forecast COVID 19 transmission trends and enhance proactive public health interventions. By leveraging a multivariate time series dataset containing nine key epidemiological and behavioral features, the model accurately predicts daily infection rates over a 7 to 14 day horizon. The system includes an automated alert mechanism that classifies outbreak severity into risk levels (low, medium, high, critical) and dispatches notifications to public health authorities. In addition, the platform generates context specific recommendations, including guidance on scaling ICU capacity, implementing contact tracing, and adjusting testing strategies. Performance evaluation demonstrates high predictive accuracy with an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of 0.91, outperforming baseline models such as ARIMA and hybrid CNN LSTM configurations. The solution’s modularity and scalability make it adaptable for future pandemics by retraining the model on updated datasets. Integration with smart city infrastructure ensures real time responsiveness, while the rule based recommendation engine offers actionable insights for timely decision making. This research contributes a robust, AI driven framework for pandemic forecasting and preparedness, aligning public health intelligence with the operational capabilities of modern urban environments.

title: A Modularized and Greedy Strategy-Based Framework for Enhanced DV-Hop Model
authors: Zhou Zhou, Han Shen, Mohammad Shojafar
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: This paper proposes an innovative solution to address the limitations of the Distance Vector-Hop (DV-Hop) model, which fails to meet localization accuracy requirements and lacks a robust role analysis mechanism for flexible application expansion. By integrating a pre-experimentation mechanism, the model is systematically deconstructed and improved, resulting in the development of a modularized and greedy strategy-based DV-Hop localization algorithm (denoted by GSMDV-Hop). The proposed approach employs pre-experimental tests to identify the optimal performance functions within each module through a greedy strategy. A binary controller is introduced to seamlessly integrate these modules, enabling flexible control. Experimental results demonstrate that the incorporation of optimized modules reduces localization error by an average of $50 \%$, with peak optimization rates exceeding $70 \%$. The proposed algorithm significantly outperforms existing methods in terms of optimization effectiveness, stability, and versatility, making it a compelling choice for advanced localization tasks in diverse IoT applications.

title: Distributed Energy Resource Management Model in a Virtual Power Plant Integrated to a Radial Distribution Network
authors: Cristhian Medina-Ortega, Javier Revelo-Fuelagán, Didier Villaquiran-Samboni
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: The integration of distributed energy resources (DER), such as renewable sources, energy storage and flexible loads, has become a solution to improve the efficiency, flexibility and sustainability of electricity distribution networks. In this context, Virtual Power Plants (VPP) offer an effective alternative to coordinate these resources and allow their active participation in electricity markets, in addition to optimizing system operation. Therefore, an energy management model for a VPP integrated in a radial distribution network is presented, using the standardized IEEE 33-node system as a reference. The optimization model was implemented in GurobiPy considering the operational constraints of each DER, as well as the technical limitations of the network, using a power flow approach. In addition, it allows optimal sizing of energy resources to maximize the economic gains of the VPP and incorporates a demand response strategy to reduce consumption at times of high prices. The results are supported by AC power flow simulations in PandaPower, optimizing the technical performance of the network by reducing losses and improving voltage profiles in different scenarios.

title: Performance Analysis of Golay-Coded OFDM-IM Systems: A USRP-Based Approach
authors: Hussam Alsalameh, Ibrahim Develi, Busra Karahan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: The Index Modulation-Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM-IM) technique has emerged as a promising alternative to traditional OFDM in recent years, offering performance enhancements. However, high-frequency operations in 5G and beyond networks introduce challenges like hardware impairments (HWIs) and channel fading, making it essential to evaluate their effects on system performance and develop solutions. This study investigates the benefits of Golaycoded OFDM-IM systems compared to their uncoded counterparts. Experimental validation using the LabVIEW platform and USRP-2439R hardware demonstrates that Golay coding significantly enhances BER performance across varying Energy per Bit to Noise Power Ratio (Eb/N0) conditions. The results indicate that the Golay-coded system achieves up to 37% BER reduction at low Eb/N0 levels (-25.83 dB) and maintains a $\mathbf{2 3 \%}$ improvement at $\mathbf{- 1 6. 6 7 ~ d B}$, highlighting its effectiveness in mitigating transmission errors across various Eb/N0 levels. These findings contribute to advancing secure and efficient communication technologies, particularly for IoT applications.

title: Multi-Modal Personalized Federated Learning for Human Intent Prediction
authors: Maximilian Forstenhäusler, Christos Anagnostopoulos
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: This paper presents an overview of ongoing doctoral research, which explores multi-modal personalized federated learning for human intent predictions. Situated within the field of computer science, specifically Machine Learning, the study aims to address several challenges with utilizing and harmonizing multiple Machine Learning disciplines, such as fusing different data sources, e.g., time series and videos or images, decentralized learning, and personalization. The research adopts quantitative methods, such as experimental evaluation, simulation-based studies, and comparative analysis, and is currently at the early stages of development. By participating in the doctoral consortium, I seek constructive feedback on research design and research direction as well as the opportunity to engage with peers and senior researchers for collaborative dialogue and professional growth. This paper outlines the background, objectives, and describes anticipated contributions.

title: Development and Control of an Autonomous Agrivoltaic System with Active NFT Hydroponics for Off-Grid Applications
authors: Michelle Vanessa García Pérez, Juan Manuel España, Tatiana Manrique
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: Climate change has driven the adoption of renewable energies. However, concerns related to land use have arisen when large expanses of photovoltaic systems are deployed, especially when developed alongside agriculture, contributing to issues such as deforestation and biodiversity loss. This paper presents the design, implementation, and control of an autonomous agrivoltaic system that integrates active hydroponics using the Nutrient Film Technique (NFT) with solar energy generation, thereby mitigating the environmental effects of both sectors: agriculture and the implementation of massive photovoltaic systems. Aimed at deployment in non-interconnected areas (ZNI), the autonomous agrivoltaic system combines photovoltaic generation with vertical hydroponic cultivation to optimize land use, water efficiency, and energy independence. The proposed agrivoltaic system features a solar tracking mechanism controlled by a proportional-integral (PI) controller, which enhances energy capture by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$28.69\%$</tex> compared to fixed-panel configurations. Real-time monitoring and control of environmental and operational variables are achieved through a wireless interface using NI myRIO-1900 and LabVIEW, enabling remote supervision. Experimental validation demonstrates improved crop yield, a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$33\%$</tex> reduction in land and water usage, and reliable off-grid operation. The system exemplifies a scalable, sustainable solution for integrated food and energy production in rural and resourceconstrained environments.

title: D-Feat: Fast and Efficient Defense in the Feature Space Against Backdoor Attacks
authors: Marin Matjanec, Donik Vršnak, Sven Lončarić
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Image and Signal Processing and Analysis (ISPA)
abstract: Backdoor attacks represent a research field that has attracted significant attention in recent years, mainly due to their stealthiness and high success rates. The main goal of backdoor attacks is to manipulate the model's behavior during inference. This is achieved by embedding hidden triggers in the training data and potentially modifying training labels. With the growing integration of AI models into autonomous systems, backdoor attacks present a critical security risk. Various defense strategies have been developed to mitigate these threats. The most notable category of defenses relies on reconstructing the trigger pattern from the poisoned model. However, we observe that current defense methods demonstrate suboptimal performance with respect to trigger similarity as well as computational and memory efficiency. In this paper, we propose D-FEAT, a novel method that significantly reduces memory and time consumption compared to existing defenses. The reduction in time and memory requirements enables our method to be applied effectively in real-world scenarios. Using a lightweight neural network, we reconstruct the backdoor trigger entirely within the model's feature space, where the representations are denser and more abstract. It requires no assumptions about the form of the trigger, nor does it require scanning classes to identify a potential trigger, unlike many other methods. We evaluated our method on benchmark datasets and found it to perform, on average, comparably to or better than state-of-the-art defenses in backdoor mitigation. Additionally, D-FEAT excels in backdoor removal consistency, effectively mitigating every attack tested.

title: On the Adaptability of ML Reliability Estimation Techniques to Federated Settings
authors: Junjian Yan, Paulo de Carvalho, Jorge Henriques, João Loureiro, Chan-Tong Lam, Henrique Madeira
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: Federated learning (FL) enables collaborative model training without centralizing data, thereby preserving privacy, but it introduces new challenges for assessing the reliability of AI predictions. Classical reliability estimation methods from centralized machine learning cannot be directly applied in FL due to data heterogeneity, limited observability, and communication constraints. This paper presents an early-stage investigation into adapting representative reliability techniques—spanning data-driven, model-driven, and complementary information-based methods—to the federated setting. For each category, we analyze feasibility, outline privacy-preserving adaptations, and discuss trade-offs in terms of accuracy, computation, and communication. While no experimental validation is provided at this stage, the study offers preliminary insights that may guide future research and empirical evaluation of reliable FL systems.

title: QIRopt: An Optimization Method for Quantum Intermediate Representation
authors: Junjie Luo, Haoyu Zhang, Jianjun Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: This paper proposes a dataflow-based optimization method called Quantum Intermediate Representation Optimization (QIRopt) within the LLVM infrastructure. QIRopt has two main functions: preprocessing QIR code to expose more optimization opportunities to the LLVM optimizer and optimizing QIR code to avoid redundant loading and construction of qubits and qubit arrays. We evaluated QIRopt on the IBM Challenge Dataset, and the results demonstrate its effectiveness in reducing redundant operations in QIR code. A preliminary implementation of QIRopt and a case study on real-world code further confirm that our approach enhances the LLVM optimizer's ability to optimize preprocessed QIR code.

title: QubitVise: Double-Sided Crosstalk Attack in Superconducting Quantum Computers
authors: Adriana Aranguren Arellano, He Xie, Jakub Szefer
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: This work presents a novel security attack based on CNOT gate induced crosstalk in superconducting qubit systems. Compared to previous work, this work introduces a double-sided crosstalk attack where attacker's circuits are located on either side of the victim circuit executing in a multi-tenant cloud-based quantum computer. The attacker, a malicious tenant or user, can interfere with, or disrupt, the state of neighboring qubits in the victim tenant or user without direct access to victim's qubits, by taking advantage of interference and crosstalk among the otherwise logically isolated qubits. New aspect of this attack is the location of the attacker's circuits on both sides of the victim. Experimental validation on cloud-based Rigetti quantum devices demonstrates that these attacks can compromise data integrity and cause the victim's circuit's outputs to change. Magnitude of the change is evaluated using total variational distance and tested on number of common benchmarks that can execute on today's quantum computers. This work underscores the need for improved isolation mechanisms and secure scheduling in multitenant quantum computing cloud environments.

title: Paddy Leaf Disease Prediction using Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning
authors: Vinitha Archimedies, Dinesh Kumar R
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Food security in the farm sector principally depends on the production of paddy, one of the major cereal crops that can be subjected to attack by the foliar diseases that are causatively initiated by the fungi, bacteria, viruses, and insects. The old manual sensing is time consuming and prone to mistakes and it is uneconomical to use in vast geographical locations that are climatologically sensitive. The paper provides its solution of an AI/ML-Styled model which classifies, diagnoses, and recognizes the paddy leaf illness with an excellent precision. A large amount of the image collection on the variants of the diseases was taken and a list of the preprocessing mechanisms was employed to keep up with the application such as the removal of the noise and division of the images that can enhance the quality of the picture. CNN, MobileNet, ViT and Hybrid networks were used to perform developments of deep learning. The basis of accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and inference time was used to perform an analysis of a performance. The other models of learning namely the hybrid and transfer models produced a better result due to the over 98 per cent accuracy. The results interpretation was based on visual tools that included use of bar graphics, spider charts and heatmaps. Distribution of data and data scaling was solved with data augmentation. The implementation of the system in the mobile/ web structures, as proposed is capable of making the diagnosis of the disease on the field in real-time in the resource-less rural environment.

title: Q-Cluster: Quantum Error Mitigation Through Noise-Aware Unsupervised Learning
authors: Hrushikesh Pramod Patil, Dror Baron, Huiyang Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum error mitigation (QEM) is critical in reducing the impact of noise in the pre-fault-tolerant era, and is expected to complement error correction in fault-tolerant quantum computing (FTQC). In this paper, we propose a novel QEM approach, Q-Cluster, that uses unsupervised learning (clustering) to reshape the measured bit-string distribution. Our approach starts with a simplified bit-flip noise model. It first performs clustering on noisy measurement results, i.e., bit-strings, based on the Hamming distance. The centroid of each cluster is calculated using a qubit-wise majority vote. Next, the noisy distribution is adjusted with the clustering outcomes and the bitflip error rates using Bayesian inference. Our simulation results show that Q-Cluster can mitigate high noise rates (up to 40% per qubit) with the simple bit-flip noise model. However, real quantum computers do not fit such a simple noise model. To address the problem, we (a) apply Pauli twirling to tailor the complex noise channels to Pauli errors, and (b) employ a machine learning model, ExtraTrees regressor, to estimate an effective bit-flip error rate using a feature vector consisting of machine calibration data (gate & measurement error rates), circuit features (number of qubits, numbers of different types of gates, etc.) and the shape of the noisy distribution (entropy). Our experimental results show that our proposed Q-Cluster scheme improves the fidelity by a factor of 1.46x, on average, compared to the unmitigated output distribution, for a set of low-entropy benchmarks on five different IBM quantum machines. Our approach outperforms the state-of-art QEM approaches RZNE [28], M3 [24], Hammer [35], and QBEEP [33] by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.26 \mathrm{x}, 1.29 \mathrm{x}, 1.47 \mathrm{x}$</tex>, and 2.65 x, respectively.

title: Development of Formation Flight Control Algorithms for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles
authors: Anh Tuan Pham, Trong Tu Nong, Chi Thanh Vo, Van Hoa Duong, My Duyen Ha, Van Ngan Du, Quang Quy Lam, Thuan Hoang Tran
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Informatics (ICCRI)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a formation flight control method for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs). The main objective is to ensure that UAVs can maintain a stable formation, coordinate efficiently, and adapt flexibly to real-time environmental changes. The proposed algorithm integrates centralized control methods, trajectory optimization, and sensor data processing to enhance synchronization among UAVs. Simulation results and practical experiments demonstrate that the algorithm significantly improves formation stability while minimizing positional deviation. This research contributes to increasing the level of autonomy and expanding the applications of UAVs in areas such as surveillance, search and rescue, and terrain mapping.

title: Artificial Intelligence-Powered Protocols for Enhancing Security in Next-Generation Communication Networks
authors: V. Esther Jyothi, Rajashree Rajashree, S Phani, Laxmi Hugar, Ruhisulthana Shaik, Sandeep Poddar
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Rock-solid and real-time security is a burning challenge in the world of next-generation communication technologies, where leading 5G and soon-to-be 6G networks are taking centre stage. Such networks facilitate immense interconnection, low latency as well as high data rate functionality that highly exacerbates the sophistication and intensity of the communication system. Conventional security measures are inadequate to track and counter advanced cyber attack which are highly dynamic and adaptive to the changing network environments. The paper discusses how to incorporate Artificial Intelligence (AI) methods, such as machine learning, deep learning, and reinforcement learning, in the design of security measures powered by Artificial Intelligence. These are smart protocols, which can learn about the behavior of the network, can identify anomalies in real-time and automatically respond to different forms of attacks, including zero-day threats. The proposed method is confirmed by simulation settings and real world data showing better detection rate, more latency, and better flexibility than common approaches. The current study helps in developing the future secure, intelligent, and resilient communication systems.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Retaining Higher-Order Terms in Combinatorial Optimization Problems
authors: Kazuki Ikeuchi, Yoshiki Matsuda, Shu Tanaka
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Ising machines, including quantum annealing machines, are promising next-generation computers for combinatorial optimization problems. Due to hardware limitations, most Ising-type hardware can only solve functions expressed in linear or quadratic terms of binary variables. Therefore, problems with higher-order terms require order reduction, which increases the number of variables and constraints and may degrade solution quality. This study evaluates the effectiveness of directly solving such problems without order reduction by using the polynomial unconstrained binary optimization (PUBO) solver implemented in Toshiba's Simulated Quantum-inspired Bifurcation Machine+ (SQBM+). We compare its performance against a conventional quadratic unconstrained binary optimization (QUBO) solver on the same hardware platform. As benchmarks, we use a vehicle routing problem with distance balancing and the low autocorrelation binary sequence (LABS) problem, both of which naturally include higher-order interactions. Results show that the PUBO solver consistently achieves superior solution quality and stability compared to its QUBO counterpart, while maintaining comparable computational time and requiring no order-reduction compilation, indicating the potential advantages of directly handling higher-order terms in practical optimization problems.

title: Energy Community Management Using Replicator Dynamics and Lagrangian Relaxations
authors: Sofia Chacón, Katerine Guerrero, Germán Obando, Andrés Pantoja
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: Energy management systems (EMSs) are essential for the development and sustainability of energy communities (ECs), as they enable addressing growing energy demand and ensuring the efficient utilization of distributed energy resources (DERs). Efficient models and algorithms are required to optimize resources, reduce generation costs, or mitigate energy losses. In this work, we propose an optimization model that minimizes costs, maximizes generator rewards, and ensures that the energy produced within the EC is efficiently utilized by its members. Additionally, we develop an algorithm that integrates replicator dynamics (RD) with a Lagrangian relaxation (LR) to solve welfare maximization problems. The proposed approach is validated in a scenario with eight agents over 24 hours, achieving a relative error of less than 0.41% in the welfare value compared to a standard interior-point (IP) method. Furthermore, the incorporation of a filtering mechanism is analyzed, showing a better convergence and reduced computational time.

title: Integrated Diffusion Filtering and Edge-Aware Sharpening for Medical Image Enhancement
authors: P. Venkatramana, Okili Naveen Kumar Reddy, Thalari Balaji, Nukala Vamsi Krishna, Pujari Jayanth Kumar, Ramireddypalli Satya Prakash
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Image enhancement is the basic step and most important in medical image analysis which will be used for further processing of the images that are acquired through various sources. This paper presents a multi-scale image enhancement framework that is designed to improve image quality through enhancement process mainly concentrating on the detection of pneumothorax. The proposed method concentrates on iterative diffusion which is done with adaptive coefficients, resulting in edge preservation over the side reduction in noise. This is followed by unsharp masking to improve the structural clarity in the non-edge regions. Further, multi-scale diffusion and non-linear gamma correction are applied to further refine image contrast and sharpness, which are lagging in the existing techniques. The effectiveness of the approach is quantitatively evaluated using PSNR, SSIM and MSE. Experimental results show that the proposed technique outperforms the existing benchmarks with an improvement in PSNR of $29 \%$, SSIM of $14 \%$ and MSE is reduced to a single digit value when compared to the existing techniques having double digit value.

title: Performing an analysis of the attributes of SMART solid-state drives in statistical packages
authors: Saveliy Gordeev, Nikolay Kucherov, Egor Shiriaev, Vitalii Lapin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: The article discusses S.M.A.R.T. (Self-Monitoring Analysis and Reporting Technology) technology as a tool for assessing the condition of hard drives and predicting potential failures. It is emphasized that in-depth analysis of S.M.A.R.T. data is critically important for timely identification of problems and prevention of information loss. The paper proposes a methodology for analyzing S.M.A.R.T. data based on the use of statistical packages. The article focuses on the key S.M.A.R.T. indicators, which are the most informative for fault prediction, and demonstrates the use of statistical methods to identify anomalies and trends in their values.

title: Variational Quantum Linear Solver for Simulating Quantum Transport in Nanoscale Semiconductor Devices
authors: Qimao Yang, Jing Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: This work develops simulation methods that enable the application of the variational quantum linear solver (VQLS) to simulate quantum transport in nanoscale semiconductor devices. Most previous work on VQLS applications in semiconductor device simulations focuses on solving the Poisson equation, where the coefficient matrix of the sparse linear system is real and symmetric. Solving the quantum transport equation, however, leads to coefficient matrices that are complex and non-symmetric. This work addresses the challenges of applying VQLS to quantum transport simulations. We propose new forms of cost functions to solve complex and non-symmetric linear systems with faster computing speed. We further develop efficient decomposition methods for cost function evaluation, which target reducing the quantum circuit complexity and improving noise robustness when solving the quantum transport equation using the nonequilibrium Green's function method. While classical computation faces the challenge of the “curse of dimensionality” as the spatial-energy numerical grid dimensions grow, the proposed quantum-computing-based method scales logarithmically with the grid size, which offers a promising opportunity for addressing the computational challenges of solving quantum transport in semiconductor devices.

title: Study on Visualization Method and Application of Well Doping Issue on 16 Nm FinFET IC
authors: Yanfen Wang, Li Tian, Shijun Zheng, Yi Che, Gaojie Wen
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: With the continuous advancement of semiconductor technology, the device size has reached the nanometer scale. To tackle the challenges of small-size effects like short-channel effects, fin field-effect transistors (FinFETs) have emerged. This study, through an instance of memory built-in self-test (MBIST) fault analysis manifested as threshold voltage drift, elaborately expounds two innovative approaches for visualizing and characterizing WELL doping defects in the Memory area of 16nm FinFET chips at the metal layer. First, passive voltage contrast (PVC) is employed to visually characterize the WELL doping defects at the M1 layer. Second, under the condition of low acceleration voltage, the WELL doping defects are visually characterized at the M0 layer by means of the nano-probe electron beam absorption current (EBAC) test method, and the contour of the WELL doping defects is clarified. Research reveals that this method is not only simple and rapid in the test process, but also less destructive and risky compared to methods such as scanning capacitance microscopy (SCM). More importantly, the methodology successfully achieves the visualization and characterization of large-scale WELL doping defects, allowing us to understand the overall contour of the defects and providing intuitive and accurate data for chip manufacturers to deeply analyze the root causes of failures. The conclusion indicates that this method has significant advantages and application value in the failure analysis of 16FF chips, offering robust technical support for the manufacturing optimization of future chips.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning Models for Cyberbullying Identification in Textual Data
authors: Hema R, Karthika G, Resmi R Nair, Dharshini Ds, Logeshwari P
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Cyberbullying has been a significant issue in online communities, posing threats to individuals' mental and social health. This paper examines the use of deep learning and natural language processing (NLP) methods for automated cyberbullying detection in text data. A complete preprocessing pipeline is applied, involving URL and mention removal, stop-word removal, and text normalization, to improve data quality for model training. For the detection issue, various architectures of deep learning are used, i.e., Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs), Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), and hybrid models like CNN-LSTM and CNN-GRU. Tokenization and padding on the dataset ensure equal input length before training on the model. Evaluation on performance is done on accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score with comparative analysis on all models. Experimental evidence reveals that hybrid models are more accurate than independent CNN and RNN architectures, with better classification accuracy and generalization. This highlights the potential of combining deep learning and NLP methods in building automated systems for cyberbullying identification. This work's findings can inform the development of AI-powered content moderation tools, leading to safer, more inclusive, and robust digital spaces.

title: Stochastic MILP-Based Optimal Placement and Sizing of PV and Wind Generators Using Discrete Scenario Modeling
authors: Juan C. Ramirez Arias, Luis A. Gallego Pareja, Oscar Gomez Carmona
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: This paper addresses the optimal placement and size of photovoltaic (PV) and wind turbine (WT) generation units in power distribution systems under uncertainty. The variability in solar irradiance and wind speed is modeled using two-parameter Weibull distributions, and a scenario-based approach is applied to capture the stochastic nature of the energy resources. Scenarios are generated using the method-ology proposed by Bertsimas and Sim, to ensure a balance between representativeness and tractability. These scenarios are incorporated into a Mixed-Integer Linear Programming (MILP) model that optimizes the allocation of renewable resources while satisfying operational and technical constraints. The proposed approach is validated on the 69-bus distribution test system, demonstrating its effectiveness in managing uncertainty and improving system performance.

title: An Adversarial Approach for Urban Anomaly Detection Across Completion Spatiotemporal Data
authors: Xinghong Jiang, Yong Ma, Changhao Jin, Jiang Luo, Yunni Xia, Yongzhao Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Urban anomalous events, such as traffic congestion and unexpected crowd gatherings, can threaten public safety if not detected in time. Early detection is crucial for enhancing urban safety. However, urban anomaly detection is faced with two major challenges. First, learning anomaly distributions from traffic data is complicated due to the scarcity of anomaly datasets. Second, accurately modeling traffic dynamics is hindered by the frequent absence of traffic datasets. To address these challenges, we propose a adversarial approach for urban anomaly detection across completion spatiotemporal data ($A^{2}-C S T$). This method involves a spatiotemporal generator that predicts normal traffic dynamics and a discriminator that differentiates predicted values from real data. Both components are trained adversarially to mitigate the issue of scarce anomaly data. Given the inherent correlation between nodes in the spatiotemporal dimension, we introduce a data completion method based on federated learning. This method combines knowledge from similar nodes with local data to optimize the local data completion model, addressing missing traffic data. We validate the $A^{2}-C S T$ method on both real-world and simulated datasets. The experimental results show that $A^{2}-C S T$ outperforms existing methods in detecting anomalous events. Moreover, the proposed data completion method enhances the effectiveness of $A^{2}-C S T$ in anomaly detection.

title: The Effect of Training Strategy on Image Classification Using Representations of Learning-Based Image Compression
authors: Fariba Saadati-Monem, Azadeh Mansouri, Ahmad Mahmoudi-Aznaveh, Hossein Motamednia
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: The use of images is no longer limited to humans, as machines have also become consumers of images. With the expansion of neural networks, image-based analytical tools have been developed. Conventional compression approaches like JPEG, H.264, and HEVC are designed to maintain visual quality for human viewing, but they are not optimized for deep learning models employed in computer vision tasks such as classification, segmentation, and object recognition. In addition to superior compression performance, learning-based image compression methods can integrate seamlessly with analytical tasks by utilizing the scalable feature space they generate for computer vision tasks. In this study, a learning-based image compression network is combined with an image classification network and trained using an interactive approach. Employing this approach in network training enhances the scalability of compressed-domain features and stabilizes the training process. The results demonstrate that this approach not only preserves and improves the performance of the compression network compared to traditional methods but also stabilizes the training process and achieves better accuracy for image classification using the extracted features. On average, the proposed method achieves a performance improvement of 7.99%.

title: A Ladmm Beamforming Method with Asynchronous Admm-Based Distributed Training
authors: Jiawei Lei, Yuhao Yang, Shen Dong, Junxia Xiao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: This paper presents a LADMM (Learned ADMM) beamforming method employing asynchronous ADMM-based distributed training for array signal processing. Exploiting ADMM's ability to decompose global optimization into local subproblems with minimal variable exchange, we implement a Ray-based asynchronous parameter-server architecture to accelerate LADMM training across multiple nodes. Experiments demonstrate substantial improvements in training efficiency and scalability compared with single-node training, while maintaining robust beamforming performance under severe interference. The results highlight the potential of asynchronous ADMM for efficient distributed deep learning in adaptive beamforming applications.

title: Motor Fault Detection in VSC-HVDC Converter Station Valve Cooling Systems Using Small-Sample Anomaly Feature Mining and Acoustic Fingerprint Recognition
authors: Shi Jiao, Jiancheng Zhang, Mingming Zhong, Sijun Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: The low fault incidence and stable operation of motors in VSC-HVDC converter station valve cooling systems limit the availability of typical fault samples. To address this, a novel fault detection method is proposed by integrating a small-sample anomaly feature mining algorithm with acoustic fingerprint recognition. Piezoelectric accelerometers are used for data acquisition, with sensor placement optimized via Pearson correlation. A hybrid EMD-wavelet denoising technique reduces diagnostic errors, and anomaly features are extracted from the processed data for fault detection. Experimental results confirm improved accuracy and robustness against interference, demonstrating strong practical value.

title: Ultra-High Contrast Visualization of SiN/SiO Layer Using OBF STEM
authors: Masayasu Yoneda, Yuhiro Segawa, Masahide Shima, Kyoichiro Asayama, Shuji Kawai, Kazuya Yamazaki
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (STEM), one of the techniques in Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), is widely used to analyze the structure of semiconductor devices. In conventional STEM imaging such as Bright-Field (BF), Annular Bright-Field (ABF), Low-Angle Annular Dark-Field (LAADF) and High-Angle Annular Dark-Field (HAADF), the contrast depends on the atomic numbers of the elements in the observed specimen, as well as the atomic density along the direction of the electron beam. However, for layer structures like Silicon Nitride (SiN) / Silicon Oxide (SiO), it has been challenging to distinguish between layers because each layer sometimes consists of a similar composition, such as Silicon oxynitride (SiON). In this report, we introduce the Optimum Bright Field (OBF) STEM, is highly sensitive to differences in the specimen's projected potential, including variations in electromagnetic fields, composition, and atomic density. We performed observation and elemental analysis on a specimen with SiO/SiN layer using STEM. The interfaces of layer structure were not clearly observed in BF, ABF, LAADF, and HAADF images obtained under standard conditions. However, by appropriately adjusting the convergence angle and acquiring ultra-high contrast OBF images, the interfaces of the layer structure was clearly observed. SiN/SiO layer structure verified by OBF image was equivalent to Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) result.

title: Assessing Blue-Collar Workers Cognitive Skills Through Gamified Tasks and Analytics
authors: Vanya Gupta, Hitendra Vaishnav
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: This study presents a gamified framework for assessing the cognitive abilities of blue-collar workers in the manufacturing sector. Conventional cognitive testing methods, such as the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA), fail to capture the dynamic and high-pressure decision-making skills required for operating complex machinery. To address this gap, six Python-based mini-games were developed using Pygame to evaluate attention, memory, spatial reasoning, problem solving, and decision-making. A cohort of 20 industrial workers was assessed, and the total gamified scores demonstrated a strong positive correlation with MoCA results (r = 0.74, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.682). Furthermore, cognitive retraining and job-role reassignment of a welding operator showed significant improvements in both cognitive performance and operational efficiency. These findings establish the novelty and significance of gamified cognitive assessment as a scalable, engaging, and cost-effective approach to workforce optimization. The research outcomes contribute to industrial safety, productivity enhancement, and informed workforce deployment strategies.

title: AI-enabled Framework for Intrusion Detection in DNP3-Enabled Smart Critical Infrastructures
authors: Devam Patel, Jigar Bhoye, Fenil Ramoliya, Rajesh Gupta, Sudeep Tanwar, Hossein Shahinzadeh, Mahtab Bagheri
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: Smart Critical Infrastructure (SCI) systems, such as traffic monitoring systems, water treatment plants and power plants etc. have become an important aspects of our day-to-day life activities. Even though they provide a lot of benefits by using sensors and analysing data, SCI systems have now become vulnerable to cyber security related threats. Vulnerabilities in Distributed Network protocols, like Distributed Network Protocol 3 (DNP3) will make our systems more prone to security breaches. This paper introduces an ensemble learning based network analysis for improved and more reliable intrusion detection system in SCI and DNP3 based architectures. The ensemble model uses multiple AI models to detect breaches, improved accuracy and stability. AI techniques for decision-making are performed. The main content of this work include detailed analysis of the performance of ensemble model, high accuracy in intrusion detection and the consistency of the model in successfully determining attacks across multiple datasets and can handle various types of attack. The proposed framework will enhance the intrusion detection effectively which is very important for protecting smart critical infrastructure from cyber attacks.

title: Accurate and Scalable Simulation of Cavity-Based Networks in Modular Quantum Architectures
authors: Sahar Ben Rached, Zezhou Sun, Guilu Long, Santiago Rodrigo, Carmen G. Almudéver, Eduard Alarcón, Sergi Abadal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Cavity-mediated interconnects are a promising platform for scaling modular quantum computers by enabling highfidelity inter-chip quantum state transmission and entanglement generation. In this work, we first model the dynamics of deterministic inter-chip quantum state transfer using the Stimulated Raman Adiabatic Passage (STIRAP) protocol, analyzing fidelity loss mechanisms under experimentally achievable qubitcavity coupling and decoherence parameters. We then extend the NetSquid simulator, typically used for simulating longrange quantum communication networks, to support cavity-based communication channels for mediating inter-chip state transfer and entanglement generation. We model cavities as amplitude damping channels parameterized by physical system characteristics; cavity decay rate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\kappa$</tex> and qubit-cavity coupling strength <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$g$</tex>, and analyze the impact of intrinsic qubit decoherence factors dictated by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T_{1}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T_{2}$</tex> times. Our simulations accurately represent the system's dynamics in both strong and weak coupling regimes, and identify critical trade-offs between fidelity, latency, and noise factors. The proposed framework supports faithful modeling and scalable simulation of modular architectures, and provides insights into design optimization for practical quantum network implementations.

title: Transformer-based Action Recognition Employing Informative Frames
authors: Alireza Rahnama, Adel Pour Bordbari, Azadeh Mansouri
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: Transformer models are widely used in many fields and have achieved remarkable success in modeling sequential data such as NLP, audio processing, and video understanding. In this paper, we present a novel method for frame selection and action recognition in videos; to select more suitable frames, we choose the most informative data by comparing the similarity between frames. In the next step, we extract features from the selected frames using transfer learning, and in the last step, we perform the final classification using the transformer model. Our proposed CNN-Transformer method achieves the recognition accuracies of 99.37% and 97.53% for UCF-11, and KTH action datasets respectively, which are two popular datasets in the field of action recognition.

title: One-Class Lightweight Interpretable Filtering For Academic Profiles and Strategic Themes Affinity
authors: Marcos Paulo Silva Gôlo, Matheus Yasuo Ribeiro Utino
publish: 2025 IEEE/SBC 37th International Symposium on Computer Architecture and High Performance Computing Workshops (SBAC-PADW)
abstract: Filtering affinity between strategic themes and academic profiles plays a key role in public policies, mainly in Brazil. Although large language models (LLMs) currently represent the state-of-the-art in text mining, they suffer from limitations such as high computational and financial costs, as well as substantial electricity consumption, particularly in High-Performance Computing environments, which leads to significant carbon emissions. These factors highlight the need for lightweight filtering mechanisms to avoid unnecessary LLM calls. Unsupervised similarity-based filters and binary classifiers also face challenges, including a lack of theme specificity and the requirement for large amounts of labeled data. To address these issues, we propose the use of theme-specific one-class learning, where classifiers are trained using only positive high-affinity examples, combined with the theme description and its keywords. This approach aims to reduce carbon emissions while maintaining filter performance. It requires only a small amount of labeled data, making it suitable even for themes with few known profiles, and provides theme-specific adaptability. We leverage embeddings derived from language models to ensure computational efficiency, and project these embeddings into two dimensions to guarantee interpretability, enabling visualization of the decision function and supporting parameter tuning. Our experiments demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms a textual similarity baseline with similar carbon emissions, achieving higher f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>-scores in identifying relevant pairs. Additionally, the method’s interpretability proved valuable for understanding model decisions and generating insights into the data.

title: Abnormal Oxygen Failure Analysis on a Tri-layer Au/Pd/Ni Surface Finish
authors: Yanfei Zhao, Qingrui Jiao, Tuanqiao Hu, Zhiyuan Wang, Huihong Yuan, Lei Zhu, Xiaomin Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: Surface finishing technologies play a crucial role in printed circuit board (PCB) assembly and its reliability. A tri-layer of Gold/Palladium/Nickle (Au/Pd/Ni) stacking structure has been widely used as a metal surface finish on chip-carrier boards and high-end PCBs. The key role of surface finishes is to prevent oxidation and to preserve solderability. However, the oxidation is difficult to avoid especially for Ni. Conventionally, XPS depth profile is the top priority choice to study the oxygen residual in a tri-layer Au/Pd/Ni pad. However, in this failure case, due to Au and Pd element that were diffused into the Ni layer during XPS depth profiling, it is difficult to make an accurate judgement if there is oxygen residual. The results demonstrated that AES combined with TOFSIMS technique is proven to be an effective method for this particular failure case.

title: Harnessing Environment-Mediated Crosstalk: Mutual Performance Enhancement in Parallel Quantum Annealing
authors: Jargalsaikhan Artag, Koki Awaya, Takumi Kanezashi, Daisuke Tsukayama, Moe Shimada, Jun-Ichi Shirakashi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Parallel Quantum Annealing (PQA) is a technique to improve computational throughput by running multiple independent problems concurrently. However, the concurrent execution of independent problems on a shared physical device gives rise to the possibility of unintended crosstalk mediated by the hardware environment. This work investigates a novel strategy to not only probe but actively harness these interactions. We hypothesize that applying relative time offsets to the annealing schedules of parallel problems can control these environment-mediated dynamics. To show this, we executed two independent ferromagnetic Ising chains (up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N=500$</tex> qubits) in parallel on a D-Wave quantum annealer, systematically varying the schedule offset of one chain relative to the other. Our experimental results reveal a strong, non-monotonic dependence of the Ground State Probability (GSP) on the applied offset. Most significantly, we discovered non-zero offset regimes where both concurrently running problems achieved higher GSPs than their respective single-run baselines. This counter-intuitive finding of mutual performance enhancement suggests a controllable, cooperative dynamic mediated by the shared quantum environment. This reframes environmental crosstalk from a simple source of error into a potential resource, opening new avenues for schedule optimization and for probing the complex open-system dynamics of near-term quantum devices.

title: Constructing Optimal Noise Channels for Enhanced Robustness in Quantum Machine Learning
authors: David Winderl, Nicola Franco, Jeanette Miriam Lorenz
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum Machine Learning (QML) is rapidly evolving. Recent studies suggest that quantum noise could improve classifier robustness. To verify this claim, we developed a semidefinite programming model that, given a dataset and a QML ansatz, constructs the most robust noise channel possible. In our smallscale experiments, we first explore the range of behaviors generated by this optimized noise channel. Secondly, we show that, despite recent claims, the direct impact of noise is modest compared to the substantial robustness improvements achieved through increasing the number of qubits. Aside from that, we utilize our framework to assess different noise channels in terms of their robustness and certifiability.

title: Wide Range Capacitive Readout Circuit Using Sampling and Integration Method
authors: Shukri Bin Korakkottil Kunhi Mohd, Hazem Zainal, Ruhaifi Abdullah Zawawi, Sofiyah Sal Hamid, Nuha A. Rhaffor, Asrulnizam Abd Manaf
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: This paper presents a design and simulation of a capacitance-to-voltage readout circuit tailored for wide-range capacitance sensing. The design is implemented using 180 nm CMOS process technology. The proposed method is based on sampling and integration mechanisms of switched-capacitor by utilizing the capacitor ratio to achieve high sensitivity and accuracy in relative capacitance readout. A number of integrations defines the readout range, where a higher number of integrations is required for a lower capacitance readout. As for the simulation, the design leverages capacitance detection at the sub-pF capacitance range. The results show 0.1mV/2fF and 0.4mV/100fF resolutions for 1-20fF and 0.1-1pF ranges obtained by pre-configuring the input voltage and number of integrations. The output is suitable for digitization using an Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC), which is then ready for further processing with a Microcontroller Unit (MCU).

title: Research on Tire Joint Quality Prediction Based on LSTM-Transformer Optimized by EI-MOBO
authors: Qingduo Hu, Wei Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: In the tire manufacturing industry, existing traditional prediction methods often fail to meet the requirements of intelligent industrial production. This paper proposes a prediction model based on the LSTM-Transformer hybrid architecture, combined with the innovative MOBO-EI (Multi-Objective Bayesian Optimization with Expected Improvement) algorithm for hyperparameter optimization. The LSTM-Transformer model adopts a dual-channel design: the LSTM layer captures longterm temporal dependency features, and the multi-head attention mechanism identifies the influence weights of key production nodes. After the fusion of these two types of features, a multiobjective quality prediction is output through the fully connected layer. This paper presents a multi-objective Bayesian optimization algorithm with expected improvement, which innovatively integrates the Expected Improvement (EI) acquisition function on the basis of the probabilistic surrogate model of Bayesian optimization. It simultaneously optimizes the model validation loss and complexity (parameter scale) to obtain Pareto optimal solutions. Experiments show that on the real tire production dataset, the optimized model proposed in this paper achieves remarkable results. It improves the MSE by 30% and the MAE by 20%. It is particularly effective in predicting targets of different scales, among which the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{2}$</tex> of the small-scale model is increased by 30%, showing obvious improvements compared with traditional models.

title: Gradient Bandit Experts For Node Selection In Edge Computing
authors: Saleh Abdullah Alfahad, Shameem A Puthiya Parambath, Christos Anagnostopoulos
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Node selection is a critical issue in Edge Computing (EC), necessitating the identification of appropriate edge nodes for effective execution of tasks. This process entails maneuvering through limitations such as restricted resources, fluctuating network conditions, and heterogeneous processing capabilities among nodes. The efficacy and overall performance of EC systems are significantly reliant on the optimization of node selection algorithms. Due to the dynamic and varied characteristics of EC environments, adaptive strategies utilizing real-time feedback are crucial. To tackle this issue, we present ExpGradBand, an innovative technique designed for node selection in EC. ExpGradBand expands the Multiarmed Bandit (MAB) framework by using gradient-based selection methods alongside historical contextual data to improve decision-making performance. We assess the usefulness of ExpGradBand by comprehensive experiments in comparison to leading algorithms. The findings emphasize the exceptional value of ExpGradBand.

title: Repositioning Quantum Cellular Automata for Dependable Quantum-Classical Systems
authors: Nicholas H. Stapleton, Vicente Leyton-Ortega
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum Cellular Automata (QCA) provides a structured model of distributed quantum computation with inherent locality and regularity properties that are suited to dependable execution. However, QCA remain largely absent from discussions on reproducibility, fault management, and orchestration in heterogeneous quantum-classical systems. We propose a dual-axis framework that situates QCA within both computation and physical realizability, revealing regions where robust, scalable, and hardware-constrained quantum dynamics may reside. By revisiting prior results through the lens of reproducibility and architecture resilience, we suggest that QCA offers a potential substrate for benchmarking and system-level co-design.

title: A Novel Deep Learning Framework for Brain Tumor Detection Enhanced by Runge-Kutta Optimization
authors: Soheil Sheikh Ahmadi, Alireza Sheikh Ahmadi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: Brain tumors are among the most severe medical conditions, and achieving timely and precise diagnosis is crucial for enhancing treatment effectiveness and patient survival. In this study, we propose an advanced deep learning approach that integrates a Runge-Kutta Inspired Optimization Algorithm (RKIO) to optimize the classification of brain tumors. By leveraging principles from numerical differential equations, RKIO dynamically adjusts hyperparameters such as learning rate and weight updates, enhancing both convergence speed and model stability. The framework integrates a pretrained Xception network for feature extraction, advanced data augmentation (e.g., brightness adjustment), and strategically placed dropout layers to reduce overfitting. Fine-tuning through selective unfreezing of higher layers further adapts the model to domain-specific MRI data. Experiments on a publicly available brain tumor MRI dataset achieved a classification accuracy of 96.5%, with consistently high precision and recall. These findings demonstrate the effectiveness of the RKIO-based framework in improving the robustness and accuracy of medical image analysis, paving the way for more reliable automated diagnostic systems in healthcare.

title: PrepGenius: An AI Interview Assistant
authors: Sushma Nagdeote, Ashton Serrao, Pearl Dsouza, Namrata Joshi, Sujata Chiwande
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The competitive job market forces candidates to struggle with ATS rejections together with inadequate interview skills and restricted career path visibility. This paper describes PrepGenius which is an AI-powered job preparation platform designed to solve these difficulties through natural language processing alongside facial and speech recognition and customized feedback. The platform evaluates resume quality by analyzing ATS compatibility through its keyword extraction system. The platform delivers immediate mock interview sessions with performance evaluation tools and generates customized multiple-choice assessments from job posting details. The platform delivers three key benefits including enhanced resume evaluation results and improved candidate self-assurance through communication feedback along with individual career direction based on performance monitoring. PrepGenius operates as a scalable smart user-friendly solution for job readiness through Django and Tailwind CSS, SQLite and OpenCV, MediaPipe, Google Gemini API and Speech Recognition technologies. The research demonstrates that AI technology enables substantial improvements in employability through analytical insights combined with customized recommendations.
