title: Effective and Scalable Path Planning and Motion Coordination for Four-Way Shuttle Vehicles in Storage/Retrieval Systems
authors: Xingyao Han, Zhe Liu, Jieshi Xu, Yuhong Tan, Hesheng Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Recently, Shuttle-Based Storage and Retrieval Systems (SBS/RSs) have emerged as a cornerstone of modern robotic handling systems. However, motion conflicts between four-way shuttle vehicles are introduced frequently due to the sparsely connected roadmap topology. Furthermore, the different time and energy costs between linear and direction-changing motions bring additional difficulties for classic solvers when applied directly. To address these issues, we propose Dynamic Graph-Driven A* (DGA*) for cooperative path planning in SBS/RSs. By fully exploiting the structured topology of SBS/RS roadmaps, the algorithm extracts sector-level topological graphs enriched with spatiotemporal attributes, effectively resolving conflicts while simultaneously optimizing motion costs. In addition, Recursive Preemption and Avoidance (RPA) is introduced to ensure motion coordination in congestion-prone areas commonly seen in SBS/RSs, through a combination of independent avoidance and recursive avoidance mechanisms. We implement our approach in a real warehouse with more than 240 vehicles and achieve a 17% improvement in system throughput while reducing runtime.

title: Digital Twin Architecture Design and Testbed Deployment for Satellite-Terrestrial Integrated Networks
authors: Luhui Wang, Xiao Ma, Jianyong Fan, Fulin Li, Ying Li
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Satellite-Terrestrial Integrated Network (STIN), with its wider coverage and more flexible network structure over its counterparts, is a crucial application scenario for the Sixth Generation (6G) mobile communications. However, the depolyment of network infrastructure and verification of related technologies are challenging. Therefore, a novel test framework is urgently needed to advance research outputs on STINs. Motivated by the recent proliferation of Digital Twin (DT) technology, the DT empowered STIN platform has been considered as a key enabling technology for the future 6G-based Internet of Everything (IoE). Nevertheless, there is still a lack of effective cases of applying DT technology in STINs. In this work, we discuss the importance of DT technology for the research and development of STINs. The prototype of the Multilayer Modular Architecture (MMA) for the DT in STIN is proposed. Through a hierarchical and modular design, the model is made more versatile and extensible. Meanwhile, aiming at the difficulties in multiple access caused by the high dynamics and large-scale delays in STINs, we propose a lightweight multiple-access protocol and take it as an application case of MMA. Furthermore, the test platform and the deployment scheme that we suggest are presented. Finally, the test results show that MMA can correctly verify the working logic of the proposed protocol in STIN, which provides an important reference for future research in IoE technology.

title: Dilated Transformation-Guided Unsupervised Multimodal Learning for Hyperspectral and Multispectral Image Fusion
authors: Yuanchao Su, Sheng Li, Yicong Zhou, Lianru Gao, Mengying Jiang, Xu Sun, Haiwei Li, Enke Hou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Multimodal fusion widely uses convolutional layers to capture local correlations and adjust feature dimensions. However, the progressive expansion of the receptive field in convolutional layers often compromises spatial context retention, leading to the loss of fine details. Furthermore, the fixed-size kernels typically used in standard convolution restrict the network’s ability to capture multiscale contextual details. To address this limitation, this paper develops a dilated transformation-guided unsupervised multimodal learning (DTUML) method to fuse a high-resolution multispectral image (HR-MSI) and a low-resolution hyperspectral image (LR-HSI), thereby generating a high-resolution hyperspectral image (HR-HSI). Our DTUML adopts a dual-stream encoder architecture to conduct multimodal data, where one stream focuses on preserving spectral information from LR-HSIs, while the other emphasizes the acquisition of spatial details from HR-MSIs. These complementary features are subsequently integrated to ensure spectral fidelity and retain spatial detail. Then, a convolutional layer restores dimensional consistency and outputs an HR-HSI. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of DTUML, showing superior performance and strong competitiveness compared to state-of-the-art methods. Code: https://github.com/yuanchaosu/TGRS-DTUML.

title: Online Gain Selection for Induction Machine State Observers Using a Genetic Algorithms
authors: Daniel Wachowiak
abstract: Sensorless induction machine drives rely on state estimators whose gains affect stability, dynamic response, and robustness; however, these gains are typically tuned offline by experts using iterative simulations and specialized tools. This paper proposes a fully automated, online gain-selection algorithm executed directly on the drive’s microcontroller using a genetic algorithm. The method utilizes a versatile fitness function based on pole placement of a linearized estimator model. To ensure safe deployment, an on-target verification stage has been employed that validates the candidate gains for stability and adequate dynamic performance across a wide range of rotor speed prior to deployment in the target control system. The approach is generic to observers for which a linearized dynamic representation can be obtained, and its feasibility is demonstrated on two representative cases: a simple flux observer and a higher-order extended speed observer, confirming scalability under resource constraints typical of production microcontrollers. Results indicate that the proposed scheme achieves reliable gain selection on embedded hardware without external computing infrastructure.

title: Microstrip Ring Sector Dual-Circularly Polarized Antenna with Tilted Beams
authors: Jian Yu, Bei-Yan Shi, Zhan-Ming Chen
abstract: This paper presents a design approach for a fundamental-mode-based microstrip ring sector antenna capable of dual-circularly polarized (CP) radiation with tilted beams. Theoretical analysis, grounded in multi-mode resonance theory, reveals that the desired symmetric dual-CP radiation is achievable under radial asymmetric and circumferential symmetry boundary conditions by reshaping the truncated leaky-wave antenna-derived patch structure. As a proof of the design approach, a prototype featuring a flared angle of 180° and a radius ratio of 4.0 is implemented with a low profile of 0.041-wavelength. Measurement results demonstrate an impedance bandwidth of 17.1% and 3dB axial ratio bandwidths of 14.5% (θ = -25°), 12.0% (θ = +25°) and 13.6% (θ = +30°) at the φ = 90° plane, with enhanced gains of 4.55, 4.74 and 4.80 dBic. The design outperforms conventional counterparts by achieving high performance using a simplified single-layer structure, striking a balance between performance and complexity.

title: Prescribed-time Tracking Control for Constrained Nonlinear Systems with Hysteresis and Its Application to Piezoelectric Positioning Stage
authors: Heyu Hu, Shengjun Wen, Xinyuan Tian, Changan Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper studies the prescribed time tracking control problem of constrained nonlinear systems with hysteresis. With the help of system transformation technology, the convergence time and constrained boundaries are combined into common system variables of a newly unconstrained system, whose stabilization indicates that the effect of prescribed time control can be achieved, and all states remain within the constraint range. The designed neuroadaptive controller has the following three features: (1) The convergence time and tracking accuracy of the system error can be flexibly selected, and the initial error of the system does not need to be kept within the pre-set boundary range; (2) It introduces a unified constraint transformation method capable of handling both performance-related soft constraints and safety-critical hard constraints for prescribed-time tracking; (3) A polynomial-based envelope function is integrated into the play operator of the modified Prandtl-Ishlinskii model, thereby enhancing its capability to accurately characterize asymmetric hysteresis nonlinearities. The effectiveness of this method is verified through a piezoelectric positioning system.

title: BoNC: Discovering and Classifying Novel Encrypted Botnet Traffic
authors: Huancheng Hu, Ziyun Li, Christian Doerr
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Constantly evolving botnets pose high risks to cyber infrastructure, resulting in evasion of defence system, disruption of critical services and catastrophic financial damage. Therefore, it is crucial for effective botnet traffic detection to discover and identify new emerging threat. Although recent deep learning-based methods performed well at classifying known botnet traffic but failed to handle unseen threats. This deficiency enables novel botnets to remain undetected, evade existing defenses, and inflict severe damage in real-world scenarios. To address these gaps, we propose a unified framework, Botnet Novel-class Classification (BoNC), which multi-classifies unlabelled encrypted botnet traffic by leveraging known classes to establish decision boundaries for previously unseen ones. We evaluate BoNC on three public encrypted traffic datasets with diverse labelled and unlabelled ratio configurations. BoNC consistently outperforms prior state-of-the-art methods and accurately classifies known botnets and discovers unseen botnet variants in open-world scenarios.

title: Acoustic Frequency Comb-Based QPSK Demodulation Using Nonlinear MEMS Resonators
authors: Ting-Yi Chen, Wei-Chang Li
abstract: This work demonstrates a microelectromechanical systems (MEMS)-based phase shift keying demodulator that leverages nonlinear resonators. In particular, this work employs an internal-resonating MEMS resonator that generates acoustic frequency combs. The spacing of these combs is dynamically modulated by a primary driving signal and an auxiliary signal that carries the phase-encoded information. The discrete variations in comb spacing serve as the demodulation metric, enabling accurate retrieval of the original phase-encoded data. This approach offers a feedforward demodulation structure, which obviates the need for phase-locked loops and mitigates potential I/Q mismatch issues. Through slightly tailored actuation configurations, both simulations and experiments present successful demodulations of binary and quadrature phase-shifted signals. This work presents a promising alternative to transistor-based demodulation systems and marks a significant step toward MEMS-based radio frequency front-ends.

title: Prognostic value of microvessel density at the boundary of invasive breast cancer patients based on multiphoton microscopy
authors: Liqin Zheng, Jianping Huang, Deyong Kang, Xi Chen, Zhen Lu, Jiajia He, Gangqin Xi, Zhijun Li, Xiahui Han, Lianhuang Li, Jianhua Chen, Chuan Wang, Zhonghua Han, Jianxin Chen, Wenhui Guo, Na Fang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Quantum Electronics
abstract: Peritumoral microvessels at the boundary of invasive cancer tissues were obtained from 602 patients using multiphoton microscopy (MPM) according to their relative spatial distribution between microvessels, tumor nests and collagen fibers. Microvessel density score (MVD-score) for each patient was obtained based on MPM images, and the prognostic value of peritumoral MVD was evaluated using Cox proportional hazards regression, receiver operating characteristic analysis, and Kaplan-Meier survival analysis. The results showed that MVD-score was an independent prognostic factor for disease-free survival and overall survival of patients with invasive breast cancer. By analyzing the clinical model (combined clinical independent factors), MVD model and nomogram model (combined MVD-score with clinical independent factors), we found that MVD model could achieve better prognostic predictive effects than each individual clinical independent prognostic factor, and achieve a prognostic value similar to that of the clinical model. In addition, the nomogram model improved the prognostic value of the clinical model after adding MVD-score.

title: Distributed MPC with SQP for Coordinated V-Formation of Omnidirectional Robots in Static Obstacle Fields
authors: Tuan P. Duong, Hoang T. Tran, Vinh Q. Nguyen, Long Q. Dinh, Uy V. Le, Minh T. Nguyen
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Informatics (ICCRI)
abstract: This paper presents a distributed model predictive control (DMPC) framework enhanced with sequential quadratic programming (SQP) for coordinating omnidirectional mobile robot formations in static obstacle environments. The proposed method enables a team of robots arranged in a predefined V-shaped formation to follow a zigzag trajectory led by a designated leader robot. Each follower robot optimizes its local control inputs based on predicted trajectories of its neighbors within a directed communication graph, enabling decentralized execution. A unified cost function is formulated to balance formation maintenance, trajectory tracking, obstacle avoidance, and control effort. Simulation results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed approach in maintaining the desired formation while avoiding successfully obstacles along the zigzag path. The framework offers a scalable solution for real-time formation control in structured environments.

title: Distributed Quantum Bit-Phase-Flip Error Correction based on CSS Codes and GHZ States
authors: Shahram Babaie, Chunming Qiao
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: This paper introduces a new Distributed Quantum Error Correction (DQEC) architecture based on Calderbank-Steane-Shor (CSS) codes to address the limitations of physical qubit availability in monolithic systems. The original quantum state is first distributed across the Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ) state, generated on seven distinct Quantum Processing Units (QPUs), and then encoded as superpositions of even-weight and odd-weight components of the CSS code. By distributing the seven physical qubits needed for a logical qubit based on CSS, each QPU can accommodate more logical qubits compared to conventional (non-distributed) cases where all the physical qubits of a logical qubit are confined to a single QPU. The effectiveness of the proposed architecture is evaluated in terms of its ability to detect X-errors, Z-errors, and Y-errors through stabilizer generators.

title: Using Fog Computing to Accelerate Metagenomic Data Analysis
authors: Ekaterina Bezuglova, Nikolay Kucherov, Maria Lapina, E A Mary Anita, D Vinodha, A K Sujatha, J Jenefa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: This article discusses the challenges of processing and analyzing metagenomic data, the volume of which is continuously increasing due to the development of sequencing technologies. Traditional methods such as cloud computing and supercomputing face limitations such as high latency, network dependency, high costs and data security risks. Alternatively, fog computing and hybrid architectures are proposed to distribute the computational load between local devices and cloud systems. This reduces latency, optimizes costs and improves data security. The paper analyzes the advantages of fog computing in metagenomic data analysis, compares it with traditional methods and suggests ways to implement this technology in bioinformatics. The results show that fog computing systems and hybrid systems are promising solutions for applications requiring fast analysis and high data security, such as medical diagnostics and environmental monitoring. title: CAAFR: Comparative Analysis of Amazon and Flipkart Reviews
authors: Akshatha G, Joel A, Karthik K H, Katta Navya, M Kavacin
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: We explore product reviews of Amazon and Flipkart in three large product categories: Electronics, Books, and Food, to systematically analyze the relative strengths and weaknesses of both platforms with the help of machine learning. The reviews were web scraped, preprocessed, and preserved in Comma-Separated Values (CSV) files for training and testing. Sentiment labeling was done using both the Bag of Words model and Valence Aware Dictionary and sEntiment Reasoner (VADER) to allow both rule-based and statistical views of sentiment identification. Trained models were run on the server side, and their accuracy was determined through accuracy scores, precision, recall, F1-scores, and confusion matrices. To facilitate interpretability, interactive visualizations were built with Streamlit so that users can analyze sentiment distributions, model comparisons, and temporal changes in customer opinions. Results show clear differences in customer sentiment trends between platforms and product categories, which are actionable inputs for enhancing customer experience and platform stability. This work reinforces the usefulness of integrating web scraping, natural language processing, and machine learning to uncover insights on consumer behavior in e-commerce. Potential future expansions can involve expanding to other domains, implementing deep learning-based sentiment models, and using advanced feature extraction methods for higher predictive quality.

title: Deep Learning for Inclusive Psoriasis Diagnosis: Enhancing Accuracy with DenseNet-121
authors: P. SenthilKumaran, B. Indrani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Globally, psoriasis affects more than 125 million people and causes red, scaly patches that cause both physical and emotional distress. Despite the need for accurate and timely diagnosis, current clinical practices have limitations. Historically, medical imaging datasets have been underrepresented or subjectively assessed. Psoriasis Skin Dataset is used in this work to detect and assess the severity of psoriasis. Over 2,800 images with various skin tones and psoriasis manifestations are included. Using DenseNet-121 and ResNet50 deep learning models, along with robust data augmentation and image preprocessing. Using this research, the work aims to improve diagnosis accuracy and generalization of psoriasis. In addition to addressing dataset biases, hair interference, and lesion variability, innovative solutions enhance model performance. These models provide a more equitable and reliable method for diagnosing psoriasis through accurate classification and severity evaluation. This work has DenseNet121 achieving 98.5%, ResNet- 50 achieving 97.14%, and CNN achieving 96.2%. Multi-disease detection and personalized dermatological care are also improved by this work. In the long run, it facilitates the diagnosis of psoriasis and supports better patient outcomes.

title: Triangular Shaped Half Mode Substrate Integrated Waveguide (THMSIW) Antenna for Sub-6GHz and WiMAX Applications
authors: V Shiva Prasad Nayak, Kaumudi Manthri, Venkata Sai Krishna Perali, Manjunathachari K, Ramyasree Monamgari
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: This paper presents a compact, Triangular Shaped Half Mode Substrate Integrated Waveguide (THMSIW) Antenna for Sub-6GHz and WiMAX Applications. The proposed antenna is implemented on an FR-4 substrate having a thickness of 1.6mm and also having dielectric constant of 4.3 and copper material thickness of 0.035mm. The antenna is loaded with semicircular and hexagonal slots on the top of the patch and a rectangular slot on the bottom of the radiating ground plane to achieve the dual-band performance. The antenna is simulated and optimized using CST Studio Suite software. The results demonstrate successful dual-band operation, covering the frequency bands of 3.47GHz to 3.55GHz, and 4.8GHz to 4.92GHz. The antenna exhibits good impedance matching within these bands, with Voltage Standing Wave Ratio (VSWR) values of 1.0388 and 1.0297 at 3.51GHz and 4.85GHz. Proposed antenna achieves peak gains of 3.93dBi and 3.31dBi, with matching radiation efficiencies of 72% and 79% for the operating frequencies 3.51GHz and 4.85GHz bands, respectively. Moreover, the proposed antenna produces steady and suitable radiation patterns across both operating frequencies. The suggested antenna is appropriate for deployment in modern 5G communication systems and WiMAX applications.

title: Surface Code Entanglement Ejection
authors: Kento Samuel Soon, Fumiyoshi Kobayashi, Naphan Benchasattabuse, Shota Nagayama
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Scaling fault-tolerant quantum computing beyond a single processor demands logical—logical entanglement. While surface codes excel in local error correction, creating robust, distributed entanglement remains challenging. In this work, we introduce Entanglement Ejection—a protocol for generating physical—logical entanglement from a single logical qubit. This subroutine establishes logical—logical entanglement via entanglement swapping with a physical Bell pair provided by a quantum network. Unlike common injection-based methods, our protocol is deterministic, requiring no post-selection and thereby has the potential of reducing spatio-temporal resource overhead. We show via numerical simulations under a superconducting-specific noise model that this potential resource efficiency comes at the cost of a slightly higher, yet comparable, logical error rate.

title: Automatic Generation of Digital Twins for Network Testing
authors: Shenjia Ding, David Flynn, Paul Harvey
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: The increased use of software in the operation and management of telecommunication networks has moved the industry one step closer to realizing autonomous network operation. One consequence of this shift is the significantly increased need for testing and validation before such software can be deployed. Complementing existing simulation or hardwarebased approaches, digital twins present an environment to achieve this testing; however, they require significant time and human effort to configure and execute. This paper explores the automatic generation of digital twins to provide efficient and accurate validation tools, aligned to the ITU-T autonomous network architecture’s experimentation subsystem. We present experimental results for an initial use case, demonstrating that the approach is feasible in automatically creating efficient digital twins with sufficient accuracy to be included as part of existing validation pipelines.

title: Machine-Learning based Detection of Quantum Attacks
authors: Rajasekar L, Hansa, Riddhipan Manna, Srividhya S, Telugu Maddileti, Pongiannan R K
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: With advent of Quantum Computing, traditional cyber security mechanisms are failing. This paper discusses the effectiveness of certain machine learning models in detecting such quantum attacks on quantum systems. The dataset used is custom generated using qiskit and AerSimulator and it focuses on three states of system, normal state, side-channel attack state and intercept-resend attack state. Machine learning models like logistic regression, neural networks, SVM and XGBoost were trained on the dataset. The highest accuracy observed was 0.81 obtained using XGBoost. These findings highlight the challenges of quantum attack detection and suggest future research directions for improving classification accuracy.

title: ECG based Heart Disease Classification and Prediction using Deep Learning Methods
authors: Pradeep Kumar D, K Dharmarajan
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Cardiovascular diseases are an important cause of morbidity and mortality in most parts of the world and there is a need to find accurate and early diagnosis of this disease. Manual techniques of analysis on ECG might be time-consuming and susceptible to errors, which makes the application of deep learning (DL) techniques in automating HD classification and prediction possible. This study aims to evaluate how well various DL models such as CNN, LSTM, CNN+LSTM, and ConvLSTM perform in categorising and forecasting cardiac illness using ECG signals.. CNN has the capability to capture spatial correlations, LSTM can perform on temporal sequences, CNN+LSTM can inherit the former two features, ConvLSTM is capable of adding convolutional operations to LSTM cells to improve feature representation and overcome the problem of gradient vanishing. A high accuracy of the models when tested on the created models on labeled ECG datasets was measured using parameters (indicators): accuracy, specificity, recall, false positive rate (FPR) and true negative rate (TNR). Quantitative results show that ConvLSTM showed the best performance with 95.6 accuracy, 98.7 specificity, 96.4 recall, 0.5 FPR and 0.90 TNR, whereas CNN+LSTM too performed well with 94.5 accuracy, 98.0 specificity. The paper finds that hybrid DL architectures, especially the ConvLSTM architecture, achieve robustness, reliability and precision of automated diagnosis of heart disease based on ECG, which is a potential clinical support tool at its early stages of detection.

title: A Floriculture Plot as a Research Catalyst for Multidisciplinary STEM Learning: A Practical Approach
authors: Ulises Tamez-Duque, Rita Salazar, Alfredo Cantú, Zita Valdés
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a practical multidisciplinary project aimed at strengthening student competencies commonly required in STEM education. The initiative centered on an agroecological practice, which served as a catalyst for diverse learning experiences and technological applications across disciplines. Methodological and logistical considerations, including equipment, infrastructure, and learning tools, were addressed to ensure successful execution. The resulting experience demonstrated significant impact on both students and faculty, contributing to an incremental and innovative strategy for education within a private Mexican high school context.

title: Approximating Degenerate Quantum Maximum Likelihood Decoding Using the Chase Algorithm
authors: Takeshi Kakizaki
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We propose quantum Chase decoding as an approximation to degenerate quantum maximum-likelihood decoding, by efficiently searching for Pauli errors and estimating the logical error probability. With the proposed decoder, concatenated Hamming codes achieve a logical error threshold of 5.5 %, compared to 2.5 % with conventional syndrome decoding.

title: A Study on the Construction of a Model for Recognizing Apparent Cracks in Concrete Based on Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Li Ren
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of feature ambiguity, strong background interference and insufficient recognition accuracy in the recognition of apparent cracks in concrete structures, this paper proposes a deep recognition model based on convolutional neural network. The model takes ResNet-50 as the backbone, and introduces multi-scale feature fusion and channel attention mechanism to strengthen the ability of extracting the morphology of micro-fine cracks. By constructing a multi-source crack image dataset and carrying out systematic training and validation, the model exhibits excellent recognition performance and robustness in multiple scenarios. The experimental results show that the proposed model significantly outperforms traditional methods in terms of accuracy, F1-score and generalization ability, and has good engineering application prospects and scalability.

title: Predicting Disease from the Skies: A Hybrid Intelligence Approach using Weather-Driven Health Analytics
authors: K. Malarkodi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: We relied on hybrid intelligence and combined Random Forest and LightGBM classifiers to help predict weather-related diseases. The system used temperature, humidity and precipitation as the main items for predicting diseases. Ensembling by means of soft voting was used to increase performance, so the predictions of both classifiers were used together. As a result of using this approach, accuracy, precision, recall and F1-score were all enhanced. Hybrid models were better than single classifiers in many cases such as for respiratory and water-borne illnesses whose symptoms can change with weather. Testing on held-out samples showed that the model was strong enough to generalize its findings. Moreover, because the model is computationally efficient, it is a good fit for health surveillance systems used in practice. The outcomes point out that machine learning is useful for public health forecasting because it offers a flexible warning system for both predicting diseases and recognizing their early signs.

title: Failure Analysis of Transistors Under Various Gate Voltage Biases
authors: Hui Yang, Zixuan Li, Jinhua Huang, Ling Yang, Lingxiao Liu, Yanfei Zhao, Younan Hua, Xiaomin Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: Failure analysis is of great significance in advanced integrated circuit. It enables the identification of failure mechanisms, thereby facilitating the improvement of manufacturing processes and the enhancement of product yield. In this paper, the failure analysis of transistors under various gate voltage biases is conducted. By using a Nanoprober to apply different gate voltages, two types of transistor gate failure samples are induced. Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) inspection is carried out on these samples to identify the defect mechanisms of the gate electrode under different voltages. The first type of failure shows performance degradation in threshold voltage (VT) and on-state current, which is attributed to the pre-existing defects in the HfO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> layer and stress-induced transition in the metal gate. The second type is catastrophic burnout, caused by the Fowler-Nordheim (F -N) tunneling effect under extreme electric field. This study provides an alternative method for analyzing the failure mechanism and enhances the understanding of the device reliability of HKMG FinFET devices.

title: Solving Large-Scale Vehicle Routing Problems with Hybrid Quantum-Classical Decomposition
authors: Andrew Maciejunes, John Stenger, Daniel Gunlycke, Nikos Chrisochoides
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We present a two-level decomposition strategy for solving the Vehicle Routing Problem (VRP) using the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm. A Problem-Level Decomposition partitions a 13-node (156-qubit) VRP into smaller Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) instances. Each TSP is then further cut via Circuit-Level Decomposition, enabling execution on near-term quantum devices. Our approach achieves up to 95% reductions in the circuit depth, 96% reduction in the number of qubits and a 99.5% reduction in the number of 2-qubit gates. We demonstrate this hybrid algorithm on the standard edge encoding of the VRP as well as a novel amplitude encoding. These results demonstrate the feasibility of solving VRPs previously too complex for quantum simulators and provide early evidence of potential quantum utility.

title: Spatial-Temporal Digital Twin for Crop Disease Prediction: A Hybrid ConvLSTM-Graph Neural Network Approach
authors: V. Gopinath, M. Sangeetha
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The increasing worldwide menace of plant diseases, causing, inter alia, annual losses of $3B due to coffee leaf rust, calls for the deployment of high-tech predictive tools above traditional reactive measures. Existing Systems relies upon manual scouting or analysis based on past weather information and incidents within the vicinity of a plantation, or basic machine learning methods (e.g., random forests) applied to segregated data sets, which results in suboptimal accuracy (60-70%) and fairly late detection (⩽7 days preceding visible symptoms). The thrust of this work goes to proposing Innovative Method a spatiotemporal digital twin integrating a hybrid ConvLSTM-Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) for 14 days pre-symptom disease prediction. The framework fuses multi-modal data, such as satellite NDVI (10m resolution Sentinel-2), drone thermal imagery (0.5 cm/pixel), IoT soil sensors (pH/moisture 15 min interval), and ERA5 microclimate forecasts into a physics-informed deep learning architecture. The ConvLSTM models temporal dynamics of canopy health, whereas the GNN models pathogen spread across the plants represented by graphs using graph attention (GAT) layers. Next, intervention strategies from the digital twin simulation layer built in Unity3D are tested with reinforcement learning (PPO algorithm). Validated with the 50 Colombian coffee farms dataset from 2021 to 2023, this system has obtained early rust detection with 88.3% precision (14.2 days of average lead time), with optimized treatment plans allowing a 34.7% reduction in pesticide usage, and increasing yields by 16.1% versus control groups. The model was 22.8% ahead of existing systems in F1-score and demonstrated generalizability to wheat rust in synthetic trials. This demonstration established that operational digital twins in hybrid deep learning architectures can bring crop protection from reactive to the predictive stage, hence working towards the sustainable agricultural goals set by FAO for 2030. Future directions may include edge AI deployment via NVIDIA Jetson with alerts in the field and prescription tracking via blockchain.

title: Engineering for a Better World: Embedding the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Into Engineering Education
authors: Kazeem Aderemi Bello, Rendani Wilson Maladzhi, Mbuyu Germain Ntukub
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: This study looks at the ongoing gap between engineering education and the real-world application of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). While issues like climate change, inequality, and limited resources call for changes in how engineers are trained, current programmes mostly focus on technical skills and often overlook important areas like systems thinking, ethics, and sustainability. The paper examines the barriers that make it hard to include SDGs in engineering education, such as strict curricula, a lack of faculty expertise, and little interdisciplinary work. It also highlights positive factors like increased student interest in meaningful education, access to open learning materials, and chances for international cooperation. To close the gap, the study suggests a framework based on three key areas: integrating SDGs into the curriculum, hands-on learning, and strong institutional support. This approach aims to connect education with global development needs, promote ethical responsibility, and improve practical problem-solving skills. In the end, the study calls for a major change to train engineers who are globally aware and focused on sustainability.

title: Sampling-Based Quantum Optimization Algorithm with Quantum Relaxation
authors: Hiromichi Matsuyama, Yu Yamashiro
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Combinatorial optimization is one of the promising applications of quantum computation. Variational Quantum Algorithm (VQA) is a classical-quantum hybrid algorithm framework for noisy quantum devices. However, the quality of the solution is readily affected by statistical fluctuations and physical noise, making it challenging to maintain applicability for largescale problems. In contrast, sampling-based quantum algorithms have recently been successfully applied to large-scale quantum chemistry problems. In the sampling-based framework, the quantum device is used only for sampling, while the ground state and its energy are estimated on the classical device. In this study, we propose the Sampling-based Quantum Optimization Algorithm (SQOA) that leverages these advantages for combinatorial optimization. There are two challenges in constructing SQOA. The first challenge is that we need to encode the optimization problem in a non-diagonal Hamiltonian, even though many VQAs encode it into the Ising Hamiltonian, which is diagonal. The second challenge is that we need a method for efficient preparation of the input state to be sampled. To address the first challenge, we utilize the Quantum Relaxation (QR) method for encoding an optimization problem within a Hamiltonian. This method achieves a higher encoding density by mapping multiple variables to a single qubit, thus requiring fewer qubits for larger problems compared to the Ising Hamiltonian approach. Moreover, to address the second challenge, we investigate the parameter transferability within the Quantum Alternating Operator Ansatz for QR Hamiltonians. We show that restricting parameters to a linear form exhibits moderate transferability for 3-regular Max-Cut problems, similar to transferability observed in the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm. Therefore, this property allows us to efficiently prepare the input state for a large problem instance using the parameters obtained from a small problem instance. We leveraged transferability to create input states and applied SQOA with QR to the Max-Cut instances. By transferring parameters from a 20-node problem, we demonstrate that SQOA with QR provides high-quality solutions for 40-node problems without variational parameter optimization.

title: Fed-Adapter: A Parameter-Efficient Federated Learning Framework for Brain Tumor Detection
authors: A R Nitesh Kumar, Keerthika P
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Improving disease diagnosis requires accurate and early brain tumor detection from MRI scans. Centralized deep learning algorithms employed raise data privacy, variation in imaging modalities among institutions, and communication overhead in large-scale deployments. This paper proposes a Fed-Adapter, a parameter-efficient federated learning architecture that uses PEFT with adapter modules for decentralized brain tumor detection, that addresses these issues. The proposed Fed-Adapter uses lightweight adapter layers on a fixed MobileNetV2 backbone to train and send a few parameters during the federated updates. This design saves computational and communication costs without compromising the model accuracy. This work uses FedProx to stabilize local updates using a proximal regularization term to reduce effects of non IID data distribution across clients. The proposed framework was tested using a publicly accessible Brain Tumor MRI dataset and achieved 97% classification accuracy, which is comparable to that of a fully centralized MobileNetV2 model. It preserves patient privacy and enables multi-institutional collaboration. Grad-CAM-based visualization improved tumor localization. According to extensive studies, Fed-Adapter outperforms typical federated learning baselines in terms of prediction performance and communication efficiency. PEFT, adapter modules and FedProx in a federated setup provide a privacy-preserving, resource-efficient, and clinically interpretable brain tumor diagnosis solution using MRI data.

title: Quantum Education in Africa: Innovative Models, Collaborative Frameworks, and the Path Forward
authors: Farai Mazhandu, Mhlambululi Mafu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The state of quantum education in Africa is in a nascent but promising stage. Various initiatives are emerging across the continent aimed at enhancing understanding and interest in quantum education. As global interest in quantum technologies grows, Africa is at a pivotal juncture, with the opportunity to cultivate a new generation of quantum leaders and innovators. This work examines how various emerging quantum science and technology programs, existing collaborations, research initiatives, and grassroots movements can enhance the continent's quantum education ecosystem, spotlighting emerging innovative models and the Africa Quantum Consortium's potential for coordinated growth. While Africa has made significant progress, significant challenges remain, including limited funding, inadequate infrastructure, and a shortage of trained educators in quantum sciences. Despite these challenges, quantum education in Africa is beginning to take shape, driven by a growing awareness among students and educators that quantum concepts are essential to understanding the modern scientific world. Quantum education in Africa is important for Africa and the rest of the world. In particular, it fosters a new generation of skilled scientists and engineers capable of tackling complex challenges and driving innovation in diverse fields. This will lead to advances in various technologies, benefiting both Africa and the global community. In addition, focusing on innovative models and collaborative frameworks will help close the technological gap between Africa and developed nations, encouraging economic growth and improved living standards. Ultimately, this work advocates for a holistic approach that integrates academic resources, industry partnerships, and policy support to build a robust quantum ecosystem across the continent. Given the limitations imposed by the format of this work and the pace in which quantum science is advancing, it is not feasible to acknowledge all contributors or to present a comprehensive overview of the most recent quantum science and technology advancements in Africa. As such, we recommend that readers consult the cited works and related references for further insights. Most significantly, through these highlighted efforts and developments, Africa can position itself as a significant player in the global quantum science and technology landscape, driving both technological advancement and socio-economic development.

title: A Multi-Cloud Approach to Cost Optimization with AWS and Azure Fleet Services
authors: Lucas Silveira Serrano, Miguel de Lima, Felipe A. Portella, Lúcia M. A. Drummond
publish: 2025 IEEE/SBC 37th International Symposium on Computer Architecture and High Performance Computing Workshops (SBAC-PADW)
abstract: High Performance Computing (HPC) is increasingly moving to the cloud, where Spot instances offer significant cost savings compared to On-demand price models. However, selecting instances remains challenging due to a large variety of instance types and costs across different regions and providers. This work investigates strategies for allocating a set of Spot instances (a Spot fleet), simultaneously, in commercial clouds, focusing exclusively on raw pricing. AWS and Azure are first analyzed independently to highlight their particularities in pricing models and instance offerings. Building on this analysis, a multi-cloud solution (MC-Fleet) is proposed to support cost-efficient selection of a set of instances across providers. Extensive experiments demonstrate MC-Fleet effectiveness, achieving cost savings of 23% against a fully provisioned AWS single region us-east-1 and up to 47% over an incomplete provisioned sa-east-1.

title: Promoting Female STEM Vocations: Sharing Experiences in Colombia, Ghana, and Spain
authors: Martha Sofía Carrillo Landazábal, Paloma Diaz, Yolanda González-Arechavala, Olga Esther Haydar Martínez, Yaniris Yaneth Mendoza Alvarez, Mónica de Fatima Alcalá Narvaez
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: The rate of female students in STEM studies is around 30 %, and even lower in disciplines such as civil, industrial and computing engineering. As the market and society demand a greater number of engineers, attracting and retaining more female talent in engineering has become a global challenge to avoid losing talent. In this context, the Fundación Universitaria Tecnológico Comfenalco in Colombia initiated a project to gain a broader perspective on the problem and potential solutions, taking into account the current participation of females in engineering studies in Colombia, as well as in other countries, such as Ghana and Spain. The project started with a study profiling current female engineering students aimed at identifying significant differences between the three countries. A trip to Spain was organised to learn about the approaches employed by the Women and Technology Chair at Universidad Carlos III de Madrid and the Chair for the Promotion of Women in STEM Vocational Training for Sustainable Mobility (STEM Women Chair) at Universidad Pontificia Comillas. This paper introduces the visit to Madrid of a group of female students and academics of diverse engineering degrees from two universities in Colombia, Fundación Universitaria Tecnologico Comfenalco in Cartagena and Institución Universitaria Salazar y Herrera in Medellin, and the Kumasi University of Ghana of Ghana. During the visits, participants learned about the activities carried out in Spain and also visited leading companies in various engineering sectors. The impact of the visit was assessed through questionnaires and video testimonies. Results show that it was a motivating experience for all participants. The visiting academics were exposed to strategies for promoting STEM studies that could inspire future programs. Visiting students learnt about innovative and multidisciplinary engineering projects and possible career opportunities, such as research, that they had not considered before. For Spanish academics, participating in the project allowed them to learn about the situation of women in engineering in countries such as Colombia and Ghana, as well as the problems they face. Spanish students could meet students from other countries whose life circumstances differ, allowing them to appreciate their situation better and become more empathetic about other cultures.

title: Counter-Adversarial Estimation and the Square Root Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Space Extended Kalman Filter
authors: Alberto Zamora, Kyle J. DeMars
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Multisensor Fusion and Integration for Intelligent Systems (MFI)
abstract: Estimating states could become uniquely challenging due to nonlinear and uncertain dynamics, limited or unreliable observations, and the presence of external disturbances, such as signal interference and spoofing. This paper introduces the square root reproducing kernel Hilbert space extended Kalman filter (SRREKF) as a novel approach for robust and adaptive state estimation. By leveraging an online expectationmaximization algorithm together with square root factors, the SRREKF not only learns unknown system parameters and approximates nonlinear dynamics and measurements, through kernel-based function representations, but also contributes to preventing the covariance matrices to lose their positivedefiniteness. This framework enables accurate and stable threat detection and active sensing, offering a promising approach for resilient spacecraft navigation under uncertain conditions. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed SRREKF with online EM significantly outperforms the standard EKF in terms of estimation accuracy, particularly under nonlinear and noisy measurement conditions.

title: ACC: Ensuring Eventual Consistency across Diverse Data Stores in End-Cloud Collaboration
authors: Wenbo Zhao, Longhai Li, Hui Li, Mingtao Chen, Mingsong Xie, Yuheng Chang, Jiangtao Cui
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: This study presents the Asynchronous Concurrent Control (ACC) system, a lightweight middleware for cloudassisted database synchronization to ensure eventual consistency across geo-distributed mobile devices. ACC offloads conflict resolution to the cloud and uses a branch-and-merge approach to track and merge client states in the cloud, propagating differential updates through anti-entropy packets. This reduces cloud-client interactions, and minimizes computational burdens on mobile devices. Experimental results show that ACC achieves low synchronization latency with minimal impact on write performance and improves efficiency during offline reconnection.

title: Edge-First Language Model Inference: Models, Metrics, and Tradeoffs
authors: SiYoung Jang, Roberto Morabito
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: The widespread adoption of Language Models (LMs) across industries is driving interest in deploying these services across the computing continuum, from the cloud to the network edge. This shift aims to reduce costs, lower latency, and improve reliability and privacy. Small Language Models (SLMs), enabled by advances in model compression, are central to this shift, offering a path to on-device inference on resourceconstrained edge platforms. This work examines the interplay between edge and cloud deployments, starting from detailed benchmarking of SLM capabilities on single edge devices, and extending to distributed edge clusters. We identify scenarios where edge inference offers comparable performance with lower costs, and others where cloud fallback becomes essential due to limits in scalability or model capacity. Rather than proposing a one-size-fits-all solution, we present platform-level comparisons and design insights for building efficient, adaptive LM inference systems across heterogeneous environments.

title: An Adaptive and Deterministic Ensemble Gaussian Mixture Filter for Cislunar Relative Navigation
authors: Dalton Durant, Felipe Giraldo-Grueso, Renato Zanetti
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Multisensor Fusion and Integration for Intelligent Systems (MFI)
abstract: The objective of this paper is to develop an onboard nonlinear filter for cislunar relative navigation. An effective onboard filter must be accurate, consistent, efficient, and verifiable. Recent work has shown that the Ensemble Gaussian Mixture Filter (EnGMF) is an accurate and consistent nonlinear filter capable of handling non-Gaussian probability distributions. However, its fixed number of Gaussian components restricts efficiency, and its random resampling step prevents verifiability. To address these issues, the EnGMF is refined such that it adaptively reduces the number of Gaussian components, and it deterministically resamples using Fibonacci grids with optimal reduction. The presented cislunar scenario relies solely on noisy azimuth and elevation angle measurements obtained from vision-based sensors (e.g., cameras), demonstrating both the need for nonlinear filtering and its potential for deepspace operations. Simulation results indicate that the refined EnGMF approaches maintain the accuracy and consistency of the traditional EnGMF, and also improve its efficiency and ensure verifiability.

title: Erasure Minesweeper: Exploring Hybrid-Erasure Surface Code Architectures for Efficient Quantum Error Correction
authors: Jason D. Chadwick, Mariesa H. Teo, Joshua Viszlai, Willers Yang, Frederic T. Chong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Dual-rail erasure qubits can substantially improve the efficiency of quantum error correction, allowing lower error rates to be achieved with fewer qubits, but each erasure qubit requires <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times$</tex> more transmons to implement compared to standard qubits. In this work, we introduce a hybrid-erasure architecture for surface code error correction where a carefully chosen subset of qubits is designated as erasure qubits while the rest remain standard. Through code-capacity analysis and circuitlevel simulations, we show that a hybrid-erasure architecture can boost the performance of the surface code-much like how a game of Minesweeper becomes easier once a few squares are revealed-while using fewer resources than a full-erasure architecture. We study strategies for the allocation and placement of erasure qubits through analysis and simulations. We then use the hybrid-erasure architecture to explore the trade-offs between per-qubit cost and key logical performance metrics such as threshold and effective distance in surface code error correction. Our results show that the strategic introduction of dual-rail erasure qubits in a transmon architecture can enhance the logical performance of surface codes for a fixed transmon budget, particularly for near-term-relevant transmon counts and logical error rates.

title: Stock Market Prediction Using LSTM Networks: Leveraging Machine Learning for Accurate Forecasting of Stock Price Trends
authors: Vimal Sekar, Rajkumar Pandiarajan, Kailasam Selvaraj, G Sakthivel Raj, V Venkadesh, T Radha Krishnan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Stock market prediction is a complex task due to market volatility, global crises, and political factors. Traditional methods, such as technical and fundamental analysis, often fail to capture non-linear patterns. With advancements in machine learning, Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks have become effective for time series forecasting, learning long-term dependencies in sequential data. This research employs LSTM networks to predict stock price trends using five years of structured historical stock data from Yahoo Finance, including features like closing price, trading volume, and moving averages. Preprocessing techniques such as data normalization, missing value handling, and outlier removal were applied to enhance data quality. The model’s performance, evaluated using MSE, RMSE, and MAE, was compared against traditional methods like ARIMA and simple RNNs, demonstrating LSTM’s superior accuracy. Experiments with different architectures, such as stacked and bidirectional LSTM, were conducted to optimize performance. Results highlight LSTM’s ability to model complex price movements, providing valuable insights for investors. This study underscores the potential of deep learning in financial forecasting, contributing to the advancement of predictive analytics in financial markets.

title: Combined Application of XPS and TOF-SIMS in Quantitative Analysis of Trace Elements Boron and Phosphorus
authors: Younan Hua, Lei Zhu, Xu Ke, Lois Liao, Xiaomin Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: In this paper, two analysis techniques of XPS and TOF-SIMS will be jointly applied to analyze the composition of residual contamination elements after the aluminum (Al) surface cleaning process of automotive parts, especially for quantitative analysis of trace elements boron (B) and phosphorus (P). TOF-SIMS will be used for confirming the existence of the trace element B and P to ensure and improve the accuracy. XPS is often used to quantitatively analyze trace elements, but for some elements with complex peak positions, it is confusing and challenging to accurately determine the elements. By using TOF-SIMS for confirmation, XPS’ misjudgment of trace elements can be avoided, thereby obtaining more accurate XPS quantitative analysis results. It is known that TOF-SIMS has better sensitivity than XPS. But its quantitative analysis is not as good as that of XPS. The combination of the two techniques makes full use of their respective advantages, not only to avoid missing elements detected by XPS, but also to obtain more accurate XPS quantitative analysis results. In this paper, we will use both XPS and TOF-SIMS methods to accurately and quantitatively analyze B and P trace elements after the Al surface cleaning process of automotive parts.

title: Enhancing Professional Growth Through Digital Education and International Engagement in Online Graduate Programs
authors: Adriana Vargas-Martínez, Jaime Mora Vargas, José Rivas-Vázquez, Luis Falcon-Morales, Grettel Barcelo-Alonso, Gerardo Velasco-Gutierrez, Eduardo Castanares-Marquez, Jose Herrera-Corral, Jorge Rodriguez-Ruiz, Jessica Izquierdo-Alvarez, Kenneth William-Bauer, Yatziri Rodriguez-Guerra, Anna Garate-Escamilla, Luis Herrera del Canto, Maria Castro-Jaramillo, Alejandra Bautista-Hernandez
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: The digital transformation of graduate education has significantly broadened access and increased flexibility, particularly for working professionals pursuing continued development. At Tecnológico de Monterrey, the Professional Impact Graduate Programs (PIGPs) reimagine online education by embedding international collaboration, experiential learning, and personalized academic trajectories. This paper evaluates these elements using a mixed-methods approach with data from over 2,500 students. Findings indicate that global classrooms, immersive experiences, and applied projects correlate with greater satisfaction, retention, and career progression. The modular program architecture-including specialties, high-specialty certificates, areas of emphasis, and alternative credentials-provides multiple entry and exit points aligned to individual career paths. Programs such as the Master in Cybersecurity, Applied Artificial Intelligence, and Engineering Management exemplify how industry collaboration, global partnerships, and digital delivery coalesce to create transformative learning experiences. The study offers strategic insights for institutions seeking to merge digital flexibility, global engagement, and professional relevance in graduate education.

title: Swin Transformer-Based Retinal Vessel Segmentation with Hierarchical Attention and Adaptive Pathway Enhancement
authors: Shurui Liu, Haina Zou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Retinal vessel segmentation is crucial for diagnosing ocular and systemic diseases. However, existing methods face challenges such as uneven capillary distribution, blurred boundaries, and lesion interference. This study introduces SwinATDNet, a novel U-shaped segmentation model that enhances performance by integrating a Swin Transformer with an adaptive transformer-triggered pathway module and a dual-pooling hierarchical spatial attention network (DP-HSAN). In the encoder stage, sequential Swin Transformer blocks capture global contextual features, while the DP-HSAN module in the decoder enhances spatial features during upsampling. The adaptive transformer-triggered pathway bridges the semantic gap between encoder and decoder outputs. Experiments on DRIVE, STARE, and CHASE-DB1 datasets demonstrate the superiority of our method, achieving accuracies of 98.67%, 98.51%, and 97.21 %, respectively, outperforming existing approaches.

title: Improvement of a Formation Fitting Algorithm
authors: Junkuan Chen, Tianshun Chen, Yuankun Peng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Formation fitting plays an increasingly important role in array signal processing. The conventional approach is to directly interpolate the values of heading sensors. Due to the inherent errors of heading sensors, the fitting values of remote array elements will deviate greatly from the true values under the iterative accumulation of errors. In addition, the selection of fitting order can also cause various problems. Fitting only uses the current value, which is insufficient for data utilization. Therefore, this paper improves the above conventional methods by introducing adaptive ideas into formation estimation and applying forgetting factors to historical data, fully utilizing the information of data. Finally, the effectiveness of this method is verified using actual data, which can be well applied to engineering. Among them.

title: Efficient Personality Prediction using Multi-Output Regression with ALBERT and RoBERTa Models on Social Media Data
authors: Nakka Sai Spoorthi, M Nagaraju, Shaik Farahana, Shaik Imeen Roshni
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Using social media content to predict personality traits has become relevant to the development of user modeling and personalization. A transformer-based Natural Language Processing (NLP) model developed to predict the Big Five personality traits will be presented, utilizing posts from the social media platform Reddit. The Personality and Demographics of Reddit Authors (PANDORA) dataset is leveraged to train and evaluate ALBERT and RoBERTa models in a multi-output regression design. To facilitate performance improvement and efficiency analysis, we employ several optimization strategies, including gradient clipping, weight decay, early stopping, hyperparameter configuration, and mixed-precision training. To further enable use in realistic contexts, personality scores are converted into narrative, descriptive summaries. In terms of the relative performance of RoBERTa and ALBERT, results show that ALBERT outperforms RoBERTa, based on all key evaluation metrics: Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Mean Squared Error (MSE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score. Results also suggest that smaller transformer models perform satisfactorily in the context of personality traits. Directions for future extension of this work include better support for multilingual inputs and improved interpretability of outputs.

title: A Lazy Resynthesis Approach for Simultaneous T Gate and Two-Qubit Gate Optimization of Quantum Circuits
authors: Mu-Te Lau, Hsiang-Chun Yang, Hsin-Yu Chen, Chung-Yang Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: State-of-the-art quantum circuit optimization (QCO) algorithms for T-count reduction often lead to a substantial increase in two-qubit gate count (2Q-count)-a drawback that existing 2Q-count optimization techniques struggle to address effectively. In this work, we propose a novel lazy resynthesis approach for modern tableau-based QCO flows that significantly mitigates the 2 Q -gate surges commonly introduced during T-count optimization in Clifford+T circuits. Experimental results show that our approach reduces 2 Q-count overhead by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$54.8 \%, 15.3 \%$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 8. 0} \%$</tex> compared to tableau-based, ZX-calculus-based, and path-sum-based QCO algorithms, respectively. In terms of runtime, our method achieves speedups of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.81 \times$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$13.1 \times$</tex> over the tableau-based and ZX-calculus-based methods, while performing comparably to the path-sum-based approach. In summary, the proposed lazy resynthesis technique not only enhances the quality and performance of tableau-based QCO algorithms but also demonstrates superior efficiency and scalability compared to alternative QCO approaches such as ZX-calculus and path-sumbased techniques.

title: Passivity-Based PI Control of Boost Converters with Gain Scheduling in Continuous Conduction Mode
authors: Francisco Daniel Esteban, Federico Martin Serra, Oscar Danilo Montoya, César Leonardo Trujillo, Walter Gil-González
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: Using a proportional-integral passivity-based control (PI-PBC) framework, this paper addresses the modeling and nonlinear control of a DC-DC boost converter operating in continuous conduction mode (CCM). The converter is first described through an averaged state-space model, which is reformulated as a port-Hamiltonian (pH) structure to facilitate energy-based control design. A PI-PBC law is proposed using component-wise error signals, and its stability is rigorously demonstrated via Lyapunov analysis. To improve dynamic performance across varying operating points, a gain-scheduling formulation is introduced, allowing the control gains to adapt as functions of the desired equilibrium state. The simulation results confirm that the proposed PI-PBC strategy provides accurate voltage regulation and fast transient response while ensuring continuous conduction. The controller exhibits robustness under reference changes and load disturbances, and the gain-scheduled designs outperform constant-gain implementations in terms of overshoot reduction and settling time.

title: Emergency Patching Management System (EPMS): A Critical Component of SCADA System Security
authors: T John Sunder Singh, J.I. Sheeba, S Pradeep Devaneyan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems play a vital role in managing critical infrastructure but are highly susceptible to cyberattacks. Emergency patching is an essential security measure that enables the rapid deployment of fixes for critical vulnerabilities. However, SCADA systems present unique challenges, such as legacy system compatibility, minimal downtime requirements, and limited testing opportunities, making emergency patching complex. This paper examines these challenges and outlines a structured emergency patching framework, including vulnerability assessment, risk-based prioritization, controlled deployment, and rollback planning. Additionally, it introduces the Emergency Patching Management System (EPMS) as a strategic approach to streamline patching while minimizing operational risks. By adopting a well-defined emergency patching process, organizations can strengthen SCADA system security, mitigate cyber threats, and ensure the resilience of critical infrastructure.

title: Resilient Inference for Personalized Federated Learning in Edge Computing Environments
authors: Ke Xiao, Qiyuan Wang, Christos Anagnostopoulos, Kevin Bryson
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) and Edge Computing (EC) offer innovative approaches to enable distributed learning systems that prioritize data privacy and low-latency communication. Personalized FL (PFL) enhances traditional FL by tailoring models to the needs of each participant and improving local inference performance. Given the resource constraints and potential for edge node failures, optimized inference task rescheduling mechanisms play a crucial role in ensuring resilience in inference services. Existing methods often ignore the impact of the inherent model differences on inferential tasks leading to suboptimal personalization in EC. To address this challenge, we propose a framework, SOIR, which effectively integrates model similarity into the rescheduling process. The inference task rescheduling problem in EC is formulated with a Mixed Integer Nonlinear Programming (MINLP) model, and an efficient algorithm is introduced to solve it. Our experimental results showcase the applicability and effectiveness of SOIR in FL-based resilient EC environments.

title: Leveraging Large Language Models for Anomaly Detection in Microservices Architectures
authors: Diego Frazatto Pedroso, Luís Almeida, William Akihiro Alves Aisawa, Inês Dutra, Sarita Mazzini Bruschi
publish: 2025 IEEE/SBC 37th International Symposium on Computer Architecture and High Performance Computing Workshops (SBAC-PADW)
abstract: Cloud computing has become a key enabler of scalable and high-performance applications, allowing systems to be deployed rapidly. At the same time, the increasing sophistication of cloud-native environments brings new challenges related to system dependability. Ensuring resilience under such conditions is a fundamental responsibility of IT providers, who must safeguard service continuity and operational stability. The widespread use of microservice-based designs has created an ecosystem with a growing number of interacting components, including frameworks, application layers, hypervisors, and orchestration platforms. This distributed and layered environment produces a massive volume of log data originating from heterogeneous sources. Without automated support, extracting useful insights from these logs becomes a highly complex task. One promising direction to mitigate this challenge is the use of Machine Learning, particularly methods grounded in Large Language Models (LLMs), which can dynamically detect recurring structures and anomalies in event streams. Building on this idea, our work introduces an anomaly detection framework deployed within a microservices environment running on Kubernetes with Istio. The framework integrates an LLM trained on a diverse set of fault scenarios. To create these scenarios, we relied on Chaos Mesh for fault injection and Locust for workload stress testing. The evaluation confirmed that the model achieved high accuracy in identifying anomalies. It consistently detected all injected faults, although a small number of false positives were observed. Importantly, these false alarms remained at acceptable levels, highlighting the approach’s practical applicability.

title: Hierarchical Fault Diagnosis for Bearings via OCSSA-Optimized VMD and Attention-Enhanced CNN-BiLSTM
authors: Liangsong Huang, Xu Xiang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Rolling bearings serve as critical components in rotating machinery, where their operational integrity directly dictates system safety. To address the limitations of conventional deep-learning approaches in processing non-stationary vibration signals and achieving high-precision fault diagnosis, this study proposes an integrated diagnostic framework based on hierarchical feature learning termed OCSSA-VMD-CNN-BiLSTM-AM: (1) OCSSA-optimized VMD for self-adaptive decomposition with automatic determination of modal number K and penalty factor <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha$</tex>; (2) CNN-based extraction of joint timefrequency features from decomposed modes; (3) Utilize BiLSTM to learn the temporal correlation patterns of fault features and effectively capture long-term dependencies; (4) Attention-based weighting to amplify discriminative features while mitigating longrange information decay. The results show that the recognition accuracy of this algorithm reaches 99.1667%. It has significant advantages in the fault diagnosis of rolling bearings and provides a new reference method for the fault diagnosis of rolling bearings.

title: Transforming Dairy Standards: Machine Learning in Milk Quality Prediction
authors: Anjaneyulu Nelluru, Sasidhar Reddy Gaddam, V T Ram Pavan Kumar M, Sriharsha Vikruthi, Naresh Kumar Bhagavatham, Vellaturi Gopikrishna
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: This research presents an effective and practical method for predicting essential milk quality parameters—fat, protein, lactose, and somatic cell count—by utilizing mid-infrared (MIR) spectroscopy along with machine learning techniques. Among the models tested, Random Forest Regression (RFR) consistently delivered the most accurate predictions, outperforming both Support Vector Regression (SVR) and Gradient Boosting Machines (GBM), with R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> values surpassing 0.90 in most cases. A key strength of this approach lies in its ability to identify the most relevant MIR spectral regions, offering insights into the chemical makeup of milk and enhancing the transparency of the predictive model. Unlike high-cost sensor technologies, this framework relies on routinely collected MIR data, making it a more accessible and cost-effective option for real-time, on-farm milk quality assessment. By combining domain-specific knowledge with statistical learning, the study contributes a reliable and interpretable tool for improving dairy herd management and ensuring consistent milk quality.

title: Engineering Physics Education Through Radio Astronomy and the Sustainable Development Goals
authors: Carolina B. Rodríguez-Garza, Antonio Hernández-Gómez
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: This paper reports a one-week, research-based immersion developed in Mexico by Tecnológico de Monterrey in collaboration with the Instituto de Radioastronomía y Astrofísica (IRyA-UNAM) for undergraduate Engineering Physics students. The program combined lectures and colloquia, observation of graduate thesis defenses, and hands-on data-analysis workshops (CASSIS, CARTA, CASA), and included a short sciencecommunication piece linking radio astronomy to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). We present descriptive findings from two editions (2024 and 2025; <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{N}{=}$</tex> 34). For the 2025 cohort (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=18$</tex>), anonymous pre- and postprogram surveys indicate increases in self-reported familiarity with radio astronomy and in interest in pursuing graduate study (from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 0 \%}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 8 \%}$</tex>). Qualitative justifications suggest that perceived relevance grew through connections to engineering practice and societal impact. While participation was voluntary and samples sizes were small, the initiative illustrates how integrating authentic research practices with SDG framing can broaden academic horizons in programs where such content is rarely available and offers a scalable model for institutions with limited infrastructure via open datasets, remote facilities, and partnerships.

title: Analyzing University Student’s Feedback: An Integration of BERT and Bi-LSTM Approach for Text Classification
authors: Nisha Raveendran, Atulya Arya, D.K Sanjana, R Siva Ranjini, M. Haritha, Vinayak Hegde
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: A favorable learning environment is essential for student development beyond academics. This study analyzes university feedback using text classification, employing BERT for word embeddings and Bi-LSTM for classification. The model categorizes feedback into infrastructure, extracurricular activities, and placements, achieving an accuracy of $99.35 \%$. The results provide actionable insights for improving university services and enhancing student satisfaction.

title: Dynamic Load Balancing in Cloud Computing Using Memetic Algorithm for Better Response Time
authors: K Krishna Sowjanya, K P Bindu Madavi, Gaurav Khater, Aaron Jacob, Emaduddin Shamim Ahmad
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Load balancing is a critical aspect of distributed computing systems, involving the distribution of workload across multiple resources to ensure optimal utilization and performance. In today’s digital landscape, where the demand for online services continues to grow exponentially, efficient load balancing mechanisms are indispensable for maintaining high availability, scalability, and reliability of web applications, cloud services, and network infrastructures. The paper implements a load balancing solution using a Memetic Algorithm, an amalgamated optimization method that integrates elements of genetic algorithms with local search methods. By leveraging the principles of evolutionary computation and problem-specific knowledge, memetic algorithms offer a promising approach to addressing the complex optimization and the hurdles connected with the load distribution across the systems. The proposed algorithm is compared with the existing algorithms and proved to be slightly better than the traditional algorithm in terms of response time. Experimental results show that the proposed approach reduces response time by 0.26 seconds.

title: Control of Inverse Response Processes by Direct Synthesis Control: A CSTR Case Study
authors: Sebastian Vega, Johny Iza, Isaac Robalino, Matias Rueda, Pablo Sinchiguano, Oscar Camacho
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th Colombian Conference on Automatic Control (CCAC)
abstract: This paper proposes a Direct Synthesis Controller (DSC) for inverse response nonlinear processes. The method utilizes the direct synthesis framework to design a controller that takes into account the process's inverse response characteristics and nonlinearities. A systematic design procedure ensures stability and enhances set-point tracking and disturbance rejection. The approach's effectiveness is demonstrated through simulations of benchmark nonlinear processes with inverse response behavior. A comparative analysis reveals that the DSC outperforms conventional control strategies in terms of transient response, steady-state accuracy, and robustness to model uncertainties. The results highlight the DSC's potential as a viable solution for controlling complex, inverse-response, nonlinear systems in industry.

title: Enhancing Endoscopic Diagnosis of Gerd and Polyps: A Comparative Study of Deep Learning Models for Multi-Class Classification
authors: Abdul Kadar Muhammad Masum, Md Fokrul Islam Khan, Md Ruhul Rabbi, Arif Hossen, Khandaker Mohammad Mohi Uddin, Abu Kowshir Bitto
