publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Informatics (ICCRI)
abstract: Accurate and timely diagnosis of gastroesophageal disease and polyps from endoscopic images remains a demanding but crucial function in clinical practice due to visual analogy between pathological and non-pathological tissues. In this research, comparative evaluation of three deep learning models, ResNet-50, InceptionV3, and Ensemble Transfer Learning (Ensemble TL) framework, for multi-class classification of GERD, GERD Normal, Polyp, and Polyp Normal using highresolution endoscopic images is presented. The models were evaluated based on performance metrics: accuracy, precision, recall, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex> measure, and classification accuracy. ResNet-50 showed strong baseline performance with an accuracy of 73% and balanced performance on Polyp detection (F1: 0.78). Its GERD recall (0.65) and GERD Normal precision (0.64) reflected challenges in separating closely similar visual features. InceptionV3 achieved improved performance, particularly in GERD (F1: 0.78) and Polyp (F1: 0.83) detection, with a overall accuracy of 77 %. It did degrade its performance in GERD Normal sensitivity, though. The Ensemble TL model outperformed all the individual models, with a highest accuracy of 87 % and achieving improved <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F 1$</tex> scores for all disease classes: GERD (0.85), GERD Normal (0.82), Polyp (0.94), and Polyp Normal (0.87). These enhancements are credited to the ability of the model to integrate high-level features from ResNet and Inception architectures, enhancing global and local feature learning. The paper underlines ensemble learning's role in complex medical imaging applications, giving consistent and transferable performance across diverse forms of diseases.

title: An Intelli Bio-DECO: An Intelligent Bio-Inspired Dynamic Edge Computing Optimization for IoT Cloud Systems
authors: Ravindrareddy Chilukuri, Gadicherla Sirisha, Gundaram Sampath, G.. N. R. Prasad, Satyanarayana Nimmala, Karuna Pabba
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: The surge of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has resulted in an extraordinary escalation in data generation, presenting substantial problems to conventional cloud computing models. Edge computing has arisen as a viable approach to address these difficulties by facilitating data processing at the network periphery. Nonetheless, optimizing edge computing resources in IoT-Cloud systems continues to be a formidable challenge. This research introduces a unique Dynamic Edge Computing Optimization (DECO) framework that utilizes Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) to enhance resource allocation in IoT-Cloud systems. The suggested PSODECO framework employs a fitness function that incorporates several objectives, such as latency, energy consumption, and resource utilization. Simulation results indicate that the PSODECO framework surpasses current optimization methods, realizing substantial decreases in latency (up to 30%) and energy consumption (up to $25 \%$). The suggested framework provides an effective solution for optimizing edge computing resources in IoT-Cloud systems, facilitating real-time data processing and analytics for diverse IoT applications.

title: Evaluation of Training Strategies for Ambrosia Pollen Detection on Outdoor Images
authors: Ivana Miličić, Nina Pajević, Dimitrije Stefanović, Marko Panić, Branko Šikoparija, Roland Sarda-Estève, Benjamin Guinot, Nemanja Djuric
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Image and Signal Processing and Analysis (ISPA)
abstract: Automatic pollen detection has recently gained significant research attention due to its importance for public health. Numerous computer vision methods have been proposed for this task, with the majority relying on two-stage object detection models applied to optical microscopy images. However, twostage approaches generally suffer from higher inference times, making them less suitable for real-time pollen monitoring tasks. Moreover, model performance on measurements from outdoor data samples remains largely unexplored because they introduce additional challenges, including visually complex backgrounds and the presence of other non-pollen particles such as dust, spores, and debris. In this work, we investigate the limits of the one-stage detection model YOLOv11 on Ambrosia pollen detection in images of outdoor and laboratory-prepared samples, acquired with the AeroTape device. We systematically evaluate training strategies, analyzing the effects of using either laboratory or outdoor images, their combinations, and also the use of data augmentation. The results show that incorporating augmented lab-prepared pollen images into training achieves the best mAP@50-95, highlighting the benefits of controlled laboratory data and one-stage detectors for improved generalization.

title: Quantum Memory Development for the Quantum-Accelerated Internet Testbed
authors: Ashlyn D. Burch, Yisheng Lei, Joseph C. Chapman, Zongfeng Li, Mahdi Hosseini, Nicholas Peters
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: As quantum computation continues to advance, distributed quantum computing is emerging as a crucial configuration, offering a means to leverage the best technology across diverse platforms. This approach is essential for enhancing scalability and advancing quantum resources towards faulttolerant demonstration. A fundamental element of this design is the establishment of scalable quantum networks with robust quantum memory systems. We have recently demonstrated a high efficiency and high bandwidth solid-state quantum memory developed for the Quantum-Accelerated Internet Testbed (QuAInT) at Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL), reaching <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$28.5 \pm 0.2 \%$</tex> efficiency and a 630 MHz absorption window in the material. This work for QuAInT represents a collaborative endeavor across multiple institutions to establish the groundwork for a national quantum internet connection. We will highlight that work here, as well as our strategic vision to build a lower temperature and low-latency quantum memory platform.

title: CURE as a Catalyst for Developing Transversal Competencies in Freshman Year
authors: Pedro Jacinto Páramo-Kañetas, Ivonne Yznaga-Blanco, Felipe Hernández-Rodriguez
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: This study examines the effectiveness of Course Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) in developing transversal competencies such as critical thinking, communication, and problem-solving among first-year engineering students. Despite the recognized benefits of CURE in promoting research skills, there is limited understanding of its impact on first-year students. The study involved 45 students who participated in three challenges during their first semester: Remote Operated Vehicles (ROV), Water-Powered Rockets (WPR), and Solar Water Heaters (SWH). These challenges required students to apply scientific knowledge to real-world problems and present their findings through research papers, presentations, and posters. The methodology included workshops on scientific article analysis, APA citation, literature reviews, research paper writing, and poster creation. The progress of students was assessed using a 5-point Likert scale questionnaire and a rubric evaluating the quality of their research outputs. Results showed significant improvements in competencies: Additionally, around 90% of the students reported enhanced research skills. The findings suggest that integrating CURE into the freshman year curriculum is effective for developing key competencies and prepares students for future academic and professional challenges. Although limited by the single-semester timeframe, this study highlights the potential of CURE to improve research skills and provides a foundation for future research on its long-term impact.

title: Fostering STEAM Self-Efficacy, Empathy, and Civic Responsibility Through a Service-Learning STEAM Project in Lower Secondary Education
authors: Nhi Phan, Thi-Phuong-Vy Nguyen, Kuen-Yi Lin
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: This exploratory study examines the integration of service-learning and STEAM education (SL–STEAM) to foster Grade 8 students' STEAM self-efficacy, empathy, and civic responsibility. The ten-week SL–STEAM project engaged students in designing and constructing mosquito trap lamps to support the well-being of boarding students at a local secondary school. Using a mixed-methods, quasi-experimental design, the study compared an experimental group <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(n=24)$</tex> and a control group (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=28$</tex>) through pre–post surveys and student reflections. Quantitative results showed substantial improvements in empathy and marginally significant gains in STEAM selfefficacy for the experimental group. Civic responsibility improved within both groups but showed no significant between-group difference. Qualitative findings reinforced these patterns, indicating positive development across all three domains. These results offer initial insights into the potential of SL–STEAM to support both academic and socio-emotional outcomes in lower secondary education, while also indicating that civic outcomes may require ongoing engagement to develop measurably. The study's limitations, including the small sample size, single-institution context, and short intervention duration, underscore the need for further research to examine the scalability and long-term impact of SL–STEAM approaches.

title: Prediction of the Soil Nutrition Level Applying Deep Learning to Hybrid Model
authors: Karthika B, Vinitha A
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Sustainable agriculture and maximum production of plants require fertilizers. Nevertheless, traditional agricultural systems do not focus enough on real-time soil fertility, crop type, and soil peculiarities, which is why the method is rather inefficient and this practice is harmful to the ecosystem. The current paper introduces a context-aware system tool which recommends fertilizer that incorporates the usage of Internet of Things (IoT) along with more sophisticated machine learning (ML) models. The architecture with NPK-based sensors managed by IoT monitors the levels of nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium of soil on a real time basis. Such data, together with crop and soil type are transferred through RF-433 MHz modules into a cloud-based server where data processing takes place. Within the range of the supervised learning ML algorithms, four ones are checked regarding predictive accuracy: Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machine, Gaussian Naive Bayes (GNB), and K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN). The best training and test accuracy of 96 and 94 percent, respectively was attained by GNB. The usage of sensors showed good agreement with standard chemical testing and had small deviations (0.34 N, 0.36 P, -0.13 K) proving the validity of the sensor system. The suggested solution is cost-effective, scalable and applicable in remote uses and it facilitates real-time, site-specific and environmentally sustainable fertilizer decisions.

title: An Application of Quantum Computing to Modeling Human Decision-Making
authors: Joseph Fluegemann, Jiaqi Huang, Raghavendra Pradyumna Pothukuchi, Margaret Martonosi, Jerome Busemeyer, Jonathan D. Cohen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We present a quantum cognitive model that can be implemented on a quantum machine. This model uses solutions of the Schrödinger equation to model human cognitive control and decision making in a standard paradigm in psychology: the two-alternative forced-choice (2AFC) task, where participants are forced to choose between two competing alternatives. In the model, the two alternatives map to a multiple square well potential energy function. The depths of the wells correspond to attentional control, while the widths corresponds to features of the stimulus. Using this potential energy, the time-independent Schrodinger equation can be solved for an energy eigenstate basis of the bound states of the system, with higher energies corresponding to higher levels of focus. The full time-dependent Hamiltonian involves an oscillating field that evolves the system from ground state to superpositions of the excited states. The probabilities of the choices in the task are calculated as the probability of finding particles in a particular potential well. Furthermore, the quantum framing of this problem makes this problem suitable for mapping to quantum computing implementations. The state of the system follows the trajectory of a ground state, which can be mapped to a variational quantum eigensolver (VQE) implementation. Meanwhile, the time-dependency and oscillating field can be simulated using current quantum simulation methods and Rabi oscillations. Since our problems can be mapped onto currently-available NISQ prototypes of 2040 qubits, they represent an application domain with tractable near-term quantum-computing resource requirements.

title: Investigating Methods for Emotion Recognition in Women Using Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Mohammadreza Yamaghani, Seyed Sadegh Hosseini, Zahra Dashti, Azamossadat Nourbakhsh
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: Emotion recognition has emerged as a significant challenge in the field of human-machine interaction. Recent advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) have enabled more accurate analysis and identification of emotions, particularly in women. This review article explores AI and ML-based methods and techniques for emotion recognition in women. A comprehensive literature review is conducted, examining various approaches, including natural language processing (NLP), facial analysis, and voice analysis. Specific challenges related to emotion recognition in women, such as cultural and gender differences, are analyzed. Furthermore, potential applications of these technologies in areas such as mental health, marketing, and recommendation systems are discussed. The findings suggest that combining multimodal data and employing deep learning models can significantly enhance the accuracy of emotion recognition. However, further research is needed to improve models, develop specialized datasets, and address ethical and privacy concerns. This article serves as a reference for researchers and developers interested in advancing this field. This article reviews the latest papers published in 2023 in databases such as Google Scholar, PubMed, IEEE Xplore, and Springer.

title: Basketball Player Trajectory Detection for Identifying Playing Styles based on Intelligence Method
authors: Azamossadat Nourbakhsh, Mohammad Ali Chavooshian, Mohammad Reza Yamaghani
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: Vide target tracking and trajectory is an important problem which is based on image and video processing. This article use intelligence methods for this purpose. In general, the proposed approach is 3d Convolutional Neural Network (3d-CNN) with SL-HOF descriptor which create a semi-supervised learning method. There is a series of main literature in this field that the proposed approach use them such as mobility detection with probabilistic reasoning and for display objects target tracking and trajectory used motion-based method and for tracking, feature-based method used. Convolutional Neural Network is a deep learning technique which has feature extraction part as random selection, but for improving this part, SL-HOF descriptor used to detect and track movement at any frame by frame. UCSD and Avenue dataset used in this article. Also, 240 sports video clips of 3 categories (i.e., basketball, football and volleyball), where are collected from Olympic Games, NCAA Championship, and NBA on YouTube. Evaluation criteria of proposed method represent better result in comparison to recent methods in ROC, AUC, NLR, PLR and Cut-off. In this article, we first survey about any target trajectory in any images and video frames. Then we use proposed method for basketball player trajectory detection for identifying playing styles.

title: Deep Learning-based Temporal-Spatial Model for Stroke Rehabilitation Posture Estimation using StrokePoseNet
authors: Priya Matharasi D, Chandramohan S, Raja Ramamoorthi, B Muthukumar, Thamizharasan R, Deepak Arumugam
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Stroke rehabilitation plays a crucial role in restoring motor functions in patients suffering from neurological impairments. Accurate posture prediction and assessment during physiotherapy sessions are vital for tracking recovery and guiding therapeutic interventions. In this study, proposed StrokePoseNet(SPN) a novel temporal-spatial deep learning architecture designed to predict and classify rehabilitation postures based on joint coordinate sequences. Our approach combines 1D Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to extract spatial features from individual frames and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks to capture temporal dependencies across sequences. Utilized the publicly available Toronto Rehabilitation Stroke Pose Dataset, which includes posture sequences of stroke patients performing various rehabilitation exercises. SPN was trained and evaluated using standard machine learning metrics, achieving a classification accuracy of 96.42% and a balanced F1-score of 95.99%. Comparative analysis with baseline models such as Random Forest, SVM, and standalone CNN or LSTM architectures confirmed StrokePoseNet’s superior performance. The outcomes reinforce that the model can be implemented in real-time scenarios in the clinical setting, proposing a data-based method to monitor stroke treatment through the form of intelligent physiotherapy frameworks.

title: Analysis of Influencing Factors on CDM Discharge Current of Large-Sized Packaged Chips
authors: Liyi He, Menghua Wang, Linxiao Yuan, Xiao He, Dan Yang, Na Mei, Keqing Ouyang
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: This article mainly studies the influence of machine calibration and charging time on the peak current of Charged Device Model(CDM). Through comparison tests, it is found that machine calibration has a very obvious impact on the CDM peak current, even above 1 A, and is not strongly correlated with package size, pin type, and test voltage. In addition, we found that when the FCBGA package size is greater than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4000 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>, the charging time needs to be increased to more than 350 ms or above, and 400 ms is recommended to ensure that the charging is completed. And when the package is less than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2000 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>, a charging time of 300 ms is sufficient to meet the charging completion. The above findings provide corresponding references for the setting of CDM test conditions and CDM current design.

title: COUNTER: Cluster GCN based Energy Efficient Resource Management for Sustainable Cloud Computing Environments
authors: Han Wang, Sukhpal Singh Gill, Steve Uhlig
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Cloud computing, thanks to the pervasiveness of information technologies, provides a foundational environment for developing IT applications, offering organizations virtually unlimited and flexible computing resources on a pay-per-use basis. However, the large data centres where cloud computing services are hosted consume significant amounts of electricity annually due to Information and Communication Technology (ICT) components. This issue is exacerbated by the increasing deployment of large artificial intelligence (AI) models, which often rely on distributed data centres, thereby significantly impacting the global environment. This study proposes the COUNTER model, designed for sustainable cloud resource management. COUNTER is integrated with cluster graph neural networks and evaluated in a simulated cloud environment, aiming to reduce energy consumption while maintaining quality of service parameters. Experimental results demonstrate improvements in resource utilisation, energy consumption, and cost effectiveness compared to the baseline model, HUNTER, which employs a gated graph neural network aimed at achieving carbon neutrality in cloud computing for modern ICT systems.

title: Enhancing Employability in Biotechnology Engineering through University-Industry Partnerships
authors: Vianney Lara-Prieto, M. Ileana Ruiz-Cantisani, Rebeca M. Garcia-Garcia, Eduardo J. Arrambide-Leal, Jorge Membrillo-Hernández
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: Universities are committed to preparing professionals with the knowledge and competencies to meet the workforce needs and address the complex challenges that our society faces. Engineers must provide innovative solutions to improve the world sustainably, creating a better place for the next generations. Engineering graduates at our university are usually highly employable locally and globally. However, variations in employability levels exist among the different engineering programs. This study presents a case study of the Biotechnology Engineering program in a Mexican university and the various efforts implemented to foster the graduates' employability, where the university-industry partnerships played a significant role. The study describes the universityindustry partnerships and elements of our educational model, such as challenges where students and faculty are immersed with industry as academic partners in a challenge-based learning environment, and industrial placements as formative experiences. The employability of biotechnology engineering graduates of the last three semesters was analyzed to observe the effects of these efforts. Students, faculty, and industry addressed real-world challenges faced by the companies, providing students with formative and hands-on experiences. These opportunities enabled students to apply the knowledge and skills acquired in their academic program to practical industry contexts. These experiences helped students better understand the professional landscape and their career interests while becoming familiar with potential employers seeking new talent. Industry, in turn, benefited from fresh perspectives and innovative proposals generated by students, gaining insight into their capabilities and identifying potential talent. As a result, employability indicators for the Biotechnology Engineering program showed a relevant improvement. Challenge-based learning bridges academic training and industry needs. University-industry partnerships proved mutually beneficial, helping students develop competency and workforce readiness while providing companies with fresh ideas and access to emerging talent.

title: Advanced Packaging of Conformal Wideband Antennas for UAVs with Optimized RCS Reduction
authors: Manish Kumar Rauniyar, Kundan Kumar Suman, Ravi Kumar Gangwar
publish: IEEE Transactions on Components, Packaging and Manufacturing Technology
abstract: This article presents an advanced packaging architecture for conformal wideband antennas intended for unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), with specific emphasis on Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) connectivity and radar cross-section (RCS) reduction. The proposed design employs a cavity-embedded Vivaldi antenna, where conformal behavior is achieved through a curvature-matched machined cylindrical cavity and Rohacell support. The antenna is engineered to operate across 2-18 GHz, providing wideband coverage suitable for multi-functional UAV communication and sensing. The packaged structure enhances the realized gain (5-12 dBi across the band) and achieves a significant RCS reduction down to –18 dBsm, facilitating improved survivability and reduced detectability in radar-monitored environments. Fabricated on a RO4350B substrate, the antenna maintains a compact footprint of 0.45λ₀ × 0.34λ₀ × 0.0016λ₀ at 2 GHz and is optimized for aerodynamic compatibility with UAV fuselage contours. Comprehensive full-wave simulations and measurements validate the performance of the integrated antenna–cavity assembly in terms of impedance bandwidth, radiation characteristics, and scattering behavior. The presented packaging approach demonstrates a robust pathway for UAV-centric wideband antenna integration, offering improved radiation stability, reduced signature, and compatibility with next-generation V2X communication systems.

title: Performance Analysis of Police Equipment Materials Based on SiC/CFs/EP Composite Materials
authors: Junqiang Ge
abstract: ABSTRACTExisting studies on silicon carbide/carbon fiber/epoxy resin composites lack a systematic multi-dimensional performance evaluation, and the mechanism of the effects of reinforcement ratio, particle size and molding process on the performance is not clear. This limits its scale-up application in police equipment. Based on this, three reinforcement distribution solutions were designed and prepared for the study (A: monolayer carbon fiber +silicon carbide. B: 0°/90° staggered carbon fiber +silicon carbide. C: gradient silicon carbide content 0-20 wt. %). In this study, the mechanical, thermal, abrasion, and impact resistance properties were systematically tested using vacuum assisted resin infusion molding process. Test results indicated that the tensile strength and elastic modulus of Solution C-20% were 12.60% and 12.84% higher than those of the baseline Solution A, respectively. The flexural strength increased by 29.00%, and the compressive strength increased by 31.40%. Additionally, compared to Solution A, Solution C-20% exhibited a 33.33% reduction in friction coefficient, a 45.24% reduction in wear rate, and an impact strength of 22.8 kJ/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. In the riot helmet application, the SolutionC-20% increased the service life by 59.52%. Overall, the optimized configuration achieved more than 30% average improvement across key mechanical indicators and nearly 60% enhancement in service life compared to the baseline, demonstrating its strong application potential for high-protection police equipment.The study established a multidimensional evaluation system covering mechanics, thermodynamics, wear resistance, and protection. Furthermore, this method clarified the comprehensive optimization strategy of 20 wt. % silicon carbide, 0°/90° carbon fiber layering, and gradient distribution. It provides quantitative basis and engineering path for the design of lightweight, high-protection composite materials for police use.

title: Locally Differentially Private Truth Discovery for Sparse Crowdsensing
authors: Pengfei Zhang, Zhikun Zhang, Yang Cao, Xiang Cheng, Youwen Zhu, Zhiquan Liu, Ji Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering
abstract: Truth discovery has emerged as an effective tool to mitigate data inconsistency in crowdsensing by prioritizing data from high-quality responders. While local differential privacy (LDP) has emerged as a crucial privacy-preserving paradigm, existing studies under LDP rarely explore a worker's participation in specific tasks for sparse scenarios, which may also reveal sensitive information such as individual preferences and behaviors. Existing LDP mechanisms, when applied to truth discovery in sparse settings, may create undesirable dense distributions, provide insufficient privacy protection, and introduce excessive noise, compromising the efficacy of subsequent non-private truth discovery. Additionally, the interplay between noise injection and truth discovery remains insufficiently explored in the current literature. To address these issues, we propose a lOcally differentially private truth diSCovery approach for spArse cRowdsensing, namely OSCAR. The main idea is to use advanced optimization techniques to reconstruct the sparse data distribution and re-formalize truth discovery by considering the statistical characteristics of injected Laplacian noise while protecting the privacy of both the tasks being completed and the corresponding sensory data. Specifically, to address the data density concerns while alleviating noise, we design a randomized response based Bernoulli matrix factorization method BerRR. To recover the sparse structures from densified, perturbed data, we formalize a 0-1 integer programming problem and develop a sparse recovery solving method SpaIE based on implicit enumeration. We further devise a Laplacian-sensitive truth discovery method LapCRH that leverages maximum likelihood estimation to re-formalize truth discovery by measuring differences between noisy values and truths based on the statistical characteristic of Laplacian noise. Our comprehensive theoretical analysis establishes OSCAR's privacy guarantees, utility bounds, and computational complexity. Experimental results show that OSCAR surpasses the state-of-the-arts by at least 30% in accuracy improvement.

title: Multi-dimensional Feature-Guided Cross-Population Human Activity Recognition and Prediction
authors: Renbo Liu, Yangfei Zhao, Pei Lv, Ke Wang, Weifeng Zhang, Zhaoyang Ge, Mingliang Xu
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: With the rapid development of wearable devices and intelligent sensing technologies, the demand for human behavior recognition in rehabilitation medicine and human-machine collaboration has been increasing. To address the issue of high variability in gait features caused by individual differences in cross-population gait analysis, and to tackle the insufficient generalization ability of models due to the coupling of pathological features with normal gait, we propose a multi-dimensional spatiotemporal feature-guided SG-LSTM framework, based on a dual-branch architecture comprising symmetric LSTM (S-LSTM) and grouped LSTM (G-LSTM) networks, for cross-population lower-limb activity recognition and prediction. On the one hand, the S-LSTM module with a symmetric input structure is used to explicitly model the spatiotemporal symmetry of lower-limb joints in normal gait. On the other hand, the G-LSTM module with a joint functional grouping strategy and local motion decoupling is employed to explicitly model the abnormal motion coupling of lower-limb joints in pathological gait. Furthermore, a dynamically weighted multi-task loss function is designed to jointly optimize gait trajectory prediction and classification tasks, allowing the framework to simultaneously produce both outputs and enhance the adaptability of the model. Extensive experiments on our self-constructed gait dataset as well as the HuGaDB and WearGait-PD datasets demonstrate that the proposed method not only outperforms several existing approaches in cross-population human behavior prediction and gait recognition, but also holds potential clinical application value, achieving state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance.

title: RIS-Assisted Simultaneous Legitimate Monitoring and Jamming for Industrial Wireless Networks
authors: Yuquan Xiao, Qinghe Du, Likang Zhang, Yijing Ren, Xiao Tang, Maged Elkashlan, Zhu Han
abstract: In this paper, we study Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface (RIS)-assisted simultaneous legitimate monitoring and jamming techniques for industrial environments, in which a Legitimate Monitor (LM) and a Legitimate Jammer (LJ) can continuously monitor and jam suspicious communications. Specifically, we propose a Block Coordinate Descent and Particle Swarm Optimization (BCD-PSO) based scheme to optimize RIS's phase shift matrix for reducing the jamming power meanwhile satisfying the Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) requirement for successful monitoring. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed scheme can significantly reduce the jamming power and improve the Successful Monitoring Probability (SMP). Moreover, we examine and find that there exists the best deployment of RIS to further enhance the system performance.
