title: Entanglement Swapping with Misty States
authors: Lia Yeh, Mary Ganey, Prabhav Gudapati, Ginger Jia, SeungHwan Jung, Yisakor Melke, Sudha Swain, Christina Naylor, Ethan Parr, Amy Pezzoni, Carla Gehlhausen, Daphne John, Greg Beutler, John Phillips, Kevin Moist, Rachel Zhao, Rebekah Randall, Vickie Houlihan, Colleen Rock, Scout Winchester, Adrian German
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The misty states formalism introduced by Terry Rudolph in 2017 is an alternative pedagogical approach that acts as a bridge to the standard quantum computation curriculum. We have shown elsewhere how it works, by using it to prove and demonstrate: phase kickback, Bernstein-Vazirani, Deutsch-Josza, the Grover quantum search, superdense coding, teleportation and the GHZ game. Here we use it to communicate entanglement swapping (also known as the teleportation of entanglement).

title: Quantum Integration of Spiking Leaky Integrate-and-Fire Neurons and Variational Circuits for Enhanced Multiclass Classification
authors: Mandeep Kaur Saggi, Amandeep Singh Bhatia, Sabre Kais
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Quantum-AI is Ushering in a new scientific revolution, where Quantum Spiking Neural Networks (QSNN) with Quantum Leaky Integrate-and-Fire (QLIF) neurons propel advancements in the modeling of complex biological systems and neural networks. Inspired by the remarkable synergy between quantum mechanics and biological spiking neurons, we present a novel QSNN architecture that leverages QLIF to tackle complex AI tasks. Leveraging entanglement, the quantum variant of SNNs acts as a game-changer, offering faster computation, enhanced accuracy. QLIF Spiking Neurons provide a powerful solution to scalability issues, advancing the potential of AI and quantum technologies in neural networks and complex problem-solving across industries and science. Our approach presents the QLIF model, where neurons integrate incoming signals and fire upon a threshold crossing, creating spikes that interact with quantum circuits to form a quantum-spiking neural network. Our work aims to: (i) enhance computational time and (ii) enrich the learning capabilities of the training model. Our results highlight that QSNN not only accelerates training but also improves accuracy, particularly in deeper quantum circuits. This demonstrates the effectiveness of integrating spiking neural dynamics into quantum models, paving the way for more efficient and biologically inspired quantum learning systems. The proposed approach holds promise for future applications in neuromorphic quantum computing and real-time edge intelligence.

title: Research on the Construction of Digital Competence Framework for Engineering Talents-Based on Literature Review Approach
authors: Huiming Fan, Yuxi Fan, Yu Gong
publish: 2025 World Engineering Education Forum - Global Engineering Deans Council (WEEF-GEDC)
abstract: In order to further their digitalization objectives and encourage the growth of the manufacturing sector, nations all over the world are increasingly choosing to cultivate composite and inventive engineering talent with both professional and digital competencies. Nonetheless, there remains disagreement among academics over the meaning and components of digital competency. In order to analyze the three aspects of competence definition, element composition, and topic differences, the study employs the literature review technique and focuses on the definition and components of digital competence of engineering abilities. A five-dimensional consensus on technical hard skills, transversal soft skills, management coordination skills, cultural responsibility, and continuous learning and adaptability is formed by the elements of competence, according to the study, which also reveals that different framework developers have different priorities for the digital competency of engineering talents. Through the study, the article seeks to help the development of engineering talent's digital competency.

title: Simulation Evaluation of Monocular Visual SLAM: ORB-SLAM3, DROID-SLAM, DPVO, and DPV-SLAM
authors: Kazuki Adachi, Yoshitaka Hara, Sousuke Nakamura
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Multisensor Fusion and Integration for Intelligent Systems (MFI)
abstract: In this paper, we conduct simulation experiments on major monocular visual SLAM methods and qualitatively evaluated the performance of each method. The methods use in the evaluation are the classical ORB-SLAM3, the deep-learningbased DROID-SLAM, and its successor Deep Patch Visual Odometry / SLAM (DPVO / DPV-SLAM). In our experiments across several environments, we compared three types of data: 3D reconstructed point cloud maps, camera trajectory of accuracy, and the processing time of each SLAM method. These experiments showed that ORB-SLAM3 provided stable performance with the shortest processing time, while DPVSLAM with classical loop closure achieved the highest accuracy by effectively correcting scale drift. In contrast, DROID-SLAM was limited by its high computational cost.

title: Impact of Macroeconomic Indicators and NLP-Based Budget Sentiment on FDI Inflows
authors: Sanatan Tripathi, Srushti Moghe, G Harsha Vardhini, Harsh Garg, Arya Mahashabde, Anil Jadhav
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Foreign Direct Investments (FDI) spur economic growth through increased production, employment, and technology, especially in developing economies such as India. This research investigates the under-explored effect of policy sentiment from India’s Annual Financial Statements (Budget) on FDI inflows (1990-2022), combining macroeconomic data with sentiment analysis via NLP. Regression models explore the Budget Sentiment Score with conventional indicators such as GDP growth, inflation, trade balance, and population. Model comparison with and without sentiment scores, the research finds that actual economic measures far exceed policy announcements in explaining FDI inflows. GDP per capita exhibits a high positive correlation with FDI inflows ($=15.74$, p $(\lt)0.01$), whereas GDP growth is negatively correlated ($=-3.66$, p $(\lt)0.01$). The sentiment score, while being positively correlated with FDI inflows $(r=0.604)$, failed to significantly enhance the explanatory power of the model ($=-2.27, \mathrm{p}\gt0.05$). The study points out that although budgets provide information, tangible economic fundamentals are the major drivers of FDI.

title: Optimal Scaling Quantum Interior Point Method for Linear Optimization
authors: Mohammadhossein Mohammadisiahroudi, Zeguan Wu, Pouya Sampourmahani, Jun-Kai You, Tamás Terlaky
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The emergence of huge-scale, data-intensive linear optimization (LO) problems in applications such as machine learning has driven the need for more computationally efficient interior point methods (IPMs). While conventional IPMs are polynomial-time algorithms with rapid convergence, their periteration cost can be prohibitively high for dense large-scale LO problems. Quantum linear system solvers have shown potential in accelerating the solution of linear systems arising in IPMs. In this work, we introduce a novel almost-exact quantum IPM, where the Newton system is constructed and solved on a quantum computer, while solution updates occur on a classical machine. Additionally, all matrix-vector products are performed on the quantum hardware. This hybrid quantum-classical framework achieves an optimal worst-case scaling of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathcal{O}\left(n^{2}\right)$</tex> for fully dense LO problems. To ensure high precision, despite the limited accuracy of quantum operations, we incorporate iterative refinement techniques both within and outside the proposed IPM iterations. The proposed algorithm has a quantum complexity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathcal{O}\left(n^{1.5} \kappa_{A} \log \left(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\right)\right)$</tex> queries to QRAM and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathcal{O}\left(n^{2} \log \left(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\right)\right)$</tex> classical arithmetic operations. Our method outperforms the worst-case complexity of prior classical and quantum IPMs, offering a significant improvement in scalability and computational efficiency.

title: Optimizing Telco Networks with Foundation Models: A Scalable Approach for Tabular Data
authors: Franck Le, Keith Grueneberg, Erich Nahum, Douglas Freimuth, Vadim Sheinin
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Foundation models have revolutionized natural language processing and computer vision, yet their potential for tabular data, particularly in telecommunications, remains underexplored. We apply foundation models to large-scale telco drive test data, achieving up to $30 \%$ relative gain in $R^{2}$ over state-of-the-art methods like XGBoost. A central focus is transforming numeric telco data into tokens, enabling meaningful embeddings. Unlike NLP and computer vision, the telco domain lacks pretrained models, necessitating training from scratch to capture domain-specific patterns. We also detail data preprocessing and sequence conversion techniques tailored for foundation models, as well as the trade-offs of various numeric binning methods (e.g., cut, qcut, Lloyd-Max quantization) affecting data balance and token frequency. Beyond KPI prediction, we demonstrate the ability of the foundation model as a network optimization simulator, offering significant advantages over manual tuning. Our results show that foundation models excel on large datasets with millions of rows and high categorical complexity, consistently outperforming XGBoost, which remains more effective on simpler datasets. Furthermore, foundation models achieve up to $13 \%$ relative gain in $R^{2}$ in public tabular datasets, underscoring their versatility for complex, high-dimensional data challenges.

title: Partitioned Hybrid Quantum Fourier Neural Operators for Scientific Quantum Machine Learning
authors: Paolo Marcandelli, Yuanchun He, Stefano Mariani, Martina Siena, Stefano Markidis
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: We introduce the Partitioned Hybrid Quantum Fourier Neural Operator (PH-QFNO), a generalization of the Quantum Fourier Neural Operator (QFNO) for scientific machine learning. PH-QFNO partitions the Fourier operator computation across classical and quantum resources, enabling tunable quantum-classical hybridization and distributed execution across quantum and classical devices. The method extends QFNOs to higher dimensions and incorporates a message-passing framework to distribute data across different partitions. Input data are encoded into quantum states using unary encoding, and quantum circuit parameters are optimized using a variational scheme. We implement PH-QFNO using PennyLane with PyTorch integration and evaluate it on Burgers' equation, incompressible and compressible Navier-Stokes equations. We show that PH-QFNO recovers classical FNO accuracy. On incompressible Navier-Stokes, PH-QFNO achieves higher accuracy than its classical counterparts. Finally, we perform a sensitivity analysis under input noise, confirming improved stability of PH-QFNO over classical baselines.

title: First Experience with Real-Time Control Using Simulated VQC-Based Quantum Policies
authors: Yize Sun, Mohamad Hagog, Marc Weber, Daniel Hein, Steffen Udluft, Yunpu Ma, Volker Tresp
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: This paper investigates the integration of quantum computing into offline reinforcement learning and the deployment of the resulting quantum policy in a real-time control hardware realization of the cart-pole system. Variational Quantum Circuits (VQCs) are used to represent the policy. Classical model-based offline policy search was applied, in which a pure VQC with trainable input-output weights is used as a policy network instead of a classical multilayer perceptron. The goal is to evaluate the potential of deploying quantum architectures in real-world industrial control problems. The experimental results show that the investigated model-based offline policy search is able to generate quantum policies that can balance the hardware cart-pole. A latency analysis reveals that while local simulated execution meets real-time requirements, cloud-based quantum processing remains too slow for closed-loop control.

title: Extending Learning-by-Asking to Real-World Visual Question Answering
authors: Sunil Netra, Anil Vijarnia, Satish Bhambri, Pranav Malhotra
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Learning-by-Asking (LBA) is an interactive learning framework that enhances sample efficiency in Visual Question Answering (VQA) tasks by allowing models to actively generate and pose questions during training. This process mimics human curiosity-driven learning, leading to more effective knowledge acquisition. Previous studies have demonstrated LBA’s success in structured, synthetic environments such as CLEVR, where questions follow predefined logical patterns. However, its applicability to real-world datasets, which contain more diverse and complex natural images, remains largely unexplored. In this paper, we extend LBA to large-scale real-world datasets such as VQA v2 and GQA by integrating transformer-based question generation models, including GPT and T5, to produce semantically rich and contextually relevant questions. Additionally, we employ curriculum learning techniques to prioritize the selection of the most informative questions, optimizing the learning process. Through extensive experimentation, we assess LBA’s ability to generalize beyond synthetic settings, comparing its performance against traditional supervised learning approaches. Our findings suggest that LBA maintains its effectiveness in real-world scenarios by improving sample efficiency and enhancing model robustness. However, challenges remain in ensuring question diversity, mitigating biases, and addressing ambiguities in natural image datasets. Future work could further refine LBA by incorporating human-in-the-loop feedback mechanisms and exploring open-world generalization techniques.

title: FedHDC-IDS: A Hyperdimensional Computing Based Network Intrusion Detection Systems for IoT Networks
authors: Othmane Belarbi, Yogha Restu Pramadi, Omer Rana, Yuhua Li, Aftab Khan, Theodoros Spyridopoulos
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Traditional AI-based Network Intrusion Detection Systems (NIDS) typically rely on centralised analysis of collected data, which is impractical and raises privacy concerns in distributed IoT networks. Federated Learning (FL) has been explored as a method to preserve privacy, enabling decentralised model training in AI NIDS. Although FL minimises data transfers, it still suffers from high communication overhead and increased computational costs that emerge from the underlying Deep Learning (DL) model. FedHDC-IDS, a novel approach that combines Federated Learning (FL) and Hyperdimensional Computing (HDC) to enhance the security of IoT networks through efficient collaborative learning while preserving user privacy. HDC offers lightweight, energyefficient learning with fast convergence, making it well-suited for resource-constrained IoT devices. Our framework uses Radial Basis Function (RBF) encoding to efficiently represent data and FedAvg for model aggregation. Evaluated on the CIC-ToNIoT dataset, FedHDC-IDS demonstrates performance comparable to MLP-based FL systems while reducing training time by $1.46 \mathbf{x}$ and model size by $67 \%$.

title: Trustworthiness and Consensus in Distributed and Connected Autonomous Systems
authors: Lei Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 45th International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems Workshops (ICDCSW)
abstract: Recognising that many next-generation mobile applications are discretely distributed in their topology and that an individual node possesses more and more capabilities for local decision-making, one promising solution is to utilise distributed consensus protocols/mechanisms for achieving trustworthy joint decisions among the participants. Unlike centralised systems where information is sent to a central node for decision, the distributed system make decision among the nodes, who are not required to trust each other, though predefined fault-tolerant distributed consensus schemes.

title: Detecting Stealthy Data Poisoning Attacks in AI Code Generators
authors: Cristina Improta
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: Deep learning (DL) models for natural language-to-code generation have become integral to modern software development pipelines. However, their heavy reliance on large amounts of data, often collected from unsanitized online sources, exposes them to data poisoning attacks, where adversaries inject malicious samples to subtly bias model behavior. Recent targeted attacks silently replace secure code with semantically equivalent but vulnerable implementations without relying on explicit triggers to launch the attack, making it especially hard for detection methods to distinguish clean from poisoned samples. We present a systematic study on the effectiveness of existing poisoning detection methods under this stealthy threat model. Specifically, we perform targeted poisoning on three DL models (CodeBERT, CodeT5+, AST-T5), and evaluate spectral signatures analysis, activation clustering, and static analysis as defenses. Our results show that all methods struggle to detect triggerless poisoning, with representation-based approaches failing to isolate poisoned samples and static analysis suffering false positives and false negatives, highlighting the need for more robust, triggerindependent defenses for AI-assisted code generation.

title: Analysis and Prediction of Agricultural Yield Using XGBoost, CatBoost and Light GBM Algorithms
authors: Chandragupta Raghav, Alka Chaudhary, Devershi Pallavi Bhatt
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Agriculture is one of the most important industries for our survival and technology is making it better every day. This paper concentrates on crop yield analysis and prediction using a machine learning algorithm from a dataset that has considerations like crop type, soil type, irrigation method, fertilizer usage, and water consumption. The dataset will act as a foundation to understand important relations and trends causing variations in yield. Advanced predictive models using XGBoost, CatBoost and LightGBM techniques are used. Result reveals that machine learning methods can very effectively predict the agricultural yield, thus providing further insights into optimization of resource usage and improving decisions regarding farming practice.

title: Feature Extraction Using Sparse Autoencoder in Automatic Image Tagging
authors: Farzad Khodayari, Ehsan Pazoki
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis (IPRIA)
abstract: With the increasing volume of images, processing high-dimensional feature of image presents challenges, particularly due to the curse of dimensionality, which adversely affects the accuracy and speed of automatic image annotation algorithms. Consequently, extracting appropriate features is a critical challenge in this domain. Another significant issue is the scalability of algorithms; however, dimensionality reduction methods based on deep learning can effectively address this problem. In this paper, we employ a feature extraction method using sparse autoencoders to tackle these challenges. This approach reduces high-dimensional image feature vectors, mitigating the curse of dimensionality and consequently enhancing both the accuracy and speed of image annotation methods. For the image tagging phase, we utilized a modified version of the traditional 2PKNN method, a well-established search-based image annotation technique. The MIRFlicker dataset, consisting of social images, served as our data source. By evaluating common metrics such as precision, recall, F1-Score, and AUC against previously reported methods, we found that our approach achieved an F1-Score of $\mathbf{1 6. 7} \boldsymbol{\pm} \mathbf{1. 1}$, a Macro AUC of $14.4 \pm 0.7$, and a Micro AUC increase of $6.9 \pm 0.2$ compared to similar works. Furthermore, the sparse autoencoder-based feature extraction method reduced the execution time of the search-based algorithm by one third compared to traditional dimensionality reduction techniques.

title: On the Potential of Quantum Computing in Classical Program Analysis
authors: Yicheng Guang, Pietro Zanotta, Kai Zhou, Yueqi Chen, Ramin Ayanzadeh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Classical program analysis techniques, such as abstract interpretation and symbolic execution, are essential for ensuring software correctness, optimizing performance, and enabling compiler optimizations. However, these techniques face computational limitations when analyzing programs with large or exponential state spaces, limiting their effectiveness in ensuring system reliability. Quantum computing, with its parallelism and ability to process superposed states, offers a promising solution to these challenges. In this work, we present <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Q E X$</tex>, a design that uses quantum computing to analyze classical programs. By synthesizing quantum circuits that encode program states in superposition and trace data dependency between program variables through entanglement, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Q E X$</tex> enables the simultaneous exploration of program behaviors, significantly improving scalability and precision. This advancement has broad applications, from debugging and security verification to optimizing compilers for next-generation hardware. As a proof-of-concept, we evaluated QEX on 22 benchmark programs, demonstrating its effectiveness in analyzing program states. To support more language features and make <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Q E X$</tex> realized sooner in Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computing (FTQC), we propose <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{QEX}-\mathrm{H}$</tex> which hybridizes QEX with classical analysis techniques. To our knowledge, this work is the first proposal to use quantum computing for classical program analysis.

title: Noise-Robust Few-Shot Classification via Gated Memory-Augmented Prototypical Networks
authors: Qiuyu Lang, Xichen Ling
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: The initial Prototypical Networks (ProtoNets) are prone to interference when handling support sets with noise, resulting in reduced classification accuracy. This paper suggests two major enhancements to ProtoNets to address this issue: first is a memory module that stores and utilizes stable category representations from previous tasks, and second is a noiseaware gating mechanism that adapts the model's reliance on current prototypes and memory representations based on the current task's noise level. Studies in environments with varying levels of Gaussian noise demonstrate that incorporating the gating mechanism greatly enhances model accuracy.The complete model, which combines memory and gating mechanism, achieves optimal performance across multiple noise levels. GM-ProtoNet greatly improves accuracy while maintaining constant FLOPs and keeping inference latency under 4 ms, demonstrating an excellent lightweight design with practical deployment potential and minimal additional computational overhead.

title: Energy-Efficient Scheduling and Power Control in 5G V2X Networks
authors: Namratha Akshaya, Namrutha M, Niharika Reddy G, Thangam S
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Energy efficiency is a major challenge in 5 G V2X networks, especially for battery-limited vehicles and network devices that must support high data rates. This paper proposes an Energy-Efficient Scheduling and Transmit Power Control Scheme to optimize energy use while maintaining accuracy and response time. The approach combines a dynamic scheduling algorithm and adaptive power control to minimize energy consumption. Specifically, an Interference-Aware Scheduling Scheme and an Adaptive Power Control Model are designed for safety-critical and non-safety communications. Simulation results show that the proposed method reduces energy consumption by $\mathbf{X} \%$ while improving network performance metrics such as latency and reliability. These improvements make the approach practical for real-world 5G V2X deployments, enhancing efficiency in energyconstrained environments.

title: Towards Multi-Platform Mutation Testing of Task-Based Chatbots
authors: Diego Clerissi, Elena Masserini, Daniela Micucci, Leonardo Mariani
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: Chatbots, also known as conversational agents, have become ubiquitous, offering services for a multitude of domains. Unlike general-purpose chatbots, task-based chatbots are software designed to prioritize the completion of tasks of the domain they handle (e.g., flight booking). Given the growing popularity of chatbots, testing techniques that can generate full conversations as test cases have emerged. Still, thoroughly testing all the possible conversational scenarios implemented by a taskbased chatbot is challenging, resulting in incorrect behaviors that may remain unnoticed. To address this challenge, we proposed Mutabot, a mutation testing approach for injecting faults in conversations and producing faulty chatbots that emulate defects that may affect the conversational aspects. In this paper, we present our extension of Mutabot to multiple platforms (Dialogflow and Rasa), and present experiments that show how mutation testing can be used to reveal weaknesses in test suites generated by the Botium state-of-the-art test generator.

title: A Model for Real-Time Pre-Processing of Sensitive Data on Internet of Things Devices
authors: Egor Shiriaev, Nikolay Kucherov, Maria Lapina
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Pre-processing of data in a fog computing network for IoT devices in real time requires optimization of algorithms and task distribution to work under limited resources. Using fully homomorphic encryption allows processing encrypted data without decrypting it, ensuring a high level of confidentiality. Fully homomorphic encryption schemes such as TFHE, BFV, BGV and CKKS are optimized for various types of data and tasks, making them applicable in IoT systems. The resulting model, based on the integration of fully homomorphic encryption with fog computing, helps to minimize latency, reduce network load and ensure secure data processing in real time, which is especially important for smart cities, healthcare and the Industrial Internet of Things.

title: Chatbots-based Systematic Review for Student Learning and Engagement with LLMs
authors: Rohini S, T. Sethukarasi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) are Artificial Intelligence (AI) systems designed to process and generate natural language, enabling them to mimic human communication. With advancements in deep learning, chatbots are increasing in this modern world. Chatbots are automated conversational agents that allow humans to interact with machines naturally and intuitively. In the field of education, chatbots have the potential to transform teaching and learning by engaging students, tailoring learning experiences, assisting educators, and providing valuable insights into students' behaviours. Although various strategies have been developed for incorporating LLM-based chatbots into legal pedagogy, there remains a gap in research exploring the recent design techniques for chatbot-learner interactions within educational settings. Hence, this study presents a systematic review to understand, compare, and reflect on recent attempts to utilize LLM-based chatbots in education to enhance Legal pedagogy. At first, the described literature is presented for analyzing the general concept of the LLM. Further, the dataset description of conventional models is discussed in this work. For a better understanding, the advantages and disadvantages of the present models are analyzed and listed. In the end, the future gap and challenges are explained to develop an effective LLM-based chatbot for student learning and engagement. This study contains a systematic review of the existing body of knowledge, critically assesses the potential and limitations of LLM chatbots in legal pedagogy, and sets a direction for future inquiry and development in this field.

title: Secure and Scalable Healthcare Document Integrity using Merkle Tree Variants and Public Blockchain Anchoring
authors: Tibin Thomas, Jubilant J Kizhakkethottam, Joby P P, Neethan Elizabeth Abraham
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Healthcare data management demands secure, scalable, and efficient systems to uphold patient’s data with safety and integrity. Existing frameworks are primarily based on a centralized database, or a centralized data model, Centralized models have vulnerability outcomes of tampering, latency exposure, and reduce the extent of volume that can be accessed due to integrated and static pathways. In this paper, the proposed system presents a lightweight document verification framework with a 4-ary Merkle trees, optimally adjusted for NoSQL structures, such as Mongo DB. Periodic anchoring of root hashes maintained in an blockchain, results in a speedy validation if evidence is tampered, and reduced proof complexity to permit integration made for validated high frequency flows of health care data.

title: Differential Mobile Robot Path Tracking with Backstepping and GWO Based Optimized FOPID Controllers
authors: Hoang T. Tran, Long Q. Dinh, Dung T. Nguyen, Mui D. Nguyen, Duong M. Phung, Minh T. Nguyen
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Informatics (ICCRI)
abstract: To improve the efficiency of differential mobile robots (DWMR), improving their trajectory tracking capabilities is important. Especially in navigation problems with complex paths. This paper presents a new combination of Backstepping Controller (BSC) and Fractional Order Proportional-IntegralDerivative (FOPID) controller for DWMR. The improved Grey Wolf Optimization (GWO) strategy combines GWO with the Slime Molding Algorithm (SMA) to determine the parameters of FOPID. The designed controller addresses the nonlinearities, ensuring system stability and accurate trajectory tracking. The cost function used for the optimization process is a combination of Integral Absolute Error (IAE) and Integral Mean Square Error (ISE) to minimize the state deviation and enhance the response capability. The results are demonstrated through simulations on MATLAB-Simulink with different trajectory scenarios and compared with state-of-the-art optimization techniques such as PSO or GWO. The results show that the controller helps to improve the trajectory tracking ability, the cost function and the position error are improved compared to other optimization techniques.

title: Two Requirements Scenarios That Trigger Human Errors in Software Development: a Case Study in the Aviation Industry
authors: Fuqun Huang, Yichen Wang, Yikun Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: Software requirements specifications play a critical role in ensuring the reliability of software systems. This paper examines how two novel requirements scenarios-Selectivity and Post-completion Error-can trigger developers to introduce defects into programs. These scenarios are grounded in psychological theories of human error and are not addressed by conventional requirements quality standards. A case study was conducted to investigate whether and how these human errorbased criteria manifest in real-world aviation industry projects. The study analyzed ten aviation-related software systems, with defect data collected by an independent third-party testing center during certification tests. The results indicate that violations of the proposed criteria in requirements specifications do, in fact, lead to corresponding errors during the design and coding phases. Based on these findings, we recommend incorporating these two criteria to proactively prevent and detect software defects.

title: SPTAD: Transformer with Sinusoidal Prototype Guidance for Time Series Anomaly Detection
authors: Yushi Li, Zhenyu Wen, Mengxue Lin, Jiajia Zhu, Shuyan Liu, Zesheng Hu, Ming Zhu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Multivariate time series anomaly detection plays a crucial role in ensuring the safety and stability of industrial systems. Currently, reconstruction-based methods rely on the powerful capability of deep learning models to extract temporal features, showing excellent performance in modeling normal patterns. However, they also tend to extract unnecessary anomalous features, leading to reconstruct of anomalies well. To address this issue, we propose a Transformer with Sinusoidal Prototype Guidance for Time Series Anomaly Detection (SPTAD). We introduce a sinusoidal prototype guidance module that uses structural priors of periodic subspaces to constrain the model to reconstruct within the normal pattern space by aggregating normal patterns based on prototype similarity. It enhances the model's representation capability in the latent space while avoiding interference from anomalous features. Moreover, SPTAD employs Transformer to capture long-term dependencies in time series, improving its ability to model global temporal features. Experiments on three real-world datasets demonstrate that SPTAD achieves an average F1 score of 95.59%, significantly outperforming six baseline methods.

title: Adaptive Optimization of Multi-scene Image Feature Extraction for Metering Asset Fragmentation Operations and Maintenance
authors: Wanxu Zhao, Xiaoze Liu, Tingting Zhang, Yu Cui
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: In the fragmented operation and maintenance scenarios of electric power metering assets, the construction of metering boxes, the rotation of old equipment, marketing census, on-site inspections and inspections, etc., put forward very high requirements for image feature extraction technology. These scenarios not only have significant differences in work objectives, archiving needs to accurately record the details of the appearance of the equipment, inspection needs to quickly identify potential safety hazards, marketing census needs to balance the accuracy and efficiency, but also face the complexity of the field environment, uneven data distribution and other issues, resulting in the accuracy, efficiency and stability of image feature extraction is difficult to achieve synergistic optimization. Traditional fixed models such as Mask R-CNN can ensure a certain degree of accuracy, but the delay is too high in real-time scenarios; MobileNet-SSD is lightweight but cannot meet the demand for fine-grained feature extraction, and both of them have a significant decrease in stability under the interference of backlighting, motion blur, and so on. Aiming at this situation, this paper proposes an adaptive feature extraction framework of “Scene Sensing Dynamic Adaptation - Joint Optimization”. The framework realizes automatic scene identification through the “demand interference” two-dimensional quantitative model, adjusts the extraction strategy on demand based on the two-branch dynamic network, and combines meta-learning and transfer learning to complete cross-scene knowledge reuse and anti-interference optimization. The experimental results show that in the measurement box archiving scenario, the feature extraction accuracy of “one box with multiple signatures” reaches 95.3 %, which is 12.7 % higher than that of traditional Mask R-CNN; in the on-site inspection scenario, the inference time of a single image is reduced to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 9 m s}$</tex>, which is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 6. 2 \%}$</tex> shorter than that of MobileNetSSD; and under different interference scenarios such as backlight and motion blur, the inference time of a single image is reduced to 89 ms, which is 46.2 % shorter than that of MobileNet-SSD. In different interference scenarios such as backlight and motion blur, the accuracy fluctuation is controlled within 4.8 %, which is significantly better than the fixed model. Meanwhile, in small sample scenarios (e.g., only 1,000 training images in the archiving scenario), the feature extraction accuracy of the framework reaches 91.2 %, which is close to the training effect of the traditional model with 5,000 samples, and significantly reduces the cost of data annotation. This study not only provides a dynamically adapted image feature extraction scheme for the fragmented operation and maintenance of power metering assets, but also provides a referable technical path for the intelligent optimization of visual feature extraction in multiple scenarios.

title: High-Fidelity Digital Human Light Field Rendering Method Based on Tsdf and Super-Resolution Neural Networks
authors: Xuwen Zheng, Shujun Xing, Xinzhu Sang, Binbin Yan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advanced Algorithms and Neural Networks (AANN)
abstract: Light field displays have great potential in the field of 3D display, but high-fidelity digital human real-time light field content generation is still challenging. Existing techniques are difficult to balance frame rate and image quality, and suffer from slow operation and low image quality. In this paper, we propose a new method to improve the sparse-view image quality by a lightweight super-resolution network, ESPCN, and to improve the rendering frame rate and view generation quality by using depthguided reprojection and optimized ray casting techniques. In the target view shading stage, a 3D spatial contrast mapping strategy is introduced to more accurately simulate the color differences between viewpoints, reduce noise, and improve image detail and visual quality. Experiments show that this method achieves realtime rendering of a high-fidelity digital human with a model size of 1.5 GB, containing 100,000 triangles, at a total resolution of 8 K, with a light field view count of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0}$</tex>, and a frame rate of up to 100 fps.

title: Quantum Parrondo's Game with Single Qubit Quantum Walk
authors: Yun-Hsuan Chen, Ran-Yu Chang, Tsung-Wei Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Parrondo's paradox shows that alternating two losing strategies can yield a net positive outcome—a counterintuitive effect relevant to probabilistic systems and control. We demonstrate a quantum analogue using single-qubit inhomogeneous quantum walk—unlike prior work that required multi-coin or position-dependent constructions. Instead, we apply a local phase gate at the origin and alternate two fixed <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SU}(2)$</tex> coins, with parameters from recent inhomogeneous quantum walks. Sequence ABB yields positive displacement despite no individual bias. This establishes that coherent interference alone can reproduce the Parrondo effect in single-qubit systems, with implications for low-cost quantum algorithms and transport protocols.

title: A 71 DB Spurious-Free Dynamic Range (SFDR) and Low Power CMOS Hybrid Digital-To-Analog Converter (DAC) for 5G New Radio Sub-6 GHZ Applications
authors: Norhamizah Idros, Jagadheswaran Rajendran, Selvakumar Mariappan, Asrulnizam Abd Manaf, Narendra Kumar, Arokia Nathan
publish: 2025 IEEE 32nd International Symposium on the Physical and Failure Analysis of Integrated Circuits (IPFA)
abstract: This paper presents a high speed 16-bit hybrid Digital-to-Analog converter (DAC) featuring a digital filtering mechanism designed to eliminate glitches and ensure high signal integrity at an operational speed of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 0 0 ~ M S} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>. Fabricated using a 65 nm process and operating on a 1 V supply, the hybrid DAC integrates a current-steering (CS) architecture for the six most significant bits (MSB) and a binary-weighted resistors (BWR) for the ten least significant bits (LSB), effectively managing power consumption. Occupying an active area of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.06 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>, the DAC consumes 8.36 mW of power. It demonstrates differential nonlinearity (DNL) ranging from -0.11 to +0.10 LSB and integral nonlinearity (INL) from -0.17 to +0.15 LSB. Performance metrics at low and Nyquist frequencies have been recorded. At <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 0 ~ M H z}$</tex> input signal frequency, the spurious-free dynamic range (SFDR) is 79.23 dB and signal-to-noise ratio (SNDR) of 75.29 dB. While at the Nyquist frequency, the corresponding SFDR and SNDR is 71.14 dB and 70.72 dB, respectively. The proposed hybrid DAC demonstrates high resilience to process, voltage, and temperature (PVT) variations, with performance deviations constrained to within 4 %. This confirms its robustness and suitability for deployment in 5 G New Radio (NR) sub-6 GHz applications. The architecture delivers high-speed and high-resolution data conversion with notable accuracy and energy efficiency, offering a viable and power-conscious solution that aligns with the stringent requirements of modern <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 G}$</tex> NR sub-6 GHz communication systems.

title: Qamomile: A Cross-SDK Bridge for Quantum Optimization
authors: Wei-Hao Huang, Hiromichi Matsuyama, Wai-Hong Tam, Keisuke Sato, Yu Yamashiro
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Qamomile is a software development kit specifically designed for quantum optimization. Unlike other quantum SDKs such as Qiskit or PennyLane, Qamomile provides a framework that bridges classical mathematical optimization models and quantum circuit representations by leveraging an intermediate representation. Acting as a bridge between classical problems and quantum computing, Qamomile provides broad compatibility and deployment flexibility. Qamomile supports a variety of quantum computing platforms including Qiskit, QURI Parts, PennyLane, QuTiP, QuEra, and CUDA-Q. By standardizing the workflow from problem definition to result analysis, Qamomile empowers researchers to perform consistent benchmarking and comparative studies across hardware and algorithmic strategies. This interface accelerates the exploration of quantum advantage in optimization tasks and enhances reproducibility in quantum algorithm research.

title: EdgeAware: Distributed Intelligence for Latency-Sensitive Applications
authors: Sathish Kuppan Pandurangan, Alycia Sebastian
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Latency-sensitive applications like augmented reality, autonomous vehicles, and industrial internet of things (IoT) require that data is processed and acted upon very quickly, something traditional cloud models struggle to accommodate. This study introduces EdgeAware, a new methodology for distributed intelligence, developed specifically to enable low latency and high reliability through edge computing. EdgeAware describes a framework containing four salient components: a Latency-Aware Task Offloading Module, Federated Model Partitioning (FMP), Adaptive QoS Scheduling, and a Context-Aware Feedback Loop, it strategically integrates them to distribute workloads between edge and cloud. The amount of workloads sent to the cloud or edge is determined through real-time system metrics and reinforcement learning. The potential of EdgeAware is demonstrated through experiments that show the methodology outperforms three models, relating to latency, energy efficiency, average, model accuracy, and SLA task deadline. Specifically, the methodology is demonstrated to combat environmental dynamism while adhering to strict latency constraints. EdgeAware lays out a strong base for future research into real time intelligent systems, while it can be extended to areas like 6G, security and will lay a foundation for continual learning.

title: A Novel Deep Learning Approach for Intrusion Detection in Smart Manufacturing: A Generative Convolutional Network (GenConvNet) with DHDO
authors: Premkrishnan P, Lawrance G, Sam Paul
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: Manufacturing Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) are intensively integrated with the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) and are susceptible to a range of cyber threats. The paper proposes a new hybrid deep learning-based intrusion detection system for smart manufacturing CPS for the first time. To identify the best features for attack detection, we presented a new Dynamic Hippopotamus Dipper Optimization (DHDO) method based on a hybrid of Dynamic Dipper Throated Optimization (DDTO) and the Hippopotamus optimization algorithm (HOA). Next, we used the new deep learning algorithm GenConvNet (Generative Convolutional Networks) for intrusion detection. GenConvNet adopted aspects of Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs), through which we improved detection of known and unknown attacks. We implemented the proposed model using Python and tested the model using the ICS-ADD dataset. We reported an accuracy of 94.5%, precision of 93.8%, sensitivity of 94%, and specificity of 95.2% for the proposed DHDO model. Overall, we showed that the proposed model benchmarked several standard models, such as CNN, LSTM, GRU, and RNN. The proposed model provides no new intrusion detection technology but indicates a path to handle complex manufacturing data while improving security for CPS.

title: Design and Modelling of Saliva-based Immunity Prediction System
authors: T. Vasudeva Reddy, R Anirudh Reddy, M S S Bhargav, E. Pooja, K. Pavitranath Reddy, K. Karthikeya
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The human immune system is a critical line of defense against infections, in order to diagnose, there are blood-based tests which are invasive, these indicate antibody levels which are held accountable for the low immunity score of an individual, these diagnoses also require a well-equipped laboratory environment, and one cannot test individually, it also consumes a lot of time to process. With a growing demand for accessible health care solutions, there is a pressing need for non-invasive, portable technologies that can access immune status efficiently. The proposed system presents the design and development of a saliva-based immunity measurement system using the ESP32 microcontroller, biosensors like pH sensor and TDS/Conductivity sensor are used to read the biomarker values (IgA, Il-6, cortisol) present in the diagnostic fluid and an Analog-to-Digital Converter, precisely ADS1115 is used to process the sensor outputs, enabling digital analysis. This model eliminates the requirement of laboratory and promote the use of non-invasive sampling technique. This proposed solution offers a low-cost, portable, and user-friendly approach to immunity monitoring.

title: User Text Analysis for Mental Health Insights using Transformer-based Models
authors: J. Jasmine Gabriel, G. Harini, Abhirami M, Rajasekaran A, R. Raja, K. Raju
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: The increasing global occurrence of mental health disorders such as anxiety, depression, bipolar disorder, and suicidal ideation highlights the critical need for scalable and automated detection mechanisms. Traditional methods often lack real-time applicability and may exhibit biases due to data imbalance, limiting their effectiveness in early identification. This work addresses these challenges by proposing a Natural Language-based mental health classification system leveraging a fine-tuned Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) model to analyze user-generated textual data. A Kaggle mental health dataset comprising 53,043 statements was pre-processed through normalization, and class imbalance was mitigated using RandomOverSampler (ROS). Without ROS, the model showed a strong bias toward the majority classes, leading to suboptimal performance, particularly for underrepresented conditions. Post-ROS implementation, the system achieved notable improvements, with accuracy rising from 87% to 91%, and F1-scores for minority classes such as Bipolar and Suicidal reaching up to 0.99. The final model was integrated into a Streamlit-based web application to enable real-time, accessible mental health screening. Overall, this approach offers a scalable solution for digital mental health monitoring and early intervention by helping identify and support the treatment of individuals showing signs of psychological distress.

title: A Quantum Speedup in Localizing Transmission Loss Change in Optical Networks
authors: Yufei Zheng, Yu-Zhen Janice Chen, Prithwish Basu, Don Towsley
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The ability to localize transmission loss change to a subset of links in optical networks is crucial for maintaining network reliability, performance and security. Quantum probes, implemented by sending blocks of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n$</tex> coherent-state pulses augmented with continuous-variable (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{C V}$</tex>) squeezing (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=1$</tex>) or weak temporal-mode entanglement <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(n>1)$</tex> over a lossy channel to a receiver with homodyne detection capabilities, are known to be more sensitive than their quasi-classical counterparts in detecting a sudden increase in channel loss. The enhanced sensitivity can be characterized by the increased Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence of the homodyne output, before and after the loss change occurs. When combined with the theory of quickest change detection (QCD), the increase in KL divergence translates into a decrease in detection latency. In this work, we first revisit quantum probes over a channel, and consider the ratio of quantum to classical KL divergences as a metric for quantum speedup. We generalize previous results on <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=1$</tex> (CV squeezed states) to arbitrary values of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n$</tex>, and discuss the monotonicity and asymptotics of this ratio with respect to the parameters of the quantum probe. Assuming a subset of nodes in an optical network is capable of sending and receiving such probes through intermediate nodes with all-optical switching capabilities, we present a scheme for quickly detecting the links that have suffered a sudden drop in transmissivity. Since quantum probes lose their sensitivity with increasing loss in the channel, we first propose a probe construction algorithm that makes the set of links suffering transmission loss change identifiable, while minimizing the longest distance a probe traverses. We then introduce new cumulative sum (CUSUM) statistics with a stopping rule, which allows us to run the CUSUM algorithm to quickly localize the faulty links using our constructed probes. Finally, we show that the proposed scheme achieves a quantum speedup in decreasing the localization delay.

title: Forecasting the Future: A Hybrid Approach to Stock Market Prediction with LSTM, XGBoost and LightGBM
authors: Shailendra Kumar Mishra, Amith Hegde, Payal Kawar, Sujana B Hadalagi, K Sanjay Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Communications (InC4)
abstract: Stock price prediction is complex due to market volatility and uncertain trends. This paper presents a hybrid machine learning model combining Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), LightGBM, and XGBoost to enhance short-term stock forecasting. The approach includes data preprocessing, outlier detection, and model training to ensure reliable predictions. LSTM captures sequential trends, while LightGBM and XGBoost refine predictions using gradient boosting. The model is evaluated using Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) and Mean Absolute Error (MAE), demonstrating improved accuracy compared to standalone models. A comparative analysis highlights its effectiveness in tracking market trends while reducing prediction errors. The results confirm that the LSTM- XGBoost-LightGBM hybrid model balances precision and adaptability, making it a promising tool for financial forecasting.

title: Efficient Anonymous Spammer Review Detection using K-Nearest Neighbour Algorithm
authors: K. Malarvizhi, Madhu Sai. D, Chinna Varun. K, Sai Chandu. K, Anil Teja. M, Vaishnavi A
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems and Internet of Things (ICoICI)
abstract: E-commerce review sites are an important driver of consumer buying behavior, but the legitimacy of such websites is increasingly brought into question by the deluge of fake reviews, especially from anonymous reviewers. This work outlines the key issue of detecting fake reviews that erode consumer trust and site reputation. Conventional detection systems such as support vector machines and decision trees are susceptible to failure in successful detection of anonymous spammers. In an attempt to address such shortcomings, by introducing an advanced fake review detection system incorporating a variant K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) algorithm with text sentiment analysis and behavioral pattern analysis. The system examines linguistic signals, user behavior, and temporal review patterns to differentiate between authentic and inauthentic content. Rigorous testing reveals a new methodology with precision at a 92.7% accuracy rate that outscores existing alternatives at a low false positive rate. This research provides an overview of a scalable and automated system that is capable of protecting review sites from fraudulent behavior even when reviewer identity is anonymous.

title: Linking Medical Device Assurance Cases
authors: Tiago de Moraes Machado, Mark Lawford, Richard F. Paige, Alan Wassyng
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Software Reliability Engineering Workshops (ISSREW)
abstract: Traceability and assurance cases (ACs) are crucial for certification of medical devices built on product line platforms. Prone to inconsistencies in handling product lines, monolithic ACs can complicate traceability of claims, arguments and evidence. We previously introduced the separation of assurance for certain medical devices into two linked ACs: a Technological Assurance Case (TAC), addressing system safety concerns disregarding clinical effects on patients; and a Clinical Assurance Case (CAC), addressing safety of a clinical application. A key observed gap is the absence of traceability that links them to extend their utility. We now propose a traceability metamodel as part of TACTICS (Traceable Assurance Cases for Trustworthy Integrated Compliance and Safety), a model-based methodology to support traceability across multiple assurance cases. We present an overview of this traceability process, conceptually, using a TAC/CAC for a medical system as an example, discussing its benefits, challenges and limitations.

title: Multiplexed Control at Scale for Electrode Arrays in Trapped-Ion Quantum Processors
authors: Ryutaro Ohira, Shinichi Morisaka, Ippei Nakamura, Atsushi Noguchi, Takefumi Miyoshi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: The scaling up of trapped-ion quantum processors based on the quantum charge-coupled device (QCCD) architecture is difficult owing to the extensive electronics and high-density wiring required to control numerous trap electrodes. In conventional QCCD architectures, each trap electrode is controlled via a dedicated digital-to-analog converter (DAC). The conventional approach places an overwhelming demand on electronic resources and wiring complexity. This is because the number of trap electrodes typically exceeds the number of trapped-ion qubits. This study proposes a method that leverages a high-speed DAC to generate time-division multiplexed signals to control a large-scale QCCD trapped-ion quantum processor. The proposed method replaces conventional DACs with a single high-speed DAC that generates the complete voltage waveforms required to control the trap electrodes, thereby significantly reducing the wiring complexity and overall resource requirements. Based on realistic parameters and commercially available electronics, our analysis demonstrates that a QCCD trapped-ion quantum computer with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> trap electrodes can be controlled using only 13 field-programmable gate arrays and 104 high-speed DACs. This is in stark contrast to the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> dedicated DACs required by conventional control methods. Consequently, employing this approach, we developed a proof-of-concept electronic system and evaluated its analog output performance.

title: Critical Coupling Analysis for Determination of Proper Receivers Number and Position in a One-to-Many Inductive Power Transfer System
authors: Pavel Smirnov, Eduard Mindubaev, Arseny Danilov, Polina Kapitanova
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: The rapidly growing number of electronic devices requiring frequent charging is driving the critical need for the development of one-to-many wireless power transfer systems. Theoretical analysis of critical coupling in a one-to-many inductive power transfer (IPT) system is conducted. Based on the analytical results, a framework for evaluating critical coupling as a function of the number of receivers and their spatial position is provided. The developed approach allows to predict combinations of receiver number and placement that lead to critical coupling condition in the system. An experimental prototype was fabricated to validate the analytical model and the proposed framework. The theoretically predicted critical coupling is confirmed experimentally through the direct measurements of power delivered to the load (PDL) and power transfer efficiency (PTE) in case of one, two and three receivers. This analysis expands the understanding of one-to-many IPT systems and can be used for further investigation of critical coupling. From a practical perspective, this research opens promising directions for designing one-to-many IPT systems that can maintain predefined PDL and/or PTE levels despite changes in the number of receivers, or support predefined operational mode (fast charging, effective charging) for a fixed number of receivers. This functionalities can be achieved through proper positioning of the receivers on the marked surface of the transmitter without any additional control circuits or sophisticated control algorithms. Such one-to-many IPT systems show significant potential for both consumer electronics and industrial applications.

title: Building a Professional Master's Program in Quantum Computing: Bridging Academic, Training and Industry Needs
authors: Shahpoor Moradi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
abstract: Since quantum technologies are quickly advancing to be used in actual applications, there is an increased demand to have graduate programs prepare recent graduates and practicing professionals from science and engineering disciplines to have competencies to enter the nascent quantum workforce. In this presentation, we detail key lessons learned from developing and launching the University of Calgary professional master's program in Quantum Computing, deliberately created to prepare students entering this rapidly evolving domain of employment. The presentation highlights the program's innovative curriculum, featuring hands-on lab experiences with tools like Qiskit, and a stream-based structure encompassing theory, software, hardware, and business. A distinctive strength of the program lies in its partnership with Quantum City-a Calgary-based initiative that connects academia, industry, and government to foster Alberta's quantum ecosystem. This collaboration provides students with valuable exposure to real-world applications and meaningful industry engagement. Educators, program developers, and academic leaders attending the presentation will leave with actionable recommendations and insights to build accessible, industry-focused quantum education programs to support today's quantum economy.
